description: In the last-minute tax maneuvering in Congress this week, wind power came out well.

title: Bracing for the Next Political Standoff
description: One fiscal showdown drew to a close this week, as the president signed a bill to raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans. But the sense of relief among businesses was tempered by the anticipation of political battles to come. Next month, Congress is set to negotiate over raising the debt ceiling.

title: Modi and the Muslims Malaise
description: DELHI  To think of Narendra Modi, the four-term chief minister of Gujarat, as a potential prime minister and the man who might revive the flagging fortunes of the B.J.P., Indias main opposition party, is to ignore the reality of Gujarat.

title: Hormel to Buy Skippy Peanut Butter
description: 3:12 p.m. | Updated

title: MacLaines Next Life
description: AS if the impending nuptials of Lady Mary and Matthew Crawley, not to mention all the social and economic upheaval of the early 1920s, were not enough to set servants scurrying and sherry glasses crashing in the decorous halls of Downton Abbey, that period drama is getting one more shock to its system when its third season begins Sunday on PBSs Masterpiece. This year Shirley MacLaine joins its cast as Martha Levinson, the mother of Cora, Countess of Grantham (Elizabeth McGovern), who arrives from America bringing a tart tongue and liberal attitudes unfamiliar to her daughters aristocratic household.

title: A Bit of Britain Where the Sun Still Never Sets
description: NOT long ago the actor Jim Carter replaced the crisp butlers uniform he wears on Downton Abbey with a snug Lycra ensemble for a getting-away-from-it-all cycling trip in Cambodia. Shooting had ended on the third season, which begins Sunday on PBS, and he celebrated with a long ride along the Mekong River. Amid the ancient temples of Angkor Wat he found himself wilting in the steamy climate  and suddenly swarmed by a group of Asian tourists screaming, Mr. Carson!

title: Refined Titillation, With Breeding as the Tease
description: A lot of time and discussion have been spent deciphering the extraordinary success of Downton Abbey, but its actually pretty simple. This series about British aristocrats and their servants is Fifty Shades of Grey: soft-core pornography, but fixated on breeding and heritage rather than kinky sex.

title: State Comptroller Sues Qualcomm for Data About Its Political Contributions
description: The New York State comptroller, seeking to force greater public disclosure of corporate political spending, has sued Qualcomm, demanding to view internal records of political expenditures by the company, one of the countrys largest makers of computer chips for mobile devices.

title: The View From Notre Dame: Its All in the Numbers
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  In many ways, Notre Dames 2012 season has defied description. It also defies the numbers.

title: BuzzFeed Announces $20 Million in New Financing
description: BuzzFeed, the social news Web site that was one of the media industry darlings of 2012, began the new year by announcing Thursday morning that it had raised nearly $20 million in new financing from its investors.

title: Walking Like a New Yorker
description: Dear Diary:

title: Opinion Report: Pointing Fingers
description: From the editorial page

title: Skeptics See Hidden Agendas in Latest Anglo-Argentine Spat
description: LONDON  Argentinas president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, is on the offensive again over Britains refusal to hand over the Falkland Islands, the windswept South Atlantic archipelago that Argentines know as Las Malvinas.

title: Thursday Reading: Home Composting in the City
Tax Break That Helps Private School Parents Is Made Permanent
description: The fiscal legislation just passed by Congress, known as the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012, makes permanent a little-known tax break for people who send their children to private or religious schools for kindergarten through 12th grade.

title: The Creator of Justified Answers Your Questions
description: With its colorful mix of dry humor, graphic violence and twisted characters, FXs Justified is one of the few Elmore Leonard-inspired projects that has managed to capture some of the flair of the authors crackling prose. The series returns for its fourth season on FX on Jan. 8.

title: Robert Griffin III: What a Good Quarterback Means
description: Hey, Tony. I just wanted to say to you: Dont listen to what anybody else is saying about you. Youre a great quarterback, man. And this game doesnt mean anything. Robert Griffin III to Tony Romo, as captured by a microphone for Showtimes Inside the NFL, via Michael David Smith, ProFootballTalk.com

title: A Conversation With: Psychologist Rajat Mitra
description: Dr. Rajat Mitra, a clinical psychologist, is the director of the Swanchetan Society for Mental Health, a nongovernmental organization in India that provides counseling and support services to survivors of violence, abuse and trauma. He is one of the few people in the country who has closely studied sex offenders to understand the motivation behind their attacks, interviewing hundreds of them in Tihar Jail in Delhi over several years.

title: Daily Report: Avis Also Buys Zipcar Ethos
description: The $500 million acquisition of Zipcar by the Avis Budget Group represents a perhaps inevitable evolution for a company that has been more successful as a collectivist concept than as a profit-making venture, Andrew Martin reports in The New York Times.

title: Barnes & Noble Reports Decline in Nook Sales
description: The state of Barnes & Nobles struggling digital Nook Media business, which last week received a significant investment from Pearson, became more clear on Thursday.

title: Barnes & Noble Faces Steep Challenge as Holiday Nook Sales Decline
description: 8:21 a.m. | Updated For Barnes & Noble, the digital future is not what it used to be.

title: Lawsuit Against HBO Claims Cruelty to Animals on Luck
description: 10:44 a.m. | Updated

title: The Children of a Tragedy Are Returned to School Life
description: MONROE, Conn.  On the first day back, Sean Murray said, his 9-year-old son, Brendan, was eager to return to school and see his friends, but he was nervous at the same time.

title: Biogen Idec Gives Up on Drug for Lou Gehrigs Disease
description: A closely watched experimental drug to treat Lou Gehrigs disease failed to work in a late-stage clinical trial, the drugs developer, Biogen Idec, said Thursday, disappointing medical experts who had hoped it might be a useful tool against the poorly understood and fatal illness. The company said it would discontinue work on the drug.

title: Data Dump: Are Potential Panelists Scorning Google?
description: Suppose a stranger showed up at your house, a shiny new modem under his arm. He says he wants to attach the device to your computer so he can see everything you do online  how you update your Facebook friends with news about your cats, how you use Twitter to flatter your boss, how you single-handedly are keeping the cult of Kim Kardashian alive. He says he will use the information to help make the Internet run more smoothly. All mankind will benefit.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Al Jazeeras Deal for Current TV
description: Al Jazeera, the Arab news giant financed by the government of Qatar, announced its plans to buy Current TV, the failing progressive network co-founded by Al Gore. The deal will give Al Jazeera a much bigger footprint in the United States, reaching 40 million households. After the acquisition was announced, Time Warner Cable said that it would no longer carry Current TV.

title: Actor Ages Into His Broadway Comeback
description: WHEN Reed Birneys big break finally came, after 30 years as a journeyman actor in New York, he nearly let it pass him by. Like many performers who had seen dream role after dream role go to bigger stars, Mr. Birney had lost faith in himself. Supporting parts and forgettable guests spots on Law & Order were cold comfort as he watched, at home in pajamas, as former classmates like Sigourney Weaver and Mercedes Ruehl walked Hollywood red carpets. Mr. Birney even started to believe what an anonymous poster once wrote on a blog about his performances in countless nice-guy parts. That he was a lightweight.

title: What Were Reading
description: Slate: The chicken nugget: a biography. Small, salty, spongy and reviled by food purists, the lowly nugget can now be tracked to its little-known but likely progenitor: a Cornell University poultry-science professor named Robert C. Baker, who proposed the nugget in 1963, way before McDonalds introduced its wildly popular McNuggets in 1980.  Glenn Collins

title: That Russian Movie Star, Grard Depardieu
description: MOSCOW  At the time, it seemed like a joke. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, at his annual news conference before more than 1,000 journalists last month, declared with a mixture of braggadocio and magnanimity that if one of the worlds best-known Frenchmen, the actor Grard Depardieu, really wanted to renounce his French citizenship, he would find the doors to Russia wide open  with a residency permit and Russian citizenship his for the asking.

title: The Many Sides of Ray Lewis
description: When Ray Lewis announced his impending retirement from the Baltimore Ravens on Wednesday, it fell neatly in line with the dichotomy that has been Lewiss entire career. Was his idea to do this before the Ravens first playoff game an invaluable emotional boost to his teammates, or a look-at-me moment at a team-focused time? Was Lewis merely the games greatest middle linebacker, or the kind of head-wrecking force that necessitated the N.F.L.'s making the game safer, a campaign, fittingly, Lewis has put his face to? Was he a great statesman, or the shady guy the N.F.L. once fined a substantial sum for his involvement in a murder?

title: Poetry Pairing | Fire and Ice
description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Robert Frosts classic poem Fire and Ice with an Opinion piece by James Atlas that, in addition to quoting Frosts poem (and T.S. Eliot as well), states that whether in 50 or 100 or 200 years, theres a good chance that New York City will sink beneath the sea. The piece is called Is This the End?

title: Help Sought for Ground Zero Volunteers Who Lack Proof of Service
description: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker, is calling on the Bloomberg administration to find a formal way of helping people who volunteered at ground zero after the terrorist attacks prove that they were there and are eligible for federal compensation.

title: A Voracious Demand for Shark Fins
description: A series of photographs taken this week by an environmental campaigner underline Hong Kongs role as the epicenter of the global trade in shark fins. Shot in the citys Kennedy Town neighborhood over three days, they show thousands of shark fins drying on the roof of a large industrial building.

title: Michele Norris to Return to NPR in New Role
description: 1:50 p.m. | Updated Michele Norris, the NPR host who took a 15-month leave of absence while her husband worked for the Obama campaign, will return to the public radio network in February, NPR said Thursday.

title: Francine Prose: By the Book
description: The author, whose recent books include The Turning and Reading Like a Writer, enjoys skimming writers memoirs for gossip about people she knows.

title: After Soft Start, Holiday Sales Gained
description: Many major American retailers were able to recover from a slow start to December shopping, according to monthly sales results reported on Thursday.

title: The Education of David O. Russell
description: The movie director David O. Russell was in the South Bronx the other day, working with the Ghetto Film School, a nonprofit that helps teenagers learn the craft of filmmaking. Mr. Russell has been an active adviser to the school nearly since it was founded, and has helped bring other directors and stars on board.

title: Al Jazeera Seeks a U.S. Voice
description: TimesCast: With its acquisition of Current TV, the news channel comes of age. | Grard Depardieu finds a Russian ally in his campaign against French taxes.

title: Banks Face New Checks on Derivatives Trading
description: After spending two years and millions of dollars to temper a regulatory crackdown, the worlds biggest banks are now resigned to a wave of new oversight.

title: George Saunders Has Written the Best Book Youll Read This Year
description: In a little sushi restaurant in Syracuse, George Saunders conceded that, sure, one reality was that he and I were a couple guys talking fiction and eating avocado salad and listening to Alanis Morissette coming from the speaker above our heads. Another was that we were walking corpses. Wed been on the subject of death for a while. A friend I loved very much died recently, and I was trying to describe the state I sometimes still found myself in  not quite of this world, but each day a little less removed  and how I knew it was a good thing, the re-entry, but I regretted it too, because it meant the dimming of a kind of awareness that doesnt get lit up very much. I was having some trouble articulating it, but Saunders was right there, leaning in and encouraging. He has a bushy blond mustache and goatee going gray, and sometimes, when hes listening intently, he can look a little stern, as if he just stepped out of a tent at Antietam. But then he starts talking and the eyebrows go up and its all Chicago vowels and twinkly Doug Henning eyes, and if you didnt know that he was more or less universally regarded as a genius, you might peg him as the superfriendly host of a woodworking show on daytime public access.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 3
Obama Signs Tax Deal Remotely Using Autopen
description: President Obamas decision to quickly sign the tax bill passed by Congress this week required him to reach across the Pacific Ocean and the continental United States to do so.

title: Concert at Carnegie Hall Will Honor the Songs of Prince
description: An annual concert at Carnegie Hall to raise money for music education will feature Talib Kweli, the Roots and the Blind Boys of Alabama this year as they pay tribute to the songs of Prince.

title: With Win Over Canada, U.S. Reaches Final at World Junior Championship
description: The United States crushed Canada, 5-1, on Thursday to advance to the gold medal final of the World Junior Championship in Ufa, Russia.

title: Next-Generation Environmental Activist Dies at 39
description: Accolades for the Canadian-born executive director of the Rainforest Action Network, who died last week in rough surf on a Mexican beach, focused not just on her accomplishments but on her relative youth.

title: Dean Poll Buys Gallaghers
description: As expected, Gallaghers, the 85-year-old near-Broadway steakhouse that was a shrine to Runyonesque Manhattan, has been purchased by Dean J. Poll, who has run the Central Park Boathouse for more than 12 years. The restaurant has been open continuously since it announced that it was for sale in October.

title: Arianna Huffington and Me
description: This month, Townies goes out of town, to Washington, D.C.

title: Looking Into a Mothers Bible
description: No one mines his own life in the service of understanding the American experience better than Walter Kirn. He has written about his Mormonism and his college education, and, for this magazine, he has written (among many other topics) about meeting his girlfriend via Facebook friending, taking Adderall and being fired. Now Kirn, the author of Up in the Air and other novels, has written about discovering his mothers Bible, or more precisely discovering her marginalia in the Bible. (And for more thoughts on marginalia, see Sam Andersons first Riff column.)My Mothers Bible, which appears on Byliner, is hard to categorize. It is at once an exegesis of Genesis and Exodus and a wail of mourning for his mother, who died suddenly, from a strep infection of the brain. In his musing on Rebekah helping her son Jacob to conspire against his brother, Esau, Kirn writes:

title: Skyfall and Other Art Directors Guild Surprises
description: The dingy carpets and heavy drapes worked: Sharon Seymour, the production designer for Argo, made the cut with the Art Directors Guild, which has announced its annual award nominees. Ms. Seymour made the list for period film, alongside Sarah Greenwood for Anna Karenina, J. Michael Riva for Django Unchained, Eve Stewart for Les Misrables and Rick Carter for Lincoln.

title: Al Jazeera Buys Current TV
description: With its acquisition of Current TV, the news channel Al Jazeera comes of age.

title: The Envelope, Please: Leobardo Espinoza
description: Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a first-generation, low-income college applicant in Kansas, says it is unfair to assume that students like me have an easier path to college.

title: A College Applicant With an Advantage Manages Expectations
description: We do our best to blog about what to expect in the admissions process, but I want to clear up one thing for all the students out there who are going to be part of this process in the years to come: An experience of this magnitude cannot be synthesized in a few paragraphs. Its a process that isnt understood until its experienced.

title: Nothing Eye-Popping Except the Statistical Line
description: One nights work: 28 points, 13 rebounds, 6 assists, 3 blocks, 1 steal.

title: Look of The Moment | Jessica Chastain
description: The Look: Shades of Grape. An aubergine trench paired with berry-colored sunglasses, lip and bag is delicious. Gold jewelry adds luster to the soothing, monochromatic effect.

title: Vanderbeek Buys Out His Fellow Owners of the Devils
description: After years of financial intrigue and infighting, Jeff Vanderbeek, the controlling owner of the Devils, has bought out his partners and now owns all of the team and its home, the Prudential Center in Newark.

title: Depardieu Granted Russian Citizenship
description: The actor  Grard Depardieu finds a Russian ally in his campaign against French taxes.

title: Not So Friendly in Italy
description: A so-called friendly match turned ugly Thursday in Italy.

title: Boehner Retains Speakers Post, but Dissidents Nip at His Heels
description: WASHINGTON  Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio was narrowly re-elected speaker of the House on Thursday amid open dissent from conservatives on the House floor that signaled that the turmoil and division of the 112th Congress is likely to spill into the newly constituted 113th.

title: A Great Fight for Freedom
description: The overcast skies of Jan. 1, 1863, ushered in the era of emancipation across the Kansas prairie. The absence of sunshine, though, did not dampen the spirits of the men of the First Kansas Colored Infantry at their camp at Fort Scott. That afternoon they celebrated the issuance of President Abraham Lincolns Emancipation Proclamation in what an eyewitness described as the old-fashioned Southern style: barbecue and speechmaking.

title: Automakers End 2012 With Sales at 5-Year High
description: DETROIT  Automakers on Thursday reported their strongest sales year since 2007, posting solid December results in the United States and promising more growth in 2013.

title: M.T.A. to Begin Restoring and Expanding Some Bus Services
description: Though the Metropolitan Transportation Authority recently lost its chairman, it is poised this week to add several new or restored bus services drafted under his watch.

title: Theater Talkback: Les Misrables, Stage to Screen
description: When excitement stirs about the latest movie adaptation of a stage musical, I usually find myself surfing a tide of mixed emotions. My inner cheerleader, whose pom-poms are sometimes coated in a thick layer of dust, rallies in the excited belief that a once-dominant American art form  the Broadway musical  will gain a little luster in the eyes of a public now mostly glued to screens of various sizes.

title: Transocean to Pay $1.4 Billion in Gulf Spill Accord
description: Transocean has agreed to pay a total of $1.4 billion in civil and criminal fines and penalties for its role in the Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster in 2010, the Department of Justice just announced.

title: Keep Your Shoes On, T.S.A. Tells Some Fliers
description: The Transportation Security Administration recently put into effect new screening procedures that make boarding easier for children, older travelers and frequent fliers  populations that are unlikely to pose a security risk  so that it may devote its attention to other passengers.

title: Children, Choosing Their Religion
description: The fastest-growing religious affiliation in the United States is no religion at all. That has meant an increase in parents raising their children outside of the community provided by a church or synagogue. For Katherine Ozment, writing for Boston magazine, it also meant soul searching because, as she writes:

title: Googles Antitrust Victory
description: The Federal Trade Commission found that Google had not violated antitrust statutes in the way it structures its Web search application, dealing a setback to Googles rivals. Edward Wyatt, reporting from Washington, has the details. You can also read the F.T.C.s news release on the results of its inquiry, and the prepared remarks of its chairman, Jon Leibowitz.

title: Many European Nations Dont Confront Past Atrocities
description: Can Germany ever close the chapters of World War II? Over the past 60 years, successive German governments have been compensating victims of the Holocaust.

title: A Snapshot of the Growing Ranks of Women in Congress
description: Perhaps the first sign of the historic number of women  20 in the Senate and 81 in the House  gracing the 113th Congress came at 10:45 Thursday morning, when female members of the House Democratic caucus gathered on the House steps for a group photo.

title: Putin Grants a Passport to Depardieu
description: Vladimir V. Putin has stepped into the feud between Grard Depardieu, the French actor and would-be tax exile, and Frances tax-the-rich Socialist government.

title: Hezbollah Chief Urges Lebanon to Help in Syrian Crisis
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, openly urged the Lebanese government on Thursday to take a more active role in finding a political solution to the civil war in neighboring Syria and to open its border to refugees to avert further bloodshed.

title: Finding a Center in Prison
description: Three times a week, Robbie Norris teaches yoga in a windowless room to inmates at the Richmond City Jail in Virginia.

title: Violence in Aleppo
description: Violence in the 22-month-old civil war in Syria continued Thursday with shelling in Aleppo.

title: Quirks of the Game: The Rise of the Pick-Six
description: On the final day of the N.F.L. season, the Jets briefly led, 3-0, against Buffalo before quarterback Mark Sanchez, facing a third-and-5 from his own 15, rushed a pass to Jeremy Kerley. Bills linebacker Bryan Scott read the play and caught the ball on the run, steaming in for an easy touchdown.

title: Obama Disputes Limits on Detainee Transfers Imposed in Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama set aside his veto threat and late Wednesday signed a defense bill that imposes restrictions on transferring detainees out of military prisons in Afghanistan and Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. But he attached a signing statement claiming that he has the constitutional power to override the limits in the law.

title: A Series of Poses for Fitness, Inside and Out
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Three times a week, Robbie Norris, a lean, 50-year-old yoga teacher, hops into his blue 1992 Volvo station wagon with his yoga mat and heads to his class in a drab brick building.

title: David O. Russell, Part 2: The Uses of Enchantment
description: David O. Russell is keen to talk about his silver linings. Five years ago, after foundering earlier with I  Huckabees, he was invited (by Sydney Pollack, no less) to adapt the novel Silver Linings Playbook, and he leapt at the chance. I had to work, he said. It makes you squeeze the toothpaste out of the tube  you cant overthink it, you have to just write the script, write it now, turn the draft around now.

title: Why Am I Shrinking?
description: Relax. Youve been through this before.

title: Pretax Transit Benefits Raised for 2013
description: Those who commute to work using mass transit or van pools are eligible for the same amount in employer-provided pretax commuter benefits this year as their colleagues who drive and park, thanks to the fiscal package passed by Congress this week.

title: Swiss Bank Pleads Guilty to Tax Law Violations
description: Switzerlands oldest private bank on Thursday admitted to helping Americans evade United States taxes, the first time a foreign financial institution has pleaded guilty to tax law violations.

title: A Victory for Google as F.T.C. Takes No Formal Steps
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission on Thursday handed Google a major victory by declaring, after an investigation of nearly two years, that the company had not violated antitrust or anticompetition statutes in the way it arranges its Web search results.

title: Wheelies: The Bad News/Good News Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: From Albany, With Mirth and Frankincense
description: ALBANY  The lobbyists are now comparing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to Jesus.

title: The Envelope Please: Sush Krishnamoorthy
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student in New Delhi who is applying to universities in the United States, is looking forward to an exciting life, regardless of where I go to college.

title: Imre Molnar, Provost at College for Creative Studies, Dies at 61
description: Imre Molnar, provost of the College for Creative Studies in Detroit, one of the countrys leading schools for automotive designers, died on Dec. 28, the school announced. He was in California and had a heart attack while bicycle riding. He was 61.

title: Joness Health Key to Alabamas Line
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Alabama center Barrett Jones waltzed into a ballroom Thursday to fulfill his news media obligations, wearing a black boot on his left foot. On Monday night, he will be asked to stop, block and move 326 pounds of Louis Nix III, the Notre Dame nose guard. Sprained foot or not, it will not be easy.

title: Swiss Gunman Had Weapons Taken Away Previously
description: PARIS  As much as many Americans, the Swiss love their guns, seeing them as integral to their national traditions of self-reliance, independence and international neutrality, with a trained and equipped citizen-army capable of deterring any foolish invader. Many Swiss, after serving in the army, keep their service weapons at home, and the country has no national register for firearms.

title: The 113th Congress Begins
description: TimesCast Politics: Speaker John A. Boehner faces down his caucus. | The delay of a Hurricane Sandy relief bill sets off a revolt.

title: Pakistani in Terror Case Is Extradited to New York
description: A Pakistani man living in Britain who is accused of plotting terrorist attacks there and in the United States was extradited on Thursday to face terrorism charges in New York.

title: Lessons From Europe on Averting Disaster
description: Will the United States follow the European path in 2013?

title: Now on Sale at Starbucks: Squares Credit Card Reader
description: If youre going to be having a cup of coffee with a colleague to talk about starting the next great business, why not grab a way to charge your future customers while youre at it?

title: Gerda Lerner, a Feminist and Historian, Dies at 92
description: Gerda Lerner, a scholar and author who helped make the study of women and their lives a legitimate subject for historians and spearheaded the creation of the first graduate program in womens history in the United States, died on Wednesday in Madison, Wis. She was 92.

title: In Last Meeting, Fed Officials Debated Length of Program to Stimulate Job Market
description: WASHINGTON  Just a few months after announcing a campaign to reduce unemployment, Federal Reserve officials are already debating how soon to stop it, reflecting persistent internal divisions about the efforts value.

title: Philadelphia, Past and Present
description: Centuries of history mingle with recent openings in this tour of Philadelphia.

title: 36 Hours in Philadelphia
description: A CITY with dozens of beguiling neighborhoods, a daunting number of world-class museums and a key role in the story of the nations founding, Philadelphia has seen a parade of openings over the last decade: ambitious design-centric boutiques, an ever-expanding universe of Stephen Starr restaurants and stylish hotels in artfully remodeled historic high rises. Entire neighborhoods have been transformed, parks have been built, and a wave of newcomers  transplants priced out of places like New York and Washington  have brought new energy to the cultural and culinary landscape.

title: A Sydney Suburb Draws New Crowds
description: Redfern is being rehabilitated thanks to a cultural scene developing in all directions.

title: Why You Wont Be the Person You Expect to Be
description: When we remember our past selves, they seem quite different. We know how much our personalities and tastes have changed over the years. But when we look ahead, somehow we expect ourselves to stay the same, a team of psychologists said Thursday, describing research they conducted of peoples self-perceptions.

title: Former SAC Portfolio Manager Pleads Not Guilty in Insider Case
description: The man at the center of the most lucrative insider trading case ever brought pleaded not guilty on Thursday, raising the stakes in the governments investigation of his former employer, SAC Capital Advisors.

title: Lambeau Is Next Test for Vikings Rookie Kicker
description: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn.  The first day the kicking instructor Nick Gancitano worked with a skinny teenager named Blair Walsh on a high school field near Walshs home in Boca Raton, Fla., Gancitano noticed something that set the young prospect apart from others.

title: These Are a Few of Our Favorite Designs
Odious Provisions in the Defense Bill
description: For the second year in a row, President Obama has signed a military budget bill with odious provisions that further entrench the practice of indefinite military detention for terrorist suspects, make it nearly impossible to close the Guantnamo Bay prison camp, and actually leave open the possibility that the military could arrest and detain an American citizen without due process.

title: Time Warner Cable Says It Will Keep Open Mind on Reinstating Al Jazeera
description: Time Warner Cable minced no words when it announced on Wednesday night that it was dropping Current TV, just hours after Al Jazeera acquired the channel. Our agreement with Current has been terminated and we will no longer be carrying the service, the distributor said. We are removing the service as quickly as possible.

title: Murrays Cheese Bar
description: Inside the Greenwich Village restaurant that specializes in various forms of cheese.

title: Weighing the Outcome of SeaWorlds I.P.O.
description: SeaWorlds next investment splash might be smaller than its last. The Blackstone Group is ready to take public the amusement parks operator it bought in 2009 from Anheuser-Busch InBev.

title: Say Cheese, and Walk Out Smiling
description: CONSIDER the knife on your table, its curved, forked tip like a devils tongue. It is a sign. You are not here for balance or restraint. You have come for one thing: bring out the cheese.

title: Questions Linger for Hosts After Sale of Current TV
description: Eliot Spitzer, Jennifer Granholm, Joy Behar and the other hosts on Current TV have no idea what comes next.

title: Zipcar, Avis and Age Discrimination Against Renters
description: For those of us who like picking up a Zipcar for a few hours without having to talk to anyone and dislike waiting for the rental car bus or in line, Avis Budget Groups acquisition of Zipcar is cause for a bit of fear. However the synergies end up benefiting both companies, you have to wonder whether some of them will degrade Zipcars service or policies.

title: Ideas for English Language Learners | Labeling Photos, Sequencing Passages and More
description: Each month, Larry Ferlazzo, a teacher and edublogger, offers ideas for using recent Times articles, photographs and videos to engage English Language Learners  or any students for whom The New York Times can be challenging.

title: A Nerdy-Dirty Primer on Primal Urges
description: One of the drawbacks of working in a bookstore, something I did for many years, is that it can be like working in a small-town pharmacy: You learn things about people you might rather not know. What sort of face do you put on when your new girlfriends mother comes to the counter with a Newt Gingrich novel, a scented candle and a copy of The Herpes Survival Guide?

title: Bledsoe Cools, but Clippers Stay Hot for Now
description: One of the most entertaining stories of the first 20 games of this season was the Clippers backup guard Eric Bledsoe. Not only were his statistics astounding  he held the second highest Player Efficiency Rating among point guards at 24.4 through Dec. 14 (only his teammate Chris Paul had a higher PER)  but he was also a thrill to watch. You did not want to miss any of Bledsoes 18 minutes a night because each moment held the potential for one of the fantastically athletic plays which only he was capable of making. Bledsoe seemed primed to fulfill a crucial role on a very strong team.

title: Lez Zeppelin at the Brooklyn Museum
description: Led Zeppelin has been enjoying quite the victory lap lately, being lauded at the 35th Kennedy Center Honors last month and releasing a concert film of its triumphant 2007 reunion in the fall.

title: Times A-Wasting; Pick Up a Kettlebell
description: EVEN for the most diligent exerciser, spending endless hours in the gym to get into or stay in shape can start to feel like punishment.

title: Short Takes
description: Sorry about the failure to post anything earlier. It was a combination of family responsibilities and, to be frank, sheer weariness over the folly of our public life. And I really dont feel up to any extended discussion even now. Instead, just a few short takes on things that caught my eye:

title: Christie Takes a Swing at His Party, Possibly Hurting His Political Future
description: Gov. Chris Christie admirably threw himself upon the shoals of national Republican Party politics this week.

title: Aki Sasamotos Lines of Reasoning
description: As Aki Sasamoto sees the world, an object is never merely its humble self. It may be, as the artist has written, her grandmother, who became a kimono belt after her death. Or her music teacher, who became a wig worn after chemotherapy. In other words, objects exist within a web of associations and relationships that are utterly personal, but also  at times  bewilderingly universal. Sasamoto, whose work was included in the 2010 Whitney Biennial, makes these connections visible through networks of cords and cables that demarcate lines across spaces and between repeated motifs like lemons and doughnuts. In her performances, she frequently wields a thick marker to draw whirlwind diagrams of coincidence or alliances, as if she were an unusually aggressive math teacher (the field in which she began her studies). The relentless pace of her narration is matched in her nimble and mercurial movements; her installations often act as room-size jungle gyms, from which she effortlessly folds, wraps or dangles her body, navigating around her audience.

title: Friday Night Music: The Head and the Heart
description: Yes, I know that its only Thursday afternoon. But Im off to dinner with friends now, and I have a nightmare travel day tomorrow  three different flight segments, almost 12 hours from first takeoff to final landing. So its now or never.

title: Criticism After Storm Aid Bill Stalls
description: Northeast Republicans erupted in anger after a Hurricane Sandy relief bill stalled in the House.

title: Times Fleeting for Storm-Displaced Pets Free Care
description: In the comfort of a warm Brooklyn warehouse, they have had free meals, walks, shots, flea removal, behavior therapy and even laser-light shows. But now the partys over for 140 pets still left at the temporary shelter set up by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals for owners uprooted by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Chorus Line Cassie, Where She Left Off
description: What other location could the title of Donna McKechnies bright, brassy new cabaret show, Same Place: Another Time, possibly refer to but New York, the city she conquered playing a character based on herself in A Chorus Line?

title: Soccer Team Walks Out on Racist Fans in Italy
description: As my colleague Jack Bell reports, an exhibition match between one of Italys leading soccer teams and a lower division club was abandoned on Thursday after a black player responded to racist chanting from fans by kicking a ball into the stands and walking off the field in Busto Arsizio, outside Milan.

title: A Months Worth of Links for New Year
description: Its sad that I feel the need to lead with news about guns, but thats regrettably where we are: America has 15,000 more gun stores than grocery stores (and in some states its easier to get guns than food stamps). American gun deaths will exceed traffic fatalities by 2015, and of course the gun lobby has squelched injury prevention research. Heres a great post about the silence of gun manufacturers after massacres. Also, The Nation reveals how Walmart helped make the AR-15 the most popular assault weapon in America.

title: Want a Long Obituary? Be President, Pope or Publisher
description: Combining my last two posts  one on long stories, one on front-page obituaries  here are a few more numbers to ponder.

title: Meteorite Offers 2-Billion-Year-Old Glimpse of Mars
description: A meteorite found in the Sahara, one of the oldest ever to come from Mars, offers evidence that life could have existed there more than two billion years ago, researchers say.

title: Northern Passage
description: When the country was too distracted to notice, caught up as it was with two world wars and the Depression, a great movement of people, of some six million African-Americans fleeing the Jim Crow South, was upending the social geography of the country itself. The Great Migration would figure into much of the literature and music of 20th-century urban life  Wright, Ellison, Baldwin and Coltrane  and, decades after it ended, it still lives in myth and shadow, casting a spell upon race relations to this day and captivating the lives and imaginations of its descendants.

title: They Grow Up, but They Remain a Lifetime Pursuit
description: LOS ANGELES

title: More Flexibility Added for Roth 401(k) Conversions
description: The new fiscal bill, the American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012, includes a provision that adds more flexibility to Roth retirement accounts.

title: A Shy Italian, Made for Everyday
description: WHAT is greatness? When that question is asked about wine, it sometimes is answered too narrowly.

description: POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y.  Jose Morquecha dragged his knife from beneath the chin up toward the pigs ear, twisted the neck and, with a final tug of his blade, held the head aloft.

title: Pop Listings for Jan. 4-10
description: Pop

title: Subaru Initiates Recall to Eliminate Potential Fire Threat
description: The National Highway Transportation Safety Administration said on Thursday that Subaru of America was recalling some models of the 2010-11 Legacy and Outback; the 2006-12 Tribeca sold before January 2012; and the 2009-12 Forester. The recall was initiated to repair a possible short-circuit in the doors puddle-light that could cause smoke or fire.

title: Adele Had Top Album of 2012
description: For a second time in a row the year in music belonged to Adele.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 4-10
description: Jazz

title: Broadway Diva Is a Muse, as Gay Boy Comes of Age
description: In an amusing guest appearance as herself on Will & Grace, Patti LuPone is dissed by a hysterically irate Jack McFarland, the character played by Sean Hayes. People either love me, or they hate me, she comments with the proud forbearance of one accustomed to both extremes.

title: Arts Ambient Sounds Coming Soon to Taxis
description: If youre one of those people who automatically punch the off button on Taxi TV screens, slow down. Art has just joined the mash-up of news clips and ads. Starting Wednesday and running through Feb. 5 about 3,000 New York City taxis will feature a 30-second video by the artist Ryan McGinley. Taken from the second version of Mr. McGinleys video for the Icelandic band Sigur Ros, the clip, called Varuo, shows his friend Jessica Tang wearing nothing but a gold wig and blue T-shirt, skipping barefoot through the streets of New York.

title: After a Spurt of Optimism in N.H.L. Lockout, Union Considers Options
description: Hopes for a prompt settlement in the 110-day old N.H.L. lockout were scuttled Thursday when players began voting to reauthorize Donald Fehr, the unions executive director, to disclaim interest in representing the union.

title: The Envelope Please: Chandler Buckingham
description: It seems like a lot of things are up in the air, writes Chandler Buckingham, a high school senior in Arkansas, and the suspense is threatening to wear me down.

title: Rig Owner Will Settle With U.S. in Gulf Spill
description: The driller whose floating Deepwater Horizon oil rig blew out in 2010, causing a massive oil spill, has agreed to settle civil and criminal claims with the federal government for $1.4 billion, the Justice Department announced Thursday.

title: 32 Pilgrims Are Killed by Bombings in Central Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Attackers killed at least 32 pilgrims in Iraq on Thursday, the police said, in what appeared to be a spate of sectarian-motivated violence as the country continued to struggle with a political crisis in its fractured government.

title: Chubby, Skinny, Accepting
description: RIGHT around the time I reached my goal weight, I met the man I would marry. I was living in New York and working briefly in Los Angeles as a television producer; he was my video editor. I was 5-foot-3 and weighed 90 glorious pounds.

title: Branding in Brooklyn: A World of Change
description: My Brooklyn, Kelly Andersons sensitive study of gentrification in her home borough, is as much personal essay as urban-policy survey. Having watched her once ethnically diverse Park Slope neighborhood slowly transform into a hip, expensive brand  and realizing that she had been in the vanguard of that transformation  Ms. Anderson begins to question the complex forces that determine a citys character.

title: Living With Cancer: Chemo-Feet
description: Prickly, frozen, cramped, numb: my feet ache as if they were tightly bound in plastic wrap or affixed on cardboard, or I dont feel them at all. Several years ago I was infused with a standard form of chemotherapy that causes what oncologists call peripheral neuropathies. Side effects have turned into permanent after-effects.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Brazil, Pakistan and Central African Republic.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Jan. 4-10
description: Classical

title: An Improvisational Cosmology, Vibrations Ever Expanding
description: Theres still residual energy in the music of the pianist Lennie Tristanos circle from the late 1940s and 1950s. The tunes are beautiful and charged: breezy on the surface but almost scarily focused within themselves, with their strange phrase lengths, metrical games over steady 4/4 time, long lines of straight eighth notes intermittently flicking into double time, harmonic elasticity, constant invention. They can easily be reimagined, because they were themselves reimaginings  of standards, of bebop phrasing, of what rhythm sections should do and not do.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 4-10
description: Dance

title: Last-Minute Performance Extends a Centenary
description: With the joyous, overwhelmingly busy John Cage centenary celebrations of 2012 now at an end, adherents might worry that the musicians who trotted out all manner of Cage scores last year might be ready to shelve them now. It felt doubly fortunate, then, to encounter a performance of Cages seminal Sonatas and Interludes for Prepared Piano on Wednesday evening at the Stone, the spartan East Village music laboratory founded and maintained by the composer John Zorn: doubly not only because the account, by Conor Hanick, was a marvel of poetic concentration, but also because it was not even planned until a few days ago.

title: Celebrating Monteverdis Vespers With Attention to 400-Year-old Details
description: The Green Mountain Project, an outgrowth of the New York-based early-music group Tenet, presented Monteverdis 1610 Vespers at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Times Square on Wednesday evening. It was the groups third New Years performance of this work in four years. (Last years was dedicated to the 1640 Vespers.) And to judge from the capacity crowd and the enthusiastic reception, the tradition is taking root as a sequel to the glut of pre-Christmas Messiah performances.

title: Seeing Opportunity, WPP Adds to Its Investments in Latin America
description: Martin Sorrell, chief executive of the British advertising giant WPP, is not deterred by the political tension in Argentina or economic setbacks in Brazil. Far from it: his firm is still investing in Latin America.

title: Personal Connection Amid Political Dissonance in the Middle East
description: Tell me about France, says Naim (Mahmoud Shalaby), a young Palestinian man dodging Israeli missiles in Gaza. It will make me dream.

title: A Master Plan to Merge Two U.T. Schools
description: EDINBURG, Tex.  Robert S. Nelsen, the president of the University of Texas-Pan American, does not like to think of the 85-year-old institution he has run since January 2010 being abolished by the Legislature.

title: In Winter, TVs in Bloom
description: A full-fledged winter television season has been with us for at least four or five years, and it just keeps getting bigger. This year January alone will feature the debuts of more than 100 new series or new seasons of established shows.

title: The British Class Divide, on a Personal Scale
description: Life rushes by so fast, it flickers today and is gone tomorrow. In 56 Up  the latest installment in Michael Apteds remarkable documentary project that has followed a group of Britons since 1964, starting when they were 7  entire lifetimes race by with a few edits. One minute, a boy is merrily bobbing along. The next, he is 56 years old, with a wife or an ex, a few children or none, a career, a job or just dim prospects. Rolls of fat girdle his middle and thicken his jowls. He has regrets, but their sting has usually softened, along with everything else.

title: Try a General, and Gentle, Compliment
description: A friend who was morbidly obese lost a considerable amount of weight, which greatly improved her appearance. I complimented her on her weight loss and told her how great she looked. But I was mortified when she replied that shed lost the weight because of a terrible disease. Should I not have complimented her to begin with? How should I have responded after learning her unfortunate news? Ray, Chicago

title: 12 Ways to Skin a Potato
description: Baked, braised, mashed and fried.

title: Yukon Gold Standard
description: There are the up-and-coming root vegetables with near-celebrity status  celeriac, parsnips, beets  and then there is the potato. Simultaneously beloved and despised, the potato is our most-grown and most-eaten vegetable and the one that is sometimes seen as a leading villain in the obesity pandemic.

title: National Geographic to Produce Killing Kennedy
description: The National Geographic cable channel, looking to expand its original history-based programming, has bought the rights to Killing Kennedy, a best seller by Bill OReilly.

title: GTT
description: DALLAS

title: Neighborhood Joint: Charlies Calypso City
description: As other record stores have headed toward obsolescence, Rawlston Charles, who opened Charlies Calypso City in 1972, has managed to reinvent the store for each era and turn it into a hub for Brooklyns Caribbean community.

title: Still Stopping Me in My Tracks
description: PEOPLE often ask me to name my favorite building. And I always answer that its whichever one Im just then finding out about, because there is nothing like the thrill of discovery.

title: The Winter TV Season
description: More than 100 new series or new seasons of established shows will make their debuts in January.

title: Five Star Treatment, at Least Until Curfew
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Tony Montana, the Scarface drug lord, enjoyed the pool there. James Bond and Goldfinger played gin rummy there. The rapper Drake performed there on Monday for New Years Eve. At the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach, the real may be more far-fetched than the make-believe.

title: $100 Million Buys More Than You Think
description: FOR $100 million, the buyers of Casa Casuarina, the mansion that once belonged to the fashion icon Gianni Versace, will get a 23,000-square-foot spread in Miami Beach with a 54-foot-long pool lined with mosaic tiles and 24-karat gold. They will acquire millions of dollars worth of Italian furniture  one rooms windows alone are framed by $250,000 in silk-and-velvet drapes, the current owner said.

title: A Survivor of College Rejection Refuses to Lose Her Resolve
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of The Choice class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her fifth post is below.  Tanya Abrams

title: Congress Renews Credit for Biodiesel Industry
description: The Congressional budget deal brokered this week kept tax breaks in place for a variety of industries, but biodiesel got something even better: a retroactive reinstatement of a dollar-a-gallon credit going back to January 2012, when it lapsed.

title: With Accessory, Officers Looking Sharp and Staying Safe
description: There is the old joke about why firefighters wear red suspenders (to keep their pants up, of course). Now add to that the query on why police officers wear clip-on neckties.

title: Writing the Hardship Letter
description: HOMEOWNERS having trouble paying their mortgages may try to elicit sympathy from their lenders in long, emotional letters laden with woe.

title: Once Again, Legislating Will Disrupt Politicking
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Calypso Beats at Cheers, Caribbean Style
description: SINCE Rawlston Charles opened Charlies Calypso City, on Fulton Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, in July 1972, the store has been a hub for Brooklyns Caribbean community, reinventing itself for each era.

title: France: Basque Party to Disband
description: The Basque nationalist political party, Batasuna, already illegal in Spain, announced Thursday that it would dissolve itself in France as well. The party was banned in Spain for its connections to the armed Basque separatist group ETA, for which it acted as its political wing. Two members of the party, Maite Goyenetxe and Jean Claude Aguerre, speaking in Bayonne, the center of the Basque region in France, announced the dissolution of Batasuna, but said they would continue to press for an independent Basque nation. In 2011, ETA announced that it had abandoned violence after a four-decade campaign for an independent homeland that claimed more than 800 lives.

title: Testing States Huge Backlog of Rape Evidence Kits Comes With Hefty Price Tag
description: There are some 20,000 untested rape kits sitting on evidence shelves in police departments across Texas, the state Department of Public Safety estimates. Each box with samples of hair, skin and clothing represents one of the worst moments of the victims life, a crime that was followed by hours in a doctors office submitting the most personal evidence.

title: How to Talk to Iran
description: IF there are any two words in Persian that President Obama should learn, they are maslahat and aberu. Maslahat is often translated as expediency, or self-interest. Aberu means face  as in, saving face. In the nearly 34 years since the Islamic revolution in Iran, expediency has been a pillar of decision making, but within a framework that has allowed Iranian leaders to save face. If there is to be any resolution of the nuclear standoff, Western leaders must grasp these concepts.

title: A Move With Music in Mind
description: FOR nearly two decades, Mark Nutter lived and worked in Los Angeles as a writer for screen and television.

title: A Fun-Loving, Carefree Spirit Becomes the Face of Anxiety
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Scanning the sumptuous breakfast buffet, the golfer Charlie Beljan looked like any other hotel guest in his shorts, flip-flops and T-shirt with a hang loose decal. The hand with the pinkie and thumb raised, and the three middle fingers curled in a signal that everything is all right belied Beljans low-grade unease.

title: Inquiry Into Tech Giants Tax Strategies Nears End
description: Congressional investigators are wrapping up an inquiry into the accounting practices of Apple and other technology companies that allocate revenue and intellectual property offshore to lower the taxes they pay in the United States.

title: Color These Images Rare and Delicate
description: Producing the earliest color photographs was a grueling task. In the 1890s, as companies started manufacturing photosensitive glass plates, employees on the factory floors were routinely exposed to clouds of benzene and ammonia. Photographers ladled out dose after dose of similarly toxic compounds to develop the images, and had to lug around cumbersome darkroom equipment.

title: Reflections
description: With New Years hoopla behind us, we begin to turn a corner on the season of long nights and short days. But theres still a good stretch of darkness ahead, and New York City museums have their lights on bright.

title: The New Tell-All Fed
description: Chicago

title: Better, if Not Cheaper, Care
description: IT is conventional wisdom that end-of-life care is an increasingly huge proportion of health care spending. Ive often heard it said that people spend more on health care in the year before they die than they do in the entire rest of their lives. If we dont address these costs, the story goes, we can never control health care inflation.

title: Japanese Man Vacations on Syrian Front Lines
description: Toshifumi Fujimotos vacation pictures, posted on his Facebook page, show him in poses familiar to any tourist. He lines up with interesting people, tries local activities and shows the sights. Except in the case of Mr. Fujimoto, a Japanese tourist, that means images of what appear to be Syrian rebel fighters engaged in battle, of himself firing an assault rifle and of the corpses of some of the 60,000 people the United Nations has said have died in Syria since a civil war began there early last year.

title: Subway Deaths Haunt Those at Trains Controls
description: Late one December morning in 2005, Tracy Moore was pulling her R train into the Steinway Street station in Queens. It is a sloping stretch of track, undulating like a roller coaster, Ms. Moore said. She was traveling about 30 miles per hour.

title: Jayne Cortez, Jazz Poet, Dies at 78
description: Jayne Cortez, a poet and performance artist whose work was known for its visceral power, its political outrage and above all its sheer, propulsive musicality, died on Dec. 28 in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Honoring the First Flush With Parades and Pull-Ups
description: FOR parents, milestones worthy of commemoration in a young childs life can include the loss of a first tooth or the first trip to the barbershop. Training a child to use the toilet, however, is often met with much less enthusiasm.

title: BMW Tops Mercedes in Luxury Sales
description: It was a December to remember for most luxury automobile sales operations in the United States, with BMW, Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Acura, Infiniti, Porsche, Audi and others all reporting particularly strong finishes to an already good 2012.

title: Old Case Suggests Hard Road for a Governors Suit
description: A quarter-century ago, the N.C.A.A. announced unprecedented penalties for Southern Methodist University after it found that players had been paid from a slush fund, invoking the so-called death penalty by suspending the football program for the 1987 season.

title: The Future of Venezuela
Battles of the Budget
description: The centrist fantasy of a Grand Bargain on the budget never had a chance. Even if some kind of bargain had supposedly been reached, key players would soon have reneged on the deal  probably the next time a Republican occupied the White House.

title: An Afghan Soldiers Journey From Ally to Enemy of America
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  It was only after the young Afghan soldiers hatred of Americans had grown murderous that he reached out to the Taliban.

title: Rise in Guns Confiscated at Airports
description: ATLANTA  The number of guns confiscated at airports across the United States is on the rise, the Transportation Security Administration says.

title: Communications Satellites Made Legal for Export
description: To the delight of American satellite makers, communications satellites  which orbit Earth to relay phone calls, link ships to shore and broadcast television programs  will become legal for civilian export under legislation that President Obama signed into law on Thursday.

title: Winning Is No Laughing Matter for Notre Dames Nix
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  The camera panned across the lush, green, Irish landscape, when a voice came from off-screen.

title: Suffering Fools Gladly
description: Recently I was reading a magazine profile of a brilliant statistician. The article mentioned, in passing, that this guy doesnt suffer fools gladly.

title: Prostitutes in Israel Are Finding New Lives in Training for the Fashion World
description: TEL AVIV  For 20 years Aviva, 48, flamboyant and transgendered, worked the streets of the business district of this Mediterranean city, as well as the seedy square mile around the central bus station and the Tel Baruch beach, once a notorious hub of Israeli prostitution that has become a spruced up stretch of sandy coast.

title: Misplaced Secrecy on Targeted Killings
description: For years, President Obama has been stretching executive power to claim that the authorization to use military force against Al Qaeda gives him the unilateral authority to order people killed away from any battlefield without judicial oversight or public accountability  even when the target is an American citizen.

title: Experts Advise Cuomo on Disaster Measures
description: ALBANY  Two panels of experts charged with studying how New York can better prepare for disasters like Hurricane Sandy said Thursday that the state should create a strategic fuel reserve, require some gas stations to install generators and update its building codes.

title: Oil Rig Aground off Alaska Is Damaged but Not Leaking, Shell and Coast Guard Say
description: A Shell Oil drilling rig that ran aground in the Gulf of Alaska has incurred water damage to its deck and electrical systems but is otherwise stable, officials with the response team handling the accident said Thursday.

title: Penn State: Lessons Not Learned
description: If it were possible to compound the reasons for outrage over the serial child rape committed at Penn State, Gov. Tom Corbett took a brazenly misguided step in that direction Wednesday. The governor filed a federal lawsuit to force the N.C.A.A. to revoke the highly deserved sanctions imposed on the school and its powerful football program for a scandal that reached the highest levels of the university.

title: Beginnings
description: A day in a fresh year that begins with a sunrise view of Mount Rainier and ends with a sunset at Key West forces inevitable questions about the implausibility of this oversize nation. Is it crazy to think that a few broad ideas still hold together a land of earnest strivers represented by a Congress of window breakers?

title: Shattered Subdivision Offers a Trail of Clues
description: Even before they heard that family photographs were missing, investigators said they sensed something was not right with the scattered remains of Monserrate Shirleys home.

title: Carlesimos Team Should Stay So, at Least for Now
description: One week has passed since the Nets dismissed Avery Johnson, promoted P. J. Carlesimo and set the N.B.A. aflutter with speculation about Phil Jackson. In that time, the Nets have won three times, lost once and done little to clarify their coaching situation.

title: S.E.C. Ends Scrutiny of Former Top Aide to Buffett
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided not to file insider trading charges against David L. Sokol, a onetime top lieutenant at Berkshire Hathaway, Mr. Sokols lawyer said Thursday.

title: Liked but Not Feared, Boehner Keeps a Job Some Might Ask Why He Wants
description: WASHINGTON  Public service was never meant to be an easy living, Representative John A. Boehner lamented Thursday, moments after he overcame a Republican insurrection to win re-election as speaker of the House. For Mr. Boehner, it may only get tougher from here.

title: Lawyers, Saying DNA Cleared Inmate, Pursue Access to Data
description: MOUNT OLIVE, W.Va.  Convicted of robbing and raping an 83-year-old woman, Joseph A. Buffey at 19 was no ones idea of a choirboy. A marijuana smoker and high school dropout, he was out thieving on the night in question 11 years ago and broke into the Salvation Army near the womans home to steal the bell-ringing money.

title: 2 Americans Are Advised Not to Visit North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The State Department said Thursday that it had advised against a visit to North Korea by the former governor of New Mexico, Bill Richardson, and Googles executive chairman, Eric E. Schmidt.

title: Al Jazeera in America
description: Al Jazeera, the pan-Arab news network, has long wanted to gain a bigger American television audience, and it may have finally found a way to do that by buying Current TV. But as the deal was being signed, Time Warner Cable announced it would immediately stop carrying Current, a struggling channel partly owned by former Vice President Al Gore. While the cable company has the legal right to cut off Current, the decision is unfortunate and could block access to an important news source.

title: Spurs Stars Play, but Sit by the End
description: The San Antonio Spurs arrived in New York at 2 a.m. Thursday after playing in Milwaukee on Wednesday night. They had played Sunday and Monday as well. That left Coach Gregg Popovich in a familiar predicament.

title: Gore Went to Bat for Al Jazeera, and Himself
description: Al Gores Current TV was never popular with viewers, but it was a hit where it counted: with cable and satellite providers. When he co-founded the channel in 2005, Mr. Gore managed to get the channel piped into tens of millions of households  a huge number for an untested network  through a combination of personal lobbying and arm-twisting of industry giants.

title: Day of Records and Firsts as 113th Congress Opens
description: WASHINGTON  As the 113th Congress opens, the Senate and the House are starting to look a little bit more like the people they represent.

title: For Swisher and the Indians, a Match Made in Ohio
description: CLEVELAND  Whenever Nick Swisher was stationed in right field as a visiting player, he would revel in the song played in the bottom of the eighth inning. Hang On Sloopy has official song status in the state of Ohio, and when it blared from the Progressive Field loudspeakers, Swisher, who has roots here, would spell O-H-I-O with his body, Yankee uniform be damned.

title: Taking Calls on Abortion, and Risks, in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Every time the phone rings, Angela Erpel feels her nerves swell. Sometimes it is a scared teenager on the other end, or a desperate mother of three. There are the angry ones, too, with callers playing the sounds of crying babies or sending text messages with pictures of aborted fetuses.

title: Middle Finger Flashed in 06 Lives On in Suit
description: There is usually no mistaking the act or intent of extending a middle finger.

title: Lottery Numbers
Bans and Rules Muddy Prospects for Gas Drilling
description: In three decades of drilling, John C. Holko said, his oil and gas business has never faced such a hostile environment.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 4, 2013
description: Were all trying to move on, but theres a nervous sickness. Im not sure thatll ever go away.

title: The Opening Day of the 113th Congress
description: Members of the 113th Congress were sworn in on Thursday, marking a day of firsts and records for both chambers.

title: Whos Sari Now?
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  I am not sure what this says about me, or anything else, for that matter, but I am beginning to enjoy solving the themeless Fridays more than I enjoy some of the themed early week puzzles. Maybe its because I can solve them now.

title: DAntoni Responds to Criticism With a Congratulations
description: Mike DAntoni was surprised that Amare Stoudemire would claim that he was not taught how to play good defense until Mike Woodson became his coach last year.

title: Pippin Is Returning to Broadway
description: The memorably tuneful musical Pippin, a staple of high school and college theater troupes, will return to Broadway this spring for the first time since its original five-year run ended on Broadway in 1977, the shows producers announced on Thursday night. The approximately $8 million production  a transfer of the current Pippin revival running at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.  will begin performances on March 23 at the Music Box Theater and open on April 25.

title: Corrections: January 4, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Google Pushed Hard Behind the Scenes to Convince Regulators
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For 19 months, Google pressed its case with antitrust regulators investigating the company. Working relentlessly behind the scenes, executives made frequent flights to Washington, laying out their legal arguments and shrewdly applying lessons learned from Microsofts bruising antitrust battle in the 1990s.

title: Fiscal Deal Fails to Allay Doubts on U.S. Global Power
description: WASHINGTON  Two years ago the departing chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, declared that the most significant threat to our national security is our debt. After a decade in which the nation had chased Al Qaeda and invaded Iraq, Admiral Mullen was saying, in essence, that the biggest enemy was us.

title: 3 Officers Are Wounded in 2 Shootings; a Gunman Is Killed
description: Three New York City police officers were shot Thursday night in two separate encounters, including one at a Brooklyn subway station that left a gunman dead.

title: Arthur Caliandro, Minister at Marble Collegiate, Dies at 79
description: The Rev. Arthur Caliandro, who had the daunting task of following the popular Rev. Norman Vincent Peale to the venerable pulpit of Marble Collegiate Church in Manhattan and then used it to reach out to people of other faiths, low-income children, women and gay congregants, died on Sunday at a rehabilitation center in the Bronx. He was 79.

title: A Rebels Methods Go Mainstream
description: LAS VEGAS  It is a Monday afternoon, and one of the most controversial figures in college basketball history sits quietly at the end of a rectangular table at Landrys, a seafood restaurant on West Sahara Avenue that is, both physically and metaphorically, a long, long way from the glitz and glitter of the Strip.

title: Bad Neighborhood, Good Children and a Creative Mother
description: Gunfire and police sirens punctuate the soundtrack of the streets outside Yoshita Childresss home, an apartment that offers frequent views of middle-of-the-night brawls and arrests.

title: Houses of Worship Seeking FEMA Grants Face Constitutional Barrier
description: Hurricane Sandy flooded and battered St. George Malankara Orthodox Church of India in New Dorp, Staten Island, ruining its basement, windows and doors. Yet, when its vicar contacted the Federal Emergency Management Agency to ask for a grant to help with the estimated $150,000 rebuilding cost, he said he got a clear answer: No.

title: Venezuela: After Surgery, Chvez Is Fighting a Severe Lung Infection
description: President Hugo Chvez is fighting a severe lung infection that has led to a respiratory deficiency, the countrys information minister said Thursday. Mr. Chvez is in a Cuban hospital following emergency cancer surgery on Dec. 11. Officials have given few details about his condition, although they had said the surgery caused complications, including a respiratory infection. Thursdays announcement was the first time the infection was characterized as severe. Mr. Chvez, who was re-elected in October, is due to be sworn in for a new six-year term on Jan. 10, but officials have warned he may not be healthy enough to return home by then, which could set off a constitutional battle with the political opposition.

title: Growing Strains for Muslim Brotherhood and Emirates
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government on Thursday remained mired in a dispute between the Muslim Brotherhood, the countrys leading Islamist movement, and the United Arab Emirates, which this week said that it had arrested several Egyptians accused of forming a Brotherhood cell, stealing state secrets and conspiring with Brotherhood leaders in Egypt.

title: Loyalty, Pessimism and Altruism at Mets Blood Drive
description: The warmth of spring training felt far away, the optimism of opening day even more so.

title: How the Auto Industry Fared in December
description: How the automobile industry fared in December.

title: Knicks Sharpen Their Defense in Rout
description: Over an 82-game season, Coach Mike Woodson knows he will need to motivate his team. Woodsons pregame pitch to the Knicks on Thursday was not intense. Instead, his players watched highlight after highlight of their defensive execution in their first 10 games, in which they went 8-2.

title: Word of the Day | mendacious
description: mendacious \men-da-shs\ adjective

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10 P.M. (IFC) PORTLANDIA Fred Armisen and Carrie Brownstein, above center, reprise some of their popular Portland, Ore., residents, like the ever-prepared Dave and Kathy; the passionate Nina and Lance; and the militant bike messenger, Spyke, and his girlfriend, Iris, in this Season 3 premiere. Kyle MacLachlan also returns as the citys mayor, joining a guest cast including Chlo Sevigny, Jeff Goldblum, Kumail Nanjiani, Roseanne Barr, Matt Berry, Rose Byrne, Jim Gaffigan, Bill Hader, Juliette Lewis, Matt Lucas, J Mascis, Bobby Moynihan, Martina Navratilova, Patton Oswalt, George Wendt and the band the Dirty Projectors.

title: News Quiz | January 4, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 4, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on 56 Up, On the Road and This Is 40.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 4
description: NEWS The U.S. Federal Trade Commission on Thursday handed Google a big victory in its ongoing battle with regulators, finding that the Internet giant does not violate antitrust or anti-competition statutes in the way it structures its Web searches. Edward Wyatt reports from Washington.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Tech Design Comics and Artificial Intelligence Money
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Jan. 4, 2013
description: This question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the Opinion piece Out of Africa.

title: Sandy Hook Students Head Back to School
description: In A Desire for Normalcy as Sandy Hook Students Return to Class, Peter Applebome and Marc Santora write about the first day back at school for students in Newtown, Conn.

title: From Bangladesh, a Photo Festival Builds Bridges
description: There are well over a hundred photo festivals around the world, and new ones pop up almost daily. Many claim to be international, usually exhibiting a few local photographers alongside some international  read Western  photographic luminaries.

title: When Has a Teacher Inspired You?
description: Zack Conkles award-winning short documentary film Wrights Law is about his crazy and really amazing former high school physics teacher, Jeffrey Wright.

title: Can Forgiveness Play a Role in Criminal Justice?
description: At 2:15 in the afternoon on March 28, 2010, Conor McBride, a tall, sandy-haired 19-year-old wearing jeans, a T-shirt and New Balance sneakers, walked into the Tallahassee Police Department and approached the desk in the main lobby. Gina Maddox, the officer on duty, noticed that he looked upset and asked him how she could help. You need to arrest me, McBride answered. I just shot my fiance in the head. When Maddox, taken aback, didnt respond right away, McBride added, This is not a joke.

title: Japanese Envoy Tries to Mend Ties With South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan reached out to South Koreas incoming president, Park Geun-hye, on Friday by sending a special envoy to Seoul with calls for mending ties that had become strained under their predecessors.

title: Kayaker Aborts Solo Pacific Voyage
description: For much of last year, kayaking enthusiasts around the world were keeping tabs on Wave Vidmar, who said he was planning to kayak from California to Hawaii  totally alone and unsupported. The 48-year-old Mr. Vidmar expected the journey over the rolling Pacific Ocean would take between 45 and 65 days. And the 3,100-mile odyssey would rank among the longest of its kind, if successful.

title: School Rankings: Whats in a Number?
description: HONG KONG  If I had a dollar every time I heard someone say that a university was ranked in the top something-or-other, Id have a lot of dollars.

title: Portraits From the Kochi Biennale: Sculptor Ernesto Neto
description: At the Kochi-Muziris Biennale in the Kerala State city of Kochi, India Ink has been interviewing exhibiting artists about their work, their expectations for the biennale and the politics of art. The fair will continue until March 13.

title: A Survivor of College Rejection Refuses to Lose Her Resolve
description: When I studied evolutionary biology in 10th grade, the science behind phrases like survival of the fittest became clear to me. My very inspiring biology teacher told us that in fact, Darwin had not coined that phrase. Rather, his theory of natural selection evidently advocated the survival of the species which can adapt.

title: The Complexities of Comparing Medicare Choices
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Wild-Card Matchups: Rookies Take Spotlight
description: Vikings (10-6) at Packers (11-5)

title: The Early Word: 113th
description: In Todays Times:

title: Seizures of Illegal Ivory Are Rising in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Customs officials in Hong Kong announced on Friday their third large seizure of smuggled ivory in less than three months, saying they had intercepted 779 elephant tusks weighing 2,900 pounds in a container originating from Kenya.

title: Czechmate
description: DECIN, Czech Republic  When Vaclav Havel died a little more than a year ago, a Czech friend wrote to me that she feared for the future. For many Czechs, the former playwright and dissident remained a moral authority long after he had led the peaceful Velvet Revolution that brought down Czechoslovakias Communist dictatorship in 1989.

title: Chief Justice Roberts to Preside at Obama Swearing-In
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas inaugural planning committee will announce Friday morning that  surprise!  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. will deliver the oath of office to Mr. Obama when he is sworn in for a second term later this month.

title: Q&A: How to Turn an Excel Spreadsheet into Mailing Labels
description: Q.

title: Bomb Attack in Syria Kills at Least 10 as Reports of Executions Surface
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  An explosion struck a gas station in the Syrian capital, Damascus, early on Friday, killing at least 10 people in the second attack in three days on people lining up for scarce fuel.

title: Daily Report: Google Pushed Hard Behind the Scenes to Convince Regulators
description: For 19 months, Google pressed its case with antitrust regulators investigating the company. Working relentlessly behind the scenes, executives made frequent flights to Washington, laying out their legal arguments and shrewdly applying lessons learned from Microsofts bruising antitrust battle in the 1990s, report Claire Cain Miller and Nick Wingfield of The New York Times.

title: App Smart Extra: Keeping Fitness Resolutions
description: This week App Smart was full of apps that can help you, one way or another, to stick to any New Years resolutions youve made.

title: A Photo-Scanning Service Learns How to Get Exposure
description: Founded in 2007, FotoBridge, a West Berlin, N.J., photo-scanning service, began experimenting with social media in 2009. For its co-founders, Edward OBoyle and Julie Morris, the goal was to connect with parents, baby boomers, and what they call family memory keepers to promote awareness of digital archiving. After their initial experiments, Mr. OBoyle and Ms. Morris concluded that their target market was best represented on Facebook and with a secondary focus on Twitter to connect with younger customers and follow market influencers.

title: Googles Antitrust Victory
description: GOOGLES ANTITRUST VICTORY | The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that Google had not violated antitrust or anticompetition laws in the way it arranges its search results  a major victory for the Internet giant after a nearly two-year investigation. The decision amounts to a slap on the wrist, The New York Timess Claire Cain Miller and Nick Wingfield write.

title: Vatican Goes Cash Only Because of Lack of Money-Laundering Controls
description: LONDON  If youre planning a trip to the Vatican, be sure to take cash.

title: Tom Coughlin, Chip Kelly and Moneyball Football
description: Morning links for your consideration, a day before wild-card weekend opens:

title: Malala Yousafzai Discharged From Hospital
