description: Malala Yousafzai, the 15-year-old Pakistani schoolgirl who survived an assassination attempt by Taliban militants, was discharged from Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Birmingham, England, on Thursday.

title: Top Commercial for 2012 Was Really Big, Ace Metrix Says
description: The commercial that received the highest average score last year from viewers of national television ads in a closely followed survey was not a glitzy Super Bowl spot or an emotional Olympics spot. Nor was it a commercial that was sexy, snarky or stuffed with celebrities.

title: Were the G.O.P. Votes Against Boehner a Historic Rejection?
description: The holiday season hasnt been kind to House Speaker John A. Boehner. He was sharply criticized by fellow Republicans for failing to pass legislation providing aid to those affected by Hurricane Sandy. Earlier, he was sidelined in the negotiations to resolve the so-called fiscal cliff. And before that, he failed to garner enough support from his own caucus for Plan B, Mr. Boehners own bill to avert the fiscal crisis.

title: Opinion Report: Targeted Killing
description: From the editorial page

title: Mending the Bird Preserves Hit by Sandy
description: Conservationists are warning that swift action is needed to repair mid-Atlantic bird refuges that were badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Teenagers in The Times | December 2012
description: Welcome to our latest edition of Teenagers in The Times, a collection of articles and multimedia about young people published in December 2012 and the first week of January 2013 on NYTimes.com.

title: More European Bank Loan Sales Expected
description: 11:45 a.m. | Updated

title: A Passionate Embrace at the Bus Stop
description: Dear Diary:

title: Job Creation Is Still Steady Despite Worry
description: Despite concerns about looming tax increases and government spending cuts, American employers added 155,000 jobs in December. Employees also enjoyed slightly faster wage growth and worked longer hours, which could bode well for future hiring.

title: The Art of Blasphemy
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Administrators at the National College of Arts, Pakistans leading arts college based in Lahore, are waiting to find out whether they will be charged with blasphemy, a crime punishable by death. Last summer, the colleges contemporary arts journal reproduced homoerotic paintings by Muhammad Ali depicting clerics alongside seminude young boys.

title: Lawmakers in India Charged With Crimes Could Face Speedier Trials
description: Indias Supreme Court on Friday asked the government to consider fast-tracking trials of lawmakers who are facing criminal charges, lawyers said, after activists filed a petition demanding that legislators accused of abusing women be disqualified from public office.

title: Barney Frank Seeks Short Stint in Senate
description: Barney Frank is finding it hard to say goodbye to Congress.

title: A Life Raft for Seaport Museum: $500,000 Gift
description: Having called out for help after Hurricane Sandy, the South Street Seaport Museum has received $500,000 from an anonymous donor and $100,000 from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

title: Breakfast Meeting: Victories for Gore and Google, but Not Barnes & Noble
description: Al Gore used his considerable lobbying and negotiating skills when he started Current TV in 2005, and he used them again last month in arranging the sale of the channel to Al Jazeera, Brian Stelter reports on Friday in The New York Times. He used persuasive legal arguments with cable and satellite providers to convince them that Al Jazeera, like Current, offered news content and that they were obligated to carry the new channel run by the Middle Eastern news organization. In the process, Mr. Gore, already estimated to be worth about $100 million, assured himself some $100 million more from the sale.

title: Four Years Later, 28,000 More Jobs
description: For jobs, the past four years have been a wash.

title: What Were Reading
description: Elizabeth Minchilli in Rome: Dont be afraid of cardoons.  Jeff Gordinier

title: A Changing of the Guard Among Veterans in Congress
description: The 113th Congress convened for the first time on Thursday, welcoming the largest wave of veterans of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan since those wars began more than a decade ago.

title: Puccinis Crossover Dalliance
description: AN operetta, Puccini wrote to his Viennese friend and agent Angelo Eisner on Dec. 14, 1913, is something I will never do. This Italian masters intense, serious and vocally strenuous operas would seem to have little in common with the formulaic, comic Viennese operetta. Yet Puccini signed a contract to write an operetta for the Carltheater in Vienna a few months later.

title: Shedding Light on the Last Frontier
description: MOMENTS after walking into a Chelsea cafe the choreographer Emily Johnson accepted a compliment for her vintage black-and-white brocade coat. But there was a catch. You do, she said as her blue eyes twinkled mischievously, have to take it off awkwardly.

title: Shooting of Two Officers Began With a Minor Violation Used to Fight Crime
description: When New York City transit officials adopted a rule more than seven years ago to bar subway passengers from walking between cars, the reason was rider safety: They wanted to stop people from darting from one car to another while the train was moving.

title: No Wrath, but Some Discontent, When Nobel Prize Was Awarded to Steinbeck
description: When their best-laid schemes of mice and men, and authors and writing, went awry, the members of the Swedish Academy made the best of what they thought was a bad situation in 1962: they awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature to John Steinbeck. The decision came amid their general dissatisfaction with the candidates for the prize that year, according to documents recently released by the academy.

title: Jan. 6  12
description: COLOR and emotion swirl through Michael Powells BLACK NARCISSUS (1947), set at a convent school and hospital perched 8,000 feet up in the Himalayas. An Indian general used to keep his women at this place, now run by Anglican nuns (led by Deborah Kerr), and it still feels buffeted by strong currents of eros. Even the walls, painted with lush nudes, whisper of sex. Whats a nun to do?

title: Rubbing Out the Mob in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES

title: An Uncomfortable Tale, Told Anew
description: THE estate of Ralph Ellison had never allowed his classic 1952 novel Invisible Man to be adapted for another medium, until Oren Jacoby came along. And even after Mr. Jacoby turned the 439-page book into a play  with not a word of new dialogue, as part of the agreement  many theaters passed on staging it, calling it unwieldy or wrong for their audiences.

title: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Know: Its Avatars Year
description: Celebrity interviewers, time to step your game up. Tina Fey and Amy Poehler, hosts of the Golden Globes on Jan. 13 and everyones favorite ladies of all time  or maybe just ours  have released a video of themselves answering the usual kind of questions theyll get as they prepare for the ceremony.

title: They All Want Chip
description: Now that Oregon has won its Fiesta Bowl game, everyones retinas have recovered from encountering the Ducks latest uniform and the crowd in Arizona has finally stopped chanting, We want Chip, the frenzy can truly begin. In fact, by the time you finish Leading Off, Ducks Coach Chip Kelly might have been hired by the Eagles. Or the Browns. Or the Bills. Even the Chiefs might stop their fire-breathing pursuit of Andy Reid and hire Kelly instead. Listen hard enough and you may even hear that the Lakers believe he can bring out the best in Kobe Bryant. Yes, Kelly is hot, eyebrow-searing hot.

title: Bluefin Tuna Sold for Record $1.76 Million in Tokyo Auction*
description: Jan. 5, 12:42 p.m. | Read updates below |

title: This Weeks Movies: Jan. 4
description: This week, Times critics look at the Michael Apted documentary 56 Up and also take a look back at earlier releases, This Is 40 and On the Road. See all of this weeks reviews here.

title: Images of North Korean Leaders Wife Fuel Pregnancy Rumors
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The wife of the young North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, might have recently given birth, South Korean journalists reported on Thursday.

title: An Antidote for Climate Contrarianism
description: I would guess a few Green readers had the experience, over the holidays, of arguing yet again about global warming with a parent or brother-in-law who thinks its all a big hoax. Maybe theres some undiscovered substance in roast turkey that makes people want to pick fights around the dinner table.

title: A Parents Business Travel: How Long Is Too Long?
description: A newly working parent wrote me with a dilemma. At the very beginning of a post-graduate-school career, the familys bread-winner (for now) and the parent of an 18-month-old, this parent is facing the fact that to really excel at work, travel will be required. Not short jaunts to nearby cities, but longer trips, three to six weeks at a time, to developing countries. Taking a spouse and child along is not an option.

title: G.M. Recalling 54,700 Vehicles Because of Roll-Away Danger
description: General Motors is recalling almost 54,700 of its 2013 trucks and sport utility vehicles because of a roll-away danger, according to a report the automaker filed Friday with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Andrew Sullivan on Going Back to Future as an Indie Blogger
description: On Wednesday, Andrew Sullivan, one of the pioneers of the blogging Web, decided to end his relationship with The Daily Beast, and by the way, with advertising as well. His decision made quite a splash, in part because others wonder whether he is pointing a way forward at a time when advertising rates on the Web would not seem to support a gumball habit, let alone professionally produced content.

title: The End of a Decade of Uncertainty Over Gift and Estate Taxes
description: FOR many of the wealthy, the American Taxpayer Relief Act, passed this week by Congress, is aptly named.

title: On the Trail of a Counterfeiter Called The Printer
description: ATLANTA  Making fake money remains a thriving enterprise in the United States, as it has been since before the Civil War.

title: Boomers See Improved Jobs Picture
description: The unemployment rate for younger baby boomers  ages 45 to 54  was 5.8 percent in December, the lowest since January of 2009, according to the monthly data released Friday morning by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: The Year in Jazz
description: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen, jazz critics for The Times, discuss the most noteworthy albums, performances and developments in jazz in 2012.

title: Having It Both Ways
description: Pretty much everyone inside and outside of Washington is disappointed in the fiscal cliff deal. Some argue it doesnt do enough. Others think it goes too far. Theres even disagreement on a crucial point: Does the deal increase the deficit or reduce it?

title: A Populism Worthy of the Name
description: A big part of the story of the fiscal cliff negotiations, now half-resolved and half-postponed, was that the populist wing of the Republican Party couldnt quite figure what it wanted to actually achieve, or how. The broad goals of less spending and lower taxes were clear enough, but on anything more specific the politicians and activists on the grassroots right seemed confused about what they thought the party should to be negotiating toward, or what they expected that their calls for harder hardball and/or cliff-diving would actually win in the end. (The scenarios being spun out tended to either envision extracting never-gonna-happen concessions from the Democrats across weeks of brand-destroying brinksmanship, or embracing a truly massive defeat on taxes as a the worse, the better step toward eventual conservative resurgence.) This confusion was obvious throughout, but particularly during the brief window on Tuesday when there was talk of House Republicans sending the bill back to the Senate with some amendments tacked on. If there had been any kind of strategically-plausible consensus about how conservatives actually wanted the compromise amended, then that gambit might have made some sense. But there wasnt, so it didnt.

title: Reporter Forced to Leave China Had Problem With Visa, Officials Say
description: BEIJING  Responding for the first time publicly to the case of a reporter for The New York Times who was forced to leave mainland China, the countrys Foreign Ministry said on Friday that he had not been expelled but that his visa application had simply been filed incorrectly.

title: Popcast: The Year in Jazz
description: On this weeks podcast, New York Times jazz critics Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff talk about the year in jazz for 2012.

title: The Sweet Smell of Retail
description: THE BIG PROFILE

title: Who Made That Universal Product Code?
description: On a Sunday afternoon in 1971, an I.B.M. engineer stepped out of his house in Raleigh, N.C., to consult his boss, who lived across the street. I didnt do what you asked, George Laurer confessed.

title: The 12.23.12 Issue
description: JERRY SEINFELD

title: Does an Honor Code Make It Too Easy to Cheat?
description: Im a student at a university with an honor code that is taken very seriously. Professors place a lot of trust in students integrity: they assign take-home exams with conditions (no access to textbooks, notes or Internet) and they leave offices containing answer keys unlocked at all hours. Although I have never taken advantage of this trust, it has occurred to me that it would be easy to do so with little probability of being caught. I imagine this puts struggling students in an ethically precarious position. Do professors (and people in general) have an obligation to avoid creating situations in which it is both tempting and easy for others to behave unethically? ILANA WALDER-BIESANZ, BOSTON

title: Jon Huntsman Could Do Without Bill Clintons Kudos
description: So if youre running for president in 2016, you probably have to start laying the groundwork now, right?  Can you imagine were even talking about this? Its mind-numbing that within 24 hours, people want to start talking about 2016.

title: Be Wrong as Fast as You Can
description: Heres a partial, redacted-for-the-sake-of-my-dignity list of stuff I once aspired to write but never did: a Mamma Mia!-esque rock opera called Bastards of Young, based on the songs of the Replacements. A sitcom set in Brooklyn that inverts I Love Lucy, so that the wife plays the stable, amiable breadwinner while her lovable loon of a husband hatches ridiculous schemes, often involving the production of artisanal goods. A thriller about the ultimate rogue trader who concocts a single, diabolical transaction to blow up the financial system. An HBO show, called Upstate, about a burned-out corporate raider who returns to his hometown outside Buffalo to save his fathers failing liquor store and ends up trying to rescue the whole town from the double scourge of unemployment and alcoholism. Too depressing? How about this: A reality show in which retired hockey greats like Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier compete against each other coaching teams of  ready for the deal clincher?  inner-city kids whove never been on ice skates.

title: My Personal Storage Wars
description: When my husband, Mike, died of lung cancer five years ago at age 36, I was a very sad widow. I cried a lot. I took to bed. But eventually, I decided Id had enough.

title: Lehane Continues Search for Missing Dog
description: More than a week after appealing to the public for help in finding his lost dog, Tessa  and offering a role in his next novel as a reward to the person who finds her  the author Dennis Lehane has not yet located his missing pet, but he has not given up hope.

title: Prince John Recaptures Galveston
description: It was nearing midnight of New Years Eve, 1862, when the men of the Fourth Texas Cavalry began their dash down the final stretch of the 10,000-foot railroad bridge that connected the Texas mainland to their target: the island city of Galveston, currently under the control of Union forces.

title: Autism Strains Yet Strengthens a Marriage
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Debating Films, Audiences, Epithets and Even Debate Itself
description: From trembling uvulas to spewing epithets, this awards season has not been without controversy. (Its not every day that the Senate Intelligence Committee gets into the Oscar game.) At The New Yorker, David Denby shares some thoughts on Les Miz.

title: F.D.A. Offers Broad New Rules to Fight Food Contamination
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday proposed two sweeping rules aimed at preventing the contamination of produce and processed foods, which has sickened tens of thousands of Americans annually in recent years.

title: New Shade of Green: Stark Shift for Onetime Foe of Genetic Engineering in Crops
description: In case you missed the coverage and commentary yesterday (the Twitter flow is here), you can now watch Mark Lynas, the British writer and environmentalist who once helped drive Europes movement against genetically engineered crops, apologize for those actions and embrace this technology as a vital tool for ending hunger and conserving the environment. He spoke yesterday at theOxford Farming Conferenceat Oxford University. (Many other fascinating presentations are now online.)

title: Made for Each Other
description: We wanted another family member, someone to fill out the cast, a supporting actress, John Homans, the executive editor at New York magazine, writes in his engaging and informative book that is both a survey of the latest research on canine cognition and a memoir of his years with his Lab mix, Stella. As a puppy, Stella found her way from Tennessee to an animal shelter near New York City. Even at 12 weeks old and locked in a cage, she seemed self-possessed, happy for attention but not demanding it, the author recalls. The Homans family took to her immediately and adopted her to be a companion for their soon-to-be 10-year-old son  thereby bringing the comedic and mysterious presence of canine intelligence into their lives.

title: A Grim Fraternity
description: TimesCast: Passenger deaths haunt subway operators. | How Google won its antitrust battle. | Why people underestimate how much they will change.

title: The Line Between Aggressive and Evil
description: Dont Be Evil, the founders of Google, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, proclaimed in their 2004 Owners Manual for prospective investors in the company. Despite widespread cynicism, criticism and even mockery, the company has never backed down on this core premise, reiterating in its most recent list of the things we know to be true that you can make money without doing evil.

title: Sri Lankan Dishes Answer Call for Inspiration
description: THE other day, as I was thumbing through cookbooks looking for inspiration, I came upon a recipe for chicken with cashews, and not the bland Chinese-American version that was so popular for a while. Madhur Jaffrey, the prolific authority on Indian cooking, had a Sri Lankan version in her fascinating book From Curries to Kebabs, published in 2003. In it, she describes the path beginning in India that took curries to the far reaches of the globe; to Indonesia, Africa and beyond. Her recipe, which I adapted and modified a fair bit, contained both cashews and coconut, along with a mixture of spices in a pungent, creamy sauce. It sounded wonderful and made me want to travel.

title: Former Israeli Security Chief Calls Netanyahu a Poor Leader
description: JERUSALEM  In a harsh interview published on Friday, less than three weeks before Israels national elections, a former head of the internal security service accused Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of placing his personal, opportunistic and current interests over those of the state when making crucial policy decisions regarding the Iranian nuclear program, the Palestinian conflict and other matters.

title: Skiing Maines Resorts
description: If you like your mountain experience more placid than precious, you may want to point your skis toward Maine.

title: On Maines Slopes, Plenty of Elbow Room
description: IT was the quiet that was alarming, a stillness that almost bred unease. The ride up the lift had been an exercise in solitude, and now, skiing my way down the mountain, I came to a stop, enveloped by noiselessness.

title: Congress Passes a $9.7 Billion Storm Relief Measure
description: WASHINGTON  Under intense pressure from New York and New Jersey, Congress adopted legislation on Friday that would provide $9.7 billion to cover insurance claims filed by people whose homes were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Sandy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Disney and Destiny

title: The Book Boys of Mumbai
description: As the lights turn red at the Haji Ali traffic intersection in Mumbai, the boy slouching against the railings quickly straightens up. Yakub Sheikh is just 12 years old, but he knows he has only 45 seconds to make some money. Holding aloft his wares, he dashes toward a black BMW and in his cracking preteen voice addresses the woman inside:  Fifty Shades of Grey?

title: Lapland, From Icy Plunge to Blazing Sky
description: LADIES and gentlemen, the northern lights are on, announced a member of our group, breaking the predinner weariness. It had been another long day of cross-country skiing, but his message spurred us to action. In a flash, the cabin was filled with the sound of crinkling jackets and snow pants; a few minutes later, Arctic air was blasting across our faces.

title: Mistakes? He Made a Few
description: Scientists talk about paradigm shifts as if they happen suddenly. One day, theres this paradigm. The next day, Bam! another one comes along. But, oh, how that leaves out the fun parts! The gray zones. The in-between periods of experimentation, play and openness. When it comes to the history of the so-called scientific revolution, that binary telling would certainly skip over one of historys more bizarre and largely forgotten thinkers, the 17th-century Jesuit priest Athanasius Kircher.

title: Martial Art
description: Encountering Homer in a vivid translation made Keats feel like an astonished astronomer watching a new planet swim into view. Readers unfamiliar with medieval Japanese literature  and that must mean most of us  may feel a kindred excitement on first looking into The Tale of the Heike, in a taut new rendering by Royall Tyler. If beauty and elegance, as Tyler remarks, pervade the atmosphere of the earlier Tale of Genji (which he has also translated), the fall of the Heike warrior clan, during the late 12th century, calls to mind the riotous bloodletting of the Iliad. And just as Homers epic has inspired a thousand spinoffs, much of what draws us to Japanese culture  samurai and geisha, anime and manga, woodblock prints and Kurosawa films  comes right out of the exploits recounted in this book.

title: Border Crossings
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when Kurt Weill was known mainly as the composer of a handful of hit songs, usually heard in versions far removed from their original, often transgressive contexts. Louis Armstrong, Frank Sinatra and Ella Fitzgerald transformed Mack the Knife into an upbeat jazz standard, and Bobby Darin made it a smooth pop hit. Broadway fans knew September Song, a survivor from the long-forgotten 1938 Knickerbocker Holiday. And the rock generation knew the Doors take on Alabama Song, unaware that it was all the rage in Berlin  and the centerpiece of an opera  in 1930.

title: Only 24, and at Home in the Top 10
description: ONE of the first things you notice about Benny Blanco, besides the impish brown eyes and the curly hair piled up in a Prince-like coif, are the many curios adorning his hands and wrists.

title: Coastal Sounds, and Bass Thump From Up North
description: Capital Steez

title: Fool Me Once: Spike Brings Back a Reality Classic
description: WHAT does a cable channel do when it stumbles onto a show that attracts more enthusiasm than anything else it has produced, but the premise all but forecloses any hope that it can be brought back for new editions?

title: A Round of Cocktails, Around the World
description: JAPAN was one of the places where American bartenders, having lost their gigs during Prohibition, arrived in the 1920s and 30s. Cocktail bars in Tokyo have remained a testament to that period, as Sean Muldoon, former head bartender of the Merchant Hotel in Belfast, saw firsthand during a cocktail reconnaissance trip there in 2010.

title: In the Same Boat
description: In the book business, everyone gets slapped around. As Ben Schrank intimates in his energetic new novel, Love Is a Canoe, even writers who exude calm and wisdom often hide wounded souls. But in Schranks world, authors have nothing on Manhattans viciously seasoned professionals  publishers and editors whose corner offices harbor enough sad secrets, bruised egos and busted hearts to fill the slush pile for decades.

title: Into the Wilderness
description: In theory, Bernard Bailyn should need no introduction. In actuality, the intellectual landscape is so fragmented that highly literate Americans may not know of this prolific Harvard historian, the recipient of two Pulitzers, a National Book Award, a National Humanities Medal and a Bancroft (the most important professional prize for American historians). Bailyns most influential work probably still is his Ideological Origins of the American Revolution (1967), which forever changed views of our nations beginnings. But my favorite is The Ordeal of Thomas Hutchinson (1974), a superb portrait of the last royal governor of Massachusetts, a conscientious but obtuse public servant whose inability to grasp his subjects resentments led to his becoming the most hated man in the colonies.

title: Cost of Care
description: When I finished this novel, I didnt want to review it; I wanted to reread it. Which might seem perverse if you know that for most of the last hundred pages I was dissolved in tears. Jojo Moyes, the writer who produced this emotional typhoon, knows very well that Me Before You  a novel that has already floated high on Britains best-seller lists  is, as British critical consensus affirms, a real weepy. And yet, unlike other novels that have achieved their mood-melting powers through calculated infusions of treacle  Erich Segals Love Story comes immediately to mind  Moyess story provokes tears that are redemptive, the opposite of gratuitous. Some situations, she forces the reader to recognize, really are worth crying over.

title: New York Observer Hits Reset Again, Names Ken Kurson New Editor
description: It will come as no surprise to those who follow the Manhattan media scene that The New York Observer has picked a new editor. After all, the newspaper has already had five editors in the seven years since Jared Kushner, a New York real estate developer, acquired the newspaper at the age of 25 in 2006.

title: Solving for $
description: Ever since the financial crisis, James Owen Weatherall writes in his new book, The Physics of Wall Street, words like quant, derivative and model have taken on some nasty connotations. He is out to change that.

title: Displaced Persons
description: Life Goes On is both a very good first novel and a chilling reminder of the Nazis success at destroying Germanys rich literary culture for a generation, if not longer. The author, Hans Keilson, wrote this lightly fictionalized account of his life about 80 years ago, when he was in his early 20s. To give just one example of how much the world has changed since then: Keilson tells us in an afterword that the impetus to start the novel was the fury he felt after hed been turned away as a patient by the powerful Berlin Psychoanalytic Institute. (A few years later, the institute would be taken over by a cousin of Hermann Goering, and most of its analysts would flee to Palestine.) The publisher, the great S. Fischer Verlag, accepted the novel for publication in December 1932. The extremely poor and extremely elated Keilson took his advance and went skiing for the first time in his life. When he came back, the Reichstag was on fire, the Nazis had begun arresting Communists, and the publisher told Keilson to change his ending, which had a Communist twist. The novel appeared, with the altered ending, in 1933. It was banned in 1934. And that is the story, Keilson explains in the afterword, of the last debut by a Jewish writer from the old S. Fischer Verlag.

title: A Long Goodbye
description: After Mary Anne Schwalbe learned she had advanced pancreatic cancer, in 2007, her son Will suggested she start a blog to keep family and friends informed. Schwalbe liked the idea but worried it was unseemly to broadcast news about herself, so she asked her son to write it instead. The blog became Wills Mary Anne Schwalbe News. When Mary Anne decided it would be easier if she composed the first entry, she dictated in the third person for Will to type and post  a practice that continued until the blogs, and Mary Annes, last days.

title: Hotel Review: B2 Boutique Hotel + Spa in Zurich
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Housebroken
description: Diana Wagmans fourth novel, The Care and Feeding of Exotic Pets, is about a Los Angeles divorce kidnapped by a deranged iguana owner, and its Wagmans best to date  a quick, engaging story, half thriller and half wry domestic drama. Winnies ex-husband is a celebrity game-show host who wants to be a serious actor, with a yoga-teaching trophy wife and a longing for his surfing days. Their teenage daughter keeps busy resenting her mother and fabricating outrageous abuse stories for an older, online boyfriend shes never met. Winnie herself, meanwhile, is stalled out in the center of a featureless plain of middle-aged torpor, with few desires or ambitions. (She would admit as much: her self-assessment is down to earth.)

title: Stolen Life
description: After all these years, Joyce Carol Oates can still give me the creeps. And the wellspring of terror she taps in DADDY LOVE (Mysterious Press/Grove/Atlantic, $24) was recently brought home to the entire country  a childs fear of losing a parent and a parents fear of losing a child. Five-year-old Robbie Whitcomb lives one form of that nightmare when hes snatched from the parking lot of a mall in Ypsilanti, Mich., by a whiskered man who attacks the boys mother and drives over her in his van, leaving her a pitiful broken thing.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, John Homans talks about Whats a Dog For?; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Allan Kozinn discusses Kurt Weill and Lotte Lenya; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Up Front
description: Isabel Wilkersons history of the Great Migration, The Warmth of Other Suns, was published only two years ago, but it shows every indication of becoming a classic, winning a National Book Critics Circle Award and receiving numerous Best Book citations from such sources as Newsday, The New York Times and The New Yorker. This week, Wilkerson reviews the first novel by Ayana Mathis, The Twelve Tribes of Hattie, which traces the fortunes of a woman and her children after she left Jim Crow Georgia for Philadelphia in the 1920s.

title: 'Downton' in French
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: Inside the List
description: THE FINAL FRONTIER: Thirty years ago this week, outer space was the dominant theme on the hardcover fiction list. All four of the top sellers kept an eye on the stars  or, in the case of James Michener (inset), the moon  and a fifth space novel, Douglas Adamss Life, the Universe and Everything, also touched down in the top 10. The nonfiction list was moony in its own way, with books by Leo Buscaglia and Helen Gurley Brown, but probably the most notable title was Robert A. Caros Path to Power: The Years of Lyndon Johnson, described here as the first 33 years of the life of the 36th president. Three decades later, Caros life of Johnson is rivaling Boswells in its magisterial sweep, and still going strong. Here are the complete lists for Jan. 9, 1983:

title: F.T.C. Hands Google Big Win
description: The Federal Trade Commission found that Google did not violate antitrust and anticompetition laws, clearing the way for the company to further dominate the Web search field.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE MIDDLESTEINS,  by Jami Attenberg. (Grand Central, $24.99.) Attenbergs heroine is killing herself through overeating, but this moving novels underlying subject is a suburban Jewish family, and how it reacts to the disaster unfolding in its midst.

title: Paperback Row
description: ALIBIS: Essays on Elsewhere,  by Andr Aciman. (Picador, $16.) These beguiling essays explore time, place and identity  from an extended aria on the memories evoked by the scent of lavender to elegiac meditations on Barcelona, Rome, Paris and New York. Aciman is a spirited guide, sensitive to history but alive also to food, sunshine, art and aimless wandering, Teju Cole wrote in the Book Review.

title: 'Downton' in Germany
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: Lucy Caldwell and David McDevitt
description: THEY had scheduled their wedding for Dec. 21  the day the world was supposed to end. And with just three days before the ceremony, and with so many things going wrong, even a reasonable mind might begin to think that it all seemed ominous.

title: Face Time | Joanne Froggatt
description: The actress Joanne Froggatt returns as the head housemaid Anna Bates in the highly anticipated third season of Downton Abbey, which starts this Sunday on Masterpiece on PBS. And soon shell be starring alongside James McAvoy in a movie called Filth, based on the novel by the Trainspotting author Irvine Welsh. Between work and married life, Frogatt says, shes got a perfect scenario going. Here she tells T about the style and beauty tips that keep her looking pretty.

title: On This Cruise Ship, Its Not All-You-Can-Eat
description: Just to show that cruise-ship dining is not all endless buffets at midnight, Celebrity Cruises has organized a series of pop-up meals beginning Jan. 29 that will feature luxury cruise food in three-course lunches and dinners.

title: Grid Problems Curb Indias Electric-Vehicle Appetite
description: COIMBATORE, India  In early 2012, after years of experimentation, an Indian start-up called Ampere developed an electric motorcycle that people would actually buy.

title: Book Review Podcast: Inside the Canine Brain
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Walter Vatter reviews Whats a Dog For? by John Homans, an engaging and informative book that is both a survey of the latest research on canine cognition and a memoir of his years with his Lab mix, Stella. Mr. Vatter writes:

title: Navigating College Admissions While Pretty Seriously Depressed
description: December was relatively uneventful as far as college goes. I did receive an acceptance letter from the University of Arkansas, which is exciting. As for schoolwork and life in general, it has been a little hectic.

title: Self-Perception, Past and Future
description: The Timess John Tierney discusses new research showing that people tend to underestimate how much they will change in the future.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The barbecue joint Mighty Quinns will take over a kiosk as part of Smorgasburg at Whole Foods Market Bowery, 95 East Houston Street, a collaboration between the store and the Brooklyn Flea. Hugh Mangum, the pit master, will be making pulled pork shoulder, smoked turkey breast and sides of edamame and sweet pea salad. Situated on the second floor, it will be open for lunch and dinner through Jan. 30.

title: Womens Unemployment Surpasses Mens
description: For the first time in more than six years, the unemployment rate for adult women (those over age 20), seasonally adjusted, has surpassed that for adult men.

title: Signs of Life in Worlds Factories
description: In many parts of the world, manufacturers reported gains in new orders at the end of 2012, although not in most euro zone countries.

title: Fresh Insights Where Decay Meets Architecture
description: FOR the Portuguese architect Eduardo Souto de Moura, the 2011 winner of the Pritzker Prize for architecture, there are two potential responses to the presence of a ruin in a landscape. The first is the default Romantic expression of bittersweet wonder. The second, and more intriguing, is to ask: What can I do here? What does this suggest to me that I am able to build? Mr. Souto de Moura is the subject of Reconverso, a new film by the Los Angeles filmmaker Thom Andersen, who could be the architects cinematic doppelgnger.

title: 'Downton' in Latin American Spanish
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: Factories Are Firing Up, Except in Europe
description: THE slowdown in worldwide manufacturing that began in mid-2012 may be nearing an end.

title: 'Downton' in Castilian
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: 'Downton' in Brazilian Portugese
description: The hit series is popular all over the world.

title: New Rules for the New Year
description: 2012: I call it the year in meh. Not the worst weve ever experienced, but nothing particularly great to say about it either. Like being a socialite, but in Tampa.

title: Nouvelle Vague in New York Style
description: THE past 20 years or so have turned indie filmmaking into a brand as much as an ethos, and one side effect has been a certain amnesia. Long before indie became the trademark of a festival in Utah (much less a term at times as contentious as hipster), a revolution in cinema occurred on several fronts in New York. Shot on location, often on meager budgets, these films tapped into the citys cultural and social energies: its streets, its people, its artistic fervor.

title: Homage to a Master of Silents
description: ARRIVING a tad too late for holiday giving, Kinos spectacular 14-disc Buster Keaton Collection nevertheless demands attention as an infinitely rewarding anthology of the major works of a major artist. Here is Keatons richest creative period, essentially intact: all 19 of the shorts he made as a star between 1920 and 1923, and all 11 of the silent features he made as an independent (including, for the first time on Blu-ray, the 1927 College).

title: La Guardia-Bound Pilot Arrested on Alcohol Charge
description: Updated, 3:07 p.m. | An American Eagle pilot of a flight headed for La Guardia Airport was arrested at the airport in Minneapolis Friday morning after failing a breath test for alcohol, Minnesota authorities said.

title: Bond, Oscar Bond
description: In a year when Skyfall has broken box office records for a Bond movie, and on the 50th anniversary of the franchise, the Academy has seen fit to honor the debonair British agent.

title: Excerpt: 'Legit'
description: The new sitcom starring the comic Jim Jefferies begins on FX on Jan. 17.

title: Andrew P. ORourke, 79, Rival to Mario Cuomo, Dies
description: Andrew P. ORourke, a pragmatic Republican who was chief executive of Westchester County for 14 years and his partys long-shot nominee in 1986 to challenge the re-election bid of New Yorks popular incumbent governor, Mario M. Cuomo, died on Thursday night in the Bronx. He was 79.

title: Cinnamon Rolls
description: Who doesnt like cinnamon rolls? Melissa Clark shows how to make them.

title: Legit, but Not Warm and Cuddly
description: IN Legit, a new comedy starting Jan. 17 on FX, the comedian Jim Jefferies plays himself as an agreeable lug bumbling through his life and relationships.

title: The Sweet Spot | Favorites of 2012
description: In advance of the Academy Awards nominations, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about their favorite movies and performances of 2012.

title: The Sweet Spot: Jan. 4
description: In advance of the Academy Awards nominations, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about their favorite movies and performances of 2012.

title: Knicks and Nets Rediscover What Works
description: When the Knicks played the San Antonio Spurs, their opponent on Thursday night, the first time this season, they were a surprising 5-0 team searching for legitimacy. On that November night they handed the Spurs one of their two home losses of the season and were the toast of the N.B.A.

title: Drowsy Drivers Pose Major Risks
description: A new study of driving behavior across the country found that slightly more than 4 percent of adults admit to having fallen asleep at the wheel.

title: Settling Questions About Taxes
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about the bill passed by Congress that permanently sets the estate and gift tax exemptions at $5 million. The action ends more than a decade of flux for the estate tax and, with it, more than a decade of uncertainty among the wealthy on how best to set up their finances to benefit heirs.

title: Passive Resistance
description: Following the fiscal cliff deal, President Obama declared that he would not get into another fight over the debt ceiling.

title: Friday Reading: Some Travelers Can Keep Their Shoes On
Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Curious Vampire
description: Its a sleepy start to the new year, with only one newcomer among graphic books best-sellers this week. That honor goes to Volume 1 of Blood Lad, by Yuuki Kodama (Yen Press), which is at No. 2 on the manga list. The series is about Staz, a vampire whose tough exterior hides a love for and curiosity about human culture, especially all things Japanese. When he meets a Japanese girl, he thinks hes finally found someone he can ask questions, but her life is tragically cut short. His new mission becomes restoring her ghostly form to human life. The first volume was released in December. Volume 2 follows in March and Volume 3 in May.

title: TimesTalks: Ewan McGregor
description: In a conversation with Melena Ryzik, Ewan McGregor discusses acting in "The Impossible."

title: John Sheardown, Canadian Who Sheltered Americans in Tehran, Dies at 88
description: When militant radicals seized the United States Embassy in Iran in November 1979, they intended to take all its employees hostage. But five were elsewhere in the embassy compound and escaped capture. After six tense days of furtively moving around Tehran, one of them, Robert Anders, placed a call to a Canadian diplomat with whom he played tennis, and asked for help.

title: Q. and A. With Lincoln Phillips
description: Before the first North American Soccer League briefly soared after the signing of Pel in 1975, some of the most interesting stories in 1970s soccer in the United States were found in the college game.

title: Downton Abbey Goes Global
description: A look at some of the foreign versions of Downton Abbey.

title: Coconut Milk Without the Can
description: This weeks City Kitchen column features a Sri Lankan chicken curry with cashews and coconut milk.

title: Girl Shot by Pakistani Taliban Is Discharged From Hospital
description: LONDON  Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani schoolgirl shot in the head three months ago by the Taliban for advocating the education of girls, has been discharged from a British hospital. Doctors said she had made excellent progress and would be staying with her family nearby before returning for further surgery to rebuild her skull in about four weeks.

title: Rape Victims Friend Details Attack and Delays in Getting Help
description: The male friend of a woman who died after being gang-raped and sexually assaulted with an iron rod in New Delhi described the attack for the first time publicly in an interview broadcast Friday.

title: You Can Succumb to a Sticky Temptation
description: THIS is the time of year when most people have salad on the brain. New Years resolutions and losing the holiday five propel us toward leafy green vegetables and whole grains.

title: A Vegan Resolution
description: If one of your goals for 2013 is more healthful eating, the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman can get you started. She has proposed five delicious vegan meals for the New Year that may also save you some money. She writes:

title: A Dream Wedding in Someone Elses Backyard
description: MARINA GIOVANNELLI, in her quest for a distinctive wedding location, said she wanted to break from the formulaic feel of affairs in hotels and museums in the city of her childhood, San Diego.

title: Hurricane Cost City at Least $154 Million in Overtime
description: New York City anticipated that Hurricane Sandy would be an expensive disaster for the government, and now, some of the bills are adding up.

title: How Defense Act Addresses Military Suicides and Issues of Conscience
description: When President Obama signed the $633 billion National Defense Authorization Act of 2013, he did far more than enact a spending bill.

title: Zosia Mamet By Moonlight
description: Taffy Brodesser-Akners profile of Zosia Mamet in this Sundays issue features photography by Olivia Bee, whose last work for the magazine accompanied a story about a new approach to teenage sex education.

title: Automobiles Niche Growing at Consumer Electronics Show
description: As the relationships between consumer electronics and the automotive industry continue to intertwine, more than half a dozen carmakers are planning to attend the 2013 Consumer Electronics Show to exhibit technological advances in in-car information an entertainment, mobile integration, propulsion systems and vehicle safety and efficiency.

title: An Invitation for High School Seniors to Write About Finances
description: At the University of Michigan, one application essay talked about how local education cutbacks forced high school students to pay money to play team sports. As a result, the writer could no longer afford to play.

title: Uncommon Advice for Seeking a Fresh Start
description: The Beauty Experiment: How I Skipped Lipstick, Ditched Fashion, Faced the World Without Concealer, and Learned to Love the Real Me, by Phoebe Baker Hyde. Da Capo Press. 248 pp. $16.

title: Afghanistan Frees Detainees in Show of Sovereignty Before Karzai Visits U.S.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Just ahead of a trip to Washington by President Hamid Karzai, the Afghan government released 80 detainees on Friday, part of a continuing effort to assert its sovereignty over the contentious issue of how prisoners are handled.

title: Record Ratings for New Years Rockin Eve
description: Television viewers and party hosts have been given more programming options on New Years Eve in recent times, but on Monday night most of them still chose to ring in the new year with an old, reliable standby: Dick Clarks New Years Rockin Eve With Ryan Seacrest on ABC. According to Nielsen, that countdown special attracted its largest prime-time audience ever  with 13.3 million total viewers tuning in during the 10 p.m. hour  and its highest rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic in 12 years.

title: Writers Guild Gives Flight, Looper and Master a Little Help
description: 3:48 p.m. | Updated  If anybody appreciates the power of revision, its the members of the Writers Guild, which today announced its screenplay nominations, a day after they were originally due. In the original category, the guild selected John Gatins for Flight, Rian Johnson for Looper, Paul Thomas Anderson for The Master, Wes Anderson and Roman Coppola for Moonrise Kingdom, and Mark Boal for Zero Dark Thirty.

title: The Mahogany Boxes Hold No Surprises From the Electoral College
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will serve another term in the White House.

title: To Glaze, and Glaze Again
description: In todays column and video, I attempt to persuade you to take a short break from your resolutions  a butterscotch-glazed cinnamon roll break, that is.

title: Seeking College Application Essays About Money
description: This weekends Your Money column includes a call for submissions from current high school seniors who have written their college application essays about money. Well read them all and publish the best here on Bucks. You can send us yours at moneyessays@nytimes.com.

title: Brooklyn Brewery Is on Tap for Stockholm
description: Brooklyns bid for world domination is extending to Sweden.

title: Europe Likely to Be Harder on Google Over Search
description: PARIS  By some accounts, the United States let Google off the hook when it found that the technology giant had not abused its dominance in the Internet search market.

title: Maggie Smiths Highest Compliment
description: At 43, Ol Parker was not exactly the obvious choice to adapt the screenplay for The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel, about retirees in India, so when the producer Graham Broadbent approached him, he initially wondered, Why me?

title: How We Create Those Compare & Contrast Columns
description: Eric Spitznagel, who writes the Compare & Contrast column for The One-Page Magazine, asks and answers his own questions about his process.

title: What Will Induce Nostalgia in 2033?
description: PICK a decade, any decade, from the 1920s to the 1990s. Say youre throwing a theme party with all the sartorial, musical and follicular trimmings. The clichd cultural signifiers spring to mind: Flappers in bob haircuts with cigarette holders doing the Lindy hop! Long-tressed hippies in jangly, rainbow-colored necklaces, acoustically strumming For What Its Worth! Causeless rebels in white undershirts with slicked-back hair, milling around a mass of crew-cut men in gray flannel suits at the sock hop!

title: Relocation Therapy
description: ALMOST four years ago, Marilyn Kotcher suddenly became a widow. And the large  2,250-square-foot  condominium in Fort Lee, N.J., that she and her husband had bought together and lovingly remodeled no longer seemed like home.

title: Knicks Online Community Keeps It Real for a Night
description: Full Circle is a congenially bonkers sports-and-beer bar on Grand Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where the menu features 60 or so canned beers, 5 on draft, no bottles, a modest liquor selection, free soft pretzels and hot dogs, and nothing else. The house sport is brewskee ball  the bar is owned by the creators of the first national brewskee ball league, and the dcor is given over entirely to brewskee paraphernalia  but on Thursday night Full Circle belonged to the Knicks.

title: A Hoarders Daughter Yields to a (Little) Mess
description: I grew up in a Montreal duplex lined with old newspapers, videocassettes and a Tetris puzzle of cobwebbed credenzas. My mother, born on my grandparents flight from Nazi-occupied Poland, had formative years filled with loss. She saved everything, but in doing so, created physical and emotional barriers between us. Her kitchen was not used for family meals, but to host fortresses of molding tuna cans and bags of insect-infested flour. The path to her bed was so covered with files and clothes that I could not reach her if I had a nightmare. I was an anxious child who feared intimacy.

title: Rarely Spotted, but Ready for Flight
description: TESTED 2013 Honda Accord EX-L Coupe

title: A Motherboard Walks Into a Bar ...
description: WHAT do you get when you cross a fragrance with an actor?

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 4
An Amenity Thats Going Places
description: HAMPTON COURT, a luxury rental in East Harlem, appealed to Thati Schlesinger and Renato Taralli for a variety of reasons when they were apartment hunting two years ago. But one amenity in particular helped seal the deal: a free shuttle bus to the local and express subway stops.

title: You Can Park It in the Spot for Employee of the Month
description: MY, my, late for the morning commute. Just a quick slurp of coffee; dont spill it on the tie again, and darn it, where did I leave those car keys?

title: Too Polite to Stand Out
description: The redesigned Chevrolet Malibu faces a daunting pack of midsize rivals. And while the Malibu is soft-spoken and well mannered, its not great at any single thing.

title: Federal Judge Steps Down to Join Law Firm
description: Barbara S. Jones, a federal judge and a former prosecutor, is stepping down from the bench to join the law firm Zuckerman Spaeder.

title: Q & A
description: Questions About a Washing Machine

title: Jamie Kennedy Discusses His Memorable New Years Eve Special
description: 8:03 a.m. | Updated

title: Hulus Chief Is Leaving, Raising Questions About Its Future
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated Jason Kilar, the Web wizard who turned Hulu from a punch line into a popular source of online video, said on Friday that he would step down as the sites founding chief executive in the next three months.

title: Murray Span, 1922-2012
description: One consequence of our elders extended lifespans is that we half expect them to keep chugging along forever. My father, a busy yoga practitioner and blackjack player, celebrated his 90th birthday in September in reasonably good health.

title: The Family Franchise
description: THOSE who go into the family business, if that business is writing, often have a tricky path to navigate, one that involves battling the perception of nepotism while carving out their identities.

title: Prospects for Congolese Peace Talks Grow Shakier
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Congolese rebels threatened to pull out of peace talks with the Congolese government, after accusing the Congolese military of arming militias to reinforce positions along the front lines in eastern Congo.

title: Thomas Pynchon to Publish New Book
description: He is suspicious of e-books, does not like to have his picture taken, and is often rumored to be on the short-list of American novelists who might win the Nobel prize for literature.

title: Even a Drive in the Suburbs Feels Like a 60s Vacation
description: WYCKOFF, N.J.

title: No Longer a Cautionary Tale
description: WHEN I read that Jean S. Harris had died, I immediately texted my friend Anita in Seattle to ask if shed heard. How to put this? Anita and I were Jean Harris groupies back in 1981, when the 57-year-old former Madeira School headmistress went on trial for shooting to death her philandering lover of 14 years, the 69-year-old cardiologist and Scarsdale Diet guru Herman Tarnower. We got up at dawn one cold winter morning the week Ms. Harris was on the stand and drove to the small White Plains courthouse hoping to get seats in the courtroom. We didnt drive there in any official capacity. We were ordinary young New York working women. Divorced and never married, respectively. We were former English majors. We read. We knew a thing or two about bad love. We were in therapy. We were sixth in line.

title: The Week in New York Region Pictures for Jan. 4
description: Subjects include New Years Eve in Times Square; the return of Sandy Hook students to school; and a New York Fire Department promotion ceremony.

title: Giants to Skip Albany and Train in the Meadowlands
description: The Giants will hold their 2013 training camp at their training center in East Rutherford, N.J., the team announced Friday, opting for the comfort and ease of their own facility instead of returning to the University at Albany for the 17th time in the last 18 years.

title: Unmarried Spouses Have a Way With Words
description: NOW that weve come to some consensus on same-sex marriage, lets move on to the next puzzle: what to call two people who act as if they are married but are not.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 4
description: Subjects include a video from Ryan McGinley, the Metropolitan Opera and Sandra Bernhard.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 4
description: More photographs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza, India, Kashmir and Thailand.

title: Notes on 2012 North American Auto Sales
description: The just-released 2012 North American auto sales data offer some insights into some marquee sales match-ups, like the crown for Americas best-selling vehicle, Ford vs. Chevy for muscle-car bragging rights and how well Americas definition of luxury stacks up against foreign competition.

title: Cleanup Crews Near Fukushima Plant Dump Waste in Rivers, Newspaper Reports
description: According to Japans Asahi Shimbun, cleanup crews working near the ruined Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, dumped soil and leaves contaminated with radioactive fallout into rivers.

title: Greys Anatomy Star Would Be White Knight for Small Coffee Chain
description: He only plays a doctor on TV. But Patrick Dempsey is about to become a real-life coffee magnate.

title: Rally Signals Fatahs Rift With Hamas May Ease
description: JERUSALEM  Turning the streets of Gaza City into a swarm of sunshine-yellow flags, hundreds of thousands of Palestinians celebrated the anniversary of the Fatah faction on Friday in the heartland of its militant Islamist rival, Hamas, the latest in a series of signals heralding possible reconciliation between the parties after their bitter five-year rift.

title: Will Biomimicry Offer a Way Forward, Post-Sandy?
description: As neighborhoods devastated by Hurricane Sandy begin drafting plans for reconstruction, some progressive architects and urban planners are arguing that the emerging science of biomimicry offers a way forward. The notion is that the next generation of waterfront designs could draw inspiration from the intricate ways that plants and animals have adapted to their situations over hundreds of millions of years.

title: Less Bronx-Whitestone Bridge Yielded More Stability During Hurricane Sandy
description: One very windy day in 1968, the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge began to oscillate crazily, leading drivers to abandon their cars in panic.

title: Living In | Commack, L.I.
description: Tucked behind the highways and the shopping areas on busy streets are quiet neighborhoods, most created from the 1950s to the 1980s.

title: Sensible, Even on Scarlett Drive and Rhett Court
description: WHEN Maria Diomataris and her husband, Tony, moved to Commack seven years ago from Old Bethpage, they were looking for good schools and a larger property. The prices were ridiculous in our area, Ms. Diomataris said. They bought a two-story contemporary on half an acre for about $625,000, she said.

title: Letting the Piano Find Its Inner Harp
description: A premium is placed on musicians constantly showing different sides of themselves and presenting different aspects of their repertories in each recital. But there is something to be said for treading the same ground over and over, for making sure that listeners have certain works, particularly those recently written, firmly in their ears.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $50,000,000
description: Another in the skein of palatial domiciles with Central Park vistas and/or impeccable Fifth or Park Avenue pedigrees that named their price in a resurgent 2012 luxury market and received it without the nuisance of negotiations, a full-floor co-op at 944 Fifth Avenue that sold for $50 million was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. And it wasnt even a penthouse with wraparound terraces. In fact, it is not a penthouse nor does it possess any outdoor space.

title: An Old-Fashioned Family Hauler
description: Joe Mamola of Wyckoff, N.J., has brought Station Wagon Living into the 21st century with his 1964 Ford Fairlane 500 Ranch Wagon.

title: Morgan Stanley Discloses Payouts to Senior Deal Maker
description: Morgan Stanley disclosed on Friday the timeline for some of its retirement awards to Paul J. Taubman, the senior deal maker who co-led its securities business.

title: Removing the Need to Refill Tires
description: THE steady flow of reminders to keep tires at the automakers suggested inflation levels  even President Obama chimed in  demonstrates just how far the demands of auto maintenance have diminished. With spark plugs that seem to last forever and oil-change intervals stretching to 10,000 miles and more, many owners continue to slack off when it comes to looking after tire pressures.

title: Digital Connections Will Increase as a Selling Point, Study Says
description: AUTOMAKERS are racing to ramp up their digital offerings, linking in-dash systems to smartphones and services like traffic monitors faster than you can say Pandora.

title: Patience and Progress in the Bronx
description: AS the founder and president of the Bronx Pro Group, a family-run, neighborhood-based company in Morris Park that builds, renovates and manages low- and moderate-income housing in the Bronx, Peter Magistro, 63, has seen the borough struggle and come back to life. A Bronx native and longtime resident who now lives on the Upper West Side, he has an intimate knowledge of local housing trends. He knows where the Bronx has been and where its headed.

title: Video Shows Airstrikes Near Crusader Castle in Syria
description: Video posted online by Syrian opposition activists on Friday appeared to show fresh airstrikes near the historic medieval castle Krak des Chevaliers, in Qalaat al-Hosn, west of the city of Homs near the Lebanese border.

title: As Plans for Afghan Exit Are Sketched, Hope Turns to Hatred
description: Many of the insider attacks for which the Taliban take responsibility actually start off as offers by enraged Afghan soldiers and police officers, Matthew Rosenberg reported in The Times on Thursday.

title: Azarenka Withdraws After Pedicure Injury
description: The most anticipated match of the young 2013 season was called off on Friday, when top-ranked Victoria Azarenka pulled out of her Brisbane International semifinal against third-ranked Serena Williams, citing an infection in her right big toe. It would have been a rematch of the dramatic United States Open final between the two, which Williams won, 7-5, in the third set after Azarenka had served for the championship.

title: That House Grandma Left Her Is a Mess
description: Lets see, how many name actors have enrolled in the Texas Chainsaw Massacre school of hard blows over that horror franchises history? There are Viggo Mortensen (class of 1990); Matthew McConaughey and Rene Zellweger (1994); Jessica Biel (2003); and Matt Bomer of White Collar (2006). Now add Alexandra Daddario (of Percy Jackson & the Olympians), Scott Eastwood (yes, Clints son) and Tremaine Neverson (a k a the singer Trey Songz), who graduate with flying limbs in the new, generic sixth installment, Texas Chainsaw 3D.

title: Zipcar Makes S.E.C. Filing After C.E.O.s Twitter Message
description: Scott Griffith, the chief executive of Zipcar, was still riding high on Friday, two days after Avis announced that it was buying his company for $500 million. He appeared on CNBC to discuss the sale, and showed further enthusiasm for the deal  and the publicity surrounding it  by posting on Twitter:

title: A New Eras Filmmakers Find Their Way in Cuba
description: HAVANA  Sebastin Mil barely had enough money to put gasoline in the aged bus that ferried his crew to the set each day, let alone to pay actors a salary.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Gambling Software Arrest and Silicon Valley Dress-Up
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Historians Look Back, and Inward, at Annual Meeting
description: NEW ORLEANS  Some 4,000 historians descended on New Orleans on Thursday for the American Historical Associations four-day annual meeting, replacing the chants of departing Sugar Bowl revelers with more sober talk of job interviews, departmental politics, and  at least in the official panels  the past itself.

title: New Rules Let More Beer Flow
description: LAMBERTVILLE, N.J.  When Sean Hanrahan and Nina Sassano, both of Freehold, bought tickets to the River Horse Brewing Companys oatmeal milk stout release party here last month, they noticed on Facebook that it was the first time the brewery was holding such an event, Ms. Sassano said. But they did not realize that a change in New Jersey law governing microbreweries had made such gatherings possible.

title: Leaders of Sudan and South Sudan in Ethiopia for Talks
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  The presidents of Sudan and South Sudan, two nations that have been locked in a tense dispute over borders, territory and oil since the south split off and became its own country 18 months ago, arrived in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa, on Friday for a summit meeting intended to speed up an agreement signed between both sides last September.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: A six-bedroom stone contemporary colonial in Stamford, Conn., and a five-bedroom colonial built in 1986 in Ardsley, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Hells Kitchen Studio, a NoHo triplex and a Flatbush town house.

title: The Link Between Weight and Health
description: To the Editor:

title: This Lovely 1920s Fire Alarm Box Door Could Be Yours
description: Still havent found that post-holiday gift for the nostalgic fire buff who has everything? Check out this potential bargain: the door to a surplus vintage 1925 fire alarm box. Its being auctioned by New York City, with a minimum opening bid of $50.

title: Debit and Credit Card Purchases Shut Down at Vatican
description: VATICAN CITY  If youre planning a trip to the Vatican, be sure to take cash.

title: The Heartbreak in Russias Adoption Ban
No DNA, No Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopeful in Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 4
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Years Eve in Times Square; the return of Sandy Hook Elementary students to classes; and a Fire Department promotion ceremony.

title: Fleeing North Korea Is Becoming Harder
description: CHEONAN, South Korea  The Rev. Kim Seung-eun said he could measure the increasing difficulty of smuggling people out of North Korea by the higher cost of bribing North Korean soldiers on the Chinese border to look the other way.

title: New Mortgage Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts Plans Stricter Control of Compounding Pharmacies
description: BOSTON  New laws to strengthen state control of compounding pharmacies were proposed on Friday by Gov. Deval Patrick, in hopes of preventing another public health disaster like the current outbreak of meningitis caused by a contaminated drug made in Massachusetts.

title: 17-Year-Old American Wins 2nd World Cup Race
description: ZAGREB, Croatia  Mikaela Shiffrin became the first American to capture two World Cup races before the age of 18 on Friday when she won the Zagreb FIS World Cup Night Slalom.

title: Exports of American Natural Gas May Fall Short of High Hopes
description: HOUSTON  Only five years ago, several giant natural gas import terminals were built to satisfy the energy needs of a country hungry for fuels. But the billion-dollar terminals were obsolete even before the concrete was dry as an unexpected drilling boom in new shale fields from Pennsylvania to Texas produced a glut of cheap domestic natural gas.

title: Other Fields to Conquer
description: After 33 previews and 718 performances, War Horse wraps up at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: U.S. Settles Accusations That Doctors Overtreated
description: A group of doctors who performed unusually high rates of heart procedures on patients at a community hospital in Ohio settled with the Justice Department over accusations that some of the procedures were medically unnecessary, federal regulators announced on Friday.

title: Iraqi Prime Minister Faces More Calls for Resignation
description: BAGHDAD  A political crisis facing the Shiite-led government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq appeared to escalate on Friday, as more political rivals called for his resignation and for early elections. In addition to the political arena, demand for change echoed in the streets as demonstrators expanded protests in major Iraqi cities.

title: In Mets-Like Move, Yankees Acquire Outfielder
description: The Yankees search for a right-handed-hitting outfielder/designated hitter continues to take on a distinct bargain-bin feel. Just after Christmas they signed Matt Diaz, the former Atlanta Brave, and on Friday they claimed Russ Canzler off waivers from the Cleveland Indians.

title: Truscott Board-a-Match Teams
description: The Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional took place in New York City from Dec. 26 through last Sunday.

title: Inaugural Contributors Identified
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama drew criticism last month for allowing unlimited corporate donations to finance his inaugural festivities. But when his inaugural planners released the names of donors late Friday afternoon, only a handful of companies were on the list of several hundred contributors.

title: Brazil: State to Make Addicts Get Help
description: The authorities in So Paulo, Brazils most populous state, said they would start detaining addicts of crack cocaine and sending them against their will to treatment centers. The new measure, which was announced Thursday and is set to be put into effect this month, is aimed at combating a crack epidemic visibly on display in blighted parts of the city of So Paulo, the state capital, where roving groups of addicts consume the drug in broad daylight. Officials across Brazil are searching for solutions to the problem, with Brazil ranking among the worlds largest cocaine markets. Security forces in Rio de Janeiro have been forcing crack addicts into treatment centers since 2011. On a federal level, President Dilma Rousseffs government is moving forward with a $2 billion anti-crack initiative, including awareness campaigns and enhanced efforts to combat the trafficking of cocaine into Brazil from neighboring countries.

title: Is Google Like Gas or Like Steel?
description: AFTER a two-year investigation, the Federal Trade Commission concluded this week that Googles search practices did not violate antitrust law. Those who wanted to see an epic battle like the one the government fought with Microsoft in the 1990s were sorely disappointed. But the analogy to the browser war of the Webs early days was never the right one. It failed to capture the dangers free speech would have faced if regulators had agreed with Googles critics.

title: Majesty, Energy: The Usual Stuff
description: Given the success that the Austrian-born conductor Manfred Honeck has had as music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, where he is now in his fifth season, it is surprising that it took until Thursday night for him to make his debut with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall. Yet for this career milestone appearance, Mr. Honeck stuck mainly to the staples.

title: 2 Countries Caught in Historys Awkward Embrace
description: BERLIN  Germans and Russians have an enduring fascination with each other. Although they share a long history steeped in enmity and warfare, their relationship has also involved centuries of respect. Slavs and Teutons have long struggled to understand each others cultures, languages and worldviews.

title: A Commercial Kitchen With a Built-In Market
description: FARMINGDALE, N.Y.  On a recent evening at A Taste of Long Island, a commercial kitchen and specialty food market here, the Goldfuss family  Christine, Jim and their two children, James, 17, and Kerri, 13  put on red chefs jackets embroidered with Christines Sweets, laid out baking ingredients in the kitchen and got down to business.

title: Church of England Ends Ban on Gay Men as Bishops
description: LONDON  Wading once more into an issue that has caused angry divisions among Anglicans around the world, the Church of England said Friday that gay clergymen in civil partnerships could become bishops as long as they vowed to remain celibate.

title: No Religious Exemption When It Comes to Abuse
description: Just as we think we know what an abuser looks like, we think we know what an abusive religious community looks like. We may think it is highly insular  like the Satmar Hasidic community in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, a prominent member of which was  convicted last month of sexually abusing a young girl sent to him for help. Or it is hierarchical and bureaucratic: if the Roman Catholic Church did not have so many bishops and archbishops who refused to dismiss or defrock molesters in their ranks, would so many pedophile priests have been able to carry on for so long?

title: Drying Out After a Storm, and Moving On
description: Tim Griffin was settling into his first full season in charge of the programming at the Kitchen theater and art gallery on West 19th Street in Chelsea, with hopes of re-establishing the space as an artists meeting place, when Hurricane Sandy flooded it with four feet of water from the Hudson River.

title: Teamwork Continues in Honoring a Coach
description: At another university, winning a national title in football might earn a coach a bonus, a contract extension and discounted appetizers at local restaurants.

title: Scare Adds to Fears That Clintons Work Has Taken Toll
description: WASHINGTON  When Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton fractured her right elbow after slipping in a State Department garage in June 2009, she returned to work in just a few days. Her arm in a sling, she juggled speeches and a trip to India and Thailand with physical therapy, rebuilding a joint held together with wire and pins.

title: A Culinary Crazy Quilt From a Celebrated Chef
description: Ive never liked dining in a casino setting. Parking nightmares, disorienting treks through cacophonous gambling halls  and all too often, when you arrive, prices to make the low-roller quake. Bobby Flays Bar Americain, at Mohegan Sun, isnt cheap. Eating thriftily will challenge the craftiest diner.

title: Auto Racetrack Owners Keep Coveted Tax Break
description: WASHINGTON  In the rush to pass tax legislation, owners of auto racetracks scored a victory this week even as many other industries were left behind.

title: Rebellion at Stalemate, Waiting for Undecided Syrians to Make a Move
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At his government office in the Syrian capital, Damascus, the civil servant avoids discussing what Syrians call the situation. But he quietly ponders his own private endgame, toying with defecting to the rebels, yet clinging to his post, increasingly sure there are no fighters worth joining.

title: U.S. Banks Again Hit by Wave of Cyberattacks
description: For the last week, hackers have  once again  attacked the online banking sites of several American banks.

title: Second Chance Is Paying Off for Packers and Their Center
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  Packers center Evan Dietrich-Smith could easily be mistaken for Jeff Saturday, the man whose job he took in Week 16. Both are round-faced, with matching bushy beards and heads topped by thick, brown hair. Each is listed at 6 feet 2 inches, with Dietrich-Smith at 308 pounds and Saturday a shade lighter at 295.

title: Justices Take Case on Adoption of Indian Child
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to consider cases concerning the adoption of American Indian children and whether federal judges may play a role in plea negotiations.

title: Small Plates Expand Spanish-Fare Choices
description: Westchester County, rich in the cuisine of certain nationalities, is poor in that of others. To the precious few Spanish restaurants in the county, Sala on Hudson comes as a welcome addition. And although its storefront is hidden in an unprepossessing shopping strip in Croton-on-Hudson, Sala definitely has its attractions  and theyre all on plates.

title: Nomination of Hagel Could Come Next Week
description: WASHINGTON  Chuck Hagel appears to have weathered a concerted and vocal campaign to derail his chances for defense secretary, with President Obama likely to nominate him as early as next week, administration and Congressional officials said Friday.

title: On Google, F.T.C. Set Rules of War Over Patents
description: The Federal Trade Commissions antitrust investigation of Google focused mainly on the companys lucrative search business, while its inquiry into the tech giants handling of patents seemed an afterthought.

title: Man Accused of Conspiring to Kidnap a Woman
description: When federal prosecutors accused a New York City police officer in October of planning to abduct, rape, cook and eat women, they said the officer had plotted with others who shared his impulses.

title: Soccer Racism Prompts Walkout, and Outrage
description: ROME  Italians reacted forcefully Friday to a racist incident that led players with the powerful A.C. Milan club to abandon a soccer match this week, taking a strong stand in a country where racist episodes in sporting events are generally underplayed.

title: Messages Are in Dispute in Liu Fundraising Case
description: On July 10, 2011, Jia Hou, the treasurer for the presumptive mayoral campaign of John C. Liu, the city comptroller, warned a colleague that auditors would closely scrutinize donor forms.

title: Texans Schaub Looks to Reassert Himself
description: HOUSTON  The Texans offensive linemen roared through the locker room on Segways, scattering the crowd as they headed to their stalls. They began tinkering with their new toys  Christmas gifts from Arian Foster  and quizzing one another on agility, balance and simply staying upright on the two-wheel devices.

title: Bill Cunningham | Coat of Arms
description: The fashion spotlight has shifted from women to men. The difference is, there is no shouting.

title: For Womans Poetry, an Unending List of Struggles to Draw From
description: The first time Natasha Charron performed at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe on the Lower East Side, she read a passage from her diary. It told of her experience with homelessness in New York City.

title: Estelle Cooper, Park Chief Accused of Theft, Dies at 82
description: Estelle Cooper, the former top administrator of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens who retired last January amid accusations that she had stolen more than $50,000 meant for the park from a nonprofit group she founded, died on Dec. 29 in Stony Brook, N.Y. She was 82.

title: William Rees-Mogg, Ex-Editor of The Times of London, Dies at 84
description: LONDON  William Rees-Mogg, the longtime editor of The Times of London and one of Britains most respected, if mercurial, conservative voices, who rose to the defense of Richard M. Nixon as well as the Rolling Stones, died here on Dec. 29. He was 84.

title: Pregnancy Centers Gain Influence in Anti-Abortion Arena
description: WACO, Tex.  With free pregnancy tests and ultrasounds, along with diapers, parenting classes and even temporary housing, pregnancy centers are playing an increasingly influential role in the anti-abortion movement. While most attention has focused on scores of new state laws restricting abortion, the centers have been growing in numbers and gaining state financing and support.

title: In No Rush to Leave Sabans Shadow
