title: Alexander Leaf Dies at 92; Linked Diet and Health
description: Alexander Leaf, a versatile physician and research scientist who was an early advocate of diet and exercise to prevent heart disease, and who traveled the world to make important discoveries about increasing human longevity and to help scientifically establish the dangers global warming poses to the human species, died on Dec. 24 in Boston. He was 92.

title: Plan to End Methadone Use at Albuquerque Jail Prompts Alarm
description: ALBUQUERQUE  It has been almost four decades since Betty Jo Lopez started using heroin.

title: Poignant Day for the Face of a Franchise
description: BALTIMORE  The number 52 blinked on the video board Sunday as linebacker Ray Lewis was sent onto the field to be part of the Baltimore Ravens victory formation. The number remained there long after a triumphant lap around M&T Bank Stadium.

title: What the Fight Over Guns Is Really About
Madoff Aside, Financial Fraud Defies Policing
description: LOS ANGELES  To Philip Horn, the Braemar Country Club was not just a golf course, it was an extension of his office. Most weeks, Mr. Horn, a financial adviser at Wells Fargo, chatted up potential clients between holes at the upscale club set against the backdrop of the Santa Monica Mountains.

title: Lynch Atones for Fumble With Decisive Touchdown
description: LANDOVER, Md.  Marshawn Lynch was the N.F.L.s third-leading rusher this season, but he was only a shade more than an afterthought in the frenzied weeklong buildup to Sundays N.F.C. wild-card game at FedEx Field between the Seattle Seahawks and the Washington Redskins.

title: Drilling Far From Imminent, but Debate Roils a Region
description: ONEONTA, N.Y.  If Otsego County were Hollywood, then its debate over hydraulic fracturing, the contentious method of drilling for natural gas, would be resolved as it is in the movie Promised Land, which opened here over the weekend at the Southside Mall. That is, a good-looking representative of a villainous gas company would dupe the townspeople into selling him their mineral rights, only to repent after deciding that his employer was bad and fracking, as it is known, potentially worse. And this would win him the heart of the prettiest teacher at the local elementary school.

title: After Pinpointing Gun Owners, Paper Is a Target
description: WHITE PLAINS  Local newspapers across the country look for stories that will bring them national attention, but The Journal News, a daily nestled in a wooded office park in a suburb north of New York, may have gotten more than it bargained for.

title: Students Rush to Web Classes, but Profits May Be Much Later
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  In August, four months after Daphne Koller and Andrew Ng started the online education company Coursera, its free college courses had drawn in a million users, a faster launching than either Facebook or Twitter.

title: Critics of Google Antitrust Ruling Fault the Focus
description: WASHINGTON  One of the more surprising conclusions drawn by the Federal Trade Commission when it dropped its nearly two-year antitrust investigation into Google last week was that Google, far from harming consumers, had actually helped them.

title: Providing a Template to Challenge Apple
description: TAIPEI  In the China smartphone market, Apple has seen better days.

title: Online Learning, en Masse
description: More top colleges are offering free massive open online courses, but companies and universities still need to figure out a way to monetize them.

title: Steroid Era Suspicions Have Unfairly Tainted All
description: I hope what you read here is wrong, as misguided as my prediction last spring that the Miami Marlins would win the National League pennant. When I look at the Hall of Fame ballot, I see at least a dozen players who ought to have plaques in Cooperstown. But I do not believe the writers will elect any candidates when the voting is revealed Wednesday.

title: Major Companies Push the Limits of a Tax Break
description: It began more than 90 years ago as a small tax break intended to help family farmers who wanted to swap horses and land. Farmers who sold property, livestock or equipment were allowed to avoid paying capital gains taxes, as long as they used the proceeds to replace or upgrade their assets.

title: The Early Word: Vetting
description: Todays Times

title: Having Faced Down Insecurities, Quarterbacks Will Meet With a Title on the Line
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  For a weeklong trip, Alabama quarterback A J McCarron packed 30 pairs of shoes, too many bow ties to remember, and enough hair gel to share. Some men may have been embarrassed to admit so.

title: Lottery Numbers
Judge Calls for Revision of $20 Million Payout in Bank of America Suit
description: Two pension funds that agreed to a relatively small settlement with the directors of Bank of America over its acquisition of Merrill Lynch are being ordered by a federal judge to strike a better deal beginning on Monday.

title: Sports Replay: Jan. 6
description: A view of the day in sports, including N.F.L. playoff action in Baltimore and Landover, Md., and bull riding at Madison Square Garden.

title: Ignoring Limitations and Aiming to Inspire
description: Otis Hampton once walked 40 blocks in Manhattan, and swelled with pride when he reached his destination.

title: Investor in Movie Soundtracks Buys a Record Label
description: LOS ANGELES  Some significant players in the usually quiet movie soundtrack business are about to turn up the volume.

title: City Prepares for a Strike, Maybe This Week, by School Bus Drivers
description: The possibility of a strike by New York Citys school bus drivers inched closer on Sunday, with the schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, detailing contingency plans for the 152,000 public and private students who could be affected, as, steps away, hundreds of bus drivers, union leaders and parents noisily protested the loss of job security in new contracts.

title: Talks on Teacher Evaluations Disintegrate as Deadline Looms
description: New York City and its teachers union are stuck in their negotiations over a new teacher evaluation system, jeopardizing $450 million in state aid if they have not reached a deal in less than two weeks.

title: Storm Panel Recommends Major Changes in New York
description: A new commission formed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, charged with figuring out how New York should adapt in the long term to cope with worsening storms amid climate change and population growth, has recommended an extensive menu of programs: it includes turning some of the states industrial shoreline back into oyster beds, hardening the electric and natural gas systems, and improving the scope and availability of insurance coverage, according to a draft version obtained by The New York Times.

title: No Corrections: January 7, 2013
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR In the eighth edition of The Bachelorette Emily Maynard called Sean Lowe the perfect man then eliminated him before the finale. Now the tables are turned as Sean, a Dallas businessman and former Kansas State football player, searches for his own version of the perfect woman from among 26 bachelorettes. But first he receives advice from the racecar driver Arie Luyendyk Jr., another of Ms. Maynards jilted lovers. Chris Harrison (above right, with Mr. Lowe) hosts.

title: Teachers Irate as Bloomberg Likens Union to the N.R.A.
description: Of all the polarizing things Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said and done over the years, from banning large sugary drinks to supporting congestion pricing, few have generated the sort of viral backlash that has unexpectedly mounted after his weekly radio show on Friday.

title: 11 States Get Failing Grades on Public School Policies From Advocacy Group
description: In just a few short years, state legislatures and education agencies across the country have sought to transform American public education by passing a series of laws and policies overhauling teacher tenure, introducing the use of standardized test scores in performance evaluations and expanding charter schools.

title: At Disney Parks, a Bracelet Meant to Build Loyalty (and Sales)
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Imagine Walt Disney World with no entry turnstiles. Cash? Pass: Visitors would wear rubber bracelets encoded with credit card information, snapping up corn dogs and Mickey Mouse ears with a tap of the wrist. Smartphone alerts would signal when it is time to ride Space Mountain without standing in line.

title: Word of the Day | accessory
description: accessory \ik-se-s-re, ak-, ek-, -ses-re\ noun and adjective

title: The Secret Soothsayer Behind Notre Dames Revival
description: Football is not always on the minds of Notre Dame students  especially on a dead Saturday in late February after a disappointing season. Such was the case when Scotch Henderson moseyed into my grungy dorm room. Half asleep and half hypnotized by a terrifying local commercial, I barely noticed him join me on the broken, taco-shaped futon. The glaze that fell over our eyes while watching bad TV was interruptedonly when he noticed a sock sticking to the side of the wall. That is when we realized we needed to get out  fast. But where to go? We would beeither catching the tail ends of parties or going to bed at a time that seemed more fitting for a nursing home than a college dormitory.

title: Draft of the NYS 2100 Commission Report
description: An early draft of a study with recommendations on how New York should adapt in the long term to cope with worsening storms amid climate change and population growth.

title: Indias Rape and Sexual Assault Laws Under Scrutiny
description: The death of a young rape victim in from Delhi has reopened a debate in India about the countrys sexual assault and rape laws, as sweeping changes are being demanded to improve womens rights in the country.

title: Will 2013 Be the Year of the Electric Car?
description: The Hague Last year was a good one for electric and plug-in hybrid cars, according to 2012 sales figures and experts.

title: For New York, From Paris, With Love
description: Dear Diary:

title: News Quiz | January 7, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Calls for Press Freedom in Chinas South
description: BEIJING  Something remarkable was under way in southern China on Monday: an open revolt at one of the countrys biggest and most popular news groups against the propaganda authorities, who apparently censored an outspoken New Years greeting in a major newspaper calling for constitutionalism and greater rights in China.

title: IHT Quick Read, Jan. 7
description: NEWS Sounding defiant, confident and, to critics, out of touch, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Sunday used his first public address in six months to justify his crackdown, rally his supporters and leave recent efforts toward a political resolution of the civil war in tatters. Anne Barnard reports from Beirut.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 7, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article In a New Era of Insider Trading, Its Risk vs. Reward Squared.

title: N.H.L. Lockout Nears Its End
description: In N.H.L. and Players Union Reach Tentative Agreement to End Lockout, Jeff Z. Klein reports on Sundays developments.

title: What Will People Wear at Costume Parties Celebrating the 2000s?
description: Suppose you were invited to a costume party that required all guests to dress in the style of a previous era. There you would likely see someone dressed like a disco dancer of the 70s, a hair band enthusiast from the 80s, or a flannel-and-Dr. Martens grunge rocker straight out of the 90s.

title: Real Faces, Real People, Real Love in Vietnam
description: Maika Elan didnt know what to expect two years ago when she knocked on doors at a popular hotel for gay and lesbian couples in Siem Riep, Cambodia. She was surprised when most of the guests  many of whom were foreigners  told her she was welcome to take their portraits.

title: American Group Begins Private Trip to North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Bill Richardson, the former governor of New Mexico, led a private delegation including Eric Schmidt, Googles executive chairman, to North Korea on Monday, a controversial trip to a country that is among the most hostile to the Internet.

title: Why Chip Kelly May Be Waiting for Belichick to Retire
description: John Canzano of The Oregonian has an intriguing theory on why Oregon Coach Chip Kelly might have turned down N.F.L. offers, and it doesnt involve Phil Knights Nike millions (although that couldnt have hurt).

title: Russian Holiday
description: MOSCOW  The first week of January is always a week out of time and space in Russia: all business shuts down, many people flee to more temperate climes, and those who remain, drink, eat and then drink some more. A few days into the year, the haze of smoke, alcohol and overindulgence makes it difficult to distinguish between truth and fact, reality and a fever dream.

title: January College Checklist for Seniors
description: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselors Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

description: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first eight paragraphs of the article Trendy Spot Urges Tourists to Ride In and Spend, Gangnam Style by Martin Fackler.

title: German Property Firm Backed by Goldman Plans I.P.O.
description: LONDON  A German property company owned by the Goldman Sachs investment fund Whitehall announced on Monday that it was planning an initial public offering, one of the first new listings in Europe this year.

title: Disbelief in Bihar Village of Man Accused in the Delhi Rape Case
description: AURANGABAD, Bihar  The family of Akshay Thakur, one of the six accused in the Delhi gang rape case, first learned about the incident and the nationwide protests it has inspired when local police officers came to their house looking for him.

description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

description: Update: Jan. 8, 2012

title: Indian Judge Bans Reporting on Trial of 5 Men in Gang Rape Case
description: NEW DELHI  A judge on Monday banned reporting on the New Delhi trial of a gang rape case that has attracted worldwide attention, responding to a chaotic courtroom crammed with members of the news media and a large number of female lawyers who said no one should represent the accused.

title: Foreclosure Settlement Said to Be Imminent
description: After weeks of negotiations, a $10 billion settlement over claims of foreclosure abuses by 14 banks is expected to be announced as early as Monday. The deal covers abuses like flawed paperwork and botched loan modifications, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in The New York Times, citing several people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: Two Custom-Publishing Powerhouses Join Forces
description: Two companies that are leaders in the custom publishing industry  producing publications at the behest of marketers  are being combined under the aegis of a New York-based private equity firm.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: A Digital Kingdom and the Future of TVs
description: Walt Disney World plans to begin introducing a vacation management system called MyMagic+ in the coming months that will drastically change the way Disney World visitors  some 30 million people a year  do just about everything. Visitors will wear rubber bracelets encoded with credit card information allowing them to buy everything from corn dogs to Mickey Mouse ears with a tap of the wrist. Smartphone alerts will signal when it is time to ride Space Mountain without standing in line. The ambitious plan, as Brooks Barnes reports, moves Disney deeper into the hotly debated terrain of personal data collection. Like most major companies, Disney wants to have as much information about its customers preferences as it can get, so it can appeal to them more efficiently. The company already collects data to use in future sales campaigns, but parts of MyMagic+ will allow Disney to track guest behavior in minute detail for the first time.

title: Choice to Lead C.I.A. Faces a Changed Agency
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas nomination on Monday of John O. Brennan as director of the Central Intelligence Agency puts one of his closest and most powerful aides in charge of an agency that has been transformed by more than a decade of secret wars.

title: Opinion Report: Tax Reform
description: From the editorial page

title: Monday Reading: Drowsy Drivers Pose Major Risks
Pain and Suffering for Griffin and Shanahan
description: Why did Redskins Coach Mike Shanahan keep quarterback Robert Griffin III in the game on Sunday against Seattle when he could see that Griffin was not close to 100 percent?

title: In Deal, Bank of America Extends Retreat From Mortgages
description: 9:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Protest Grows Over Censoring of China Paper
description: BEIJING  Hundreds of people gathered outside the headquarters of a newspaper company in southern China on Monday, intensifying a battle over media censorship that poses a test of the willingness of Chinas new leadership to tolerate calls for change.

title: Looking Ahead to Jets News Conference Tuesday
description: It may not seem like it, but it has been only a week since the Jets finished 6-10, gave General Manager Mike Tannenbaum his walking papers and abruptly postponed their postseason news conference.

title: France Rejects Plan by Internet Provider to Block Online Ads
description: PARIS  In a potential test case for Europe, the French government on Monday ordered a big Internet service provider to stop blocking online advertisements, saying the company had no right to edit the contents of the Web for users.

title: Court in Bahrain Confirms Jail Terms for 13 Dissidents
description: CAIRO  A court in Bahrain on Monday upheld prison sentences for 13 of the countrys most prominent dissidents, in a decision that government opponents offered as evidence that the monarchy was ignoring calls to negotiate a political solution that could quiet a nearly two-year-old uprising.

title: The Outside Man
description: Yes, Ive heard about the notion that I should be nominated as Treasury Secretary. Im flattered, but it really is a bad idea.

title: Be Ready To Mint That Coin
description: Should President Obama be willing to print a $1 trillion platinum coin if Republicans try to force America into default? Yes, absolutely. He will, after all, be faced with a choice between two alternatives: one thats silly but benign, the other thats equally silly but both vile and disastrous. The decision should be obvious.

title: Daily Report: Making Screens That Will Stand Out at C.E.S.
description: Almost every major electronic device you own is a black rectangle that is brought to life by software and content. So how can hardware companies make their products stand out in a sea of black rectangles?

title: Citigroup Names Co-Presidents
description: Citigroup announced a management reshuffle on Monday, appointing Jamie Forese and Manuel Medina-Mora as co-presidents of the bank in the latest move to steer the sprawling bank toward greater profitability.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Jan. 7
description: This is a dark, dark tunnel. There is no good ending to this. Assad believes he is winning.

title: Topman
description: The Topman collection was among the first shown at London Mens Fashion Week.

title: ONeill Theater Center Honors Christopher Plummer
description: The Eugene ONeill Theater Center announced on Monday that Christopher Plummer would receive its 13th Monte Cristo Award in recognition of his theater career, which includes two Tony-winning performances on Broadway  in the 1997 play Barrymore and in the 1973 musical Cyrano. Mr. Plummer, 83, also won the Academy Award for best supporting actor last year for the film Beginners.

title: Hobbled on Energy, India Ponders a Multitude of Dams
description: As we noted here last week, over 600 million people lost power in India last summer, setting a modern record for the number of people affected by a blackout. Well before that, though, Indias government was grappling with growing pressure to increase the dependability of its electricity service  for the growing numbers who have intermittent power and the 400 million who live without it.

title: Topman: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: Richard Gere Just Wants the Best Honor Possible
description: The screwy schedule this Oscar season meant that the Palm Springs International Film Festival awards gala, usually a reliable place to read some tea leaves because the ceremony is stocked with Academy members, was held after Oscar voting already ended. Still, Oscarologists took note of who got love and who didnt, and which speeches killed and which needed some burnishing at the event, held on Saturday and attended by many prospective Oscar players (from Argo, Les Misrables, Silver Linings Playbook and Lincoln, among others).

title: The Benefits of Uncertainty
description: When people argue that uncertainty about taxation and regulation is freezing corporate decision-making, they are generally arguing that more certainty would be a good thing for the economy. The idea, deemed so self-evident that it sometimes is left unspoken, is that corporations are hesitating to invest in the United States.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Washington Post: In Saigon, Vietnams first Starbucks will have to compete with popular local chains for the coffee market.  Julia Moskin

title: Illumina Buys Maker of Down Syndrome Test
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Illumina, the leading manufacturer of DNA sequencing machines, said on Monday that it would buy the privately held Verinata Health for at least $350 million in cash to expand its push into the diagnostics business.

title: Supreme Court to Decide on Texans Bid for Oklahomas Water
description: It was largely overlooked last year when Fort Worth, now boasting a population of 758,000, moved closer to overtaking San Francisco in population. Yet in some ways, the Texas citys early-21st-century growth spurt recalls the issues that San Francisco faced a century ago: if Fort Worth doesnt get more water, its opportunities for growth will diminish rapidly.

title: Investing: Money Plus (Lots of) Time Equals Excitement
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Joel Lovell on the Short-Story Genius George Saunders
description: Joel Lovell, deputy editor at The Times Magazine, wrote this weeks cover story about the writer George Saunders. He last wrote for the magazine about the playwright Kenneth Lonergan.

title: On Savile Row | A Tale of Two Tailors
description: When I was a young man and finally got a teaching job and some money of my own I was determined to have a Savile Row suit. (The Porsche speedster, Purdy shotgun, Renoir etching or a first edition of Popes Homer were still all beyond my ken.) I had seen all the films of Fred Astaire, Gary Cooper and Cary Grant, and the print media had been enamored by the Duke of Windsor  the most photographed man of his time  and the other elegant habitus of the Row long enough.

title: At Hearing, Police Recall Details of Horror at Colorado Movie Theater
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  The movie theater was a blood-soaked nightmare that night in July. Wounded moviegoers screamed for help and tried to crawl for the exits. Bodies lay in the aisles. The floor was a carpet of shell casings, the air stung with the smell of tear gas, and dozens of abandoned cellphones bleated incessantly.

title: Troubled Oil Rig in Alaska Reaches Safer Waters
description: A week after it ran aground along a rocky shoreline in the Gulf of Alaska, a Shell Oil drilling rig was refloated and towed to safer water for inspection, officials said Monday.

title: Ford Announces In-Car Voice Commands for Amazons Cloud Music
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Ford and Amazon will announce on Monday afternoon a new music storage system that joins the automakers Sync AppLink with the Amazon Cloud Player to enable in-vehicle voice commands. While that sounds techie, in fact it points to a safe way forward to permanently replacing CDs as a way of listening music in the car.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 7
A Cynical Writer-Director Goes for an Emotional Ride
description: Though he may be a long shot as an Oscar contender, the writer-director Ben Lewin, who made The Sessions, is a favorite of the Bagger for his uncommon directness and emotional candor. Mr. Lewin wrote the screenplay for the film, about the polio-stricken writer Mark OBrien, after reading his account of trying to lose his virginity while being mostly confined to an iron lung. (OBrien, a poet who lived in Berkeley, Calif., died in 1999.) John Hawkes, who endured weeks of discomfort and damage to his spine to play OBrien, and Helen Hunt, as the sex surrogate he hires, are both nominated for Golden Globes and Critics Choice awards, to be handed out this week.

title: Think Twice About That N.F.L. Job
description: As college footballs national championship game gets ready to kick off Monday night, you will hear ad nauseam about the two coaches, including why they will, or wont, and should, or shouldnt, parlay their big moment into a stab at an N.F.L. job  and in Nick Sabans case another stab at an N.F.L. job, even though he may still be bleeding from the last one. But if Saban or Notre Dames Brian Kelly needs any further confirmation of why this is a bad idea  and they shouldnt: even Chip Kelly is apparently choosing an N.C.A.A. gangplank at Oregon instead of an N.F.L. job  they need only to have watched Sunday nights fiasco involving Redskins Coach Mike Shanahan and the latest, most egregious example of how N.F.L. coaching makes you lose your mind.

title: Wrong-Way Escalator Hurts 5 in PATH Station
description: A very long escalator at the Exchange Place PATH station in Jersey City lurched into reverse direction during rush hour Monday, injuring five commuters, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Moral Obligation Coupons
description: Dont like the platinum coin option? Heres a functionally equivalent alternative: have the Treasury sell pieces of paper labeled moral obligation coupons, which declare the intention of the government to redeem these coupons at face value in one year.

title: China Says It Will Overhaul Sprawling System of Re-education Through Labor
description: BEIJING  China will start overhauling its draconian system of re-education through labor in the coming year, according to the state news media, signaling the incoming leaderships determination to alter one of the governments more widely despised cudgels for punishing petty criminals, religious dissidents, petitioners and other perceived social irritants.

title: A Marquee B.C.S. Matchup? To Be Determined
description: Mondays Bowl Championship Series title game is attracting a significant amount of attention from fans and the news media. Google searches for the terms BCS Championship Game and BCS Title Game are on pace to be about twice as high as they were last year. Senior executives at ESPN, which will televise the game, are openly speculating that the contest could challenge ratings records  perhaps matching the mark set in 2006, when the game between Texas and U.S.C. attracted a 21.7 Nielsen rating.

title: Hagel on Key Issues
description: Chuck Hagel, a Republican from Nebraska, was elected to the Senate in 1996 and retired in 2008. Following are some of his recent statements on issues he is likely to confront if he is confirmed as secretary of defense.

title: Klemens von Klemperer Dies at 96; Wrote of Nazi Era
description: Klemens von Klemperer, a refugee from Nazi Germany who wrote what is widely considered the seminal history of the movement among the countrys conservative elite to overthrow Hitler, died on Dec. 23 at his home in Easthampton, Mass. He was 96.

title: Standing Out Among Post-Holiday Real Estate Listings
description: Between in-laws and layovers, big meals and fat credit card statements, few people want to go shopping for a home during the holidays. So every year, right around New Years, the New York City real estate market receives a little jolt as listings that stood primping on the sidelines through December burst onto the scene, shoving their best face forward.

title: Hanging On in Chicago
description: Robert Sampson, a Harvard sociologist, talks about the resilience of Chatham, a neighborhood on Chicagos south side.

title: Hanging On in Chicago, Not Your Old Globe, and Black Death, Revisited
description: This week: A new series on how a neighborhoods character can determine its economic future, a classroom staple gets a digital makeover and two survivors of the Bubonic plague look back.

title: N.H.L. Camps May Not Open Until Saturday
description: In the initial euphoria after the N.H.L. and its players association reached a tentative deal to end the lockout early Sunday morning, league officials said that training camps could open as early as Wednesday. That has turned out to be overly optimistic.

title: The Trapezoidal Number Puzzle
description: We often think of math as being rather dry. Memorizing formulas. Calculating things. A race to a single right answer.

title: Keeping Guns Away From Children
description: I doubt that our forebears who ratified the Second Amendment in 1791 ever imagined how carelessly and callously firearms would be used centuries later. Witness the senseless slaughter of 20 innocent children and 6 adults last month in Newtown, Conn. As a mother of two and grandmother of four, I cant imagine a more painful loss.

title: Lawyers Stumble, and Clients Take Fall
description: WASHINGTON  Twice in recent years, the Supreme Court rebuked the federal appeals court in Atlanta for its rigid attitude toward filing deadlines in capital cases. The appeals court does not seem to be listening.

title: Street Style: Winter Florals
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Dec. 31.

title: For Williams and Murray, Big Victories to Begin Season
description: Although several burgeoning talents made gains toward validating their hype, the status quo won out in the first week of the 2013 tennis calendar, with all six A.T.P. and W.T.A. tournaments being won by players ranked inside the top 10.

title: Alabama Routs Notre Dame in Title Game
description: Alabama easily defeated Notre Dame, 42-14, in the Bowl Championship Series title game.

title: S.E.C. Names New Top Lawyer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Monday that it had named Geoffrey F. Aronow to be general counsel, the agencys top legal post.

title: New Picks to Lead C.I.A. and Defense
description: The Timess Mark Landler talks about President Obamas choices of Chuck Hagel to lead the Defense Department and John O. Brennan to head the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Tweet This: Hashtag Named Word of the Year
description: The baby named Hashtag buzzed about on the Internet in November may have been a hoax. But the American Dialect Society has given the Twitter-inspired term a boost by christening hashtag the word of the year.

title: After Ticketmaster Glitch, Inaugural Ball and Parade Tickets Sell Out Early
description: WASHINGTON  All the public tickets to President Obamas official inaugural ball and parade were snapped up Sunday  a day before they were scheduled to go on sale  after Ticketmaster inadvertently sent out e-mails announcing they were available, inaugural officials said on Monday.

title: A World Without Grand Bargains
description: In my Sunday column defending John Boehners record as Speaker of the House, I make the point that for all the talk about how much more bipartisan and effective Congress used to be, there really isnt a modern historical precedent for the kind of everybody hurtsbargain on taxes and entitlements that would actually be required to bring our projected spending in line with our projected revenue. The most plausible recent example of such a bargain is the deal that George H.W. Bush struck with Congressional Democrats in 1990, which brought him so much grief and helped inspire a generation of Republican resistance to tax increases: That compromise promised to cut $500 billion from the deficit over five years, which (per my back-of-the-envelope adjustments for inflation) is the equivalent of about $2.5 trillion in deficit reduction over ten years today. $2.5 trillion isa big number  but its only slightly more than the combined deficit reduction promised by last years debt-ceiling deal and this months tax increases combined  and that combination, of course, has only put a very modest dent in our long-term deficit problem.

title: Obama Fills Top Security Posts
description: TimesCast: President Obama picks new chiefs for the C.I.A. and Defense Department. | A look at how more guns means more killing. | Peruvian village forced to make way for a giant mine.

title: The Gun-Control Agenda Takes Shape
description: One week after the Newtown shooting, the National Rifle Association came out with its usual recommendations for reducing gun violence: More guns in more places, including elementary schools.

title: Sony and BMG Are Said to Team Up on Bid for EMI
description: 7:32 p.m. | Updated Sony and BMG, onetime partners in one of the music worlds biggest mergers, are teaming up again on a bid to buy  and then divide between themselves  some of the recorded music assets of EMI, according to two people with direct knowledge of the talks between the companies.

title: Japan Is Weighing Raising Military Spending
description: TOKYO  Japans new conservative government announced a review of national military strategy on Monday that analysts said was aimed at offsetting Chinas growing military power and that may increase defense spending for the first time in a decade.

title: The Role of Profit in a Social Business
description: As I reflected on the end of 2012, I decided to write a letter to our more than a hundred employees around the world to discuss the role profits play at TerraCycle.

title: Numberplay 2012: A Year in Review
description: As we begin the new year (our puzzle for this week  a trapezoidal challenge from Joshua Zucker  is already up in a separate post), lets also pause for a moment to reflect on the adventures we had in 2012.

title: Ewan McGregor on Acting With Youngsters
description: Though Ewan McGregor is up for a Golden Globe on Sunday for his performance in Salmon Fishing in the Yemen, hes been making the rounds in support of a higher-profile film, The Impossible, the based-on-a-true-story tale of a vacationing family torn apart by a tsunami. Mr. McGregor plays the father (opposite Naomi Watts), and if he knew the adage about never working with children, he didnt acknowledge it in this talk with the Carpetbagger, in which he recounts filming a scene with the young actors  Tom Holland, Samuel Joslin and Oaklee Pendergast  who play his sons.

title: Sony Issues Dylan CDs to Extend Copyright
description: In an unusual response to provisions in a new European copyright law, scheduled to take effect by 2014, Sony Music has released a compilation of early Bob Dylan recordings that is bound to become one of his most collectible albums. The 50th Anniversary Collection, which carries a subtitle  The Copyright Extension Collection, Vol. 1  that explains its purpose, was rushed to only a handful of record shops in Germany, France, Sweden and Britain just after Christmas.

title: Taking Family Seriously in Up Series
description: On Sunday I went to see the film 56 Up. Its the latest installment of the remarkable British documentary project that in 1964 began chronicling the lives of several 7-year-olds from a variety of economic backgrounds and has re-interviewed them every seven years since.

title: The Souths Orneriest General
description: On the night of Jan. 3, 1863, Confederate Gen. Braxton Bragg began withdrawing his Army of Tennessee from the Stones River battlefield. Bragg had won an impressive tactical victory three days earlier when he attacked Gen. William Rosecranss Army of the Cumberland near Murfreesboro, Tenn., but when the Confederates renewed their attacks on Jan. 2, the tough Union soldiers had held firm.

title: Diagnosis: Battered but Vibrant
description: CHICAGO  The neighborhoods best-known restaurants were failing, its crime rate was on the rise, and for the first time that anyone could remember there were foreclosures, with once tidy bungalows sitting empty and dark.

title: Saving Chatham
description: The middle-class enclave of Chatham, on the South Side of Chicago, has struggled to remain stable through the recession. It had done so for decades, but poverty from surrounding areas is closing in.

title: Forever Free
description: Two weeks after the Union garrison at Fort Sumter, S.C., surrendered to the Confederates, the New York World predicted that if Republicans persisted in their fanatical campaign against slavery, they would provoke wide-spread negro insurrections that would spread horror across the South. The World was a Democratic newspaper, and like most Northern Democrats its editors believed that slavery had no place in a war whose sole purpose was the restoration of the Union. Democrats were demanding that Republicans answer the question, What is the object of the war? But Republicans turned the tables and demanded that Democrats answer a very different question. Shall the American Republic be destroyed or shall Slavery perish? asked Horace Greeley, the most powerful Republican editor in the country. If you asked Northerners that question, he declared, their overwhelming response would be, The Republic must live, even though Slavery should have to die!

title: Producer Dick Wolfs New Novel
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Law & Order producer releases his first novel. | The challenges of online education. | Gene Liebel, chief strategy officer of HUGE, on the impact of second-screen TV viewing.

title: In Performance: Zabryna Guevara
description: The actress performs a scene from Quiara Alegra Hudess Pulitzer Prize-winning play Water by the Spoonful.

title: Chathams Community Character
description: The community of Chatham, on Chicagos South Side, has been rocked by foreclosures, business failures and recent violence, yet social scientists predict the neighborhood will remain relatively stable.

title: Ant Study Deepens Concern About Plastic Additives
description: PARIS  About five years ago, Alain Lenoir, a researcher at Franois Rabelais University in Tours, France, was studying the biochemical process by which ants differentiate between friends and foes.

title: Maura Tierney and Courtney B. Vance Join the Cast of Lucky Guy
description: Maura Tierney and Courtney B. Vance will join Tom Hanks in the cast of Lucky Guy, the Nora Ephron play coming to Broadway this spring, the shows producers announced on Monday. A bio-drama about the New York City newspaper columnist Mike McAlary (to be played by Mr. Hanks), Lucky Guy is set to begin previews at the Broadhurst Theater on March 1, with the opening night scheduled for April 1. George C. Wolfe, a Tony Award winner for Angels in America and Bring in Da Noise, Bring in Da Funk, will direct.

title: Video Shows 4 Sought in 16-Year-Olds Killing
description: The police have released a surveillance video of four young men they describe as persons of interest in Fridays  shooting death of a 16-year-old, Raphael Ward, on the Lower East Side.

title: A New Face Takes Over for Zucker on Katie
description: Michael Morrison started work on Monday as the new executive producer of Katie, the syndicated talk show hosted by Katie Couric.

title: Really? Sugar-Free Gum Helps Prevent Cavities
description: THE FACTS

title: Freezing and Sneezing
description: Q. Why do I sneeze when I feel cold?

title: Bette Midler to Play Superagent Sue Mengers on Broadway
description: The recipe for a successful one-character play would, at minimum, seem to call for two things: a powerful person to base it upon and a powerful person to play her. And a newly announced theater project surely has both: Bette Midler will perform on Broadway for the first time in more than 30 years in a play about the Hollywood superagent Sue Mengers, its producers said on Monday. The play, called Ill Eat You Last: A Chat With Sue Mengers, is written by John Logan and will be directed by Joe Mantello. It is scheduled to open on April 24 at a Shubert theater still to be determined.

title: Walkabout  1/7: Swiping Through Disney, and Learning How to Survive Avalanches
description: Big, Magical Data In the coming months, Disney plans to introduce a vacation management system called MyMagic+ that will allow visitors to buy Mickey Mouse ears with a swipe of a rubber bracelet encoded with credit card information. (The New York Times)

title: Milk of Human Kindness Also Found in Bonobos
description: Bonobos will happily share their food with a stranger, and even give up their own meal  but only if the stranger offers them social interaction, evolutionary anthropologists at Duke University report in the journal PLoS One. The researchers, Jingzhi Tan and Brian Hare, say their findings may shed light on the origins of altruism in humans.

title: Citigroups Former Internet Analyst Finds New Home at R.B.C.
description: Mark Mahaney, the former Citigroup analyst who was fired by the bank over disclosure violations, has found a new home.

title: New Insight on Itchiness as Specific Nerve Cells Are Identified
description: Mosquito bite? Poison ivy? Dry skin? Fuzzy sweater?

title: Obama's New National Security Picks
description: President Obama nominates Chuck Hagel for secretary of defense and John O. Brennan for director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Argo Leads a Round of Critics Awards
description: The team behind Argo may be celebrating today, or they may be wondering, what next? (Or possibly both.) Ben Afflecks comedic thriller took home the top trophy from the Online Film Critics Society, which announced its prizes today. Chris Terrios screenplay also won.

title: Hold the Butter
description: IF Emmanuel Verstraetens dream comes true, something different will happen when you open a restaurant menu.

title: Obama Nominates Hagel as Defense Secretary and Brennan as C.I.A. Chief
description: WASHINGTON  Risking a potentially rancorous battle with Congress at the start of his second term, President Obama on Monday nominated Chuck Hagel, a former Republican senator from Nebraska whom Mr. Obama hailed as the leader that our troops deserve, to be secretary of defense.

title: Video of Chinese Censorship Protest
description: As my colleague Edward Wong reports, hundreds of protesters gathered outside the headquarters of a newspaper office in southern China on Monday to register their anger at the censorship of a recent editorial.

title: Texas Track Coach Resigns After Admitting 10-Year-Old Affair
description: On one hand, the story of Bev Kearney, the longtime womens track and field coach at the University of Texas, sounds just like the disappointing stories about a lot of coaches. She was found to have had an affair with a student and was pressured to resign by the school, which she did on Saturday.

title: Stolen Matisse to Be Returned to Swedish Museum
description: Twenty-five years ago, a burglar smashed his way into Stockholms Museum of Modern Art and took a Matisse oil painting called Le Jardin. Now the work, valued at $1 million, has been recovered and will be returned to the museum.

title: The View From Notre Dame: For Farley, a New Look and New Success
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Matthias Farley bears little resemblance to the player he was in 2011, and its not just because of a position switch he made last spring from receiver to safety.

title: Social Security Benefits Verification Letters Now Online
description: Social Security recipients can now get their benefits verification letter and conduct other business online, as part of enhanced Web services introduced Monday by the federal government.

title: Look of The Moment | Sarah Jessica Parker
description: The Look: Moto Mama. A leather biker jacket accented by matching mini-mes does it all.

title: Poachers Kill 11 Elephants in Kenyan Park
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Eleven elephants were slaughtered by ivory poachers and their tusks were chopped off, Kenyan officials said Monday, in one of the worst single episodes of poaching in Kenya in recent years.

title: Lose Weight for Your Country
description: Last week there was a lot of fanfare over a new study showing that overweight people have less risk of dying than people of normal weight. Lovers of butter cookies and Popeyes the world over surely rejoiced at the news. But at the annual meeting of the American Economic Association over the weekend in San Diego, health economists I spoke with expressed dismay over the studys fiscal implications.

title: Missoni Family Keeps Anxious Watch
description: The search for the missing aircraft carrying Vittorio Missoni continued off the coast of Venezuela for a fourth day on Monday. In the absence of any sign of wreckage, members of the Missoni family said they were exploring other possibilities of what might have happened.

title: Goal-Line Stands Shaped Notre Dame Season
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Two series. Those are what defined Notre Dames defense in this season of resurgence, as the Irish fought to an undefeated regular season and the Bowl Championship Series national title game against Alabama on Monday night.

title: The Financial Crisis in the Courts
description: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business.

title: Hobbit Leads Visual Effects Societys List
description: Evidently the experts at the Visual Effects Society could handle the rate of 48 frames per second: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey topped the list of the societys nominations today, with seven, followed by six each for Life of Pi and The Avengers (which led last years box office overall). Ang Lee, the director of Life of Pi, will also receive an honorary prize, the visionary award.

title: The Impact of Second Screen TV Viewing
description: Gene Liebel, chief strategy officer of HUGE and one of the creators of HBO GO, on how companion devices are changing TV viewing habits.

title: Canceled ABC Soaps to be Reborn on the Web
description: 3:55 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES  After some classic soap opera twists  union spats, outraged fans, squishy financing  a Hollywood production company, Prospect Park, on Monday confirmed that the canceled All My Children and One Life to Live would live on in cyberspace. For real this time.

title: Asking Hedge Funds to Turn Themselves In
description: Hedge funds had long operated under the regulatory radar, with few reporting obligations and a well-deserved reputation for secrecy. Now, the government is weighing whether to require them to report any suspicious transactions, like insider information or manipulation of stock prices.

title: How Much Are Americans Willing to Spend to Defend Europe?
description: BERLIN  At the end of this month, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, the NATO secretary general, will release new figures on defense spending by the 28 Alliance members.

title: With Deal Nearly Done, Apologies Begin
description: After locking out their players for nearly four months, the N.H.L. and its owners have wasted no time apologizing to fans.

title: Reliving Nightmare of Plague, 10 Years On
description: It was November 2002, little more than a year after planes had been flown into the World Trade Center and anthrax mailings had killed five Americans. New York City was still on edge, in a state of high alert for suspected terrorists.

title: Motherlode in 2013
description: A question for readers: What would you like to see more of on Motherlode as we head through 2013?

title: Plague Test Shows Promise
description: Around the world, up to 2,000 cases of plague are still reported to the World Health Organization every year, and the ancient disease remains a fearsome threat in many countries, especially in Africa. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently developed a quick test to help diagnose plague that has shown promising results.

title: Brennan on Key Issues
description: John O. Brennan was the top counterterrorism adviser during President Obamas first term. He became one of the presidents most trusted advisers. Here are some of his statements on key issues.

title: Media Company Taps N.F.L. Executive as President
description: BermanBraun, a fast-growing digital media/television/movie company, just scored a touchdown: Jeff Berman, a respected executive at the National Football League, will become the entertainment companys first president.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Lebanon, Bahrain and India.

title: Antidepressants Not Linked to Stillbirths
description: A mothers use of antidepressants like Prozac and other selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.s, during pregnancy does not increase the risk of stillbirth or infant mortality, a large study has found.

title: The Inspiration Behind This by That
description: We call the minicolumn This by That,the postage-stamp-size chart I compile weekly for the One Page Magazine, because its just that simple. (It was also the subject line of my first pitch list.) That isnt to say Im not stumpedsometimes. (Im always open to challenges. Please tweet @MarnieHanel to throw down.) Other times, I cant turn off the rubric. This week I opened my refrigerator and thought, Leftovers by Dinner Permutations. But no one wants to read that.

title: Sharing Psychiatric Records Helps Care
description: Sharing psychiatric records is a delicate issue, but according to a new study, keeping them secret from other doctors, or separating them from other electronic medical records, can result in poorer care.

title: Sciences Debt to Kant
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions and Answers (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Turn Down the Volume
description: To the Editor:

title: David Lee and the Warriors Resurgence
description: Now that about 40 percent of the season has passed, weve reached a point where unexpected successes cannot be easily dismissed. One such rising team is the Golden State Warriors, who, despite missing center Andrew Bogut for all but four games, have a 22-11 record, good for fifth in the highly competitive Western Conference.

title: A Start-Up Clips the Web but Doesnt Broadcast It
description: Gary Flake believes that a lot of people who share images and other content through social networking services are mostly performing, cultivating artificial online versions of themselves aimed at impressing others.

title: A Justified Incentive, or an Unfortunate Loophole?
description: Section 1031 of the tax code allows companies to avoid paying capital gains tax when selling their assets.

title: Photos of The Moment | Topman
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Ex-Prime Minister Joins Coalition for Italys Next Election
description: ROME  After weeks of wrangling, two barons of Italys political center-right  former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi and Roberto Maroni of the Northern League  said Monday that they would join forces for the countrys national and regional elections next month and that neither man would be prime minister if their alliance won.

title: The Numbers: Can Durant Join the 40-50-90 Club?
description: An occasional look at N.B.A. statistics and the players behind them.

title: Cold Spell Hits Broadway Box Office
description: After a record-setting week for several Broadway shows between Christmas and New Years Eve, the traditional post-holiday blues hit the theater district on Sunday, with five productions closing  including two, the musical Chaplin and the play Dead Accounts, that had particularly struggled to sell tickets. Producers often shutter shows right after the new year, when the profitable holiday season gives way to the reliably coldest months  January and February  on the Broadway calendar.

title: Sealed Under Turkish Mud, a Well-Preserved Byzantine Chapel
description: DEMRE, Turkey  In the fourth century A.D., a bishop named Nicholas transformed the city of Myra, on the Mediterranean coast of what is now Turkey, into a Christian capital.

title: When 4 Hours of Layover Time Isnt Enough
Creating a Dish, Not Just Reheating One
description: ALLOW me to introduce you to your microwave. I met mine just the other week.

title: Coming Soon to Online Streaming: Led Zeppelin
description: In the 1960s and 70s, Led Zeppelins tough negotiations with record companies and concert promoters helped transform the music industry. Now the band is poised to make a change to the industrys latest hot sector: online subscription services.

title: Marrone Nabs Unlikely Seat in Coaching Musical Chairs
description: It is no stretch to say this years coaching carousel has gone a little off-kilter, which was perhaps inevitable when there were seven openings at once in the N.F.L. It produced the twin curiosities of Bill OBrien being briefly in the mix after one whole season as a head coach at Penn State and Oregons Chip Kelly making the interview rounds before reportedly retreating back to the land of the Ducks, where N.C.A.A. troubles may or may not await him. And the college-coach craze may continue with either Alabamas Nick Saban or Notre Dames Brian Kelly after the B.C.S. title game Monday night.

title: Baby Recognizes Mothers Accent
description: Researcher video shows how an infant may recognize his mothers accent.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Game Wreckers and a Changing C.E.S.
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Deficits Forever?
description: Okay, smart guy, I can imagine a reader of the preceding post saying, youve just explained why you dont think a grand bargain is going to resolve our fiscal dilemma any time soon. But just last week, you were explaining why the Democrats willingness to define rich upward made it seem less likely that they would be able to raise tax rates high enough to pay for the government they want, and in the same post you notedthe conservative, entitlement-reforming path to fiscal sustainability also has an air of fantasy about it. So if liberals cant win, conservatives cant win, and the two sides cant strike a deal, how are we actually going to get our fiscal house in order?

title: Growth of Health Spending Stays Low
description: WASHINGTON  National health spending climbed to $2.7 trillion in 2011, or an average of $8,700 for every person in the country, but as a share of the economy, it remained stable for the third consecutive year, the Obama administration said Monday.

title: Avis and Hertz Acquisitions Raise Questions Over Rate Trend
description: The car rental business is consolidating, with Hertzs acquisition of Dollar Thrifty in November and the Avis Budget Groups announcement last week that it planned to buy the car-sharing company Zipcar. Does this mean that consumers will have fewer options and end up paying more to rent a car?

title: Mary Poppins To Fly Off as Aladdin Lands on Broadway
description: The Broadway musical Mary Poppins will close on March 3 at the New Amsterdam Theater to make way for extensive renovations of the Disney-owned house before its expected next tenant: A musical adaptation of the companys 1992 animated film Aladdin, according to two Broadway theater executives. The two executives spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss production plans that remain confidential. A Disney spokesman did not immediately return a phone message seeking comment on Monday.

title: With Dolcetto, a Dish of Raw Beef
description: As the panel members tasted the earthy yet elegant dolcettos, we were unanimous in suggesting crudo to go alongside. And we did not mean raw fish. Carne cruda, or raw beef like steak tartare, is a classic accompaniment for dolcetto in Piedmont in Italy. As prepared in Alba, fillet of beef is hand cut and dressed with olive oil, lemon and maybe anchovies and shavings of white truffle. But the evening before the tasting, I had a different type of carne cruda, also perfect with dolcetto, at Commerce, in the West Village. Harold Moore, the chef and a partner, seared beef deckle and served thin slices, still raw in the center, over charred mushrooms, with a light salad garnish, a shot of spice and a drizzle of ponzu, a citrus-flavored soy sauce. He calls the dish toro because its similar to his preparation for seared tuna. Cant find a butcher who sells tasty beef deckle, the rib cap? A hunk of fillet will do just fine.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 7
description: A view of the day in sports, including N.H.L. teams back on the ice and a quad rally in the Peru desert.

title: File This Away: HBOs Girls Get Nail Polish
description: The Girls of the HBO series may not have men or clothes figured out yet, but at least they have their manicures squared away.

title: Hagel Is First Vietnam Veteran to Be Nominated as Defense Secretary
description: With President Obamas announcement on Monday, Chuck Hagel moved a step closer to becoming the  first Vietnam veteran  to serve as secretary of defense.

title: Mayor to Leave Panel Overseeing Delayed Berlin Airport
description: BERLIN  The seemingly endless series of delays and debacles entangling the new Berlin airport claimed its first political victim on Monday, after the projects planned opening was pushed back yet again.

title: Legalizing of Marijuana Raises Health Concerns
description: In the 60s, marijuana was a hallmark of the counterculture, along with free love, bell bottoms, long hair and bandannas. But marijuana has had the most staying power.

title: Digital Globes Offer a Dynamic Vision
description: In the main hall of the hands-on science exhibits at the Cape Town Science Center in South Africa, a lifeless, tattered globe stands under naked fluorescent bulbs, all but ignored by children passing through on school tours.

title: Reactions to the Hagel Nomination
description: President Obamas nomination of Chuck Hagel, a former Republican senator from Nebraska, for secretary of defense sets up a potentially rancorous battle with Congress at the start of his second term. Here are a few excerpts of statements released by senators and other key players in Mr. Hagels nomination:

title: On Our Radar: A Letter to President Obama
description: Dozens of environmental and health groups send a letter to President Obama asking him to firmly address the challenge of climate change in his second term. Raise your voice, they write. Elevate the issue of climate disruption and climate solutions in the public discourse. [Natural Resources Defense Council]

title: Babies Seem to Pick Up Language in Utero
description: A new study suggests that babies learn bits of their native languages even before they are born.

title: Readers Share Own Stories of Death on the Tracks
description: A front-page article last week by our colleague Matt Flegenheimer about subway operators whose trains fatally struck people drew nearly 200 comments. Some called for installing sliding barriers on the platforms, a proposal that transit officials said would be both expensive and extremely challenging, though not out of the question. Some readers wondered why trains did not simply slow down sooner, even if it meant delaying commutes.

title: Needed: More Attention to Boys Development
description: When you learn how to examine the female reproductive system in medical school, you generally work with a professional surrogate patient, and there is often a humiliating moment when you try to palpate the ovaries only to be told, in no uncertain terms, that you are way off-target. At such a moment, the male reproductive system seems quite simple and accessible.

title: Yellow Fever: China Plans to Scan Travelers From Sudan
description: In a move that underlines how many Chinese citizens now work in Africa, Chinas quarantine officials recently urged greater efforts to make sure that a yellow fever epidemic now raging in Sudan does not come back to China.

title: New Funds Help Revive a Theater in St. Paul
description: The Penumbra Theater Company in St. Paul, a leading African-American theatrical organization whose financial woes forced the cancellation of shows and the trimming of staff last year, has raised enough money to resume programming on a limited basis, Penumbra officials announced Monday.

title: The Wounds of a Nation Still Bleed
description: The Fred Voodoo referred to in the title of Amy Wilentzs impassioned but lumpy new book on Haiti, she explains, was reporters joking name for the Haitian man (or woman) in the street, at least one commonly used a few decades back in a less politically correct era. The name now represents to her foreigners attitude of condescension filled with pity, and all the stereotypes outsiders have come to attach to Haitians  as nice people, maybe, but disorganized, uneducated, untrained, corrupt and somehow under the thrall of voodoo, a religion that represented everything the white Westerner was not: exotic, African, pagan, exciting, dangerous, deep.

title: Oil Sands Industry in Canada Tied to Higher Carcinogen Level
description: OTTAWA  The development of Albertas oil sands has increased levels of cancer-causing compounds in surrounding lakes well beyond natural levels, Canadian researchers reported in a study released on Monday. And they said the contamination covered a wider area than had previously been believed.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: The Challenges of Online Education
description: Law & Order producer releases his first novel. The challenges of online education. Gene Liebel, chief strategy officer of HUGE, on the impact of second-screen TV viewing.

title: Late-Night Ratings Are Becoming a Three-Way Race
description: And Jimmy makes three.

title: Trivializing the Debt Ceiling
description: Back in the summer of 2011, the first time Republicans threatened not to raise the debt ceiling and forced a downgrade of the nations credit rating, many in the party minimized the possible consequences of their actions.

title: Keeping Score: Characteristics of a Champion
description: Carlton J. Chin, a portfolio strategist and fund manager, and Jay P. Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, the N.B.A. finals and the Super Bowl.

title: A New Dawn for a Florida Clique
description: The whole point of having a child is to love it and to nurture it and to worry about it, Courteney Coxs character, Jules, says in the second episode of the new season of Cougar Town. And eventually, if youve done your job right, the child doesnt need you anymore.

title: Pentagon Agrees to Full Discharge Pay for Gay Troops
description: Before the repeal of dont ask, dont tell in 2011, gay and lesbian service members who were forced to leave the military because of their sexual orientation were often honorably discharged. Yet they were given only half of their discharge pay.

title: Dartmouth Controversy Reflects Quandary for Endowments
description: By the numbers, the endowment at Dartmouth had a banner year. The $3.49 billion fund returned 5.8 percent for the 12 months that ended in June  the best in the Ivy League.

title: Australian Open Seedings Are Released
description: The seedings for the singles draws of the 2013 Australian Open were announced Monday, one week before the tournament is set to begin. The respective No. 1s Novak Djokovic and Victoria Azarenka are the top seeds.

title: Jays Appear to Mourn Dead Winged Comrades
description: When a Western scrub jay dies, researchers report, other jays may hold a kind of funeral  screeching over the body for as long as half an hour.

title: Tormented During a Revolution: The Stanzas Couldnt Save This Poet
description: Since 1972 the Opera Orchestra of New York has done opera in concert, scrappily but well. Unencumbered by the economics of full productions, Eve Queler, until last year the companys director, could showcase important singers showing off far corners of their repertories.

title: Messi Named FIFAs Top Player for Fourth Year in a Row
description: Lionel Messi was honored as FIFAs world player of the year Monday for a record fourth year in a row. Messi, the 25-year-old Barcelona and Argentina star, received more than 41 percent of the vote, beating his rival Cristiano Ronaldo of Real Madrid, who was second at 23.6 percent, and two of his Barcelona teammates, midfielders Andres Iniesta and Xavi.

title: African Tour Guides, From the Fuzzy to the Armored
description: Africa, the latest blockbuster from the BBC Natural History Unit, turns the dark continent bright. Sand dunes, water holes, escarpments and ancient trees are etched with the surreal clarity the BBC team has perfected in previous opuses like The Blue Planet and Planet Earth.

title: Well Before Lincoln, Enemies of Slavery
description: Abraham Lincoln drew Steven Spielbergs cinematic attention, but Lincoln was still a store clerk when William Lloyd Garrison published the first issue of the newspaper The Liberator in 1831, vowing to not retreat a single inch in his campaign to eradicate slavery.

title: Wheelies: The Changes Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: City Names 17 Schools Slated to Close
description: In what has become an annual event in the era of mayoral control of the public school system, New York City education officials said Monday that they would move to close two schools this summer and begin to phase out 15 others that they characterized as the poorest performing.

title: Ford and G.M. Battle to Win Wired Drivers
description: Automakers began rolling out heavy artillery in the infotainment war, as the Ford Motor Company and General Motors introduced on Monday at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas open platform software kits that would enable developers to create applications for use in vehicles.

title: Test Run: Evernote Food
description: Evernote has been my auxilliary brain for several years now. I use it to jot down ideas, save articles Ive read and compile research.

title: Cunningham and Johns: Rare Glimpses Into a Collaboration
description: PHILADELPHIA  The current exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, Dancing Around the Bride, on view through Jan. 21, honors five artists: Marcel Duchamp, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Robert Rauschenberg and Jasper Johns. These artists led a movement away from expressionism in art and often away from art as an artists expression of personal feelings. The exhibition shows innumerable links among them.

title: An Early, Cover Your Mouth, Flu Season
description: For all of you New Yorkers stuck at home sniffling, coughing and cowering under the bedclothes with flu (or as the citys health department prefers to put it, flu-like illness), the city has a graph to make you feel less all alone.

title: TV Roundtable: Dick Wolf
description: The producer Dick Wolf sits down with Bill Carter and Amy Chozick to talk about his new novel, The Intercept, the success of his Law & Order franchise and fighting for ratings against cable shows.

A Rise in Violent Crime

description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Oil Minister Concedes Sanctions Have Hurt Exports
description: Irans oil minister acknowledged for the first time on Monday that petroleum exports and sales had fallen by at least 40 percent over the past year, contradicting his previous denials and providing an unusual public admission that the cumulative impact of Western economic sanctions has grown more severe.

title: Nearly 8 Million Tuned to Downton Premiere
description: Preliminary ratings for the third season premiere of Downton Abbey suggest that the show has done something remarkable: catapulted PBS into the same league as commercial broadcasters like ABC and NBC, at least for a night.

title: Nate Silver on B.C.S. Championship
description: College sports editor Connor Ennis and Nate Silver of the FiveThirtyEight Blog preview the B.C.S. Championship game between Notre Dame and Alabama.

title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
description: Ada Louise Huxtable, who pioneered modern architectural criticism in the pages of The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history  and memorably scalding those that did not  died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Youth Charged With Plotting School Attack
description: ATLANTA  An Alabama teenager was charged on Monday with plotting to set off dozens of homemade bombs and grenades in an attack that the police said might have been inspired by the massacre last month in Newtown, Conn.

title: C.E.S 2013: Cisco Wants Your Video to Find You
description: In the future, the TV shows and movies you want to watch should find you  you shouldnt have to find them. And you should be able to watch them on any device.

title: T.S.A. Experiments With Behavior Screening
description: The Transportation Security Administration is taking another step back from its one-size-fits-all security screening that requires all airline passengers to remove their belts, shoes and coats at checkpoints.

title: C.E.S. 2013: Panasonics TVs Can Recognize a Face
description: Panasonics new product introductions at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas touch on what is becoming a common theme making your TV do the work of finding shows you want to watch.

title: A Gag Gift for Clinton as She Returns to State Dept.
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton got some padded protection to go along with her security entourage when she returned to work Monday.

title: I Was Wounded; My Honor Wasnt
description: THIRTY-TWO years ago, when I was 17 and living in Bombay, I was gang raped and nearly killed. Three years later, outraged at the silence and misconceptions around rape, I wrote a fiery essay under my own name describing my experience for an Indian womens magazine. It created a stir in the womens movement  and in my family  and then it quietly disappeared. Then, last week, I looked at my e-mail and there it was. As part of the outpouring of public rage after a young womans rape and death in Delhi, somebody posted the article online and it went viral. Since then, I have received a deluge of messages from people expressing their support.

title: Finding a Way to Talk About a Disquieting Condition
description: A NEW print ad by the Crohns and Colitis Foundation of America shows a closed bathroom stall, with the gap below the door revealing the enormous clown shoes of the occupant. I.B.D. is no laughing matter, says the headline.

title: Deans Condemn Vaccine Ruse Used in Bin Laden Hunt
description: The deans of the nations top public health schools sent a letter to President Obama on Monday condemning the Central Intelligence Agencys use of a vaccination campaign ruse in the hunt for Osama bin Laden. The letter was signed by deans at Columbia, Harvard, Johns Hopkins and nine other universities. The C.I.A. has admitted hiring a Pakistani doctor to give out hepatitis B vaccine, apparently in an effort to get DNA samples from the compound that it suspected was Bin Ladens hide-out. That has caused a severe backlash against vaccination in Pakistan. Nine polio vaccinators have been shot dead, and the effort to fight polio there was halted for weeks. Deaths from measles also soared in 2012, to 306 from 64 the year before. Resistance to measles vaccine in the populous Sindh province was blamed.

title: Justices Weigh Intent of a Class-Action Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court struggled on Monday to determine whether plaintiffs class-action lawyers can avoid having their cases heard in federal court by stipulating that they will seek less than the $5 million threshold set in a 2005 federal law.

title: California: Archdiocese Loses Ruling on Records
description: A Los Angeles judge ruled Monday that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles must release the names of high-ranking church officials included in some 30,000 pages of confidential records about priests accused of sexually abusing children. The decision reverses a ruling by a judge who said he worried that including the names could further embarrass the church. But in her ruling Monday, Judge Emilie H. Elias said the publics right to know how the nations largest archdiocese handled molesting charges outweighed other concerns. The records include reports of abuse, letters to the Vatican and psychiatric reports and are likely to be released in the next several weeks, lawyers said. The Los Angeles Times and The Associated Press had filed an objection to the previous ruling that all names of church employees, including Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, would be blacked out.

title: Hints of Syrian Chemical Push Set Off Global Effort to Stop It
description: WASHINGTON  In the last days of November, Israels top military commanders called the Pentagon to discuss troubling intelligence that was showing up on satellite imagery: Syrian troops appeared to be mixing chemicals at two storage sites, probably the deadly nerve gas sarin, and filling dozens of 500-pounds bombs that could be loaded on airplanes.

title: Stricker Hangs In While Cutting Back
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  On his 27th hole of the day on Monday, Steve Stricker sat in the fairway and rolled on his back like a pill bug. Stricker had waited 67 hours 25 minutes to hit the first shot of his title defense at the Tournament of Champions, but a pinched nerve on his left side was causing him so much discomfort, he was not sure he could weather 36 holes on the hilly, 7,411-yard Plantation Course.

title: Banks to Pay $8.5 Billion to Speed Up Housing Relief
description: Federal regulators on Monday reached an $8.5 billion settlement with 10 major lenders to resolve claims of foreclosure abuses, including the use of flawed paperwork and bungled loan modifications that may have led to wrongful evictions.

title: Easing of Rules for Banks Acknowledges Reality
description: When a global committee of regulators and central bankers agreed to a new set of rules for the banking system a year and a half ago, Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, told The Financial Times, Im very close to thinking the United States shouldnt be in Basel anymore. I would not have agreed to rules that are blatantly anti-American.

title: In Japan, a Painfully Slow Sweep
description: NARAHA, Japan  The decontamination crews at a deserted elementary school here are at the forefront of what Japan says is the most ambitious radiological cleanup the world has seen, one that promised to draw on cutting-edge technology from across the globe.

title: Assad Speech Leaves U.N. Leader Disappointed
description: Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, expressed dismay over a defiant speech on Sunday by President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, in which Mr. Assad justified his attempts to crush the nearly two-year-old uprising against him, ignored demands that he step down to allow for a political transition and declared that his armed opponents were foreign puppets. In a statement released on Monday, Mr. Ban said Mr. Assads speech had not contributed to a solution that could end the terrible suffering of the Syrian people. Yet there was no indication that Lakhdar Brahimi, the special Syria envoy from the United Nations and the Arab League, would abandon his efforts.

title: Russia: Orthodox Leader Presses for More Adoptions
description: The patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church used his Christmas address on Monday to encourage Russians to adopt orphans, as the country adjusts to a decision to bar Americans from adopting Russian children. The ban, which is retaliation for American legislation intended to punish Russian human rights violators, drew criticism, including from some government officials, largely because 120,000 children in Russia are awaiting adoption. How important it is that our people should gladly, with a special feeling of gratitude to God, take orphans into their families, Patriarch Kirill I said in a recorded address broadcast for Orthodox Christmas on Monday. We should not have orphans in our country, he added.

title: Weld North Takes Controlling Stake in Juice Chain
description: The juice cleanse is all the rage, even in investment circles.

title: Favoritism Is Good
description: Of the columns I have written that have been negatively received, none has been greeted with more outrage than last Marchs Two Cheers for Double Standards. The case for a single standard is familiar and easy to make. If youre in a position either to dispense rewards (a promotion, a bonus, an appointment) or level sanctions, you should do so impartially; that is, without being influenced in your decision by family membership, friendship, religious affiliation, ethnic solidarity or any of the other considerations that can skew judgment. When a comrade and someone in the other camp engage in the same behavior, your praise or blame should be independent of the personal feelings you may have for either. Dont give your friends a pass you wouldnt give to your enemies. Dont give your brother the job if someone else not related to you at all is more qualified.

title: The C.E.S. Reality Gap
description: The Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas officially begins on Tuesday, but a tension that has run through the show for the last several years was already on display Monday, as many companies held news conferences showing off their newest gadgets. In many cases, the companies were touting larger, clearer  and more expensive  televisions. On the one hand, these televisions were impressive technological achievements; on the other, it is unclear how relevant they are to the average consumer. (Brian X. Chen wrote about how the television industry is struggling with this dynamic on Monday.)

title: Trial Begins for Scotland Yard Officer in Phone-Hacking Scandal
