description: LONDON  In the first of a number of high-profile trials expected this year in cases of alleged criminal wrongdoing at Britains freewheeling newspapers, a high-ranking Scotland Yard officer went on trial on Monday, charged with seeking to sell confidential police information to a tabloid that Rupert Murdoch ordered shut 18 months ago as the phone-hacking scandal erupted around his British newspaper empire.

title: Dreaming and Driving
description: Young undocumented immigrants who are allowed to work legally in the United States should be allowed to drive legally, too. It makes perfect sense, if only for public-safety reasons: people need to drive to work, and they should follow the law and be demonstrably competent, registered and insured. But with the politics of immigration, nothing is ever that simple.

title: Mobile Apps Drive Rapid Change in Searches
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When the Federal Trade Commission decided last week to close its antitrust investigation of Google without charges, one important factor, though hardly mentioned, was just beneath the surface: the mobile revolution.

title: The Bid to Stop Gun Trafficking
description: Instructed by President Obama to find ways to curb gun violence after the Connecticut school massacre, a working group led by Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. appears ready to recommend a package of proposals that go beyond reinstating the expired ban on assault weapons and high-capacity magazines.

title: In Fending Off Critics, Obama Points to Hagel as Vietnam War Hero
description: WASHINGTON  In his effusive endorsement of Chuck Hagel as his choice for secretary of defense on Monday, President Obama set in motion a White House campaign that officials predict will overcome weeks of accusations that the Republican former senator from Nebraska is anti-Israel, antigay and soft on Iran.

title: Nominations for Defense and the C.I.A.
description: In nominating Chuck Hagel to be defense secretary and John Brennan to be director of the Central Intelligence Agency, President Obama has selected two trusted advisers who could help him set a new tone, and conceivably a new direction, on issues of war and peace in his second term. But both candidates must provide answers to serious questions before they can expect confirmation by the Senate.

title: Questions Left for Mississippi Over Doctors Autopsies
description: JACKSON, Miss.  For a long time, if a body turned up in Mississippi it had a four-in-five chance of ending up in front of Dr. Steven T. Hayne.

title: The Right or Wrong Experience for the Job?
For Each Age, Its Agonies
description: In the new movie This is 40, the writer and director Judd Apatow casts the arrival of lifes four-decade mark as a uniquely brutal crossroads, flagged by sputtering libido, suffocating commitments and curdled dreams.

title: Landlords Are Blocking Rewiring of Cable After Hurricane, Verizon Says
description: Rewiring all of Lower Manhattan with fiber-optic cable after Hurricane Sandy would be hard enough without landlords blocking the way with their palms open. But that is what Verizon alleges some are doing.

title: Why Hagel Was Picked
description: Americans dont particularly like government, but they do want government to subsidize their health care. They believe that health care spending improves their lives more than any other public good. In a Quinnipiac poll, typical of many others, Americans opposed any cuts to Medicare by a margin of 70 percent to 25 percent.

title: With Chvez Ill and State in Flux, Videos Offer an Image of Stability
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  They run around the clock on state television, highly polished videos of President Hugo Chvez hugging children, kissing grandmothers, playing baseball and reciting poetry. As supporters around the world hold up hand-lettered signs that say, I Am Chvez, the presidents voice is heard in one of them shouting, I demand absolute loyalty because I am not me, I am not an individual, I am a people!

title: Background and Appeals Cases Involving Dr. Steven T. Hayne
description: Appeals are being filed in some of the criminal cases Dr. Steven T. Hayne worked on.

title: Bloomberg Takes on the N.R.A.
description: TO: Michael Bloomberg

title: C.E.S. 2013: Samsung Wants to Evolve Your TV Each Year
description: Samsung said it is taking a new approach to selling televisions. Americans, on average, buy a new one every 6.7 years. From Samsungs point of view, that is too long. It wants you to upgrade your TV every year.

title: For Netanyahu, Being Favored to Win Carries Its Own Risks
description: TEL AVIV  Can a candidate ever be too far in the lead for his own good?

title: Where Hepburn Lived, Last Act in Legal Drama Over Posts Height
description: In the tiny borough of Fenwick, Conn., right at the mouth of the Connecticut River, there is a glamorous estate with a $30 million price tag, 8,368 square feet of interior space, and a famous former owner: Katharine Hepburn.

title: Whom G Movies Are For
description: Administrivial iPad Commentary Alert! If you are experiencing problems on your iPad when reading and commenting on Wordplay, try switching browsers temporarily. The tech crew is aware of an issue when using Safari, and is working on a fix. For the time being, please try using Chrome or any other browser, and we thank you for your patience.

title: Corrections: January 8, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Huge Amounts Spent on Immigration, Study Finds
description: The Obama administration spent nearly $18 billion on immigration enforcement last year, significantly more than its spending on all the other major federal law enforcement agencies combined, according to a report published Monday by the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

title: Cuomo Plans New Rules in Fight Against Sepsis
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will announce in his State of the State Message this week that every hospital in New York must adopt aggressive procedures for identifying sepsis in patients, including the use of a countdown clock to begin treatment within an hour of spotting it, a state official said.

title: Sharing a Number, and the Spotlight
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Manti Teo was 5, on a drive around his hometown, Laie, Hawaii, when his father turned to him and asked, Son, when you play football, what number do you want to be?

title: Chicago Faulted on Learning Disabilities
description: When Rashaan Payne was 2 years old, his pediatrician noticed that he was not talking at the level of most children his age. After autism was diagnosed, Rashaan began receiving speech therapy once a week at his home on the South Side of Chicago, paid for by the federal and state governments.

title: Still Firing Away
description: LOS ANGELES  Chicago was great for Jamal Crawfords first four N.B.A. seasons, with adoring fans and lots of shot opportunities, even if his Bulls went 89-239.

title: In Queens, Taking the High Line as a Model
description: It has been abandoned for five decades, a railway relic that once served Queens passengers on the old Rockaway Beach branch of the Long Island Rail Road. For all those years, no one paid much notice to the ghostly tracks, long overgrown with trees and vines, as they ran silently behind tidy houses in Rego Park, dipped through ravines in Forest Park and hovered above big-box stores in Glendale.

title: Redskins Face Second-Guessing on Handling of Injury
description: For most coaches in the N.F.L., what ultimately defines them is the difference between winning and losing. For Washington Redskins Coach Mike Shanahan, however, that age-old distinction has suddenly been surpassed in importance by a new concern: the difference between being injured and being hurt.

title: Bid for Stardom by Uzbekistans Single Most Hated Person Aided by Depardieu
description: Last Updated, 1:25 a.m. Days after he appeared in person with his friend and fellow Russian citizen Vladimir Putin, the French tax exile Grard Depardieu made a virtual appearance alongside the daughter of Uzbekistans authoritarian leader, Islam Karimov, in a new music video.

title: Relieved, Rangers Gather for Workout
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Brian Boyle sat at his stall at the Rangers practice rink, beaming.

title: Judge Cries During Sentencing of Serial Killer Rodney Alcala
description: There was the 12-year-old girl who disappeared while riding her bike to a ballet lesson. The 18-year-old nurses aide who was raped, strangled and beaten with a rock. And the 27-year-old nurse who was strangled with a stocking and beaten with a hammer.

title: Rescued by a  Bailout, A.I.G. May Sue Its Savior
description: Fresh from paying back a $182 billion bailout, the American International Group has been running a nationwide advertising campaign with the tagline Thank you America.

title: U.S. Legal Officials Split Over How to Prosecute Terrorism Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration legal team is divided over whether to drop two terrorism cases originally prosecuted in a military commission at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences by significantly reducing the number of other prisoners who can receive tribunal trials.

title: Parking Signs, Cluttered and Confusing for Decades, Are Revamped at Last
description: The signs have hung for years above the streetscape, their contents mirroring the city in which they stood: talky, colorful and a bit difficult to keep up with, especially after dark.

title: Playoff Problem Lies in Quality, Not Quantity
description: At some point this off-season, the N.F.L. will ruminate on an idea to expand its playoff field by two or four teams. The concept isnt new  it was a pet project of the Kansas City Chiefs owner Lamar Hunt, who died in 2006  and it wouldnt be done in a vacuum. The extra layer of playoffs could come in exchange for a preseason reduced to two games, while the regular season would remain at 16. That makes expanded playoffs seem more appealing.

title: C.E.S. 2013: For Sony, the More Pixels the Better
description: Sony, the struggling Japanese electronics company, is trying hard to get your attention. The company cant resist highlighting big numbers for the features inside its products.

title: My Successor? Mayor Ponders Dream Choices
description: It has been a bedrock assumption of this years race for New York City mayor: Michael R. Bloomberg and the muscular political operation that guided him to three electoral victories will coalesce around his favored candidate, Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker.

title: Robert C. Holland, Governor for Fed, Dies at 87
description: Robert C. Holland, the first staff member of the Federal Reserve System to be appointed directly to its Board of Governors, died on Thursday at his home in Centreville, Va. He was 87.

title: Jill Scott, Keyshia Cole and Brandy to Headline 2013 Essence Festival
description: Jill Scott, Keyshia Cole and Brandy are among 30 vocalists and groups scheduled to perform at the 2013 Essence Festival, a four-day event on eight stages across New Orleans in July, organizers announced on Monday. Now in its 19th year, the festival has become one of the most important forums for non-hip-hop black music and culture.

title: Jets Wont Bring Back Quarterbacks Coach
description: Mark Sanchez  or whoever quarterbacks the Jets next season  will be working with a different position coach next season. The Jets opted not to retain Matt Cavanaugh, whose departure is the first of what will probably be an overhaul of the coaching staff.

title: Panel Proposes Dissolving the L.I. Power Authority
description: Calling the Long Island Power Authoritys response to Hurricane Sandy incompetent, a commission that was handpicked by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo recommended Monday that the authority be replaced by a private utility company and placed under the supervision of a beefed-up state regulatory agency.

title: Psychiatrist to Testify on Deviance of Officer
description: A prominent forensic psychiatrist who has consulted on behalf of local and federal prosecutors about such notorious serial killers as Jeffrey L. Dahmer and Theodore Kaczynski is now involved in the case of a New York police officer charged with plotting to kidnap, rape, cook and eat women, a new court filing shows.

title: At a Nuclear Plant, Hurricane Brings More Worry
description: LACEY, N.J.  Some years ago, Janet Tauro moved to the pine barrens and salt-flecked flats of the Jersey Shore, where she would raise her children. Then she found that Oyster Creek, the nations oldest nuclear plant, sat on her doorstep.

title: Chairman of Sears to Take On Chiefs Role
description: Edward S. Lampert will now have the chance to be even more hands on at Sears.

title: Lottery Numbers
Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Jan. 8, 2013
description: He was very, very relaxed. It was like there werent normal emotional responses. He seemed very detached from it all.

title: 20-Year-Old Trying for College and a Place of Her Own
description: Wendy Jerido, 20, just wants a room of her own. A place, she said with a sigh one day in the fall, where I can stay in my own little world, I dont get bothered by nobody, and nobody gets on my nerves.

title: Celtics Frustrate Anthony and Knicks in Intense First Meeting
description: Carmelo Anthony did not say a word as he walked off the court when the final buzzer sounded at Madison Square Garden on Monday night. He walked past Coach Mike Woodson, his teammates and security guards and headed toward the opposing teams tunnel  something he had not done all season.

title: Harvey Shapiro, Poet and Editor, Dies at 88
description: Harvey Shapiro, an admired American poet who chose newspaper work over the time-honored academic vocation of his peers, and who as an editor at The New York Times made an epochal assignment  what became the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.s Letter From Birmingham Jail  that ultimately never appeared in the newspaper, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Chinese Safety Concern Empties Distant Shelves
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A surge in sales of one of Australias most popular brands of infant formula has led to an unusual sight for this wealthy nation: barren shelves in the baby aisle and even rationing of baby food in some leading retail outlets.

title: Word of the Day | theocracy
description: theocracy \the--kr-se\ noun

title: All Alabama in Title Game
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  They called the football game played here Monday night a national championship, a title clash for the ages, epic, monumental, historic.

title: When Irish Fans Have Nightmares, They Will See 42 in Red
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The Notre Dame Golden Domers had waited 24 years, and then the better part of six weeks, to flock here in anticipation of cheering their team onto a national title. Instead they sat with their arms folded, their caps lowered, slouched in their seats, despondent.

title: Even Without Rondo, Celtics Gain a Boost in Confidence
description: The Boston Celtics had that familiar fourth-quarter edge to them Monday night, the absence of Rajon Rondo, their star point guard, notwithstanding. Paul Pierce kept the ball in his hands, Kevin Garnett established the offense and a cast of role players provided grittiness and hustle.

title: B.C.S. Title Game: Alabama vs. Notre Dame
description: The Crimson Tide marched with ease over the Fighting Irish in a game that did not live up to the hype.

title: A Lesson for Icons: Statues Can Come Down
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.

title: ESPN Will Show Millrose Games
description: The Millrose Games track and field meet, which was moved to the Armory in Upper Manhattan last year, will be broadcast on tape delay on ESPN in February. The meet moved uptown after decades at Madison Square Garden because of dwindling attendance and the high cost of hosting the meet, which was long the marquee indoor running event of the winter calendar.

title: Lawyers Fight Delhi Gang Rape Case Gag Order
description: A Delhi courts ban on reporting the court proceedings against five men accused in a recent gang rape case should be overturned, in order to help ensure that an attack like this does not occur again, lawyers challenging the ban said Monday.

title: News Quiz | January 8, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: In Downtime, Nets Squeeze in Some Practice
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Nets held their second practice under the interim coach P. J. Carlesimo on Monday, and only their third practice since Dec. 22, a day Carlesimo calls our last kind of quasi normal day.

title: Richard Ben Cramer Dies at 62; Wrote of Presidential Race
description: Richard Ben Cramer, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and the author of What It Takes, a prodigious account of the 1988 presidential election that has been widely hailed as among the finest books about American politics ever written, died on Monday night in Baltimore. He was 62.

title: The Death of a Poet Who Defined Hong Kong
description: BEIJING  Leung Ping-kwan, the poet and intellectual who celebrated and defined Hong Kong, had just been released from the hospital and sat, surrounded by spilling boxes of books, his trademark flat cap on his head, in his home in Hong Kongs Causeway Bay district the last time I saw him, on Dec. 9.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 8
description: NEWS A battle over media censorship in China intensified Monday with an outpouring of support for journalists at a Guangzhou newspaper who are protesting what they called overbearing censorship by provincial officials. Edward Wong reports from Beijing. Also Monday, state media said China would start reforming its draconian system of re-education through labor, as Andrew Jacobs reports from Beijing.

title: Tentative Deal Reported in Chinese Censorship Dispute
description: GUANGZHOU, China  A tentative agreement to defuse a newsroom strike by Chinese journalists over censorship controls in this southeastern provincial capital had been reached by early Wednesday, and some reporters working for Southern Weekend, the newspaper at the heart of the dispute, were told that the paper would publish as usual on Thursday, one journalist in the newsroom said.

title: A Conversation With: Economist and Author Vivek Dehejia
description: Outsiders often find India baffling, but Indians themselves can be at a loss to explain certain things that go on in the country. For example, why does the local stock market drop during a lunar eclipse? Or why isnt Indias Independence Day celebrated on the actual day British colonial rule ended?

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 8, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from The Times Magazine article What Happens in Brooklyn Moves to Vegas.

title: Journalists Go on Strike in Southern China
description: In Supporters Back Strike at Newspaper in China, Edward Wong reports on a growing demand for press freedom in southern China.

title: Should We Tax People for Being Annoying?
description: Driving home during the holidays, I found myself trapped in the permanent traffic jam on I-95 near Bridgeport, Conn. In the back seat, my son was screaming. All around, drivers had the menaced, lifeless expressions that people get when they see cars lined up to the horizon. It was enough to make me wish for congestion pricing  a tax paid by drivers to enter crowded areas at peak times. After all, it costs drivers about $16 to enter central London during working hours. A few years ago, it nearly caught on in New York. And on that drive home, I would have happily paid whatever it cost to persuade some other drivers that it wasnt worth it for them to be on the road.

title: Did a Newspaper Act Irresponsibly by Publishing the Addresses of Gun Owners?
description: The Journal News, a newspaper serving the northern suburbs of New York City, published the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in two counties in New York State. The interactive map received more views than any other article in the papers history and generated significant outrage across the nation. Calls and e-mails to the newspaper became so threatening that it decided to hire armed security guards to protect the safety of its employees.

title: Alex Webb: Rendering a Complex World, in Color and Black-and-White
description: For someone who says 99 percent of street photography is about failure, Alex Webb has had a notably successful career. From his early work in Haiti and along the United States-Mexico border, to recent projects in the United States Rust Belt, Mr. Webb, a member of Magnum Photos, had produced a deep archive of images rich in color and complexity. James Estrin recently discussed with him how his work has evolved over the last four decades. Their interview has been edited.

title: Who Should Receive Organ Transplants?
description: Joe Gammalo had been contending with pulmonary fibrosis, a scarring of the lungs, for more than a decade when he came to the Cleveland Clinic in 2008 seeking a lung transplant.

title: January College Checklist for Juniors
description: This week, The Choice is publishing our monthly Counselors Calendar, which is intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Tax Increases and Bull Markets
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Lexus Aims Gadgets at Increasing Vehicle Safety
description: Among the panoply of gizmos and gadgets taking bows this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, relatively few are intended to keep you safe in an automobile  even in an automobile thats driving itself.

title: The Early Word: Legacy
description: Todays Times

title: New Leader for Slow Food USA
description: Slow Food USA, the American chapter of the global Slow Food organization based near Turin, Italy, has hired a new executive director. The group has been without a national leader since Josh Viertel left in May, after a period filled with internal strife over its mission.

title: The State of Small-Business Lending
description: As we begin the New Year, I thought I would share some perspectives on where I think we stand in terms of access to capital and what I think will happen with small-business lending in 2013.

title: Generali to Buy Stake in Joint Venture for $3.3 Billion
description: LONDON  The biggest Italian insurer, Assicurazioni Generali, agreed on Tuesday to buy the remaining stake in an East European joint venture that it did not already own, as part of a strategy to expand in faster-growing emerging European markets.

title: Less Time for Science, and More for Religion?
description: HONG KONG  If an Indonesian government proposal goes through, millions of elementary school students in that country will lose their science classes, with that time spent on increased religious education instead. Science may still be taught as part of other classes, but it will not have separate, compulsory classes, as religion does.

title: The Child Who Made My Belly Hurt
description: TOKYO When it comes to women, Japan is an outlier compared with other highly industrialized countries: It lags regarding womens roles in politics and business, in the salary gap between the genders  and in obstetrics and gynecology.

title: Man Group Appoints Executives at Its GLG Division
description: LONDON  The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund management firm, announced several appointments in its GLG division on Tuesday.

title: Flag Protest Reignites Northern Ireland Strife
description: LONDON  The Northern Ireland city of Belfast was clearing up on Tuesday after a fifth straight night of rioting by British loyalists that has brought an ugly reminder of decades of sectarian violence that afflicted the province.

title: Opinion Report: Hagel and Brennan
description: From the editorial page

title: Closing the Heirloom Gender (and Gay) Gap
description: Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: Parallel Problems
description: A common parallelism problem arises when two modifiers are used together, connected by a conjunction, but one is a phrase and the other is a full clause with its own verb. The effect is awkward and jarring. In careful writing, the two elements should be grammatically parallel or should be reworked into a single clause. Once the problem is diagnosed, the fix is usually simple.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Strong Ratings for Downton, and New Life for Two Soaps
description: Downton Abbey began it third season on PBS by drawing nearly 8 million viewers to local public broadcasting stations. As Brian Stelter reports, preliminary ratings suggest that the show catapulted PBS into the same league as commercial broadcasters like ABC and NBC  at least for a night. With 7.9 million viewers, the premiere on Sunday night quadrupled the average PBS primetime rating and exceeded the average rating of the second season premiere by 96 percent, according to PBS and member station WGBH. While Downton Abbey was on, PBS outrated Fox, ABC and NBC, according preliminary Nielsen ratings. (CBS still ranked No. 1 for the night with episodes of The Good Wife and The Mentalist that had 10 and 10.7 million viewers, respectively.)

title: Introducing  the Mumbai/New York Photo Project
description: When asked to describe their beloved metropolis, many Mumbaikers proudly say that it can be compared with New York City. The similarities lie, they say, in the harried pace of the city, the no-nonsense nature of its residents and its cosmopolitan feel.

title: In Flies Innards, Vital Clues to Biodiversity
description: How many mammal species live in the forest? It sounds like a simple question, but the actual distributions of shy, small or rare mammals are often murky, confounding conservationists seeking to protect them.

title: Obama Nominates New Director of  C.I.A.
description: President Obama has nominated John O. Brennan as the new director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Tuesday Reading: Keeping Firearms Away From Children
A.I.G. Weighs Suing the Government
description: After paying back its $182 billion bailout, the American International Group is now considering whether to sue the government agencies that rescued it during the financial crisis. A.I.G.s board is meeting on Wednesday to weigh joining a $25 billion lawsuit filed by Maurice R. Greenberg, the companys former chief executive, claiming that the bailout cheated shareholders, DealBooks Ben Protess and Michael J. de la Merced report.

title: In Performance: Zabryna Guevara of Water by the Spoonful
description: Quiara Alegra Hudess play Water by the Spoonful, winner of the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for drama, is about the intersecting lives of a group of people struggling with issues of addiction, family resentment and forgiveness. In this scene Yazmin, an adjunct professor of music played by Zabryna Guevara, talks about how different she is from her soon-to-be ex-husband and other family members. The play continues through Jan. 27 at Second Stage Theater.

title: A Teachers Contract
description: Dear Diary:

title: As Use of Libraries Grows, Government Support Has Eroded
description: To see how New York Citys library systems stack up next to other big cities libraries in terms of government support, you might want to check the cookbook shelves under chopped liver.

title: JPMorgans Staley to Join BlueMountain Capital
description: The former head of JPMorgan Chases investment bank is leaving to join a hedge fund that profited by going against JPMorgan in a bet on corporate debt that left the bank with a multibillion-dollar loss.

title: Jonathan Saunders
description: Photos from the Jonathan Saunders show at London mens fashion week, including looks like ombre shirts and colorful suits.

title: Jonathan Saunders: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: Hang On to Yourself: New Album Coming From David Bowie
description: The Thin White Duke has returned. After a 10-year span in which communication between David Bowie and his devoted listeners had become about as infrequent as the transmissions between ground control and Major Tom, that protean rock star said on Tuesday  his 66th birthday  that he had released a new single, Where Are We Now? in advance of a new album, The Next Day, coming in March.

title: Norwegian Cruise Line Sets Price Range for I.P.O.
description: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, the cruise ship operator backed by private equity firms Apollo Global Management and TPG, on Tuesday set a price of $16 to $18 a share for an initial public offering.

title: Body of 1 Missing Boy Recovered From Lake in New Jersey
description: Rescue workers in New Jersey on Tuesday recovered the body of one of two missing teenagers who apparently fell into a partly frozen lake on Monday night.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Economist: No, really. Rice hulls  those husks left over from the milling of rice  were once viewed as waste. Suddenly, though, they are an important component of a fuel-saving line of Pirelli tires, providing income to farmers.  Glenn Collins

title: Once Again, Ryan Needs to Rebuild His Staff
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The Jets do not have a general manager, an offensive coordinator, a quarterbacks coach, a starting quarterback or, officially, a defensive coordinator. But they do have a coach, Rex Ryan, who on Tuesday engaged in what has become an annual tradition for him: admitting his mistakes.

title: A First Lady With All the Small Graces and a Lot of Grit
description: In 1934, on their first date, Lyndon Baines Johnson asked Claudia Alta Taylor, the woman who would become known as Lady Bird Johnson, to marry him. He was 26. She was 21.

title: Daily Report: Mobile Apps Drive Rapid Change in Searches
description: When the Federal Trade Commission decided last week to close its antitrust investigation of Google without charges, one important factor, though hardly mentioned, was just beneath the surface: the mobile revolution, reports Claire Cain Miller in Tuesdays New York Times.

title: Graham Yost Answers Your Questions About Justified
description: Justified, the backwoods crime drama based on stories by Elmore Leonard, returns for its fourth season on FX on Tuesday night. Graham Yost, the creator of the series, agreed to answer questions from Times readers about the show. (Previously, Steve Levitan and Christopher Lloyd answered questions about Modern Family, and Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon answered them about Homeland.)

title: Lone Suspect Held in Benghazi Attack Is Freed in Tunisia
description: CAIRO  The only known suspect jailed in connection with the deadly attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, was freed on Tuesday by the Tunisian authorities who had held him. His lawyer said he was released for lack of evidence.

title: Extreme Makeover, Israel
description: TEL AVIV  When youre in Tel Aviv  touring its busy beach cafs by day or its busy bars at night  its easy to think of Israel as an attractive place. As of last week, Israel is also an attractive place with an attractive logo: the Foreign Ministry has just released ISRAEL, a multicolored rebranded look for the countrys name.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (13, 49) THE EDUCATION OF MICHELLE RHEE Frontline examines the legacy of Ms. Rhee, right, the former chancellor of the Washington public schools and one of the most admired and reviled education reformers in the country. In a report released on Monday, StudentsFirst, the advocacy group Ms. Rhee leads, issued failing grades to 12 states on their public school policies. Her memoir, Radical: Fighting to Put Students First, is to be published next month.

title: Whats On Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE THREE STOOGES (2012) Will Sasso stars as Curly, Sean Hayes is Larry, and Chris Diamantopoulos is Moe (pictured above, from left) in this fictionalized origin story for the mostly lovable fools, and paean to the art of the eye poke, from Peter and Bobby Farrelly. Divided into episodes, the tale follows the Stooges from infancy  when theyre tossed out of a speeding car at the feet of a nun, Sister Mary-Mengele (Larry David)  to adulthood, when theyre forced to try to save the orphanage in which they were reared from the faltering economy and other calamities. Jane Lynch plays the Mother Superior who sends them out into the world, where they meet a femme fatale (Sofia Vergara) and her lover (Craig Bierko); the handsome guy from the Old Spice commercials (Isaiah Mustafa); and some of the cast of Jersey Shore. The three leads in The Three Stooges play dumb very well, particularly Mr. Sasso, Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. She added: Much of the pleasure in The Three Stooges comes from watching and hearing (the boings and thumps are terrific) grown men smack each other silly in Rube Goldberg-like formations and without suffering so much as a single black eye, enduring psychological damage or, as bad, being forced to change. Like Wile E. Coyote and those inflatable clowns that bounce back after every punch, the Three Stooges take plenty of hits but keep on coming. They are, as the Farrellys understand, testaments to human resilience, one slap and tickle at a time.

title: Whats On Thursday
description: 8:30 P.M. (13) AT THE PALEY CENTER In Shes Making News, this series focuses on the role of women in journalism and the innovative use of media through interviews with Christiane Amanpour, Maria Bartiromo, Gayle King, Soledad OBrien, Paula Zahn and, in this premiere episode, Katie Couric, above. Pat Mitchell, the president and chief executive of the Paley Center for Media, hosts each episode, which recounts the guests life story using examples of her work culled from the centers collection.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (HGTV) COUSINS ON CALL The Kitchen Cousins  the real-life cousins and best friends Anthony Carrino and John Colaneri, above, of Brunelleschi Construction  deliver a new show in which they surprise the owners of outdated homes with fresh renovations. In this series premiere, the men team up with Ellen DeGeneres to make over the house of Megan and Jonathan, volunteer first responders in New Jersey whose home was destroyed while they were helping others during Hurricane Sandy. But the cousins have only five days to complete the job before the project is revealed to the couple on The Ellen DeGeneres Show.

title: Whats On Sunday
description: 1:30 P.M. (MTV) SCOTT PILGRIM VS. THE WORLD (2010) In this film, billed as an epic of epic epicness, Scott Pilgrim (Michael Cera, above) falls for Ramona Flowers (Mary Elizabeth Winstead) and must fight, outwit and defeat her evil ex-boyfriends, played by Chris Evans, Brandon Routh and Jason Schwartzman, among others. Edgar Wright directed and wrote, with Michael Bacall, this comedy based on the graphic novels by Bryan Lee OMalley. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film offers fast cuts, off-kilter puns, sight gags and sound effects in such profusion that you may want to see it again as soon as its over. He added: At the end, the movie comes home to the well-known territory of the coming-of-age story, with an account of lessons learned and conflicts resolved. But youll swear youve never seen anything like it before.

title: Rare Cooperation Over Syria
description: TimesCast: The global effort to keep Bashar al-Assad from using chemical weapons. | Gretchen Morgenson on how big banks win on foreclosure abuse. | A Chicago neighborhood endures economic hardship.

title: A Glimpse of the Future of Parking
description: Finding a parking spot is such a travail that Calvin Trillin once wrote a book about it. But with the debut this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas of a new navigation and parking service, such driver headaches could eventually go the way of the hitching post.

title: A Womans Place Is in the House. . . and in the Senate
description: NEW YORK  A huge virtual banner should be draped on the dome of the U.S. Capitol in Washington with the words Year of the Woman  2013! both in celebration of womens victories and as a reminder, should anyone need reminding, that womens time has come.

title: Asian-Americans Gain Influence  in  Philanthropy
description: About 800 people gathered in November in a ballroom in Midtown Manhattan for one of the years more elegant galas. They dined on beef tenderloin with truffle butter, bid on ski and golf vacations in a charity auction, and gave more than $1 million to a nonprofit group based in New York.

title: Is There a Cure for the B.C.S. Hangover?
description: For everyone but the true Alabama believers  and all the college football and Southeastern Conference powers that be who get stinking rich no matter what transpires in the actual sport  today feels like the cleanup from a very bad party. As we pick our way through the discarded golden streamers and trampled leprechaun hats and try to remember why exactly the bowl system survives several eons past its defensible existence, the day-after B.C.S. hangover has nothing to do with alcohol. You could try to put a positive spin on Alabamas overwhelming victory by joining the raging Nick Saban for Emperor parade, but unless you were already one of those true Alabama believers, well, Saban does not make this easy, being roughly as huggable as a dyspeptic porcupine.

title: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: 10:45 a.m. | Updated How good are the Falcons? And the Seahawks? Can the Ravens beat the Broncos? Is Colin Kaepernick experienced enough to beat the Packers? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers about the playoffs and other football news. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.Comments for this feature are now closed.

title: The Future of Software
description: Quentin Hardy, deputy technology editor, discusses the future of software with the entrepreneur and venture capitalist Ben Horowitz.

title: Baked Ziti or Penne Rigate With Cauliflower
description: You can add vegetables to just about any baked macaroni dish. Cauliflower works very well in this one, inspired by another Sicilian cauliflower dish in Clifford A. Wrights Cucinia Paradiso.

title: On Our Radar: A Bumpy Year for Arctic Drilling
description: A time line of setbacks that Shell Oil faced last year as it pressed ahead with plans to drill for oil in the Arctic. [Think Progress]

title: Ideas to Watch in 2013: Traceable Gas-Drilling Fluids
description: For several years now, Ive been assessing policies and technologies that might allow the United States and other countries with vast shale deposits of natural gas to harvest this resource with the fewest regrets.

title: Challenges Facing New Chief of Anglo American
description: LONDON  Strikes at mines in South Africa, cost overruns at some projects and a share price that has been lagging rivals are just a few issues Mark Cutifani will have to deal with when he takes over as chief executive at Anglo American, the worlds largest platinum producer.

title: The Mumbai/New York Photo Project: On the Waterfront
description: Mumbai and New York both teem with the hustle and bustle of urban life but are bordered by the profound stillness that only water could provide. While New York City is made up of three islands  Manhattan, Staten Island and Long Island  Mumbai was once an archipelago of seven islands, which were joined together by land reclaimed from the sea by 1838.In both of these coastal cities, the waterfronts provide residents a respite from chaos, as well as a providing living for some. New York City has 578 miles of coastline, while Mumbais coastline measures 149 kilometers, or roughly 93 miles.

title: Widow of Slain Civil Rights Leader to Deliver Invocation at Inauguration
description: Myrlie Evers-Williams, a former chairwoman of the N.A.A.C.P. who is also the widow of the slain civil rights activist Medgar Evars, will deliver the invocation at President Obamas second inaugural this month, Mr. Obamas inaugural planners said Tuesday.

title: In Maharashtra, Fight Over Restaurant Bill Erupts into Riot
description: What started out as a skirmish over a restaurant bill escalated into riots that left five people dead from police gunfire and injured over 200 in Dhule, a city about 350 kilometers northeast of Mumbai.

title: After Newtown, Congress Must Act on Guns, Pelosi Says
description: WASHINGTON  As she begins her second Congress as leader of the opposition in the House, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California is confident that Democrats will get behind President Obama on the big clashes with Republicans. But she thinks the president should aggressively line up much wider support for raising the federal debt limit and enacting new gun rules.

title: A Bull in Stocks, but a Bear for Free Speech
description: The Shanghai stock market is officially in bull territory, having climbed just over 20 percent since early December. Economists forecasts for 2013 economic growth are for the most part cautiously positive, though heavy with caveats about calls for economic reforms.

title: Why Raising Capital Makes Sense for Deutsche Bank
description: A reversal on a shareholder rights issue would be a bitter pill for Anshu Jain and Jrgen Fitschen to swallow. Deutsche Banks co-chief executives vowed in September to strengthen the banks finances without tapping shareholders. But American capital rules, noncore losses and a looming Libor settlement have raised the ante.

title: Suspicion of Steroid Use Could Keep Bagwell and Piazza Out of Hall
description: Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, eligible to be elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame for the first time, will almost certainly not be named when the next choices for Cooperstown are announced on Wednesday. Instead, tallies of sportswriters who have publicly announced their ballots suggest that they may only get 40 to 50 percent of the vote, despite having statistical records that rank them as among the best players in history. A player must be named on 75 percent of the ballots to be elected to the Hall of Fame.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 8
Pablo Larran and His Unintentional Trilogy
description: In 2008, the Chilean director Pablo Larran made a splashy international debut with Tony Manero, a chilling portrait of a serial killer obsessed with John Travoltas character in Saturday Night Fever and operating seemingly unhindered at the height of Gen. Augusto Pinochets dictatorship. A few years later, Mr. Larran was back with Post-Mortem, another character study of a deviant personality, but set during the 1973 military coup that brought Pinochet to power.

title: Invitation to a Dialogue: Rebuild the House
Woody Allen Names His New Movie Blue Jasmine
description: Its hard to know where one might define the beginning of a blue period for Woody Allen, since that writer-director or his on-screen alter egos always seem to be down about something. At the very least, Mr. Allens next movie  one of the first he has made in the United States, after a run of European excursions  has a blue component to its title: it will be called Blue Jasmine, Sony Pictures Classics said Tuesday, announcing that it had acquired the film for distribution in North America.

title: Giffords and Husband Announce Campaign Against Gun Violence
description: Former Representative Gabrielle Giffords and her husband, Mark E. Kelly, unveiled a new campaign  against gun violence on Tuesday, the second anniversary of the shooting in a Tucson shopping center that killed six people and left Ms. Giffords critically injured.

title: Institute of Medicine Studying Concussions in Young Athletes
description: The Institute of Medicine, a federally financed research group, has started a 15-month investigation into sports-related concussions sustained by young athletes.

title: A Hack for a Cluttered Car
description: This morning I acted on a brilliant idea.

title: Titian Discovered at Londons National Gallery
description: A brooding portrait of a bearded man that had been buried in the bowels of the National Gallery in London, as the museums director, Nicholas Penny, put it, has been declared a Titian by art historians, conservators and curators, the Guardian reported on Monday.

title: Second Inquest Confirms Amy Winehouse Died of Alcohol Poisoning
description: A second coroner in London has ruled that Amy Winehouse died of alcohol poisoning when she went on a drinking binge after a period of abstinence, The Associated Press reported on Tuesday.

title: A Search Engine Made for Mobile Devices
description: Few tech start-ups dare to take on Google in Web search. But mobile devices are a different story.

title: C.E.S. 2013: A Fuel Cell for Phones Offers Two Weeks of Power
description: LAS VEGAS  Backup batteries for phones and tablets have gotten smaller and more powerful, with some offering about two-and-a-half charges in a package a little larger than two packs of playing cards. A new fuel cell demonstrated here at the Consumer Electronics Show says it has them beat by a factor of five.

title: C.E.S. 2013: For the Speedy, a Sneaky Radar Detector
description: Lets face it, radar detectors are made for the sneaky.

title: Police Stop-and-Frisk Program in Bronx Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: An element of the New York Police Departments stop-and-frisk practice was deemed unconstitutional by a federal judge on Tuesday, a ruling that may have broad implications for the citys widespread use of police stops as a crime-fighting tactic.

title: An Artists Game of Chance on the High Seas
description: Dice have been around a long time, at least since man first carved bone, and are one of the most potent symbols we have of the vicissitudes of dumb luck. Which is part of their fascination for the artist Max Mulhern  he is endlessly interested in the role of chance in life  and one big reason he was inspired to create Aqua Dice.

title: Kennedy Center To Review How It Awards Its Honors
description: After fielding complaints of bias from a Hispanic Arts group, the Kennedy Center announced that it is re-evaluating the way it selects the winners of its annual arts awards, The Associated Press reported.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,155 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following American recently:

title: Ex-Lawmaker Gets 5 Years in Corruption
description: Larry B. Seabrook, a pillar of Bronx politics whose nearly three-decade tenure included stints as an assemblyman, state senator and city councilman, was sentenced to five years in prison in a corruption case on Tuesday by a federal judge who said he had betrayed the public trust.

title: A Waterproof Hearing Aid From Siemens
description: A lot of people who are hearing impaired would be more active if they werent afraid of damaging delicate hearing aids that dont like the humidity of gyms or the dousings of jet skis.

title: Document: Judges Ruling on Stop-and-Frisk
description: A judge found that stop-and-frisk tactics used by the New York City Police Department outside private buildings in the Bronx were unconstitutional.

title: Artist of the Floating World
description: Max Mulhern, an American artist living in Paris, created a project to design and launch a pair of giant floating dice into the ocean.

title: A Separate Peace
description: By late 1862 Washington was abuzz with talk of colonization. Bolstered by a $600,000 appropriation from Congress over the summer, Abraham Lincoln prepared a contract to resettle African-Americans in Panama and openly pitched the scheme to a free black delegation at the White House on Aug. 14. Few were surprised when Lincoln pledged to see colonization through in the preliminary announcement of his Emancipation Proclamation on Sept. 22, but a lingering question remained. Lincoln stipulated that all colonization was to be voluntary, though as of yet few had indicated an interest or willingness to go.

title: A Talent Pool as Deep as the South
description: Miami Gardens, Fla.

title: Halting Syrias Chemical Weapons Effort
description: The Timess David E. Sanger discusses the bid to keep the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, from using chemical weapons.

title: Music Rising Charity Pledges $250,000 to New York School Music Programs
description: Music Rising, a charity founded to help rebuild music schools on the Gulf Coast after Hurricane Katrina, has pledged $250,000 in aid to school music programs in the New York City area that suffered losses during Hurricane Sandy.

title: Nets Blatche Questioned as Witness in Sexual Assault Case in Philadelphia
description: Andray Blatche came to Brooklyn last fall with a troubled past, a tantalizing athletic profile and the promise of a clean slate. The Nets offered a one-year contract and the chance for a career rebirth. Blatche pledged to become a more responsible citizen.

title: New York Archdiocese Official Is Named Bishop for Camden, N.J.
description: Bishop Dennis J. Sullivan, a top administrator in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, will be the next bishop of Camden, N.J., the Vatican announced on Tuesday.

title: Regulator Plans to Expand Its Focus
description: Wall Streets self-regulator is planning to exercise some new muscle.

title: For Big Banks, a Favorable Settlement
description: The Timess Gretchen Morgenson talks about the big banks victory in connection with foreclosure abuses.

title: Excerpt: The Magistrate
description: John Lithgow and Joshua McGuire in a scene from The Magistrate at the National Theater in London.

title: Can I Afford To Be Optimistic?
description: It is time to complete the budget for 2013. I now have the final numbers from 2012 to help in the planning/forecasting/guessing game that I have been playing for 35 years. My comptroller reminds me that every year, for as long as she can remember, she has had to reduce my projections by midyear. Great. Is it a shortcoming to be optimistic if you own a company? The answer is yes, and no. At the moment, more yes.

title: Material Support for Terrorism
description: When President George W. Bush established a prison at Guantnamo Bay on land rented from the Cuban dictatorship, held detainees without charge, often without evidence, and then concocted a system of military tribunals to try those detainees, he effectively created a separate justice system. One with only a passing resemblance to the real, constitutional system that functions fairly well on American soil.

title: Streaming Lifts Home Entertainment Spending
description: LOS ANGELES  Total spending on film and television in home entertainment formats rose ever so slightly in 2012, to about $18 billion, up 0.23 percent from $17.96 billion a year earlier, the Digital Entertainment Group, a trade association, said on Tuesday.

title: Fiona Shaw to Star in The Testament of Mary on Broadway
description: The acclaimed actress Fiona Shaw and her longtime collaborator, the director Deborah Warner, will return to Broadway this spring for the first time since their Medea in 2002 with another play about an emotionally vivid and vulnerable woman: The Testament of Mary. Ms. Shaw will play the Virgin Mary, struggling to come to grips with the life of her son some 20 years after the crucifixion. The play is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 26 at the Walter Kerr Theater and open on April 22.

title: Was a Reporters Role in a Government Prosecution a Reason to Recuse Him?
description: Its a generally accepted rule in journalism that if youre involved in a newsworthy situation, you shouldnt cover it. Most of the time that makes excellent sense.

title: Jeff Garlin Joins the Podcast Fray
description: Earwolf, which runs an extensive lineup of podcasts including the popular Comedy Bang Bang and Professor Blastoff, is adding another big name. By the Way, In Conversation With Jeff Garlin will be a biweekly series of talks with famously funny people led by Mr. Garlin, a Second City veteran perhaps best known for his role as Larry Davids pal on Curb Your Enthusiasm. It starts Thursday with a chat with Mr. David.

title: Record-Setting Heat Across the U.S. in 2012
description: A map showing which parts of the country were warmest.

title: Obamas Remade Inner Circle Has an All-Male Look, So Far
description: WASHINGTON  In an Oval Office meeting on Dec. 29, 11 of President Obamas top advisers stood before him discussing the heated fiscal negotiations. The 10 visible in a White House photo are men.

title: Koolhaas to Curate Next Venice Architecture Biennale
description: The Venice Biennale just got a little more star power. Its board of directors on Tuesday appointed the architect Rem Koolhaas to be director of its architecture sector, with responsibility for curating the 14th International Architecture Exhibition in 2014.

title: Censorship Incites Protests in China
description: Protests over censorship at one of China's most liberal newspapers descended into ideological confrontation on Tuesday.

title: A Critic of the Curb and Corner
description: The great architecture critic Ada Louise Huxtable, who died on Monday at 91, started writing for The New York Times in 1963 and just a few weeks ago was still making the most of her bully pulpit for The Wall Street Journal, railing against proposed changes to the New York Public Library building at 42nd Street.

title: Free Outdoor Wi-Fi Comes to West Chelsea
description: Residents of West Chelsea in Manhattan who were wondering what Google had done for them lately now have their answer: free Wi-Fi service for the whole neighborhood.

title: Not Even Close: 2012 Was Hottest Ever in U.S.
description: The numbers are in: 2012, the year of a surreal March heat wave, a severe drought in the Corn Belt and a huge storm that caused broad devastation in the Middle Atlantic States, turns out to have been the hottest year ever recorded in the contiguous United States.

title: What I Learned the Hard Way About Leasing a Car
description: The Internet is undoubtedly the great leveler between buyers and sellers. With a few clicks of a mouse or a swipe of your finger, you can comparison shop for items like consumer electronics and patio furniture. Even buying a car, a bastion of obfuscation, disinformation and dealer sleight-of-hand, has succumbed to the radical transparency of the Web. But what about leasing a car? That, as I so rudely discovered, is a whole other story.

title: El Toro Blanco
description: Inside the Mexican restaurant in the West Village where midcentury modernism is alive and well.

title: More Cabinet Changes Ahead
description: TimesCast Politics: Nominations beyond Chuck Hagel and John Brennan. | An interview with Nancy Pelosi. | Bloombergs active role in picking his successor.

title: Playing Cool With a Mexican Palette
description: ONCE you plow your way through the crowds struggling in vain to catch a bartenders eye at El Toro Blanco, you emerge into a dining room that might be in Santa Barbara during the last days of the Nixon administration. Ridged orange backs on half-moon banquettes stand up like a wall of Cheetos. Glazed brick walls in red and black flank curvy 1960s plywood chairs, dangling tangerine-colored pendant lights, and matadors painted on black velvet.

title: Japan Summons Chinas Envoy in Latest Escalation of Tension Over Disputed Islands
description: TOKYO  The Japanese Foreign Ministry summoned Chinas ambassador on Tuesday after Chinese ships entered Japanese-controlled waters for 13 hours, a prolonged incursion that seemed to escalate a standoff over a group of disputed islands.

title: After I.P.O. Drought, Brazil Becomes More Hospitable to Investors
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  The nations main stock exchange here forecast at the start of 2012 that 40 to 45 companies would hold initial public offerings to list their shares. Only three did.

title: Veterans Dominate Directors Guild Nominees
description: The Directors Guild announced its nominations today, and the candidates are:

title: TimesCast: For Big Banks, a Favorable Settlement
description: The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson talks about the big banks victory in connection with foreclosure abuses.

title: C.E.S. 2013: Aereo Announces Expansion, $38 Million in Financing
description: 3:13 p.m. | Updated  Adding legal background and mention of Bloomberg TV.

title: A Quick Trip Through Knicks History
description: The MSG Network analyst Alan Hahn has written a book, 100 Things Knicks Fans Should Know & Do Before They Die, recently published by Triumph Books. Hahn, also a host on ESPN radio and the author of The Knicks Fix, the Knicks team blog, recently spoke with Off the Dribble about the book.

title: C.E.S. 2013: Ralph de la Vega of AT&T Mobility
description: AT&T, the phone carrier, has a lot in store for the coming year. On Monday at the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, it said that its new wireless home security system, Digital Life, would become available in March. And it plans major expansions for its fourth-generation LTE networks for cellphones.

title: Two Soldiers Die in Clashes in Kashmir, India Says
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Indian and Pakistani soldiers traded gunfire in the disputed territory of Kashmir for the second time in three days on Tuesday, this time leading to Indian claims that the Pakistanis had killed two Indian soldiers.

title: Celtics Test Knicks Resolve by Testing Anthonys
description: The Knicks have been impressive in the first two months of the season, and not just because of all the wins. They also quickly slipped into a rhythm, establishing a successful new identity with Carmelo Anthony at power forward and Tyson Chandler in the spread pick-and-roll. The defense has been spotty but good enough: the Knicks are 23-11, even as point guard Raymond Felton sits out with an injured hand.

title: C.E.S. 2013: Have You Programmed a Ford Lately?
description: LAS VEGAS  In a bid to move more apps to the dashboard, Ford has announced it will give away tools to help software engineers adapt their apps for the Ford Sync system.

title: Women in the Obama Administration
description: While the White House itself employs about an equal number of men and women under President Obama, the gender ratio of appointees in 11 of the 15 cabinet departments favors men.

title: American Missing in Iran Was Dressed Like Guantnamo Prisoner in Photographs Sent to Family
description: Last Updated, 6:32 p.m. Robert Levinson, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who went missing in Iran in 2007, was dressed like a prisoner at the United States detention center at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, in photographs sent to his family.

title: Bacon: Its Not Just for Dessert Anymore
description: How can you miss with a shop and cafe devoted entirely to bacon, mainly in sweets? At least thats what Wesley Klein, at left, thought when he opened Baconery in early November. I love breakfast and dessert, said Mr. Klein, so bacon confections were an obvious choice. He began by selling many of the products on the Web. Now the shop, which he owns with Sean-Patrick Hillman, right, serves and sells cookies, brownies, caramels, marshmallows and other sweets, all made with bacon, but not aggressively so. Bacon strips dipped in chocolate, sandwiches like peanut butter and bacon, and even pig-shaped dog biscuits all come from the kitchen of the chef Edison Julien, center. Bacon from producers across the country, including Brooklyn Cured, Edwards, Nueskes, Bentons and Mosefund, is sold by the pound and sliced to order. Mr. Klein said he would expand the menu and planned to sell items like red velvet bacon cake balls for Valentines Day.

title: F.B.I. Says Suspect Planned Explosions
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  If all had gone according to James E. Holmess plan, someone would have tripped the labyrinthine nest of explosives he had woven around his apartment, luring the police from the Aurora movie theater where he is accused of opening fire last July, an F.B.I. agent testified Tuesday.

title: A Host for Others Gets His Own Party
description: WHEN Omar, a restaurant and private supper club, opens next month at the former Hotel Griffou in Greenwich Village, many night-life veterans may ask, Omar who?

title: Tofu and Crackers, Anyone?
description: Its doubtful that you would put out a piece of tofu with crackers to serve with drinks. But a type of tofu called misozuke, which is cured in miso, is creamy and spreadable, rich, salty, a little funky and loaded with umami. Add it to your cheese board and balance it with a sweet component like yuzu jelly, a less exotic marmalade or a fig jam. You might think of it as a stinky cheese for vegans. The tofu, made in Belmont, Calif., comes nestled in a little bamboo cradle from which it can be served.

title: Chuck Hagels Chances
description: Christians United for Israel, which calls itself the largest pro-Israel organization in the United States, issued a statement opposing Chuck Hagels nomination as secretary of defense. So did Concerned Women of America. Both groups drew attention to the former Republican Senators record on Iran and Hezbollah. Meanwhile the Log Cabin Republicans purchased a full page ad in The Washington Post to attack him on gay rights.

title: How to Cook a Steak
description: Mark Bittman is joined by Jake Dickson of Dicksons Farmstand Meats in Chelsea Market to demonstrate how to properly cook a steak.

title: Anybody Here Want to Be Mayor?
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg walked into a room filled with high-ranking government and technology officials on Tuesday morning and issued a hearty greeting:

title: Aid Groups for Syrians See Needs Growing More Dire
description: New signs of deprivation plaguing Syrias war-ravaged civilians emerged on Tuesday, with the United Nations saying it is unable to feed a million hungry residents in combat zones and aid agencies reporting an outbreak of violence in a large refugee camp in Jordan, where a winter storm felled tents and left many frustrated inhabitants shivering in a cold rain.

title: Examining the Terms of A.I.G.s Bailout
description: The American International Groups former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, is contending in a lawsuit that the government treated the companys shareholders too harshly when carrying out its 2008 rescue of the insurance giant. But a closer look at the $182 billion rescue suggests a different outcome.

title: U.S. Tech Firms Facing Stronger European Data Protection Measures
description: In the end, all of those trans-Atlantic flights may not have paid off.

title: Pelosi Previews the New Congress
description: Nancy Pelosi, the House Democratic leader, talks with The Timess Carl Hulse about the legislative battles ahead.

title: TimesCast Politics: More Cabinet Changes
Hands Off, Oil Industry Warns Government
description: Jack Gerard, the often-combative chief executive of the American Petroleum Institute, said Tuesday that the United States was at the crossroads of a great turning point in the nations energy history.

title: JPMorgan Hires Wall Street Lobbyist
description: JPMorgan Chase announced on Tuesday that it had hired T. Timothy Ryan Jr., a senior Wall Street lobbyist, as its new top regulatory officer.

title: Alexander McQueen
description: There were edgy variations of the pin-striped suit at the mens Alexander McQueen show.

title: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: For Travel Savings in 2013, Go Retro
description: Youve mastered the art of modern travel savings: your airfare alerts are set up on Kayak; you flit around Europe on cheap carriers like EasyJet and Ryanair (with vacuum-packed clothing in a carry-on to avoid baggage fees). You stay in apartments rented through Airbnb when youre not bunking with locals through CouchSurfing, bidding on Priceline or snapping up last minute rooms on HotelTonight. From the remotest corners of the earth, you stay in touch with your significant other over Gchat and your folks over Skype  when Grandma will let you off FaceTime, that is.

title: A Setback for David O. Russell, a Boon for Ang Lee and Tom Hooper
description: The problem is, there are six guys for five slots, a veteran awards watcher has been telling the Bagger all season long, and today, with the Directors Guild announcing its nominees, it appears that David O. Russell may be the odd man out.

title: Homework for Your Face
description: YES, I slept terribly last night. And the one before. And the month before that. The why matters, but only somewhat. Bad sleep is an effect game, because there will always be a cause. The problem is going to persist  how do you mask it?

title: A New Street That, if Truth Be Told, Is Anything But
description: Theres A New Street in town, and its been there for years.

title: Richard Ben Cramer On and Off the Field
description: Notices of the journalist Richard Ben Cramers death at 62 of lung cancer have rightly focused on What It Takes, his mammoth account of the 1988 presidential campaign season. Jill Abramson once called it by all odds the last truly great campaign book. Matt Bai wrote that no one else has come close to equaling it.

title: Dimon Leaves New York Fed Board as His Term Ends
description: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has left the board of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a position that had stirred some controversy after the banks big trading loss last year.

title: British Soldier Killed and Six Others Wounded in Attack by Afghan Soldier
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A British soldier who was helping to build new quarters for the Afghan National Army at a small base in southern Afghanistan was fatally shot by an Afghan soldier in the first insider attack of 2013, military officials said Tuesday.

title: Searching for New York City's Next Mayor
description: The Times's Michael Barbaro on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's active role in picking his successor.

title: Historic Power Plant in Providence, R.I., May Get Another Chance at an Encore
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  As the new year dawns on Rhode Islands capital city, a place still suffering a hangover from the recession, there is renewed interest in a waterfront building that has been vacant since plans to create a museum and hotel there collapsed in 2008.

title: Lawmakers Warn A.I.G. Not to Join Lawsuit Against U.S.
description: 8:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Giant Squid Videotaped for the First Time in its Deep Domain
description: In an interview 20 years ago, Gordon Robertson, an elderly member of the Haisla tribe along the northern British Columbia coast, recalled an extraordinary moment from his childhood when a killer whale broke the surface not far from shore in the middle of a thrashing struggle with a giant squid. Hours later, one tentacle drifted to shore, and Robertson toted it home, where his mother soon had it boiling for supper.

title: Watershed: Teaching About Gun Control After Newtown
description: Overview | What should happen in response to the shootings at Sandy Hook Elementary School? How should the nation try to prevent similar tragedies from occurring in the future? In this lesson, students will explore the political process that was set in motion by the Dec. 14 school attack that killed 20 children and 6 staff members. They will research the issues and history behind gun control in the United States and try to predict what sort of bill might eventually emerge from Congress.

title: Photos of The Moment | Oliver Spencer
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: The Envelope, Please: Bryan Stromer
description: Bryan Stromer, a student at the New York City Lab School for Collaborative Studies, couldnt stop smiling after a phone call from the Posse Foundation.

title: After Losing His Cool, Anthony May Lose Time
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Carmelo Anthony said he was wrong. He said he played Monday nights game against the Boston Celtics out of character. About 15 hours after he lost his cool and put himself in line for a possible suspension, Anthony acknowledged on Tuesday that he allowed trash talking from Kevin Garnett to get to him in a nasty-edged contest that the Knicks lost to their Atlantic Division rivals.

title: Wheelies: The Global Image Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 8
description: A view of the day in sports, which included college and professional basketball games as well as matches in the Gulf Cup soccer tournament in Bahrain.

title: Conjuring Warmth in Winters Kitchen
description: THIS sauce/side dish  a simple combination of fennel, tomatoes and olives  is magical. Not because its the best thing you ever ate, but because its transportive: you eat it and youre in the Mediterranean. This is even true with winter tomatoes (though of course its better with those of summer, and see my suggestion below), because the dominant flavors are fennel and olives.

title: Nashvilles Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
description: NASHVILLE  Portland knows the feeling. Austin had it once, too. So did Dallas. Even Las Vegas enjoyed a brief moment as the nations it city.

title: Costly Medicine
description: The United States spends much more on health care than other advanced nations with public health care systems. By most objective measures, it gets no better results.

title: Despite Promise, Federal Tax-Refund Debit Cards a No Go
description: Giving consumers who lack accounts at a bank or credit union the option of getting tax refunds on multiuse, prepaid debit cards may help bring them into the financial mainstream, a report from the Urban Institute finds. But the accounts must be low-cost, easy to use and available early in the tax season to encourage their use.

title: Lobster and Bison After Inauguration
description: WITHOUT a single filibuster or even a cross word, the bipartisan Congressional committee responsible for the lunch after the presidential inaugural on Jan. 21 has agreed on a menu featuring sustainable, artisanal and local ingredients. And many are from New York State.

title: For 2 Nominees, Vietnam Bred Doubts on War
description: Between them, Senator John Kerry and Chuck Hagel have five Purple Hearts for wounds suffered in Vietnam, shared a harrowing combat experience in the Mekong Delta and responded in different ways to the conflict that tore their generation apart. But in nominating one as secretary of state and the other as defense secretary, President Obama hopes to bring to his administration two veterans with the same sensibility about the futilities of war.

title: Study Questions Effectiveness of Therapy for Suicidal Teenagers
description: Most adolescents who plan or attempt suicide have already received at least some mental health treatment, raising questions about the effectiveness of current approaches to helping troubled youths, according to the largest in-depth analysis to date of suicidal behaviors in American teenagers.

title: Rage Against the Coin
description: (From Talking Points Memo).

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Fertility Start-Up and Polaroids New Plan
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Lebanon, Pakistan, Greece and Australia.

title: Off-Duty Correction Officer Shoots and Wounds Man in Brooklyn
description: Updated, 7:15 p.m. | An off-duty correction officer shot and wounded a man in the middle of a Brooklyn street on Tuesday, the police said. A witness said that the two men appeared to know each other and that there appeared to be a woman involved.

title: Ziel Feldman
description: Mr. Feldman, 54, is the founder and managing partner of the HFZ Capital Group, a real estate development and investment company that he formed in 2005.

title: Australian Forecasters Add New Colors to Temperature Charts to Capture Record Heat
description: How hot is it in Australia?

title: Health Care and Profits, a Poor Mix
description: Thirty years ago, Bonnie Svarstad and Chester Bond of the School of Pharmacy at the University of Wisconsin-Madison discovered an interesting pattern in the use of sedatives at nursing homes in the south of the state.

title: N.R.A. Will Send Representative to Meet with Biden on Guns
description: The National Rifle Association will send a representative to a meeting on guns later this week hosted by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., an official with the gun rights organization said Tuesday.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Winter in Brooklyn

title: Bloggers Using the Internet to Spread Truth in China
description: Profiling two of Chinas so-called citizen reporters, Stephen Maings High Tech, Low Life offers an inside look at an outsider vocation.

title: Dish Network Makes Bid for Clearwire, Topping Sprint Offer
description: 8:08 p.m. | Updated Not so fast, Sprint.

title: A Tale From Gores Quest for Current TV
description: I left one out.

title: Why No One Really Knows If Moderate Drinking Is Safe for Pregnant Women
description: Is moderate drinking (less than one drink a day) safe during pregnancy?

title: Whoopi Goldberg Plays, but Not Too Much, Working at Cuomo Event
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his staff like to stick to a script.

title: A Low-Rated Show Gets a Second Shot
description: In the second season of HBOs Enlightened, Amy Jellicoe, a self-involved do-gooder played by Laura Dern, joins Twitter. Follow me. Follow me, Amy repeats in the languid voice-over of her internal dialogue.

title: Christie Lauds New Jerseys Fortitude and Presses Congress for Storm Funds
description: TRENTON  Gov. Chris Christie opened his re-election year on Tuesday with a speech to the Legislature here that sought to underscore the reputation he earned as Americas governor after Hurricane Sandy.

title: Picking a World XI to Challenge FIFAs Spain-Only Version
description: Contrary to what FIFA would have us believe, there was soccer played outside of Spain last year. That just did not appear to be the case when the organization named its World XI on Monday at its awards gala in Zurich.

title: Fuel Leak Is Latest Setback for Boeings Dreamliner
description: Boeings newest and most sophisticated jet, the 787 Dreamliner, suffered a new mishap on Tuesday when a fuel leak forced an aircraft to return to its gate minutes before taking off from Boston, a day after an electrical fire broke out on another plane.

title: No Savior Needed for This Old House
description: The producers of the PBS series Masterpiece had an office pool going to guess the premiere ratings for Season 3 of Downton Abbey, the British period drama that has improbably become one of Americas most-buzzed-about shows.

title: Free Improvisation at a Memorial Helps Affirm a Saxophonists Legacy
description: At one point during the memorial service for David S. Ware, at St. Peters Church in Midtown Manhattan on Monday night, a slide show provided a visual record of his commanding presence. It opened with a black-and-white snapshot from when he was 5, sometime in 1955, and ran chronologically up to his final performances, in 2011. Most images showed him with a saxophone, either at the ready or held aloft, in midcry. In almost all of them he looked intensely self-possessed, exuding gravity even in repose.

title: A Lineup, Soon to Shift, Fills a Hall With Brahms
description: As the cellist David Finckel played a bittersweet melody in the first movement of Brahmss String Sextet No. 2 in G at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, it was hard not to recall that this is the last season he will perform with the Emerson String Quartet. Mr. Finckel announced last year that he would leave the ensemble, which he joined in 1979, to dedicate more time to his other substantial endeavors, which include the artistic directorship of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center with his wife, the pianist Wu Han.

title: Ada Louise Huxtables New York
description: As a rule, there are few things as stale in literature as yesterdays news columns anthologized. A 1,000-word essay prepared for immediate consumption usually doesnt read very well years later.

title: A Voting Process Overdue for Reform
description: One of the truly refreshing changes in baseball is how open it has been lately to common-sense improvements.

title: Before Expanding Outside, Market Will Revamp Indoors
description: The owner of Chelsea Market, a popular food marketplace in West Chelsea, recently ignited a public furor when the city approved plans to add office towers to the squat structure. But before construction on the towers begins, the market now plans to expand by adding eight new spaces for vendors  all without changing the exterior of the neighborhood landmark.

title: C.E.S. 2013: A Curved-Screen TV From LG
description: LG Electronics plans to throw consumers a curve. At the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, the company unveiled an OLED television with a curved screen.

title: Burned Body on Brooklyn Beach Is 14-Year-Old Girls
description: A girl whose burned body was found on a beach in Brooklyn on Sunday has been identified by the police as Shaniesha Forbes, 14.

title: Cuomo to Press for Wider Curbs on Gun Access
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, pushing New York to become the first state to enact major new gun laws in the wake of the massacre in Newtown, Conn., plans on Wednesday to propose one of the countrys most restrictive bans on assault weapons.

title: Justice Department and Patent Office Issue Policy Statement on Patents
description: The consensus among policy makers on the perils of using standard patents as competitive weapons continues to build.

title: Amazons Unknown Unknowns
description: Operating the worlds largest public cloud still leaves you with the problem of unknown unknowns.

title: If You Like Carter and Cash. . .
description: Each week, Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the Web site Valslist.com, matches artists from her generation with those of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Elvis, 1972, Madison Square Garden: The Times Took Note, and How
description: Seventy-eight years ago today, a king was born, in Tupelo, Miss. That, presumably, you knew.

title: Secret Double Standard
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Governors Undercover Mission? Buying His Twins a Car
