description: The buyer stood out as unusually inquisitive: in a series of late-night telephone calls and text messages, he kept pressing the sales team about a 1996 Ford Bronco he had spotted on eBay.

title: Siberia Is Thick With Wolves, and Hunters Are in Demand
description: MOSCOW  Wolf packs are prowling at the edges of villages in the remote Sakha-Yakutia region of Siberia, eating livestock that includes horses and domesticated reindeer.

title: Justices Rule on Staying Death Row Challenges
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Tuesday unanimously ruled that federal courts should not automatically suspend postconviction challenges from death row inmates who are mentally incompetent to help their lawyers. The decision left open the possibility that such suspensions may sometimes be warranted, but it said that they should not be indefinite.

title: Former SAC Analyst Cooperates in Insider Trading Case
description: A former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund owned by the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen, has given federal agents the names of about 20 people he said had engaged in insider trading, according to a court filing.

title: Chuck Hagel, Under Attack Again
description: Washington

title: Judge Says Harsh Detention Is Not Cause to Drop Charges in WikiLeaks Case
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  A military judge on Tuesday declined to dismiss charges against Pfc. Bradley E. Manning, a former Army intelligence analyst accused of providing archives of military and diplomatic documents to the antisecrecy group WikiLeaks, despite complaints by his defense team that he had been mistreated while being held at the Marines brig at Quantico, Va.

title: France: Budget Minister Faces Inquiry on Foreign Bank Account
description: Budget Minister Jrme Cahuzac, left, who is leading a crackdown on tax fraud, was told Tuesday that he would face a preliminary investigation into charges that he kept an illegal bank account abroad. Mr. Cahuzac said he welcomed the decision of the Paris prosecutor to open an investigation into what he calls crazy claims that he committed tax fraud by holding a Swiss bank account with UBS until 2010, when he then supposedly moved the money to Asia. The accusations were made by Mediapart, a French Web site of investigative journalism, which published a recording of a man it identified as Mr. Cahuzac. He denies that the voice is his and has said he will sue Mediapart.

title: A Financial Service for People Fed Up With Banks
description: Like many people, Josh Reich got fed up with his bank after it charged him overdraft fees and he endured painful customer service calls to fight them. But unlike most people, Mr. Reich, a software engineer from Australia, decided to come up with a better way to bank.

title: U.S. Is Open to Withdraw Afghan Force After 2014
description: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a visit by President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, the Obama administration said Tuesday that it was open to a so-called zero option that would involve leaving no American troops in Afghanistan after 2014, when the NATO combat mission there comes to an end.

title: Musburger Criticized for Remarks About Stars Girlfriend During Title Game
description: On Tuesday morning, commentary on the broadcast of the Bowl Championship Series national title game between Alabama and Notre Dame included words like creepy, awkward, uncomfortable and heteronormative.

title: Rodriguez to Have Hip Surgery on Jan. 16
description: Alex Rodriguez will have surgery on his injured left hip Jan. 16, and Dr. Bryan Kelly, who will perform the procedure, said he expected Rodriguez to return to full function after the All-Star break.

title: Next Call to the Bullpen May Be From a Cellphone
description: The reserve clause is dead. And so are wool uniforms. There are no longer eight teams in each league. And the Houston Astros have departed the National League.

title: Chinese Man Pleads Guilty in Copyright Violation Case
description: Nearly five years ago, a Chinese man named Xiang Li registered several domain names, including www.crack99.com, and embarked on an ambitious, and ultimately illegal, venture.

title: Another Slap on the Wrist
description: In the face of widespread evidence of illegal foreclosure practices, federal regulators in 2011 told the big banks to investigate themselves.

title: Menstrual Shame and Superstitions in India
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spread of Pregnancy Crisis Centers
The Poaching of Elephants and Rhinos
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine: Medicaid Purge Is Rejected
description: The Obama administration rejected Gov. Paul R. LePages request to drop thousands of people from Medicaid rolls. Mr. LePage, a Republican, had sought to eliminate Medicaid coverage for nearly 15,000 parents with incomes between the federal poverty level ($23,050 for a family of four last year) and 133 percent of that level ($30,657 for a family of four). He also wanted to end coverage for more than 6,000 19- and 20-year-olds. Marilyn Tavenner, the acting administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, told Mr. LePage in a letter that the cuts would violate a provision of President Obamas health care law requiring states to maintain Medicaid eligibility levels. But Ms. Tavenner did approve a separate plan to end Medicaid coverage for Maine parents earning more than 133 percent of the poverty level. Mr. LePage had hoped to save more than $20 million from the cuts.

title: Justice for Indias Rape Victims
description: Influenced by extraordinary street protests, Indian authorities have moved swiftly to try the men accused of gang-raping a 23-year-old physiotherapy student in New Delhi. Clearly, justice must be served, but there are disturbing aspects to the way the case is being handled.

title: In Old Taliban Strongholds, Qualms About What Lies Ahead
description: LOY BAGH, Afghanistan  The battle against the Taliban in Helmand Province was so fierce two years ago that farmers here say there were some fields where virtually every ear of corn had a bullet in it.

title: Facing Ravens and Cold, Manning Keeps Gloves On
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  The gloves are bright orange, and they would be eye-catching even if his hands werent of such intense interest.

title: Arizona: Giffords and Husband Start Campaign Against Gun Violence
description: Former Representative Gabrielle Giffords and her husband, Mark E. Kelly, unveiled a campaign against gun violence on Tuesday, the second anniversary of the shooting in a Tuscon shopping center that killed six people and left Ms. Giffords critically injured. In an op-ed article published in USA Today, Ms. Giffords, a Democrat, and Mr. Kelly, a former astronaut, explained that the effort, called Americans for Responsible Solutions, was intended to counter the influence of the powerful gun lobby. They said they wanted to encourage elected officials to prevent gun violence and protect responsible gun ownership by communicating directly with the constituents that elect them. They emphasized that they are strong supporters of the Second Amendment. We dont want to take away your guns any more than we want to give up the two guns we have locked in a safe at home, the couple wrote.

title: Super Bowl Commercial Time Is a Sellout
description: JUST as the playoff results are making it clearer which teams will play in Super Bowl XLVII, the lineup of advertisers buying commercials in the game is also becoming clearer.

title: A Mind-Boggling Claim
description: The board of the American International Group will meet on Wednesday to consider joining a misguided lawsuit against the government, which spent $182 billion to save the insurance giant from near certain failure.

title: The Market and Mother Nature
description: Whenever I hear the word cliff, I am reminded of something that President Obamas science adviser, John Holdren, used to say about how we need to respond to climate change because no one can predict when it might take a disruptive, nonlinear turn. We are driving toward a cliff in a fog, said Holdren about the climate, and thats always a good time to start tapping on the brakes. Indeed, when you think about how much financial debt weve built up in the market and how much carbon debt weve built up in the atmosphere, the wisest thing we could do as a country today is to start tapping on the brakes by both emitting less carbon to bend the emissions curve down and racking up less debt to bend our debt-to-G.D.P. curve down. Unfortunately, we are still doing neither.

title: Mothers Newfound Financial Security Benefits Son
description: The only way that Nicholas Beltran has ever been able to communicate verbally with his mother, Wilmarie Dominguez, is with two words. One sound he emits  an uh uh  very clearly means no, while the other, more commonly vocalized noise expressed as mahh  often requires investigation.

title: Interior Dept. Expedites Review of Arctic Drilling After Accidents
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department on Tuesday opened an urgent review of Arctic offshore drilling operations after a series of blunders and accidents involving Shell Oils drill ships and support equipment, culminating in the grounding of one of its drilling vessels last week off the coast of Alaska.

title: Displaying Skill and Composure, Johnson Wins Tournament of Champions Easily
description: KAPALUA, Hawaii  Only someone as athletic and powerful as Dustin Johnson could take the hilly, 7,411-yard, par-73 Plantation Course and turn it into a par-3 contest. And only someone like Johnson, whose personality is as placid as the west Maui winds are not, could describe as nice the blustery conditions that delayed the start of the Tournament of Champions for three days.

title: Q. and A. With Former U.S. Commander in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration weighs how many troops to keep in Afghanistan after 2014, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal cautioned that the United States still needs to keep forces there to help stabilize the country and urged a continued effort to advise the Afghan military that appears to be more extensive than the White House has in mind.

title: With Children, When Does Religion Go Too Far?
Chvez, Too Ill to Return to Venezuela, Will Be Sworn In Later, Official Says
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Hugo Chvez, Venezuelas cancer-stricken president, will not return from Cuba this week in time to be sworn in for the start of his new term, a top government official said on Tuesday, adding that the ceremony could legally take place at a later date.

title: Peru: 5 Americans and 2 Peruvians Die in Copter Crash
description: Five Americans and two Peruvians were killed Monday when the helicopter they were in crashed in the jungle near Pucallpa, in the central part of the country, soon after takeoff. The victims were employees of Columbia Helicopters, an Oregon-based company that operated the cargo helicopter, a two-rotor Boeing Model 234 Chinook. They were on their way to deliver materials to an oil exploration site, the company said. There was no immediate indication of what caused the crash, which is being investigated by Peruvian transportation officials. Witnesses told local news media that the helicopter appeared to have exploded after hitting the ground. Photographs showed the aircrafts charred and flattened remains in a marshy area. The company said the Americans on board were from Washington, Florida, Utah, Tennessee and Oregon.

title: An Official Vote, and an Unofficial One
description: The N.H.L. Board of Governors will convene Wednesday in New York to vote on a new collective bargaining agreement with the leagues players association. But another important item will be under consideration, even though it will not be on the official agenda: whether Gary Bettman will keep his job as commissioner.

title: Sudan: Top U.N. Aid Official Warns of Food Crisis in 2 Southern States
description: The director of United Nations emergency relief implored the Security Council on Tuesday to find ways to ensure his aid teams can gain access to two isolated southern states of Sudan. Hundreds of thousands of civilians are trapped there because of a conflict between rebels and the Sudanese government, which has accused the newly independent country of South Sudan of abetting an insurgency. The relief director, John Ging, told reporters afterward that he feared that many residents in the isolated states, South Kordofan and Blue Nile, might be dying of malnutrition and disease, while others were subsisting on roots and leaves. This is 2013, and to think that tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands of people are living in such desperate and deplorable circumstances, and we cant get in to help them as humanitarian organizations, its just not acceptable, Mr. Ging said. The United Nations and aid groups have accused Sudan of denying them access to the two states. Sudans United Nations ambassador, Daffa-Alla Elhag Ali Osman, told reporters that rebels were responsible for any impediments to aid.

title: Iran: Ayatollah Discourages Talk of Votes Fairness
description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Irans supreme leader, said its enemies would most likely try to sabotage the presidential election scheduled for June. He warned citizens and prospective candidates to avoid discussion about the fairness of the vote, suggesting that such talk was subversive and would discourage turnout. Where on earth have elections been so free as in Iran? he said in a speech in the holy city of Qom, reported by the state-run press. Watch out for your words not to dissuade people. His statement, coming five months before the vote for a successor to President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, appeared to reflect the ayatollahs concern about repeating the chaotic aftermath of the 2009 election, in which Mr. Ahmadinejad, his favored candidate, won by a suspiciously lopsided margin that opponents said was fraudulent. Postelection protests escalated into the most serious challenge that the Islamic government had faced since it took power in the 1979 revolution. Mr. Ahmadinejads two challengers have remained under house arrest for the past few years.

title: Richard Ben Cramer, Writer of Big Ambitions, Dies at 62
description: It took time for What It Takes to become a classic.

title: For Drug Users, a Swift Response Is the Best Medicine
description: Ben W. Joseph was a trial judge in the Chittenden County Criminal Court, in Vermont, and he had a problem  one shared by judges across the country that results in billions of dollars of wasteful spending by governments every year. It was 2008, and substance abuse was soaring, particularly among young people whose drugs of choice were pharmaceuticals like OxyContin, a highly addictive pain killer that has an effect similar to heroin but is much easier to obtain. Each month in his Burlington courtroom, Joseph saw defendants whod been arrested for drug-related offenses  from driving while heavily intoxicated to stealing to feed an OxyContin habit (an 80-milligram pill can cost $100 on the street).

title: Contractor Settles Case in Iraq Prison Abuse
description: WASHINGTON  An American contractor hired by the military to provide translation services for interrogators at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq has reached a $5 million settlement with scores of detainees who accused its employees of complicity in abusing them, according to financial disclosure documents.

title: Analysts Skeptical as Majority Owner Takes Role as Chief Executive of Sears
description: Just hours after a board discussion on Monday, a note went out to Sears Holdings employees from Edward S. Lampert, the companys majority owner and chairman, that he would now be its chief executive.

title: He Who Knew Not
description: WASHINGTON

title: Title Game Draws Second Biggest Cable Audience
description: Alabamas 42-14 win over Notre Dame in the B.C.S. national championship game on Monday night was seen by an average of 26.4 million viewers, the second-biggest audience for a program in cable TV history. The most-viewed program was the 2011 B.C.S. title game, Auburns 22-19 win over Oregon, which was seen by 27.3 million viewers.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Jan. 9, 2013
description: The heat was remarkable. It was prolonged. That we beat the record by one degree is quite a big deal.

title: Record Number of Misconduct Complaints Are Made Against City School Employees
description: A record number of allegations of wrongdoing against teachers and other Department of Education workers were received last year by the office that investigates misconduct in New York City schools, according to a report released on Tuesday.

title: The Saban Way: That Was Nice, Now Move On
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Early Tuesday morning, the once great Alabama running back stood on the field surrounded by the latest great Alabama team. There was Shaun Alexander, retired from a long N.F.L. career, clad in a Crimson sweatshirt. He brushed confetti from his shoulders. He slapped hands and took pictures and even dropped the d-word.

title: Texas Budget Surplus Proves as Contentious as a Previous Shortfall
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The last time Texas lawmakers began a legislative session, a cost-cutting fervor filled the marble hallways of the Capitol in January 2011 as the state faced a budget shortfall of as much as $27 billion. Legislators warned of sparing nothing and no one from deep cutbacks  from highways, to prisons, to health care for the poor, to programs for preschool children.

title: Brooklyn Man Sentenced to 15 Years in Terrorism Case
description: A Brooklyn man who pleaded guilty to supporting a terrorist group after he was arrested trying to board a plane to the Middle East to wage jihad was sentenced to 15 years in prison on Tuesday.

title: Bank Hacking Was the Work of Iranians, Officials Say
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The attackers hit one American bank after the next. As in so many previous attacks, dozens of online banking sites slowed, hiccupped or ground to a halt before recovering several minutes later.

title: A Layered Detective Yarn or Another Animal Entirely?
description: In an interview a few years back, Richard Maxwell described the experience of reading a script by his fellow playwright and director Julia Jarcho: It has density and yet it still feels ephemeral.

title: An Extended Family, Sharing Extended Pain
description: Trouble comes in surging waves for the men and women in Water by the Spoonful, the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Quiara Alegra Hudes that is making its New York premiere at the Second Stage Theater. Almost all the characters in this moving collage of lives in crisis have a grim history  and maybe a grimmer future  of substance abuse. Often their addictions have cost them dearly, leading to poverty, isolation and unbridgeable chasms between once-loving parents and children.

title: Whirling Water
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Did you solve or did you not? That seems to be the question newcomer David Ben-Merre is asking, and it reminds me of a piece of wisdom uttered by a famous exile to the planet Dagobah: Do or do not  there is no try.

title: Corrections: January 9, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Argument Is Assailed by Justices in Fraud Case
description: WASHINGTON  A Supreme Court argument that started on Tuesday as a routine consideration of the time limits for filing some kinds of securities fraud suits turned by its conclusion into a broad attack from justices across the ideological spectrum on what they said was government overreaching with the potential to do away with statutes of limitations whenever the government seeks civil penalties for any kind of fraud.

title: In Step on Light Footprint, Nominees Reflect a Shift
description: WASHINGTON  With the selection of a new national security team deeply suspicious of the wisdom of American military interventions around the world, President Obama appears to have ended, at least for the moment, many of the internal administration debates that played out in the Situation Room over the past four years.

title: Hall of Fame Has Always Made Room for Infamy
description: The Baseball Hall of Fame, the most august fraternity of its kind in American sports, unveils its latest induction class Wednesday. For the first time this year, balloters must weigh the fate of two eminent stars, Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens, who are also the most celebrated poster boys for the games disgraced steroid era.

title: A Bold Dissenter at the Fed, Hoping His Doubts Are Wrong
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Jeffrey M. Lacker, the Federal Reserves most persistent internal critic, does not much resemble a firebrand. He is personally cheerful, professionally inclined to see both sides of an issue and quick to acknowledge he may not be right. He says he would rather be wrong.

title: Illinois Tries, and Fails, to Fix Its Pensions
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill.  If ever there was a moment when Illinoiss drastically underfinanced pension systems had a real shot at being repaired, some state leaders thought it would be this week.

title: Armstrong Set to Appear on Oprah Next Week, as New Allegation Surfaces
description: Last Updated, Wednesday, 11:07 a.m. The year before his seventh and final Tour de France victory, Lance Armstrong offered to donate in excess of $150,000 to the antidoping agency in charge of keeping American athletes from using performance-enhancing drugs, according to the organizations chief executive.

title: Controlling Backboards, Nets Keep Winning
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Nets needed something to readjust their focus from the distraction involving center-forward Andray Blatche on Tuesday, and it came quickly, unexpectedly, as Reggie Evans collected rebound after rebound.

title: Rhode Island Likely to Lose a House Seat
description: It may seem early to be thinking about the redistribution of House seats that will take place after the Census in 2020, but one state, Rhode Island, is being forced to because its population is declining.

title: Devils Ready to Go, as Soon as Kovalchuk Returns
description: NEWARK  With one notable exception, the Devils sound thrilled to have a labor agreement with the N.H.L., and they are eager to start training camp in a few days, even though it comes four months later than scheduled.

title: Claude-Anne Lopez Dies at 92; Told of Franklins Private Life
description: He was a postmaster-inventor-diplomat-founding father  just another American revolutionary. She was two centuries younger but plenty worldly as well, with a blend of verve and pragmatism that had helped her escape Nazi-occupied Belgium by taxicab. Their first meetings were hardly memorable.

title: Landing an Unlikely Role in 'Flight'
description: Melena Ryzik chats with the British actress Kelly Reilly about her first movie role shot in America: a leading part opposite Denzel Washington.

title: Fred L. Turner, Innovative Chief of McDonalds, Dies at 80
description: Fred L. Turner, who as chief executive helped transform McDonalds into a global giant and introduced the world to the Chicken McNugget, the Egg McMuffin and the Happy Meal, died on Monday in Glenview, Ill. He was 80.

title: Poets Kinship With the President
description: WASHINGTON  From the moment Barack Obama burst onto the political scene, the poet Richard Blanco, a son of Cuban exiles, says he felt a spiritual connection with the man who would become the nations 44th president.

title: Nationals Morse Moves Into the Yankees Sights
description: The Yankees have been searching for a right-handed hitter to augment their lineup, with only modest results. But a relatively imposing hitter is now expected to become available.

title: Parker No Longer With ESPN
description: Rob Parker, a panelist on the First Take program who was suspended last month for his racially oriented comments about Robert Griffin III, the rookie Redskins quarterback, did not have his contract renewed, ESPN said in a statement. Parkers contact expired on Dec. 31. In a First Take discussion of Griffin, Parker asked, Is he a brother, or is he a cornball brother? Parker, who is also African-American, added: Hes black; he kind of does his thing. Buts not really down with the cause.

title: Jackson Has No Intention of Coaching
description: Phil Jackson, the No. 1 target in the Nets coaching search, told a Web site on Tuesday that he has no intention of returning to the bench, although his statement left room for a change of heart.

title: Transcript of Nate Silvers Ask Me Anything on Reddit
description: Nate Silver of FiveThirtyEight took questions Tuesday on the popular social news site Reddits Ask Me Anything section. What follows is an edited transcript, with the questions and answers sorted into several subject areas.

title: Do the Brain Benefits of Exercise Last?
description: It is well established that exercise bolsters the structure and function of the brain. Multiple animal and human studies have shown that a few months of moderate exercise can create new neurons, lift mood and hone memory and thinking.

title: TeOs Draft Stock Tumbled When Irish Did
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Manti Teos season, filled emotional highs and lows, ended with a thud Monday night.

title: Word of the Day | catechism
description: catechism \ka-t-ki-zm\ noun

title: Whos No. 1? Tom Seaver
description: Mets fans can at least say they have this over their Yankees counterparts: the lone player who wears a Mets cap in the Baseball Hall of Fame, Tom Seaver, was elected in 1992 with the highest vote percentage ever, 98.8, which is higher than Babe Ruth, higher than Joe DiMaggio, higher than Mickey Mantle.

title: Macaus Gaming Take: Sign of Chinese Emigration?
description: BEIJING  Why did gambling boom in Macau in 2012, even as Chinas economy slowed? A Hong Kong online magazine that follows the scene closely has a smart take: emigration.

title: What Ryan and Johnson Didnt Say
description: Woody Johnson and Rex Ryan were asked many questions at their news conference Tuesday. Some they did not feel like answering.

title: Record Heat Fuels Widespread Fires in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Bush fires raging across some of the most populous parts of Australia  feeding off widespread drought conditions and high winds  pushed firefighters to their limits and residents to their wits end on Wednesday as meteorologists tracked the countrys hottest spring and summer on record into uncharted territory.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASHVILLE The series resumes as Rayna (Connie Britton, above) suggests taking her daughters on tour, only to discover that Lamar (Powers Boothe) intends to hold her hostage with some family secrets. Juliette (Hayden Panettiere) and Sean (Tilky Montgomery Jones), meanwhile, have eloped, and not everyone is celebrating. And Deacon (Charles Esten) reconnects with an old love.

title: News Quiz | January 9, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 9
description: NEWS In Helmand Province in southern Afghanistan, places that were once Taliban strongholds have been transformed by the American troop surge that brought tens of thousands of marines three years ago. But there is little faith in the governments ability to maintain those security gains once the Americans leave, and many assume that the Taliban will return. Alissa J. Rubin reports from Loy Bagh, Afghanistan.

title: Sons of 94 Lead Brazil Into South American Youth Championship
description: One of the iconic images of the 1994 World Cup captures Bebeto, Mazinho and Romrio celebrating Bebetos 62nd-minute goal against the Netherlands at the Cotton Bowl.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 9, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the Economix blog post Degree Inflation? Jobs That Newly Require B.A.s.

title: Our World on a Sphere
description: In Digital Globes Offer a Dynamic Vision, Mark Vanhoenacker reports on an educational tool that can animate complex phenomena. The questions below are based on the article, but watching the video, above, will give students a good sense of the power of this technology.

title: Shimon Peres on Obama, Iran and the Path to Peace
description: This part of the conversation is highly sensitive, said the spokeswoman for Israels president. I want all cellphones taken out of the room. It was July 25, 2012, and I was interviewing Shimon Peres in a wood-paneled suite at the King David Hotel in Jerusalem. I handed my phone to one of the guards standing at the door, and Peres swiftly opened a scathing monologue against a potential Israeli attack on Irans nuclear sites. Israel cannot solve the problem alone, he said. There is a limit to what we can do.

title: How Often Do You Leave Your Comfort Zone?
description: In a recent column, Frank Bruni suggests choosing a college that will take you out of the comfortable world you have known and expand your universe.

title: An Ambitious Woman From a Delhi Neighborhood of Migrants
description: Groups of women huddled around makeshift fires on a wet mud-lane, surrounded by partially constructed houses on both sides, in Mahavir Enclave Part II in Delhi. They winced as the smoke went in to their eyes, and glanced towards the locked house with a green steel door, a barred window and white brick walls, as they remembered the young woman from their neighborhood, who has suddenly become a symbol of Indias dire treatment of women.

title: The Labor Market Post-Budget Deal
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.

title: Inside DataWinds India Operations
description: In a nondescript neighborhood of Amritsar known as Ghee Mandi, a nod to the areas past as a clarified butter wholesale market, a three-story building with blue glass windows has displayed a prominent sign: DataWind Makers of Aakash Tablets. Below the sign hangs a portrait of a Sikh saint, Baba Deep Singh, after whom the building has been named.

title: Iranian Captives Freed in Prisoner Exchange in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than 2,100 people incarcerated by the Syrian authorities were being released on Wednesday in return for 48 Iranians freed by rebels after five months in captivity, Turkish and Iranian officials said, in what appeared to be the biggest prisoner swap since the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad of Syria began almost two years ago.

title: Activists Convicted in Vietnam Crackdown on Dissent
description: BANGKOK  A court in central Vietnam convicted 14 bloggers, writers and political and social activists on Wednesday of plotting to overthrow the government and sentenced them to prison terms ranging from 3 to 13 years in what human rights groups said was the largest subversion case to be brought in years.

title: Higher Taxes? They Make This Owner Want to Hire More Employees
description: Beginning in November, just after the election  and a thorough debate over how higher taxes might affect small businesses  we started inviting readers to share the intimate details of their businesses financial conditions. We are particularly interested in exploring the relationship between income taxes and investment.

title: HSBC Sale of $9.4 Billion Ping An Stake in Jeopardy
description: SHANGHAI  The British bank HSBCs plan to sell its stake in the Ping An Group is in jeopardy after the China Development Bank decided not to finance a large part of the $9.4 billion deal.

title: J.W. Anderson
description: The fall 2013 collection offered varied interpretations of pinstriped suits and color-blocking in mens wear.

title: J.W. Anderson: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: Three Accused in Delhi Gang Rape Case to Plead Not Guilty
description: A day before the Delhi gang rape case is likely to be handed over to a new fast-track court for trial, a legal defense team for the accused seemed to be coming together on Wednesday. Two lawyers said they had been retained by some of the suspects and planned offer not guilty pleas for their clients.

title: Daily Report:  Bank Hackers Used Data Centers to Supercharge Attacks
description: There was something disturbingly different about the wave of online attacks on American banks in recent weeks, report Nicole Perlroth and Quentin Hardy of The New York Times. Security researchers say that instead of exploiting individual computers, the attackers engineered networks of computers in data centers.

title: Chinese Firm Buys U.S. Solar Start-Up
description: Just a few years ago, Silicon Valley investors were pouring money into solar technologies and talking about how they would bring the same kind of innovation to green energy that they had to the computer chip.

title: UBS Executives Questioned by Parliament Over Rate-Rigging Case
description: LONDON  Senior executives of the Swiss banking giant UBS faced tough questioning from British politicians on Wednesday over a recent rate-rigging scandal that led the company to pay $1.5 billion in fines to global authorities.

title: Charging Up (Slowly) After the Next Big Storm
description: Shopping for hardware to tide you through the next hurricane? The Electric Power Research Institute has some advice, none of it encouraging.

title: India Lodges Protest with Pakistan Over Soldiers Deaths
description: India said it summoned Pakistans envoy in New Delhi on Wednesday to strongly protest the killing and mutilation of two Indian soldiers in the disputed territory of Kashmir after the second firefight in three days between the nuclear-armed neighbors.

title: At Peace With the Past
description: DRESDEN, Germany  Seventy years ago this winter, Soviet forces surrounded and crushed Hitlers Sixth Army at Stalingrad. The Germans defeat shattered the myth of an unstoppable Nazi war machine and marked a reversal of fortunes in World War II.

title: Wednesday Reading: For Travel Savings, Go Retro
The Great Dissenters
description: My article about Jeffrey Lacker on Wednesday mentions that he is the third member of the Federal Reserves Open Market Committee to dissent at least eight times in a single year.

title: A Time to Go Solo, at Least Onstage
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Super Bowl Ads and a Bet by HBO on Enlightened
description: CBS said on Tuesday that it had sold all the available commercial time for the broadcast of Super Bowl XLVII on Feb. 3, unless a marketer wants so much to be included that money is no object. According to estimates by agency executives, CBS has sold most of its Super Bowl spots for an average of $3.7 million to $3.8 million for each 30 seconds. (By comparison, the average for Super Bowl XLVI, broadcast by NBC on Feb. 5, 2012, was $3.5 million.) Leslie Moonves, chairman and chief executive of the CBS Corporation, made the announcement at an event at the CBS Broadcast Center on the West Side of Manhattan that was billed as Super Bowl XLVII Media Day. Mr. Moonves, as Stuart Elliott reports, said room could still be found to include commercials for movie studios  which often wait somewhat longer than other marketers to decide whether to buy Super Bowl commercials  but at a price. If one of those movie companies wants to come in and pay five or six million, he said, we will find room.

title: Renaming the Librarys Lions
description: Dear Diary:

title: Opinion Report: Foreclosure Rules
description: From the editorial page

title: Oxygen Bubbles Into Facial Care Products
description: OXYGEN bars may be a relic of the late 1990s, but the element is popping up as a beauty-industry buzzword of the early 21st century  no plastic hose necessary.

title: Former SAC Analyst Assists Insider Trading Crackdown
description: Wesley Wang, a former analyst at SAC Capital Advisors, has given federal agents the names of about 20 people that he said had engaged in insider trading, according to a court filing, DealBooks Peter Lattman reports. Federal prosecutors said the extraordinary assistance was still yielding results, as the government continues to circle SAC, the hedge fund owned by Steven A. Cohen.

title: Photos of The Moment | Richard James
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Climbing the Worlds Highest Mountains to Honor Heroes
description: Our wars hit home for me when my childhood buddy, Capt. Derek Argel, died with four other airmen in a small-plane crash near Diyala, Iraq, on Memorial Day 2005. Derek and his Air Force Academy classmate Jeremy Fresques were promoted to captain just before boarding that airplane.

title: One on One: John Legere, the Hip New Chief of T-Mobile USA
description: T-Mobile USA wants to be the cool wireless carrier for hip people. Its new chief executive, John J. Legere, who wears a T-shirt under his sports coat, seems suited for the job.

title: E. Tautz
description: At the E. Tautz mens show in London, there were oversize pants and roomy sweaters.

title: E. Tautz: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: London

title: Thinking of Planting Some Grapes? Get in Line
description: PARISAcross many of the wine-producing countries of Europe, growers had special reason to celebrate the New Year. A hated European Union initiative had been defeated.

title: Several Dozen Injured in Ferry Crash in Lower Manhattan
description: One by one, the passengers shuffled toward the exits  bags in hand, music in their ears  gathering in a neat crowd to step off their New Jersey commuter ferry and into the frosty Lower Manhattan morning.

title: Accused Picasso Vandal Surrenders at U.S.-Mexico Border
description: A Houston man accused of vandalizing a Picasso painting has surrendered to federal marshals after having fled to Mexico for several months, The Associated Press reported. The man, Uriel Landeros, 22, turned himself in on Tuesday at a bridge between the United States and Mexico, near McAllen, Tex.

title: For Cornell Wrestling, a Promising Start to Season
description: Cornells wrestling team began the season with a lot of injuries (senior Steve Bosak had to have surgery on his wrist), a number of promising new wrestlers, and their biggest star in a compelling new role.

title: A Gala of Stars and Bleeps
description: 10:26 a.m. | Updated  The beauty of untelevised award shows, even in this social media age, is simple: swearing. The National Board of Review gala on Tuesday got off to an unexpectedly raunchy start when the host, Meredith Vieira, borrowed a line from Zero Dark Thirtys Maya and said, Im the  boss lady, though she used another word  thats running this show.

title: What Were Reading
description: Culinate: Luck has run out for the potluck dinner, increasingly the victim of our crammed schedules and balkanized food politics.  Patrick Farrell

title: Just Business: 2 Hedge Fund Rivals Clash Over Herbalife
description: 10:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Anti-Leak
description: Before hurtling deeper into the maw of the new year, lets note an important victory for the First Amendment from the end of 2012.

title: Photos of The Moment | Christopher Shannon

title: The Explaining Season
description: The sports calendar tells us it is football playoff season, the time of year we get to focus on only the good teams, the teams that won important games and comported themselves in a relatively professional fashion, at least well enough to escape the regular season with Super Bowl dreams intact. In reality, January is football news conference season, with barely a day going by when a coach or an owner is not sitting in front of some backdrop sponsored by a doughnut company or a health care clinic (fine bedfellows at that), explaining how his championship season morphed into something that resembled the remake of a Three Stooges movie. There are hirings and firings, coordinators axed, fresh starts and do-overs, mediocrity and calamity all cued up for the cameras.

title: I.R.S.s Taxpayer Advocate Calls for a Tax Code Overhaul
description: Lawmakers need to overhaul the tax code completely to reduce the significant, even unconscionable, burden placed on taxpayers just to file a tax return, the Internal Revenue Services ombudsman told Congress on Wednesday.

title: Sol Yurick, 87, Author of The Warriors Gang Novel
description: Sol Yurick, a writer whose best-known work, the 1965 novel The Warriors, recast an ancient Greek battle as a tale of warring New York street gangs and earned a cult following in print, on film and eventually in a video game, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: The Black Keys, Fun. and Mumford & Sons to Perform at Grammys
description: The Grammy Awards show next month will include performances from three nominees for album of the year: the Black Keys, Fun. and Mumford & Sons, the Recording Academy announced on Wednesday.

title: Cuomo Pushes for Action on Guns
description: TimesCast: The governor is set to propose a restrictive ban on assault weapons. | A recent hacking attack is linked to Iran.

title: Barbarous Relics
description: I feel comfortable in my understanding of the economics of the platinum coin, but dont claim any legal expertise. However, Laurence Tribe knows whereof he speaks  and he says that its quite legal. And so there you have it: if we have a crisis over the debt ceiling, it will be only because the Treasury department would rather see economic devastation than look silly for a couple of minutes.

title: A Deposit by Credit Card Thats Returned by Paper Check
description: Sometimes, its the little things that annoy you.

title: A Lone Yank Takes Joy in Togetherness
description: LONDON

title: 36 Hours in Naples, Italy
description: THE southern Italian city of Naples, capital of the Campania region, has a reputation sullied by corruption and crime, both petty and organized. But change is afoot. A new mayor has ushered in initiatives to clean up the city, beginning with the unclogging of streets by disposing of uncollected trash and redirecting chaotic traffic flows. A thriving contemporary art scene  in museums, galleries, and even metro stations  is propelling the citys cultural revival. Make no mistake: problems persist, but those who remain aware of the vices in this spirited, ancient city will be rewarded by its virtues.

title: Wall Streets Elite, Including Ina Drew, Honors JPMorgans Former Leader
description: Ina Drew has kept a low profile since she left JPMorgan Chase last year after the banks multibillion-dollar trading loss.

title: Video: Kelly Reilly, Flight Newcomer
description: It has been a banner year for some actors, even if theyre not Oscar hopefuls. Kelly Reilly, a British actress, made her first appearance in a movie shot on these shores, and opposite Denzel Washington, no less. Here, Ms. Reilly talks about securing her breakout role in Robert Zemeckiss Flight.

title: Talkin bout Stimulus
description: Somehow Brad DeLong has managed to produce a pretty good transcript of Sundays panel discussion. Its inaccurate in one respect: I cant believe that I was actually that grammatical. But I think it give you a very good idea of what I at least said.

title: Obama Will Take Oath to Sounds of Beyonc, Kelly Clarkson and James Taylor
description: It would not be an Obama inaugural without a little celebrity pizazz.

title: Court Seeks More Public Input on Nuclear Safety
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must either allow more public participation in its decisions about fire safety at the Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor or to show why such input is impractical or inappropriate.

title: Across Borders of Memory and Photography
description: In Guayaquils Parque Seminario, iguanas are everywhere. Karen Miranda-Rivadeneira grew up terrified of them.

title: Feeling Bullied by Parents About Weight
description: Nancy Keefe Rhodes, a therapist and writer in Syracuse, N.Y., has struggled with weight all her life. So when the uncle she idolized asked her, at age 10, if she went to Omar the tentmaker for her clothes, she was devastated. When I begged him to stop, he said he was just trying to help, she said.

title: In Your Face(book)
description: A friends son got married a while back, and because of an unfortunate rift with my friend, I was not invited. I did, however, have the pleasure of looking at the Facebook pictures and seeing how old my friend had become.

title: Cuomo Looks to Curb Assault Weapons
description: The Timess Clifford J. Levy discusses Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos push for a restrictive ban on assault weapons in New York.

title: Obamas Pick for Treasury Is Said to Be His Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON  With his choice of Jacob J. Lew to be the secretary of Treasury, President Obama on Thursday will complete the transformation of his economic team from the big-name economists and financial firefighters hired four years ago to budget negotiators ready for the next fiscal fights in Congress.

title: Hackers Target American Banks
description: The Times's Quentin Hardy discusses a recent computer hacking attack, which American officials have linked to Iran, that targeted banks in the United States.

title: New Target in Finger-Pointing Over Housing Bubble
description: No matter how many times people debunk the notion that government policy created the housing bubble, it doesnt die. Its part of what the blogger Barry Ritholtz has called the big lie of the financial crisis. Now, we are having another argument about whether the government is creating a new housing disaster for taxpayers.

title: James M. Buchanan, Economic Scholar and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 93
description: James M. Buchanan, a scholar and author whose analyses of economic and political decision-making won the 1986 Nobel in economic sciences and shaped a generation of conservative thinking about deficits, taxes and the size of government, died on Wednesday in Blacksburg, Va. He was 93.

title: Have a Good Day
description: A new year, a new day. For very young children, there really isnt much difference. Each morning seems to bring a whirlwind of emotion and possibility, hope and disappointment. And it takes a good long while to get to bedtime. Three new picture books honor the boundaries, as so many picture books do, of the 24-hour lifetimes of young children.

title: G.M. Chief Expects To Regain Market Share
description: DETROIT  Despite steady profits, last year was a rocky one for General Motors, raising questions about the strength of the companys comeback from its bankruptcy and government bailout.

title: PATH Trains to Resume 24-Hour Service
description: Seventy-two days after Hurricane Sandy devastated the PATH system, PATH trains are resuming some round-the-clock service Wednesday night, Governors Chris Christie of New Jersey and Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced.

title: Photos of the Moment | Alexander McQueen
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: C.E.S. 2013: After Delays, Pebble Wristwatch Will Ship Jan. 23
description: Pebble, the much-hyped wristwatch designed to connect wirelessly to smartphones to display information like text messages, whipped the Web into a frenzy last May when the project raised more than $10 million through Kickstarter, one of the crowdfunding platforms largest campaigns to date.

title: Are There Really No Good Job Applicants Out There?
description: The latest Small Business Optimism Index data from the National Federation of Independent Business  a major industry group for small businesses that surveys a sample of its members each month  is very disappointing. The report, issued Tuesday, showed business optimism to be near recessionary levels in December. Hiring plans in particular weakened substantially.

title: Cash for Hay Driving Thieves to Move Bundles
description: DENVER  Across the West, ranchers, farmers and county sheriffs are grappling with a new scourge: hay rustling.

title: Ada Louise Huxtable Leaves Estate to Getty Trust
description: Along with the legacy of first-rate criticism she left to the world, the pioneering architectural critic and historian Ada Louise Huxtable, who died at the age of 91 on Monday, has bequeathed her estate to the J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles. The bequest followed the trusts purchase of her archives in December; at the same time, she donated to the trust the archives of her husband, Garth Huxtable, an industrial designer. The archives will be housed at the Getty Research Institute.

title: For Americans Under 50, Stark Findings on Health
description: Younger Americans die earlier and live in poorer health than their counterparts in other developed countries, with far higher rates of death from guns, car accidents and drug addiction, according to a new analysis of health and longevity in the United States.

title: In India, Solar Ambitions Are Suddenly Outsize
description: After years of lagging behind China and the West in the adoption of solar power, some states in India are proposing to build solar farms at a galloping pace that leaves them at risk of falling short of electricity (a familiar problem here) or of paying higher prices for it.

title: Barry Manilows Return to Broadway Is Extended
description: Barry Manilows return to Broadway for a limited engagement at the St. James Theater has been extended for an additional 10 nights because of a strong demand for tickets, the producers have announced.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 9
Even Fewer Geriatricians in Training
description: Toward the end of each year, Christopher Langston, program director of the Hartford Foundation, undertakes a discouraging task. He wades through the statistics on graduate medical education, published annually in The Journal of the American Medical Association, and digs out the bad news about geriatrics.

title: Seems Warm?  Expect a Record High (for the Year So Far)
description: Just think: If the forecast is right, Wednesday will be the warmest day of the year.

title: On the Floor at C.E.S.
description: Televisions are always big news at the Consumer Electronics Show, but cars, wearable computers and even a smart fork are also on display in Las Vegas.

title: Continuity on Obamas Economic Team
description: After President Obama took office in 2009, Jacob J. Lew became a deputy secretary of state within days. Gene Sperling was serving as an adviser to the Treasury secretary. Austan Goolsbee, a longtime Obama adviser, was serving on Mr. Obamas Council of Economic Advisers. Alan B. Krueger would become an assistant secretary of the Treasury within a few months.

title: On Budget Deficits, CO2 Binges and Wise Investments
description: Heres a post, once again, on the human habit of kicking the can down the road  sometimes very different cans, depending on the person and the problem at hand.

title: C.E.S. 2013: In a Compact Container, a Terabyte of Storage
description: Kingston Digital, a company that makes flash drives, is at the Consumer Electronics Show promoting a new flash drive that can hold a terabyte of data.

title: Lawmakers in New York Move Toward New Limits on Guns
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders believe they are close to an agreement on a package of gun laws that includes a restrictive ban on assault weapons, and lawmakers hope to vote on it as soon as next week.

title: Pack Up Your Christmas Trees: Recycling Program Ends Saturday
description: Heres an urban version of the tree-falling-in-the-forest question: If you dont leave your Christmas tree at the curb by Saturday, will it be recycled?

title: Khuzami, S.E.C. Enforcement Chief Who Reinvigorated Unit, to Step Down
description: After becoming the public face of Wall Street oversight and reining in firms like Goldman Sachs, Robert S. Khuzami is walking away from the spotlight.

title: Why the Founder of a Start-Up Chose to Give Up Control
description: Last week, we published a case study about a start-up founded by a young Australian expatriate who faced a difficult choice  just how difficult was revealed by the scores of conflicting reader comments that poured in to this blog. The choice belonged to Jacqui Rosshandler, who was about to run out of money: she could mothball her breath freshener business, Eatwhatever, and find a job, or she could accept the financial lifeline offered by Arthur Shorin, longtime owner of the Topps Company, who had sold his company and was nurturing start-ups.

title: Cotton Club Parade Will March Onto Broadway
description: After two popular engagements at City Center, Cotton Club Parade  a musical revue celebrating the Harlem nightclub during the Duke Ellington era  will move to Broadway this fall, its producers announced on Wednesday. With minimal spoken text, this 90-minute show recreates many of the big-band swing and blues numbers of the Cotton Club during the 1920s and 30s, with the score including works by Jimmy McHugh and Dorothy Fields (I Cant Give You Anything but Love), Harold Arlen (Stormy Weather, Ive Got the World on a String) and Ellington (Rockin in Rhythm, Cotton Club Stomp).

title: A Family Circle Spins Around the Oval Office
description: There is something funny about 1600 Penn, but mostly in the sense of odd. Its an NBC sitcom on Thursday about a fictional first family that the network is promoting as a blend of Modern Family and The West Wing. Actually 1600 Penn seems more like a time capsule of the presidencies of Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan and period sitcoms like Growing Pains.

title: Far From the Spotlight, Parenthetical History Made
description: While the elites of tennis gather in Melbourne to compete for a record first-place prize of $2.5 million at the 2013 Australian Open, a different sort of record excess was created on the opposite sides of the globe and the tennis pantheon, at a Futures tournament in Plantation, Fla., with a total prize pool of just $10,000 to be divvied up amongst all competitors.

title: On the Floor at the Consumer Electronics Show
description: Televisions are always big news at the Consumer Electronics Show, but cars, wearable computers and even a smart fork are also on display in Las Vegas.

title: Below the Line: The Light and Dark of Zero Dark Thirty
description: One of the many challenges of making Zero Dark Thirty, Kathryn Bigelows drama about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, involved how to shoot one of the climactic scenes: the SEAL team raid on Osama Bin Ladens compound. The moment would be low in light, yet high in tension, so securing a cinematographer who could effectively shoot in near darkness was essential for Ms. Bigelow. She decided on Greig Fraser, an Australian director of photography who shot two other 2012 releases: Snow White and the Huntsman and Killing Them Softly. Those films also used darkness and light in interesting ways but were more stylized in their approach. Mr. Fraser was recently honored by the New York Film Critics Circle for his work on Zero Dark Thirty.

title: Keeping Score: Pacers Lead Central Despite Offensive Woes
description: The 2011-12 N.B.A. season was an unqualified success for the Indiana Pacers, who finished with the third best record in the Eastern Conference and put a scare into the Miami Heat before bowing out of the conference semifinals in six games.

title: Video: Cuomos State of the State Address
description: Updated, 4:08 p.m. | Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, rewriting his agenda in the wake of Hurricane Sandy and the Newtown, Conn., school massacre, proposed measures in his State of the State address on Wednesday intended to limit the damage from future storms and to reduce the scourge of gun violence. (Mr. Cuomo begins his speech about 34 minutes into the video.)

title: Wheelies: The Not-So-Green Car Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: What A.I.G. Shareholders Should Have Expected After the Rescue
description: Between the devil and the deep blue sea. Or a rock and a hard place.

title: Rare Box Stolen From Oakland Museum
description: A box created from gold and quartz at the time of the California Gold Rush was stolen early Monday morning from the Oakland Museum, in the second theft from the museum in two months, according to reports in California newspapers.

title: Away from Headlines, Bostons Bradley Makes an Impression
description: Monday nights game between the Knicks and the Celtics will be remembered for several reasons: its playoff atmosphere; Paul Pierces vintage Knicks-felling performance; and a dispute between Kevin Garnett and Carmelo Anthony that has dominated headlines since Bostons victory.

title: If Marlon Wayans Asks You to His House, Think Twice
description: A Haunted House, a film that opens Friday and stars Marlon Wayans, is ostensibly a parody of the Paranormal Activity franchise, down to the found-footage style and the setting in a generic Western tract house. Mr. Wayanss character buys a video camera to document his girlfriends move into his bachelor pad, only to discover shes brought a demon with her.

title: Planning Summer (Already!) Amid Winters Chill
description: Unbelievably, it is time to plan for summer.

title: Look of The Moment | Rachel Weisz
description: The Look: Dainty as a Daisy. A dusty floral on a prim, bow-tied dress hints strongly at vintage, but opulent accessories  gilded platforms and a glossy croc clutch  keep the effect from feeling old.

title: The Scent of Supreme Leadership
description: We are a bit late to this, but, as our fellow news bloggers Max Fisher and Andrew Sullivan have both noted, the Washington Posts man in Tehran, Jason Rezaian, reported on Twitter this week that he had discovered the perfect gift for pious Iranians who like to smoke in their cars: an air freshener in the image of Irans supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

title: Excerpt: '1600 Penn'
description: Bill Pullman is the President of the United States in this NBC sitcom.

title: Hagelian Dialectic
description: David: Gail, between 2004 and 2006 I did some preliminary work on an idea I had for a book. It was a group biography of senators who had offices on the second floor of the Russell Senate Office Building, along with selected friends. The senators were John McCain, Chuck Hagel, Joe Biden, Lindsey Graham, plus Hillary Clinton and Joe Lieberman.

title: A New Scribble on Your Dollar Bill
description: Jacob J. Lew, President Obamas reported pick for Treasury secretary, has a ridiculous signature, as the blogosphere learned from a widely circulated White House memo he signed in 2011.

title: Censored Newspaper Returns to Publication Amid Struggles
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Propaganda officials in the southern province of Guangdong have agreed to loosen some controls over an embattled newspaper whose struggle against censorship has galvanized free-speech advocates across China, according to journalists at the newspaper. But the papers weekly Thursday edition went to press late partly because of internal disputes over content, one senior editor said.

title: Public Goals, Private Interests in Debt Campaign
description: When Jim McCrery, a former Louisiana congressman, urged lawmakers last month to pursue entitlement cuts and tax reform, he was introduced on television as a leader of Fix the Debt, a group of business executives and onetime legislators who have become Washingtons most visible and best-financed advocates for reining in the federal deficit.

title: Anti-Semitism Charge Provokes Furor in Germany
description: LONDON  The Simon Wiesenthal Center has prompted an outraged debate in Germany after it included a prominent German journalists remarks in its annual top 10 list of anti-Semitic and anti-Israel slurs.

title: Debate Continues Over Public Library Plan
description: The $300 million renovation of the Fifth Avenue flagship building of the New York Public Library continues to be divisive.

title: Bonds (and Everyone) Strikes Out
description: In the most resounding referendum yet on the legacy of steroids in baseball, voters for the Hall of Fame emphatically rejected the candidacies of Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens in balloting results announced on Wednesday.

title: On Our Radar: Fires in Australia and Snow in Damascus
description: Daunting wildfires continue in the Australian state of New South Wales, but the consuming inferno that officials had feared does not fully materialize. Still, officials warn that the danger is not over and that hot conditions have moved further north. On Tuesday, Australia recorded its highest average temperature yet: 104.59 degrees Fahrenheit. [CNN]

title: Stargazing: Kerry Washington
description: Ms. Washingtons red carpet looks from Django Unchained premieres around the world.

title: Loeb Explains His Herbalife Bet
description: Daniel S. Loeb took many by surprise on Wednesday when he unveiled an 8.2 percent stake in Herbalife, countering a big negative bet by his friend William A. Ackman.

title: Most States Keep Gun Permit Data Under Wraps
description: In the extended national conversation about guns that has unfolded since the shootings in Newtown, Conn., the decision by The Journal News, a newspaper based in White Plains, to publish the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in two suburban New York counties last month has emerged as a flash point.

title: Biden, Meeting Gun Control Advocates, Vows Action
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is planning a comprehensive effort to pass legislation and use executive orders to prevent gun violence, representatives of about a dozen gun control organizations were told Wednesday at a White House meeting.

title: Lego Updates Its Mindstorms Robotics Kit
description: Lego Mindstorms EV3 ($350) is a long-awaited update to the Lego robotics kits used by many schools. The idea, Lego says, is to bring snap-together robots into every home.

title: Before Aurora Slaughter, Self-Portraits, Court Hears
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  The ghostly self portraits, taken with a cellphone hours before he opened fire at an Aurora movie theater, show James E. Holmes in the final sprint of his deadly plan, prosecutors believe.

title: Marlon Wayans Talks A Haunted House
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend spotting at the Consumer Electronics Show. | David Pogue reviews calendar apps. | Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films.

title: Academy Award Memories
description: Academy Award winners share memories of their first Oscar experience.

title: Local Ties of Obamas Choice to Lead Treasury
description: The news on Wednesday that President Obama planned to elevate his chief of staff, Jacob J. Lew, to be his next secretary of Treasury, prompted City Room to recall Mr. Lews connection to New York, which was recounted last year in this blog post.

title: More Options to Dock Your iPhone 5 From Philips
description: Hoping to satisfy iPhone 5 users, the Dutch electronics maker Philips has introduced an array of docking speakers with Apple Lightning connectors.

title: Split Decisions and That Fork in the Road
description: From Jane Eyre and Oliver Twist to Harry Potter, fictional orphans are lonely, misunderstood, often small and markedly different from the people who raise them, and all haunted by the question: Why? Why am I alone in a world where everyone else seems to belong to someone?

title: Bringing the Calendar Up to Date
description: You know whats kind of wild? We can identify products by their container designs. Youd know a ketchup bottle, even if it was empty and unlabeled, no matter what the brand. Youd know a pickle jar, or a milk jug, or a bottle of salad dressing, or a cereal box just by their container shapes.

title: Boeing Says 787 Is Safe Despite Recent Problems
description: Boeing defended the safety of its 787 Dreamliner airplane on Wednesday after three incidents in three days, saying it had extreme confidence in the innovative design and technology used in the plane.

title: Queens Man Dies Just Shy of 111th Birthday
description: Carl Berner, a former toolmaker, toy-maker, factory owner and civic activist who achieved his greatest fame for simply staying alive, died at his home in Middle Village, Queens, on Monday, 20 days shy of his 111th birthday.

title: A Historic Jazz Label Gets a New Life
description: The major-label landscape hasnt been hospitable to jazz in recent years, but theres a bit of good news on the horizon: OKeh Records, the label that released historic early recordings by Louis Armstrong, King Oliver and Duke Ellington, is being revived under the corporate umbrella of Sony Masterworks. The new OKeh roster will feature contemporary artists, including the guitarist Bill Frisell, the saxophonist David Sanborn and the pianist and keyboardist Bob James; its first release will be A Different Time, by the pianist John Medeski, on April 9.

title: Nightmare Week for Dreamliner
description: Glitches on Boeings Dreamliner airplanes have surfaced every day since Monday, our colleagues in the Business section report. That includes an All Nippon Airways aircraft at Yamaguchi Ube Airport in Japan whose on-board computer on Wednesday erroneously showed problems with its brakes; a plane operated by Japan Airlines at Bostons Logan Airport that had a fuel leak on Tuesday; another Japan Airlines plane at Logan that had an electrical fire on Monday. None of the problems occurred in-flight and none caused injuries. While the problems so far do not point to serious design flaws with the airplane, Jad Mouawad and Bettina Wassener write, they represent an embarrassment to Boeings manufacturing ability.

title: Executive Action on Guns
description: At a White House meeting about gun control this morning, Vice President Joe Biden said his boss was fully prepared to take executive action to reduce gun violence, an important but limited way to bypass the inevitable Congressional roadblocks.

title: Les Misrables Soundtrack Storms to No. 1
description: The soundtrack to the film Les Misrables is No. 1 on the latest Billboard album chart, beating out Mumford & Sons by a hair in the sleepy sales week after Christmas.

title: Islanders Defenseman Doesnt Want to Be Pushed Back to N.H.L.
description: Lubomir Visnovsky said he has had enough already and is tired of being pushed by the Islanders and the N.H.L. to return to North America rather than stay with Slovan Bratislava of the K.H.L. until the end of the season.

title: Marlon Wayans on Spoofing Horror Films
description: Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films with his new movie, A Haunted House.

title: Newtown Shooting Dominates Opening of Connecticut Legislative Session
description: HARTFORD  Choking up as he reflected on the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, in a somber State of the State address beginning the legislative session at the State Capitol here, promised to take actions aimed at preventing a similar tragedy from happening again.

title: A.I.G. Says It Will Not Join Lawsuit Against Government
description: 9:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Photos of The Moment | Christopher Raeburn
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Cuckoo Kickoff for Mens in London
description: Mens wear is in a gray area right now.

title: Seven Injured After Crane Collapses in Queens
description: A 300-foot crane collapsed on Wednesday, toppling onto a building under construction in Long Island City, Queens, trapping three workers in twisted metal and injuring seven.

title: Washington Post Ends Its Food Blog
description: The Washington Post announced Wednesday morning that it had ended its food blog, All We Can Eat.

title: Disney World Gets New President
description: LOS ANGELES  Walt Disney World has a new president: George Kalogridis will take over the top job at the Florida resort on Feb. 1. Disney Made the announcement on Wednesday as part of a broader shuffling of management at its $12.9 billion parks and resorts division.

title: A Caveat in Creating an Online Social Security Account
description: I wrote this week about expanded online services offered by the Social Security Administration through its My Social Security Web site.

title: Leno Wins Three-Way Late-Night Race
description: On Jimmy Kimmels first night as a new player in the 11:35 p.m. late-night sweepstakes with Jay Leno and David Letterman, Mr. Leno retained bragging rights  narrowly.

title: Pap Test Could Help Find Cancers of Uterus and Ovaries
description: The Pap test, which has prevented countless deaths from cervical cancer, may eventually help to detect cancers of the uterus and ovaries as well, a new study suggests.

title: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Calendars
description: David Pogue reviews calendar apps and software.

title: Are Jokes Something You Have to Work At?
description: Jonah Weiners profile of Jerry Seinfeld in our Dec. 23 issue elicited 303 responses from readers, many of whom debated whether the comedian is even funny. Said one:Jerry is safe, solid, and smooth. . . . he lulls the listener to a laugh. Said another:His talent is unparalleled: no curse words, simple everyday observations, turned into exquisite narrative.

title: A Way to Put Phones Into Helmets
description: People are loath to give up their mobile phones, even when engaged in sports risky enough to make it wise to use a helmet, like skiing, snowmobiling, motorcycling or bicycling. On top of the safety concerns, there is wind noise to contend with.

title: A Tricked-Out Bentley at C.E.S. Shows Off Techs Capabilities
description: Connected cars and autonomous autos are major draws at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week. But some of the most intriguing car technology is being shown in a customized, obsidian black 2012 Bentley Continental GT.

title: Idle Talk About Idol
description: Beliebers didnt want to believe. Last Friday, TMZ posted photos of Justin Bieber holding what the Web site said was marijuana at a party the singer had with friends at a hotel in Newport Beach, Calif. His nearly 33 million Twitter followers were stunned. How could their squeaky-clean idol let them down? Others were less charitable.

title: Leading Indian Tennis Players Agitate for Better Support
description: CHENNAI, India  In a reprise of the operatic bickering last summer over the Olympics, Indias top tennis players are once again locked in a bitter dispute with the national tennis association.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend Spotting at C.E.S.
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Trend spotting at the Consumer Electronics Show. David Pogue reviews calendar apps. Marlon Wayans, the actor and screenwriter, returns to spoofing horror films.

title: Washington National Cathedral Announces It Will Hold Same-Sex Weddings
description: The Washington National Cathedral, the nations traditional host of prayer services for presidents and memorial services for national tragedies, announced on Wednesday that it would now also hold weddings for same-sex couples.

title: Generation LGBTQIA
description: STEPHEN IRA, a junior at Sarah Lawrence College, uploaded a video last March on We Happy Trans, a site that shares positive perspectives on being transgender.

title: Stage Scenes: Ethan Hawke
description: A look at some of the actors past stage performances.

title: New Year Begins With Flurry of Ad Industry Deals
description: 4:25 p.m. | Updated The new year has barely begun, but it looks as if it may be a busy one for deal-making on Madison Avenue.

title: Tip of the Week: Finding Flights Fast
description: Now that the holiday travel season has wound down, many people are starting to look ahead to a spring vacation. Services like Kayak let you efficiently compare multiple flights to find the best fares  as well as hotels and rental cars. The experimental Google Flight Explorer page now lets travelers compare potential trips with multiple destinations and varying lengths all at once  and also shows baggage fees and which flights have Wi-Fi service.

title: Q&A: Making the Mac Take Dictation
description: Q.

title: Q&A: Returning to Windows 7
description: Q.

title: Owners Give Approval and Offer an Apology
description: Amid apologies from the leaders who called for the lockout that shut down the N.H.L. for almost four months, the N.H.L. Board of Governors approved a tentative collective bargaining agreement with the players union Wednesday.

title: Where Modernity Frames Tradition
description: LONDON  The other day I caught up with New Court, the London headquarters for Rothschild Bank, designed by Ellen van Loon and Rem Koolhaas of OMA. Opulent, context friendly, almost stealthy, its an adult building, as one of the architects who worked on the project half-jokingly put it.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 10
description: ASAP Rocky, What Im Wearing Now; Marcelo Burlons T-shirts available; not just for the pool: do-Paris swimsuits; and Givenchy sneakers to order now.

title: Aerial Autos
description: A look at Matthew Porters photographs of muscle cars in flight.

title: S.E.C. Opens Investigation Into Herbalife
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is adding to the scrutiny of Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company that has been a favorite target of prominent hedge fund short-sellers.

title: Tell Us, if You Were a Tree ...
description: RED is Marc Jacobss favorite color, and, for what its worth, his favorite former porn star is named Eddie.

title: More Votes of Confidence for Skyfall and an Obstacle for Lincoln
description: The American Society of Cinematographers keeps giving accolades to Roger Deakins. Mr. Deakins earned his 11th nomination today, for the cinematography in Skyfall, alongside another veteran nominee, five-timer Janusz Kaminski (Lincoln). Seamus McGarvey (Anna Karenina), Danny Cohen (Les Miserables) and Claudio Miranda (Life of Pi) round out their picks.

title: TV Puppeteer at Center of Controversy Quits in Puerto Rico
description: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

title: Saudi Arabia Executes Sri Lankan Maid
description: A Sri Lankan woman who was employed as a domestic worker in Saudi Arabia was beheaded by the Saudi authorities on Wednesday after she was accused of murdering an infant in her charge and then sentenced to death in a case that the Sri Lankan government and human rights groups said was flawed.

title: A Touch of Autumn
description: Looks from Stella McCartney, Nina Ricci, Cline, Chlo, Lanvin and Philosophys prefall collections.

title: Do People Actually Shop on Phones? The Answer Is Decidedly Yes
description: In e-commerce, the mobile revolution is here.

title: Scene City: Alber Elbaz Takes the Stage
description: The YMA FSF Geoffrey Beene National Scholarship Awards holds its annual dinner.

title: Starting the Year With a Bon Mot
description: THE social calendar roared back to life on Tuesday night, when the YMA FSF Geoffrey Beene National Scholarship Awards held its annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Photos of The Moment | J.W. Anderson
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Its Anybodys Guess Now, So Whom Would You Nominate?
description: With only hours to go until the Academy bigwigs, telecast host Seth MacFarlane and actress Emma Stone announce the nominees, the race is still not settled. Even veteran prognosticators are split on what will make the cut for best picture  Lincoln? Argo? Zero Dark Thirty? Les Miz? Life of Pi is creeping up in the game too, with its DGA nomination for Ang Lee, and the Bagger keeps hearing raves for Silver Linings Playbook. Other indicators, like the cinematography society nominations, are only muddying the field, at least when it comes to handicapping. If youve got money in the game on the nominations tomorrow, check some of the round-up sites here and here, and otherwise, prepare to be surprised. Who do you want to see on the list of nominees tomorrow morning?

title: Easygoing Tailoring and Tweeds in Prefall Collections
description: THE prefall collections resumed this week after a holiday break (we heard about peoples trips to St. Barth and the Bahamas), with presentations by European brands. A sign of how important these showings are, creative directors were in attendance: Peter Copping of Nina Ricci, Clare Waight Keller of Chlo, Alber Elbaz of Lanvin. Store chiefs turned up as well, along with editors and a few celebrities.

title: A Closer Look at a Shift in Britains Near-Term Global Warming Forecast
description: 7:22 p.m. | Updates below |Quite a few professional climate skeptics have been crowing in the last few days about a 20-percent downward shift in the short-term forecast for global temperature (through 2017) from Britains weather and climate agency, best know as the Met Office.Here are the graphs showing the change, with the first published in 2011 (see the related release here, thanks toLeo Hickman of the Guardian) and the next one from late last month:

title: The Library at the Public
description: AS part of the Public Theaters renovation, a cocktail lounge called the Library was added that harkens back to the buildings bookish past as the Astor Library. Tucked into the new mezzanine level, the Library looks as if it has been there for years but is, in fact, an entirely new space designed by David Rockwell.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 9
description: A view of the day in sports, which included regional soccer tournaments and Australian Open qualifying matches.

title: Crossing the Line Online: Sexual Harassment and Violence in the Age of Social Media
description: Overview | How widespread are sexual harassment and sexual violence among teenagers today, and what role is social media playing? In this lesson, students take an anonymous survey about their own experiences. They then examine several recent articles, from The New York Times and elsewhere, about sexual harassment and assault in the age of social media. Finally, they discuss the issues that arise and consider ways to take action.

title: Scouting Report
description: FASHION SHOW

title: The Politics of the Platinum Coin
description: I dont feel qualified to comment definitively on the technical legality or constitutionality of the widely-bruited proposal that President Obama should respond to House Republicans debt ceiling brinksmanship by threatening to mint a $1 trillion platinum coin. But I do feel qualified to raise some questions about the political consequences that proponents of minting the coin (a group that includes some very smart peoplenot normally given to flights of ideological fancy) seem to think will follow from such a gambit. Here is Matt Yglesias, speaking for a multitude of would-be minters:

title: Weather Channel Takes a Galactic Leap
