description: Sure, John Gatins managed to somehow turn a grim script hed repeatedly abandoned over more than a decade into an acclaimed studio film, Flight, that netted him his first Oscar nomination. But the improbable part of the whole thing, for Mr. Gatins, was that Emma Stone managed to pronounce his name correctly when she announced his Oscar nomination early Thursday morning.

title: To Counter China, Japan and Philippines Will Bolster Maritime Cooperation
description: TOKYO  In a telling sign of how Chinas rise has helped turn former wartime foes into allies, Japan and the Philippines agreed on Thursday to cooperate more closely on maritime security.

title: Thinking About the Brink
description: The platinum coin discussion has moved with startling speed, from an idea nobody took seriously (and which, as Ive mentioned, senior officials were unaware of just last month), to assertions that its ridiculous and illegal, to grudging acknowledgment that its almost surely legal coupled with strained attempts to dismiss it as an option nonetheless.

title: Visions and Voices of a Nation Divided
description: WASHINGTON  In the pursuit of justice, what is unjustified? Are there limits to what may be done in service to a righteous cause? Abstract philosophical questions, perhaps, but also political ones. And in thinking about the Civil War, the answers affect our understanding of that bloody conflict.

title: Student Shot at California High School
description: LOS ANGELES  One student was shot at a California high school Thursday morning and another student was taken into custody, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Microsofts Surface Pro Tablet Changes the Game
description: A few months back, Microsoft raised a lot of eyebrows by selling its first computer: the Surface tablet. For the same $500 that gets you an iPad, it offers better hardware and more jacks. It has only one drawback: it cant run any PC software.

title: The 12.30.12 Issue
description: THE LIVES THEY LIVED

title: A Storm Victims Luck Changes
description: For Walter Connolly, whose home in Queens was battered by Hurricane Sandy, a chance encounter in Brooklyn provided a dose of good fortune.

title: Video: Russian Protesters in New York City
description: A political awakening in Russia, set off by disputed elections and a crackdown on the opposition, has reached the immigrant community in New York. A video by Natalia V. Osipova takes a look at activists who are planning to stage their next anti-Kremlin protest here on Sunday.

title: Zizi Limona
description: Inside the Middle Eastern restaurant in Williamsburg that is free of culinary or geographic limitation.

title: A Cruise Across the Mediterranean
description: THE oxtail is in a state of beautiful disarray, all tangled, velvety strands, the tough guy turned moony poet. It has been sluiced with silan (dates boiled down into honey), barraged with cinnamon sticks and braised for five hours until utterly undone.

title: Why an I.P.O. Revival May Have to Wait
description: History rhymes, even in the capital markets.

title: TimesCast Politics: A Closer Look at Immigration Reform
New York Legislators Debate Details of Gun Law
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers have agreed they want to ban military-style weapons and high-capacity magazines, but continue to negotiate over the fine print of a broad gun-control package that would include such a ban, state officials said Thursday.

title: The Boys of Girls
description: On the HBO comedy about a group of young women, the male characters play significant roles as well.

title: The Mostly Solved Deficit Problem
description: The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has a graph:

title: Carter Family Songs in Red Hook
description: On Aug. 1, 1927, a Virginian named A. P. Carter, along with his wife, Sara, and sister-in-law Maybelle, entered a makeshift studio in Bristol, Tenn. There they recorded a handful of the songs Mr. Carter had collected in his travels across Appalachia, and in the process more or less gave birth to modern country music.

title: Judge Postpones Sentencing for Wells Fargo Broker
description: A California federal judge has delayed the sentencing of Philip Horn, a Wells Fargo broker who pleaded guilty to defrauding more than a dozen clients.

title: Blasts in Pakistan Kill Scores and Stir Fears on Elections
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Bomb blasts in two Pakistani cities killed at least 115 people on Thursday and wounded more than 270, offering harrowing evidence of how the countrys myriad internal conflicts could destabilize it as elections approach.

title: Launching a Fragrance Line (In a Manner of Speaking)
description: BRANDS often give away trips like a weekend in New York, but now Axe, the mens grooming brand, has a giveaway that it can say, without hyperbole, is out of this world.

title: A God in Pursuit of a Redemption
description: Its not often that you go to the theater these days and find yourself excitedly questioning and rethinking your reactions. Self-examining art, after all, has become such a cozy genre in itself that it rarely startles.

title: Friends Without Benefits
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Taissa Farmiga, followed by a conversation with the writer, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: Herbalife Shares Fall After Company Defends Itself
description: Herbalife  sought on Thursday to counter accusations that the company was a fraud, but it appeared that investors were still trying to decide.

title: Jacki Weaver and the Lord of Greenwich Village
description: At her last go-around with the Oscars, in 2011, as supporting actress for Animal Kingdom, Jacki Weaver said she felt like a stunned mullet. Now, as a two-time supporting actress nominee, shes moving up in the sea. Maybe like a grouper, she mused, on the phone from Los Angeles. One of those things with the big puffy lips. I still havent done that to my lips. She laughed. Now that Im going so Hollywood, maybe thats the next thing.

title: A Debate, to and Fro
description: I was looking at old photos with some tennis buddies. We all laughed at the mullet I sported in my teens. But my comment that another pal had an amazing Jew-fro back then was met with uncomfortable silence. A colleague told me that the term is racist and insensitive. But if Afro is not racist, why is Jew-fro? Dan

title: An Old Magicians Ploy Adds a Bit of Flair to a Show Thats Not Exactly About Race
description: At the start of Tar Baby, Desiree Burch, an African-American comic and actress, says she doesnt want to do a show about race and then tells the audience members that they dont really want to see one. You want to say you saw a really important show about race, she says, a sneaky smile emerging, And I want to say I did that show.

title: Drilling Down: Andrew Sullivan Decides to Start His Own Business
description: This weeks Dashboard roundup of small-business news includes a link to a news article about Andrew Sullivans decision to leave The Daily Beast and move his popular blog, The Dish, to his own, subscription-based site. Mr. Sullivan writes about politics, the economy, business and culture, but is he ready to be a small-business owner? It seems hes off to a good start, with more than 16,000 subscribers already signed up  delivering almost half a million dollars in revenue almost instantly. We decided to ask him a few questions as he enters the world of entrepreneurship.

title: In Cyprus Bailout, Questions of Whether Depositors Should Shoulder the Bill
description: LONDON  On their Web sites, the largest of Cypruss failing banks brag that their client representatives are fluent in Russian. No indication, though, whether strizhka  Russian for haircut  is part of their lexicon.

title: Sharp Words From European Minister for Countries in North
description: BRUSSELS  Jean-Claude Juncker, the departing leader of the group of ministers who oversee the euro currency, sharply criticized Northern Europeans on Thursday for demanding austerity budgets from their southern neighbors.

title: Ask Well: Exercises for Tennis Elbow
description: Question:

title: In Saudi Town, Women Protest Detentions, Leading to Their Own
description: Last weekend, Saudi security forces encircled and arrested a small group of women who were protesting the long-term detention of relatives without charges on suspicion of terrorism, and the event has touched off nearly a week of unrest in the Saudi town of Buraida.

title: Citadel Posted 25% Return Last Year, Beating Industry Again
description: It was another good year for Kenneth C. Griffin.

title: A Wide-Awake Bradley Cooper; a Sleepy Jennifer Lawrence
description: Bradley Cooper was so busy cheering on his Silver Linings Playbook colleagues Robert De Niro, Jacki Weaver, Jennifer Lawrence and, especially, the director David O. Russell that he apparently failed to notice that hed been nominated for an Oscar himself.

title: Turn Off That TV and Go Outside and Play
description: For many of us, its the most indoorsy time of the year. Its cold, blustery and wet in much of the United States (we are ignoring my friend in the South, who posted to her Facebook page this morning complaining about the mosquitoes impeding her ability to get into her garden). Going outside is complicated, particularly if you have young children. When my four were small, I once calculated that I had to put a minimum of 28 extra items of clothing on them to get them outside in the snow  and, of course, when they came back in, they came in with all 28 items (one hoped), dripping.

title: Q&A: Dealing With Duplicate Work on Dropbox
description: Q.

title: Boy, 16, Charged With Murder in Death of Another 16-Year-Old
description: The police on Wednesday charged a teenager with murder in connection with the killing of a 16-year-old last week on the Lower East Side, following a confrontation between two groups of young men.

title: Homicide Tracking Site Expanding to Chicago
description: Homicide Watch, the Washington, D.C., Web site that tracks murders, has found another crime-ridden city to cover.

title: Film to Present Irans View of Argo Events
description: TEHRAN  A tough week for Ben Affleck just got tougher.

title: Tribal Lessons
description: The custom among the Pirah Indians of Brazil is that women give birth alone. The linguist Steve Sheldon once saw a Pirah woman giving birth on a beach, while members of her tribe waited nearby. It was a breech birth, however, and the woman started crying in agony. Help me, please! The baby will not come. Sheldon went to help her, but the other Pirah stopped him, saying that she didnt want his help. The woman kept up her screams. The next morning both mother and baby were found dead.

title: One Screen, Two Points of View
description: It would be hard to find another work of contemporary art that protests war with such soulful grace and understated wit as Meiro Koizumis Defect in Vision (2011), the main attraction of a small show at the Museum of Modern Art. Projected in somewhat different versions on opposite sides of a single screen in lustrous black and white, Mr. Koizumis 12-minute video meditates on the doomed, myth-saturated mind of Japans warrior class in the last days of World War II.

title: American Eden, After the Fall
description: WASHINGTON  It is a beautiful country. I never had the pleasure of seeing it before. So said the abolitionist John Brown gazing out over the Shenandoah Valley in Virginia, on a December morning in 1859. Americans have always reacted that way to their native land. It was their great possession. Europe had history stretching back into time. America had earth, here and now all potential, paradisally green.

title: Portable Navigation Learns Some New Moves at C.E.S.
description: Portable navigation devices arent dead yet  at least not at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Several makers are promoting their wares this week, including one company that is taking a page from built-in car systems to appeal to smartphone-addicted buyers.

title: A Google+ Hangout on Modern Slavery
description: Today I participated in a Google+ Hangout with two of my heroes, Somaly Mam of the Somaly Mam Foundation, and Rachel Lloyd of GEMS Girls. Both have devoted their lifes work to fighting sex trafficking, and heres our discussion. Let me know what you think in the comments section.

title: Chinese Newspaper Protests End, but Battle Over Censorship Is Unresolved
description: GUANGZHOU, China  The demonstrations have died down, and the reporters and editors are back to work at Chinas most prominent weekly newspaper. Its latest issue was published more or less on schedule. But the paper, Southern Weekend, is sure to remain a crucial battleground over Communist Party censorship.

title: Wet Wrinkled Fingers Evolved for Better Grip
description: The prunelike wrinkles that result from a long, hot bath may have an evolutionary purpose, researchers say.

title: Richard Nixons Legacy
description: Yesterday, on the occasion of what would have been Richard Nixons 100th birthday, many journalists rehearsed an argument that goes something like this: To one generation of Americans (who grew up, as I did, in the 60s and 70s), Nixon was the personification of political evil. But his achievements, and his liberalism by the standards of todays Republican Party, may ultimately prove more significant than his failings.

title: Making Scrimshaw a Sea Companion
description: Sailors on 19th-century whale ships faced oppressive boredom, interrupted by occasional life-threatening storms and hunting expeditions. As a kind of distracting therapy, they carved whale teeth and bones into everything from dominoes to bird cages, pieces that are collectively known as scrimshaw.

title: Low Lights, Good Drink and Welcoming Soundtracks
description: It seems to have been something of a stealth invasion. The Gnarly Vine in New Rochelle, which opened in 2007, was the first of the wine bars in southern Westchester County, followed by the rather luxe Vintage 1891  in Larchmont, the cozy Crush on the other side of that town, and then, last month, BarLees in Mamaroneck on the increasingly lively Mamaroneck Avenue.

title: Jan. 10 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the intensified debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web.

title: Where the Flippers Still Flap
description: Long eclipsed by video games, pinball machines can still be played in bars, cafes and some truly odd outposts across New York.

title: For Some Dead Brands, a Tortuous Path to Resurrection
description: At a time when bankruptcy auctions are filled with sad tales of beleaguered brands, snagging a well-known name for pennies on the dollar can seem like a sure bet for ambitious investors.

title: Where the Flippers Still Flap
description: MOST of the patrons at Mission Dolores in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn go for craft beers like Dark Horse Scotty Karate Scotch Ale or the house pour, Narragansett Lager. But some do not make it as far as the bar.

title: These Law Enforcers Will Stop at Nothing
description: Gangster Squad is less a movie than a costume party run amok. Set in a late-40s Los Angeles painted in cartoon colors rather than noir shadows, it is a hectic jumble of fedoras and zoot suits, stockings and cigarettes, and red femme-fatale dresses. The accessories of choice are guns of various calibers and styles, deployed to drown out  or perhaps to emphasize  knucklehead dialogue and inept storytelling.

title: Childrens Flu Medicine in Short Supply
description: As influenza cases surge around the country, health officials say they are trying to stem a shortage of treatments for children.

title: Come Together, Bruch and Bruckner
description: Despite the many decades that their lives overlapped and the consonance of their names, like the setup of a joke, Bruch and Bruckner have little in common.

title: The Civil War and American Art
description: Works from a new exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington.

title: The Healing Power of Yoga Controversy
description: Adapted from the Afterword to The Science of Yoga, paperback edition.

title: Daulerio Is Leaving as Gawker Editor
description: 5:49 p.m. | Updated Gawker Media is getting a change in leadership. A.J. Daulerio, who became the editor of Gawker just over a year ago, is leaving and will be replaced by the writer John Cook.

title: Raised by Political Activists in a Dictatorships Shadow
description: In Clandestine Childhood a 12-year-old Argentine boy is forced into playing a dangerous game of pretend. Its 1979, three years after a military coup dtat at home and exile in Cuba with his family. Now the boy, Juan (Teo Gutirrez Moreno), who will go by Ernesto, is returning to Argentina with his parents, Charo (Natalia Oreiro) and Daniel (Csar Troncoso), and his baby sister, Victoria. We think, Charo tells Juan, its the right time to carry on fighting. In between changing diapers she and Daniel will soon be fighting Argentinas right-wing military dictatorship in the name of freedom and country  and saluting fallen compaeros with rousing cries of Pern or death!

title: No Exit for Returning Son Who Upsets His Familys Expectation of Vengeance
description: It took more than four years for Sumeidas Song, the first opera by the young Arab-American composer Mohammed Fairouz, to have a staged production. He finished the score in 2008, when he was 22, having been possessed by its source, the play Song of Death by the prominent Egyptian writer Tawfiq al-Hakim, who died in 1987. On Wednesday night at Here Arts Center Sumeidas Song inaugurated Prototype, a new festival of boundary-blurring musical-theater works produced by Here and Beth Morrison Projects.

title: Cigarette Taxes vs. Cigarette Smuggling
description: Three of every five cigarettes consumed in New York State were smuggled in from lower-tax states in 2011, according to new estimates from the Mackinac Center for Public Policy, a free-market research organization in Michigan. That is the highest smuggling rate in the country.

title: Faith and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Sheehy: Music From a Garden at Dusk
description: Cavin-Morris Gallery

title: Louise Despont: Tide Fulcrum & the Motion of Fixed Stars
description: Nicelle Beauchene

title: For Wetter or for Worse
description: LIKE expectant parents marveling at a sonogram, Christine Dennison and Tim Taylor gazed at a grainy black-and-white image made by sound waves ricocheting through water, and knew their lives would be forever changed. This was two months before the couple, professional adventurers, were married at the Explorers Club in New York in December 2010. And the image was not of an embryo but of the R-12, a Navy submarine that had been lost for nearly 70 years.

title: Bjarne Melgaard: A New Novel by Bjarne Melgaard
description: Luxembourg & Dayan

title: El Anatsui: Pot of Wisdom
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Man in Plastic Ball Dies on Russian Ski Slope
description: MOSCOW  It is called a zorb, an outsize inflatable ball in which people strap themselves, then bounce down a ski slope and, presumably, have a good time doing so. But when a zorb veered off a ski run high in Russias Caucasus Mountains earlier this month, there was little anyone could do but watch as the two men inside careened along a jagged ridge and then plunged over a precipice.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Comedy

title: As Sea Gulls Hover, Three Old Friends Reunite for a Funeral
description: There isnt a dishonest moment in Fairhaven, Tom OBriens piercing, wistful portrait of three longtime buddies in their mid-30s who reunite around a funeral in a southeastern Massachusetts fishing community. It is the dead of winter, and Peter Simonites exquisite cinematography captures the bluish snow light with such acute sensitivity to atmosphere that even in the warmth of a theater you may shiver. A line of sea gulls hovers above a red-gold ribbon of a sunset on the horizon, signaling the distant promise of spring. But for now Fairhaven (a town of about 15,000 near New Bedford) is a place of hibernation.

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Movies

title: Pop Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Pop

title: A Rigoletto Reunion Just Might Save the Day
description: In a charming, only somewhat condescending scene in Quartet, Reginald Paget (Tom Courtenay), a retired opera singer, lectures a room full of hip-hop-loving teenagers about the similarities and differences between his favorite music and theirs. Opera, he explains, is about the expression of intense emotion through song. Rap, he surmises, sort of does the same thing. There is more to it than that, of course, but Reginald is distracted before he can finish the lesson. Perhaps he might have pointed out that singing opera (and rapping, for that matter) also demands a great deal of discipline and attention to technique.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Jazz

title: Digital Notes: Amazon Rips CDs Into the Cloud
description: Amazon is turning to an unlikely old friend to step up its competition in digital music: CDs.

title: Heavily Armed and Not All That Bright
description: Billy Bob Thornton and Eva Longoria may be the marquee names in The Baytown Outlaws, a splattering action comedy set in the Deep South. But the movies caffeinated juice is supplied by the actors playing the three Oodie brothers: cretinous, tattooed, muscle-bound hit men who are the ruling outlaws of this modern-day Wild West.

title: Appeals Court Rules for Warner Bros. in Superman Suit
description: LOS ANGELES  A quest by Warner Brothers to rid its Superman character of legal entanglements just took a major leap forward.

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Classical

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Theater

title: The Joy of Zadie Smith and Thomas Aquinas
description: What place does pleasure have in a good life? Should we, following Epicurus and John Stuart Mill, take maximal pleasure as our overriding goal? Or are there higher moral values that trump pleasure?

title: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Kenya, South Africa, Brazil and Venezuela.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Dance

title: First He Is Killed, and Then He Tells His Tale
description: It is usually not a smart idea to kill off a movies central character in its opening scene. But thats what happens in Struck by Lightning, a rancid comic satire whose 17-year-old protagonist, Carson Phillips (Chris Colfer of Glee), is felled by a bolt from the blue in his high school parking lot.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 11-17
description: Art

title: Out of Prison With Little Time to Waste
description: Banshee, the latest action-and-attitude series from Cinemax, comes on strong  almost comically so. In the first few minutes the shows unnamed hero walks out of prison and down some mood-setting railroad tracks, has sex with a waitress and steals a muscle car. Having checked those items off the hard-boiled mystery mans to-do list, he branches out, tracking down an Asian hairdresser-drag queen from his past, getting shot at and chased through the streets of Lower Manhattan and narrowly avoiding death by a sliding double-decker bus.

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 11-17
description: FLIGHT OF THE BUTTERFLIES

title: Spare Times for Jan. 11-17
description: Around Town

title: Exclusive | 39 East 74th Street
description: A six-story Upper East Side town house is about to come on the market for $29.99 million.

title: Warmly Renovated in Homage to Blue
description: A STATELY six-story Upper East Side town house, carefully renovated with both family and entertaining in mind, is about to come on the market for $29.99 million.

title: Washingtons Economic Boom, Financed by You
description: One damp morning this winter, Jim Abdo was looking through architectural renderings at his office in Logan Circle, one of the many leafy Washington neighborhoods anchored by a statue of a long-dead guy riding a horse. Abdo got his start as a property developer by buying decrepit buildings and modernizing them, and his headquarters shows off the trick. The adjoining storefronts had been stripped bare and rebuilt, all warm wood and cold glass with exposed brick and beams. It looked like a Brooklyn design studio or a Silicon Valley start-up, or at least how those offices might look in a Nancy Meyers movie. But Abdo has built his business in the unstylish land of think tanks and tepid salmon lunches and boxy womens suits.

title: A Judaica Collection Heads to Auction
description: Michael Steinhardt, the New York hedge fund manager, and Judy, his wife, have long supported Jewish causes. They are also known as passionate collectors, particularly of antiquities, though their holdings are far broader than most people realize. For decades the couple have quietly collected Judaica: illuminated manuscripts, elaborate silver vessels, candelabra and menorahs, as well as simple boxes used to collect money for charity.

title: Cuts in Military Spending, Past and Present
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Brings Misery to Syria Refugees
description: For Syrian refugees in the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan, winter has brought bitter new hardship and at least one death.

title: A Flip Side to the Attack on Fracking
description: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

title: NBC Hockey Announcer Calls Girls 12-and-Under Game
description: Mike Emricks vacation, otherwise known as the 113-day N.H.L. lockout, is about to end. Unable to call National Hockey League games, Emrick has not been fully idle. He has called some college hockey games for the NBC Sports Network and dabbled in calling figure skating for NBC. But his most unusual assignment came last month: play-by-play of a girls 12-and-under league game.

title: Citizen Foment That Fed Egypts Arab Spring
description: It has been almost two years since Egypts astonishing revolution began at Tahrir Square in Cairo, the Arab Springs biggest moment. As Fredrik Stantons documentary Uprising makes clear, though, what may have seemed a spontaneous protest by millions against the oppressive 30-year rule of President Hosni Mubarak actually capped years of growing unrest.

title: The New Old-Money Upper East Side
description: IN the TV series Gossip Girl, the Brooklyn-bred character Dan Humphrey is the self-described Lonely Boy, who, realizing he can never fit into the wealthy world of the Upper East Side of New York City, starts his Gossip Girl Web site, devoted to the scandalous lives of the privileged set.

title: Avoiding Loan-Modification Hoaxes
description: HOMEOWNERS wary of being taken in by bogus loan modification specialists should not assume that a law office is the safest conduit to their lender. Consumer advocates say a growing number of fraudulent modification services involve lawyers, or people who say they are lawyers.

title: SAP Steps on the Gas
description: SAP is betting that a product that brought in 1.5 percent of its 2011 revenue is ready to scatter the competition, maybe even revolutionize SAP itself.

title: Even Before Oath, Reminders That Being a Police Officer Isnt Easy
description: Hair buzzed or in buns, hands pressed to knees, backs as ramrod straight as the cushioned burgundy seats of the Queens College auditorium would allow, more than 800 new recruits sat waiting Thursday to be sworn in to the New York Police Department.

title: New York Examines Over 800 Rape Cases for Possible Mishandling of Evidence
description: The New York City medical examiners office is undertaking an unusual review of more than 800 rape cases in which critical DNA evidence may have been mishandled or overlooked by a lab technician, resulting in incorrect reports being given to criminal investigators.

title: Richard McWilliam, Trading Card Innovator, Dies at 59
description: Richard McWilliam, whose innovative leadership of the trading card company Upper Deck helped make it an industry powerhouse at a time when baseball and other sports cards were increasingly coveted by adult collectors, died on Jan. 5 at his home in Carlsbad, Calif. He was 59.

title: Windows 8 Failed to Reverse PC Slump During Holidays
description: For weeks, there have been signs that the public was not buying new PCs over the holidays in the numbers many had hoped. Now add to them new figures from IDC, one of the best-known scorekeepers for the market, showing that worldwide PC shipments declined 6.4 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier.

title: A Bad Budget Estimate Fit Nicely With Prevailing Politics
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: An Urban Standard, Coolly Reimagined
description: INTERNATIONAL-STYLE Modernism was supposed to have a purifying effect on architecture  out with the dowdy old, in with the austere elegance of the new!

title: The Clincher: It Matches My Knitting!
description: CHRISTINE LAVIN spent most of her adult life in the city, migrating north from the East Village to a series of apartments on the Upper West Side.

title: For International Students, College Checklists for January
description: This week, The Choice published our monthly Counselors Calendar, intended to keep students on track during the college admissions process.

title: Make the Cabinet More Effective
description: EVERY four years the cabinet briefly becomes the focus of national attention in December and January  only to fade from view again after Inauguration Day. True, individual cabinet secretaries will be in the news from time to time, but the cabinet as an institution will be all but forgotten. Yet the United States could benefit greatly by strengthening its scope and role.

title: Patriots Tight End Tandem Set to Play
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Barring an unforeseen calamity, Tom Brady will have his two young, productive tight ends available Sunday when the New England Patriots host the Houston Texans in an A.F.C. playoff game.

title: His Job Safe, Strauss Next Challenge Is the G.O.P.
description: With the latest threat to his leadership easily dispatched, the speaker of the House, Joe Straus, Republican of San Antonio, has proved once again that he can hold onto the third most powerful post in state government despite a vocal contingent of critics in his partys conservative wing.

title: Russia to Let a Few U.S. Adoptions Go On
description: MOSCOW  In what could be good news for a few prospective American parents, a top Kremlin official said Thursday that Russian children whose adoptions had already been approved by a court would be allowed to join their adoptive families in the United States and would not be affected by a ban on such adoptions that President Vladimir V. Putin signed into law last month.

title: GTT
description: DALLAS

title: Going With the Flow
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Im often asked, What is the most challenging part of being a professional soccer player?

title: California: Teenager Held in Shooting at High School
description: A 16-year-old boy with a shotgun shot a fellow student on Thursday and was taken into custody after staff members talked him into putting down the gun, law enforcement officials said. The teenager walked into a classroom at Taft Union High School just before 9 a.m. and shot a male student in the chest, then fired at another student and missed, said Ray Pruitt, a spokesman for the Kern County Sheriffs Office. A teacher who began to evacuate students through a rear door in the room and a campus supervisor persuaded the teenager to put down the gun. The victim was in critical condition in a hospital.

title: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Is Guarding Against Flu
description: The Archdiocese of Boston told priests on Thursday that they could suspend distributing communion wine from a shared chalice and suggested that they ask parishioners to bow instead of shaking hands to wish one another peace to curb the spread of flu. Auxiliary Bishop Robert P. Deeley also said communion ministers should sanitize their hands before and after giving communion and try not to touch parishioners hands or tongues when distributing communion.

title: Back From the Fiscal Abyss, California Balances Its Budget
description: SACRAMENTO  California has been Exhibit A for the fiscal upheaval that has rocked states throughout the recession. Year after year, California officials reported bigger and bigger deficits and sought to respond with spending cuts that left the state reeling.

title: Fumbler? Hold On, Ravens Rice Says
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Ray Rice sounded almost Nixonian.

title: C.E.S. 2013: Whats New in TVs
description: If you ask anybody, Whats the hottest thing youve seen at this years International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas?, you get a distant look or uncomfortable head-scratching. There are enough iPhone cases and Bluetooth speakers to overflow every landfill in America. But without Apple, Google, Microsoft or Facebook on the premises, whats left to exhibit?

title: Pentagon Acts to Limit Spending in Case Cutbacks Begin in March
description: WASHINGTON  Fearing that Congress and the president may not reach a deal on spending and the deficit, the Pentagons leadership is freezing civilian hiring, limiting maintenance work and delaying approval of some contracts.

title: Dont Close Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON

title: Beware Stubby Glasses
description: If you want to deter crime, it seems that youd want to lengthen prison sentences so that criminals would face steeper costs for breaking the law. In fact, a mountain of research shows that increases in prison terms have done nothing to deter crime. Criminals, like the rest of us, arent much influenced by things they might have to experience far in the future.

title: Gun Enthusiast With Popular Online Videos Is Shot to Death in Georgia
description: CARNESVILLE, Ga.  Keith Ratliff loved guns. He built his own rifles. He kept bullets in his cars cup holder. And on the rear window he slapped a sticker of the Starbucks Coffee mermaid firing two pistols.

title: Officer at Scotland Yard Is Guilty in Hacking Trial
description: LONDON  With a jurys unanimous guilty vote on Thursday, one of the most senior female officers at Scotland Yard became the first person to be convicted of a criminal offense in the phone hacking scandal that has enveloped Rupert Murdochs newspaper empire in Britain over the past 30 months.

title: Coins Against Crazies
description: So, have you heard the one about the trillion-dollar coin? It may sound like a joke. But if we arent ready to mint that coin or take some equivalent action, the joke will be on us  and a very sick joke it will be, too.

title: Neighborhood Joint: Jubilat Provisions
description: Inside Jubilat Provisions, south of Park Slope, Brooklyn, one encounters a curtain of smoked meat and sausage and a wall of imported Polish groceries.

title: A Polish Market With a Roll Call of Kielbasa
description: JUBILAT PROVISIONS is just a few blocks south of Park Slope, in an area that is gentrifying rapidly, but the Polish markets low-slung stretch of Fifth Avenue cornered by expressways still feels like the Brooklyn noir of Pete Hamill and Tim McLoughlin, a place where, not too long ago, one could stumble upon a body.

title: Influential Womens PAC to Back Council Speaker in Her Bid for Mayor
description: The New York City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who is seeking to rally female voters in her quest to be mayor, will pick up an endorsement on Friday from Emilys List, the influential national political action committee that backs Democratic women.

title: Iran Finding Some Ways to Evade Sanctions, Treasury Department Says
description: Despite onerous sanctions that have basically shut Iran out of the global financial system, the country is still finding some ways to bypass them, the Treasury Department said Thursday, describing what it called a small but emerging threat to the effectiveness of the sanctions effort.

title: In Second Look, Few Savings From Digital Health Records
description: The conversion to electronic health records has failed so far to produce the hoped-for savings in health care costs and has had mixed results, at best, in improving efficiency and patient care, according to a new analysis by the influential RAND Corporation.

title: Americas Health Disadvantage
description: It is no secret that the United States spends a lot more on health care than any other country yet ranks far behind other advanced nations in keeping its citizens healthy. This has been well documented in studies of older people and of newborn infants. It is now shockingly clear that poor health is a much broader and deeper problem than past studies have suggested.

title: A Tough Road for Federer in Australia
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  All eyes were on the placement of the No. 3 seeds  both of them the reigning Olympic gold medalists and United States Open champions  when the singles draws for the 2013 Australian Open were held Friday morning in Melbourne.

title: Alabama Gets Lost in the Matrix as Computer Ranks It No. 2
description: After Alabama thrashed Notre Dame on Monday night in the Bowl Championship Series title game, it was strikingly obvious which team was best.

title: Governor of Colorado Calls for Stricter Controls on Gun Sales
description: DENVER  Nearly six months after a mass shooting in a Colorado movie theater stirred cries for action on gun violence and mental illness, and with last months killings at Connecticuts Sandy Hook Elementary School still fresh in peoples minds, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper of Colorado called Thursday for universal background checks on all gun sales in the state.

title: Mali Government Is Left Reeling After Islamists Take Village Long Held by Army
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Islamists advanced into territory held by the Mali government on Thursday, overrunning a long-held defensive position in the center of the country and dealing a significant blow to the Malian Army in its attempt to contain the militants who have seized the nations north, according to a Malian Army officer.

title: New York City to Restrict Prescription Painkillers in Public Hospitals Emergency Rooms
description: Some of the most common and most powerful prescription painkillers on the market will be restricted sharply in the emergency rooms at New York Citys 11 public hospitals, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday in an effort to crack down on what he called a citywide and national epidemic of prescription drug abuse.

title: In Tighter Loan Rules, Wiggle Room for Banks
description: Homeowners got their first big chance to judge the fledgling regulator charged with policing abusive lending after the introduction of a broad set of mortgage rules on Thursday.

title: The Longest Nights
description: In early winter, when the heavy rains come to the Pacific Northwest and we settle under a blanket of sullen sky, something stirs in the creative soul. At the calendars gloaming, while the landscape is inert, and all is dark, sluggish, bleak and cold, writers and cooks and artists and tinkerers of all sorts are at their most productive.

title: A Passover Different From All Others
description: Candy-colored and sugarcoated, Let My People Go! tosses gay stereotypes into a Jewish holiday, adds the bedroom-door-banging beats of French farce, then piles on the dysfunction. And if youre still with me after that lot, then youre exactly the audience this movie is looking for.

title: Financial Crisis in the West Bank
description: The Palestinian Authority, which governs parts of the West Bank not under Israeli control, is in financial crisis. Its leaders are finding it increasingly difficult to pay 180,000 government employees, including security forces as well as other civil servants.

title: Did We Save the Whales?
Costs of Medical Care at the End of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigotry at Soccer Matches
description: To the Editor:

title: A Catalyst for New York Citys Rebirth
description: To the Editor:

title: Progress on Mortgage Regulations
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has issued long-awaited rules on mortgage lending that should help protect home buyers and the global financial system from a repeat of the subprime disaster. But the rules, which were announced on Thursday and go into effect next year, include some features that could hurt lower-income borrowers.

title: Priorities Are Far Apart as Karzai and Obama Meet
description: WASHINGTON  The last time President Obama and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan spoke face to face, it was on a video conference call on Sept. 21. Mr. Obama, distracted by an election in which the Afghanistan war was barely discussed, deflected Mr. Karzais most probing questions about the future of the American commitment there.

title: Texans Shrug Off Rout, and Questions It Raised, in Hope of Avenging It
description: HOUSTON  They have been derided and disrespected to such an extent that no one would have blinked if the Houston Texans had pushed back by now, letting fly a venomous tirade of trash talk at the doubters and defending their reputation.

title: A Celebration That Accentuated an Absence
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chvez is famous for speeches that last for hours, and Thursday should have been a special day for the loquacious socialist to let loose. But even with a parade of foreign dignitaries in town to laud him and a large, boisterous crowd on the day he was to be sworn in for a triumphal new term, Mr. Chvezs silence spoke loudest of all.

title: Day After Crash, Focus Is on Ferrys Control System
description: One day after a New Jersey commuter ferry slammed into a Lower Manhattan dock, injuring scores of passengers, the vessels captain trained investigators attention on problems with the control system, which he said did not respond as he tried to put the boat in reverse near shore.

title: Shutout in Cooperstown
description: Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens were not voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday. The rejection was hardly surprising but is still a stunning thing. Two of baseballs all-time best  Bonds, the home-run king, and Clemens, the pitcher with the most Cy Young awards  were shunned by baseball writers in what Tyler Kepner of The Times called the most resounding referendum yet on the legacy of steroids in baseball.

title: A Boyhood Friendship Fractured by War
description: An awkward blend of anti-Semitic atrocities and identity-swapping absurdity, the World War II drama My Best Enemy struggles to find a convincing tone. Sidling around the violence with a plot that juggles class resentment, counterfeit art and a limp love triangle, the film wobbles between high-stakes adventure and high-tone caper.

title: Heat, Flood or Icy Cold, Extreme Weather Rages Worldwide
description: WORCESTER, England  Britons may remember 2012 as the year the weather spun off its rails in a chaotic concoction of drought, deluge and flooding, but the unpredictability of it all turns out to have been all too predictable: Around the world, extreme has become the new commonplace.

title: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Votes to Approve Diabetes Drug
description: A federal advisory panel voted 10 to 5 on Thursday to approve a diabetes drug that could be the first in a new class of drugs in the United States to treat the disease, although several members raised concerns about potential cardiovascular risks and its use in people whose kidneys are impaired.

title: Death of a Prisoner
description: The filmmaker Laura Poitras follows the tragic return home to Yemen of a Guantnamo Bay prison detainee, Adnan Latif.

title: Death of a Prisoner
description: When President Obama pledged to close the Guantnamo Bay prison on his first day in office as president in 2009, I believed the country had shifted direction. I was wrong. Four years later, President Obama has not only institutionalized Guantnamo and all the horrors it symbolizes, but he has initiated new extrajudicial programs, like the presidents secret kill list.

title: Geithners Tenure Defined by Financial Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  In a matter of days, the nations Treasury secretary, Timothy F. Geithner, will leave the department he first joined more than two decades ago and re-enter private life for the first time since he was in his 20s.

title: Unpacking the Pandoras Box of Technology
description: Melding futurist theorizing and parental musings, Avi Zev Weiders overambitious, misshapen documentary Welcome to the Machine is a strange beast. Experts at describing our collective tomorrow share screen time in the film with the admonitory writings of Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabomber. Mr. Weider, meanwhile, stays up nights worrying aloud about his prematurely born triplets, the products of in vitro fertilization.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 11, 2013
description: Its absurd that this money will be distributed with such little regard to who was actually harmed.

title: Blatche Focuses on Job as Inquiry Continues
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Two days after a woman said she was sexually assaulted in Nets forward Andray Blatches hotel suite in Philadelphia, Blatche said he was not worried about an investigation.

title: For a Homeless Deaf Man, an iPad Makes Life Easier
description: Some of the problems Abreham Zemedagegehu faces as a homeless person in New York, like cold weather and lack of sleep, are fairly predictable. Some are less so: the police have gotten angry with Mr. Zemedagegehu because they did not realize that he could not hear their instructions. He was born with no hearing in one ear and only a little in the other.

title: Pakistan: A New Clash in Kashmir
description: The Pakistani Army said Thursday that Indian troops had killed another Pakistani soldier in the latest round of clashes in Kashmir, the disputed Himalayan region. In a sudden escalation of longstanding tensions this week, each side has bitterly accused the other of violating the de facto border in Kashmir, which both sides claim in its entirety. In recent days, India said two of its soldiers had been killed by the Pakistanis, and Pakistan had earlier accused India of killing one of its soldiers. The clashes have occurred amid tentative steps by the two nations to improve relations.

title: Man Sets Fire, Killing One Person, Police Say
description: After arguing with the mother of his child, a man set a fire in the second-floor hallway of his Manhattan apartment building on Thursday night, igniting a rapidly spreading, five-alarm blaze that killed one person and injured at least nine, the authorities said.

title: Monks in California Breathe Life Into a Monastery From Spain
description: VINA, Calif.  The rebirth of a medieval Cistercian monastery building here on a patch of rural Northern California land was, of course, improbable. William Randolph Hearst, the newspaper tycoon, brought the dismantled Santa Maria de vila monastery from Spain but failed to restore it. The City of San Francisco, after some fitful starts at bringing the monastery back to life, left its stones languishing for decades in Golden Gate Park. The Great Depression, World War II and lethargy got in the way.

title: Djokovic and Azarenka Are Top Seedings
description: Third-seeded Andy Murray, the Olympics and United States Open winner, landed in the same half of the draw for the Australian Open as No. 2 Roger Federer. That leaves top-seeded Novak Djokovic with the much easier task of a possible semifinal meeting against No. 4 David Ferrer.

title: As Nurse Lay Dying, Offering Herself as Instruction in Caring
description: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.  It was early November when Martha Keochareon called the nursing school at Holyoke Community College, her alma mater. She had a proposal, which she laid out in a voice mail message.

title: Russian Dressing
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  This one fell beautifully for me. I dont know whether you had the same experience. When you can lay in all those wonderful long answers (THE SITUATION! DRUNK DIALED! ROSETTA STONE!) it really does feel like the puzzle is doing the work for you, doesnt it?

title: Who Do You Think You Are, Anyway?
description: As you watch The Other Place, a slick, potently acted drama by Sharr White that opened on Broadway on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, it may strike you now and then that your mind is playing tricks on you. Facts that seem firmly established in one scene melt into vapor a few scenes later, leaving you with a vague itch to press pause to sort things out, or maybe rewind. Or both.

title: Corrections: January 11, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Terminally Ill, a Nurse Offers Herself as a Subject of Study
description: Martha Keochareon volunteered herself to be a lesson for nursing students interested in learning about pancreatic cancer, death and dying, and pain management.

title: Advocate for the Homeless Announces a Mayoral Run
description: George T. McDonald said he spent 700 consecutive nights in Grand Central Terminal during the grittier days of 1980s New York, offering food and help to homeless people, in an effort that he later developed into a nonprofit organization, the Doe Fund, which helps find jobs for the indigent.

title: F.D.A. Warns 2 Producers on Egg Safety
description: Two large egg producers have received warning letters from the Food and Drug Administration, which said they violated a two-year-old rule aimed at preventing salmonella contamination.

title: Associate of Arms Dealer Arrested
description: Richard A. Chichakli, a dual United States and Syrian citizen who has been described as a close associate of the Russian arms trafficker Viktor Bout, was arrested on Wednesday in Australia, American authorities said. He is expected to be extradited to the United States, where he faces charges in Manhattan of conspiring with Mr. Bout to violate international sanctions by attempting to buy two Boeing aircraft from companies based in the United States. Mr. Chichakli, whohaspreviously denied being in business with Mr. Bout, faces a maximum 20-year sentence on each of nine counts if convicted, prosecutors said. Mr. Bout is serving a 25-year sentence for conspiring to sell weapons to people he believed were Colombian terrorists intent on using the arms to kill Americans. Michele M. Leonhart, the administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, called Mr. Chichakli a key criminal facilitator in Viktor Bouts global weapons trafficking regime.

title: George T. McDonald Announces Candidacy
description: Mr. McDonald, an advocate for the homeless and president of the Doe Fund, says that he will run to be the next mayor of New York City. Michael M. Grynbaum of The New York Times analyzes his chances.

title: Knicks Try to Focus as Anthony Has to Sit
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Although Coach Mike Woodson was disappointed that the N.B.A.suspended Carmelo Anthony for Thursdays game against the Pacers, there was little time to bemoan the decision during the Knicks morning shootaround.

title: A Lesson in Dying
description: With less than two months to live, Martha Keochareon teaches students about cancer and dying.

title: Bank Deal Ends Flawed Reviews of Foreclosures
description: Federal banking regulators are trumpeting an $8.5 billion settlement this week with 10 banks as quick justice for aggrieved homeowners, but the deal is actually a way to quietly paper over a deeply flawed review of foreclosed loans across America, according to current and former regulators and consultants.

title: From Freezing to Burning: Extreme Weather Across the World
description: Around the world, extreme has become the new commonplace.

title: In Transition, Hagel Gets Up to Speed on Iran
description: WASHINGTON - Chuck Hagel, President Obamas nominee for secretary of defense, is perceived to have an Iran problem. And this week he has started to deal with it.

title: Errors Mount at High-Speed Exchanges in New Year
description: Confidence-shaking technology mishaps have been an almost daily occurrence at the nations stock exchanges in the new year.

title: As Child, Suspect Fixated on Explosives, Police Say
description: As a boy, Aaron Greene fixated on weapons and explosives: he rigged booby traps, assembled crude pipe bombs and fashioned a potato launcher with materials he bought at a local hardware store, according to the police and former neighbors.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 10
description: A view of the day in sports, from the daring heights of snowboarding to the dangerous moves of the Dakar Rally.

title: In the New Legislature, Some Demographic Shifts
description: If state lawmakers in the 83rd legislative session ever need legal representation, they will not have to look far; nearly a third of their colleagues are lawyers. If they want a tutorial on new technology, they will have help  the Legislature, with its dozens of new members, is becoming increasingly youthful, according to research into legislative records.

title: Japan Approves $116 Billion for Urgent Economic Stimulus
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government approved emergency stimulus spending of more than $100 billion on Friday, part of an aggressive push by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to kick-start growth in Japans long-moribund economy.

title: Jeanne Manford, 92, Who Stood Up for Her Gay Son, Inspiring Others, Dies
description: After her openly gay son was beaten in April 1972 for protesting news coverage of the gay rights movement, Jeanne Manford, an elementary school teacher in Flushing, Queens, did not tell him to stop embarrassing the family. She wrote a letter to The New York Post criticizing the police for not protecting him.

title: Obama Nominates Lew for Treasury
description: President Obama nominated Jacob J. Lew, the White House chief of staff, to succeed Timothy F. Geithner as secretary of the treasury.

title: Lottery Numbers
Jeffrey OConnell, Legal Scholar of No-Fault Coverage, Dies at 84
description: Jeffrey OConnell, a legal scholar who helped devise the model for no fault auto insurance to protect traffic accident victims, lower car insurance rates and curb ambulance-chasing lawyers, died on Sunday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 84.

title: Consent Rule May Proceed for a Circumcision Ritual
description: New York City health officials may proceed temporarily with a plan to require parental consent before an infant may undergo a particular Jewish circumcision ritual, a federal judge ruled Thursday.

title: A Chainsaw-Free Mainstream
description: For the past few years, the Oscars have been haunted by the fear that the pictures, to paraphrase Norma Desmond, had gotten small. Or at least that the kind of pictures worthy of Academy Awards no longer operated at a scale demanded by a worldwide broadcast. The box office numbers of best picture nominees seemed to be shrinking as the movie business split in two. At one end was a specialized boutique outfit, at the other a franchise factory geared to the international mass market. Between those poles was a hole where the serious mainstream movies used to be.

title: Knicks Miss Anthony, and Too Many Shots, in Loss to Pacers
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Coach Mike Woodson put his hands on his head before looking down and shaking it. J. R. Smith jumped up and down, wishing the ball would bounce off the rim and into the net. Even Tyson Chandlers tip-ins found a way to spin out.

title: Evan Connell, Novelist of Many Genres, Is Dead at 88
description: Evan S. Connell, a versatile writer praised for his spare portrayal of the frost and repression within a fictional upper-class Midwestern family as well as for his account of the very real and bloody battle that was Custers Last Stand, was found dead early Thursday in an assisted-living facility in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 88.

title: Anheuser-Busch Will Promote Two New Products in Super Bowl XLVII Ads
description: 11:33 a.m. | Updated The marketer that typically buys the most commercial time during the Super Bowl each year has ambitious plans for the game this year, which include pitches for two new products.

title: Word of the Day | offhand
description: offhand \f-hand, -hand\ adjective and adverb

title: Snake on a Plane, in Real Life
description: HONG KONG  A 10-foot python managed to cling to the outside of a Qantas plane during a two-hour flight from Australia as stunned passengers watched, a feat that drew inevitable comparisons to the popular 2006 movie Snakes on a Plane.

title: Huell Howser, Folksy Public TV Host, Is Dead at 67
description: He interviewed painters on the Golden Gate Bridge and sat atop the H of the Hollywood sign. He followed Julie Nixon Eisenhower up the stairs to her fathers tiny boyhood bedroom in Yorba Linda, Calif. He profiled an 88-year-old white woman who proudly remained in her South Central Los Angeles home after all her white neighbors fled to make way for black residents.

title: City Suspends License of Operator in Queens Crane Collapse
description: The operator of a crane that collapsed in Queens on Wednesday afternoon, trapping three construction workers and injuring seven in all, had been trying to lift a load more than twice the cranes capacity, the city said Thursday in a statement announcing a suspension of the operators license.

title: Lessons From India: How to Promote the Polio Vaccine in Pakistan
description: India currently is observing a significant public health milestone: two full years without a new case of poliomyelitis, the paralyzing and sometimes deadly virus that has robbed so many millions of our children of productive futures.

title: News Quiz | January 11, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Carbon Taxes Provoke Debate on Economic Impact
description: THE HAGUE  Since the beginning of the year, California, the most populous of the United States, has a price on carbon emissions.

title: Mourning Online for Pakistani Rights Activist Killed in Quetta Bombing
description: Last Updated, 3:17 p.m. Bombs in two Pakistani cities killed at least 115 people on Thursday, with the worst carnage inflicted by two explosions a few minutes apart in the southwestern city of Quetta, taking the lives of at least 81 people. As my colleague Declan Walsh reports from Islamabad, Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a Sunni militant group with strong ties to the Pakistani Taliban, claimed responsibility for the attack in a Quetta neighborhood dominated by ethnic Hazara Shiites.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 11
description: NEWS The disappearance of Sombath Somphone, leader of a respected nonprofit organization in Laos, who was last seen being stopped at a police checkpoint, has raised alarms that the Southeast Asian communist countrys nascent liberalization could be sliding backward. Thomas Fuller reports from Vientiane, Laos.

title: Report Depicts Horrific Pattern of Child Sexual Abuse by BBC Celebrity
description: LONDON  Scotland Yard and Britains leading child welfare group drew a horrific picture of more than 200 cases of sexual abuse of victims as young as 8 by the BBC host Jimmy Savile in a report released on Friday, and prosecutors admitted for the first time that shortcomings in interviewing some of the victims allowed Mr. Savile to escape prosecution before his death at the age of 84 in 2011.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Jan 11, 2013
description: This question was written by Katherine Schulten. It comes from the Opinionator piece Why Do Stars Think Its O.K. to Sell Soda?

title: Flu Season Has Arrived With a Vengeance
description: In Flu Widespread, Leading a Range of Winters Ills, Donald G. McNeil Jr. and Katharine Q. Seelye report on the many flu and flulike ailments making the nation ill.

title: Syrian Rebels Say They Seized Helicopter Base in the North
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian rebels, led by jihadist battalions, said Friday that they seized the largest helicopter base in the north of the country, a potentially significant blow against the governments escalating air war that also highlighted lingering questions about the prominent role of Islamic extremists in the uprising.

title: Hotel Fire in Philippines Kills 7, Officials Say
description: OLONGAPO CITY, Philippines  A fast-moving fire ripped through a small hotel early Friday morning near the former United States naval base in Subic Bay, killing seven people, including four foreign visitors to the area, officials said.

title: Where the Viper Gets Its Vroom
description: Inside a newly reopened Chrysler plant in Detroit.

title: What Were the Best Movies You Saw in 2012?
description: The Oscar nominations are in, two weeks earlier than usual this year, and nine films are nominated for Best Picture.

title: Mamas, Dont Let Your Babies Grow Up to Be Newspaper Photographers
description: When Fred R. Conrad was growing up in Jackson, Mich., in the 1950s, his first heroes were the cowboys he saw on his familys black-and-white television. He dreamed of being the Lone Ranger, or Roy Rogers. His mother even taught him to ride on a retired cow pony named Brazos.

title: Fijis Government Rejects Proposed Constitution
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Fijis military government intends to discard a draft constitution unveiled last month by a renowned professor of constitutional law, a key component of measures intended to help return the coup-plagued nation to democracy ahead of elections set for late next year, the nations ruler has announced.

title: Brawling With Bulls for Major Bucks
description: EIGHT SECONDS hardly sounds like an eternity  unless you have a 1,500-pound bucking bull between your spurs by the name of Whiskey Cures Ugly. Imagine yourself aboard a twisting roller coaster in the midst of an earthquake with a sonic boom for a soundtrack. Eight seconds suddenly becomes harrowingly timeless for a professional bull rider.

title: A Dream College Acceptance Arrives at Bedtime
description: In my last post, I wrote about my reaction to finding out that my mother has breast cancer. Her recovery is going well. She is preparing to start chemotherapy.

title: France Battling Islamists in Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali  The international standoff with Islamists controlling northern Mali took a decisive turn on Friday, as French forces engaged in an intense battle to beat back an aggressive militant push into the center of the country.

title: The Early Word: A Broader Plan
description: In Todays Times:

title: Why the Unemployment Rate Is So High
description: Laura DAndrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Bill Clinton.

title: Divisional Matchups: Defense Is Crucial
description: Packers at 49ers

title: China Said to Crack Down on Censorship Protests
description: People across China have been detained or questioned in recent days by security officers for publicly supporting the journalists at the Southern Weekend newspaper who have been protesting strict censorship, according to a human rights group and online posts discussing the plights of some detainees.

title: Taking a Zen Approach to Caregiving
description: You try to help your elderly father. Irritated and defensive, he snaps at you instead of going along with your suggestion. And you think this is so unfair and feel a rising tide of anger.

title: Business Owners Reflect on Small Victories  and the Dangers of Growth
description: In my last post, She Owns It business group members looked back on what it took to survive 2012 and talked about their goals for the New Year. This post continues that conversation.

title: Quirks of the Game: The Case for Fred McGriff
description: Buried far down the list of Hall of Fame vote-getters released Wednesday is one who didnt capture any headlines for his lack of votes. Thats only fitting because during his career, his achievements were increasingly buried beneath headlines touting big-name players with big muscles. When it comes to the Hall of Fame, Fred McGriff is perhaps the quintessential victim of the way the game was corrupted by the players, players union, owners and the commissioner.

title: Railway Fare Increase Announced
description: The Indian government said Wednesday that it would raise all railway passenger fares, which would be the first across-the-board increase in nine years, as it grapples with a growing fiscal deficit and weak finances.

title: Democracy. Period.
description: MADRID  This week a video went viral in Spain. It shows an unidentified man and woman standing in an empty room while a futuristic, techno-inflected beat zaps behind them. They stare at the camera with toothy smiles and declare that they are holding a press conference from the future.

title: European Regulators Propose Overhaul of Benchmark Interest Rate
description: LONDON  European regulators called for a major overhaul of a benchmark interest rate on Friday, but stopped short of demanding direct regulatory oversight after a rate-rigging scandal.

title: India Moves to Block Dolphin Shows, Citing Cruelty
description: Indian animal welfare officials moved this week to block plans to put performing dolphins on display at theme parks and malls across the country, saying it would violate federal laws about cruelty to animals.

title: Big Four Still Missing a Vital Element: Nadal
description: MELBOURNE  With another Australian Open about to begin on Monday, the addition and subtraction continues at the top of the mens game.

title: On Our Radar: Trapped Whales Appear to Break Free
description: About a dozen killer whales that had been trapped under sea ice and bobbing frantically for air around a single hole appear to be free after a shift in the ice, village officials in Canadas remote north say. [Associated Press]

title: In 40-Year Marriage, Gay Sons Struggle Was a Unifier
description: Boomings Making It Last column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

title: Regulators Will Review Boeing 787s for Safety
description: Federal authorities on Friday ordered a comprehensive review of electrical systems in Boeings new 787 Dreamliner after a spate of incidents, including a battery fire this week in Boston, 15 months after the technologically advanced aircraft came into service.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Oscar Nods, Music by Beats, and a Space Age Ad Promotion
description: The 85th Academy Awards season got under way on Thursday as the heaviest number of Oscar nominations  including nods for best picture  went to Lincoln, about a presidents struggle with the Civil War; Life of Pi, about a shipwreck survivor and a tiger; Silver Linings Playbook, a comedy, of sorts, about a man with bipolar disorder; and Les Misrables, filled with songs of the oppressed. Close behind were Argo, about political captivity; Amour, a French-language film about aging and dying; and Django Unchained, a tale of slavery and retribution. Beasts of the Southern Wild, which chronicles a childs encounters with rising floodwaters in the bayou, and Zero Dark Thirty, about the murky pursuit of a national enemy, also received best picture nominations. As Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report, the shocker was a triple snub in the best director category: Kathryn Bigelow (Zero Dark Thirty), Ben Affleck (Argo) and Quentin Tarantino (Django Unchained) were passed over despite widespread expectations that one or all of them would be nominated. Instead, the nominations went to Steven Spielberg (Lincoln), Ang Lee (Life of Pi), Michael Haneke (Amour), David O. Russell (Silver Linings Playbook) and Benh Zeitlin (Beasts of the Southern Wild, his first film). In all, nine films received best picture nominations in a field that can include as many as 10 or as few as 5, depending on how voters from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences spread their hand.

title: Top Pirate Quits as Tide Turns Against Somali Raiders
description: LONDON  A notorious Somali sea raider known as Big Mouth is a pirate with a retirement plan.

title: Opinion Report: The Hall of Fame
description: From the editorial page

title: This Week's Movies | Jan. 11, 2013
description: The New York Times critics on Gangster Squad, Quartet and Clandestine Childhood.

title: Friday Reading: Lower Doses of Sleep Drugs Advised for Women
Wells Fargo Kicks Off Bank Earnings
description: WELLS FARGO KICKS OFF BANK EARNINGS | Investors are gearing up for the latest round of bank earnings reports, after a sluggish year for Wall Street. Wells Fargo announces results at 8 a.m. with a conference call set for 10 a.m. Analysts are expecting fourth-quarter earnings of 89 cents a share, an improvement over the period a year earlier, amid signs that the housing market may be beginning a recovery. Still, Wells Fargos net interest margin, the difference between what the bank charges borrowers and pays depositors, has fallen in recent quarters.

title: Wells Fargos Mortgage Gains May Be Unsustainable
description: 8:40 p.m. | Updated

title: One Mans Noise Is Anothers Symphony
description: Dear Diary:

title: Murder in Paris
description: ISTANBUL  It is easy to be cynical about the Turkish governments stated intention to bring about a settlement to the countrys vexing Kurdish problem. Yet someone took very seriously the authorities recently announced decision to negotiate with Abdullah Ocalan, the founder of the Kurdistan Workers Party (P.K.K.), on his island prison not far from Istanbul.

title: Tebow May Not Have a Place to Land
description: Tim Tebow may be too popular to play football anymore.

title: Possible Client Redemptions Weigh on SAC Capital
description: The hedge fund giant SAC Capital Advisors is steeling itself for a possible wave of withdrawal requests from clients amid the governments intensifying scrutiny of its trading practices.

title: Is Japan the Country of the Future Again?
description: In the broad sense, surely not, if only because of demography: the Japanese combine a low birth rate with a deep cultural aversion to immigration, so the future role of Japan will be severely constrained by a shortage of Japanese.

title: California in Surplus
description: Guess whose state budget crisis seems to be over?

title: Cities on Silk
description: In 2010, Azin Valy, a co-founder of I-Beam Design, an architecture firm in Manhattan, was doing research for an urban design show called FORECLOSED: Rehousing the American Dream held at the Museum of Modern Art in 2012. As she looked at dozens of aerial views of cities in Texas, Nevada and Florida, showing not just the street grids but also the mountains, rivers and lakes, she said, These cities are so beautiful. Why hasnt anyone used them in fashion?

title: Daily Report: Tech Problems Plague Exchanges
description: Confidence-shaking technology mishaps have been an almost daily occurrence at the nations stock exchanges in the new year, Nathaniel Popper reports in Fridays New York Times.

title: Thai Buyer Contends Ping An Sale Is on Track
description: SHANGHAI  The Charoen Pokphand Group of Thailand said on Friday that it had the resources to complete its planned $9.4 billion acquisition of shares in Ping An Insurance of China, disputing reports this week that its deal to buy the stake from the British bank HSBC was in jeopardy.

title: The Hall of Fame Took My Advice
description: Two years ago, when Mark McGwire finally publicly apologized for using steroids, I argued that extending forgiveness to McGwire was a necessary step toward a broader reckoning with the fact that the vast majority of steroid users from his era other potential Hall of Famers very much included  will probably never be exposed:

title: Arraignment in Colorado Theater Shooting Postponed
description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  The judge hearing the case against James E. Holmes, the man accused of killing 12 people and wounding dozens more at an Aurora, Colo., movie theater in July, agreed on Friday to postpone Mr. Holmess arraignment for two months at the defenses request.

title: Official Urges Greater Accountability by Euro Members
description: BRUSSELS  Olli Rehn, the European commissioner in charge of the euro, defended the blocs austerity policies on Friday and urged legislators to pass a law that would let him push countries even harder to shore up their finances.

title: Hot Wheels in Hot Pursuit of Artifice
description: MATTHEW PORTER is shopping online for a vintage muscle car, and not just any car will do. He is tempted by a 66 Dodge Charger but isnt crazy about its glossy white paint job. A 72 Plymouth Road Runner would appeal, but its tricked out for racing, with 43 painted on its roof and Pepsi decals all over. The 70 Plymouth Superbird? It lacks the steroidal contours he craves. He passes on a couple of convertibles and then discovers a 67 Ford Mustang Shelby GT 500.

title: Oscars First Family? Depends on How You Count
description: 6:25 p.m. | Updated  The Hustons  grandfather Walter, father John and daughter Angelica  are known as a three-generation Oscar family, with dozens of nominations among them.

title: What Were Reading
description: Smithsonian: Everything you were afraid to ask about the Scoville scale, that measure of fiery heat. (The worlds hottest pepper, the Trinidad Scorpion Maruga, rates at two million Scoville heat units.) Blame it all on Wilbur Scoville, a pharmacist, who introduced the scale in 1912.  Glenn Collins

title: Status Updates
description: Last year, a line in an article on the fate of Barnes & Noble gave my heart pause  and sent me on an all-consuming tear. If we lose more brick-and-mortar bookstores, the article noted, the classics in particular will be hard hit.

title: Up Front
description: In her review of Susanna Sonnenbergs She Matters, a memoir of female friendships, Susan Chira makes note of a particular kind of connection that can develop between women: In the land of Cheerios, dirty diapers, fleeting naps and interrupted sleep, other mothers are a lifeline.

title: Girls
description: This memoir of female friendships inspired a parlor game I suspect many readers will want to play  musing about the friends who shaped our own lives. The first best friend, the one to whom you clung and whispered all your secrets, and then outgrew. The big-sister friend, who married before you, had children before you and showed you her way of navigating those passages. The friend who let you down, who vanished during a crisis, and the one who stayed by your side. The friend you wronged without understanding how. The friend you simply had fun with, and the one you called when you were in despair.

title: Inside the List
description: AGAINST ORGANIZATION: Some Scientologists are more famous than others. Even without Going Clear, Lawrence Wrights book about the churchs ties to Hollywood, most people could tell you that Tom Cruise and John Travolta are members of L. Ron Hubbards club. But what about famous authors?

title: Paperback Row
description: THE VANISHERS,  by Heidi Julavits. (Anchor, $15.) Julavitss darkly comic novel follows Julia Severn, a talented student at an institute for psychics in New Hampshire. After suffering a near-lethal psychic attack at the hands of her jealous mentor, Julia is lured into searching for an enigmatic French artist who may hold insights into her mothers long-ago death.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE TWELVE TRIBES OF HATTIE,  by Ayana Mathis. (Knopf, $24.95.) Mathiss deeply felt first novel works at the rough edges of history, within a brutal and poetic allegory of a black family beset by tribulations after the Great Migration to the North.

title: Priests of the Invisible
description: Last summer and fall, the Museum of Modern Art displayed a work called Tapestry of the Thousand Longest Rivers in the World. A witty, complex piece by an Italian artist named Alighiero e Boetti, it deserved the long look that museumgoers gave it. But visitors who saw the work during a previous exhibition, in 2008, were at least as tickled by the text of an accompanying plaque: In 1968 Alighiero Boetti changed his name by inserting an e (and in Italian) between his first and last names to indicate that he (and by extension, anyone) was not a single but a multiple self.

title: Styron Visible
description: For a person whose sole burning ambition is to write  like myself  college is useless beyond the sophomore year, William Styron wrote to his father in 1946, after returning from Platoon Commander School in Quantico, Va., to resume his studies at Duke. Styron would go on to graduate  he was a nice boy, and eager to please his doting father  but he wasnt kidding about his monomaniacal focus on writing, and in many ways the early pages of this splendid book are the hardest. They are very earnest, albeit not in the Hemingway sense  that is to say, theres nothing here about getting ones leg nearly blown off in Italy or falling in love with ones nurse or trout fishing in Michigan. In the young Styrons case, it was all but entirely about the writing. Happily, his diligence soon bore fruit: by Page 21 his mentor at Duke, William Blackburn, has already brought Styrons work to the attention of Hiram Haydn, the editor at Bobbs-Merrill who would eventually publish Styrons first novel, Lie Down in Darkness, in 1951, when the author was only 26.

title: Rethinking the Unthinkable
description: One of the striking features of our long coexistence with nuclear weapons is how the fear of them has receded. In the 1950s and 60s, when Hiroshima and Nagasaki were vivid memories, these novel and monstrous weapons loomed over our politics and penetrated our popular culture. The nuclear doomsday thriller On the Beach filled us with visceral dread. The dark satire of Dr. Strangelove played on real concerns. The laughter provoked by the twisted genius of Tom Lehrer was nervous laughter:

title: Dacca Dreams
description: Somewhere in the middle of Scenes From Early Life, Philip Henshers circuitous new novel of wartime Bangladesh, a lawyer and his wife are arguing over the chilies and tomatoes and mangos that have been left out to dry on their balcony.

title: Ableman Unbound
description: Words are everything to Guy Ableman, a novelist for whom prose celebrates our lower instincts and is therefore greater than poetry. His subject is sex (a giddy reviewer praises one of his novels as a verbal spermfest), and when hes not actually writing hes preparing to, by mouth-writing on solitary London walks. Despite being an accomplished and celebrated writer with a beautiful wife and an equally beautiful mother-in-law, he is deeply unhappy. Why? Because Guy Ableman has been born into a postliterate age.

title: Home Front
description: Here are two new novels by prizewinning authors, both set during World War II and featuring a brother in the armed services who is missing in action. Both are for middle-grade readers, though one is more or less intended for girls and the other for boys.
