Patricia Reilly Giff is the author of many books for children, two of which (Lilys Crossing and Pictures of Hollis Woods) have won Newbery Honor awards. This is Clare Vanderpools second novel; her first, Moon Over Manifest, won the Newbery Medal in 2011.

title: Midnight in Paris
description: Just One Day, the new novel by Gayle Forman (author of the well-received If I Stay and Where She Went), has an epigraph from As You Like It: All the worlds a stage, and all the men and women merely players. The story of Allyson, a good girl on a European tour, and Willem, an adventurous Dutch actor, is about playing and playacting in all their many senses. After seeing him perform in Twelfth Night, Allyson impulsively accepts Willems invitation to spend a day together in Paris. He calls her Lulu, the nickname of the silent film actress Louise Brooks, and neither asks her real name nor discloses much about himself.

title: A Wizard in Training
description: Creating a middle-grade fantasy world comes at the price of scrutiny and comparison. There are so many on the shelves these days; any new one must work hard to justify its existence.

title: Bookshelf: Artists
description: Picture books about Henri Matisse, Horace Pippin and more.

title: Bookshelf: Artists
description: COLORFUL DREAMER  The Story of Artist Henri Matisse.  By Marjorie Blain Parker.Illustrated by Holly Berry.  32 pp. Dial. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

title: Becoming America
description: Oh, the American spirit! Is there a more slippery notion? Its so difficult for adults to wrap our heads around Americas national character  to absorb its inconsistencies and hypocrisies, opportunities and injustices  that even the professional patriot Walt Whitman had to cop to contradicting himself in his attempt to contain our multitudes.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Bill Keller discusses three new books about nuclear weapons; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Susan Chira talks about Susanna Sonnenbergs She Matters; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Insurgents in Jharkhand Plant Bombs Inside  Bodies
description: Maoist insurgents in Jharkhand state have started to hide explosive devices in the bodies of their enemies, police officials said, a new tactic in the long battle between Indian security forces and the insurgents.

title: Senator Rockefeller Is Retiring After Five Terms
description: 11:22 p.m. | Updated  A revised version of this post is available here.Senator John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia, the scion of the Rockefeller family who established himself as a liberal voice in Congress, said on Friday that he would retire in 2014 at the completion of his fifth term in the Senate.

title: Common Core Practice | A Mining Village in Peru, Weapons in Syria and Inaugural Poetry
description: Each Friday we collaborate with a classroom in New Jersey to test and publish three short writing ideas that address Common Core Standards and that are grounded in New York Times content.

title: Leading Off: The N.F.L.s Collision Course, With Itself
description: The two sets of football stories keep rolling along, as if on different sets of train tracks, not yet crossing but getting closer, their impending collision bringing something no one can yet imagine.

title: Seth MacFarlane Is Already Under Fire, and He Hasnt Even Hosted Yet
description: Seth MacFarlanes unusual foray into the Oscar nominations morning  its not common for a host to help with the announcement  left a lot of people worrying about his coming turn as host of the telecast. Is Seth MacFarlane already a terrible Oscar host? wondered Slate.

title: Riff, the Beloved Community
description: There are times  like when John Coltrane plays A Love Supreme  that jazz becomes a mystical experience, burrowing deep into your soul. The Rev. Peter Heltzel knows a bit about both, being a jazzhead and a theologian. A few years ago, spellbound by the artistry of a combo in a West Village basement jazz club, he had a revelation: if musicians can start with standards and transform them, why cant preachers be equally adept?

title: The 46 Places to Go in 2013
description: See our list of destinations to visit, from No. 1 Rio to No. 46 Paris.

title: U.N. Expresses Dismay Over Saudi Execution of Sri Lankan Maid
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights office expressed its deep dismay on Friday over Saudi Arabias execution of a young Sri Lankan housemaid accused of killing a child, a sentence carried out despite concerns about flaws in the conviction process and numerous international appeals for clemency.

title: Westhoff Criticizes Jets Handling of Tebow
description: While working for the Jets, Mike Westhoff offered blunt and unfiltered opinions. But in retirement, he can speak even more freely, and in a radio interview Friday morning, he unloaded on his former employers for the way they handled Tim Tebow.

title: Vieira to Leave Who Wants to Be a Millionaire
description: Disney is searching for a new host for the syndicated game show Who Wants to be a Millionaire.

title: This Weeks Movies: Jan. 11
description: In this weeks video, Times critics offer their thoughts on the crime drama Gangster Squad, Dustin Hoffmans directorial debut Quartet and the Argentine film Clandestine Childhood. View all of this weeks reviews here.

title: N.H.L. Players Begin Voting on Labor Deal; Approval Expected by Saturday
description: The N.H.L. owners won the main thing they were after in the new collective bargaining agreement  reducing the players share of revenue from 57 percent to an eventual 50 percent, but the players are expected to approve the deal by a wide margin in voting that ends Saturday morning.

title: Hamid Karzai Visits the White House
description: TimesCast: A series of meetings with President Obama. | Possible evidence errors in New York City rape cases. | Planning your finances in case of sudden death.

title: My Biker Initiation
description: One of Americas greatest bars is in the unheralded working-class town of Hoosick Falls, N.Y., nearly an hour northeast of Albany. To call the Man of Kent a roadhouse isnt exactly right, but its location makes it a favored spot not just for skiers on their way from New York to the slopes of Vermont but also for bikers tearing through New England.

title: Once Upon a Time, There Was a Person Who Said, Once Upon a Time
description: Good morning. My name is Steve Almond. Ill be your narrator for today. I felt duty bound to introduce myself because the following essay is actually about narrators, and it begins with what we in the narrating business call a triggering anecdote.

title: Is a Rumor Enough to Go On?
description: A few years ago, the daughter of a family friend had twins. Shortly afterward, one twin died. Recently I heard that the twins father, who is now estranged from the mother, accidentally smothered the baby with his body as he slept, almost certainly while intoxicated. I asked if the father had been charged, perhaps with negligence or something similar. I was told that the mother of the children lied to investigators to prevent the father from being charged. Of course, the accusation could be gossip; though I dont think it is. What is the best thing to do in this situation? NAME WITHHELD

title: Nick Kroll Takes a Hike
description: To talk to you, I had to track you down in Peru, where you were hiking in the mountains. Dont take this the wrong way, but you dont seem like the hiking type.  I thought I would pull a reverse Chappelle and leave the country before my show even came out. In high school I went to a place called the Mountain School. Its on a farm in Vermont, and I read Emerson and Thoreau and ran around the woods. Now I go hiking with a bunch of my comedy buddies. We talk about our emotions. I also do a lot of writing on hikes, just to get the blood flowing and the ideas moving.

title: Who Made That Hershey Bar?
description: In the late 1880s, Milton Snavely Hershey, an American entrepreneur, sought to invent a new kind of caramel. Years before, as an employee at a candy shop in Denver, he learned to cook a tender caramel infused with milk  a vast improvement over its gluelike competitors. Hershey added more and more milk to his confection, until hed transformed his candy into a buttery dollop. Consumers went wild for it.

title: When Should a Child Get an E-Mail Account?
description: I created an e-mail address for my 11-year-old two years ago. My now 8-year-old got one at 7, as a reward for completing a reading chart for second grade. (If Id known she wanted one as badly as she did, Id have set the bar much higher.)

title: Getty to Return Ancient Artifact to Sicily
description: After two years of research, the J. Paul Getty Museum has decided to voluntarily return a terracotta head believed to depict the god Hades to Sicily, where recent excavations have uncovered fragments indicating that the head was illicitly removed in the 1970s from a site of a sanctuary of Demeter.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 11
Talking About Sex
description: The four stars of Sex and the City discuss their characters and the process of turning the hit television show into a movie.

title: Gun Control Group Urges Expanded Background Checks
description: WASHINGTON  The Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence, one of the nations leading gun control groups, said on Friday that it wanted the White House to focus its attention on expanded background checks for gun buyers as part of a broad push to reduce gun violence in the wake of the school attack in Connecticut last month.

title: He Tickled His Funny Bone, and Ours
description: WASHINGTON  Its been a while  more than a decade  since the last big American survey of Nam June Paik (1932-2006), the avant-garde musician, multimedia wizard and video art pioneer. Thats a whole epoch in the history of the Internet, and eons in the shelf life of consumer electronics; the chunky televisions Paik tinkered with, the building blocks for his most famous installations, are now obsolete. Yet much of his work, as seen in Nam June Paik: Global Visionary, at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, feels startlingly current.

title: They Got 2012 Right. What About 2013?
description: To many politicians, the deal that raised taxes on the wealthy and averted the fiscal cliff was a sellout, a cop-out, a Band-Aid  in short, nothing good. And now the debt ceiling showdown is looming. So why have stock investors cheered, pushing the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to five-year highs?

title: When Preventive Medicine Involves Guns
description: Prevention is the surest form of medicine. This is a fact. It is with clean hands from strenuous, frequent washing and the habitual application of hand sanitizer that we are able to restrict the diffusion of bacterial and viral nasties, of parasitic organisms and interloping, malevolent fungi. With these simple measures, we are able to arrest potentially hazardous threats to our health and well-being before they have had the chance to infiltrate us. Prevention. Any doctor, nurse practitioner, lab coat or orderly will attest to this.

title: Maestro With the Turtle Tattoo
description: Montreal

title: A Patron With Passion in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Obama and Karzai Meet in Washington
description: President Obama and President Hamid Karzai meet to discuss the future of the American commitment in Afghanistan.

title: Fallout From Match Fixing in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The recent global lifetime ban of 41 South Korean players for match-fixing does not do the soccer scene in the East Asian country any favors. It perpetuates the perception that the practice is ongoing when it all stems from the one, admittedly serious, outbreak in 2011 that is still moving slowly through the system at home and abroad, both at a soccer and legal level.

title: Explanations and Advice for Those Hit Hardest by New Tax Increases
description: WHILE the affluent will pay more in taxes this year, that is probably not the case for the very wealthiest  those worth hundreds of millions or more. They may still be paying a lower tax rate than Warren Buffetts secretary.

title: Young Tops Blake in Surprising Qualifying Match
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The first time James Blake played Donald Young was in Arthur Ashe Stadium, in a first-round night match during the 2008 United States Open ). Blake won in five sets, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1, 4-6, 6-4.

title: City Council to Examine Possible Mishandling of Rape Cases
description: Following a  report in The New York Times on Friday that the citys medical examiners office was reviewing 800 rape cases in which critical DNA evidence may have been mishandled or overlooked by a lab technician, the City Council announced that it would hold an emergency hearing to look into the problem.

title: A Remote Control for Your Life
description: Dozens of companies at the Consumer Electronics Show showed off connected accessories that communicate with smartphones.

title: Jan. 13  20
description: SINCE opening in 2008 LE POISSON ROUGE has provided a home for some of New Yorks most groundbreaking new-music composers and performers. But over time the club has come to host the full range of classical musics history. Just the first half of this week offers an expansive overview.

title: Jan. 11 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web.

title: Etiquette Lessons for the Braggart: Step 1, Dont Pretend to Be Humble
description: MOST of you are probably not aware that, in the last month, many seniors in high school have learned whether they have been accepted to their top-choice college.

title: Highlights From Obamas News Conference With Karzai
description: President Obama, after meeting with President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan, said Friday that the United States would be able to accelerate the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan in coming months because of gains made by Afghan security forces.

title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
description: Paul Hunt still remembers the dilemma that he and his wife, Lynn, faced in early January 2010 at their home in rural north-central Minnesota. The couple had just moved into their ultra-efficient house, on the outskirts of Pine River, population 944, but still lacked a thermostat and were about to go out of town for more than two days. It was bitterly cold, and an exterior sensor, one of the many dotting their house, suggested that the nighttime temperature would dip far below zero. Should they leave the heat on or turn it off?

title: Republican Says Akin Was Partially Right About Rape
description: Two months after the incendiary issues of rape and abortion helped defeat two Republican Senate candidates, a veteran House Republican from Georgia reopened the subjects on Friday, telling a group in suburban Atlanta that the former Republican senatorial candidate Todd Akin of Missouri was partially right when he said that women do not become pregnant when raped.

title: Toasting and Grinding Spices
description: Is grinding your own spices really worth the effort? Melissa Clark explains why the answer is yes.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 10 P.M. (TMC) MY WEEK WITH MARILYN (2011) Michelle Williams, above, in an Oscar-nominated role, steps into the pumps and pencil skirts of Marilyn Monroe, and Eddie Redmayne plays Colin Clark, a documentary filmmaker who claimed to have spent an intimate interlude with her in 1956 while they were making The Prince and the Showgirl. This film, an adaptation of his diaries, also features Kenneth Branagh, in another nominated role, as Laurence Olivier, Monroes co-star and director, whose infatuation and ego clashes with Monroe caused him to call her the stupidest, most self-indulgent little tart Ive ever come across. When the shoot went from bad to worse, he told her: Just be sexy. Isnt that what you do? Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, He didnt get Monroe, and she is similarly out of the grasp of this movie, adding: Ms. Williams tries her best, and sometimes thats almost enough. Shes too thin for the role, more colorlessly complected than creamy, but she whispers and wobbles nicely. Still, Ms. Dargis said: The problem isnt Ms. Williams or the serviceable work of the director, Simon Curtis, but a script by Adrian Hodges that hews faithfully to Clarks clichs. Instead of the complex woman familiar from the better books about her, the film offers a catalog of Monroe stereotypes: child, woman, smiling exhibitionist, shrieking neurotic, the barefooted free spirit and, lamentably, the martyr teetering in heels toward her doom. The tragic Monroe is obviously dramatic, but the intimations of disaster dont fit a movie that works so hard to be breezily, easily likable.

title: The Divided Influence of Gnosticism
description: In the latest First Things, David Bentley Hart has an interesting essay on Carl Jungs eccentric, esoteric, solipsistic and impenetrable Red Book, which includes some perceptive remarks on the difference between the modern manifestations of Gnosticism and the more ancient variety:

title: Blood Oranges Add a Ruby Hue to Dishes and Desserts
description: THE last bottle of holiday wine has been drunk, the discarded Christmas trees have been pulped to mulch and my local farmers market has shrunk to a few crates of muddy roots and yellowing kale. Its time to celebrate something new: the arrival of blood oranges.

title: The Changing Newsroom Environment
description: | Several updates below |Theres been a flurry of blog, Facebook and Twitter shock and anger following Katherine Bagleys exclusive report for Inside Climate News on the decision by The New York Times to shut down its standalone environment pod and redistribute that able team of reporters and editors to other desks (not necessarily other duties).

title: Weekend Fare
description: Peter Dale, the chef of The National in Athens, GA, will cook up Southern food with a Mediterranean twist in two dinners at City Grit, 38 Prince Street, in SoHo, on Friday at 7:30 p.m. and Saturday at 7 p.m. A five-course meal will be served. Tickets are $75 per person, with wine and beer extra.

title: Off the Charts: High Tech, High Dividends
description: The information technology sector, which once disdained paying dividends to shareholders, now pays more dividends than any other sector in the Standard & Poors 500.

title: Bands Name Punches Its Ticket to Russia
description: Sometimes a witty name can take you places. Just ask the American indie pop band Someone Still Loves You Boris Yeltsin. On Sunday, the quartet will headline the Old New Rock Festival in Yekaterinburg, Russia. Boris Yeltsin, the former Russian president, was a native of the region around Yekaterinburg.

title: Milk Group Opts for Bigger Super Bowl Ad Presence
description: A marketer that until now has had a low-key Super Bowl presence is going all in this time around.

title: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler Will Be Giving Sondheim His Big Break
description: Seth MacFarlane may not be allowed to drink at the Oscars, but Tina Fey and Amy Poehler have invented a Golden Globes drinking game.

title: Chief Keef and Cultural Tourism
description: A minor Twitter dispute about a new rap album recently led to some larger discussions about how black pop is understood or misunderstood in the media. Host Ben Ratliff and Times pop critic Jon Caramanica talk about the young Chicago rapper Chief Keef, the original spark for the debate. Later they are later joined by Brian B.Dot Miller, content director of the hip-hop blog Rap Radar, for a conversation about age, class, race, memory, and music criticism.

title: Information Technology Dividends Outpace All Others
description: FOR what appears to be the first time ever, information technology companies in the Standard & Poors index of 500 stocks are paying more in dividends than companies in any other sector, S.&P. reported this week.

title: Smartphones Become Lifes Remote Control
description: LAS VEGAS  The smartphone is no longer just a portable computer in your pocket. It has become the remote control for your life.

title: After Deadly Fire, a Man Is Charged With Murder
description: The police charged a 45-year-old man with murder, arson and attempted assault on Friday, after a fire in Manhattan that left one person dead and several others injured on Thursday night.

title: Palestinians Set Up Tents Where Israel Plans Homes
description: JERUSALEM  Adopting a tactic more commonly employed by Jewish settlers who establish wildcat outposts in the West Bank, scores of Palestinian activists erected tents on Friday in a hotly contested piece of Israeli-occupied West Bank territory known as E1, and they said they intended to stay put.

title: Get Your Finances Together
description: The Your Money columnist Ron Lieber profiles a Seattle woman whose Web site helps individuals and families prepare their financial lives for the unexpected.

title: Calling All Cauliflower
description: At my house we eat cauliflower like popcorn. Using a simple recipe from Alice Waters, we slice it thin, toss in olive oil and salt, and roast. One head of cauliflower is never enough.

title: Popcast: Chief Keef and Cultural Tourism
description: This week: Chief Keef, hip-hop journalism and cultural tourism.

title: Street Style From Pitti Uomo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: C.E.S. 2013: The Voice-Controlled Home, With a Catch
description: The annual International Consumer Electronics show in Las Vegas is always filled with astonishing prototypes for products that dont exist and may never exist, although you hope they will someday.

title: Uncertainty Hangs Over Wall Street in 2013
description: Big American banks have plenty to prove in 2013. Wells Fargo aside, their valuations have languished below book value. After a strong 2012 for stock markets and with fourth-quarter earnings reports imminent, JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs are again near that level. But when they get there, it will be a relief rather than anything to crow over.

title: A Strange Sail
description: As the year 1862 ended, Union naval forces had consolidated effective control of much of the Texas Gulf Coast. From Sabine Pass in the North to the mouth of the Rio Grande, almost all of the roughly 450 miles of Texas coastline were safely in their hands. During that year, minor engagements at Corpus Christi, Galveston and Sabine Pass had effectively secured the coastline from most Confederate shipping.

title: The Generator Is the Machine of the Moment
description: IN the days that followed Hurricane Sandy, the developer of the luxury condominium 150 Charles Street hunkered down with his team of architects and engineers to rethink the buildings design.

title: Not an Exotic Mushroom, but a Satisfying One
description: I ENJOY wild mushrooms, but I happen to like ordinary white button mushrooms, too; the cultivated kind, the ones that are also called champignons de Paris (especially by the French). Simply sauted in a little butter or olive oil and finished with garlic and parsley, or sliced raw for a salad with a lemony dressing  what could be better? Theyre completely satisfying.

title: A Sundance Offshoot in Brooklyn?
description: 1:36 p.m. | Updated  LOS ANGELES  The Sundance Film Festival, having started a London offshoot last year, may be coming to New York next. Such a move would put the venerable movie bazaar in more direct competition with the Tribeca Film Festival, which is overseen in part by Geoffrey Gilmore, Sundances former director.

title: The Dicey Parent-Teacher Duet
description: The teacher-parent relationship is a lot like an arranged marriage. Neither side gets a lot of say in the match. Both parties, however, share great responsibility for a child, which can lead to a deeply rewarding partnership or the kind of conflict found in some joint-custody arrangements.

title: Wheelies: The Were Hiring Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Sweet Spot | Free Speech and Guns
description: A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about free speech and the gun issue  and when violence veers too close to what is real.

title: Red Bulls Release Preseason Plans
description: The Red Bulls have no coach (yet) and one not-so super pick (No. 22 over all) in Thursdays Major League Soccer draft, and now players frequent-flyer accounts are about to take a hit after the club on Friday announced its preseason training plans.

title: Kimmel Gains in Coveted 18-49 Age Group
description: On his third day as an 11:35 p.m. late night host, Jimmy Kimmel took his biggest step yet to separate himself from the two titans of that time period, David Letterman and Jay Leno. He started pulling away, at least for one night, among the most important audience in late night.

title: Wells Fargo Awash in Mortgage Gains
description: The Federal Reserves extraordinary efforts to stimulate the housing market and the wider economy continues to benefit banks bottom lines.

title: The View from Baylor: Back at No. 1
description: The Baylor Lady Bears are back in familiar territory, reclaiming the No. 1 spot in The Associated Press poll after seven weeks out of it.

title: Putting Myself Out There, and Waiting for a College to Accept
description: A college application is an individuals proposition about why he or she would best fit in a particular school. The same goes for the interview process. It really is an opportunity to show who you were then, who you are now, and who you want to be in the future.

title: A Trail of Bullet Casings Leads From Africas Wars Back to Iran
description: The first clues appeared in Kenya, Uganda and what is now South Sudan. A British arms researcher surveying ammunition used by government forces and civilian militias in 2006 found Kalashnikov rifle cartridges he had not seen before. The ammunition bore no factory code, suggesting that its manufacturer hoped to avoid detection.

title: A Shocking Death, a Financial Lesson and Help for Others
description: SEATTLE

title: Opera Meets Philosophy
description: It has the makings of an extremely high-brow reality show: find four composers, give them a set of philosophical questions and see what kind of opera each comes up with. The Royal Opera in London has presented the challenge to Kaija Saariaho of Finland, Mark-Anthony Turnage of Britain, Luca Francesconi of Italy and Jrg Widmann of Germany. In a statement on Thursday the company said it had come up with the questions in collaboration with the philosopher Slavoj Zizek, and will ask the composers to write works responding to them. The questions are: What preoccupies us today? How can we today stage ourselves? What are the collective myths of our present and future? The operas are expected to be presented in 2020.

title: Getting Your Will and Estate Plans Together
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I pay a visit to Chanel Reynolds, a widow who has built a site whose name cannot be mentioned here (though I can give you a link to it). It encourages you to get your will, living will and power of attorney done. And it urges you to collect all of your financial and other account information in one place and let a few trusted people know where to find it.

title: The Sweet Spot: Jan. 11
description: This week, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about free speech and the gun issue  and when violence veers too close to what is real.

title: Affleck Can Joke but Hollywoods Puzzled by Snubs
description: Ben Affleck continued his roll of giving funny and pointed (yet classy) awards speeches. At the Critics Choice ceremony on Thursday night, where Argo won the best picture and best director trophy just hours after Mr. Affleck had been snubbed by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, he began his speech the only way feasible.

title: In a Wartime Telegram, a Look at a Frustrated Lincoln
description: One way to think of it is this: It is a page from the script for the script for Lincoln.

title: So Much for the Growing Class War
description: Despite all the talk of the lazy 47 percenters, the scruffy 99 percent versus the entitled top 1 percent, contentious proposals to raise taxes on the rich, and the uncapped political donations of billionaires, the class war apparently abated last year, if you believe the American public.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $24,750,000
description: A century-old Upper East Side town house  a landmark with an off-again-on-again relationship to the market since 2008, when it was offered for $32.75 million, finding no takers  was yet another beneficiary of the December dash to seal the deal on luxury properties before onerous tax implications kicked in. At $24.75 million it was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Baseballs Hit King Finds a New Team, and Queen
description: Already banned from baseball for betting on games, Pete Rose now has another infraction on his record: His new reality show, Pete Rose: Hits & Mrs., tests positive for tedium.

title: Flu Season Deaths Reach Epidemic Level but May Be at Peak, C.D.C. Says
description: Deaths in the current flu season have officially crossed the line into epidemic territory, federal health officials said Friday, adding that, on the bright side, there were also early signs that the caseloads could be peaking.

title: Giants, Jets, Broncos: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: Christa Justus and Mark Linn-Baker
description: EVEN those who spend their lives in the limelight can feel star-crossed when confronted by the harsh reality of the New York City dating scene.

title: Mexsicko City Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
description: MEXICO CITY  This megacity of more than 20 million rang in the New Year with a pleasant revelation: the region registered 248 days in 2012 in which the air quality considered good.

title: Keeping Environmental Reporting Strong Wont Be Easy
description: Those who care deeply about environmental issues were understandably concerned Friday after learning that The Times was dismantling its special team  or pod  of seven reporters and two editors.

title: Shell Violated Air Permits for Arctic Ships, E.P.A. Says
description: The Environmental Protection Agency says that Shell committed numerous violations of the air pollution permits for its two Arctic drill ships, adding to the companys catalog of Alaskan offshore woes.

title: My Travel Wish List
description: WE travel for pleasure, for a door-slamming sense of Im outta here, for a change of air, for edification, for the big vulgar boast of being distant, for the possibility of being transformed, for the voyeuristic romance of gawping at the exotic; and sometimes we travel because we have been banished. I was banished once, and it fortified me.

title: Guns, Abortion and Mistrust
description: Before his closed-door meeting with gun-control advocates on Wednesday, Vice President Joe Biden chatted briefly with reporters. What he told them incensed right-wing news sources. The Drudge Report splashed headshots of Hitler and Stalin.The Examiner ran a story claiming that President Obama would ban guns and act like a dictator by taking legally owned firearms from nonviolent Americans.

title: Obama Accelerates Transition of Security to Afghans
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, eager to turn the page after more than a decade of war, said Friday that beginning this spring American forces would play only a supporting role in Afghanistan, which opens the way for a more rapid withdrawal of the troops.

title: Unions Back Revisions of Labor Law in France
description: PARIS  French labor unions and business leaders struck a deal on Friday to overhaul swaths of Frances notoriously rigid labor market, moving to tame some of the most confounding rules in the 3,200-page labor code as the country tries to increase its competitiveness and curb unemployment.

title: Understanding the Home Appraisal Process
description: BEFORE anyone can buy a house with a loan from a bank or refinance a mortgage, the lender needs an objective assessment of the propertys value  after all, the home is the banks collateral for the loan. Assessing the value is the job of the appraiser.

title: Feeling For | Gerard Tullys Snake Ring
description: Its the year of the snake (the Chinese New Year begins on Feb. 10) and in honor of that, the Gerard Tully designer Ryan Kearney is adding an 18-karat solid yellow gold snake to his menagerie of diamond-eyed animal rings. Since theyre made to order, no two rings are exactly alike (wait time: three weeks). Snakes can be hypnotic, and Ive been told that this ring is, too, Kearney says. Charming is the name of the game. Hissssss.

title: Newark Mayor Takes First Official Step Toward a Senate Run
description: Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark has taken his first official step toward running for the United States Senate in 2014.

title: A Scene From Luv
description: A scene from "Luv," directed by Sheldon Candis and starring Common and Michael Rainey Jr.

title: Just Cry Uncle: Write, and Direct, What You Know
description: IN the film Luv, opening Jan. 18, an 11-year old boy learns some not-always-lovely life lessons from his paroled uncle on the streets of Baltimore. Its director, Sheldon Candis, 33, has learned a few lessons himself on the way to making his first feature, which had its premiere at last years Sundance Film Festival. A Baltimore native, Mr. Candis loosely based the films story, which he wrote with Justin Wilson, on childhood experiences with his own uncle: riding around late at night in his car and listening to his advice on how to be a man. His possible criminal connections werent an issue. The fictionalized version goes deeper, exploring what happens when role models exhibit less than model behavior.

title: New Womens League Allocates Players
description: The National Womens Soccer League on Friday divvied up 55 national team players from the United States, Mexico and Canada among the eight clubs scheduled to begin play in the leagues inaugural season in the spring.

title: State of the Union Date Is Set
description: President Obama will deliver the first State of the Union address of his second term on February 12, having received a formal invitation from House Speaker John A. Boehner on Friday to address a joint session of Congress on that date.

title: Obama and Karzai Hold Press Conference
description: President Obama and President Hamid Karzai spoke about postwar Afghanistan at the White House on Friday.

title: Low-Cost Shelters for Feral Cats
description: A display of cat shelters from eight New York City architects and designers.

title: For Feral Cats, a Few New Places to Call Home
description: EIGHT New York City architects and designers proudly displayed their new low-cost houses at a show in Manhattan on Thursday, and not a single client was present. Feral cats are like that.

title: A Mixed Start for the Winter TV Season
description: The flipping of the calendar to the new year also signals the arrival of televisions winter season, with many new and returning TV shows vying for attention.

title: 50-Year Term for Burning a Woman to Death in an Elevator
description: Calling the crime one of the most brutal he had seen in his judicial career, a judge in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Friday sentenced a man who burned a woman to death in an elevator to 50 years in prison.

title: The Tax Code and the Very Rich
description: Almost anyone who receives a paycheck will pay higher taxes this year. But as Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week, the very wealthiest Americans  those worth hundreds of millions or more  usually dont get paychecks. These people, generally partners in private equity firms or hedge fund managers, earn much of their money as a share of their funds earnings. And those earnings are taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income.

title: Would Exporting the Natural Gas Surplus Help The Economy, or Hurt?
description: Natural gas exports are turning into Washingtons hottest energy question.

title: Book Review Podcast: The State of the Nuclear World
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Bill Keller reviews three new books that address the current thinking about nuclear weapons. Mr. Keller writes:

title: Taking In the Winter Jazzfest (Or Trying to, Anyhow)
description: The Winter Jazzfest heaved into being in 2005, subsuming all three floors of what was then the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa. Over the last eight years the festival has expanded and relocated  its geographical center, since 2009, has been the Bleecker Street bar district, in and around Le Poisson Rouge  but its core function hasnt changed at all.

title: Spokesman for Cuomo to Become Chief of Staff
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, who is known for his careful, if aggressive, cultivation of the news media, is promoting his press spokesman to serve as his chief of staff.

title: On the Market | Second Homes in Miami
description: A beachfront contemporary, a waterfront Mediterranean, a South of Fifth condo, a Venetian Islands waterfront and a Downtown condo.

title: Butlers Next Challenge: The Atlantic 10
description: The Butler mens basketball team had one of the toughest nonconference schedules in the country. They played three teams that were in the top 25 at the time of their games, as well as six teams from last years N.C.A.A. tournament. That schedule included Xavier, Marquette, North Carolina, Illinois, Northwestern, Indiana and Vanderbilt. On Jan. 19, Butler plays Gonzaga, ranked No. 9.

title: Designing for Calm
description: IT should come as no surprise that violence in mental health facilities causes psychological and often physical harm to health care workers and patients. Whats shocking is how prevalent it is.

title: Teachers Grade Hinges on Students Playoff Test
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In his only planned meeting with local reporters before Saturdays playoff game against Green Bay, 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick was asked 23 questions in five minutes.

title: Spices: When to Grind, When to Toast
description: This weeks video shows how to toast and then grind whole spices, a worthy endeavor.

title: Sundance Makes a Family of the Denied
description: THE first-time feature-film director Stacy Sherman was on the edge of her seat in a Los Angeles movie theater, watching Silver Linings Playbook, when she received the e-mail shed been waiting for. Ms. Sherman had been repeatedly checking her BlackBerry in those days leading up to Thanksgiving, and at last she scanned the words: Sundance, Claires Cambodia (the name of her movie) and, finally, we are sorry.

title: Screams and Curses: A Beast Nominee Gets the News
description: The screenwriter Lucy Alibar based parts of Beasts of the Southern Wild on her own relationship with her father, who lives in the rural South and never saw her one-act play, from which the indie hit and best-picture nominee was adapted. So it was particularly gratifying to have him and her mother be a part of her Oscar morning on Thursday. I didnt think they had a TV that worked, she said, but I guess they did, they were watching it.

title: Q&A: Resetting a Kindles Automatic Bookmark
description: Q.

title: Q & A
description: Landlady Demands Half of Rent in Cash

title: Any Lawful Steps Urged to Avert Default
description: WASHINGTON  The Democratic leadership in the Senate asked President Obama on Friday to take any lawful steps available to avoid a default on the nations debt if Republicans continue to press their demand that an increase in the governments borrowing limit be accompanied by spending cuts of the same magnitude.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 11
description: Subjects include performances by Ethan Hawke and Tamar Shelef, and the recently refurbished Kings Cross Station.

title: In Defense of Child Bribery
description: Im an unabashed briber of my children.

title: The Messy Work of Examining Disorganizations
description: THE Brooklyn documentarians Audrey Ewell and Aaron Aites were watching live online as Occupy Wall Street started its ill-fated march over the Brooklyn Bridge. It was October 2011, and there was this crazy drama unfolding, Ms. Ewell said. All of a sudden everybody is being arrested  and then the guy who was filming it said his batteries were running low, and the screen went black.

title: Train a Parent, Spare a Child
Week in Review: When Hedge Fund Managers Clash
description: DealBook analyzed new loan rules and examined cuts at Morgan Stanley. Andrew Ross Sorkin said the easing of rules for banks acknowledges reality. A.I.G. weighs whether to sue the U.S. but decides against it; two hedge fund managers clashed; an ex-SAC analyst cooperated on an insider case; Bank of America made a deal to extend a retreat from mortgages; and banks agreed to pay $8.5 Billion to speed up foreclosure relief.

title: King of the Hill, Indeed, With a Price to Match
description: TROY, N.C.

title: Listing of Films of 2012 by Female Directors
description: Of the 250 top films at the box office last year, 9 percent were made by female filmmakers. Most were working on their own, a few had partners. Here are their films, in alphabetical order:

title: The Rear-Engine Corvette That Was Never to Be
description: ON Sunday evening, just ahead of two press preview days for the 2013 North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Chevrolet will unveil the seventh generation of the Corvette. While the two-seat sports car accounts for a small fraction of Chevys total sales, it is a vital element of the brands image  and, in fact, its longest-running passenger-car nameplate.

title: Female Directors Gain Ground, Slowly
description: FOR those rooting for women to make strides in Hollywood the news that Brenda Chapman, a screenwriter and director of Brave, had been replaced at the helm midway through production of that animated film about the flame-haired archer came as a blow last year. The happy ending is that the movie on which Ms. Chapman shares directing credit (with Mark Andrews) ranks eighth at the box office in 2012.

title: Engineers Bring Processes of Nature to Design
description: Biomimetic is a popular term among designers and engineers. Imitating natures shapes promises more efficient as well as more elegant buildings and vehicles. Now get ready to hear morphogenesis. Not content with adopting the forms of nature, engineers are looking to adapt the processes of nature to design.

title: Yoko Ono Takes Fight Against Gas Drilling to Albany
description: ALBANY  For months they have been descending on Albany: farmers, environmentalists, latter-day hippies and placard-bearing parents.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 11
description: More photographs.

title: Reviving a Dream Vette
description: The XP-819, a storied Corvette engineering prototype, is progressing toward the final phases of a restoration at a shop in Long Island.

title: How to Shoot a Viper
description: For this weeks Look, we sent Brett Beyer to photograph the Chrysler auto plant in Detroit where the Dodge Viper is manufactured. Recently I spoke to Beyer about how he made his pictures.

title: The End of Courtship?
description: MAYBE it was because they had met on OkCupid. But when the dark-eyed musician with artfully disheveled hair asked Shani Silver, a social media and blog manager in Philadelphia, out on a date Friday night, she was expecting at least a drink, one on one.

title: A Nuclear Post-Mortem for Sandy
description: The operators of the Oyster Creek nuclear plant, the reactor that declared an alert during Hurricane Sandy, made several small errors, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday. But an inspection team has concluded that performance was acceptable and that emergency action level declarations were timely.

title: Manufacturing a Viper
description: Inside a newly reopened Chrysler plant in Detroit, a car revs to life.

title: Fashion News Were Reading Now
description: Alexandros Pissourios captures the calm chaos of backstage beauty at the Meadham Kirchhoff mens-wear show in London in a fashion film. The man behind the coifs? James Pecis, who was also responsible for the models neon tresses from last season.

title: The Week in Pictures for the New York Region, Jan. 11
description: Subjects include the effort to create a High Line in Queens, the State of the State address from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, and the final days of the Long Beach Boardwalk.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Strange Hiring Questions and Curved Controls
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Whispered Lyrics, Spooky Snippets, Old Frontiers Anew
description: Dom La Nena

title: Tending to Veterans Afflictions of the Soul
description: FORT WORTH  On a drizzly Saturday afternoon in September 2005, the Rev. Rita Nakashima Brock awaited her instructions at a vast Washington rally against the Iraq war. The protest march, numbering more than 100,000, was the latest and among the largest events in her nearly 40 years of pacifist activism.

title: A Cold Case of Cold-Blooded Murder
description: ON a hot July day in 1977, one of New Yorks ugliest summers, my 23-year-old cousin, Ellen Hover, left her Third Avenue apartment. She had an appointment with a young photographer who had asked to take pictures of her. His name, hed told her, was John Berger.

title: Graphic Design: What a Trip
description: O.K., kids and curators: its official.

title: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
description: Photos from China, Pakistan, India and Spain.

title: Nam June-Paik at the Smithsonian
description: The exhibit Nam June-Paik: Global Visionary, on view at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, D.C.

title: Shows Go On, Under New Proprietors
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.

title: A Generation Gap? Not on This Web Site
description: YOUNG, stylish women may spend thousands of hours and hundreds of dollars trolling the Web for everything from naughty to nice at sites like Shopbop, Net-a-Porter and Rue La La. But what about their mothers?

title: Doctors Recommend Flu Shot for Children With Egg Allergies
description: Amid an unusually widespread outbreak of the flu, a medical association of allergy specialists said Friday that even children with severe egg allergies should get flu shots.

title: A Rugged Benz That Still Rides Smooth
description: The Mercedes-Benz GL350 is a unique beast, offering vanlike capaciousness, an interior worthy of the S-Class and a helping of legitimate old-school S.U.V. abilities.

title: More Emergency Visits Linked to Energy Drinks
description: A rising number of patients, many of them young people, are being treated in emergency rooms for complications related to highly caffeinated energy drinks like Red Bull, Monster Energy and 5-Hour Energy, new federal data shows.

title: Industrys New Year Buffet: Entrees and a Few Desserts
description: THE annual North American International Auto Show, which opens in Detroit on Monday with two days of press previews, is off life support after a few touch-and-go years when various automakers pulled out and some threatened to go elsewhere.

title: Palestinians Rally Support Online for West Bank Protest Camp
description: About 200 Palestinian activists set up camp, and a Twitter feed, on Friday in a part of the Israeli-occupied West Bank just east of Jerusalem known as E1, where Israel plans to build homes for thousands of new settlers. The activists described their encampment as the start of a new Palestinian village named Bab al-Shams, Arabic for Gate of the Sun, after a book by the Lebanese novelist Elias Khoury.

title: Living In | Richmond Hill
description: A diverse part of Queens, made up of single- and multifamily homes with a smattering of apartment buildings.

title: Indo-Caribbean Content, Victorian Style
description: RICHMOND HILL, in southeastern Queens, is the ultimate study in New York diversity. It is a place to eat Caribbean cuisine, shop for Bollywood movies, worship at a Sikh temple and stroll through streets lined with Victorian-era houses, a slice of pure Americana.

title: C.E.S. 2013: A Genuinely Novel Gadget, the Self-Driving Car
description: Most of whats on display at this years Consumer Electronics Show is the same as what was on display at last years Consumer Electronics Show. Phones, TV sets, accessories. Minus Microsoft, of course.

title: A Conversation With Bill Moyers
description: I taped a long talk with Bill Moyers yesterday. Heres the link. It should also be aired on most PBS stations this weekend; listings at the Moyers site.

title: As Flu Rages, Caregiving Suffers
description: The flu started in the personal care center at Masonic Village in Elizabethtown, Pa., then moved to the nursing home. Within a few days, seven older adults had taken ill.

title: Discolored Slopes Mar Debut of Snow-Making Effort
description: After a decade of legal battles, a ski resort in Northern Arizona recently became the first in the world to make artificial snow totally out of sewage effluent. On Dec. 24, Arizona Snowbowl fired up its snow guns for the first time, and to everyones surprise, the snow that blasted onto the mountain was yellow.

title: Is That A Backbone I See?
description: Senate Democrats give Obama full backing in any unilateral action he might take on the debt ceiling. Reports say that Harry Reid is still partial to the 14th amendment; but theres also the coin and the coupons.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Pakistanis Protest the Killing of 86 Shiites
description: ISLAMABAD  Protesters and distraught family members of 86 Shiites from the Hazara ethnic group killed in two bomb blasts on Thursday in the southwestern city of Quetta braved biting cold to stage a sit-in on Friday, refusing to bury their dead till the Pakistani Army took control of the city to provide them with security.

title: A Crash Course in Mandarin, With No Books or Interpreters
description: Ready to learn a little Mandarin? Head down to the Public Theater for the next week or so, where Cest du Chinois, a language lesson in the lively form of an interactive theater piece, is being presented as part of the Under the Radar festival.

title: Friday Night Music: More The Head and the Heart
description: Still listening to this band a lot:

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Get the Media Out of the Honoring Business
description: It is no great sacrifice for me to say that those who regularly cover major league baseball should get the heck out of the business of Hall of Fame voting. Thats because I work for a newspaper, The New York Times, that doesnt allow its reporters to participate in the business  and thats exactly what it is  of electing ballplayers to a club that will not only elevate their historic standing, but will enhance their earning power.

title: Dont Own It? Still Make Money on Land Sale Near Brooklyn Bridge
description: Hipsters are not the only ones reaping benefits from the soaring value of real estate in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn. All of Consolidated Edisons customers could soon share in a minor windfall from the sale of the next piece of Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: Wearing Gray, Breathing Hard and Repeating Themselves
description: Performed by two people wearing combinations of leotards and medieval attire, Sacre, by the French choreographer David Wampach, is fairly silly, slightly boring and very peculiar. The boring and the peculiar aspects actually work to the pieces advantage. What little happens keeps happening again and again  but it is so sheerly odd that the repetitions encourage you to slap on meanings, making it more interesting than it is. Still, despite its bizarre sides, the work is ultimately both flimsy and fatuous.

title: Moving Back in Time and Nearer to Nature
description: So much care has gone into making Emily Johnsons Niicugni that you can almost smell it. At the Baryshnikov Arts Center, where this dance installation had its New York premiere on Wednesday as part of Performance Space 122s Coil Festival, 51 lanterns hand-sewn from fish skins hang over the stage and audience. A map inserted in the program specifies not just which of the many volunteers made which lamp but also how many thousands of miles the fish might have traveled in its migrations.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Sri Lankan Parliament Impeaches Chief Justice
description: NEW DELHI  Defying a court order, Sri Lankas Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Friday to impeach the nations chief justice, a significant step in a worsening showdown between the legislature and the judiciary that has alarmed democracy advocates and many foreign governments.

title: For Golden Globes, Its a Good Time
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  It is awfully easy to make fun of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association.

title: Lawyers Say Police Confused Bomb Suspects Doodle With Nazi Symbol
description: Lawyers for Aaron Greene, the man charged with keeping an explosive chemical in his Greenwich Village apartment, criticized investigators on Friday for linking what they said was a mere doodle by their client to a Nazi symbol.

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 11
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the effort to create a park in Queens like the High Line; Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos State of the State address; and the final days of the Long Beach Boardwalk.

title: Judge Settles Dispute Over Rare Gem Collection
description: A legal dispute over a rare collection of 295 naturally colored diamonds currently on display at a London museum was recently settled in favor of a New Jersey diamond dealer who had spent years assembling the collection.

title: Lessons Learned, and Put on a Plate
description: When I first moved to New Jersey in 1987, residents of downtown Jersey City who cared about the latest trends in food did their dining in Hoboken. In 2001, Marco & Pepe opened to accommodate the growing influx of urban homesteaders, and now there are Madame Claude Cafe, the Light Horse Tavern and Thirty Acres, among other notable restaurants. There is also Satis.

title: Mortality Rate by Year
description: Last week, the percentage of deaths from pneumonia and influenza moved slightly above the epidemic threshold, to 7.3 percent. In recent years, though, this figure has risen much higher.

title: Voices as an Instrument
description: A 50-year-old shower crooner takes a turn with the nations oldest a cappella group, the Whiffenpoofs of Yale.

title: Singing for Their Supper
description: DURING my brief tenure as a member of one of the nations oldest a cappella groups, the Whiffenpoofs of Yale, I learned a shortcut. I call it fakeappella. You keep your mouth very liquid, and when you get to a note and lyric that you are entirely sure of, you do to that note and lyric what a flame thrower would do to a piece of Kleenex.

title: Options for Protecting Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: You Think 40 Is No Picnic? Try Life at 60
description: To the Editor:

title: Google in North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: A Remark by Hagel
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking a College
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco and the Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: What Came First? The Sack
description: ENGLEWOOD, Colo.  Von Miller is happy to show off the shiny, white, personalized high-tops he will wear in Saturdays playoff game against the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Bill Cunningham | Legs of Manhattan
description: The gothic and medieval eras are casting their spells over fashion. Today's look of black leggings and abbreviated coats suggests men in the 1400s.

title: Inside a Greek Poets Work, a Reflection of Her Countrys Hard Times
description: ATHENS

title: A Homey Style That Is All Italian-American
description: In search of an antidote to the jet-fueled pace of holiday entertaining, we landed the Friday before New Years at Sophias Ristorante Italiano, a casual and accommodating eatery on Route 1 in Westbrook. This unassuming space has housed three other restaurants during the past several years, but longtime locals will probably remember Martys Seafood Restaurant, where beachgoers fortified themselves with fried fish and hot dogs after a day in the sun. Sophias is the third Connecticut restaurant for owner Mauricio Salgar, who also owns the Black Seal in Essex and Gabrielles in Centerbrook.

title: Bollywood Laughs at Corruption
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: Greece Votes to Raise Tax on Higher Earners
description: ATHENS  Greek lawmakers voted late Friday to increase taxes on middle- to high-income earners, self-employed professionals and businesses despite vehement objections by the political opposition and several ruling coalition deputies who said austerity-weary citizens should not be subjected to further pain.

title: Saudi Arabias King Allows Women to Join National Advisory Council
description: Women are not allowed to drive and cannot yet vote in Saudi Arabia, but on Friday they were given a voice in an advisory council that debates the kingdoms legislation.

title: Activists Document Sit-In by Families of Bombing Victims in Pakistan
description: Last Updated, 8:31 p.m. Hours after it started on Friday night, Pakistani television began to report on a protest in the city of Quetta, where relatives of scores of people killed in bomb attacks one day earlier sat beside coffins in the street, refusing to bury their loved ones until they received assurance that the state would protect them.

title: Trouble in Russia Over Ban of Adoptions by Americans
description: MOSCOW  The moratorium on the adoption of Russian children by Americans, which began as a fight between two countries, began this week to look like a fight between Russians and themselves.

title: A Horror Movie Parody
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: Motorcycle Auction Brings Unexpected Results
description: 3:42 p.m. | Updated LAS VEGAS  The Bonhams Las Vegas Motorcycle Auction on Thursday produced some upsets and surprises as some of the most highly anticipated lots did not sell, others sold for unexpected prices and a 1954 BMW Rennsport RS54 Sidecar was a top seller.

title: Seeking Truth; Finding Fear
description: Bluebeard is about wanting to know the unknowable. The rich old man of the title entrusts his young wife with the keys to his castle, warning of a single room she must not enter.

title: Taste of Adventure, With Hint of Familiarity
description: Italian-Kitchen, a new, shoe-box-size trattoria in Ardsley that taps into the ode to nonna and rustic-modern vein, is the perfect sort of place to eat on a cold night. The muscular, full-flavored food  thick slices of roasted eggplant layered with mousse-like ricotta and bold tomato sauce; pink-centered slabs of hanger steak punched up with Gorgonzola dolce; tortellini stuffed with duck liver and dusted with fennel pollen; rich dark-chocolate bread pudding thick with golden raisins  is packed with lots of calories, and lots of simple pleasures.

title: Tipsy Corporate Intrigues That Fill Billable Hours
description: There arent enough church services to cleanse Sunday of what Showtime does to it with the return of its iniquitous triumvirate, Shameless, House of Lies and Californication.

title: Warming and Weighty Reds
description: When winters chill sets in and menus tend toward hearty fare, a weighty red wine lends a warmth of its own.

title: Death of a Daughter
description: The death of a young woman who was raped by several men in New Delhi in December has shattered the dreams of her father.

title: Winter Jazzfest: Pretty Postbop From a Comfy Seat
description: Bryan and the Aardvarks, led by the bassist Bryan Copeland, specializes in an unabashedly pretty strain of postbop, chamberlike and euphonious. At the Culture Project theater on Bleecker Street, early in the going at Winter Jazzfest on Friday night, they sounded ready for a bigger stage, or at least an indie film soundtrack.

title: From French Roots, a Multicultural Menu
description: Both the food and the dcor at Bistro Etcetera, on Main Street in Port Washington, are as eclectic as the name suggests. There is nothing haphazard about the cooking, though: the chef and owner, Karen Melanie LaRocco, clearly knows what she is doing.

title: A Cancer Cycle, From Here to China
description: MORE than one million people in the Chinese city of Handan awoke last week to the alarming news that an essential source of their drinking water, the Zhouzhang River, had been dangerously contaminated by a 39-ton chemical spill in the nearby city of Changzhi. What made the news even more shocking was that the leak, from a factory pipe, had started at least five days earlier but had been kept secret by government officials, who allowed millions of their neighbors to keep drinking.

title: Claude Nobs, Founder of Montreux Jazz Festival, Dies at 76
description: Claude Nobs, who founded the Montreux Jazz Festival in 1967 and built it into an international phenomenon far more famous than the small Swiss resort town where it was held  and far more musically inclusive than the term jazz festival would suggest  died on Thursday in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 76.

title: How to Shoot a Gun
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.

title: New Jersey Symphony President Quits After Questions on His Past
description: Richard Dare made a splash last year as an outspoken entrepreneur turned arts administrator and started work on Jan. 2 as the president and chief executive of the New Jersey Symphony, with the promise that his business acumen would bring it new luster.

title: Cinematic Polish for an Evolving Shore Town
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.

title: Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
description: The most successful players at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last month were Judith Bianco and Win Allegaert of New York City, and Hemant Lall of Dallas and his son, Justin Lall of Las Vegas.

title: For India Rape Victims Family, Many Layers of Loss
description: MEDAWARA KALAN, India  The village of Medawara Kalan lies down a one-lane dirt track, past mustard fields, thatched-roof huts and piles of neatly stacked cow dung patties, dried to use for fuel.

title: Hostess Names Flowers as Lead Bidder for Bread Brands
description: Hostess Brands said on Friday that it has picked Flowers Foods as the lead bidder for most of its bread brands, a group of names that includes onetime staples like Wonder Bread.

title: 1908 Courthouse Reborn as a Museum
description: GLEN COVE, N.Y.

title: When Rangers Roamed the Halls
description: Barry Becks tomato-red perm stopped me in my tracks as I rounded the corner on the second floor of the Ramada Inn in Armonk, N.Y. It was mid-September 1983, and I had been in the hotels employ for two weeks. It was only then that I noticed the squirming mummy being carried by Beck, the Rangers captain, and Nick Fotiu, the teams resident brawler.

title: Twelfth Night Twit Gets a Turn in the Spotlight
description: Even the most audacious actors rarely play a suicide attempt for laughs. But in his acclaimed one-man show I, Malvolio, the British performer Tim Crouch flings a noose over a ceiling pipe, slides a chair underneath and blames everyone for his lot in life  audience members included. So will they muster compassion for this character, a puritanical blowhard who has just spent 30 minutes attacking them for a variety of sins, or will they indulge baser instincts and mock him in kind?

title: A Big Exhibition About an Even Bigger War
description: NEW ORLEANS The project has already taken almost as long as the war it chronicles, and the most difficult part is yet to come. But on Sunday, when the National World War II Museum opens its third building here, it will be just midway through a strategic expansion, creating a $325 million campus of six buildings, extending along three square blocks near the Pontchartrain Expressway. What is promised by 2016 is an epic survey of the American experience during the war.

title: The Flu. Who Knew?
description: Everybody is talking about the flu. Never have I seen so many people trying to open doorknobs with their elbows. Epidemic spurs rush to hospitals, announced The New York Post under a Flu York front-page headline. A financial Web site offered a list of undervalued stocks in the funeral service industry. The mayor of Boston declared a public health emergency. Google Flu Trends painted a map of the country in deep red and inspired a raft of terrifying predictions. (Outbreak could be the worst on record.)

title: China: Landslide Buries a Rural Village
description: A rescue operation was under way in a rural part of western China after a landslide buried a village in Yunnan Province, killing at least 42 people and injuring two others, the authorities said Friday. Officials in Beijing ordered an all-out rescue effort to search for survivors after reports said that 19 children were among the missing, according to Xinhua, the official state news agency. The landslide, which took place in a mountainous region about 340 miles northeast of Kunming, the provincial capital, was said to have been set off by heavy rain and snow.

title: Sony Defends Zero Dark Thirty After Oscar Voter Speaks Out
description: LOS ANGELES  Its official: Zero Dark Thirty is now a political football not just in the United States Senate, where several senators have been challenging its portrayal of torture in the hunt for Osama bin Laden, but also within the voting ranks of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Bolivia: Morales Wins Victory as U.N. Agrees to Define Some Coca Use as Legal
description: Traditional uses of the coca leaf in Bolivia will no longer be considered illegal under a United Nations antidrug convention, the organization said Friday. Coca is the plant used to make cocaine, but many people in Bolivia, which has a majority indigenous population, chew it as a mild stimulant, a use that has continued since pre-Colombian times. Bolivians also use the plant as a tea, in medicines and in religious or social rituals. The government of President Evo Morales withdrew from the international agreement a year ago as it sought an exception for traditional uses of the plant within its borders. The change was a diplomatic victory for Mr. Morales, above. To block the change, 62 United Nations members would have had to object; only 15 did, including the United States. Bolivia will now rejoin the convention, which could help it receive aid in fighting drug trafficking.

title: Russia: Ex-Defense Chief Faces Accusers
description: State investigators on Friday accused the former defense minister, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, of obstructing a corruption investigation into real estate dealings by the Defense Ministry, and suggested that he might soon face criminal charges. Mr. Serdyukov, who was dismissed by President Vladimir V. Putin in November, invoked his constitutional right not to incriminate himself during an interrogation, a spokesman for the state Investigative Committee said. Several of his former aides have already been charged in the case.

title: Pictures From the Week in Business, Jan. 11
description: President Obama nominated Jacob J. Lew to be the Treasury secretary, the Consumer Electronics Show took over Las Vegas and Boeing ran into more problems with its 787 Dreamliner.

title: Senator Reid Takes Fresh Aim
description: During a tight re-election campaign in 2010, when the vote of gun owners was crucial, Harry Reid, the Democratic majority leader of the Senate, not only showed his prowess with a 12-gauge shotgun  hitting two clay pigeons from the air  but also invited Wayne LaPierre, chief executive officer of the National Rifle Association, as his guest for the opening of a new shooting range in Searchlight, Nev. Mr. Reid, a former policeman, eagerly displayed his sportsmans enthusiasm to the voters.

title: Horse Deaths at Aqueduct Stir Action by State Board
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced Friday that it would order necropsies for all horses that sustain deadly racing injuries on Aqueducts inner dirt track after four fatalities at the racetracks meet, which opened Dec. 12.

title: Little Hope Seen for Iran Nuclear Talks
description: The top United Nations nuclear monitoring official expressed renewed pessimism on Friday about negotiations with Iran, set for next week. The talks are aimed at gaining access to a restricted military area, which his inspectors suspect may have been used for atomic bomb-trigger testing work. The official, Yukiya Amano, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, said that the outlook is not bright for obtaining permission from Iran to visit the site, Parchin, which is about 20 miles south of Tehran. Mr. Amanos remarks contrasted with a more optimistic tone from the agency less than a month ago, when his deputy, Herman Nackaerts, expressed hope that the negotiations this Wednesday would lead to final agreement on an inspection plan.

title: Makers of Violent Video Games Marshal Support to Fend Off Regulation
description: WASHINGTON  With the Newtown, Conn., massacre spurring concern over violent video games, makers of popular games like Call of Duty and Mortal Kombat are rallying Congressional support to try to fend off their biggest regulatory threat in two decades.

title: New Yorks Pension Muscle
description: When the United States Supreme Court issued its flawed 2010 decision in the Citizens United case, unleashing millions of dollars in corporate spending on political campaigns, there seemed to be one small prescription for relief. Justice Anthony Kennedy, writing for the majority, noted that prompt disclosure of political expenditures would allow stockholders and citizens to hold corporations accountable. Shareholders, he said, could determine whether the corporations financing of campaigns advances the corporations interest in making profits.

title: Rebel Coalition in Central African Republic Agrees to a Short Cease-Fire
description: Bringing a tentative close to an uprising that brought the Central African Republic to the brink of civil war, the government and rebel fighters seeking to oust the president signed a deal on Friday for a weeklong cease-fire that could mature into a peace plan.

title: Back When I Was Packing
description: I know what it feels like to be a gun lover.

title: Squidolatry
description: Two points about the giant squid, Architeuthis dux, recently caught on video by Japanese scientists and now writhing all over the Internet. It is not a colossal squid, Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni, which is even larger. And this is not the first deep-water image of a giant squid. In 2004, Japanese scientists photographed one taking their bait nearly 3,000 feet underwater in roughly the same location, some 600 miles south of Japan.

title: The Corvette XP-819
description: In 1964 General Motors engineers built an experimental Corvette called the XP-819. Now it is being restored by a team of automotive craftsmen in Valley Stream, N.Y.

title: Florida Record Store Goes the Way of the 8-Track
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  South Florida, a place forged by people from elsewhere  another state, another country  has always been quick to discard yesterday for tomorrow.

title: Theories and Motives Abound in the Killing of 3 Kurds in Paris
description: PARIS  With her signature long hennaed hair, fiery resolve and olive-green military fatigues, Sakine Cansiz was a feminist, guerrilla fighter and former political prisoner as adept at wielding a machine gun as organizing political protests from a jail cell.

title: Baltimore Fullback Is Dangerous Player in Endangered Role
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Vonta Leach sat at his locker inside the Baltimore Ravens training facility this week, grabbed a pair of scissors and began the painstaking process of cutting through the thick bandages that encased his sprained right knee. He groaned. He grimaced. He stared at a swollen mess.

title: The Afghan Wars Last Chapter?
description: President Obama said on Friday that the United States is moving toward a responsible end to the war in Afghanistan that has lasted for 12 years. At a news conference, he and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan filled in some details on how they would get there, but there are still many questions that must be addressed.

title: Revolutionary Language
description: Listen closely.

title: Mariangela Melato, Italian Actress, Dies at 71
description: Mariangela Melato, an Italian actress who achieved fame alongside Giancarlo Giannini portraying complicated relationships in the provocative films of Lina Wertmller, including The Seduction of Mimi and Swept Away (by an Unusual Destiny in the Blue Sea of August), died on Friday in Rome. She was 71.

title: Portrait of Duchess Is Unveiled, and the Criticism Is Withering
description: LONDON  They did not necessarily know much about art, but they knew they did not like the way the Duchess of Cambridge looked in her new portrait.

title: Goalie Arrives in Vancouver but May Not Stay Long
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  The resolution of the lockout might have wiped the slate clean for most N.H.L. players, but for Vancouver goaltender Roberto Luongo, the end of one wait was the beginning of a new one.

title: New York City Ties Doctors Income to Quality of Care
description: In a bold experiment in performance pay, complaints from patients at New York Citys public hospitals and other measures of their care  like how long before they are discharged and how they fare afterward  will be reflected in doctors paychecks under a plan being negotiated by the physicians and their hospitals.

title: After 65 Years, Specs Records of Florida Closes
description: At Specs Records and Tapes in Coral Gables, the music didnt stop and neither did the memories.

title: Man Taking Generic Drug Can Sue Branded Maker
description: The Alabama Supreme Court ruled on Friday that a patient could sue a brand-name company for failing to warn about a drugs risks even though he had taken a generic version of the product that the company did not make.

title: A Gathering of Banjo Masters
description: When Bla Fleck was growing up and walking the streets of New York City with his banjo in tow, he found that his instrument was often a magnet for derision. What I would hear from people was: Squeal like a pig! a reference to an infamous scene in the John Boorman film Deliverance, or Yee-haw!

title: In Hershey, an Original A.H.L. Team Plays On Uninterrupted
description: HERSHEY, Pa.  Ken Hatt came to town in 1933 to attend what was then known as the Hershey Industrial School, Milton Hersheys boarding school for orphans. After graduating in 1941, he worked in the ticket office at the arena where the Hershey Bears played hockey. He loved the sport, and so, it turned out, did the co-worker who became his wife. They bought their first season tickets in 1946.

title: Winter Jazzfest: Nine-Man Band Fleshes Out a One-Man Show
description: The trombonist and composer-arranger Jacob Garchik released one of the odder (and better) jazz recordings of last year: The Heavens: The Atheist Gospel Trombone Album. The ethical/religious connotations of the album are probably best left to another forum; whats germane here is the fact that the Heavens, on record, is a one-man show, a product of shrewd overdubbing and self-sufficient conviction.

title: In the Wrong Business
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Doug Peterson and Brad Wilber are two of the nicest people I know in the field of crossword puzzle construction. Lovely men they both are, with an air of gentility about them, and decent table manners for the most part. So I dont understand why they insist on beating me silly with their crosswords.

title: Corrections: January 12, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Officer Held in Plot to Kidnap Women Balks at Jail Transfer
description: Gilberto Valle, the New York police officer charged with plotting to kidnap, kill and eat women, had been held in a special unit of the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan, separated from other prisoners, apparently for his own protection.

title: A Collection of Sculpture All About the Artists
description: A hundred years after Pablo Picasso shaped a guitar from cardboard, and nearly a century since Marcel Duchamp signed a urinal and called it art, its easy to forget that these were huge transgressions against the lineage of Western sculpture. Previously, sculpture consisted of objects in stone, bronze or wood. But as Once Removed: Sculptures Changing Frame of Reference at the Yale University Art Gallery shows, sculpture can be made of anything now, from feathers and video to Vaseline.

title: Forcing Turnovers Is the Patriots Way
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  They dont dominate or intimidate. All they do is give you a little wiggle room  and then make you look bad. Sometimes really, really bad.

title: After Immigration Arrests, Online Outcry, and Release
description: PHOENIX  Immigration agents arrested the mother and brother of a prominent activist during a raid at her home here late Thursday, unleashing a vigorous response on social media and focusing new attention on one of the most controversial aspects of the Obama administrations policies on deportation.

title: With Skullcandy, Look Stylish While Playing Video Games
description: Skullcandy is known for adding youthful flair to audio gear. So when the company acquired Astro Gaming, a maker of premium gaming accessories, it made sense that it would introduce a line of stylish, less-expensive gaming headsets with the Skullcandy brand.

title: No Jail Time for Ex-Doctor, 85, Convicted of Drug Charge
description: The former doctor sat in courton Friday waiting to be sentenced for a crime that breached every tenet of his professional code. He had run his house in Staten Island like a drug mill, selling the prescription painkiller oxycodone to all comers  including undercover federal agents. The guideline sentence for his crimes was up to six years.

title: On Subway Platforms, More Warnings for Riders
