title: Times Square Bow Tie Is to Get Belts of Steel and Granite
description: Times Square, one the most free-flowing public spaces in the world, will be constrained a bit by the addition of dozens of stainless-steel bollards and granite barriers that are intended to prevent terrorists  and drunks  from driving vehicles on to the pedestrian plazas that have been created between West 42nd and West 47th Streets.

title: Disruptions: Design Rivals Technology in Importance
description: Last year, at Apples event to announce the iPad Mini, I was wandering around the gadget petting zoo the company sets up after each product unveiling. As I turned a corner, I bumped into Timothy D. Cook, Apples chief executive, who immediately wanted to show me something.

title: Notes on Japanese Numbers (Boring)
description: A bit of a backup, utility post, for those trying to keep track of these things.

title: Now Streaming | Prada Fall 2013 Mens Collection
description: The Fall 2013 mens collection from Prada at Milan Fashion Week, scheduled to commence at 6 p.m. Milan time. Delays may occur.

title: Bomb Kills 14 Pakistani Soldiers as Attacks Shake Up Provincial Government
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A powerful roadside bomb in the militant hub of North Waziristan killed at least 14 Pakistani soldiers and wounded at least 25 on Sunday, a senior military official and local tribesmen said.

title: Zero Dark Thirty, in Wider Release, Captures Box-Office Crown
description: Controversy about its torture scenes certainly didnt hurt Zero Dark Thirty as it expanded nationwide over the weekend. The dramatic thriller about the hunt for Osama bin Laden took in a strong $24 million, easily enough for No. 1. Zero Dark Thirty, a Sony-distributed film that cost about $45 million to make, has grossed an estimated $29.5 million since arriving in limited release on Dec. 19, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data.

title: Foxconn Begins Bribery Investigation
description: SHANGHAI  Foxconn Technology, the huge contract electronics manufacturer that makes the Apple iPhone and other popular products, said that it was investigating whether its employees had accepted bribes from supply-chain partners.

title: Photos of The Moment | Versace
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Washington Is Home (for Now at Least), but Sotomayor Stays True to New York
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Sonia Sotomayor is a proud daughter of New York City, and her adjustment to life in the nations capital has been rocky. Do not get her started, for instance, on ordering takeout.

title: Prada: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: Milan

title: Original Review: Picnic
description: Brooks Atkinsons 1953 review of William Inges play.

title: Powell Defends Obamas Pick for Defense
description: President Obamas nominee for secretary of defense, Chuck Hagel, received a resounding vote of support on Sunday from a fellow Republican moderate, Colin L. Powell, who said Mr. Hagel, a former senator from Nebraska, was superbly qualified to lead the Pentagon.

title: Excerpt: 'Picnic' on Broadway
description: Sebastian Stan, Ben Rappaport and Ellen Burstyn in a scene from the Broadway revival of William Inge's play.

title: Prada
description: Milan

title: U.S. Debate on Gun Laws Is Put to a Test in Colorado
description: DENVER  With politicians in Washington deeply divided over new gun regulations, an urgent national debate ignited by the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School is storming into state legislatures across the country. And nowhere is that debate more emotionally charged or politically consequential than here in Colorado, a reluctant crucible for the battle over guns.

title: Photos of The Moment | Neil Barrett
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Ed Asner Adds His Voice to Zero Dark Thirty Protest
description: LOS ANGELES  Sunday dawned crisp and clear here, with wintry (for Southern California) temperatures lingering in the 40s and 50s. But the rhetoric was already hot, as Hollywood got ready for a Golden Globes ceremony at which the table talk  if not the stage banter  almost inevitably will turn to the political flare-up around Zero Dark Thirty.

title: Seeking Fresh Start, Knicks Dispatch Hornets With Ease
description: The Knicks called it a must-win game, a first for them this season. They vowed to be the more aggressive, more physical team on their home court. And they said they were going to use this game, a Sunday matinee against theNew Orleans Hornets, as a way to start a new winning streak after their first three-game skid.

title: Applause at Missoni, but an Empty Stage
description: MILAN  Rising for a standing ovation at the end of the Missoni show, as much in respectful sympathy as praise, the crowd here this afternoon found itself clapping for no one.

title: The Very Model of a Modern Major Lyricist
description: Try to imagine how American musical comedy might have evolved without the precedent of Gilbert and Sullivan, and be thankful for the elevated standard of satirical nonsense this British teams delirious patter songs established for the 20th century. In the words of Alan J. Lerner, W. S. Gilbert raised lyric writing from a serviceable craft to a legitimate popular art form. Johnny Mercer bluntly declared, We all come from Gilbert. Would it be stretching a point to suggest that rap songs fusillades of rhyme also owe something to Gilbert?

title: At a Temple of Electronica, Drumming Up Lights to Carry the Rest
description: Gaping holes and deliberate convolutions define the songs of Purity Ring, the Canadian duo that performed at Webster Hall on Saturday night, the second of two nights. Megan James is the singer and occasional percussionist; Corin Roddick controls the electronics and keeps busy in real time with drumsticks, tapping on lanterns that light up as they trigger individual notes. Purity Ring combines programmed tracks that are overtly artificial with idiosyncratic content, creating a carnal presence in a digital environment.

title: Real-World Killings Pressure TV Fiction
description: LOS ANGELES  When Kevin Reilly, the chairman for entertainment at the Fox network, commissioned an ambitious thriller series called The Following, about a Hannibal Lecter-like serial killer who inspires a legion of deranged followers, his intention was to challenge the cable business, not the culture.

title: A Met Debut Helps Elevate Puccinis Stepchild of an Opera
description: Often when a young singer makes a Metropolitan Opera debut, the engagement is in effect a tryout for potential future assignments. Not so with the Latvian soprano Kristine Opolais, who made her Met debut on Friday night as Magda in Puccinis Rondine, a return of Nicolas Jols stylish 2008 production. Without releasing the details a Met official made it clear before her debut that the company has some big plans for Ms. Opolais in coming seasons

title: In a Work From the Dawn of Opera, Daniel Avoids Becoming Some Lions Lunch
description: The point of operas origins, the moment when various age-old combinations of music and drama came together in a newly integrated way, keeps being pushed further back.

title: To Tell a Story, You Have to Have the Right Moves
description: Dance is an oral tradition in which roles and works are passed one from one generation to the next. But what happens to the personal stories? On Thursday evening at the Theater at the 14th Street Y the dancer Todd Allen shared a good one in honor of The Men Dancers: From the Horses Mouth. At the age of 5, while growing up in Salt Lake City, he planted a tree with Martha Graham, who was traveling through the city. As the only boy in his dance program, Mr. Allen was chosen to appear at the ceremony. Graham was a pyramid of purple with a head in a bun, as he put it. I dont remember any arms.

title: A Deadpan Look at Life Before and After a Stroke
description: I found myself praying, Peggy Shaw says in her new solo show Ruff, recalling the day she suffered a stroke. It seemed the natural thing to do, since she had already fallen to her knees. If you get me through this I will stop wearing suits, she remembers thinking. I will get married. I will pay market rent in Manhattan. I will not wear skinny jeans. Ill take antidepressants.

title: Photos of The Moment | Calvin Klein
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: An Effort to Untangle Scientologys Mysteries
description: Lawrence Wrights avowed purpose in writing Going Clear is to understand why Scientology, a religion known for its bizarre creation myth, mining of church members secrets and draconian punishment system, has appeal. What do its adherents get out of it? he asks. How can seemingly rational people subscribe to beliefs that others find incomprehensible? Why do public personalities  hes talking to you, Tom Cruise  associate themselves with a faith that is likely to create a kind of public relations martyrdom?

title: Before Carrie Graduated to Those Manolos
description: Seen outside the long shadow cast by Sex and the City, The Carrie Diaries is relatively inoffensive (based on its pilot episode): a fair to middling CW teenage soap opera with some nice performances, particularly by Matt Letscher as the father of the 16-year-old Carrie Bradshaw and Austin Butler as her first crush. Its not relationship material, but you wouldnt feel guilty about spending a night with it.

title: What Is On Your Tennis Wish List for 2013?
description: The Australian Open begins in a few hours, and with the seasons first Grand Slam tournament comes contemplation about the year ahead. The Times Christopher Clarey lays out what he hopes to see during the 2013 season. Among his wishes are a run at a Grand Slam, better rivalries in womens tennis, accurate speed guns, a better antidoping program, and breakthroughs for Chinese men and South American women. He would also like to see players take a break from towel breaks:

title: Years of Frustration to Tears of Joy
description: ATLANTA  Through more than 250 games with two teams in 16 N.F.L. seasons, Tony Gonzalez never cried tears of joy. He saw players on other teams do it, of course, watching with envy as his opponents were so overwhelmed by the emotion of a victory that they wept on their shoulder pads. But for Gonzalez, those tears never came.

title: Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan
description: The second most successful team at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last month was Justine Cushing, Melih Ozdil and Joel Wooldridge of New York City, and Adam Kaplan of New Port Richey, Fla. In five events they had three wins, one second and one fourth.

title: After Rocky Year for Start-Ups, Investors Are Pickier
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Call it the Facebook effect. Until recently, investors had been all too eager to pour millions into any Web start-up with rapid growth, regardless of whether it made money or even had plans to do so down the road. But after Facebooks rocky initial public offering and flameouts at Zynga and Groupon, venture capitalists are entering a picky phase.

title: They Left Their Hearts at Coogans Bluff
description: Once they were the darlings of Coogans Bluff, but now the San Francisco Giants are the darlings of a bar in New Yorks East Village as well as thousands of passionate baseball fans back East who stay up late to root.

title: Argo, Les Miz, Homeland and Girls Win Big at the Golden Globes
description: Tonight the Hollywood Foreign Press Association handed out its Golden Globe awards at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

title: Taylor Dance Company Offers a Bargain
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is to announce on Monday that it will commemorate the 25th anniversary of Mr. Taylors Brandenburgs (above) and Speaking in Tongues by selling $5 tickets to the March 6 performance of the two dances in four separate pop-up shops across Manhattan. Every seat at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center will be sold at the discounted price, and tickets will be distributed equally among all pop-up locations. Tickets must be purchased in person, with a limit of two per buyer. More information including participating sites, on-sale times and dates can be obtained by calling (212) 431-5562.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data scheduled to be released includes retail sales for December, the Producer Price Index for December, and business inventories for November (Tuesday); the Consumer Price Index for December, industrial production for December and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, housing starts for December and the Philadelphia Fed index for January (Thursday); and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for January (Friday).

title: Serious Flaw in Java Software Is Found, Then Patched
description: 6:53 p.m. | Updated Oracle fixed a security flaw in its Java software on Sunday, after the Department of Homeland Security warned users to disable Java software completely, citing a security hole that allows hackers to take control of their machines.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Winter Jazz Festival Packs in the Bands, Ideas and Crowds
description: The ninth annual Winter Jazzfest reached capacity at around 7:30 on Saturday night, which meant that a lot of bands that arent completely hot in New York became so by the laws of supply and demand. It was right around that time that I heard the owner of the Zinc Bar, Alex Kay, use this-inbox-is-full tones to deliver the following sentence to a line of disappointed faces on West Third Street in Greenwich Village: You will not get in to see Tigran tonight.

title: Winter Jazzfest 2013
description: Scenes from the ninth annual music festival.

title: What Speeding Cars Do
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Steve Salmon must have what recording engineers call Golden EARS. His third time out in The New York Times as a crossword constructor is no different than his first two times: cleverly punny and sure to cause a guffaw or two. Some people can just hear where the puns are, and apparently Mr. Salmon is one of them.

title: More Modest Growth for China
description: Consumer-price inflation is rising in China and producer-price declines have eased. Those trends are a sign that the economys maximum sustainable growth rate may not rebound to its previous double-digit levels.

title: Documenting a Generations Fall
description: One of the lasting effects of the Great Recession has been the economic spiral downward of the American middle class, and no group has been harder hit than the boomer generation, men and women in the prime of their working lives.

title: A Hilton Web Site Prescribes Vacations for Workers Ills
description: HILTON HOTELS AND RESORTS, the flagship brand of Hilton Worldwide, has joined forces with The Onion, the satirical news Web site, to attract leisure travelers to its hotels, following in the footsteps of other advertisers who are using humor to lure younger customers.

title: President of Sri Lanka Dismisses Chief Justice
description: NEW DELHI  President Mahinda Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka removed the nations chief justice from office on Sunday in the culmination of a widely criticized impeachment process that has crippled the nations courts and may precipitate a constitutional crisis.

title: In Beleaguered Detroit, a Media-Wise Group Shows Reporters the Brighter Side
description: In September, a group of nearly 40 journalists and bloggers, some from well-known news organizations like Forbes, Bloomberg, The Wall Street Journal and Reuters, boarded a bus in downtown Detroit and headed for one of the most run-down neighborhoods in the city. As they peered through the windows at block after block of dilapidated, abandoned homes, a young community organizer spoke eloquently about the areas revitalization efforts.

title: Katherine Sarafian and Mark Andrews
description: An interview with Katherine Sarafian and Mark Andrews, the producer and the director of the animated film Brave.

title: The Seventh-Generation Corvette Is Unveiled in Detroit
description: DETROIT  The Stingray is back, in name and in spirit.

title: Google Gains From Creating Apps for the Opposition
description: For many people, smartphone shopping comes down to a choice of Apples iPhone or one powered by Googles Android software.

title: Questioning Greek Growth
description: Suzanne Daley, a Times correspondent, reports from Greece on efforts to raise revenue with gold mining despite worries about environmental dangers and lax oversight.

title: First Rangers Practice Finds Tortorella in Midseason Form
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The N.H.L. got back to business Sunday, which for the Rangers meant that John Tortorella, their ingenious and volatile coach, was back in charge, damning by faint praise and praising by faint damns.

title: Guns, Maps and Data That Disturb
description: Should data have a conscience?

title: Jason Clarke at the Golden Globes
description: A chat with the actor Jason Clarke, appearing in Zero Dark Thirty.

title: Hagel to Meet Schumer to Discuss Policy Issues
description: WASHINGTON  In what could be a crucial moment in the Obama administrations efforts to advance the nomination of former Senator Chuck Hagel as secretary of defense, he will meet this week with Senator Charles E. Schumer, the most influential Jewish member of the Senate, who is expected to press Mr. Hagel on issues concerning Iran and Israel.

title: The Myth of Nuclear Necessity
description: TRENTON

title: The Red Carpet at the Golden Globes
description: Style from the red carpet of the 70th Golden Globes.

title: Greece Sees Gold Boom, but at a Price
description: IERISSOS, Greece  In the forest near here, bulldozers have already begun flattening hundreds of acres for an open pit gold mine and a processing plant, which Canadas Eldorado Gold Corporation hopes to open within two years. Eldorado has reopened other mining operations around here, too, digging for gold, copper, zinc and lead from nearby hills.

title: Invasion of the Data Snatchers
description: YOU are the editor of a local newspaper. A reporter on your staff comes to you having obtained (by legal means) one of the following:

title: Flawed Forensic Work

title: Rise in Health Premiums
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunger in Guatemala
description: To the Editor:

title: Core Beliefs of the G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Mercedes-Benz CLA Plays Peek-a-Boo
description: DETROIT  Mercedes-Benz offered a sneak preview here on Sunday night of its 2014 CLA250, a harbinger of an all-new range of small cars designed to compete with the BMW 1 Series and similarly sized small luxury models.

title: Digital Reading on the Rise for Children (With a Qualifier)
description: Digital reading is rising fast among children ages 6 to 17, but this is not necessarily translating into a greater desire to read, according to a report released on Monday by Scholastic Inc.

title: With Transit Chairmanship, a Familiar Face Slips Back Onstage
description: THE answer was obvious even before the question was posed, but we felt like asking anyway. Given reports that Michael R. Bloomberg has been shopping around for someone hed like to anoint as the next mayor, is it possible that Fernando Ferrer got a call? Mr. Ferrer smiled. It was a half-smile, one registering both amusement and bemusement.

title: Hollande, Long Seen as Soft, Shifts Image With Firm Stance
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France has regularly been criticized as indecisive, even complacent. But the events of the last few days will go some way toward changing his image, as Mr. Hollande has moved swiftly to use the French military in Mali and Somalia after pulling off an important compromise with domestic unions over job creation.

title: Cond Nast Writer Deals Stir Dispute
description: Its a dream tucked in the backs of many journalists minds: the article they write becomes a blockbuster movie and they reap a healthy share of the profits, a walk on the red carpet and  who knows?  maybe even an Oscar.

title: Private Pain, Played Out on Public Stage
description: BOSTON  When he was a boy in North Carolina in the 1960s, Michael Mack wanted to be a priest, until his priest sexually molested him. He prayed he would forget the experience, but, he said, the memory tingled like a phantom limb.

title: House to Take Up Storm Relief Bill Amid Battle Over Spending
description: WASHINGTON  The House will move ahead this week with a multibillion-dollar package to provide aid to victims of Hurricane Sandy, but the legislation is already caught in an escalating debate over spending and deficits that foreshadows another ugly fight among Republicans.

title: Taking to the Stage to Recount Abuse
description: Michael Mack wanted to be a priest, until his priest sexually molested him. The result is Conversations With My Molester: A Journey of Faith.

title: Georgia Frees 190 Inmates Deemed Political Prisoners
description: TBILISI, Georgia  Georgia on Sunday released 190 inmates identified by lawmakers as political prisoners, the first group to be freed under a sweeping amnesty law passed last year by a new Parliament.

title: Univision to Form an Internal Advertising and Media Unit
description: Univision Communications, in its quest to unify the look and feel of the network and its properties, is expected to announce on Monday the creation of the companys first internal advertising and media agency. The new unit, Univision Agency, will create promotional content for all Univision properties, including broadcast, radio and digital, and provide research and creative services for internal and external clients.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: After Decades, Cuba Eases Travel Rules to Maintain Ties
description: HAVANA  The door slammed shut behind Gloria 11 months after she left Cuba for Miami in mid-2011. Close to her dream of obtaining American residency, she ignored her governments deadline to return home and gave up her rights as a Cuban.

title: Japan Steps Out
description: For three years economic policy throughout the advanced world has been paralyzed, despite high unemployment, by a dismal orthodoxy. Every suggestion of action to create jobs has been shot down with warnings of dire consequences. If we spend more, the Very Serious People say, the bond markets will punish us. If we print more money, inflation will soar. Nothing should be done because nothing can be done, except ever harsher austerity, which will someday, somehow, be rewarded.

title: Ralph G. Martin, a Best-Selling Biographer, Dies at 92
description: Ralph G. Martin, a best-selling author of political and celebrity biographies whose subjects included the Kennedys, Golda Meir and Winston Churchills mother, died on Wednesday in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 92.

title: After Years of Discord, California and Nevada Agree on Tahoe Development
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif.  Deep in the Sierra Nevada, 39 trillion gallons of crystalline water straddles the border between California and Nevada.

title: What Is a Hacktivist?
description: The untimely death of the young Internet activist Aaron Swartz, apparently by suicide, has prompted an outpouring of reaction in the digital world. Foremost among the debates being reheated  one which had already grown in the wake of larger and more daring data breaches in the past few years  is whether Swartzs activities as a hacktivist were being unfairly defined as malicious or criminal. In particular, critics (as well as Swartzs family in a formal statement) have focused on the federal governments indictment of Swartz for downloading millions of documents from the scholarly database JSTOR, an action which JSTOR itself had declined to prosecute.

title: U.S. Warplanes Enter Somalia Airspace
description: American warplanes entered Somali airspace on Friday in support of an attempt by French commandos to rescue a French agent held hostage by Al Shabab militants in Somalia, President Obama told Congress in a letter on Sunday.

title: Win in Rematch Sets Up Another
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  There were still 20 minutes of football to be played at Gillette Stadium when the game ended. Exploding fireworks, euphoria in the stands, all zeros on the clock  confirmation of it all would come soon enough, and indeed it did.

title: Proposing the Unprecedented to Avoid Default
Ex-Montana Athlete Sentenced in Rape
description: HELENA, Mont.  A former running back for the University of Montana Grizzlies football team has been sentenced to 30 years in jail for the rape of a childhood friend in 2010 as she slept on a sofa in his apartment.

title: One Republican Steps Forward
description: Until now, the Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, has not seen a single member of his caucus dare to buck his fierce opposition to a law requiring fuller disclosure of campaign contributions. But last month, Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, broke through the partisan wall to propose a badly needed mandate for transparency by the growing army of unrestricted, unidentified donors who underwrite attack ads and other stealth tactics that have so disfigured American politics.

title: Can the Catholic Schools Be Saved?
description: To the Editor:

title: Japans Latest Economic Transfusion
description: The $116 billion stimulus package unveiled Friday by Japans new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, is a step in the right direction for the worlds third-largest economy and Americas fourth-largest trading partner. Mr. Abes predecessors in the center-left Democratic Party unwisely followed a course of fiscal austerity, and paid the price for it last month at the polls.

title: An Incomplete Fix
description: Thanks to the fiscal cliff deal, the alternative minimum tax will not ensnare tens of millions of middle-class Americans for whom it was never intended. The deal raised the income thresholds before the A.M.T. kicks in and indexes them for inflation going forward. As a practical matter, this means that 28 million filers who would have had to pay the tax on their 2012 returns have been spared and are much less likely to have to pay the tax in the future.

title: Wilson Already Looking Ahead to Beginning His Sophomore Season
description: ATLANTA  In the morgue silence of the Seattle locker room, several Seahawks sat frozen on folding chairs, staring straight ahead at nothing. A few heads were hidden beneath white towels. One player sniffled.

title: Judd Apatow at the Golden Globes
description: A talk with Judd Apatow, the producer of the series Girls.

title: Unspeedy Trial in Louisiana
description: It has been nearly 50 years since the Supreme Court held that the Constitution guarantees every indigent criminal defendant a right to counsel.

title: Vereens Fun Game Puts Oomph in Patriots Run Game
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  He figured he would at least play. That much Shane Vereen thought he could count on for the Patriots playoff opener Sunday against the Houston Texans. He had earned that much with his play during the regular season, hadnt he?

title: French Strikes in Mali Supplant Caution of U.S.
description: BAMAKO, Mali  French fighter jets struck deep inside Islamist strongholds in northern Mali on Sunday, shoving aside months of international hesitation about storming the region after every other effort by the United States and its allies to thwart the extremists had failed.

title: Both Sides in Gun Debate Agree: Punish Background-Check Liars
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 80,000 Americans were denied guns in 2010, according to Justice Department data, because they lied or provided inaccurate information about their criminal histories on background-check forms. Yet only 44 of those people were charged with a crime.

title: Nets Fight Through Injuries and Surge Past Pacers
description: Coach P. J. Carlesimo was reluctant to admit it, but there was added emphasis on Sundays game for the Nets. His players did not shy away from weighty superlatives and used terms like playoffs and need to win.

title: Upstate Gun Owners Cast a Cold Eye on Cuomo Effort
description: TONAWANDA, N.Y.  Harold W. Schroeders first gun was his late fathers prized Winchester 12-gauge shotgun, bequeathed to him when he turned 16. In college, Mr. Schroeder and his classmates kept guns in their fraternity house so they could hunt pheasant.

title: A Data Crusader, a Defendant and Now, a Cause
description: At an afternoon vigil at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Sunday, Aaron Swartz, the 26-year-old technology wunderkind who killed himself on Friday, was remembered as a great programmer and a provocative thinker by a handful of students who attended.

title: Australian Open Chronicles: Greetings from Down Under
description: Irina Falconi, an American who is playing at the Australian Open, will write posts throughout the tournament for Straight Sets as she did during the United States Open last year. She has her own tumblr page, and can be followed on Twitter.

title: Mandy Patinkin at the Golden Globes
description: An interview with Mandy Patinkin, an actor on "Homeland."

title: Lottery Numbers
Devils Start Working While Waiting for Kovalchuk to Return
description: NEWARK  As delighted as the Devils were to begin crash-course preparations Sunday for a 48-game regular season after the lockout, the focus was inevitably on the players who were not there.

title: In California, Its U.S. vs. State Over Marijuana
description: STOCKTON, Calif.  Matthew R. Davies graduated from college with a masters degree in business and a taste for enterprise, working in real estate, restaurants and mobile home parks before seizing on what he saw as uncharted territory with a vast potential for profits  medical marijuana.

title: Crowned Miss America 2013, Living in a Borough of Ms.
description: When the news rippled through the bars, cafes and organic markets, some people just raised their eyebrows. Others laughed.

title: Michael Haneke at the Golden Globes
description: The director Michael Haneke discusses "Amour."

title: Kansas Heat That Has Little to Do With the Weather
description: The Roundabout Theater Companys revival of William Inges Picnic opened on Sunday night, starring an exceptionally well-developed torso. Of course the torso belongs to a person, the actor Sebastian Stan. But it has been given the kind of lavish individual attention that would seem to warrant above-the-title billing.

title: South Park Creators to Start Company, Important Studios
description: The creators of South Park are branching out beyond the underpants business.

title: City Officials Say School Bus Strike Would Be Irresponsible
description: The New York City schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, said on Sunday that a strike by the citys school bus drivers was all but inevitable and angrily dismissed it as irresponsible and disrespectful to students and parents.

title: Actors From Argo at the Golden Globes
description: Victor Garber and Tate Donovan discuss their acting work in "Argo."

title: Newtown Debates Schools Fate After Shooting
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Many people here still remember the huge green footprints that once led up to the front entrance of Sandy Hook Elementary School. Children were told that they had been left by the Jolly Green Giant.

title: David O. Russell at the Golden Globes
description: David O. Russell, the director of Silver Linings Playbook, discusses his film.

title: Armstrongs Business Brand, Bound Tight With His Charity
description: After Lance Armstrong was successfully treated for testicular cancer more than 15 years ago, his sports agent predicted that the rising cycling star, then in his 20s, would be more marketable than ever.

title: Pharmacies Pressed to Meet High Demand for Flu Vaccine
description: Pharmacies around the city struggled to meet the demand for flu vaccinations on Sunday, a day after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared a public health state of emergency in response to a drastic increase in the number of flu cases this year.

title: Finding in Kung Fu Movies a Refuge, and Perhaps a Calling
description: Alejandrina Cruz may be the only Bronx grandmother with a kung fu movie collection to rival that of a subway salesman laden with cartons of contraband.

title: Zosia Mamet at the Golden Globes
description: A talk with Zosia Mamet, an actress from Girls, on the Golden Globes red carpet.

title: Knicks Stars Latest Move: Changing Their Diets
description: The Knicks two highest-paid players, Carmelo Anthony and Amare Stoudemire, took a break from talking about basketball after Sundays game to discuss their recent diets: Stoudemire revealed that he has been following a vegan diet for almost three months, and Anthony said he had spent the past 15 days fasting.

title: Hornets Say Theyre Eager to Lean on Davis, as Soon as Hes Ready for It
description: Anthony Davis did not alter many shots against the Knicks on Sunday. He rebounded the ball mostly when it came near him and scored 13 points on 13 shots, with eight rebounds and a block. His well-known unibrow  a furry caterpillar lounging above his eyes, a valley nestled between two grassy hills  was more conspicuous than his play.

title: Susan Nolen-Hoeksema, Psychologist Who Studied Depression in Women, Dies at 53
description: Susan Nolen-Hoeksema, a psychologist and writer whose work helped explain why women are twice as prone to depression as men and why such low moods can be so hard to shake, died on Jan. 2 in New Haven. She was 53.

title: List of Golden Globe Winners
description: MoviesBest Picture, Drama:Argo

title: Inquiry Is Said to Find Fraud at Bronx Water Plant
description: An investigation into work performed on the troubled $3.2 billion Croton water treatment plant in the Bronx, one of the citys largest public works projects, has uncovered fraud and other crimes that are expected to lead to criminal charges against two men, and a deferred prosecution agreement, according to people with knowledge of the case.

title: A.F.C. Championship Preview: Ravens at Patriots
description: Ravens (12-6) at Patriots (13-4)6:30 p.m. Eastern, SundayCBS Line: Patriots by 8.5

title: Chinas Citic Telecom in $1.2 Billion Deal for Macau Phone Company
description: HONG KONGShares in Citic Telecom, a unit of the state-backed Chinese conglomerate Citic Group, soared after it announced a $1.2 billion deal to take control of the dominant telecommunications company in the casino hub of Macau.

description: MELBOURNE, Australia  It has been the right time for some long, hard looks in the mirror for Caroline Wozniacki, long No. 1 but now No. 10.

description: A view of the day in sports, from N.F.L. playoff games to the first practices of N.H.L. teams.

title: A Salute to Girl Power in Hollywood
description: At a time when President Obama is under attack for appointing so many white men  and so few women  to senior positions in the White House, Hollywood seemed intent Sunday on correcting the imbalance at the Golden Globes.

title: In Swartz Tribute, Hackers Attack M.I.T. Site
description: Anonymous, the loose collective of hackers, attacked the Web site of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology on Sunday, in a tribute to Aaron Swartz, the 26-year-old technology programmer who killed himself on Friday.

title: Golden Globes to Argo and Les Misrables
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Hollywood insiders had a field day on Sunday as the 70th Golden Globes turned into a feast of smart-mouthed humor aimed at two of their favorite subjects: politics and themselves.

title: North Korea: Tweeting Its Way to the Future?
description: BEIJING  Twitter in North Korea? It sounds about as likely as snow in the tropics.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is not like looking for a needle in a haystack  these are people you know are too violent to buy a gun.

title: Corrections: January 14, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Government Quells Maoist Rebellion in West Bengal
description: KOLKATA Prime Minister Manmohan Singh has often called the conflict against the Communist Party of India (Maoist) the greatest internal security threat that India faces. With some 6,000 dead in Indias heartland since 2005 alone, it has certainly been one of the most violent.

title: A City of Black Coats
description: Dear Diary:

title: U.P.S., Facing Resistance in Europe, Drops Bid for TNT Express
description: 8:41 p.m. | Updated

title: News Quiz | January 14, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Steppe by Steppe
description: DALANZADGAD, Mongolia  The fire went out at 3 a.m. The cold on the floor of the ger woke me up. It was mid-December and minus-7 degrees Fahrenheit on our scrap of the Gobi Desert. As I lay awake, on the other side of the ger from a family of three, I thought that of all the people in the world, Gobi nomads must be the toughest. Drought and cold and sandstorms and isolation confound the gathering of the materials that perpetuate life, and yet these people survive.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 14, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article N.H.L. and Players Union Reach Tentative Agreement to End Lockout.

title: Violence Against Women in India
description: In Indias New Focus on Rape Shows Only the Surface of Womens Perils, Gardiner Harris writes about the epidemic of violence against women in India.

title: Faded Colors, Empty Rooms on the Shore
description: The first time Douglas Ljungkvist saw Ocean Beach, N.J., it reminded him of a labor camp. It was 1993 and Mr. Ljungkvists then-girlfriend had suggested they rent a cottage in the Jersey Shore hamlet, as her family had done for years.

title: Is Dating a Thing of the Past?
description: Dinner and a movie. A walk in a park after a picnic for two. They might not be original, but these are classic date ideas.

title: Part 1: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
description: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

title: The Science of Prophets and Profits
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. She recently edited and contributed to For Love and Money: Care Provision in the United States.

title: The Early Word: Guns
description: Todays Times

title: In Chile, Turbulence Ahead
description: Jim Thomson is principal oceanographer at the Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. He studies ocean surface waves and coastal processes and wrote about his expedition to the North Pacific in the fall.

title: The Oldest Crime in the Book
description: MOSCOW  All we talk about these days is murder. Someone I used to know, one of those people who is everyones friend, is accused of having murdered his wife. After killing her, he ostensibly staged an elaborate hoax, pretending to search for her for days before he even tried to dispose of the body  whereupon, if the police are to be believed, he was caught and confessed.

title: China Hints at Far Wider Welcome to Overseas Investors
description: HONG KONG  In what would be a drastic liberalization of Chinas huge but still cloistered capital markets, the countrys top securities regulator said Monday that foreign investment could be allowed to rise as much as tenfold.

title: Erasing Playoff Demons, One Atlanta Player at a Time
description: Here it goes again. I guess it wasnt meant to be. Atlanta tight end Tony Gonzalez, talking about his thoughts when Seattle scored 21 consecutive points in the fourth quarter to take a 28-27 lead.

title: India Could Retaliate Against Pakistan for Beheading, Army Chief Says
description: The Indian military may retaliate at a time of its choosing for the recent beheading of an Indian soldier by the Pakistani army, the chief of the Indian army said Monday, ahead of a meeting at the border of the two countries.

title: Shots Fired Into Offices of Greek Governing Party
description: ATHENS  Unidentified gunmen sprayed bullets into the headquarters of Greeces governing New Democracy party in central Athens before dawn on Monday, adding to a wave of politically motivated violence in recent days as Greece struggles with its worst economic crisis in a decade.

title: U.N. Official Urges Scrutiny of North Korea
description: GENEVA  The chief human rights official at the United Nations, Navi Pillay, called on Monday for an international inquiry into human rights offenses committed by the North Korean government over many decades.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 14
description: NEWS French fighter jets struck deep inside Islamist strongholds in northern Mali on Sunday, shoving aside months of international hesitation about storming the region after every other effort by the United States and its allies to thwart the extremists had failed. Adam Nossiter, Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti report.

title: Behind the Cover Story: Stephen Rodrick on Getting Access to Lindsay Lohan
description: Stephen Rodrick, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this weeks cover article about the making of the movie The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader and includesLindsay Lohan. title: The Fitbit Flex Improves on Its Rivals

By measuring your physical activity, and even comparing your efforts with your friends, they make you constantly aware of your sad sedentary life, and always remind you to take the stairs or park farther away. The good ones also track your sleep, which is usually a completely invisible, undocumented part of your life. That window onto the invisible one-third of your existence can have a huge effect on your health, productivity and self-awareness.

Mr. Swartz was facing millions of dollars in fines and up to 35 years in prison after being accused of using MITs computers to access scholarly papers.

title: Whats On Monday
description: 8 P.M. (TCM) AFIS MASTER CLASS: THE ART OF COLLABORATION In this latest installment the series focuses on the artistic relationship between the director Robert Zemeckis and the cinematographer Don Burgess, who together have made Forrest Gump (1994), Contact (1997), Cast Away (2000) and Flight (2012). The interview is followed at 9 by What Lies Beneath, their 2000 thriller about a doctor (Harrison Ford) who, unknown to his beautiful wife (Michelle Pfeiffer, above with Mr. Ford), has betrayed her by having an affair. But when she starts seeing the face of a young woman (Amber Valletta) in their home, he dismisses her terror as delusion  until it becomes clear that the apparition is out for revenge. The men also discuss some movies that have inspired them, including Mike Nicholss Carnal Knowledge (1971), about two college friends (Jack Nicholson and Arthur Garfunkel) coping with the sexual revolution, to be shown at 12:45 a.m.

title: Healthy Comforting Food: Warm Skillet Salads
description: Comforting isnt a word I usually associate with salads, but this week I put together five grain salads that fit that bill. Over the years I have developed a number of delicious whole grain salads that combine various grains with vegetables, herbs and often nuts, tossed in a tangy dressing. I have also married many a grain and vegetable in a pilaf. I decided to bring both concepts together in hearty salads that Im calling skillet salads; each one is heated through in a skillet just before serving.

title: How To Lose At American Politics
description: No doubt thanks to my timely intervention in the great $1 trillion coin debate, the Treasury Department explicitly rejected the possibility that the White House would mint a platinum solution to the debt ceiling debate this weekend. I put the word solution in quotation marks because Im confident that the coin gambit would have solved exactly none of the problems that its supporters claimed it was designed to address. No matter how many clever arguments exist to justify the maneuver, the politics of coin minting would have been just terrible for the White House  and because public opinion would have shaped how both the markets and the other branches of government would have responded to the move, those terrible politics would have ultimately produced exactly the kind of long-run outcomes (from swifter spending cuts to a stronger and more radicalized G.O.P.) that most of the coin-minters wanted to avoid.

The event will take place on Feb. 26 at the Best Buy Theater. Mr. Gill and Ms. Harris will anchor the show, inviting several special guests onto the stage to swap songs and stories in an informal format known in Nashville as a guitar pull. The other performers have yet to be announced. Tickets are $1,000 and the proceeds from the event go to support the museum in Nashville.

title: Armstrong and Winfrey: Familiar Names in a Time-Honored Ritual

And then he ran into deep trouble over accusations that he had doped his way to the top of the sport.

title: At Gucci, Italian With an English Accent
description: During a particular spate of Anglophilia, certain image-obsessed upper-class Neapolitan gents of the early 20th century sent their tailors to London to learn English style. Having analyzed Englishmens tastes for suits with high armholes, a squared-off shoulder, a suppressed waist and armoring woolens, they came home and completely Italianized what they had learned. The results were slouchy and unconstructed renditions of a classic Savile Row suit. By the 1980s, this adaptation came to seem inherently Italian and thus gave the world the career of Giorgio Armani.
