title: Valuing Chrysler Too Cheaply
description: Fiats chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, seems to want Chrysler to be the most undervalued automaker. Thats the implication of his latest offer to buy a slice of the Detroit manufacturer from the United Automobile Workers retiree health care trust. Mr. Marchionne has put $198 million on the table for 3.3 percent, valuing 100 percent of Chryslers stock at $6 billion. Its worth much more.

title: National Book Critics Circle Names 2012 Award Finalists
description: The National Book Critics Circle on Monday announced the finalists for its 2012 awards, including Katherine Boo, who won the National Book Award in November for Behind the Beautiful Forevers, a deeply reported look inside a Mumbai slum.

title: Guesstimating the Vettes M.P.G.
description: After months of speculation and rumors, most as accurate as Lindsay Lohans parallel parking, the redesigned Corvette Stingray is finally here. And we know its fast. But Tadge Juechter, the cars executive chief engineer, says that surprises are still in store leading up a showroom arrival in late summer.

title: Judge Finds California Boy Responsible in the Killing of His Neo-Nazi Father
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  The young son of a neo-Nazi knew right from wrong when he shot and killed his father, and he is therefore responsible for second-degree murder, a judge ruled on Monday.

title: As Shostakovich Found Out, Mother Russia Can Be Tough
description: Memory is an active muse, as demanding as an Olympics gymnastics coach, in Opus No. 7, a suitably unforgettable work from the Dmitry Krymov Lab and the Moscow Theater of Dramatic Arts. In this thrillingly inventive production, which runs at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn through Sunday, performers in search of lost time find themselves faced with a herculean array of obstacles and chimera.

title: Clinical Trials Flawed by Biased Reporting
description: Randomized placebo-controlled clinical trials are the gold standard for demonstrating the efficacy and toxicity of new treatments and drugs, but according to a new study, most of them are compromised by poor or biased reporting of benefits and harms.

title: Golden Globes Ratings Surge
description: The latest edition of the Golden Globes soared in the ratings on Sunday night as Tina Fey and Amy Poehler  two graduates of Saturday Night Live  proved that good writing and experience with live television comedy can translate into widespread plaudits.

title: In the Afflecks Corner, Genuine Shock
description: 4:47 p.m. | Updated The Warner Brothers/InStyle Golden Globes afterparty, held in an ornate tent off the lobby of the Beverly Hilton, is usually dimly lit, the better to encourage dancing  and it works: more than once has the Bagger found herself in some losing twist-off with the cast members of Glee.

title: Personal Narratives, All Bound In Fantasy
description: No one writes more powerfully than George Saunders about the lost, the unlucky, the disenfranchised, those Americans who struggle to pay the bills, make the rent, hold onto a job they might detest  folks who find their dreams slipping from their grasp as they frantically tread water, trying to keep from drowning.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 14
description: A view of the day in sports, including a golfers image and hockey players practices.

title: Justice Clarence Thomas Breaks His Silence
description: WASHINGTON  One of the abiding mysteries at the Supreme Court is why Justice Clarence Thomas has failed to say a word in almost seven years of arguments. On Monday, when he finally broke his silence, the mystery was replaced by a riddle: Just what did Justice Thomas say?

title: Iceland Suspends E.U. Talks Ahead of Elections
description: BRUSSELS  Iceland on Monday largely suspended talks on joining the European Union that began after its banking sector collapsed in 2008, plunging the nation into a period of economic turmoil.

title: Keeping Score: A Quarterback Who Can Run Away With the Title
description: When Colin Kaepernick rushed for 181 yards in San Franciscos playoff victory over Green Bay on Saturday night, setting the single-game rushing record for a quarterback, it was immediately declared that he was reinventing the way the position was played.

title: Dangers of Marijuana? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: When Parents Tease (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gladiators in Suits': The Fashion of Scandal
description: The costume designer Lyn Elizabeth Paolos work on ABCs Washington, D.C., drama Scandal has garnered a lot of buzz of late, particularly regarding the way she outfits the shows lead character Olivia Pope, a high-power fixer, or crisis-management professional (played by Kerry Washington). Though viewers may not have guessed, the show is shot entirely in Los Angeles, where Paolo also creates the wardrobe for TNTs Southland and Showtimes dark comedy Shameless. But Paolo has worked in Washington before, editing the looks for The West Wing, which, along with extensive research, informs her portrayal of the political characters on Scandal, from the president and his cabinet to the politicians whose dilemmas Pope and Associates is charged with resolving. Here, Paolo tells T about creating a realistic but stylized version of the nations capital.

title: Cracking Down on Malevolence at Candlestick
description: As a city, San Francisco has an image of the laid-back hippie Mecca, populated by the live-and-let-live crowd. That image, however, does not extend to 49ers fans and how they behave at Candlestick Park. In fact, that behavior has so degenerated over the past few seasons that police are doubling down on trying to restore something resembling civility.

title: A Hamlet Based on Brevity, the Soul of Wit, and Little Toys
description: Its easy to think of activities that could reasonably be completed in a half-hour. You could cook a pasta puttanesca, get a solid workout on the treadmill, buy a tube of toothpaste at Duane Reade.

title: A Parade of Floats for Obamas Inaugural
description: It wont be Macys on Thanksgiving Day, but President Obamas inaugural parade next Monday will feature eight floats, made by a company that has been building presidential floats since the 1949 inauguration of Harry Truman.

title: Deep Under Antarctica, Looking for Signs of Life
description: Three major scientific projects set out this season to seek evidence of life in lakes deep under the Antarctic ice  evidence that could provide clues in the search for evidence of life elsewhere in the solar system, perhaps in Marss past, or even now under the surface of Enceladus, one of Saturns moons. But only one of the projects, a $10 million expedition from the United States, has a chance of identifying long-hidden microbes before the weather on the frigid continent puts an end to drilling in about a month.

title: A BMW for the Masses, Kind of
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14: 2013 BMW 320i

title: Mining Electronic Records for Revealing Health Data
description: Over the past decade, nudged by new federal regulations, hospitals and medical offices around the country have been converting scribbled doctors notes to electronic records. Although the chief goal has been to improve efficiency and cut costs, a disappointing report published last week by the RAND Corp. found that electronic health records actually may be raising the nations medical bills.

title: The Law on Board, and Coyotes on the Runway
description: I GREW up near Kennedy Airport, right on the border of Queens. Sometimes the approaching planes were so loud that I thought they were landing in our yard. I used to get a flashlight and go to my bedroom window and turn the thing on and off. I thought I was signaling the pilots. Thats when I fell in love with aviation. I was president of a private jet company. Now, Im in the tequila business, mostly flying to meet clients, find new clients and check on production. I even named the brand Avin, the Spanish word for plane.

title: A Moment of Zen, on the Go
description: Ed Michael Reggie, a health care executive from New York, is even more devoted to his yoga practice on the road than he is at home.

title: Geithner Urges Congress to Act as Early as Possible on Debt Ceiling
description: The Treasury Department has officially set a deadline for raising the debt ceiling, albeit a loose one: Congress needs to act by mid-February or early March, or the country will face an unprecedented default.

title: Buffalos Albright-Knox Gets a Director from Much Farther North
description: The Albright-Knox Art Gallery, Buffalos modern and contemporary art museum, announced on Monday that Janne Sirn, director of the Helsinki Art Museum in Finland, will become its next director. Dr. Sirn is believed to be the first director from the Nordic region to take the helm of a major American art museum.

title: How to Go Vegan
description: From the archives.

title: A Sprint That Is Littered With Pitfalls
description: With players reporting in various states of readiness and little time in the downsized training camp for planning, the frantic sprint to the N.H.L. playoffs is set to begin Saturday after the four-month N.H.L. lockout.

title: When a Performance Is a Workout, and Vice Versa
description: Every evening in the alley next to the Belasco Theater on West 44th Street, Seth Numrich, the 25-year-old star of Golden Boy, goes through an hourlong boxing workout that would exhaust even Rocky. Often coached by Dion Mucciacito, a friend who also plays a boxer in the show, Mr. Numrich  wearing shorts, boxing boots and a hoodie, his hands taped in Everlast boxing wrap  starts by playing Jay-Z on a speaker and by jumping rope, crossing his arms and hopping on one foot and then the other, the way fighters do.

title: Treasures at the Met Wafting Through the Air
description: If you are going to play at the Met, the cellist Edward Arron said from the stage before a performance by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert on Friday evening, you should put true treasures on display. Mr. Arron and his colleagues have highlighted treasures old and new during his stint as artistic director of the group, now celebrating its 10th season as the museums resident ensemble.

title: Life in the Red
description: DETROIT  The belt-tightening was the easy part. Cancel the cable. Skip the air conditioners. Ration the cellphone, unplug the wireless Internet, cook rice and beans  done, and done.

title: A Time to Fight
description: Faced with the foreclosure of her home, Detroit resident LaKeisha Tuggle devised creative solutions to weather economic hardship.

title: Obama Speaks on Raising Debt Limit
description: President Obama addresses the need to increase the debt limit and other issues during a news conference Monday at the White House.

title: Hospitals Turn Away Visitors With Flu Symptoms
description: People who wish to visit loved ones in the hospital take heed: At some medical centers, a cough or a sneeze will probably get you turned away.

title: One Womans Many Racial Musings
description: Remember when postracial was all the rage? That brief period in 2008 when the election of Barack Obama spawned a forests worth of think pieces name-dropping Tiger Woods, Eminem and the like?

title: Photos of The Moment | Salvatore Ferragamo
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Honda Fit With Off-Road Intentions
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14 Honda Urban S.U.V. Concept

title: Suicide Prompts Investigation at M.I.T.
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: M.I.T. examines its involvement in the suicide of Aaron Swartz. The post-Golden Globe marketing push by movie studios. Networks revisit conversations about violence.

title: School Bus Drivers Union Calls for Strike on Wednesday
description: For the first time in more than three decades, New York Citys largest union for school bus drivers plans to strike on Wednesday morning, a move that would affect more than 150,000 students.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Suicide Prompts Investigation at M.I.T.
description: M.I.T. examines its involvement in the suicide of Aaron Swartz. The post-Golden Globe marketing push by movie studios. Networks revisit conversations about violence.

title: An Exclusive Event for Expensive Cars and Their Admirers
description: DETROIT  Exotic vehicles are not a standard sight on metro Detroit freeways. The allure of the obscure is what made the Gallery at the MGM Casino a hot $500 ticket on Saturday evening. For a sixth consecutive year, about 500 attendees strolled among the 30 exotic vehicles on display in a private room at the casino as a precursor to the North American International Auto Show.

title: Reflecting on War and Its Tentacles
description: Shock and awe entered the mainstream vocabulary in 2003, when the term denoted the military doctrine of an overwhelming display of force that would be used in the invasion of Iraq. That the designation can have a markedly different meaning to the men and women who serve in the armed forces is a central point of Soldier Songs, a musical theater piece by the composer David T. Little. When the work had its New York premiere on Friday night at Pace Universitys Schimmel Center for the Arts, shock and awe took on a new meaning: that of staging aesthetic.

title: In the Round: 2014 Chevrolet Corvette Stingray
description: The Chevrolet Corvette Stingray at the Detroit auto show. To control the view of the car, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

title: Giant Squids Ready for Small-Screen Debut
description: For decades, scientists and sea explorers have sought to hunt down and photograph the giant squid  a legendary monster of the deep with eyes the size of soccer balls and long tentacles lined with sucker pads. Dead specimens had been caught in nets or washed up on shore, but they revealed few of the species behavioral secrets.

title: Study Measures Impact of Chinas One-Child Policy
description: The Chinese policy that limits most families to having one child has had psychological fallout for the children born after it was instituted in 1979, economists report in the journal Science.

title: Yo La Tengos Fade and Cristina Patos Migrations
description: YO LA TENGO

title: Greek Tragedy, Economic Mayhem and Other Sources of Modern Movement
description: Those of us who dont know the drag-ball world may not be aware that the word realness has specific implications: its about passing as something youre not. The point arose at the end of last week, when I attended the opening events of American Realness 2013, the festival of experimental dance and category-defying performance that is now in its fourth annual season.

title: World Music Informed by the Past and Fiery in the Here and Now
description: Globalfest rediscovered America in its 10th annual showcase of world music, with 12 groups on Sunday night on three floors of Webster Hall. This years lineup included Mucca Pazza, a madcap marching band from Chicago; the Stooges, a New Orleans brass band; La Santa Cecilia, a Mexican-American band from Los Angeles; Martha Redbone, a singer born in Kentucky with American Indian roots; and A Tribe Called Red, an American Indian electronic dance music group from Canada.

title: The Lifting of a Veil, Discreetly
description: The answer to the puzzle of Jodie Fosters rambling, raw, semi-confessional speech at the Golden Globes on Sunday may have been right there at the outset, when she skittishly quoted a lesser-known Saturday Night Live character and shouted: Im 50! Im 50!

title: Globalfest at Webster Hall
description: The 10th annual showcase of world music included 12 groups on Sunday night on three floors of Webster Hall.

title: Bentley Offers Speed-Dating for a Party of Four
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14: 2013 Continental GT Speed Convertible

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Mali, France and South Africa.

title: Equation of Time Solves Mystery of Gray Mornings
description: As the parent of teenage boys who have to be dragged out of bed on school days, I had been looking forward to earlier sunrises once the winter solstice was past. But early January mornings seemed darker than ever while at the same time, the sky was clearly lighter around 5 p.m.

title: Showtime Venturing Into Documentary Territory
description: The pay cable channel Showtime has been closing the gap with the rival HBO in the realm of original series  an achievement rewarded with a strong showing at Sundays Golden Globes ceremony  but one major distinction has remained: HBO has long been the channel with a commitment to attention-grabbing original documentaries, and Showtime the channel without.

title: Wow! (Whatever It Was Jodie Foster Said)
description: THE Golden Globe Awards started out being all about Tina Fey and Amy Poehler  perhaps the best award-show hosts ever  but by evenings end most of the talk was of Jodie Foster and the rambling, riveting speech (watched by her date, a stone-faced Mel Gibson) in which she seemed to simultaneously come out of the closet and announce her retirement from acting. On Twitter, Ms. Fosters speech brought praise for its bravery as well as derision for not being brave enough.

title: Transit Workers Union to New York City Transit
description: In a letter to Thomas F. Prendergast, the president of New York City Transit,  John Samuelsen, president of Transport Workers Union Local 100, has proposed measures to reduce the number of deaths on New York City subway tracks.

title: Struggling in Chicago
description: To the Editor:

title: Black and Famous but Out to Pasture
description: Early in the premiere of Real Husbands of Hollywood, the comedian Kevin Hart shows up for an afternoon party at a huge Los Angeles home where the grill is being tended by Nick Cannon, the actor, comedian and husband of Mariah Carey.

title: Video: Flammable Liquid Used in Robbery
description: At first, the man who entered a 24-hour Harlem check-cashing store early on Dec. 24 appeared to be simply holding a beverage.

title: Bernanke Unplugged
description: Much is made of the fact that Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, is more open and candid than his predecessors, but in fairness, thats a low bar. His public appearances are infrequent by comparison with other national leaders, his remarks are guarded and his personal life is carefully obscured.

title: Expanding Elite Status to the Security Line
description: THE Transportation Security Administration plans to widen the pool of travelers who qualify for PreCheck, its 14-month-old expedited security program that allows selected passengers to pass through special checkpoints without having to remove laptops from bags or take off their shoes, belts or outer coats.

title: With the RS7 and SQ5, Audi Adds More Power
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14: Audi RS7 Sportback and 2013 SQ5What is it? The RS7 is an asphalt-scorching, 560-horsepower take on the German automakers elegant A7 sedan  Audi would prefer you not call the A7 a hatchback, but it is one. Meanwhile, the SQ5 is a high performance take on Audis Q5 sporty utility.

title: BMWs Easy Math: Four Costs More Than Three
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14: BMW Concept 4 Series Coupe

title: Department of Homeland Security: Disable Java Unless It Is Absolutely Necessary
description: Even after Oracle fixed a serious security flaw in its Java software on Sunday, the Department of Homeland Security warned that the fix was not sufficient and urged users to disable Java on their Web browsers.

title: Why Obama May Drive a Hard Bargain
description: President Obama has repeatedly stated that he will not negotiate over the federal debt ceiling, which must be raised soon to avoid a default.

title: As Sales Lag, Nissan Cuts Price on Leaf Electric
description: After disappointing sales last year for its Leaf electric car, Nissan announced on Monday that it was cutting the price of the base model in 2013 by 18 percent, increasing the cars driving range and offering two other trim lines with more features.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Bookless Libraries and Anti-Drone Clothing
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Tipsarevic Matches Hewitts Relentlessness in First-Round Win
description: Lleyton Hewitt was feeling it Monday. After holding serve to go up by 6-5 in the first set against Janko Tipsarevic in his opening match at the Australian Open, Hewitt moved in for the kill, forcing two straight backhand errors to get to love-30.

title: A Return to Albany After a Scandal
description: ALBANY  Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez on Monday made his first public appearance here since a sexual harassment scandal engulfed his political career, forcing him to step down as the Brooklyn Democratic chairman.

title: Infiniti Turns to Drive-by-Wire for the Q50 Sedan
description: Introduced on Monday, Jan.14 The 2014 Infiniti Q50 sedan

title: Agencies Push JPMorgan to Improve Risk Controls
description: Federal banking regulators hit JPMorgan Chase with two enforcement actions on Monday for failures in risk management that led to a multibillion-dollar trading loss, the first formal sanctions in a case that damaged the banks reputation and brought heightened scrutiny to its trading operations. The regulators also ordered the bank to fix breakdowns in money-laundering controls that threatened to allow tainted money to move through its network..

title: Search Crew Finds World War II Plane That Crashed in Greenland
description: The Coast Guard said Monday that a private team had located a World War II rescue plane that crashed on the southeast coast of Greenland 70 years ago with three service members on board.

title: An Alarm in the Offing on Climate Change
description: The natural conservatism of science has often led climatologists to be cautious in their pronouncements about global warming. More than once they have drawn criticism for burying their fundamental message  that society is running some huge risks  in caveats and cavils.

title: Gaza: Farmer Killed at Border
description: A Palestinian farmer died Monday hours after he was shot in the northern Gaza Strip. Palestinian medical officials accused Israeli soldiers of killing the farmer, Mustafa Abu Jarad, 21, but a military spokeswoman denied any Israeli involvement. Since November, when a cease-fire between Hamas, the militant group that runs Gaza, and Israel was brokered by Egypt, Israeli troops have killed three Palestinians near the restricted border area. Also on Monday, rescue workers recovered the body of a Palestinian who had been trapped in a smuggling tunnel under Gazas border with Egypt. The man, Ali al-Qadi, was in the tunnel with two other people on Saturday when it collapsed after a period of heavy rain.

title: Trendspotting: Taffeta and Tulle at the Golden Globes
description: As he escorted stars from the stage to the red carpet last night, Ryan Seacrest, a host on the E! Entertainment Golden Globes broadcast, was compelled to exhort repeatedly, Be careful getting down.

title: 1st Part of Offshore Wind Power Line Moves Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  An audacious plan to lay a multibillion-dollar wind power transmission spine under the seabed from southern Virginia to the New York City area will take a step forward on Tuesday with an announcement of plans for the first leg, a 189-mile segment running from Jersey City to a spot south of Atlantic City.

title: Brandweeks Obituary Proves Premature
description: A FAMILIAR name on Madison Avenue is making a kind of comeback.

title: In Ads, Coke Confronts Sodas Link to Obesity
description: The Coca-Cola Company began a new television ad campaign Monday aimed at getting on the healthy side of the national debate over obesity  a novel step for a company built on sugary soft drinks.

title: U.S. to Give Spy Drones to Afghans, Karzai Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Hamid Karzai announced Monday that the United States would give Afghanistan its own fleet of aerial surveillance drones and would speed up the handover of detainees held by American forces. It was his first public comments since returning from a visit to Washington.

title: Concession After Days of Protest in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For years, residents of the impoverished and violence-riven province of Baluchistan have complained about their chief minister, angry that he was enjoying a lavish lifestyle in Pakistans capital even while their province slid deeper into a quagmire of militant attacks, state repression and sectarian bloodshed.

title: A Poorer San Bernardino, and a More Dangerous One, Too
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif.  The gunshots ripped through a house party here, an hour before midnight on New Years Eve, wounding three and killing one. It was a brutal, if fitting, cap to a year that left this city bloody and broke.

title: Methadone for Inmates
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats Ailing City Catholic Schools Isnt Lack of Money
description: To the Editor:

title: The Women Are Watching
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back at Life
description: To the Editor:

title: A Phased-In Carbon Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: What Palestinians Need
description: To the Editor:

title: The Troubling State of Americans Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Corolla Furia Concept May Signal a New Styling Direction for Toyota
description: Introduced on Monday Toyota Corolla Furia ConceptWhat it is: Its a styling exercise meant to tease the next Corolla and the latest creation of the Toyota design chief, Tokuo Fukuichi, who was responsible for the distinctly styled Previa van during his last tenure at Toyota.

title: Falcons Offense Makes a Habit of Going for the Long Ball
description: As the Atlanta Falcons prepare for Sundays N.F.C. Championship game against San Francisco, the focus for many observers will be on the 49ers ability to score points. This makes sense; quarterback Colin Kaepernick, after all, shredded Green Bays defense in the divisional round and outgunned Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers, one of the leagues premier producers of big plays.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,156 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Illuminating Jewish Life in a Muslim Empire
description: JERUSALEM  A batch of 1,000-year-old manuscripts from the mountainous northern reaches of war-torn Afghanistan, reportedly found in a cave inhabited by foxes, has revealed previously unknown details about the cultural, economic and religious life of a thriving but little understood Jewish society in a Persian part of the Muslim empire of the 11th century.

title: Parents Financial Support May Not Help College Grades
description: Parents saving for college costs, take heed: A new national study has found that the more college money parents provide  whether in absolute terms or as a share of total costs  the lower their childrens college grades.

title: Dim Hopes for a Free Press in China
description: GUANGZHOU, China

title: Why We Must Help Save Mali
description: SANTA FE, N.M.

title: Malis Atrocities Began When It Lost Its Democracy
description: IN 2005, after the world failed to prevent mass atrocities in Rwanda, the Balkans and Darfur, the United Nations declared that nations had a responsibility to protect populations everywhere from genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity.

title: Worry Over Sales Spurs Talk of Cheaper iPhones
description: By now, most of the world knows what an iPhone is  and they know it typically doesnt come cheap.

title: Starring in Drama in Iran: TV Itself
description: TEHRAN  On Sunday, as they do each week, Shahnaz and her elderly mother turned on the smuggled satellite receiver, its dish carefully hidden on the balcony, and sat back to watch their favorite soap opera, The Tulip Age.

title: Draft Federal Report Sees Big U.S. Impacts from Global Warming
description: 5:51 p.m. | Updated below |

title: States Will Be Given Extra Time to Set Up Health Insurance Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  The White House says it will give states more time to comply with the new health care law after finding that many states lag in setting up markets where millions of Americans are expected to buy subsidized private health insurance.

title: Swartz Suicide Fuels Argument Over 1986 Computer Law
description: The suicide of Aaron Swartz has drawn new scrutiny to a federal law that has been widely used to prosecute a variety of people accused of being trolls, bullies and cyberthieves.

title: Ravens Want Revenge to Come From Winning, Not Words
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Baltimore Ravens defensive tackle Haloti Ngata said he tried to be a dispassionate observer of the divisional playoff game between the New England Patriots and the Houston Texans. As he watched the game on television, Ngata studied both offenses, at least until the third quarter, when it became clear that the Patriots were well on their way to securing a rematch with the Ravens in Sundays A.F.C. Championship game.

title: Colorados Marijuana Muddle
description: DENVER

title: To Get Movies Into China, Hollywood Gives Censors a Preview
description: LOS ANGELES  When Kung Fu Panda 3 kicks its way into Chinas theaters in 2016, the countrys vigilant film censors will find no nasty surprises.

title: In First Day of New Rules, Cubans Make Travel Plans
description: HAVANA  Cubans flocked to immigration offices and travel agencies on Monday, eager to take advantage of a lifting of government travel restrictions that have been in place since Fidel Castro was a dark-bearded firebrand in his 30s.

title: The Moment for Action on Guns
description: The next few weeks represent a once-in-a-generation opportunity to harden the nations gun laws and reduce the threat of rapid-fire violence in America. A month after the slaughter of 20 children and seven adults in Newtown, Conn., Vice President Joseph Biden Jr.s commission is about to present a series of recommendations for new laws, and it is vital that his panel gets it right and that Congress immediately takes action on its report.

title: In Open Short of U.S. Men, Top Two Will Meet Early
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Sam Querrey, who at No. 22 is the only seeded American man in the singles draw of the Australian Open, finished his first-round singles match on Monday with an inside-in forehand winner, moving past a Spanish qualifier, Daniel Muoz-de la Nava, in four sets.

title: Getting Through the Flu Season
description: As Americans scramble to find dwindling supplies of flu vaccine, there are signs that this flu season, the worst in recent years, may be starting to wane, according to federal health officials.

title: Fortunes of Facebook May Hinge on Searches
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Nearly a year after it announced its bid to go public, Facebook is confronting the ultimate burden of the information age: how to help its users find what they are looking for amid the billions of pictures, likes and status updates they post every day.

title: Doctor Returns to Congo and Is Hailed as a Hero
description: BUKAVU, Democratic Republic of Congo  It was as if someone extraordinarily famous had come to town. Thousands of people craned their necks as the motorcade roared by, cellphones out to grab a snap, an air of expectation and excitement eclipsing all the street noise of clanging Coke bottles and beeping motorcycles.

title: Why Steal Tide?
Catholic Schools Await More Closing Bells
description: For 135 years, Holy Cross School has taught at the Crossroads of the World, educating first the offspring of longshoremen and dockworkers, now the children of bus company, hotel and office workers in Times Square.

title: Morsis Slurs Against Jews Stir Concern
description: CAIRO  Nearly three years ago, a leader of the Muslim Brotherhood delivered a speech urging Egyptians to nurse our children and our grandchildren on hatred for Jews and Zionists. In a television interview months later, the same leader described Zionists as these bloodsuckers who attack the Palestinians, these warmongers, the descendants of apes and pigs.

title: Dont Skimp on Sandy Aid
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey made an impassioned pitch on Monday to his fellow Republicans in the House of Representatives to vote on Tuesday for almost $50 billion in Hurricane Sandy disaster relief. New Jersey does not expect anything more than what was done for Louisiana and Alabama and Mississippi in Katrina, and what was done in Joplin, Mo., what was done in the floods in Iowa. We dont expect anything more than that, but we will not accept anything less, Mr. Christie said.

title: A Widening War in Mali
description: Frances initial airstrikes have, so far, failed to halt the southward advance of Islamist rebels in Mali. Containing these militias, which are sheltering international terrorist groups, and the threat they pose to West Africa and the wider world is essential. But President Franois Hollande should resist beginning a ground assault, which would almost certainly turn into a protracted counterinsurgency campaign that France should not take on and cannot afford.

title: The Banker Who Put His Faith in Armstrong
description: When Lance Armstrongs interview with Oprah Winfrey about his suspected use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs is broadcast on Thursday, an investment banker will most likely be watching it very carefully (and nervously): Thomas Weisel.

title: A Movie Mogul Rising
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Back when there were only a couple of Harry Potter pictures, and provocative youth films like The Hunger Games and Twilight were barely a twinkle in Hollywoods eye, Warner Brothers tried  and failed  to make a movie of Orson Scott Cards book Enders Game.

title: Questions Linger After Knicks Send-Off to London
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Knicks practiced into the night Monday, went through an air travel security checkpoint at their practice facility, then jetted for London, their franchise cornerstone, Carmelo Anthony, all but spirited out of the country under a mysterious veil.

title: Police Barricades and Curfews Wear on Jersey Shore Nerves
description: BRICK, N.J.  Last week, the Mantoloking Bridge to Route 35, the road linking seaside towns and generations of memories along the Jersey Shore, finally reopened.

title: The Foreclosure Fiasco
description: Its been five days since Jessica Silver-Greenbergs article on the latest bank settlement was posted on The New York Timess Web site. Im still shaking my head. Her story behind the story of the $8.5 billion settlement between federal bank regulators and 10 banks over their foreclosure misdeeds illustrates just about everything that is wrong with the way the government has handled the Great Foreclosure Crisis.

title: Fishing for Giant Squid
description: For decades, scientists and sea explorers have sought to hunt down and photograph the giant squid. The hunt is over.

title: Rubio Pushes His Party on Immigration Changes
description: As President Obama and Democratic leaders are preparing a major push to overhaul the immigration system, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is asserting his leadership among Republicans on the volatile issue, previewing a proposal that includes measures to give legal status to millions of illegal immigrants.

title: As Clock Ticks, Bloomberg Is Still Seeking a Worthy Heir
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is obsessed with estate planning.

title: Corrections: January 15, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Things Spun By Old Salts
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Ive gotten so used to Peter A. Collinss commemorative puzzles that, in a sort of cruciverbal Pavlovian response, I found myself automatically thinking about what sort of anniversary might be occurring (the first episode of THE PAPER CHASE, maybe?) as soon as I saw his byline.

title: How Pursuit of Billionaire Hit One Dead End
description: When Jonathan Hollander left his high-flying job at SAC Capital Advisors in late 2008, he departed one of Wall Streets premier hedge funds.

title: Wal-Mart Plans to Hire Any Veteran Who Wants a Job
description: Wal-Mart, the nations largest retailer, will announce Tuesday a plan to hire every veteran who wants a job, provided that the veterans have left the military in the previous year and did not receive a dishonorable discharge.

title: Tight End Eager to Help Suddenly Has a Job to Do
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  He said he always wondered. Its human nature, perhaps, to look at the New England Patriots from the outside as a football voyeur. How do they do it? Will I ever be able to find out for myself?

title: New Position for Kerrey Is a Surprise
description: Bob Kerrey, the former president of the New School who failed in a recent bid to return to the United States Senate, will soon become an executive with a new education venture based in San Francisco.

title: Thompson Raises $1 Million in 6 Months for Mayoral Bid
description: In his strongest fund-raising showing yet, William C. Thompson Jr., who lost the mayors race to Michael R. Bloomberg in 2009, announced on Monday that his campaign had collected more than $1 million in the last six months.

title: Islanders Unsure if They Will Get a Key Player Back
description: SYOSSET, N.Y.  Only one N.H.L. player who played overseas during the lockout has refused to return to his team.

title: Harsh New Restrictions Imposed on Muslim Cleric, Lawyers Say
description: Lawyers for a disabled Islamic preacher jailed in Manhattan said on Monday that the Federal Bureau of Prisons had recently imposed harsh new restrictions on their client, which have made it harder for him to prepare for his trial.

title: 3rd-Seeded Williams Hurts Ankle but Cruises
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A routine first-round match at the Australian Open on Tuesday suddenly turned into a bit of a scare midway through the first set when Serena Williams rolled her right ankle.

title: Leaving Job to Raise Better Children, but Then Feeling the Financial Strain
description: Look at the neighborhood, said Jennifer Brito, a single mother raising three children in Washington Heights. Theres drugs on every corner.

title: Trial Begins for Priest and Teacher Accused of Abusing Altar Boy
description: PHILADELPHIA  A Roman Catholic priest and a schoolteacher sexually abused a 10-year-old altar boy at different times more than a decade ago, assaulting him in a church sacristy in Northeast Philadelphia and in the back of a car, a prosecutor alleged on Monday.

title: Lhota, at Business Luncheon, Talks Up 13 Race for Mayor
description: In words that came as a shock to almost no one, Joseph J. Lhota, the former chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, suggested on Monday that he would probably enter the 2013 race for mayor.

title: McIlroys Well-Remunerated Risk
description: Rory McIlroys rocket ride to immortality publicly entered its second phase Monday with the official announcement of his sponsorship with Nike, whose equipment and apparel he will exhibit starting this week at his 2013 debut beside Tiger Woods, Nikes first golfing icon, in the United Arab Emirates.

title: Lottery Numbers
On Louisiana Range, the Giraffe and Antelope Will Play
description: NEW ORLEANS  The Audubon Nature Institute and San Diego Zoo Global were expected on Tuesday to announce the development of a breeding program for rare and endangered species on 1,000 acres south of this city, bringing herds of antelope, okapi and Masai giraffe to graze on the banks of the Mississippi River.

title: Holden Returns to Field for Bolton
description: Tuesday, 5:38 p.m. | Updated The American midfielder Stuart Holden played the final 16 minutes of Boltons 2-0 victory at Sunderland on Tuesday in the F.A. Cup. It was Holdens first official game in 16 months, and just his second since he sustained a serious knee injury in March 2011.

title: Group From Congress Asks, Why Does America Hate Us? (Answer: See Congress)
description: About a dozen members of Congress gathered in a Midtown Manhattan hotel ballroom on Monday, an intentional remove from the marbled corridors of the United States Capitol, to chew over some uncomfortable questions: Why are we so ineffective? Why cant we manage to be the least bit civil to one another? And why does America hate us?

title: Union of Subway Drivers Urges Slower Train Speeds
description: The union representing subway operators has advised its workers to drastically reduce their trains speed as they enter stations, a directive prompted by the recent deaths of two people who were shoved in front of oncoming subway trains.

title: Russian Military Ordered to Switch to Socks
description: Near the end of World War II, Soviet and American soldiers met at the Elbe River in Germany. Lacking a common language, they compared their boots.

title: Armstrong Admits Doping, and Says He Will Testify
description: In an interview with Oprah Winfrey that is scheduled for broadcast on her network on Thursday, Lance Armstrong confessed that he used performance-enhancing drugs during his cycling career, according to two people briefed on the interview, which was recorded Monday in Austin, Tex.

title: Senator Asks to View Files on Killings of Americans
description: WASHINGTON  A Democratic member of the Senate Intelligence Committee demanded Monday that he and other committee members be allowed to review secret Justice Department legal opinions justifying the killing of American citizens in counterterrorism operations.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Jan. 15, 2013
description: To basically eradicate assault weapons from our streets in New York as quickly as possible is something the people of this state want.

title: Kerdiles Keeps Commitment and Powers Wisconsin
description: Unlike many North American sports, hockey players can choose to develop outside of an educational setting, in the Canadian Hockey League, though some contend that the on- and off-ice value of a college experience makes it the clear choice for most players.

title: Turning to the Web for a Medical Diagnosis
description: Thirty-five percent of American adults said they had used the Internet to diagnose a medical condition for themselves or someone else, according to a new Pew Research Center study. Women are more likely than men to turn to the Internet for diagnoses. Other groups more likely to do so are younger people, white adults, people with college degrees and those who live in households with income above $75,000.

title: Word of the Day | ramble
description: ramble \ram-bl\ verb and noun

title: California to Give Web Courses a Big Trial
description: A plan to offer an array of online college classes at a California state university could, if the students are successful, open the door to teaching hundreds of thousands of California students at a lower cost via the Internet.

title: Carving Her Path at Her Pace
description: Mikaela Shiffrin, one of the best skiers in the world, does not describe herself as a prodigy or the next Lindsey Vonn. For now, she is focused on graduating high school.

title: Williams Twists Ankle but Breezes to Win
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A routine first-round match at the Australian Open on Tuesday suddenly turned into a bit of a scare midway through the first set when Serena Williams rolled her right ankle. Leading Edina Gallovits-Hall of Romania by 4-0, Williams was pulled into the short court by a slice backhand by Gallovits-Hall. Gallovits-Hall then swept a wide forehand to the far court. Williams stretched but lost her balance and fell to the court.

title: Company Defrauded City in Water Plant Work, Contractor Says
description: An electrical contractor controlled by the German engineering conglomerate Siemens AG admitted on Monday that a related company had defrauded New York City in connection with work it performed on the troubled $3.2 billion Croton water-filtration plant by evading requirements that they hire companies owned by women or minorities and have a licensed master electrician overseeing the work.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 8:30 P.M. (Sundance) CAREER GIRLS (1997) Two former college roommates  Hannah (Katrin Cartlidge) and Annie (Lynda Steadman, above left, with Ms. Cartlidge)  once locked in constant battle try to re-establish their relationship over a weekend in this Mike Leigh drama. Joe Tucker plays Adrian, a smug real estate agent selling a flat who barely remembers the time he once lounged around their druggy lair and broke their hearts. With his usual deep, engrossing attention to behavioral detail, Mr. Leigh uses Career Girls to visit and fuse these contrasting chapters into a continuum of the womens lives, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. Over the course of their brief reunion, Hannah and Annie reveal the present while they talk about the past, and the film explodes with jittery, hand-held flashbacks to match their buried emotions. The movie, she added, doesnt impose any false closure on its wistful portraits, nor does it contrive more than a few strained coincidences (like Adrians reappearance) to create a conventional story.

title: Roche Hires Academic to Take Lead on Research
description: The Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche is turning to a prolific American academic scientist to revitalize its lagging research operations.

title: News Quiz | January 15, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Indian Court Issues Warrant for Porsche C.E.O.s Arrest
description: An Indian court has issued an arrest warrant for Matthias Mller, chief executive and chairman of Porsche, the German carmaker, and eight other executives from the company.

title: Talking Trust With Chinas Army
description: BEIJING  China will soon publish a new country map that expands its claims to disputed territories. Japan has announced its  first increase in defense spending in 11 years in a move widely perceived as countering China. Recently, fighter planes and other aircraft have been used by both countries as tensions grow over a group of islands in the East China Sea that both claim, called the Diaoyu in Chinese and Senkaku in Japanese.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 15
description: NEWS Despite intensive airstrikes by French warplanes, Islamist fighters overran a strategic village and military post in central Mali on Monday, indicating that the war against extremists who have carved out a jihadist state in the nations north could be a long and difficult one. Steven Erlanger, Alan Cowell and Adam Nossiter report.

title: Alibabas Founder to Give Up C.E.O. Title, but Will Remain Chairman
description: After 14 years of building up the Alibaba Group into one of the biggest Internet companies in the world, Jack Ma is taking a step back from the chief executive role of the Chinese e-commerce giant.

title: French Pledge More Troops for Mali as Airstrikes Continue
description: PARIS  France carried out new airstrikes overnight against Islamist fighters in central Mali, as Paris pledged on Tuesday to commit more troops to a potentially protracted campaign against extremists pressing south from a jihadist state they have forged in the desert north of the country.

title: New Self-Driving Systems Are Poised to Change the Way We Drive
description: In Drivers With Hands Full Get a Backup: The Car, John Markoff and Somini Sengupta write about some of the new technologies that are poised to make cars even safer.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 15, 2013
description: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the City Room blog post Psst, Were Showing a Film on This Guys Wall, and, Oh, Dont Warn Him.

title: The Smartphone Have-Nots
description: Earlier this month, Larry Mishel, the president of the Economic Policy Institute, stood at a lectern in a small hotel conference room in San Diego and fiddled with a computer until his PowerPoint presentation flashed on the screen. Mishel then composed himself, paid tribute to his intellectual opponent sitting in the front row and began a speech that, he hopes, will reorient the U.S. economy away from the 1 percent or the 0.1 percent and toward the rest of us.

title: Does Facebook Ever Make You Feel Bad?
description: Seeing all those smiling photographs and hearing about how much fun everyone else is having  can Facebook actually make us feel worse about our lives? The results of a new study suggest that very idea.

title: A South Bronx Family Album
description: When Ricky Flores started taking pictures as a high school senior in 1980, he did what a lot of young photographers did: he photographed his friends, family and neighbors. He captured giddy, even goofy moments, of dancers in the park, teenagers on stoops and costumed children on Halloween.

title: In New Delhi, Women Marry Up and Men Are Left Behind
description: Theres an unexpected problem in New Delhis high-end marriage market, according to Gopal Suri, who has been a marriage broker for two decades.

title: Part 2: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
description: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

title: Internal Forces Besiege Pakistan Ahead of Voting
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Barely a year after fears of a possible military coup plunged Pakistani politics into chaos, the country is in crisis again  this time besieged on multiple fronts by forces that threaten the civilian government just a few months ahead of elections.

title: Study: More to Meal Delivery Than Food
description: Whats a simpler idea than Meals on Wheels? Older, lower-income people who have trouble driving, cooking or shopping  or paying for food  sign up with a local agency. Each day, volunteers or paid staff come by and drop off a hot lunch. Federal and state dollars and local charities foot the bill.

title: Coins, Bills and the National Debt
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

description: Todays Times

title: OkCupid Wants to Send Members on a Crazy Blind Date
description: OkCupid, the dating site, has spent the last few years experimenting with ways to appeal to increasingly tech-savvy and pressed-for-time singles. In 2011, the company rolled out a locals feature that showed other singles nearby who were available to get a drink or see a movie. Last summer, the company introduced offline events that brought members together for gatherings like a beer tasting or a barbecue cook-off, to mingle and perhaps inspire a love connection.

description: LONDON  At just about every level, it seems, the writ of Prime Minister David Cameron is under challenge, as much in foreign as in domestic policies, as he seeks to implant a reforming Conservative vision  or perhaps merely secure his political flanks.

title: Rights of Passage
description: ISTANBUL  I suspect Im not the only journalist who cant remember his first kiss but whose knees go wobblyat the thought of his first front-page story. My own was the newspaper equivalent of a peck on the cheek: a squib in The Daily Telegraph about how the British Consulate in Istanbul was shutting down its well-trod social club to make room for a new visa section.

description: Q.

title: A Business Owner Goes Back to School
description: I read with interest an article in The Times about online college courses a couple of Sundays ago. Prompted by a rather roundabout turn of events, I recently took a business course online.

title: Former Assistant to a Salomon Is Found Guilty of Stealing $1.3 Million
description: A former secretary at Citigroup was found guilty late Monday of stealing $1.3 million from William R. Salomon, the 98-year-old son of a founder of Salomon Brothers.

title: Chelsea Clinton to Headline Inaugural Day of Service Event
description: Chelsea Clinton will be in Washington on Saturday to serve as the honorary chairwoman of President Obamas National Day of Service, a call to volunteerism that will start the presidents inaugural weekend, officials will announce this morning.

description: The fall 2013 collection shown in Milan.

description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14 Volkswagen Passat Performance Concept

title: Wreckless Driving
description: TEL AVIV  Israeli drivers have a reputation for having bad road manners: Theyre aggressive and needlessly competitive; they wont let anyone pass them; theyre on the phone constantly. Google Israeli drivers are and you get: crazy, a danger and even the worst. The most dangerous thing in Israel is the Israeli driver, one tour guide warns his potential clients.

title: In Pursuit of Cohen, One Dead End
description: IN PURSUIT OF COHEN, ONE DEAD END | The governments investigation of suspicious trading at SAC Capital Advisors has relied on lower-level employees who are mined for information about the firms boss, Steven A. Cohen. But the investigation of Jonathan Hollander, a former SAC employee who cooperated with prosecutors, shows the challenges of using that strategy, DealBooks Peter Lattman and Ben Protess report.

title: Climate Scientist Backs Bill to Curb Emissions
description: Michael E. Mann, a prominent climatologist at Penn State, has thrown his support behind an effort to get Pennsylvania to do more to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions.

title: Face to Face With Mom in the Mirror
description: It happens when you least expect it. You look into the mirror just as youve done every other day since Year Zero, but today your mother is staring back at you. The face you didnt intend to inherit, the waist you would never allow to be altered by time, the expression of the lip or eye that echoes a familiar face, not yours, is right there in front of you.

title: Brooklyn Museum Finds Some Problematic Gifts Cant Be Returned
description: The Brooklyn Museum seemed to have garnered a bonanza in 1932 when it received a large bequest from the estate of Col. Michael Friedsam, president of the elegant retail emporium B. Altman.

title: Words We Love Too Much
description: Colleagues and readers have nominated another crop of words and phrases that seem to appear with numbing regularity in our prose. Some are unavoidable on occasion, and none deserve to be banned outright. But take this as an invitation to look for fresher alternatives.

title: In the Round: Lexus LS460 F Sport AWD
description: The Lexus LS460 F Sport AWD at the Detroit auto show. To control the view of the car above, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

title: And Now, via Google, Time Travel Through the Streets of Segovia
description: PARIS  Last month, Google and the Network of Jewish Quarters in Madrid announced an online pilot project that offers an expansive street-level tour of Spains long-ignored medieval neighborhoods that were emptied by the Spanish Inquisition. As I explored the site, to my surprise, the photographs of ancient, sand-colored stone walls in Segovia connected me with my own ancestors: my 16th great-grandparents.

title: Tuesday Reading: How to Procrastinate Positively

description: LONDON  The British music retail chain HMV announced on Tuesday that it had entered administration, a form of bankruptcy, as it became the latest British company to suffer from the countrys flagging economy.

description: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 14 Hyundai HCD-14 Genesis Concept

title: After Holidays, Broadway Box Office Slumps
description: The annual post-holiday crash on Broadway continued last week. Over the first half of January, box-office grosses dropped by 50 percent for Annie, Chicago, Mamma Mia!, Mary Poppins, Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark and The Phantom of the Opera from their high points in late December, which is traditionally the most lucrative time of the year for Broadway musicals.

description: Dara-Lynn Weiss wrote what became an infamous article for Vogue magazine last year, describing how she helped her 7-year-old, Bea, battle childhood obesity  by putting her on a calorie-counting diet. At the time, I described their situation this way:

title: All Your Base Are Belong To Us, Continued (Still Wonkish)
description: Steve Randy Waldman replies reasonably to my post about the currency domination of the monetary base. But I think were still having a failure to communicate.

title: Daily Report: Facebooks Challenge in Search
description: Nearly a year after it announced its bid to go public, Facebook is confronting the ultimate burden of the information age: how to help its users find what they are looking for amid the billions of pictures, likes and status updates they post every day.

title: New Dan Brown Novel Coming in May
description: 9:30 a.m. | Updated

title: Sunk Costs: Mark Sanchez and the Concorde
description: We havent forgotten about the Jets, who still dont have a general manager, or an offensive coordinator, or many of their other assistant coaches. Most important, they dont have a quarterback.

title: In Debt Game, an Early Move From Obama
description: In a high-stakes negotiation, the most important moves often come not in the end game but at the very start, when one side or the other prevails in defining what is on the table. If you listened closely, you might have heard President Obama try to do just that in his news conference on Monday, when he suggested that Washington will have tamed the governments debt problems if the two parties can agree on another $1.5 trillion or so in spending cuts and tax increases.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood Navigates China, and a Pritzker Heir Navigates Hollywood
description: As Hollywood studios look to tap into the fast-growing Chinese film market, they are increasingly having to navigate their way through that countrys sometimes inscrutable censorship process, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes write in The New York Times. As they do so, they are discovering some details and themes that wont pass muster, and that other things can be negotiated so that both the filmmakers and the Chinese censorship board are satisfied. Billions of dollars are riding on the outcome, because international box office revenue is such a crucial element in the success or failure of a picture.

title: Resonance Concept Signals Design Direction for Nissan
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: Nissan Resonance Concept

title: Memes of the Moment (Silly)
description: Having a low-energy morning. So, if youre finding some of the blogospheric discussion puzzling right now, a brief guide.

title: New Chairman of Petersen Museum Sees Expansion Ahead
description: A new leadership team plans to make the 20th anniversary of the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles more than a milestone on the calendar. The anniversary  in June 2014  provides an opportunity to lift the Petersen into global recognition as one of the great automotive museums in the world, said Peter Mullin, the new chairman of the museums board of directors.

title: Schumer Says Hes Satisfied With Hagel on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  In a boon for the Obama administrations efforts to advance the nomination of Chuck Hagel as secretary of defense, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York told President Obama on Tuesday that he was optimistic that he could vote for Mr. Hagels confirmation based on his grilling of Mr. Hagel on a variety of issues pertaining to Israel and Iran.

title: In Performance: Elizabeth Marvel in Picnic
description: In William Inges 1953 play, Picnic, the arrival of Hal, a handsome drifter, unleashes resentment and sexual longing in the residents of a small Kansas town on Labor Day. In this scene Elizabeth Marvel plays Rosemary, an old-maid schoolteacher who confronts Hal in a drunken rage. The Broadway revival of Picnic runs through Feb. 24 at the American Airlines Theater.

title: Awaiting the Great Confession
description: You do have to hand it to Lance Armstrong and Oprah Winfrey, two icons  one disgraced, the other faded  who have found a way to milk several days worth of attention out of awaiting the Great Confession. The good news is, we have been dripped on by the leak that Armstrong did indeed admit he used performance-enhancing drugs. (In other news: the world is round.) That gives us two more days to figure out where the Oprah Winfrey Network is in our cable lineup before Thursdays broadcast, which is now being dragged out into a "two-night event," so a few people might remember it exists for another day. The bad news is, the interview has been taped, so all of our great suggestions for what Winfrey should ask Armstrong are going to go for naught. Had she only called first.

title: A Sharper Focus on Television Violence
description: in the wake of the shooting of schoolchildren in Newtown, Conn., television executives grapple with the issue of violence on their networks.

title: What Were Reading
description: The Wall Street Journal: Did KFC sell chicken with higher-than-permitted levels of antibiotics to customers in China? Shanghai authorities are investigating, and the chains corporate chairman has apologized to diners in a newly health-conscious China. (Subscription required.)  Glenn Collins

title: Jan. 15 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web. On Tuesday, New York lawmakers voted voting on changes to gun laws that would expand the states ban on assault weapons and limit access to guns by the mentally ill. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.s recommendations include multiple steps that President Obama can take without legislative action. And religious leaders, including the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, is expected to weigh in on the debate.

title: The Nissan Versa Note Sure Looks Like a Hatchback
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15 Nissan Versa Note

title: A French Grand Bargain
description: Even as Grard Depardieu drew the worlds attention to Frances high marginal tax rates by taking up Russian citizenship, French labor unions and businesses reached an agreement late Friday night on significant reform of the countrys labor laws. The deal should help create new jobs while protecting workers, and should also help stabilize the government of President Franois Hollande, which has been struggling to reenergize the economy.

title: An Eclectic Rock Pioneer Traversing the Borderline
description: Musicians often lead eventful lives with changes of direction that reflect their shifting interests and their responses to the musical landscape. But few have covered as much of the waterfront as John Cale, the Welsh rocker who performs three shows at the Brooklyn Academy of Music this week.

title: Coming Back: Decorating in the Dark
description: As the Red Hook Lobster Pound rebuilt after being flooded during Hurricane Sandy, Susan Povich struggled with choosing paint colors during a power failure.

title: K.H.L. Wont Allow Islander to Play Without Waiver
description: The K.H.L. said Tuesday that Lubomir Visnovsky would not be allowed to play for Slovan Bratislava in his native Slovakia unless the Islanders and the N.H.L. released him from his contract.

title: Channel Surfing: Hawaii Five-Os Choose-Your-Own Adventure
description: 2:18 p.m. | Updated  Monday nights episode of Hawaii Five-0 had two different villains  a greedy academic if you watched it on the East Coast, a feckless student if you watched it on the West  but just one victim: the audience.

title: Guggenheim Hires Former Yahoo Chief for Media Venture
description: Guggenheim Partners said on Tuesday that it had hired Ross Levinsohn, a former Yahoo chief executive, to lead a new media unit that includes Billboard, Adweek and the Hollywood Reporter.

title: New York Gun Legislation
description: The text of the bill passed by the New York State Legislature and the roll call of the Senate and Assembly members votes.

title: Credit Rating Agency Warns of Downgrade if Debt Limit Is Not Raised
description: Fitch Ratings Ltd. warned on Tuesday that Congresss failure to raise the federal governments statutory borrowing limit would very likely prompt a downgrading of the United States Governments credit rating, and the agency seemed to suggest that Congress should simply do away with the debt ceiling altogether.

title: The NRA and Me
description: This is all my fault.

title: Johnson Controls Offers Start-Stop Battery System
description: Forget high-voltage hybrids and instead look to the practicality of 48-volt systems, says Johnson Controls.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 15
Morsi's Inflammatory Comments
description: TimesCast: Past words haunt Egyptian president. | A financial case fizzles. | Rebuilding after Hurricane Sandy.

title: The Least (and Most) Expensive Cars to Insure
description: Not many people consider insurance when they go car shopping, but your premiums can vary a fair bit depending on the type of car you buy. Insure.com each year compiles a list of the 20 least (and most) expensive cars to insure, and a number of S.U.V.s and crossover vehicles are among the cheapest for the 2013 model year.

title: Chinese Vase Said to Sell for Less Than Half Its Record-Setting Price
description: When an 18th-century Chinese vase made for the Qianlong emperor sold for a record $83 million at a West London auction more than two years ago, it seemed like one of those rag-to-riches stories that was almost too good to be true. The price was more than 50 times the auction estimate and a record for any Asian work of art ever sold at auction. The bid was made by an agent on behalf of the Beijing-based collector Wang Yaohui, according to a Bloomberg report  posted on Monday.

title: Lens: Ricky Floress Portraits of the South Bronx
description: Ricky Floress photos of the South Bronx in the 1980s belie the grim stereotype of a crime-ridden, burning borough. The stripped cars, hip-hop culture and the buildings aflame are there, but so is the full range of human experience and emotion. The photographers images from that era, along with those of five others, will be displayed in a new exhibition opening this weekend at the Bronx Documentary Center.

title: Goldman Retreats From Plan to Award Bonuses Later in Britain
description: LONDON  Goldman Sachs decided on Tuesday that it would not delay the payment of bonuses to its staff in Britain, a move that would have helped investment bankers and other highly paid employees benefit from a lower income tax rate.

title: National Book Awards to Diversify Judging Pool
description: Looking to broaden its appeal to the public and increase its impact on sales, The National Book Foundation, which presents The National Book Awards, announced Tuesday that it would increase the number of finalists and diversify the judging pool.

title: Thigh Beats Arm for Childhood Vaccine
description: Children are less likely to develop bad reactions to the DTaP vaccine, a routine immunization shot that protects against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, or whooping cough, if they get it in their thigh instead of in their arm, a new study shows.

title: Photos of The Moment | Umit Benan

title: Dozens Killed as Explosions Hit Syrian University
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least two deadly explosions, possibly caused by airstrikes or bombs, devastated the campus of Aleppo University in Syria on Tuesday as students were taking exams, a major escalation of the violent struggle for control of the countrys largest city. The opposition and the government blamed each other for the blasts, among the worst since the Syrian conflict began nearly two years ago.

title: Coming Soon to North America: Penalty Shot Fever
description: What with that soul-smothering N.H.L. lockout lasting so long, it might take a little something to get hockey fans back into the swing, or nudge casual sports fans toward remembering hockey is a sport. (Hint: Played on ice, very entertaining until ambulances are required.) To help, we bring you the best of a wacky penalty shot contest at the K.H.L. All-Star game in Chelyabinsk on Sunday, courtesy of Jori Lehtera, an East team all-star who plays for Sibir Novosibirsk. Lehtera was a 2008 draft pick by the St. Louis Blues, who could use this kind of inventiveness.

title: The Birds and Birders of Central Park
description: Like many visitors to Central Park, the author Jonathan Franzen thought for years that only gray pigeons and brown sparrows could be seen in the man-made space at the center of Manhattan. It wasnt until the day he went deeper into the Ramble with birder friends that he saw feathers with bright yellows, blues and blacks flitting from branch to branch.

title: Mass Grave Found in Aleppo Amid Fierce Fighting
description: The bodies lay pell-mell under sticky, red earth at Al Islamiah, a sprawling cemetery in Aleppo. Here and there, a limb or a strip of clothing was visible: the tip of a rubber sandal, a clump of curled-up toes, shoeless feet in blue socks. And then there was the face: a prominent nose, a half-open mouth framed by gray stubble, eyes covered with a blindfold. Whatever had happened to the others, there seemed little doubt as to how this man had met his end.

title: A Ford F-150 Concept, Larger Than Life

title: Warm Millet, Carrot and Kale Salad With Curry-Scented Dressing
description: I love millet but it is tricky to cook; it can easily turn to mush. I have found that cooking more than 2/3 cup at a time can be problematic because the millet at the bottom of the pot becomes gummy by the time all of the millet is cooked. But the tiny, nutritious seeds of grain expand so much during cooking that you dont need more than 2/3 of a cup for this recipe, and if you toast the seeds in a little oil first and take care not to stir the millet once youve added the water you will get a fluffy result.

title: Juniper Jumps Into Software Networks
description: Juniper Networks is in a tough place. It has long been a distant second to Cisco Systems in the business of computer networking. It now faces the same industry shifts bedeviling Cisco, primarily a change from running networks with high-margin hardware to deploying cheap commodity computers and fancy software.

title: Skillet Soba, Baked Tofu and Green Bean Salad With Spicy Dressing
description: You can make this salad with wide rice noodles, but I love the nutty flavor and wholesomeness of buckwheat soba.

title: Skillet Brown Rice, Barley or Triticale Salad With Mushrooms and Endive
description: Triticale is a hybrid grain made from wheat and rye, which farmers and health food stores alike had high hopes for in the 1970s. It is a good source of phosphorus and a very good source of magnesium, but apparently the yields were disappointing to farmers and it never really caught on among consumers. I had sort of forgotten about it until I came across it again recently at Bobs Red Mill. I like its chewy texture and earthy flavor, both very similar to farro or wheatberries. Any hearty, toothsome grain works well in this salad, so Ive given you a choice.

title: Emancipation  Then What?
description: Two weeks after President Abraham Lincoln signed the Emancipation Proclamation, a headline in The Detroit Free Press asked, Is a Negro Eligible to the Presidency? The editorial that followed offered an unequivocal Yes. A fiercely pro-Democratic paper, The Free Press despised the fact that the presidency, along with all official positions, could now be open to the nigger.

The problem is that the cable, which would be buried under the seabed, is what grid officials call a multidriver project, or a project that is undertaken for more than one reason  something that those officials have little experience with.

Quinn, the New York City Council speaker and a presumptive candidate for mayor, laid out in a speech on Tuesday a series of proposals for improving the citys schools, which included replacing textbooks with computer tablets, creating online resources for parents and extending the school day for many students.
