description: Even as profit surged, the board of JPMorgan Chase cut the pay package of its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, by 50 percent, in light of a multibillion-dollar trading loss last year.

title: Art Basel Enters Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  The dessert served at the Art Basel Hong Kong media luncheon was a large, hollow chocolate globe that self-destructed when hot fudge was poured over it. As expected, in a room filled with art types, everyone had to discuss it instead of just eating it. Did it symbolize the breakdown of global boundaries as Art Basel prepared its first fair in Asia? Or the melting away of a beloved and quirky local event? (Or maybe the Mandarin Orientals pastry chefs were just in overdrive).

title: An American, 17, Shows Her Power and Promise
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Despite being a spectator, Pam Shriver looked flushed Wednesday as she left Show Court 3 at the Australian Open.

title: Indias Police Force Lags Much of the World
description: A recent spate of violent crimes against women in northern India has led to increased scrutiny of the Indian police force. In Delhi, after the gang rape and subsequent death of a young woman, residents called for the resignation of the citys chief of police and the retraining of the overwhelmingly male police force.

title: No Easy Path for Obamas Gun Safety Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  The fact that President Obama would make an all-out push for new gun restrictions seemed all but inevitable from the moment he delivered tearful yet resolute remarks to the nation in the hours after the Newtown, Conn., school massacre last month.

title: Bolstered by Investments, Goldman Sachss Profit Soars
description: 4:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Selling Some Old Sparkle From Nights at Studio 54
description: As Steve Rubell saw it, the key to a successful party was populating a room with guests more interesting than you.

title: A Hospital Network With a Vision
description: As the United States struggles to find new business models for health care, some innovators are looking to other industries, ones that provide high-quality services for low prices. In a recent article in The New Yorker, for example, Atul Gawande suggests that the Cheesecake Factory restaurant chain  with its size, central control and accountability for the customer experience  could be a model of sorts for health care. Thats not as outlandish as it seems. The worlds largest provider of eye care has found success by directly adapting the management practices of another big-box food brand, one that is not often associated with good health: McDonalds.

title: Interior Secretary to Step Down in March
description: WASHINGTON  Ken Salazar, the blunt-spoken lawyer and rancher who took over the scandal-ridden Interior Department at the outset of the Obama administration, said Wednesday that he would step down  in March to return to his home in Colorado.

title: The Road to Bamako
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Mamadou Doumbia was so thrilled that France intervened this weekend to beat back a jihadi offensive in Mali that on Monday he took me to buy a French flag to mount next to the Malian flag on the dashboard in his taxi.

title: Opinion Report: Jobs for Vets
description: From the editorial page

title: The Central Park Ducks in Winter
description: Dear Diary:

title: Stone Links: Dating Made Easy (All Too Easy)
description: Taking off from Dan Slaters essay in The Atlantic, the philosopher and Stone contributor Peter Ludlow pinpoints the source of the trouble with online dating. In the language of economics (which is probably apt), the most basic cost, of which the ones Slater identifies are just consequences, is that it creates a near frictionless market where transaction costs are all but eliminated. But it is friction, the complications it introduces, Ludlow thinks, that is exactly what we need in loveeven if its not what we want.

title: How Aaron Hernandez Opened a Throwing Window for Tom Brady
description: Aaron Hernandez did it all for the Patriots in their 41-28 victory over Houston on Sunday. With tight end Rob Gronkowski out of the game, Hernandez was targeted nine times, finishing with six receptions for 85 yards.

title: Panetta, at Vatican, Says Pope Thanks Him for Service
description: ROME  On what is probably his last trip as defense secretary, Leon E. Panetta had an audience on Wednesday morning at the Vatican with Pope Benedict XVI, who told him, Mr. Panetta said, Thank you for helping to protect the world. Mr. Panetta said he replied, Pray for me.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Gun Data Under Wraps, and Mixing and Matching Disney Characters
description: New Yorks new gun law has a provision that restricts access to data about gun owners in the state, Christine Haughney writes in The Times. That component was included in the legislation in response to the publication of names and addresses of gun permit holders in two suburban New York counties by The Journal News, a newspaper based in White Plains, N.Y. The decision to print that information with an accompanying map outraged gun owners across the nation and prompted a backlash against the papers employees. Now some journalists are lamenting the loss of data previously available as a reporting tool.

title: Wednesday Reading: Improve Your Flu Shots Potency With Exercise
Goldman Profit Blows Through Expectations
description: Goldman Sachs on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter profit of $2.89 billion, or $5.60 a share, well above results in the period a year earlier and handily beating analysts expectations of $3.78 a share. The results were buoyed by strong trading and investment banking results. The firms conference call is at 10:30 a.m.

title: Hong Kong Reconsiders Changes to Corporate Database
description: HONG KONG  The second-highest official in Hong Kong said Wednesday that the government was reviewing a proposed rule change that had prompted a groundswell of worry among global banks, accounting firms, investors and media companies who fear the loss of a powerful tool against corruption in China.

title: Daily Report: Facebook Introduces a New Search Tool
description: Facebook has spent eight years nudging its users to share everything they like and everything they do, reports Somini Sengupta in Wednesdays New York Times. Now, the company is betting it has enough data so that people can find whatever they want on Facebook. And on Tuesday, it unveiled an ambitious new tool to help them dig for it.

title: Sexual Myopia
description: Every once in a while a male friend in his 60s tells me that try as he might, he just cannot get turned on by women his own age and naturally I channel Cher in Moonstruck and let him have it: Snap out of it, I say! Look in the mirror! We all age! Whats more important to you, a woman 30 years younger whom you can show off on the beach or someone who doesnt draw a blank when you talk about Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov? Not that I have that many conversations in which I need to reference Bullwinkle and Boris Badenov, but when I do I dont want to have to get bogged down in the whole back story. This is why I know this whole cougar thing is a myth. I do not know any women in their 60s who want a 30-year-old boyfriend because what would they talk about?

title: Lumire | The French Fifty Shades
description: When it comes to erotica and pornography, whether hard, soft, sadomasochistic or merely steamy, the French believe they have done it first, done it better and done it all. So the French version of the Fifty Shades of Grey trilogy should have flopped.

title: Lafayette Selects Its First Female President
description: Lafayette College has named Alison R. Byerly as its 17th president, making her the first woman to lead the liberal arts institution in Easton, Pa.

title: Will Boeings Problems Benefit Its European Rival?
description: LONDON  Boeing faced the latest setback for its new 787 Dreamliner on Wednesday and industry-watchers are speculating whether the aircrafts recent troubles could provide a boost for Airbus, the U.S. companys European archrival.

title: Trinkets and Doodads for Those Who Are Just Looking
description: Seeing all the new cars may be the reason automotive journalists from all over the world gather at the Detroit auto show during press days at the Cobo Center, but part of the fun is also seeing what tchotchkes the automakers hand out on the show floor. The new Corvette Stingray is important and all, but wasnt that a really cool paperweight Chevy handed out along with the press materials about the car? They went fast.

title: Channeling Armstrong
description: O.K., so you find yourself with another day to kill while frantically searching your on-screen cable TV guide looking for the Oprah Winfrey Network  Honey, you sure it isnt the Alerta TV network? I found that in the 400s. Halogen TV, maybe?  and youve decided to wonder whether you will be sick of Lance Armstrongs big staged confession before it even starts. This is a distinct possibility. After all, Winfrey has already done interviews about the interview (sigh), let people know Armstrong will not come off as contrite (eye roll) and will quite likely try to paint cyclings leadership as the truly bad guys (stomach churn). Winfreys network helped exactly nothing by deciding to drag the thing over two nights, so you can be doubly preannoyed at the whole sideshow.

title: JPMorgan Report on Trading Loss Takes Aim at Top Executives
description: The bad bet that cost JPMorgan Chase more than $6 billion has already provoked scrutiny from regulators and federal agents.

title: American Airlines Reports a Thin Profit
description: American Airlines, which is in the final stages of bankruptcy and under pressure from US Airways to merge, on Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter profit mostly because of lower costs and some reorganization credits.

title: At Strikes Root, Runaway Costs In Busing Pupils
description: The day before the start of New York Citys first school bus strike in 34 years, a long yellow bus pulled up at Public School 282 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and the little bodies that popped out could be counted on one hand: Three. The big bus had dropped off part of its cargo earlier, at another school, but in all, 10 children had ridden on a bus fit for about 60.

title: Another Change in the Oscar Rules for Documentaries
description: While everyone was busy prepartying and donating money, the Academy quietly announced a major rule change to its members. As GoldDerby.com reports, an e-mail on Saturday informed voters that choosing the best documentary, best animated short and best live-action short would no longer be such exclusive affairs.

title: From Death Strip to Tech Campus
description: BERLIN  Travis Todd, an American tech entrepreneur, pointed at the snow-covered construction site behind his shared office. Twenty-five years ago, East German border guards would have gunned down anyone caught in the restricted zone along the Berlin Wall. Today, Google and other investors are turning an abandoned brewery in the death strip into a technology campus.

title: What Were Reading
description: Food & Wine: Scarlett Johansson wishes she could have raw oysters with Bette Davis.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Jan. 16 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web. On Wednesday, President Obama announced a push for new laws to restrict the availability of guns and to embrace a series of executive actions that he can take without seeking congressional approval.

title: Extortion Charges for 29 Tied to Trash-Hauling Industry
description: In the annals of organized crime and extortion, there is no end to the victims and their suffering, from movie stars and Wall Street brokers to truck drivers and small businessmen.

title: An Insiders Insider Returns to Politics, This Time as an Outsider
description: ROME  The dark, double-breasted suits have long been a mainstay, but now former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has taken to wearing the occasional fedora. It lends him a rakish, retro air as he embarks on what many Italians, foreign investors and no doubt Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany hoped would never happen: another election campaign.

title: Second Stage Adds Nobody Loves You
description: Nobody Loves You, a musical satire about reality television and its shameless contestants, will be the final production in the 2012-13 season at Second Stage Theater, the company said on Wednesday. The musical  which features a book by Itamar Moses (the playwright of The Four of Us and a writer for televisions Boardwalk Empire), music by Gaby Alter, lyrics by Mr. Moses and Mr. Alter and choreography by Mandy Moore (of televisions So You Think You Can Dance)  chronicles a young man who competes on a fictional reality show (also called Nobody Loves You) in hopes of regaining a lost girlfriend and of exposing the contrivances of the show.

title: The Mannequin Also Speaks
description: LAST Thursday, a rarefied intersection of the downtown creative set packed the Envoy Enterprises gallery on Rivington Street. Curators from the New Museum and the Clocktower Gallery mingled with musicians like Santigold and the cabaret siren Lady Rizo.

title: Viva La Villa | Prison-Side Palazzo
description: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

title: Youth and Experience in Harmony
description: One of the worthy activities of the George London Foundation has been its series of voice recitals at the Morgan Library & Museum, in which an established and an emerging artist share a program.

title: Militants Seize Americans and Other Hostages in Algeria
description: BAMAKO, Mali  The French military assault on Islamist extremists in Mali escalated into a potentially much broader North African conflict on Wednesday when, in retribution, armed attackers in unmarked trucks seized an internationally managed natural gas field in neighboring Algeria and took at least 20 foreign hostages, including Americans.

title: The Dalloway
description: LESBIANS tired of the same old bars in Manhattan  Cubbyhole, Henrietta Hudson, the Stonewall Inn  have a new spot to call their own. Opened in November, the Dalloway, named after the Virginia Woolf character, is owned by two reality TV stars: Kim Stolz of Americas Next Top Model, and Amanda Leigh Dunn of The Real L Word.

title: Putting Limits on Guns
description: TimesCast: What to expect from President Obamas gun control proposal. | France begins a ground war against Malian insurgents.

title: Tell Us Your Candidates for Obama Cinema
description: As the presidents second inauguration approaches, The Timess chief film critics, A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, are proposing a new genre: Obama Cinema. In a highly preliminary, wildly speculative thematic guide  as they put it  they argue that its possible to view recent American films as reflections of different aspects of the nation and especially its leader since 2008.

title: Movies in the Age of Obama
description: FOUR years ago, on the historic occasion of Barack Obamas first inauguration, we took a look at the good, bad and outrageous movie characters who helped make his election possible. The road to the White House, we wrote, hadnt just been paved by Mr. Obamas speeches, innovative campaign strategies and the hopefulness of a majority of voters, but also by decades of African-American men in movies. From the class striving of Sidney Poitiers everyman in the classic film A Raisin in the Sun to Will Smiths messianic loners in recent titles like I Am Legend, the movies have ennobled, consecrated, glorified, immortalized and, most important, normalized the figure of the black man.

title: Keeping Score: Magic Pay Less Attention to the 3-Point Line
description: The 2012 off-season was tumultuous for the Orlando Magic. From late May to early August they fired Stan Van Gundy, the best coach in franchise history; traded Dwight Howard, the best player in franchise history; and lost the free agent Ryan Anderson, the leagues most improved player last season.

title: Obama to Put Everything Ive Got Into Gun Control
description: WASHINGTON  Four days before taking the oath of office, President Obama on Wednesday staked the beginning of his second term on an uphill quest to pass the broadest gun control legislation in a generation.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 16
Bronx Zoo Welcomes Baby Gibbon
description: Half a world away from its native habitat, a white-cheeked gibbon was born in the Bronx.

title: France Battles Rebels in Mali
description: The Timess Greg Winter talks about the escalating conflict in Mali, where the government and France are fighting Islamist insurgents.

title: Kids Draw the News: Draw the School Bus Strike
description: Updated | Feb. 4, 2013 We are no longer accepting submissions for this assignment.

title: 2014 Transit Van: Ford Builds a Better Box
description: Introduced on Tuesday: 2014 Ford Transit commercial vehicle

title: White House Gun Proposals
description: The White House released a series of documents on Wednesday outlining the presidents plan for reducing gun violence.

title: A Right of Insurrection?
description: Opponents of gun control often argue that they need firearms for self-defense. Most of them mean that literally  defending themselves and their homes and families against intruders. Others have a more grandiose understanding of self-defense. They find gun control anathema because they believe that firearms safeguard the right to rise up against the American government.

title: Steve Rubell Memorabilia at Auction
description: Items from Mr. Rubells collection of items associated with Studio 54 are up for sale.

title: Levine Sees More Opportunity Representing Canada
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  The United States once seemed to attract defecting tennis champions in droves, with Martina Navratilova, Monica Seles and even Ivan Lendl, late in his career, switching to representing the United States.

title: In the Round: Chevy Impala LTZ
description: The Chevrolet Impala LTZ at the Detroit auto show. To control the view of the car, click on the image and move the cursor left or right.

title: Photo Replay: January 16
description: The day in sports, including the World Cup downhill and the Australian Open.

title: White House Denounces Web Video by N.R.A.
description: WASHINGTON  The National Rifle Association provoked a furious response from the White House on Wednesday by releasing a video accusing President Obama of being an elitist and a hypocrite because he opposes posting armed guards at schools, while his daughters have Secret Service protection.

title: A Soap Maker Sought Compatibility in a Merger Partner
description: For Eric Ryan and Adam Lowry, the quest began in 2001 in what they call a dirty little flat in San Francisco, where the two childhood buddies from Detroit first plotted to disrupt the all-but-impenetrable cleaning products industry long dominated by giants like SC Johnson and Procter & Gamble.

title: The Fisker Karma With a V-8, Courtesy of Bob Lutz
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: VL Automotive Destino

title: What Factors Affect Your Credit Score
description: A Web site from an arm of the credit bureau Experian now offers a free tool that can help you see how different financial steps, or missteps, can affect your credit score.

title: On Our Radar: The Python Hunting Contest
description: Eleven Burmese pythons have been captured in Florida since a hunting contest for the snakes, an invasive species, began in southern Florida on Saturday. [The Miami Herald]

title: The Fall Lines Fault
description: The warehouses that once serviced the wharves of Richmond, Va., now house restaurants and stores, including the venerable independent Fountain Bookstore. A heron rookery bustles in the riverside treetops, the nestlings nourished by the fish that crowd the turbulent, oxygen-rich shallows below. The rapids offer the best urban kayaking in the United States.

title: A Spirited American Tale
description: Todays booksellers, surrounded by tablets and e-book readers of varying gigabytes and styles, are by all appearances in the throes of a daunting battle. But in 1775, Henry Knox, a bookseller in colonial America, got tangled in a war of a more traditional stripe.

title: In Effort to Preserve Bedford-Stuyvesant, Some Ask: For Whom?
description: With block after block of crisply handsome 19th-century row houses arrayed in almost military precision, punctuated on the avenues by fantastically turreted schoolhouses and apartment buildings, the area of Bedford-Stuyvesant between Bedford and Tompkins Avenues and Monroe and Fulton Streets is unquestionably a historical district.

title: Christian Rocker Tops the Chart
description: New albums by a Christian singer-songwriter and a band of masked rap-rockers have taken over the Billboard chart, as the music industrys post-holiday sales doldrums continue.

title: Where South Beach Meets the Stage
description: The focus of Focus Dance, the multiprogram festival presented by Gotham Arts Exchange at the Joyce Theater last week, is less on whos dancing than on whos in the audience: the potential buyers in town for the annual Association of Performing Arts Presenters conference. Most of the selections had been shown recently in New York, but one company was making a New York debut: Rosie Herrera Dance Theater.

title: Full Transcript of Biden and Obamas Remarks on Gun Laws
description: The following is the complete transcript of President Obamas remarks on gun laws on Wednesday in Washington. (Transcript courtesy of Federal News Service.)

title: Ex-Governor, Disgraced in Scandal, Eyes Congress
description: Mark Sanford, the former South Carolina governor whose career and marriage crumbled as he pursued a relationship with an Argentine woman, on Wednesday made official his decision to run for Congress.

title: Hotel Review: Alfonso XIII in Seville, Spain
description: UPSHOT

title: Social Search and the Difficulties of Discovery
description: In literature and philosophy, in both West and East, the notion of search refers to expansive, ambitious human pursuits. We have, alternately, searched for the Promised Land and the holy grail. Astronomers have searched for life in outer space. The Buddha searched for truth.

title: Obama Unveils Plan for Gun Laws
description: President Obama outlined his proposals to reduce gun violence in the United States, urging Congress to approve expanded background checks, a ban on assault weapons and other restrictions.

title: Has Snowboarding Lost Its Edge?
description: LATE last summer when Shaun White, the two-time Olympic gold medal snowboarder and X-Games superstar, was charged with public intoxication and vandalism, he became at age 26 an accidental metaphor for his sport: a young phenom all grown up, and in a spot of trouble.

title: Only for Those Who Arent Photosensitive
description: Last weekend Japan Society presented its 15th annual contemporary dance showcase and once again opened a window onto the East Asian scene. The seriess artistic director, Yoko Shioya, remarked that the Internet has made that scene more easily accessible. She also said that her focus has shifted from new companies to new works, since so many dancers and choreographers are now freelancers and eager to collaborate with artists outside dance. Sounds like New York.

title: Pushing France Onto the Digital Stage
description: PARIS  When the most prominent new face in Frances effort to oversee the new economy speaks, her pronouncements may be followed almost as closely in Silicon Valley and Seoul as in Paris.

title: Forecast: More Sunshine at Sundance (at Least on Screen)
description: The Sundance Film Festival has long had a dual personality. The atmosphere is typically fun and fizzy  Stars! Swag! Hot tub hopping!  while the films are dark and depressing, sometimes to the point of self-parody.

title: Milan Top 5
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Below the Line: Designing Moonrise Kingdom
description: While Moonrise Kingdom, Wes Andersons whimsical feature about young romantics in a small island community, didnt make the cut for best picture at last weeks Oscar nominations, it did receive a nod for its screenplay and was recognized by the Producers Guild of America, while also making several critics top 10 lists.

title: Introducing Building the Team: Flower Power
description: Three years ago, I knew nothing about flowers.

title: Rossignol Rentals Introduce Its Technology
description: Memories of ill-performing rental gear  skis with the turning ability of a two-by-four, boots that pinch  are a big deterrent to occasional skiers, especially those who havent visited the slopes recently enough to realize that todays equipment has vastly improved, making it easier to become a better skier.

title: Knicks Practice in London With Anthony Backing Dolan
description: LONDON  After a trans-Atlantic flight, the Knicks returned to work Wednesday, adjusting to their temporary surroundings with a practice session at O2 Arena and a clinic for children who might have been only vaguely familiar with N.B.A. players.

title: The Latest in Anti-Politics
description: Gail Collins: David, the House Republicans are going off for their annual retreat this week. As a sign of my good intentions, I am not going to make any jokes involving Custer and Little Bighorn.

title: What Is Driving Growth in Government Spending?
description: Its one of the most fundamental political questions of our time: Whats driving the growth in government spending? And it has a relatively straightforward answer: first and foremost, spending on health care through Medicare and Medicaid, and other major social insurance and entitlement programs.

title: Have an N.B.A. Question? Howard Beck Has Answers
description: 3:56 p.m. | Updated What has happened to the Mavericks? Are the Nets good enough to go beyond the first round of the playoffs? Can the Lakers be repaired? Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers about the season. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear next week on Off the Dribble.

title: Still Flying Beyond Gravitys Pull
description: Nearly a decade has passed since Idina Menzel introduced her signature song, the Stephen Schwartz anthem Defying Gravity in the 2003 Broadway smash Wicked.

title: Study Discovers DNA That Tells Mice How to Construct Their Homes
description: The architectural feats of animals  from beaver dams to birds nests  not only make for great nature television, but, since the plans for such constructions seem largely inherited, they also offer an opportunity for scientists to tackle the profoundly difficult question of how genes control complicated behavior in animals and humans.

title: Sandy and the Hastert Rule
description: A quick look at the House vote on $50.7 billion in federal aid to repair the damage from Hurricane Sandy suggests that it passed pretty easily on Tuesday night, 241 to 180. The real news is in how the two parties split: Republicans voted overwhelmingly against it, while all but one Democrat supported it.

title: Will Gridlock Last?
description: Lately Ive been arguing that both political parties should probably lower their expectations for what theyre likely to achieve in a divided Washington D.C. This would mean focusing on consolidation (for liberals) and rebuilding (for conservatives), making small-ball deals instead of seeking grand bargains and comprehensive reforms, giving up on the idea that some brilliant legislative gambit will suddenly break the House Republicans or force the White House to accede to G.O.P. demands, and accepting that the next wave of significant legislating will probably have to await a shift in the balance of power come 2014 or 2016.

title: Reversing Course, Kelly Leaves Oregon to Become Coach of the Eagles
description: On Saturday evening, the Philadelphia Eagles sent out a curious statement. They explained that they had no regrets about how much time they had spent interviewing the best college coaches for their vacant head coaching spot, despite knowing there was only a remote chance one of them would leave for the N.F.L. The statement was an indication the Eagles were moving on, having failed to land their top choice.

title: Comparing Wall St. Bonuses? Theres an App for That
description: Its a ritual as old as Wall Street. Come bonus time, employees furtively compare their pay to see how they measure up.

title: Oxygen Drops Plans for All My Babies Mamas
description: The cable channel Oxygen has scrapped a show in development called All My Babies Mamas after the promotion of an online petition that condemned the channel, accusing it of exploiting and stereotyping black children and families.

title: Incoming Members of Congress Not Exactly Average Joes
description: With the rise of the Tea Party movement, the image of Average Joe Citizen taking over Congress has captured the medias imagination, from rural northern Florida, which sent a large-animal veterinarian, Ted Yoho, to the House, to eastern Michigan, which elected a reindeer farmer and Santa Claus impersonator, Kerry Bentivolio.

title: Inaugural Committee Previews Weekends Festivities
description: I love the idea of any show that begins with Chuck Schumer and ends with Beyonc.  Brent Colburn, communications director for President Obamas inaugural committee, describing Mondays swearing in ceremony on the west front of the Capitol. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat, will make remarks opening the ceremony and Beyonc will sing the national anthem at the end.

title: Houston Symphony Chooses New Maestro
description: The Houston Symphony on Wednesday named the Colombian-born Andrs Orozco-Estrada as its next music director. Mr. Orozco-Estrada, 35, will begin conducting the orchestra regularly next season and take over officially with a five-year contract in the 2014-15 season.

title: A Breath of Florida, Alligators Included
description: Parsons Dance returned to the Joyce Theater on Tuesday with works by the choreographer David Parsons, including his new Dawn to Dusk, as well as a commission by a former company member, Katarzyna Skarpetowska. Each serve watered-down versions of dances by master choreographers: Mr. Parsons, as usual, draws from Paul Taylor, with whom he danced. Ms. Skarpetowska, at least in her new Black Flowers, channels Martha Graham.

title: Anti-Auto Show Focusing on Alternative Transportation
description: DETROIT  The North American International Anti-Auto Show, an art exhibition timed around the show at the Cobo Center, opens Friday night with a black-tie preview at the Contemporary Art Institute of Detroit. Admission is $1 to the green carpet event, where anti-auto show girls will unveil some of the artwork from 14 artists highlighting alternative transportation-based themes.

title: Family Art
description: Dieter Roths works live on as a family business.

title: Into Antarcticas Dark Depths
description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

title: Could Responsibilities Help Prevent Teenage Suicide?
description: One recent Saturday, a friend of mine drove across town to a gun store. She bought a pistol, went back to her car in the parking lot, and ended her life.

title: Gun Reform for a Generation
description: We usually cringe when politicians drag ordinary people onstage for their events. But the four children who appeared with their parents and President Obama in the White House on Wednesday at his announcement on gun control proposals drove home the nature of the crisis facing the country. While guns and gun control have been a subject of debate among politicians and lawyers and lobbyists and pollsters and political groups in the center and on the fringes, our children have been living in a free-fire zone for sociopaths with virtually unfettered access to instruments of mass murder.

title: Lance Armstrong Faces the Media
description: TimesCast Media+Tech: Oprah Winfreys network prepares to show the Lance Armstrong interview. | John Green, the author and video blogger, goes from YouTube to Carnegie Hall. | Apps for the ski slopes.

title: Teaching About the Flu With The New York Times
description: Flu Attack! How a Virus Invades Your Body, a video from NPR

title: Producer Says James Brown Biopic Is Finally a Go
description: The movie producer Brian Grazer says that he has obtained the rights to James Browns music from the singers estate and that he is moving ahead with a long-delayed film about Mr. Browns life. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Mr. Grazer said that he had brought in Mick Jagger as a producer and that they intended to begin casting the movie soon, using a revised version of a script Mr. Grazer commissioned years ago from the British screenwriters Jez and John-Henry Butterworth.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Lance Armstrong Faces the Media
description: Oprah Winfreys network prepares to show the Lance Armstrong interview. John Green, the author and video blogger, goes from YouTube to Carnegie Hall. Apps for the ski slopes.

title: Owning a Home, Mortgage Free
description: With all the painful foreclosures during the recent economic downturn, its easy to forget that some homeowners dont even have mortgages. Nearly a third of homeowners  29.3 percent of them  do not, according to a recent analysis by the real estate site Zillow.

title: Europe Weighs Requiring Firms to Disclose Data Breaches
description: BERLIN  To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require companies that store data on the Internet  like Microsoft, Apple, Google and I.B.M.  to report the loss or theft of personal information in the 27-nation bloc or risk sanctions and fines.

title: An Actors Evolution, by Way of Some Famous Scenes
description: Right from the start of his career James DeVita could perform Shakespeare with his hands tied behind his back.

title: Seven Features Announced for New Directors/New Films Series
description: Sarah Polleys documentary exploration into her own family and Shane Carruths followup to his 2004 debut, Primer, are among the features that will be presented at this years New Directors/New Films series, the annual program presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, the organizations said on Wednesday.

title: Students Letters to Obama
description: Read three student letters, released by the White House to The Associated Press, asking President Obama to change gun laws.

title: Ask Well: Do I Need a Flu Shot if Ive Had the Flu?
description: Question:

title: Spicing Up a Ho-Hum Tech Show
description: Hi boss! Im back from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. You assigned me to report on whats new and exciting, but I have some bad news. The answer is: almost nothing.

title: Winehouse Foundation Gift to Help Brooklyn Conservatory Students
description: The Amy Winehouse Foundation has awarded $25,000 to the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music to finance scholarships for teenage jazz musicians. The parents of Amy Winehouse, Janis and Mitch Winehouse, attended a short ceremony at the nonprofit conservatory in Park Slope on Wednesday morning to hand over a giant facsimile of a check to Karen Geer, the executive director.

title: Growing Up With Hinschs
description: One of the last vestiges of my childhood in Brooklyn will be gone when Hinschs, the luncheonette-cum-ice cream parlor in Bay Ridge, closes down as planned in March.

title: Germany to Move 674 Tons of Gold
description: FRANKFURT  Nearly half of Germanys gold reserves are held in a vault at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York  billions of dollars worth of postwar geopolitical history squirreled away for safe keeping below the streets of Lower Manhattan.

title: Whats in Obamas Gun Control Proposal
description: The initiative to reduce gun violence announced by President Obama includes both legislative proposals that would need to be acted on by Congress and executive actions he can do on his own.

title: If You Like the Moody Blues, Try Alt-J
description: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to that of her 20-something sons generation.

title: Lance Armstrong Opens Up to Oprah
description: On the eve of Lance Armstrong's interview with Oprah Winfrey, The Times's Brian Stelter talks about the fallen athlete as he faces the media.

title: An Acura MDX Prototype With Front-Wheel Drive
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2014 Acura MDX Prototype

title: Video Shows Flaming Wreckage After Helicopter Crash in London
description: Video and photographs posted online by witnesses showed smoke and fire on a street in central London after a helicopter crash on Wednesday. The police said the aircraft hit a crane atop a residential tower, exploding into flames and hurtling to the ground during the morning rush, my colleagues Lark Turner and Alan Cowell reported.

title: Alfa Romeo Returns to America, via China
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2007 Alfa Romeo 166  check that, its now a 2013 Guangzhou Trumpchi

title: When Scots Cut Loose, They Go All the Way
description: New York seems to be lacking in proper date plays  you know, lively love stories that might lead to dinners in dark places and public make-out sessions. Of course theres Once, the Tony-winning, boy-almost-gets-girl musical on Broadway. But if youre looking for a less obvious, more affordable show to see with that special someone you slipped your number to last week at Citarella, you could do worse than Midsummer, written and directed by David Greig.

title: Kathryn Bigelow Steps Up Defense of Zero Dark Thirty
description: As the political and film industry tensions around Zero Dark Thirty rise, Kathryn Bigelow, a naturally reserved woman who dislikes public speaking, has taken more opportunities to defend her film, about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, and its portrayal of torture as a tactic used by the C.I.A. in its manhunt.

title: Pot Goes to Florida, and Vice Versa
description: Dave Barry has written a comic novel that features lost luggage, beaches, hapless tourists from Michigan, exotic animal life, drugs, wild mix-ups, laughable oldsters and the trademarked zaniness of Florida. Not at all coincidentally Tim Dorseys new comic novel features these same ingredients, although Mr. Dorseys hapless tourists come from Wisconsin.

title: H.P. Said to Have Suitors for Two Units
description: Hewlett-Packard has received a number of inquiries from would-be buyers for its Autonomy and Electronic Data Systems units in recent weeks, though the technology company is not interested in selling at the moment, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

title: By the Fadduh of 60s Parodies
description: Broadway history is punctuated with failures, but some are more spectacular than others. Surely hopes were high in 1969 when Allan Sherman, he of Hello Muddah, Hello Fadduh and the best-selling song-parody album My Son, the Folk Singer, delivered a musical about the strains of infidelity then sweeping across suburbia. Despite Dorothy Loudon as its star and George Abbott as its director The Fig Leaves Are Falling closed after four performances, leaving behind a memorable pan from Clive Barnes of The New York Times. There is nothing much wrong with the show, he wrote, that a new book, new music, new lyrics, new settings, new direction, new choreography and a partially new cast would not quite possibly put right.

title: Counting the Vanishing Bees
description: A new method for monitoring the decline in bee populations may prove a useful tool in much-needed conservation efforts. It requires only a few hundred pan traps: bright shallow bowls partly filled with soapy water or propylene glycol.

title: Segregation Linked in Study With Lung Cancer Deaths
description: African-Americans who live in highly segregated counties are considerably more likely to die from lung cancer than those in counties that are less segregated, a new study has found.

title: China Arrests 7 in New Effort to Stop Tibetan Self-Immolations
description: BEIJING  The authorities in northwest China have detained seven people they say organized the fatal self-immolation of a Tibetan villager in October, photographed his burning body and then sent the images abroad.

title: YouTube to Carnegie Hall
description: Thanks in no small part to a YouTube channel he started with his younger brother, the best-selling author John Green enjoys literary success  and his own concert performance at Carnegie Hall.

title: Cadillac, Ford, Nissan and Lutz Win Design Awards
description: The annual Eyes on Design Awards for design excellence at the Detroit auto show were presented late Tuesday as the last event of press days.

title: A First Look at Saint Laurent in the Stores
description: Hedi Slimanes first designs for Saint Laurent, including his spring mens wear and a womens resort collection that had not previously been shown to the news media, began appearing in stores this week, giving customers their first opportunity to see the clothes up close. Barneys New York has a small selection of the mens designs, including a cotton hoodie that costs nearly $1,000, and some womens pieces like a minidress in an animal print ($4,490) are now available online.

title: Different Shades of German Rivalry
description: January does not look like its going to be a good month for Schalke.

title: Smithsonian and Patent Office Work Together on Expo
description: The Arts and Industries Building on the National Mall has been closed for extensive renovations since 2004. But in anticipation of its reopening next year, the Smithsonian announced on Wednesday that it is starting a programming and exhibition series this summer at the Patent and Trademark Offices headquarters in Alexandria, Va.

title: Shelby Focus ST Looks Back to the 1980s
description: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 15: 2013 Shelby Focus ST

title: Rodriguez Has Hip Surgery; Yankees Expect Six-Month Recovery
description: The last time Alex Rodriguez had hip surgery was 2009. He did not return until May 8 that season, but managed to hit 30 home runs and knock in 100 runs, then went on a remarkable tear in the postseason to lead the Yankees to a World Series title. Four years later, Rodriguez is hoping for a taste of the same formula, although the recovery time could be three times as long.

title: Lawmaker Weighs In on Gun Issue
description: An interview with Congressman Mike Thompson, chairman of the Congressional Gun Violence Prevention Task Force.

title: In Italy, a British Outpost
description: MILAN

title: Suiting Up in Milan
description: There is still a special quality to Italian goods.

title: Dennis Kucinich Signs as Fox News Contributor
description: Dennis Kucinich, the former Democratic congressman from Ohio, is the Fox News Channels newest contributor.

title: Robert Wolf Said to Hire Goolsbee as Adviser for His Firm
description: One of President Obamas favorite bankers is teaming up with one of the presidents go-to economists.

title: A-List Guide to the Inauguration Parties
description: WHEN aides to President Obama announced that there would be only two official inaugural balls this weekend  the fewest in recent memory  Washington insiders and veteran partygoers shrugged.

title: Audis Trackside Diversion in Detroit
description: Having revealed two vehicles with a combined output of 914 horsepower, Audi was feeling particularly racy at this years Detroit auto show. Perhaps to drive the point home, the German automaker invited journalists to a night of go-karting, following the first media preview day on Monday.

title: Tougher Line Needed on Dimon
description: JPMorgan Chase has gone soft on Jamie Dimon over the so-called whale trade.

title: Models and Actresses Start Makeup Lines
description: The transition from modeling or acting to running a company is not easy.

title: From Celebrity to Entrepreneur
description: ON an overcast Monday afternoon, while many of her peers were nursing Golden Globes hangovers, Drew Barrymore was greeting members of the press at the TriBeCa headquarters of Maesa, a cosmetics manufacturer that is her partner in a new line, Flower. It began arriving at Walmart stores on Jan 2, with items priced from $4.98 to $13.98.

title: Morsi Says His Slurs of Jews Were Taken Out of Context
description: CAIRO  A spokesman for President Mohamed Morsi said on Wednesday that inflammatory comments that he made about Jews before taking office had been intended as criticism of Israeli policies toward the Palestinians but had been taken out of context. The spokesman said that Mr. Morsi respected all monotheistic religions and religious freedom.

title: Memorable Clips
description: Mia Farrow, Linda Evangelista, Grace Coddington and others as examples of a radical change in hairstyle.

title: The Karlie Is Turning Heads
description: THE haircut of the year has arrived. Yes, already. Vogue is calling it the Chop, others have named it the Karlie, after the model Karlie Kloss.

title: Study Confirms Benefits of Flu Vaccine for Pregnant Women
description: While everyone is being urged to get the flu vaccine as soon as possible, some pregnant women avoid it in the belief that it may harm their babies. A large new study confirms that they should be much more afraid of the flu than the vaccine.

title: Photos of The Moment | Carven
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Times Communications Executive Is Leaving
description: 1:25 p.m. | Updated Robert Christie, senior vice president of corporate communications for The New York Times Company, is leaving the company and his position is being eliminated, The Times announced Wednesday.

title: In Thoreaus Flower Journal, Clues for Climatologists
description: Henry David Thoreau was a peculiar fellow. After his secluded stint at Walden Pond, his fixation with the natural world only grew. Starting in 1852, his journal turned into a two million-word project documenting seasonal observations around his small Massachusetts township, Concord. Over the next six springs he could be seen racing about town like a madman in an effort to spot and record that years first elusive blooms, all the while taking notes.

title: Scouting Report
description: LE SHOPPING

title: Netanyahu Issues Veiled Barb in Response to Reported Criticism From Obama
description: JERUSALEM  Days before an Israeli election that he is expected to win, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday directed a veiled barb at President Obama, who was quoted this week as denouncing Mr. Netanyahus policies.

title: Moodys Gives Colleges a Negative Grade
description: The credit reporting agency Moodys said on Wednesday that it had revised its financial outlook for colleges and universities, giving a negative grade to the entire field.

title: On Snowy Slopes, Fingers Glide Down the Touch Screen
description: I love skiing: the thrill of racing down a tricky trail, the tingle of icy air in your lungs, the mountaintop views, the sips of mulled wine. Like everyone, I take a tumble now and again, and I am prone to getting lost among the trails and ski lifts, and stuck in the occasional snowdrift. At least my red hair helps my friends find me on the slopes.

title: Scent of Chekhov May Confuse the Senses
description: Remember those much-parodied Calvin Klein fragrance commercials that Richard Avedon did in the mid-1980s? The ones with glamorous, sexually ambiguous young creatures in stark rooms, striking languorous poses and speaking enigmatic nonsense? Well, thats kind of what Tina Satters Seagull (Thinking of you), part of Performance Space 122s Coil Festival, feels like, at least at first.

title: App Smart: Ski Trip Apps
description: Kit Eaton reviews apps that could help you out on your weekend ski trip.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran and Egypt.

title: Homes for $1.6 Million
description: Properties in Connecticut, Washington, D.C. and Houston.

title: What You Get for ... $1.6 Million
description: ROXBURY, CONN.

title: A Snub by Oscars? Affleck Has an Answer
description: Ben Affleck said to ask him anything. Nothing is off limits, he said, adding later, Theres nothing that you can ask me that hasnt been asked of me before.

title: Letting Dance Carry Music: Balanchine Put Tchaikovsky in Perspective
description: Peter Martins will soon reach his 30th anniversary as ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet. The companys schedule for the whole 2012-13 season reads as a statement of what Mr. Martins believes matters most to its identity. The fall season concentrated on the series of Stravinsky ballets that was the most celebrated and radical part of the founder and choreographer George Balanchines work; the current season, through Feb. 24, celebrates Balanchines no less important Tchaikovsky ballets (following the six-week season of George Balanchines The Nutcracker, a core ballet for reasons apart from its popularity). And the spring season will focus on Mr. Martinss own ballets. Premieres by both Justin Peck and Christopher Wheeldon are spaced over months.

title: Rich Littles Many Characters
description: A Las Vegas show by the countrys pre-eminent impressionist in the 1970s may be headed to Broadway.

title: In Choosing a Tablet, First Try It On for Size
description: In the grand scheme of worries, deciding which size tablet to get  they all sit within a roughly three-inch screen range  does not quite rank.

title: Shopping Snapshots: Jan. 17
description: Spring fashion is still a few weeks away from stores, but there are stellar pieces in many of the resort collections that can breathe life into your exhausted winter wardrobe.

title: Make No Mistake, but if You Do, Heres How to Correct It
description: Newspaper people try to get everything right, but given that they are human beings writing and editing huge amounts of copy on unforgiving deadlines, often they dont.

title: Obama Plans to Name Close Aide on National Security as Chief of Staff
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is planning to elevate a key national security deputy, Denis R. McDonough, to White House chief of staff, administration officials said on Wednesday, making perhaps his closest foreign policy adviser the gatekeeper to the Oval Office.

title: Where Knowing Your Way Around a Song Trumps Youth
description: An awards show without acceptance speeches, only performances by the winners of their best material: that was the considerable enticement of the 11th annual New York Nightlife Awards, presented at Town Hall on Monday evening in a three-hour-plus marathon hosted by the writer and comedian Bruce Vilanch.

title: A Dream of a Lifetime, Fully Lived in Hours
description: The rhythmic squeak of rotating blades on a windmill outside a rustic country inn; wind rushing through the grass; unsmiling characters viewed sidelong through half-open doors: These are among the repetitive aural and visual motifs in Eduardo Nuness Southwest that evoke the relentless passing of time and the weight of the world on people struggling to survive.

title: An Unheralded Muse of Midcentury Fashion
description: FASHION history lesson: At the 1965 inauguration of Lyndon B. Johnson, his wife, Lady Bird, wore a matching coat-and-dress daytime ensemble in a shade of red so vivid that it was described in press reports as American Beauty.

title: Supreme Court Hears Argument on the F.C.C.s Authority to Rule on Cellphone Towers
description: WASHINGTON  In June, two Texas cities asked the Supreme Court to decide a practical question and an abstract one, both concerning how quickly local zoning authorities have to respond to applications from telecommunications companies to build wireless towers.

title: The 1.6.13 Issue
description: GEORGE SAUNDERS

title: A Minimalist House Near Oslo
description: A starkly designed house in Drammen is on the market for $1.6 million (8.7 million Norwegian kroner).

title: House Hunting in ... Norway
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM MINIMALIST HOUSE NEAR OSLO

title: Hearings Set on the Gowanus Cleanup
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to hold two public meetings next week on its proposed Superfund cleanup of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The massive job involves dredging contaminated sediment from most of the canal at a cost of up to $504 million. The agency is also proposing that the city control raw sewage discharges by installing holding tanks that would temporarily retain excess sewage and storm water during rains until treatment plants can handle the load.

title: When Pills Fail, This, er, Option Provides a Cure
description: The treatment may sound appalling, but it works.

title: Comedy Not Intended for the Squeamish
description: With jolting premieres coming up from shows like The Following and Bates Motel, the winter television season is going to separate viewers who like their TV strong and unsettling from those who dont.

title: In the Post-Pocket-Protector Era, Reigning on Reality TV Contest
description: Reality televisions perennial problem is that many people who are not professional actors are awkward and unappealing on camera. The solution? Make a show about people who by definition are awkward and unappealing.

title: Prominent Republicans Criticize Obamas Executive Actions
description: Prominent Republicans are accusing President Obama of abusing his executive power by taking 23 executive actions on gun violence at the same time that he asked Congress to pass legislation.

title: A Show Makes Friends and History
description: Scandal, now in its second season, has been a success for ABC. Last week the show had 3.52 million viewers aged 18 to 49 and 8.4 million total viewers. Among the group aged 18 to 34 it typically ranks first in its 10 p.m. Thursday time slot. A political thriller set in Washington, Scandal has attracted some inside-the-beltway fans like the political strategists Donna Brazile and Roland S. Martin, who have both tweeted about the show.

title: A Defiant Oui for Fifty Shades
description: PARIS

title: Tweaking Raps Rules, but With Respect
description: What are the hallmarks of great rapping in 2013? Lyrical imagination and complexity, sure  those are always on the list. But theyre increasingly sharing space with things like texture, emotion, versatility, experimentation and confidence. Rap has always made room for innovation, eccentricity and dialect, but the range has never been wider.

title: Last Time Around, Striking Bus Drivers Had Plenty of Company
description: The New York of 1979, much like the New York of mid-January 2013, was a city of unbused schoolchildren.

title: F.A.A. Grounds U.S.-Operated Boeing 787s
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said Wednesday that it was grounding all Boeing 787s operated by United States carriers until it can determine what caused a new type of battery to catch fire on two planes in nine days.

title: A Novelist and His Brother Sell Out Carnegie Hall
description: Goofy variety shows are not the stock in trade of most authors, especially those who write emotionally wrenching novels about teenagers dying of cancer, but John Green inhabits a multiplatform world with few boundaries. So when he took the stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night along with his brother, Hank, to celebrate the one-year anniversary of the release of Johns critically acclaimed book The Fault in Our Stars, all of his diverse interests were on display.

title: Jaime Ortiz-Patio at the 1982 Bermuda Regional
description: Jaime Ortiz-Patio, a former president of the World Bridge Federation, died on Jan. 3 in Marbella, Spain. He was 82.

title: Creatures Small and Great
description: In the world of bio design, tiles are animated and moss is electric.

title: The Beauty of Bacteria
description: IF were to believe half a century of daytime TV commercials, housekeeping is war  a perpetual battle against the sneaky soldiers of nature. For decades, weve armed ourselves with cleaning products to slay bacteria, scrape away fungus and torture mites. As our household organisms move up the evolutionary ladder, acquiring wings and faces, we hire mercenaries to drive them out.

title: Camellias That Can Take the Chill
description: In cold climates, early bloomers make the best choices.

title: Ready for Their Cold Snap
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa.

title: In Meeting With Somali President, Clinton Should Stand Up for Rape Victims
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  On the eve of Secretary Clintons first official meeting with the new Somali president, Hassan Sheik Mohamud, heres a story she should think about.

title: Hoax Is Revealed as Irish Star Says He Was Duped
description: Manti Teo, Notre Dames star linebacker, was one of the feel-good stories of the 2012 college football season, excelling on the field despite the deaths of his grandmother and his girlfriend, he said, within hours of each other.

title: From Disney, a Video Game Universe on One Platform
description: Disney Interactive Studios went to great pains to lay out its new multiplatform gaming initiative, Disney Infinity, and with good reason. Infinity, which is to be released in June, will have a lot of elements at the start, and has the potential to grow into a behemoth.

title: Transforming an Ugly Duckling on the Upper West Side
description: Before and after views of a handkerchief-sized apartment made livable.

title: A Spirited Game of Musical Rooms
description: AS anyone who has ever been disappointed by the New York housing market knows, the experience can be something like a bad date: Drawn in by the promise of a handsome exterior, you make your way hopefully down a featureless corridor and persevere up a sagging stair, only to find a duplex of spaces that are sloppily renovated, bizarrely configured and so small as to be almost uninhabitable.

title: F.A.A. Statement Grounding Boeing 787s
description: Following is the statement issued Wednesday evening by the Federal Aviation Administration ordering the temporary grounding of Boeing 787s operated by carriers in the United States:

title: Shopping for Patterned Bedding
description: Gaby Basora, a fashion designer, goes in search of colorful printed sheets.

title: Russian Court Rejects Jailed Punk Band Members Request to Be With Young Son
description: MOSCOW  A judge in Siberia on Wednesday rejected an appeal by a member of the punk protest band Pussy Riot to be released temporarily so that she could be with her 5-year-old son while he was growing up, telling the courtroom that having a small child did not prevent her from committing a serious crime.

title: Patterned Bedding
description: GABY BASORA breezed into the John Robshaw showroom in Chelsea wearing a yellow coat with black stitching, a black-and-cream jumpsuit in what looked like a tribal print, a velvet blazer and animal print pumps.

title: Market Ready
description: Q. How can I dress up the foyer to make the best

title: Stained Glass, From Churches to Malls
description: Brian Clarke, 59, a stained-glass artist, will present more than 50 works in Between Extremities, a show that opens Thursday at one of the Pace galleries in Chelsea. Mr. Clarkes glass can be found in chapels, mosques and synagogues, but also in corporate headquarters and shopping centers. He has collaborated with architects including Renzo Piano, Zaha Hadid and Norman Foster. Born in the north of England to a coal miner father and a mother who worked in a cotton mill, he lives in London.

title: In Education, China Takes the Lead
description: China has invested heavily in a huge expansion of higher education.

title: Sit, Inhale, Whatever
description: If you have been searching for a one-of-a-kind piece for home or garden, you might be interested in Mary Janes High Chair ($10,000). Originally designed by the Princeton, N.J., artist Peter Stefferson for a licensed California marijuana dispensary, it is, Mr. Stefferson says, a homage to the positive attributes of an old and respected American Indian medical and recreational herb. So what happened to the original client?

title: Illumination, Inspired by Catastrophe
description: Giulio Cappellini, the Italian design entrepreneur who helped start the careers of such luminaries as Jasper Morrison, Tom Dixon and Marcel Wanders, has made another find: a young Swedish designer, Johan Lindsten, whom Mr. Cappellini discovered at the Salone Satellite, a showplace of young talents that is part of the International Furniture Fair in Milan. Their first collaboration is a lamp by Mr. Lindsten made of thin-walled, handblown colored glass. Called Meltdown, the lamp is Mr. Lindstens comment on the nuclear catastrophe at Fukushima, Japan. Instead of being suspended within the fixture, the light bulb rests against the bottom of the glass and looks ready to dissolve.

title: Art Imitates Indianapolis
description: Indianapolis Museum of Art curators have filled a nearby hotel with contemporary art that resonates with and sometimes mocks the region. At theAlexander Hotel, designed by Gensler, which opens Monday, windows here and there are covered with the artist Kim Becks vinyl silhouettes of local weeds (above). The sculptor Sonya Clark built a portrait of the Indianapolis hair-care tycoon Madam C. J. Walker out of 3,840 combs (top right). Paul Villinskis wall-mounted installation is made from vinyl records by musicians including the Gary, Ind., native Michael Jackson (top left). And Mark Foxs stream-of-consciousness text, cut from reflective stainless steel, notes that John Dillinger is buried about seven and a half miles from the Alexander, and that hotel rooms are zones of mirrors and copulation.

title: Tips From a Backyard on a Dirt Road
description: Margaret Roach, the garden writer and blogger who lived out the fantasy of not only making it to the top (editorial director of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia), but also chucking it for an old house in upstate New York, wrote about her first adventures with snakes and solitude in And I Shall Have Some Peace There: Trading in the Fast Lane for My Own Dirt Road. Now, in The Backyard Parables: Lessons on Gardening, and Life (Grand Central Publishing, $26), she really digs in. Along with observations of wind, caterpillars and bacteria  Mycobacterium vaccae can elevate the mood and stimulate immune cells  she offers details like shoveling alone, through thigh-high snow, in the dark of night, to hammer a hole in the ice of a frog pond so the frogs didnt suffocate. For fans who crave her gardening advice, dont worry. She tells how to protect banana plants in winter, and put up a deer fence, too.

title: I Went After Guns. Obama Can, Too.
description: SYDNEY, Australia

title: Digital Notes: Measuring Growth in Dollars and Page Views
description: The popularity of satellite and Internet radio is starting to lead to larger royalty checks for musicians.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Walmarts Phone Asterisk and Tech Money Stories
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Sales at Angela Adams, Love Adorned and Others
description: In-stock wool rugs are 20 percent off at Angela Adams, through Monday; (800) 255-9454, angelaadams.com.

title: Megabytes From the Motor Show: The Final Chapter?
description: Manufacturers were still giving out flash drives containing press materials at the 2013 Detroit auto show, but not as many as at past shows. More companies are switching to either paper releases or just telling reporters to go to their media sites for the information. This just builds ones appreciation for the drives that are handed out.

title: Russian Gangster Fatally Shot on Downtown Moscow Street
description: MOSCOW  Not much is known about the underworld kingpin known as Grandpa Hassan, except that somebody really wanted him dead.

title: Being Bin Laden
description: LONDON

title: Obama Tells Senate That Its Time to Confirm A.T.F. Director
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama indicated on Wednesday that along with asking Congress to pass measures like an assault weapons ban, he would be increasing pressure on lawmakers to do something they have refused to do for the past six years: confirm a permanent director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.

title: AT&T Allows FaceTime for Limited Data Users. What About Unlimited?
description: AT&T said on Wednesday that it would allow more of its iPhone customers to use Apples videoconferencing app, FaceTime, over its cellular network. But customers with unlimited data plans are still left out.

title: Who Says You Can Kill Americans, Mr. President?
description: WASHINGTON

title: New Coach to Give Bayern Munich a Hint of Barcelona
description: Pep Guardiola, the worlds most sought-after soccer coach, will take over as  head coach of the German powerhouse Bayern Munich at the conclusion of the season.

title: Pakistan Says Preacher and Crowd at Risk
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two days after a charismatic preacher swept into the capital surrounded by thousands of supporters, Pakistans government responded by rejecting his political agenda and hinting that an operation to dislodge him was imminent.

title: Candidates Stepmother Declines to Endorse Him for Public Advocate
description: Noah E. Gotbaum, a son of the labor leader Victor Gotbaum, can count on his family name for a boost as he runs this year for the office of New York City public advocate.

title: Democrats in Albany Propose Giving Illegal Immigrants Access to Aid for College
description: Responding to more than two years of lobbying by immigrants advocates, the Democratic majority in the New York State Assembly threw its support on Wednesday behind a comprehensive bill that would make state financial aid available to illegal immigrants at colleges and universities.

title: For Space Station, a Pod That Folds Like a Shirt and Inflates Like a Balloon
description: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  An inflatable space pod to be attached to the International Space Station in a couple of years will be like no other piece of the station.

title: U.S. Military Stops Sending Detainees to Some Afghan Prisons on Rights Fears
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American military has suspended the transfer of detainees to some Afghan prisons out of concern over continuing human rights abuses and torture, the NATO-led International Security Assistance Force said Wednesday in response to questions about the subject.

title: The Point of Lance
description: Right now youre probably asking yourself: What can the Lance Armstrong scandal teach us as a nation?

title: Taking Aim
description: This week the president aimed high in the gun debate, and the National Rifle Association aimed low, despicably low.

title: A Talk With Ben Affleck and Tony Mendez
description: Melena Ryzik talks to Ben Affleck and the real life inspiration for his character in Argo, Tony Mendez.

title: Soldier, Husband, Father, Lost in War
Syrian North Sees Increase in Violence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At least two dozen people, many of them Syrian government soldiers, died Wednesday when three powerful car bombs exploded in Idlib, according to the opposition, and the government announced it was carrying out new operations in and around Idlib and Aleppo.

title: Vincent Sombrotto, Who Led Postal Strike, Dies at 89
description: Vincent Sombrotto, who as a rank-and-file letter carrier led a wildcat strike that shut down post offices across the country in 1970, prompting President Richard M. Nixon to call out the National Guard, and who went on to lead one of the nations most powerful postal workers unions for 24 years, died on Jan. 10 at a hospital near his home in Port Washington, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Your [Choose Your Expletive] Ad Here
description: WORDS that once would have had mouths on Madison Avenue washed out with soap are becoming common enough in advertisements that one could wonder if the familiar Wendys slogan from 1984, were it being introduced today, might be brought out as Wheres the [choose your expletive] beef?

title: Former Counsel to Paterson Is Fined on an Ethics Law Violation
description: A lawyer who served as chief counsel for Gov. David A. Paterson has paid a $3,500 fine for violating a state law limiting the interactions between former employees of the governors office and the state government.

title: What to Ask After Years of Denials
description: Standing atop the podium at the 2005 Tour de France, Lance Armstrong addressed the crowd after he won a record seventh Tour, looking into the sea of cycling fans gathered along the Champs-lyses in Paris and publicly challenging those who had suspected he had doped to win.

title: Lessons From Guns and a Goose
description: When I travel abroad and talk to foreigners about the American passion for guns, people sometimes express a conclusion that horrifies me: in America, life is cheap.

title: Prime Minister Ready to Stake Britains European Role on a Referendum
description: LONDON  Now, it is David Camerons turn.

title: Big Donors Dominate Cuomos Fund-Raising, Analysis Finds

title: An Added Mission for Arizona Sheriffs Immigration Posse: School Patrols

Four years ago, he packed his guns and his urge to give back to the community and joined Sheriff Joe Arpaios volunteer posse, a group best known for its supporting role in the sheriffs immigration raids.

title: Another Face-Off for Nuclear-Armed Rivals
description: One of the likeliest flash points for a nuclear war is the enduring conflict between India and Pakistan, which have scores of nuclear weapons. In recent weeks, several fatal incidents across the disputed Kashmir border have stoked new fears that the firing of bullets could escalate into something even worse.

title: As Israeli Vote Nears, Arab Apathy Is a Concern
description: BAKA AL-GHARBIYA, Israel  There are two distinct strains of voter apathy here in what is known as the Triangle, home to many of Israels 1.5 million Arab citizens.

title: U.S. Sees Hazy Threat From Mali Militants
description: WASHINGTON  As Islamic militants methodically carved out a base in the desert of northern Mali over the past year, officials in Washington, Paris and African capitals struggling with military plans to drive the Islamists out of the country agreed onone principle: African troops, not European or American soldiers, would fight the battle of Mali.

title: Report Details Missteps in Trading at JPMorgan
description: Long seen as one of the most careful banks on Wall Street, JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday drew back a curtain on a rare breakdown, showing traders acting on their own and concealing losses while managers seemingly turned a blind eye.

title: JPMorgans Board Uses a Pay Cut as a Message
description: Shortly after the markets closed on Tuesday afternoon, an emissary from JPMorgan Chases board of directors walked two flights down to the 48th-floor corner office of the banks chief executive, Jamie Dimon, to deliver a stark message. The board had voted to slash Mr. Dimons annual compensation for 2012 by half.

title: In Britain, Basketball Can Be a Tough Sell
description: LONDON  Our secondary school, a fairly average one in the rural English town of Yeovil, population 40,000, was, like the majority of others in the country, very much a hot spot for soccer as the 1990s unfolded. Soccer was what we played and talked about during morning breaks, at lunchtime and after classes.

title: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Jan. 17, 2013.

description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  When Terrell Suggs tore his right Achilles tendon over the off-season, his Baltimore Ravens teammates were concerned, and that might be putting it mildly. How would the defenses pass rush hold up? Suggs seemed almost irreplaceable.

description: SANYA, China  Zhang Xiaopings mother dropped out of school after sixth grade. Her father, one of 10 children, never attended.

title: Pakistan Criticizes Obamas Plan for Turning Over Military Command in Afghanistan
description: Pakistans foreign minister on Wednesday issued a biting critique of President Obamas plan to accelerate the handover of military command in Afghanistan to Afghan forces, declaring that the border with Pakistan has become less well managed and that the United States is leaving without determining whether you have accomplished your objectives.

title: Felony Charges for Officer Accused of False Arrest
description: A New York City police officer was charged with 10 felony counts of filing a false document in connection with what prosecutors said was an unwarranted arrest of a man in a Harlem housing project last year.

title: At Many Top Public Universities, Intercollegiate Sports Come at an Academic Price
description: Public colleges and universities that compete in N.C.A.A. Division I sports spend three to six times as much on each athlete as they do to educate each of their students, according to a new report by the Delta Cost Project at the American Institutes for Research.

title: Israel: U.S. Immigrant Convicted in Palestinian Deaths
description: A Jerusalem court on Wednesday convicted an American immigrant who lived in a West Bank settlement of killing two Palestinians in 1997. Known as the Jewish terrorist, Yaakov (Jack) Teitel was also convicted of other crimes, including bombings in 2008 that wounded a leftist Israeli professor and a teenage boy belonging to a community of Jews who believe in Jesus. Sentencing is planned for February.

title: About-Face as Slumping Hawks Crush Sizzling Nets
description: ATLANTA  The Nets seven-game winning streak came to a thudding end Wednesday night when they were run off the Philips Arena floor, 109-95, by an energetic Hawks team missing its best player.

title: Report Criticizes School Discipline Measures Used in Mississippi
description: Less than three months after the Justice Department sued Meridian, Miss., after finding that school students there were routinely arrested without probable cause, a report by a group of civil rights organizations says that overly harsh school disciplinary policies are common throughout the state.

description: Marc Trestman was smart enough for Bernie Kosar, Steve Young and Rich Gannon. He was valued enough by the nine N.F.L. teams that hired him as an assistant over nearly two decades. Trestman was seasoned enough, finally, as a head coach, to compile a 64-34 record and consecutive Grey Cup championships in five seasons with the Montreal Alouettes of the C.F.L.

title: Lottery Numbers

description: SANTA CLARA, Calif.  So there was Justin Smith, inside a tent on Wednesday, behind a lectern, clad in gray San Francisco 49ers sweats complete with the requisite lineman stains. His face hinted at neither worry nor concern. That whole thing about a partly torn triceps tendon?

title: Yuri M. Schmidt, Rights Lawyer in Russia, Dies at 75

title: Courtside Eavesdropping Does Not Flatter the Knicks
description: In a maneuver that owes more to Austin Powers than James Bond, the Knicks owner, James L. Dolan, may have tarnished his teams reputation, and that of his best player, with a stunt involving two microphones and a plan to surreptitiously record on-court comments by Carmelo Anthony. Unfortunately, the plan was carried out in the most conspicuous, ham-handed manner since the 1960s sitcom Get Smart featured spies hiding in trees.

title: Conrad Bain, Father on Diffrent Strokes, Dies at 89
description: Conrad Bain, an accomplished stage and film actor who was best known for a late-career role on television as the white adoptive father of two poor black boys on the long-running comedy Diffrent Strokes, died on Monday in Livermore, Calif. He was 89.

description: The New York Cosmos, whose forebears ignited a soccer boom four decades ago, said Wednesday that they hoped to build a stadium near Belmont Park Race Track in Nassau County, just over the border with New York City. The stadium would be part of a new shopping and entertainment district.

title: Torrential Rains Paralyze Indonesian Capital

title: A Conversation With: Sikkim Chief Minister Pawan Kumar Chamling
description: Tucked away in the Himalayas, Indias Sikkim state has averaged an annual growth of 12.6 percent over the last eight years. The state of 600,000 people is of strategic importance to India, surrounded by China, Nepal and Bhutan on three sides. The former monarchy of Sikkim joined the Indian federation of states in 1975 and has been the most peaceful among Indias strife-torn northeastern states.
