title: Another Hard Day of Trying to Stay Alive
description: Out on patrol with the Afghan National Army, not an American solider in sight.

title: Which Way Did the Taliban Go?
description: The village was abandoned. Streets deserted. Houses empty. Behind the central mosque rose a steep escarpment. Behind the escarpment mountains upon mountains. Up there  above the timberline, among the peaks  a white Taliban flag whipped in the wind. Several Afghan soldiers were admiring it when a stunted and contorted person emerged from an alley. Dressed in rags, he waved a hennaed fist at them and wailed. Tears streamed down his face. Most of the soldiers ignored him. Some laughed uncomfortably. A few jabbed their rifles at his chest and simulated shooting. The man carried on undeterred  reproaching them in strange tongues.

title: Pakistani Preacher Ends Protest in Government Deal
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, the preacher turned political activist who led thousands of his supporters to occupy the heart of the Pakistani capital, ended his protest on Thursday night after the government granted his party largely symbolic input into the countrys electoral process.

title: Jordan Says It Wont Accept New Refugees if Syria Falls
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the latest sign of the intense pressures Syrias war has placed on its neighbors, Jordans prime minister said Thursday that his country would not accept thousands of new refugees likely to flee Syria if President Bashar al-Assads government collapsed.

title: Part 4: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
description: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

title: A Delicate Mating Game of Partners for Mixed Doubles
description: MELBOURNE, Australia Shortly before 4 p.m. Wednesday, time was running out to find a partner with whom to saunter into the male-female competition unique to the Grand Slam events.

title: Keep Kelly Atop Police Department, New Yorkers Say in Poll
description: Whether Democrat or Republican, white or nonwhite, male or female, wealthy or not, New York City voters overwhelmingly like Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and would prefer that he remain in the job under the next mayor, a Quinnipiac University poll released on Thursday found.

title: Officials Say Checks Wont Be in the Mail
description: The jig is up.

title: France Sends Reinforcements to Confront Islamist Forces in Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali  French soldiers have battled Islamist militants in direct clashes on the ground in central Mali since just after landing last week, according to officials, and fighting continuedon Thursday as hundreds of French reinforcements arrived. The ground battles expanded the campaign against the militants, who have seized much of the nation, beyond the airstrikes used initially.

title: In Thailand, a Broader Definition of Insulting Royalty
description: BANGKOK  It has become almost routine in Thailand for judges to hand down jail sentences to those convicted of offending the countrys king. But an unusual ruling issued on Thursday appears to considerably broaden the interpretation of Thailands already restrictive lse-majest law.

title: How Good Does Karaoke Have to Be to Qualify as Art?
description: John Brophy, the mastermind of Americas greatest karaoke night, lives in a well-kept bungalow in a neighborhood of small homes in southeast Portland, Ore. When I visited on a weekday afternoon last spring, Brophy, then 36, wore a ringer T-shirt and dark jeans. His wrist was encircled by a half-dozen bracelets, and his dark hair swooped in front of his face. Like many Portlanders, hes in a band, called Gingerbread Patriots, although currently the band is on hiatus  the Shows section of the Gingerbread Patriots Web site is empty but for the words 2009 will bring shows shows and more shows!

title: What I Sang on My Epic Karaoke Odyssey
description: For this weekends magazine, I wrote about my epic six-day karaoke odyssey in Portland, Ore., hoping to figure out why this citys karaoke scene is so ridiculously vibrant. I visited karaoke nights at tiki bars, strip clubs, comedy clubs, honky-tonks and pizza places, interviewing K.J.s (karaoke jocks), fans, strippers and Portlands mayor. But I also, of course, sang. A lot.

title: Maybe There Is Such a Thing as Bad Publicity
description: In part because we are a social enterprise with a mission that most people support keeping waste out of landfills and incinerators TerraCycle has been blessed with a lot of good publicity. In fact, we talk about having what we call a negative-cost media department that in 2012 generated more than 4,500 articles around the world. Thats more than 12 articles per day! (You can see an example of this coverage here.) We call the department negative-cost because we have been able to produce marketing books, TV shows that earns us money while also promoting the company.

title: Louisville Slugger
description: The Pendennis Club in Louisville, Ky., is a big Georgian pile that might have appeared in the Thackeray novel it was named for, full of wealthy afternoon nappers and drawling black-tie gentry. In the early part of the last century, the clubs headwaiter was a black man named Henry Bain. His contribution to the world was at least as important as the newspapers and racehorses, banks and bridges sired by the white club members he served. Bain invented a sauce.

title: Jan. 17 Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web. On Thursday, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. called on the nations mayors to support the White House gun measures, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appointed a task force to look beyond gun control at mental illness, addiction and other underlying causes of gun violence

title: Conference Title Game Probabilities, and the Kaepernick Effect
description: The second-year quarterback Colin Kaepernick has certainly fulfilled the expectations of 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh, who elected to start him over the veteran Alex Smith midway through the season. Kaepernick has proved to be a definite upgrade, bringing two new dimensions to the 49ers offense: his ability to run and his ability to throw deep. Its very difficult to assess the value of a player like Kaepernick, but lets try anyway.

title: How We Come Up With Our Big, Important Chart
description: The Big, Important Chart on The One-Page Magazine allows me to fulfill a pretty basic impulse: measure and rate things. Being a comedian in real life, I especially appreciate the opportunity to arbitrarily assign mathematical meaning to material that does not necessarily warrant it, like the length of Gerard Butlers beard or the heroism of Adam Wests Batman versus Christian Bales.

title: The Countersettlement
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Last Friday 200 Palestinians made their way to the top of the hill east of Al Zaim, a village near Jerusalem, in a zone known as E1, which the Israeli government has designated for Israeli settlements. Setting up 20 tents amid boulders and balding patches of grass, they announced the establishment of the village of Bab al-Shams (Gate of the Sun, in Arabic) by order of the people, without permission from the occupation, or any other body.

title: All Your Base Are Belong To Us: What Is the Question?
description: OK, we are indeed, as Steve Randy Waldman says, all dorks, and so are you if you are reading this. Whats more, were inarticulate dorks, or so it seems.

title: A Mending Spain Finds Willing Bond Buyers
description: MADRID  January is turning out to be a bumper month for Spain and some of the euro zone economies most in need of debt financing, with governments and companies flooding the market with bonds that have sold at significantly lower interest rates than just a few months ago.

title: Daily Report: Europe Weighs Requiring Firms to Disclose Data Breaches
description: To combat a rise in cybercrime, the European Commission is considering a plan to require companies that store data on the Internet  like Microsoft, Apple, Google and I.B.M.  to report the loss or theft of personal information in the 27-nation bloc or risk sanctions and fines, Kevin J. OBrien reports Thursday in The International Herald Tribune and The New York Times.

title: On the Non-equivalence of Greenhouse Gases and Entitlement Spending
description: One fairly common trope in budget discussions  Im pretty sure Ive done it myself, somewhere along the line  is to compare attitudes toward fiscal issues and those toward environmental issues. The usual version, which I must have used, is to compare attitudes toward the long run: pointing out how strange it is that many people profess to be deeply concerned about the state of the Social Security trust fund in the year 2037, while being apparently indifferent to the state of the climate around the same time, which is all too likely to involve things like a permanent drought in the southwest and so on.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Levity Gets a Screening at Sundance, and Questions for Armstrong
description: The Sundance Film Festival, which gets under way Thursday in Park City, Utah, has long had a reputation for showcasing dark, sobering films. Now the festival is getting a face-lift, of sorts, Brooks Barnes writes in The Times. The event has nearly tripled the number of comedies appearing in its top three categories, a lineup that should leaven the mood and bring it line with the festive, glitzy atmosphere that pervades the ski town when the festival is in session.

The bank reported a widely expected 63 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit after settling claims over its mortgage business. The earnings of $732 million amounted to 3 cents a share, narrowly beating estimates of 2 cents a share, based on analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters. The banks quarterly revenue was down about 25 percent, to $18.7 billion. The conference call is scheduled for 8:30 a.m.

description: Takuro Kuwatas gem-studded vessels, in vivid Pop Art reds and blues, appear far removed from traditional Japanese tea ceremony ware. Similarly, the artists sherbet-hued bowls  malleable-looking structures with cracked, milk-white armors of glaze  could only be surreal, even psychedelic renderings of tea ceremony ceramics.

title: Ken Salazars Legacy
description: The Obama administration will soon lose three of its most public-spirited and progressive players on environmental policy. Lisa Jackson made great strides on climate and clean air issues as head of the Environmental Protection Agency. Jane Lubchenco worked tirelessly and creatively to resist the decline in threatened fish populations as boss of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Both announced their wish to return to private life last month. The latest departure is Ken Salazar, who said Wednesday that he will leave his post as interior secretary in a few weeks.

title: The Cleric in the Container
description: LONDON  Between 25,000 and 50,000 people marched on Islamabad this week to demand the resignation of the government and electoral reforms. At the head of the movement is Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a cleric who recently returned to Pakistan from Canada.

description: This weeks Poetry Pairing matches Pentatina for Five Vowels, a poem by Campbell McGrath with an article, Why You Wont Be the Person You Expect to Be by John Tierney, and the related video, above.

title: Fighting for Light Amid Urban Noir
description: After sundown the familiar, big, beautiful, soul-dirty town in Broken City looks as if it were built from shattered glass. Thats especially true from the air, where the director, Allen Hughes, likes to take a gods-eye measure of whats below, the camera gliding over the glittering lights and shadows as black as the abyss. This is a place so ominous that the sun never seems to shine, leaving the gray streets and people washed in an icy blue light. One glance and its obvious that this is New York, though its a city Mr. Hughes has painted a darker shade of noir.

title: Difficult Choices on Debt if the U.S. Hits the Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON  By mid-February or early March, the United States could face an unprecedented default unless it raises its debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said this week.

title: Outsize Personality Joins, and Jostles, Mayors Race
description: To pump himself up for tense negotiations with the City Council, Joseph J. Lhota listened to the soaring theme song to the film Top Gun, and, afterward, relaxed to the soothing tones of Gregorian chants.

title: Lying Becomes an Official Sport
description: Lets just go ahead and declare this the national day of lying in sports. We have such a spectacular range of them on display, the world of sports lies is starting to look like the cereal aisle at a grocery store. Its overwhelming. It was enough that we were going to be treated Thursday night to the latest in the Lance Armstrong lie fest  the Oprah talk-show confession  but then we got Chip Kellys pivot from Im staying at Oregon to the Eagles money smells so good. And those are only the hors doeuvres before you hit the all-you-can-eat buffet of lies that is the story of Notre Dame linebacker Manti Teos fabricated dead girlfriend.

title: Louis Vuitton: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Gun Control and Suicide
description: If youre looking for a reason to be skeptical that the gun control proposals President Obama unveiled yesterday would actually have an impact on violent crime, look no further than the historical examples invoked by gun control advocates praising the White Houses effort:

title: Excerpt: 'Newsreaders'
description: The newsmagazine parody, a spin-off of "Childrens Hospital," begins Jan. 17 on Adult Swim.

title: Reporting the News for Adult Swim
description: WHENEVER Childrens Hospital, the kinetically goofy medical show spoof on Adult Swim, wants to push its satire even further into the meta-sphere, it brings in Louis La Fonda. Hes the inept fake newsman, played by the comic actor Mather Zickel, who reports on the shows shenanigans for the parody-within-a-parody 20/20 knockoff, Newsreaders.

title: Louis Vuitton
description: Mens fall 2013 collections in Paris.

title: Flu Season Strikes Again ... and Again
description: The flu comes every year and this years strain has hit early and hard. The Timess Donald G. McNeil Jr. says plenty of people are sick, but dont just blame influenza.

title: Ben Affleck, Resurgent Yet Again
description: Early on, Argo was seen as a front-runner for awards this season: in August it was shown in a sneak preview at the Telluride Film Festival, where The Kings Speech started its journey to best picture, and in September it received a standing ovation at the Toronto International Film Festival, the same response that Slumdog Millionaire, another best picture winner, received. But as late arrivals like Lincoln, Les Misrables and Zero Dark Thirty picked up steam, Argo began to seem like an underdog, a status more or less solidified when the film received seven Oscar nominations but not one for its director, Ben Affleck, a nod usually necessary for a best-picture win.

title: Jared Diamond: By the Book
description: The author of The World Until Yesterday says that if he had to recommend one book of geography to children, he would suggest his own Guns, Germs, and Steel.

title: The Fallout of a Chance Medical Finding
description: An incidental finding  I was convinced of it. My patient had undergone a CT scan of the abdomen at another hospital because of stomach pains and incidentally noted was a 2-centimeter mass in her adrenal gland. She brought in the report for me to see, nervous that she might have cancer.

title: Why Am I Getting Mellower?
description: You are a member in good standing of an elite group dedicated to the proposition that the pursuit of happiness is for suckers. Baby Boomers: The Gloomiest Generation, is how the Pew Research Center put it a few years ago after conducting a survey.

title: Drinking Like a Poet
description: One chilly evening more than a decade ago, my Glasgow-born-and-bred friend Angus Robertson greeted me at his Brooklyn Heights doorway in his kilt and sporran and welcomed me to my first Burns supper, the Scottish celebration on Jan. 25 that honors the poet Robert Burns. About 20 of us gathered around the haggis (nothing to be afraid of, basically a big mealy sausage), neeps and tatties (thats turnips and potatoes) and whisky-fortified gravy. Then the time arrived for dessert, poetry, song and whisky. Lots of Scotch whisky, selected with care by our hosts.

title: The Road to Bamian
description: For the people of Bamian, the roads, paved for the first time in the Afghan provinces history, have brought both opportunity and peril.

title: Mali's Challenge for Washington
description: TimesCast: Policy makers weigh options and appetite for involvement. | Ben Affleck on his inspiration for Argo. | Responding to a virulent flu season.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 17
Wheelies: The Booming Business Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: SurveyMonkey Raises Nearly $800 Million While Staying Private
description: SurveyMonkeys fund-raising success is showing that the business of Internet surveys is worth a lot of money.

title: An Inquiry Into Discolored Snow
description: As I wrote last Friday, after a decade of legal battles, Arizona Snowbowl recently became the worlds first ski area \to make snow totally out of wastewater, piped directly from the sewage treatment plant in neighboring Flagstaff. That the snow emerging from the snow guns was streaked with a yellow hue raised eyebrows and stirred environmental and health concerns.

title: U.S. Weighing Policy Options in Mali
description: The Times's Mark Mazzetti talks about the challenges facing Washington in crafting a strategy for dealing with Islamist militants in Mali.

title: Seth MacFarlane on Hosting: It Could Be a Disaster. Who Knows?
description: Tina Fey and Amy Poehler pulled in high ratings and good reactions for their debut as hosts of the Golden Globes, which means that Seth MacFarlane, neophyte host of the Oscars, may be sweating.

title: Monument to a City
description: My wife and I began to unconsciously prepare ourselves for living in Washington, D.C., long before we actually moved to the city. Over the course of three years and half a dozen trips from our apartment in Paris to my parents home deep in the Virginia suburbs, we imagined hypothetical versions of our life there. We wandered through Georgetown and pictured ourselves living in a colonial-style mansion on a cobblestone road. We went out to eat in Columbia Heights and imagined life on a not-too-quiet street near our favorite strip of restaurants and bars.

title: Young People Paying Off Card Debt More Slowly
description: Younger Americans not only borrow heavily on their credit cards, but they repay the debt at slower rates than previous generations, new research from Ohio State University finds.

title: Philadelphia Vandalism of Quaker Building Is Seen by Some as Union Intimidation
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was several weeks ago when vandals struck the building site, setting fire to a crane, cutting deep gashes in steel columns and loosening the bolts that anchored them. The episode resulted in about $500,000 in damage and was, the authorities believe, apparently an attempt to halt the construction of a Quaker meeting house.

title: Memories of a Kid on a Hot Tin Roof
description: A NEW Broadway production of Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,like the one scheduled to open on Jan. 17, will always ring with a certain importance in the theater world, but for me it brings on an additional spell of nostalgia. In 1974, at 10 years old, I landed a thrill of a summer job as one of the kids in Cat  those no-neck monsters as Tennessee Williams so memorably called them. My parents had responded to an ad for open auditions at the American Shakespeare Theaterin Stratford, Conn. I was offered the role, the production turned out to be a hit, and we transferred to New York the following fall.

title: Ratings for American Idol Premiere Are Down Again
description: It looks like those who predicted American Idol would be down another 20 percent this year  despite Foxs best efforts to pump it up with new judges like Mariah Carey and Nicky Minaj  could get jobs posting betting lines in Las Vegas.

title: Solving Bus Strikes Impact on Special Needs Students Isnt Simple
description: New York Citys bus strike is disproportionately affecting one of its most vulnerable populations: children with special needs, whose symptoms or travel limitations can make it extremely challenging for their parents to get them to school using other methods of transportation. Marie Myung-Ok Lee, who has written for about the challenges and joys of raising a child with developmental disabilities, including autism, in New York City, reminded me yesterday that children like her son depend on continuity and predictability in ways that children without his symptoms do not. And many children in the citys special education programs present particular challenges for bus drivers and their aides. They may be prone to violent tantrums, or need physical help. Its a different job, and a different relationship, than the phrase bus driver immediately suggests.

title: A Gentle Giant of a Catfish Fades From Sight
description: The captain leaned heavily into his pole, nudging the boats nose off the sandy bank. As the boat swung into the swift current of the Mekong, he scrambled back behind the wheel, the engine roared, and we resumed our downstream journey toward Luang Prabang, Laos.

title: Arizona Congresswoman Hires Immigrant Activist After She Details Raid
description: PHOENIX  Erika Andiola, the young immigrant activist who prompted outrage on social media last week after her messages and tearful video chronicled the arrests of her mother and brother during an immigration raid here, is the new outreach director for Representative Kyrsten Sinema, the freshman congresswoman known for her staunch opposition to Arizonas stance on illegal immigration.

title: From Sketch to Stage: The House of von Macram'
description: A look at Tristan Rainess costume design for the new pop musical at the Bushwick Starr.

title: Armstrong Stripped of 2000 Olympic Medal
description: On the eve of Lance Armstrongs public admission that he used performance-enhancing drugs during his cycling career, he was stripped of yet another prize: his bronze medal from the 2000 Sydney Olympics.

title: Officials Seek Energy Drink Information
description: Three Democratic lawmakers sent letters to 14 marketers of highly caffeinated energy drinks on Thursday requesting information about the products ingredients and any company studies showing their risks and benefits to children and young people.

title: Double Duty Tests Serena Williamss Ankle, And it Holds Up
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  There may never have been so much doubt about how a player would respond after a 6-0, 6-0 victory.

title: Museum of Arts and Design Director Announces Departure
description: After 16 years as the director of the Museum of Arts and Design, Holly Hotchner, 61, has announced that she will step down from her position at the end of April.

title: The Long Wait
description: The filmmaker Jason DaSilva reveals the challenges for the disabled in navigating New York Citys public transportation system.

title: Orbitz Videos Hope Lookers Become Bookers
description: The travel booking site Orbitz is looking to inspire you with more than good deals.

title: No Comment Necessary: Conspiracy Nation
description: Via Salon

title: Russian Comforts on Antarctic Ice
description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

title: Gun Violence Is a Topic of Discussion at Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Gun is a short film about a man who buys a handgun for protection and becomes obsessed with the newfound sense of power it gives him. Valentine Road, a documentary, looks at a school shooting in California. Blue Caprice was inspired by the 2002 Beltway sniper attacks.

title: MoMA Names Winner of 14th Young Architects Program
description: Starting in late June, the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, will feature a tall steel frame that is balanced in place with large fabric containers filled with water. The project was designed by Caroline ODonnell of Ithaca, N.Y., whose firm, CODA, has been selected as the winner of the annual Young Architects Program in New York.

title: The Long Wait
description: I love New York. When I was younger, the city was my playground. You could find me on any given weekend catching brunch with a friend at a cafe, going to an East Village restaurant for dinner and then hopping the subway to a nightclub in Chelsea. But at age 25, nine years ago, I was told I had multiple sclerosis, and I saw my freedoms slowly vanish. I grew up quickly, learning to plan daily activities with precise schedules and strategies for getting from one place to another, while trying to maintain some semblance of the life Id enjoyed. Its not M.S. that exhausts me, its the barriers that prevent me from conducting my daily activities. Public-transportation challenges have turned my playground into a sand pit.

title: Dining, Discs and More in Durham, N.C.
description: Take a bite of this towns motor-to-mortar movement and play a round of golf in the woods on a trip around this Southern city.

title: 36 Hours in Durham, N.C.
description: THE tobacco and textile industries left their imprint on Durham long ago, but now the historic brick mills and repurposed factories form the backdrop of North Carolinas re-energized Bull City. Recently, artist studios and upstart galleries have multiplied in the flourishing downtown area, where new bakeries, pizzerias, tapas bars and food trucks  and trailers and buses and even the odd tricycle  seem to surface at every turn. Since Big Tobacco is dead, consider this cool mix of culture and food the new Durham blend.

title: 3 Tips for Finding Rental Car Deals
description: WITH airfares and hotel rates rising last year, its some consolation that prices for rental cars actually decreased on average, and are expected to remain about the same in 2013.

title: Restaurant Report: The Grove in Toronto
description: English cuisine has taken its hits, many of them, at least in recent years, unjustifiably. Plenty of chefs are doing exciting and innovative things in kitchens across Britain. But beyond the generic fish-and-chips gastro pub, English cuisine has not caught on in other countries.

title: The Story of Hip-Hop
description: The rap superstar Jay-Z performed eight concerts in September to open the Barclays Center in Brooklyn. It was a crowning moment both for the borough and for this native son, born Shawn Carter, who grew up in the Marcy Houses just up the street in Bedford-Stuyvesant.

title: Winfreys Channel Is Set to Break Through
description: Last Tuesday afternoon, Oprah Winfrey called the co-presidents of her cable channel OWN with some jump-on-the-couch-with-joy news. Lance wants to talk, she said, referring to Lance Armstrong, whom she had been courting for a confessional interview about his long-denied use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Pauline Phillips, Flinty Adviser to Millions as Dear Abby, Dies at 94
description: Dear Abby: My wife sleeps in the raw. Then she showers, brushes her teeth and fixes our breakfast  still in the buff. Were newlyweds and there are just the two of us, so I suppose theres really nothing wrong with it. What do you think?  Ed

title: Facebook App Adds Free Voice Calls. Will Anyone Care?
description: Facebook doesnt just want you to poke, message and stalk your friends. Now it wants you to actually talk to them.

title: U.S. Calls for Cooler Heads in Dispute Over Asian Islands
description: TOKYO  A top American diplomat called Thursday for cooler heads to prevail in an emotional quarrel over disputed islands that has raised tensions in Asia, and he urged the leaders of China and Japan to begin private consultations to avoid a potentially dangerous escalation.

title: Wedding Q. and A.
description: A Guest List Thats About Who You Know, and Dont Know

title: Preoccupying My Mind With Summer Plans as Colleges Decide My Fate
description: With the college application process now complete on my end, I have all the time in the world to focus on my class 12 board examinations.

title: 7-Year-Old Takes Gun to School
description: A handgun was found in the backpack of a 7-year-old student at a public elementary school in Queens on Thursday morning, New York City officials said, leading to a tense few hours as the school was placed on lockdown while the police made sure there was no danger.

title: Rendering a City With a Blowtorch
description: Something mythic  a sight to inspire fear and wonder  tears its way into existence toward the end of Minsk, 2011, the beautiful and brutal performance piece from the Belarus Free Theater. Like many of the richest moments in theater, this one involves very simple elements: black ink, a long roll of brown paper and a naked woman.

title: Life, Interrupted: Brotherly Love
description: There are a lot of things about having cancer in your 20s that feel absurd. One of those instances was when I found myself calling my brother Adam on Skype while he was studying abroad in Argentina to tell him that I had just been diagnosed with leukemia and that  no pressure  he was my only hope for a cure.

title: Reporting in The Times on Football Stars Nonexistent Girlfriend Was Glancing, but Still Troubling
description: The truly strange  and still unfolding  tale of the Notre Dame football star and his nonexistent dead girlfriend has lessons for journalists, including those at The Times.

title: Tanoshi
description: Inside the omakase surprise of a sushi restaurant on the Upper East Side.

title: Car-Seat Installation in the Real World: Harder Than It Looks
description: Wheres the real-world video of car-seat installation?

title: Web Hunt for DNA Sequences Leaves Privacy Compromised
description: The genetic data posted online seemed perfectly anonymous  strings of billions of DNA letters from more than 1,000 people. But all it took was some clever sleuthing on the Web for a genetics researcher to identify five people he randomly selected from the study group. Not only that, he found their entire families, even though the relatives had no part in the study  identifying nearly 50 people.

title: Sushi That Delights in the Details
description: DONT WAIT TOO LONG to eat, the waiter half-whispered, bending slightly so the other diners wouldnt hear. The seaweed will lose its crispness.

title: Photos of The Moment | 3.1 Phillip Lim
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: A Simpler Form for Home Office Deductions
description: If you work at a home-based business, the Internal Revenue Service has some (potentially) good news: Its going to offer a simpler option for taking a tax deduction for home offices.

title: The Appetite Workout
description: Every January, many people start working out, hoping to lose weight. But as studies attest, exercise often produces little or no weight loss  and even weight gain  and resolutions are soon abandoned. But new science suggests that if you stick with the right kind of exercise, you may change how your body interacts with food. Its more than a matter of burning calories; exercise also affects hormones.

title: Channel Surfing: Faking It With Newsreaders
description: In the narrow programming niche of 15-minute late-night television comedies, there is a handful of auteurs: Seth Green (Robot Chicken), Jon Glaser (Delocated) and Rob Corddry (Childrens Hospital). Their faces pop up before midnight  Mr. Corddry on Ben and Kate, Mr. Glaser on Parks and Recreation, Mr. Green, reunited with his Buffy the Vampire Slayer co-star Alyson Hannigan, on a recent episode of How I Met Your Mother  but in the wee hours theyre nobodys guest star.

title: New York City Elections Are Becoming Ever More Costly
description: Its often been said that democracy can be messy. In New York City, its also increasingly expensive, especially the way the Board of Elections operates.

title: Quirks of the Game: For Coaches, a Tough Road Back to Super Bowl
description: First, Robert Griffin IIIs knee buckled and took the Washington Redskins season down with it, then Peyton Manning took a knee and down went the Denver Broncos season. Both Mike Shanahan and John Fox are being questioned for their coaching decisions, but these were more than typical playoff losses  both men lost out on a chance to make history.

title: Dells Ups and Downs With Options
description: It was an amazing American success story, in which a college student in his dorm room created what became one of the largest computer companies in the world. In the 1990s, its share price tripled in each of three consecutive years. But after the bubble burst, it resorted to accounting fraud to persuade investors it was doing better than it really was.

title: Three Windows 8 Features Worth Celebrating
description: You already know my overall opinion of Windows 8: that its two very good operating systems  one for touch screens, one for mouse and keyboard  idiotically superimposed on each other. You wind up with duplicate everything: two Web browsers, two help systems, two search features, two control panels (actually three, but never mind). Its very confusing.

title: No Deal on Teacher Evaluations; City Risks Losing $450 Million
description: The Bloomberg administration and New York Citys teachers union said Thursday that they had failed to reach a deal on a new system for evaluating 75,000 public school teachers, putting the city into immediate danger of losing out on up to $450 million in state and federal money and raising the possibility of cuts to staff and programs.

title: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Robson Does the Dirty Work in Beating Kvitova
description: Laura Robson of Great Britain prevailed over Petra Kvitova of the Czech Republic in an error-filled match at the Australia Open Friday that was nonetheless dramatic. In a match pitting two powerful lefthanders, each seeking to take control of the point with big first-strike tennis, Robson made the necessary adjustments to will her way to a stunning upset, 2-6, 6-3, 11-9, over Kvitova, the No. 8 seed and the 2011 Wimbledon champion.

title: Dries Van Noten
description: Mens fall 2013 collections in Paris.

title: Lance Armstrongs Other Career: Auto Pitchman
description: On a logistical level, the Tour de France is as much a chaotic auto rally as it is about the cyclists. Hundreds of cars carrying team officials, doctors, mechanics, reporters and V.I.P.s constantly jostle for position in front of and behind the riders while dozens of motorbikes flit in between to add to the general noise and confusion.

title: Few Silver Linings in Gloomy Bank Reports
description: Bank of America and Citigroup are giving investors nothing but reasons to fret.

title: Livestrong and the Perils of Corporate Sponsorships
description: On Tuesday, Sporting Kansas City announced it had severed its sponsorship agreement with Livestrong, the cancer charity founded by the disgraced cyclist Lance Armstrong. The announcement came two days before Armstrong was to confess on television to doping during his career, which included seven Tour de France titles.

title: A Smattering of Food Links
description: Potentially big: A superior court in Hyde County, N.C., ruled that the state has authority to require Rose Acre Farms, a facility housing nearly four million egg-laying hens, to be regulated under the federal Clean Water Act because of pollutants released from ventilation fans in the henhouses. Unprecedented. The F.D.A. proposed two sweeping rules aimed at preventing the contamination of produce and processed foods, taking a long-awaited step toward codifying the food safety law that Congress passed two years ago. And New Mexico lawmakers have introduced legislation that calls for the mandatory labeling of G.M.O.s within the state. Washington State joins the state, along with a half-dozen others.

title: What Was Dear Abbys Most Helpful Advice?
description: Pauline Phillips, who was better known for nearly 60 years as Abigail Van Buren, the author of the syndicated column Dear Abby, died Wednesday in Minneapolis at 94, her syndicate said in a statement.

title: Look of The Moment | Marion Cotillard
description: The Look: Mad for Plaid. A dress with a trompe loeil tartanesque effect in sequins is made even prettier with pastel rose appliqus.

title: At Republican Retreat, Ryan Urges Unity on Fiscal Issues
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  As House Republicans hunkered down here for a two-day retreat to discuss the future of their conference, Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin warned members that they had to recognize the realities of the divided government that we have and urged members to unite behind leadership on the coming fiscal debates.

title: The Barbarous Years
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rs Have It
description: To the Editor:

title: Cats
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith Vieira Said to Be in Talks for Daytime Show
description: Meredith Vieira, the former co-host of NBCs Today show, is in talks with another division of NBCUniversal about hosting a syndicated talk show.

title: News and News Analysis': Navigating Fact and Opinion in The Times
description: Overview | Why is it important to be critical consumers of news media? How do we discern fact from opinion in The New York Times, and in other news reports? In this lesson, students will become familiar with the layout of the NYTimes.com home page and learn how news and opinion articles are labeled and organized for clarity. Then students will carefully consider the difference between fact and opinion and create guiding questions to help discern between the two when reading a news or opinion piece from any news source. Finally, they will use their guiding questions to compare two pieces on the same news event, separating opinion from fact on the sentence level.

title: Digital Notes: Amazon Enters Apples Phones to Compete on Music Downloads
description: Amazon has stepped up its competition against iTunes with a version of its MP3 store for Apples iPhones and iPod Touch devices.

title: Rosa Parks Statue to Be Added to the Capitol
description: Rosa Parks, the civil rights leader, will become the first African-American woman to have her likeness depicted in the Capitols Statuary Hall when a statue of her is installed later this year, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said in an interview Thursday.

title: Drawing Upon Diverse Interviews
description: One of the first projects done in the United States by the French-born, British-raised artist Alexandre Singh was a sprawling, delirious collaboration with Jonah Freeman and Justin Lowe titled Hello Meth Lab in the Sun, installed at the Ballroom in Marfa, Tex., in 2008. (Mr. Freeman and Mr. Lowe went on to show a similar version in New York.) It was a virtuosic display  a warren of varied spaces that included a motel check-in counter, a hippie hide-out and an abandoned meth lab  that was perfectly suited to that decadent art-world moment and that piggybacked on the extreme environments of artists like Mike Nelson, Christoph Bchel and Gregor Schneider.

title: A Beat Poets Colorful Crew, in Black and White
description: Allen Ginsberg (1926-1997) was a great poet but not a great photographer. So while Beat Memories: The Photographs of Allen Ginsberg at the Grey Art Gallery is an interesting exhibition, it is in certain ways disappointing. The best you can say about the pictures Ginsberg took during two periods in which he dabbled in the medium  the 50s and early 60s and the 80s and 90s  is that they are the works of a competent amateur. The bigger disappointment, however, is that much of the history that Ginsberg lived through and did so much to alter as a countercultural activist is missing.

title: A. Scott Berg to Publish Biography of Woodrow Wilson
description: A decade after he began work on it, A. Scott Berg, the author of best-selling biographies of Katharine Hepburn and Charles Lindbergh, has finished his biography of Woodrow Wilson. Titled Wilson, it will be published in September, G. P. Putnams Sons said Thursday.

title: Few Possibilities for Prosecution at JPMorgan
description: The internal report released by JPMorgan Chase this week related to a disastrous bet on a hedging strategy may not be a good guidebook for federal prosecutors.

title: 16.2 Million Vehicles Recalled in 2012, Safety Agency Says
description: A total of 16.2 million vehicles were recalled last year, with slightly more than half made by Toyota and Honda, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Thursday.

title: Russia Warns of Retaliation Over U.S. Ruling on a Jewish Collection
description: MOSCOW  The Russian government warned angrily on Thursday that it would retaliate against any effort by the United States to enforce a ruling by a federal judge in Washington who has ordered Russia to pay fines of $50,000 a day for refusing to return a disputed collection of Jewish books and documents to the Chabad-Lubavitch Hasidic group.

title: A Popularity Present for Michelle Obama
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll offers a gift of another sort for Michelle Obama on her 49th birthday Thursday  Americans positive views of her outstrip the negative by about 4 to 1.

title: Biden Getting an Autobiography From The Onion (Whether He Wants It or Not)
description: Hombre, youve just done Uncle Joe a real solid buying this book, begins the foreword to a new autobiography attributed to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. I aint the kind of guy who forgets his debts. Next time we meet theres a tallboy of ice cold Beast on me. And if youre a lady, I know a few tricks to repay you with interest, if you catch my drift.

title: Thompson Says He Wouldnt Raise Taxes if Elected Mayor
description: Differentiating himself from his likely Democratic rivals in the mayoral race, William C. Thompson Jr. vowed on Thursday that he would not raise taxes if elected.

title: What Issue? Stern Wants More Audio Taping at N.B.A. Games
description: LONDON  In his first public comments on the Knicks use of recording microphones at Madison Square Garden last weekend, N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern said that he doubted there was any issue for him to address and that he would actually like to see more mikes around in league arenas so that the audio records of games would be more robust than they are now.

title: Highlights and Analysis: Knicks Defeat Pistons in London
description: As the N.B.A. continues its plan to extend its brand globally, the Knicks played the Detroit Pistons before a sold-out crowd at the O2 Arena in London. Steven Cotton will supply occasional updates from the game.

title: Gun Debate Moves to Capitol Hill
description: TimesCast Politics: Proposals face Congressional resistance. | Business groups want restraint on debt ceiling threats. | The White House readies a new team of advisors.

title: A Swollen Stream of Consciousness
description: Ken Kesey, the author of that great American novel of mental illness One Flew Over the Cuckoos Nest, once cited with approval a precept of his fathers: Good writing aint necessarily good reading.

title: Anna Deavere Smith Wins Gish Prize
description: One of the largest prizes awarded in the arts, the $300,000 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, is going to the actress and author Anna Deavere Smith.

title: Eyes Wide Shut
description: That crunching sound you hear is Lawrence Wright bending over backward to be fair to Scientology. Every deceptive comparison with Mormonism and other religions is given a respectful hearing. Every ludicrous bit of church dogma is served up deadpan. This makes the books indictment that much more powerful. Open almost any page at random. That tape of L. Ron Hubbard, Scientologys founder, that Wright quotes from? It was a part of a lecture Hubbard gave in 1963, in which he talked about the between-lives period, when thetans are transported to Venus to have their memories erased.

title: Red Bulls Take Midfielder in Draft
description: And with their sole pick in the 2013 Major League Soccer SuperDraft, the New York Red Bulls select Georgetown midfielder Ian Christianson

title: Crowds Gather in Turkey to Honor 3 Kurds Killed in Paris
description: HATAY, Turkey  Tens of thousands of people gathered Thursday in the southern city of Diyarbakir to mourn the deaths of three Kurdish activists murdered in Paris last week, an outpouring that some said amounted to the largest political gathering that the Turkish authorities had ever allowed the Kurds to stage.

title: An Uneasy Turn at the G.O.P. Retreat
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.  Well, that was awkward.

title: TimesCast Politics: Gun Debate Moves to Capitol Hill
Rock, Paper, Scissors, Guitar and Sound
description: Keith Rowe is 72, and the instrument hes been associated with for nearly 50 years is an electric guitar, laid flat on a table. Near the guitar are the things he uses for manipulating the sound of the guitar or interacting with it: flat objects of various weights and hardnesses, a couple of effects pedals, a small electric fan, a wad of steel wool, a small radio, an iPod, a sound mixer.

title: Irish Hostage Is Safe and Free in Algeria, but Britons Are Told to Brace for Bad News
description: Following a military raid on a gas facility in Algeria, where a heavily armed group of Islamist militants took dozens of workers hostage, the Irish government confirmed on Thursday that a man from Belfast who had been part of the group taken captive was freed. The fate of other hostages remained unclear.

title: E*Trade Names Former Barclays Executive as New Chief
description: E*Trade Financial on Thursday named Paul T. Idzik, a former executive at Barclays, as its new chief, ending a five-month search for a new leader.

title: 2 Reports on Oil Sands Paint a Dire Picture
description: Opponents of the Keystone XL pipeline and the heavy Canadian crude oil that it would carry released two reports on Thursday asserting that the environmental impacts of the project are worse than previously estimated, and urged the Obama administration to veto it.

title: An Evening of Finnish Pride and Germanic Brio
description: Many oppressive regimes have tried to manipulate the role of music in their citizens lives. The Taliban banned it almost entirely, and the Nazis prohibited performances of works by degenerate composers. The Soviets branded as formalist scores that didnt meet the requirements of Socialist Realism, demanding patriotic and folk-tinged pieces.

title: Intels Profit Falls 27% as PC Sales Drop
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Intel has money, smart people and resolve, but it still doesnt have a quick fix for the deterioration of its largest market  personal computers.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 17
description: A view of the day in sports, including a Knicks-Pistons game in London and sled dog racing in France.

title: Maybe Naked, Curvy or Clumsy, and Probably Socially Unorthodox
description: By presenting a theatrical account of human energy, each choreographer offers us a distinct view of human potential. So does each dance company and each dance festival. This week presents us with an exercise in compare-and-contrast: the American Realness festival (through Sunday) continues, just as New York City Ballet has commenced its winter season (through Feb. 24); there are days when you can go from one to the other.

title: Meet Dave Grohl, Film Promoter
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Sundance doesnt officially start until Thursday night. But already a rock star has given the movie crowd a master class in how to use the festival as a launching pad for a new film.

title: The Past Is Haunting Them
description: A facetious nickname for the chilly psychological thriller Brief Reunion might be The Rat and the Bat. The rat is the movies wary, furtive protagonist, Aaron (Joel de la Fuente), a successful software entrepreneur who lives in a picture-perfect New Hampshire farmhouse with his wife, Lea (Alexie Gilmore). The bat is an unwelcome visitor from his past.

title: Inquiry Questions Actions of N.B.A. Union Chief, but Finds No Criminality
description: A nine-month independent investigation determined that Billy Hunter failed in his fiduciary responsibilities as the executive director of the National Basketball Players Association and that the unions executive board should consider replacing him.

title: Beat Memories
description: Images from an exhibition of photographs by the poet Allen Ginsberg.

title: Perennial Crowd Pleasers
description: New art books look at Winslow Homer in Maine, Mati Klarweins album covers and more.

title: This Years Jazz & Heritage Festival Leans Heavily on Pop
description: Jazz acts are scarce in this years New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, the sprawling outdoor event that runs for two weekends in late April and early May. The headliners announced on Thursday include Billy Joel, Fleetwood Mac, Maroon 5, the Black Keys and John Mayer. The citys spring music festival has become a potpourri of American genres, including pop, blues, jazz, funk, country, rock, gospel, zydeco and salsa. Some of the other big-name acts on the bill are Earth, Wind & Fire; Willie Nelson and Family; the Dave Matthews Band; Jill Scott; Widespread Panic; Jimmy Cliff; the Gipsy Kings; and B.B. King. Among the well-known jazz artists will be Ellis Marsalis, Nicholas Payton, Wayne Shorter and Stanley Clarke. Much of the lineup still includes musicians born in New Orleans or Louisiana, and the list of local heroes appearing this year includes Irma Thomas, the singer and pianist Allen Toussaint, the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the Nevilles and Dr. John.

title: Old All-Stars Who Still Dazzle the Eye
description: Those of us who love the arts often deify the arcane. We dont want to lurk with the herd as it grazes on Lincoln. We dont want to get spattered by another colossal hemorrhaging of Picassos profligate genius.

title: Alejandra Villagra, Jason van Dalen
description: AMONG mountaineers its known as the E-bomb, letting it drop that you have climbed Mount Everest  an accomplishment with an unassailable mystique, occupying a higher plane than, say, running with the bulls in Pamplona or scuba diving off the Great Barrier Reef.

title: Former Bookkeeper Accused of Stealing From Masa
description: The thefts at Masa, the high-priced sushi restaurant in the Time Warner Center, began slowly, and in small amounts. One day in June 2011, $100 was taken from that days substantial sales receipts. But the amounts that went missing kept growing, and at first went unnoticed.

title: Test Run: Maura Magazine, an iPad Mini-Mag
description: Something interesting is happening in the world of iPad publishing.

title: Its as Good as Glue: Mending Shattered China
description: Clunky repairs on antique china are attracting a growing circle of fans.

title: White House Posts Videos of Children Asking Obama to Address Gun Violence
description: A day after President Obama called for broad new gun laws, the White House published on its YouTube channel videos of four children reading their own letters about guns.

title: Will Congress Approve Obama's Gun Plan?
description: The Times's Michael D. Shear takes a look at the chances of President Obama's gun control package getting through the House and Senate.

title: A Place to Put All Those Curiosities
description: Many exhibitions convey the propulsive force of human curiosity, but few manage to do so as engrossingly and with as much immediacy as Rooms of Wonder: From Wunderkammer to Museum, 1599-1899, a lavish repast of illustrated rare books and ephemera at the Grolier Club. The appetite for knowledge about foreign lands, unfamiliar animals and all the workings of the world  both natural and man-made  permeates this show, which delves into the origins of the modern museum.

title: A New Obama Cabinet Takes Shape
description: The Times's Peter Baker examines the new team of White House advisers, including Denis R. McDonough, considered to be a top choice to replace Jacob J. Lew as the White House chief of staff.

title: New Showcase for a Neglected Era
description: When the curator of American art at the Brooklyn Museum began work on an exhibition to coincide with next years anniversary of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, she happened on a trove of works from the Black Arts Movement, the cultural arm of the black power movement of the 1960s and 70s. This was an area of the art market long neglected but recently attracting attention.

title: 2014 Corvette Stingray Has Its New York Coming-Out Party
description: Only days after making a worldwide debut at the Detroit Auto Show on Sunday evening, the 2014 Chevrolet Corvette, now with the retro-inspired Stingray name attached to it, traveled about 600 miles east for its first appearance in New York City. Compared to the glitz and glamor that greeted the sports car upon its introduction in the Motor City, the Big Apple event was noticeably less frenetic and much more informal.

title: Comedy Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Comedy

title: Movie Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Movies

title: The Caucus Click: Finishing Touches
Bob Mizer: Artifacts
description: Invisible-Exports

title: Pop Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Pop

title: Paul Laffoley: The Boston Visionary Cell
description: Kent Fine Art

title: For Such a Little Trailer, Theres a Lot Going On
description: They might be sleepwalkers, they might be larvae. Moving numbly  as if through trauma  they resemble an unknown species. Eiko and Koma, the celebrated Japanese duo, are giving a series of daylong performances of The Caravan Project through Monday in the lobby of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: George Maciunas: Anything Can Substitute Art: Maciunas in SoHo
description: 41 Cooper Union Gallery

title: Loans for Fixer-Uppers
description: BARGAIN hunters ought not to overlook properties in need of extensive repairs. A federally backed lending program enables buyers to roll the cost of necessary fixes into their mortgage, which can sometimes yield a quick return on their investment.

title: Theater Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Theater

title: Nathaniel Robinson: Outer Air
description: Feature

title: Mixing Solemn With Snappy
description: The venerable Schneider Concerts, a chamber music series at the New School, has long been a source of high-quality solo recitals, trios and quartets at affordable prices. In fact, affordable is a just a polite way of saying truly cheap: $82 for a seven-concert subscription.

title: Daniel Buren: Electricity Fabric Paint Paper Vinyl ...
description: Petzel Gallery

title: Twists and Turns in Becoming a Man: A Day in Baltimore
description: By his own account Vincent is a man who knows how to handle his business, and at first glance, you might take him for a conventional kind of businessman. His trim gray suit and chunky gold wristwatch go nicely with the black Mercedes-Benz sedan parked in front of his mothers modest Baltimore house. Vincents young nephew, Woody, idolizes his uncle, drawing him, in a school notebook, as a fearless, muscle-bound superhero.

title: Society Membership Proposed for Yale Club
description: YES, its a filing cabinet, but the 22-story Yale Club, at Vanderbilt Avenue and 44th Street, is a very nice filing cabinet! That is, its incrementally more attractive than the rest of Midtowns World War I-era buildings.

title: Fury of a Woman Scorned? Multiply That by Three
description: A woman abandoned by her lover, left to grapple with feelings of betrayal, despair and desire for justice: who couldnt relate?

title: Fitness Center in a Hotel Room
description: A FREQUENT traveler, Soozan Baxter never bothers with the hotel gym. Instead, she checks with the front desk to make sure there is a tub in the bathroom, an iron in the closet and a sturdy bench or ottoman in the room.

title: Jazz Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Jazz

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Classical

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Pakistan, Syria, Indonesia and Mali.

title: Dance Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Dance

title: The Spirits Are Back in Force in Brooklyn
description: For generations, one of the first things visitors to the Brooklyn Museum encountered was the Hall of the Americas, the two-story rotunda right off the main lobby. And when you were in it, you knew you were home. Its towering, glowering Northwest Coast totem poles were city landmarks the way the New York Public Library lions were. Its fantastic kachina dolls radiated a celebrity glow. The 2,000-year-old Paracas Textile, one of the worlds rarest Andean weavings, was high on the list of best-kept art secrets in town. Knowing its value made Brooklyn regulars a society of connoisseurs.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 18-24
description: Art

title: This Weeks Movies | Jan. 18
description: Times critics review Broken City, Luv and Greenwich Village.

title: Spare Times for Jan. 18-24
description: Around Town

title: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 18-24
description: ERTHS DINOSAUR ZOO

title: With Crowd on Their Side, Anthony and the Knicks Romp in London
description: LONDON  It was London, but it could have been Midtown Manhattan. With Spike Lee courtside, with the Detroit Pistons not looking any more formidable in England than they do at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks rolled to a 102-87 victory Thursday that had most of the sellout crowd of 18,689 cheering in approval.

title: Minimalism Wrapped in a Mystery
description: In his Notes on Cinematography, the great French director Robert Bresson argued against the use of music in films. Noises must become music, he wrote. Many of Bressons techniques and ideas  the employment of nonprofessional actors, the adaptation of naturalistic means to spiritual ends  have taken hold among European filmmakers in the past decade or so. Perhaps nowhere more strikingly than in the work of Bruno Dumont, whose second feature, Humanit, won the Grand Prix in Cannes in 1999, the year of Bressons death.

title: Shellfire From Myanmar Enters China, Drawing a Rebuke
description: BANGKOK  China said Thursday that it had expressed grave concern to the Myanmar government after a shell, apparently fired during fighting between Myanmar troops and ethnic rebels, landed in Chinese territory, and a Chinese government spokesman called for an immediate cease-fire.

title: City Jobs Lost in Storm Are Returning, but Unemployment Rate Is Flat
description: New York Citys job market started to shrug off the effects of Hurricane Sandy at the end of the year, new employment statistics showed on Thursday.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Writing Siris Lines, and Ray Kurzweils Future
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Life, Death and Transformation in the Americas
description: Images from the exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Where Dread Throbs and Little Girls Scuttle
description: Guillermo del Toro, the reigning godfather of motion-picture horror, is the modern-day Val Lewton, the legendary producer of atmospheric chillers like The Curse of the Cat People. If youre a movie fan, you know that horror doesnt get much better than this, and when it comes to contemporary offerings it rarely gets more enjoyable than Mama. Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that dont often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you dont want anyone to take an ax to them.

title: Blackstones Latest Hired Help? No, Just Two Well-Dressed Visitors
description: It appears that a couple of visitors to the Blackstone Group elevated the private equity firms dress code for an afternoon.

title: When They Hammered Out Justice in the 60s
description: It is striking how many of the 1960s folk music pioneers in Laura Archibalds entertaining documentary, Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation, are still earnestly plugging away 50 years later. If rock stars often burn out, folkies tend to slowly fade away.

title: Rubio Outlines Elements of His New Immigration Plan
description: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, a Republican who is on a talking tour to publicize his proposals for an immigration overhaul, said on Thursday that tighter enforcement at the borders and in workplaces would be central to his plan, which would also offer legal status to millions of illegal immigrants.

title: The Smartphone Frontiers: India, Russia, Brazil
description: Here in the United States, if you whip out a clamshell flip phone, chances are youll be called a caveman or Luddite. But elsewhere, there are still some emerging countries where the old-school cellphone has yet to become pass.

title: 2 Papa Smurfs: A Reputed Wise Guy and a Reputed Wiseguy
description: One of them is believed by the authorities to be a mob associate who extorted owners of garbage-hauling companies in New York City suburbs. The other is believed to be at least 542 years old, very short and wise, with blue skin and a white beard.

title: Barely Literate, Roma Pupils Struggle for Schooling
description: Part case study on entrenched racism, part heartbreaking human-rights story, Our School observes the feinting of small-town officials in rural Transylvania as they try to duck a mandate to integrate Roma children into the regular school system.

title: What I Love |  Dr. Fredric Brandt
description: A luxury condominium in West Chelsea has sweeping city views from Jersey City to the George Washington Bridge.

title: A Home Convenient to Both Art and Clouds
description: SOME people have a spouse to come home to, others a child. Fredric Brandt, the cosmetic dermatologist who is in charge of the faces of Madonna, Stephanie Seymour and Kelly Ripa, has a life-size wooden sculpture of a man by the French artist Xavier Veilhan.

title: Norwegian Cruise Line Prices I.P.O. at $19 a share
description: Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings is setting sail into life as a newly public company in good stead.

title: From Real-Life Governor to Small-Town Sheriff
description: During a delicious 60 seconds or so in Arnold Schwarzeneggers new movie, The Last Stand, two bad guys are dispatched to their eternal punishment in memorable fashion. It may say something about Mr. Schwarzeneggers post-gubernatorial future in action movies that he is not the trigger man in either killing.

title: Inside the Lives of Somali Pirates
description: A documentary that yearns to be an adventure movie, Stolen Seas cant resist drowning its invaluable insights in thundering, drum-heavy music and flashing visuals. Magnificent in its thoroughness and nuance, this dense, multifaceted study of Somali piracy really needs to settle down.

title: A Hacker Says Smart Grid Can Be Penetrated
description: A hacker wearing a fake beard and dark sunglasses took the stage at a computer security conference in Miami on Thursday and showed a group of about 60 security researchers how to intercept the radio communications between Silver Spring Networks, a maker of smart grid technology, and its clients, which include major utilities like Pacific Gas and Electric and Pepco Holdings.

title: All Eyes on the Ball, Not the Condos
description: PROFESSIONAL athletes who have just signed seven- and eight-figure contracts can, virtually overnight, become enthusiastic investors in high-end real estate.

title: Neighborhood Joint: The Ink Pad
description: The Ink Pad, a 300-square-foot store in the West Village, is home to an inventory of more than 10,000 rubber stamps.

title: Photos of The Moment | Raf Simons
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Build Your Own Inaugural Address
description: Choose among 20 excerpts from past inaugural addresses to create a speech that touches on common themes.

title: For Making Impressions of Anything
description: A LOT of people come in and go, What are those little blocks? Anna Chiang said, laughing. She was standing in the middle of the Ink Pad, surrounded by her inventory of more than 10,000 rubber stamps.

title: Obamas 2012 Operation Turns Over a New Leaf
description: 1:09 p.m. | Updated  An updated version of this post is available here.

title: An Apartment With Guest Potential
description: AFTER graduating from Columbia University, Lena Evans spent time overseas, working in Italy. When she returned to New York, she headed for the West Village.

title: What Should Be Done About Guns?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Longer School Day?
description: To the Editor:

title: No Parking Any Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Preoccupying My Mind With Summer Plans as Colleges Decide My Fate
description: Sush Krishnamoorthy, a student from New Delhi, is part of The Choice class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her sixth post is below.  Tanya Abrams

title: Americans Views on Gun Control
description: A New York Times/CBS News Poll of Americans views on gun control.

title: Wilds Big Signings Reinvigorate a Hockey-Crazy City
description: ST. PAUL  When it comes to hockey and his beloved Minnesota Wild, Dan Austin can be a patient man.

title: Massacre at School Sways Public in Way Earlier Shootings Didnt
description: The massacre of children at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., appears to be profoundly swaying Americans views on guns, galvanizing the broadest support for stricter gun laws in about a decade, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Ovation, Then Apology, for Serbian Song
description: UNITED NATIONS  At the conclusion of the Serbian song March on the Drina at a concert this week in the United Nations General Assembly, Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and other senior officials rose in a standing ovation  apparently not realizing that it is associated with massacres carried out in the 1990s against civilians who were under the protection of United Nations peacekeepers.

title: The New York Times/CBS Poll on Guns
description: The latest New York Times/CBS poll explores public attitudes on firearms and gun control.

title: Cameron Delays Talk on New Role in Europe
description: LONDON  The stage for the one-man show was set, the drama widely anticipated and the critics assembled. But the star dropped out at the last moment, saying he would reschedule when he could.

title: Some Marketers Rethink Super Bowl Ad Previews
description: FEW on Madison Avenue who emulate the habits of highly effective people would admit to borrowing from the Nixon White House. But as marketers that will advertise in Super Bowl XLVII plan pregame strategies, many are opting for what was described during the Watergate era as a modified limited hangout.

title: Guns, Safety and Mental Health
Russia to Let U.S. Adoptions in Final Stages Go Through
description: MOSCOW  Russias federal child rights commissioner said Thursday that American citizens in the final stages of adopting children here would be allowed to take custody and return to the United States, providing some clarity after more than two weeks of confusion over a new law banning adoptions by American citizens.

title: In Teo Story, Deception Ripped From the Screen
description: The show on MTV is called Catfish, and this is how it works.

title: Audit, Citing Mismanagement, Finds SUNY Downstate in Dire Fiscal Straits
description: As SUNY Downstate Medical Center bled money over the past few years, 15 of the hospitals top administrators were paid taxpayer-financed salaries over $200,000, while nearly 500 lower-paid employees were sent layoff notices, according to a state comptrollers audit released on Thursday.

title: Jan. 17 Updates on Armstrongs Confession
description: The Lede rounded up online reaction to Lance Armstrongs interview with Oprah Winfrey on Thursday night in real-time, with additional fact-checking and context provided by Juliet Macur, Sarah Lyall, Brian Stelter, David Carr and Robert Mackey. The second part of the interview is scheduled to be broadcast at 9 p.m. Eastern Time on Friday and will be streamed live on the Oprah Winfrey Networks Web site.

title: Georgia: 12 Are Charged in 4-State Sex Ring
description: Prosecutors charged 12 people on Thursday with running a sex trafficking and prostitution ring across four Southern states. Authorities say the suspects lured female immigrants to the United States and then threatened them with deportation unless they became prostitutes. The operation spanned Georgia, Florida and North and South Carolina, said Edward J. Tarver, the United States attorney in Savannah. Federal agents on Wednesday rescued 11 women who were victims of the operation.

title: When Countries Cant Pay Their Debts
description: A recent court decision in a long-running legal battle between investors and the government of Argentina has highlighted problems with restructuring the debts of countries that fall on hard times. The case, which is being fought in federal court in New York, suggests that policy makers must develop a more systematic way to deal with sovereign defaults.

title: Make Law Schools Earn a Third Year
description: TODAY, leaders of the New York bar, judges and law school faculty members will gather at New York University to discuss a proposed rule change. If adopted by the states highest court, it could make law school far more accessible to low-income students, help the next generation of law students avoid a heavy burden of debt and lead to improvements in legal education across the United States.

title: A Rumble in the Jungle
description: THE new reality TV series Bamazon, on the History Channel, along with already established shows like Gold Rush and Jungle Gold, have elevated the global mining bonanza into living-room entertainment. Each focuses on a different group of Americans seeking their fortune in distant, ostensibly dangerous locales: Bamazon in Guyana, Gold Rush in Alaska and Guyana, and Jungle Gold in Ghana. But while these shows claim to depict reality, they gloss over the most awful truths of gold mining, particularly as it is practiced in the tropics.

title: Is Wild West Era for Gas Drilling Coming to an End?
description: While in Washington to run a panel at an invaluable conference on disasters and the environment this week, I spent a few minutes in a studio to discuss the issues and opportunities surrounding hydraulic fracturing for natural gas (and oil) on the Current TV show The War Room, hosted by Jennifer Granholm, the former governor of Michigan.

title: Long Islands Future, Stuck in Transit
description: Long Island, that strange place jutting east from New York City for 100 miles, was once the very symbol of Americas postwar future, of youth and growth, and is now the opposite of that. It is an old suburb that ran out of places to sprawl, was badly hit by recession a decade ago and again in the latest downturn, and is feeling its age.

title: As Shells Arctic Drilling Hopes Hit Snags, Its Rivals Watch
description: HOUSTON  Royal Dutch Shells Arctic drilling program is now officially in jeopardy and its prospects will depend on the findings of two continuing federal inquiries. One review is on the grounding of the Kulluk drill ship on New Years Eve after it was set adrift for five days in stormy weather, and the other is on the safety management of the entire Shell program.

title: Mortgage Crisis Lingers On at Citigroup and Bank of America
description: More than four years after the financial crisis, many big banks have regained their footing. But Bank of America and Citigroup remain dogged by the past.

title: Recalling Pain of Guns Toll, Mayors Urge Bills Passage
description: WASHINGTON  Some mayors spoke about the bad feeling they got with each call that there had been another shooting in their city. Others described the pain of burying police officers who had worked for them. Many recalled their attempts to console grieving families.

title: Michael Dells Empire in a Buyout Spotlight
description: The computer empire of Michael S. Dell spreads across a campus of low-slung buildings in Round Rock, Tex.

title: The States Confront Gun Violence
description: State lawmakers in Wyoming didnt need to hear President Obamas gun-control proposals on Wednesday in order to attack them. A week ago, before the White House had even decided what actions to take, Republicans introduced a bill in the Wyoming Legislature to block any federal limitation on firearms, such as an assault weapons ban. A federal agent seeking to enforce such a ban would be guilty of a felony and face five years in prison.

title: Robert Citron, Culprit in California Fraud, Dies at 87
description: Robert L. Citron, who as treasurer of Orange County, Calif., engaged in financial actions that astounded bankers and bureaucrats until his bold bets put the county in bankruptcy in 1994 and himself in prison the next year, died on Wednesday in Orange, Calif. He was 87.

title: Banker Behind Armstrong Says He Was Unaware of Doping
description: The financier Thomas Weisel recently boxed up the bright-yellow cycling jerseys that lined an entire wall of his office, which overlooks San Franciscos harbor. They were gifts from Lance Armstrong, a longtime friend whom Mr. Weisel had bankrolled through seven Tour de France wins.

title: On Antarctic Trip, Students Encounter Whales and a 30-Foot Wave
description: For private school students, trips to far-flung corners of the earth have long been de rigueur.

title: After Inquiry, Notre Dame Decided Revealing Teo Hoax Was Up to Him
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Notre Dame officials realized the stakes were high when Manti Teo, the football teams star linebacker, came to them Dec. 26 and revealed that he had been the victim of an elaborate hoax, that his girlfriend Lennay Kekua, who had died of leukemia in September, never existed. He had been duped, he told them.

title: The Dwindling Deficit
description: Its hard to turn on your TV or read an editorial page these days without encountering someone declaring, with an air of great seriousness, that excessive spending and the resulting budget deficit is our biggest problem. Such declarations are rarely accompanied by any argument about why we should believe this; its supposed to be part of what everyone knows.

title: The Next Four Years
description: President Obamas second inaugural comes at an interesting moment, what you might call the end of the era of the Grand Bargain. Throughout his first term, Democrats and Republicans didnt achieve a Grand Bargain on spending and taxes, but there was a sense that history was moving in that direction.

title: Swabian Separatists Fling Sptzle to Make Their Point
description: BERLIN  Separatists have escalated a growing conflict in the heart of the German capital. Their weapons of choice were delicious egg noodles, their victim a woman made of bronze.

title: Green Fashion on the Red Carpet
description: The movie star Bradley Cooper showed up to this weeks Golden Globes wearing an eco-friendly tuxedo. Though his designer suit looked unremarkably black, it was made to be green, having been spun in Europe from low-environmental-impact wool.

title: Movement of Missiles by North Korea Worries U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The discovery by American intelligence agencies that North Korea is moving mobile missile launchers around the country, some carrying a new generation of powerful rocket, has spurred new assessments of the intentions of the countrys young new leader, Kim Jong-un, who has talked about economic change but appears to be accelerating the countrys ability to attack American allies or forces in Asia, and ultimately to strike across the Pacific.

title: Image Becomes a Puzzle as Theories on Teo Swirl
description: On Dec. 6, Notre Dame officials said, Manti Teo received an alarming phone call: his dead girlfriend, whose loss had inspired him during what had become a triumphant year for the Fighting Irish, might still be alive. Either that or Teo, a gifted linebacker with a reputation for trusting others, had been the victim of a hoax, and the woman he thought he had come to know online and through long, emotional phone calls had never really existed.

title: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Jan. 18, 2013
description: Whoever is making that battery is doing a really bad job.

title: Critical Infrastructure Systems Seen as Vulnerable to Attack
description: The vast majority of targeted computer attacks now start with a malicious e-mail sent to a company employee. Now evidence suggests that the same technique could be used to attack watersheds, power grids, oil refineries and nuclear plants.

title: Lack of Warning on Rescue Effort Highlights Limits of Algerian Cooperation
description: WASHINGTON  On the way to Europe in October, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton made a much-publicized stop in Algeria to enlist that nations help in combating militants who had established a sanctuary in neighboring Mali, including fighters from Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb.

title: Keeping the Boats Moving Along a Mississippi Dwindled by Drought
description: ST. LOUIS  For months along the Mississippi River here, the withering drought has caused record-breaking low water levels that have threatened to shut down traffic on the worlds largest navigable inland waterway.

title: Powerful Chemical Cocktail, With a Drawback
description: A lithium-ion battery works like most other chemical batteries. A particle with an electric charge (in this case, a lithium ion) moves to one terminal when energy is applied, and the other terminal when energy is drawn off.

title: Praised but Fire-Prone, Battery Fails Test in 787
description: Powerful and lightweight, lithium-ion batteries are the perfect power source for modern gadgets. But ubiquitous as they are, their short history has also been fraught with problems  they have caught fire in cellphones, laptop computers and electric cars, and even destroyed a small Navy submarine.

title: A Storm From the South, Brewing in a Bedroom
