description: A four-alarm urgency infuses every breath that Scarlett Johansson takes in the oxygen-starved revival of Tennessee Williamss Cat on a Hot Tin Roof that opened on Thursday at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: Jihad Prince, a Kidnapper, Is Tied to Raid
description: PARIS  His entourage calls him the Prince, and after the militant Islamist takeover of a town in northern Mali last year, he liked to go down to the river and watch the sunset, surrounded by armed bodyguards.

title: Part of a Crack Response
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Weve seen this shape of grid before, but Ive always liked it because it looks to me like two hands reaching out to grasp each other, and thats a nice metaphor for the relationship between constructor and solver, isnt it?

title: Corrections: January 18, 2013
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Scientists Develop Device for Image Compression
description: Using a new class of artificial materials, scientists at Duke University have designed a sensor that compresses images far more efficiently than existing technologies like JPEG.

title: A Special Freshman Back, and Then Came the Injuries
description: Antrel Rolle has been playing football against Frank Gore since they were youngsters near Miami. When they were in high school  Rolle at South Dade, Gore a bit north in Coral Gables  Rolle always heard that Gore, blessed with elusiveness, exceptional balance and uncanny field vision, might be the best running back ever to come out of those neighborhoods, which doubled as a recruiters dream.

title: At Algerian Oil and Gas Fields Once Thought Safe, New Fears and Precautions
description: HOUSTON  The rich oil and gas fields of the Algerian Sahara have always posed a challenge for global oil companies and their field workers. One of the most inhospitable environments on the face of the earth, the stony lands bake at 120 degrees in summer and chill to well below freezing in the winter. In spring and fall they are whipped by vicious sandstorms.

title: Dartmouth Stops Credits for Excelling on A.P. Test
description: Concerned that Advanced Placement courses are not as rigorous as college courses, Dartmouth has announced that it will no longer give college credits for good A.P. scores, starting with the class of 2018.

title: Fighting in Mali Hampers Guinea Worm Disease Eradication
description: Fighting in Mali has damaged the global effort to eradicate Guinea worm disease, former President Jimmy Carter said Thursday.

title: Redford, Sundance Officials Talk About Guns in Film
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Does Hollywood play a role in gun violence? Asked that question on Thursday at the Sundance Film Festivals opening-day press conference, event officials, including Robert Redford, were reticent to wade deep into the debate.

title: The Hoax of Digital Life
description: I once tried to talk somebody out of pursuing a mail-order bride, a young Filipino who for a relatively modest fee would agree to move to Spokane, Wash., and start a new life with a complete stranger. Among the many questions raised by this half-baked plan was: How could you marry someone you had never met?

title: For Israeli TV Viewers, a Big Helping of Candidates, Both Real and Spoofed
description: HERZLIYA, Israel  On the set here this week of Israels most popular political television satire show, a character impersonating Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu stood by a large map of the region as he drew a system of fences, spiked barriers and security doors around Israels borders. He then slapped a sign over the country that read, Do Not Disturb.

title: Gen. Yang Baibing Dies at 93; Led Tiananmen Crackdown
description: BEIJING  Gen. Yang Baibing, a military strongman who carried out the violent suppression of student-led protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 and was later purged because of fears that he was accruing too much power, died here on Tuesday. He was 93.

title: Democrats Are Split Over How to Shape Approach to Gun Bills
description: WASHINGTON  As Congressional Democrats shape their strategy for considering President Obamas proposals to curb gun violence, sharp divisions are forming between lawmakers who believe the best path to success is through narrowly written bills and a meticulous legislative process, and those who advocate a more guerrilla approach.

title: Robert H. Levenson, a Visionary Adman, Dies at 83
description: Robert H. Levenson, an advertising executive who helped produce some of the mid-20th centurys most memorable campaigns, writing evocative advertisements for clients like Volkswagen, El Al and Sara Lee, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: A Nose for the Ball and a Knack for the Big Plays
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Matt Schaub called it an oh no moment. There was his fullback, James Casey, open for a short pass in the middle of the field. All Schaub needed to do was put enough arc on the ball to ensure that New Englands Rob Ninkovich would not get a hand on the ball.

title: Critics Question Chvez Signature on an Official Decree
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A tempest in an ink pot has broken out over the signature of President Hugo Chvez, which suddenly appeared on a government decree this week despite his long absence from the country.

title: Prospero Gallinari, a Terrorist, Is Dead at 62
description: Prospero Gallinari, who as a member of the Italian terrorist group the Red Brigades was convicted in the kidnapping and assassination in 1978 of Aldo Moro, the Italian prime minister, died Monday after collapsing at his home in Reggio Emilia, in northern Italy. He was 62. He was long believed to have been the gunman in the killing until a comrade took responsibility.

title: Christie Forms Panel on Firearms and School Safety
description: After facing sharp criticism for not mentioning gun violence in his State of the State speech, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey appointed a task force on Thursday to examine gun control measures and school safety, as well as look at some of the underlying problems behind gun violence, including addiction and mental illness.

title: Jewish Population Is Up in the New York Region
description: Borough Park in Brooklyn, with its preponderance of Orthodox synagogues and kosher restaurants, is the most Jewish area in the New York City region, with 78 percent of households there identifying as Jewish. Close behind is Great Neck, Long Island, with its thriving enclave of Persian Jews, and then the Five Towns, also on Long Island, where a higher percentage of Jews identify as modern Orthodox than anywhere else in the region, according to a Jewish demographic study released Tuesday.

title: Chinese Economy Expanded at End of 2012, Data Shows
description: HONG KONG  The giant Chinese economy picked up steam during the last few months of 2012, closely watched data from Beijing on Friday confirmed. But at the same time the figures underlined the view that the pace of future growth is likely to remain well below that seen in recent years.

title: Ex-Bookkeeper Is Charged With Theft at Restaurant
description: Masa is the sort of restaurant where customers know exactly what they will pay  $450 plus tax and tip  but little about what they will eat, because there is no menu.

title: Lottery Numbers
Florida Governor Backs Voting Changes
description: MIAMI  Two months after Florida was denounced for its chaotic election process, Gov. Rick Scott on Thursday endorsed three major changes proposed by the states election supervisors.

title: Officers Called to L.I. Home Find Dying Boy and No Adult
description: A caller to the police reported that a boy needed an ambulance. When the police arrived on Wednesday afternoon at the address the caller gave, an apartment in a house in Amityville, on Long Island, they found an unresponsive pajama-clad child lying on a couch. There were no adults present

title: The Many Ways to Run From Doping Charges
description: Lance Armstrongs confessional with Oprah Winfrey is another milestone for one of the longest frauds in professional sports. Shown here, a small sampling of other top athletes accused of doping.

title: Nash Is Caught in a Quick Transition
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rick Nash got what he wanted July 23 when the Columbus Blue Jackets acceded to his trade demands and dealt him to the Rangers. But the circumstances leading to his long-awaited debut Saturday against the Boston Bruins are something no one would wish for.

title: Military Judge Rejects Defense Requests at Terror Hearings
description: WASHINGTON  A military judge at the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, declined this week to rule on whether the Constitution applied to the military tribunal case involving the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. The judge also rejected a defense motion to throw out tribunal charges in the case involving the bombing of the American destroyer Cole in 2000.

title: Brooklyn Man Claims Police Beat and Taunted Him
description: A Brooklyn man who was arrested on Sunday on a variety of charges accused the police on Thursday of beating him in the entryway of his building without provocation while shouting antigay slurs.

title: Police Turn Camera Away Prior to Arrest
description: A New York City police sergeant is seen turning a surveillance camera to face a wall prior to entering the Crown Heights, Brooklyn, home of a man who was later arrested and allegedly beaten.

title: Dean of the Senate Walks a Fine Line on Conflicts
description: A clamor for ethics reform was sweeping the state and the nation in 1973 when John Whitmire, a 23-year-old college dropout, was sworn in as a freshman member of the Texas House.

title: Tribune Co. Names Chief After Ending Bankruptcy
description: Peter Liguori, a longtime television executive, was named the new chief executive of the Tribune Company on Thursday, two and a half weeks after the newspaper and television station owner emerged from a wrenching four-year bankruptcy process.

title: An Inch Shorter, a Falcons Back Grows in Stature
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga.  For most N.F.L. players, their size is a dead giveaway to their position. Then there is Jacquizz Rodgers.

title: Subdued Start for Legislators at Head of Table
description: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

title: Mourning Sudden Death of a Social-Services Angel
description: Christine Molnar, dressed for the occasion in a teal party dress, gave a heartfelt thank-you speech last Friday at the year-end party for Safe Space, the nonprofit child welfare agency she ran. The year had been particularly hard, she noted: the staff had been tested by Hurricane Sandy, which had upended the already troubled lives of their clients in southeastern Queens.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: For Armstrong, a Confession Without Explanation
description: The formerly defiant Lance Armstrong once said, As long as I live, I will deny ever doping, but sitting face to face with Oprah Winfrey in an interview that was broadcast Thursday, he reversed course.

title: Military Veterans to Dance With Obamas and Bidens at Inauguration
description: Four members of the armed forces who have served in Afghanistan and Iraq will take a whirl on the dance floor Monday night with President Obama, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and their wives, as part of the first dance at the Commander-in-Chiefs Ball, one of two official balls for Mr. Obamas second inauguration.

title: Word of the Day | rakish
description: rakish \ra-kish\ adjective

title: Dispassionate End to a Crumbled American Romance
description: I view this situation as one big lie that I repeated a lot of times is how Lance Armstrong neatly summed up the doping scandal that stripped him of his seven Tour de France titles and sank his career. And he made that confession to Oprah Winfrey on Thursday with startling equanimity. He may have been nervous, but he didnt look uncomfortable. Armstrong appeared as reasoned and dispassionate telling the truth as he did all those years that he so fluently and convincingly spun a lie.

title: Helping a River Flow
description: Actions taken to keep the Mississippi River open.

title: Medical Bills Crush Brooklyn Mans Hope of Retiring
description: Retirement was just about a year away, or so John Concepcion thought, when a sudden health crisis put his plans in doubt.

title: Site of Kidnapping in Algeria
description: Reconstruction of the attack on the In Amenas gas plant, the fourth-largest gas development in Algeria.

title: Armstrongs Confession Could Mean More Legal Trouble
description: His doping confession could mean more legal trouble for Lance Armstrong, who already faces several civil lawsuits, including a federal whistle-blower case filed in 2010 by his former teammate Floyd Landis.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) LELISIR DAMORE Anna Netrebko performs the role of Adina, a headstrong farm owner in early-19th-century Italy, and Matthew Polenzani (above with Ms. Netrebko) is the pining peasant Nemorino, who wins her heart with the help of a mysterious elixir of love, in this Metropolitan Opera opening-night production of Donizettis comic opera. Mariusz Kwiecien sings Belcore, Nemorinos swaggering rival, and Ambrogio Maestri is the potion-peddling salesman Doctor Dulcamara. Maurizio Benini conducted and Bartlett Sher directed this Great Performances at the Met presentation, which Anthony Tommasini, writing in The New York Times, called handsome and insightful. The productions contemporary element comes from showing the main characters engaged in a triangle of desire, distrust and gamesmanship, he said, adding: In her village Adina is like a prima donna, something Ms. Netrebko easily conveys. And Mr. Polenzani is coming into his prime.

title: Mali Need Not Be Frances Afghanistan
description: A colleagues question could have come from anyone in the United States.

title: For Berdych, Trophies are Worn on the Wrist
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Nearly all top tennis players have some public social media presence, with many of them on multiple networks. Maria Sharapova, who has long maintained an active Facebook page, joined Twitter this week, and has accumulated more than 60,000 followers in just a few days. Roger Federer sticks exclusively to Facebook, while Serena Williams was an early adapter of Twitter, and often tweets product endorsements and occasionally opaque allusions to her personal life.

title: News Quiz | January 18, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Greece: Ex-Official to Be Investigated
description: Lawmakers voted early Friday to investigate former Finance Minister George Papaconstantinou over his handling of a list of wealthy Greeks with Swiss bank accounts, a potential source of tax revenue that was never used by the authorities, stirring public outrage in the debt-racked country. After several hours of heated debate, 265 members of the 300-seat Parliament voted to set up a committee to determine whether Mr. Papaconstantinou should face criminal charges for tampering with the list or breach of duty. A 12-member committee of lawmakers has until Feb. 25 to submit its proposal to Parliament, which will then vote on whether to indict the former minister. Mr. Papaconstantinou has denied accusations that he removed the names of relatives from the list. Proposals to broaden the investigation to include other politicians were rejected.

title: Kenya: Study Details Poachers Toll
description: One of the worlds most closely watched elephant populations has been heavily hit by ivory poachers, scientists in Kenya said this week. In a study published Wednesday, scientists with the group Save the Elephants said that the proportion of illegally killed elephants in the Samburu area of northern Kenya had risen to more than 50 percent of all deaths and that the number of older elephants (which usually have the biggest tusks) declined drastically. Ivory demand and prices have reached a point at which poachers are willing to target well-protected, closely monitored populations, said Iain Douglas-Hamilton, founder of Save the Elephants. This is now being replicated in other protected areas across Africa. Scientists estimate that tens of thousands of African elephants are being slaughtered each year, more than at any time in decades, to meet the rising demand for ivory in Asias rapidly growing economies.

title: Defusing a Crisis in Pakistan
description: Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a Pakistani preacher, emerged on the countrys political scene, leading huge protests in Islamabad. After days of standoffs, he reached a symbolic deal with the government.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 18
description: NEWS Hours after Algerian forces raided a gas facility, there was still no official word on the number of hostages freed, killed or still held by their Islamist kidnappers. Adam Nossiter reported from Bamako, Mali, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

title: Cameron Warns That Britain Could Leave European Union
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron, who canceled a long-anticipated speech because of a hostage crisis in Algeria involving Britons, planned to deliver an explicit warning that Britain might leave the European Union if changes in its administration were not made, according to excerpts from the speech released Thursday and embargoed until Friday.

title:
As Algeria Hostage
Crisis Goes On, U.S.
Says American Died
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Defying the Algerian Armys demands to give up, the band of Islamist militant kidnappers who terrorized a remote Saharan gas field complex still held at least 10 and possibly dozens of foreign hostages on Friday, and a senior Algerian government official said there were no talks planned to end the standoff.

title: At Australian Open, Tough Talk About Armstrong
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  A world away from the leather-cushioned chairs which held Lance Armstrong and Oprah Winfrey in their interview Thursday, third-round tennis opponents Novak Djokovic and Radek Stepanek sat in their own wooden swivel chairs behind podiums under Rod Laver Arena, and discussed Armstrongs revelations.

title: From Tamil Brahmin to Kashmiri Pandit: Weddings Across India
description: Over the last five years, in the course of working on a photography book Just Another Indian Wedding, I may have witnessed and documented a greater variety of Indian weddings than any other person on earth.

title: Confession Falls Several Words Short of Closure
description: Betsy Andreu, the stay-at-home mother of three who for years was among Lance Armstrongs greatest foes, on Friday finally let the whirlwind of the past 24 hours sink in. She thought this moment would never come.

title: Harsh Light Falls on Bolshoi After Acid Attack
description: MOSCOW  The stories about vengeance at the Bolshoi Ballet go back centuries: The rival who hid an alarm clock in the audience, timed to go off during Giselles mad scene, or who threw a dead cat onto the stage at curtain in lieu of flowers. There are whispers of needles inserted in costumes, to be discovered in midpirouette, or  the worst  broken glass nestled in the tip of a toeshoe.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Jan. 18, 2013
description: This question was written by Shannon Doyne from an Op-Ed column by Joe Nocera, The Foreclosure Fiasco

title: Quack Goes the Astrologer
description: NEW DELHI  A minister in the state of Karnataka, home to the Indian infotech industry, has announced that the state government will set up a committee to find out ways to eliminate black magic. It is considering whether to require astrologers to register with the state authorities, apparently to sort out the legitimate fortune-tellers from the frauds.

title: Interest in Snowboarding on the Decline
description: In Has Snowboarding Lost Its Edge? Christopher Solomon reports on the snowboarding industry.

title: Russia, in Three Cities and 7 Rooms
description: Contradictions lie at the heart of Rafal Milachs 7 Rooms, a project that took Mr. Milach, a Warsaw-based photographer, to Russia in search of insights through the ordinary. Though he wanted to avoid clichs  vodka drinking, prisons, cadet schools, ballets  some pictures reflect their Soviet legacy. And although he traveled widely through three cities  Moscow, Yekaterinburg and Krasnoyarsk  his project didnt make sense to him until he narrowed his focus to seven individuals.

title: Would You Feel Safer With Armed Guards Patrolling Your School?
description: After the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., that killed 26 people, the National Rifle Association recommended that armed guards should be stationed at every school to prevent similar episodes. This week the N.R.A. released an ad criticizing President Obama for having Secret Service protection at his daughters school, but not promoting armed protection at every American school.

title: Myanmar Announces a Cease-Fire in Assault Against Kachin Rebels
description: BANGKOK  After weeks of intense fighting near the border with China, the Myanmar government on Friday announced what appeared to be a unilateral cease-fire in its offensive against ethnic Kachin rebels. The government also said it would pursue peace talks, but it was unclear how the rebels would react to the governments overtures.

title: Conference Championship Game Matchups
description: San Francisco at Atlanta3 p.m. Eastern, Fox

title: Peripatetic Goalkeeper Lands in Israel
description: The Israeli-born, Canadian-reared goalkeeper Tomer Chencinski signed in December with Maccabi Tel Aviv, the most successful Israeli club, adding to his meteoric rise since leaving Toronto of Major League Soccer in 2007. His contract runs through the 2014-15 season.

title: Comparing the Quality of Care in Medicare Options
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: The Early Word: Guns and the Public
description: In Todays Times:

title: Part 5: Answers to Your Questions About the Fafsa
description: Now that most college applications are in, it is time for those student applicants (and their parents) to submit what may be the most vital piece of their financial aid plans: the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, or Fafsa.

title: Daily Report: Michael Dells Empire in a Buyout Spotlight
description: Michael Dell has quietly built a reputation as one of the smartest investors on Wall Street. By amassing a prodigious portfolio of stocks, companies, real estate and timberland worth over $16 billion, Mr. Dell has reduced his exposure to the volatile technology sector and branched out into businesses as diverse as dentistry and landscaping through his MSD Capital arm, writes Peter Lattman in The New York Times.

title: Querrey Exits, Leaving No American Men in Opens Second Week
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  For the second straight year, no American man made the second week of the Australian Open.

title: Q&A: Taking Screenshots in Windows 8
description: Q.

title: Candace Bushnells Fantasy World, Starring Candace Bushnell
description: The first time I met Candace Bushnell was at a party she hosted in the Time Warner Center for her husband, the dancer Charles Askegard, who was retiring from the New York City Ballet. Bushnell looked beautiful in a sleeveless Versace cocktail dress that showed off her collarbones, toned arms and radiant, faintly tan skin. She was drinking ros through a straw.

title: As Obama Begins Second Term, Majority Approve of His Performance
description: President Obama heads into his second term in office with an overall positive approval rating, but the public remains ambivalent about his handling of the economy.

title: Despite Improving Profits, Morgan Stanleys Path Is Uncertain
description: 8:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Cambodian Strongman and Karaoke King
description: Phnom Penh  Karaoke is big in Cambodia. Very big. Office workers sing and dance the night away while sipping iced beer in windowless, bunker-like karaoke parlors known as KTVs. Younger viewers download the videos directly onto their computers and sing at home.

title: The Breakfast Meeting: Armstrong Comes Clean, and Kucinich Enters the Fox Lair
description: Lance Armstrong finally had his confessional moment Thursday, acknowledging in a television interview with Oprah Winfrey that he had used performance-enhancing drugs for much of his career. Juliet Macur writes in an analysis in The New York Times that the cyclist mixed humility and regret with a resolute rejection of some of the charges against him. Alessandra Stanley, reviewing the show as television fare, called the interview strangely low on energy and emotion, and that while Ms. Winfrey got some answers, she didnt pierce his armor. Brian Stelter writes that getting such a high-profile interview could be a breakthrough moment for Ms. Winfreys struggling network, OWN.

title: Opinion Report: Nimby
description: From the editorial page

title: Friday Reading: A Workout to Regulate Your Appetite
This Inauguration Brought to You by the State of New York
description: President Obamas home states are Hawaii and Illinois, and his second inaugural will be held in Washington, D.C., of course. But the festivities at the Capitol on Monday will have a distinctly New York flair, thanks to the man who is running them: the ultimate New Yorker, Senator Charles E. Schumer.

title: Indian Who Wants to Be a Millionaire Winner Trains Others to Win
description: For those who dream of getting on the game show Kaun Banega Crorepati for its 50 million rupee-prize, one former winner, Anil Kumar Sinha, has a warning: This is no get-rich-quick scheme.

title: Morgan Stanleys Profit Beats Estimates
description: MORGAN STANLEYS PROFIT BEATS ESTIMATES | Morgan Stanley reported a fourth-quarter profit of $481 million or 25 cents a share, including charges. Excluding one-time accounting charges, the firm had a profit of 45 cents a share, beating estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters of 27 cents a share. Revenue was $7 billion in the fourth quarter, up 23 percent from the period a year ago, when the firm reported a per-share loss of 15 cents. Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James P. Gorman, said in a release on Friday that Morgan Stanley had reached a pivot point in its turnaround strategy. The conference call is at 10 a.m.

title: Air-Conditioner Bombs
description: Dear Diary:

title: U.N. Refugee Agency Warns of Crisis in Mali
description: GENEVA  As French and African troops escalated their offensive against Islamist forces in the north of Mali on Friday, the United Nations refugee agency said it was preparing for around 700,000 people to flee the violence, many to neighboring countries.

title: Photos of The Moment | Rick Owens
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Web Tell-All on an Affair Brings Down a Chinese Official
description: BEIJING  Viewed through the lens of the Marxist tenets he so ardently promoted, Yi Junqings relationship with a female researcher would have probably been categorized as exploitive.

title: How Far Will Europeans Support Frances Counter-Jihad?
description: LONDON  It did not require a crystal ball to foresee, as Rendezvous did in our 2013 preview, that Mali would be in the news and that France might be the first to intervene there to counter a perceived terrorist threat to Europe.

title: Shinzo and the Helicopters (Somewhat Wonkish)
description: Shinzo Abes turn toward expansionary policies has, rather oddly, drawn fire from economists you might have expected to be supportive. Adam Posen  who taught me most of what I know about Japan  is against the fiscal stimulus, and wants a sole focus on monetary expansion to end deflation. Richard Koo likes the stimulus but wants to forget about the whole deflation thing.

title: Hiding, Praying, Tied to Bombs: Captives Detail Algerian Ordeal
description: The gunmen, dressed in fatigues and wearing turbans, stormed in well before dawn aboard pickup trucks, announcing their arrival with a burst of gunfire.

title: Skiing vs. Snowboarding: Whats the Coolest Mountain Sport Now?
description: In his New York Times travel article Has Snowboarding Lost Its Edge? Christopher Solomon examines why boarding has lost its mojo over the last several years. He writes:

title: What Were Reading
description: Time Out Chicago: Eating vegan  and trying not to hate it.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Extortionists Versus Con Men
description: Its looking increasingly as if House Republicans wont crash the world economy by refusing to raise the debt ceiling, at least not right now. Score a big one for the White House (provisionally); its bet that it wouldnt need a way to bypass the ceiling is looking like a winner (although it aint over until the tanned guy cries).

title: A Dramas Streaming Premiere
description: EARLY in the new Netflix series House of Cards the narrator and card player Representative Francis Underwood, played by Kevin Spacey, looks straight into the camera and tells viewers: Power is a lot like real estate. Its all about location, location, location. The closer you are to the source, the higher your property value.

title: Lifting the Veil on the Feds 2007 Discussions
description: 1/19/13 | Updated

title: Aaron Swartz and Prosecutorial Discretion
description: At the funeral for 26-year-old tech prodigy Aaron Swartz, who hanged himself last Friday, his grief-stricken father said that Aaron did not commit suicidehe was killed by the government. Legal bloggers have been debating a less literal version of that accusation: Did Mr. Swartzs prosecutors go too far? Did their zeal border on bullying?

title: Q. and A.: Dances With Cranes
description: George Archibald is fondly known as The Man who Dances with Cranes. After helping to found the International Crane Foundationin Baraboo Wis., in 1973, Dr. Archibald earned his reputation for innovative captive breeding through his work with a young whooping crane named Tex in the late 70s.

title: An Argentine Parallel
description: If a corporation or an individual pays some creditors, but not others, bankruptcy lawyers call that a voidable preference. The preference allows the creditor to get more than it would in the collective bankruptcy process, so the extra bit can be recovered by the bankruptcy trustee.

title: In Budget Talks, Getting to Yes
description: The Republican leadership blinked.

title: A Scene of Carnage Is a Movie Theater Again
description: AURORA, Colo.  Some came to the movies limping and on crutches, still hobbled from the fusillade of bullets that cut through bodies and chairs and walls that night in July. They came holding hands and snapping photos, dressed up in blazers to meet the governor or wearing T-shirts emblazoned with the face of a fallen friend.

title: Are Businesses Hesitant to Connect With Hispanic Consumers?
description: As we learned in the recent presidential election, its always a good idea to connect with Hispanic Americans. In many parts of the country, this is as true in business as it is in politics. But for some reason, many businesses seem hesitant to try to appeal to this big and important demographic.

title: I Change, You Change
description: About halfway through her new memoir, Data, a Love Story, Amy Webb pauses to address the reader. Up to this point, the authors online hunt for a husband has yielded little but farcically bad dates. In frustration she begins an analysis involving scatter plots and word clouds to discern the laws of success in online dating. I want to reveal what I found, she tells us, so that you can improve your own dating profile. (Spoiler alert: showing skin is a plus; lengthy About Me sections are a turnoff.) We then follow Webb as she uses her discoveries to lure Mr. Right. And, presumably, we close the book with a sense of how to do the same.

title: Common Core Practice | Aaron Swartz, Endangered Species and Chess in Harlem
description: For a semester now, weve collaborated with a classroom in New Jersey to test and publish three short weekly writing ideas that address Common Core Standards and that are grounded in New York Times content.

title: ... Let No Germ Put Asunder
description: AT their weddings last week, some brides wore white with red  red, sore throats and watery eyes, that is.

title: Paperback Row
description: ROGER WILLIAMS AND THE CREATION OF THE AMERICAN SOUL: Church, State, and the Birth of Liberty,  by John M. Barry. (Penguin, $18.) Williams, the 17th-century Protestant theologian and founder of Rhode Island, is regarded as the original American proponent of liberty of conscience and the separation of church and state. Barry explores the development of these fundamental ideas through the story of Williams, whose course was set in England under the influence of Francis Bacon, Edward Coke, Oliver Cromwell and John Milton.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE WORLD UNTIL YESTERDAY: What Can We Learn From Traditional Societies?,  by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $36.) To answer his subtitle, the Guns, Germs, and Steel author cites child rearing, dispute resolution and the treatment of the elderly.

title: The Making of a Justice
description: When Sonia Sotomayor was 7 years old and hospitalized with diabetes, she learned to give herself insulin shots by practicing on an orange. At home, her mother showed her how to light a burner on the stove with a match, and together they would fill a pot with water to cover the syringe and needle. Sonia was taught to wait for a boil and then to wait five minutes more. The daily shots became her way of fending off conflict between her parents: Her fathers hands trembled because of his alcoholism, and her mother, a nurse who worked long hours, would get angry when she couldnt rely on him. The last thing I wanted was for them to fight about me, Sotomayor relates in her new memoir. It then dawned on me: If I needed to have these shots every day for the rest of my life, the only way Id survive was to do it myself.

title: Gerald R. Ford Library Hires Wikipedian in Residence
description: Gerald R. Ford may have governed during a time of economic stagnation, but his library has just laid claim to a cutting-edge distinction: becoming the first presidential depository to employ an official Wikipedian in residence.

title: Days Before Housing Bust, Fed Doubted Need to Act
description: WASHINGTON  When Federal Reserve policy makers convened in August 2007, one of the nations largest subprime mortgage lenders had just filed for bankruptcy, and another was struggling to find the money it needed to survive.

title: As Dispute Over Islands Escalates, Japan and China Send Fighter Jets to the Scene
description: BEIJING  The action in the skies over the East China Sea started simply enough.

title: More Room for Doubt
description: THE first thing John Patrick Shanley will tell you about the opera Doubt is that he did it out of guilt. He agreed to a meeting with the composer Douglas J. Cuomo intending to say no, he did not want to rewrite his Pulitzer Prize-winning play turned Oscar-nominated movie as an opera libretto. But then he forgot all about it and stood Mr. Cuomo up, not even checking his cellphone to see the politely insistent reminders.

title: A Fast Start, but No Race to the Future
description: IN a video posted on YouTube last summer the gifted violinist Jennifer Koh can be seen offering a poised, passionate account of the first movement from Paganinis Violin Concerto No. 1 with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The excellence of Ms. Kohs playing will surprise no one who knows the quality and integrity of her work. What is unusual is that Ms. Koh, who will play Lutoslawskis bracing Chain 2 with the New York Philharmonic beginning Thursday, offered such a splashy showpiece in her Chicago Symphony debut.

title: Truman and Obama
description: My Sunday column on President Obamas foreign policy synthesis (as manifested in the nominations of Chuck Hagel and John Brennan) argued that he presently enjoys more trust  and with it, more latitude  on foreign policy than any Democrat since Harry Truman.Daniel Larison calls this invocation of Trumana strange anachronism, and elaborates:

title: New Owners for Vintage Hits?
description: An old copyright law stipulated that musicians who released work starting in 1978 could invoke a termination rights clause and regain full ownership over it 35 years later  in other words, now. Ben Ratliff talks to The Timess music-business reporter Ben Sisario on how new rights-reversion issues might shift the power balance between artists and their corporate minders.

title: Chief Keef Sentenced to 60 Days for Probation Violation
description: Chief Keef, the teenage Chicago rapper who often presents a street-tough image, was visibly shaken and pleaded for leniency when he was sentenced to 60 days in juvenile detention on Thursday for violating his probation on a gun charge, The Chicago Sun-Times reported.

title: Rushing Into a Mortgage Can Prove Costly
description: THE housing market in the United States is starting to show signs of improvement. Mortgage rates remain low. New construction is picking up. And the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issued guidelines last week aimed at protecting consumers from the types of mortgages  like the ones that offered deceptive teaser rates or required no documentation from borrowers  that contributed to the financial crash.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 18
Squashs Preppy Problem
description: I picked up squash when I was 8 because of a divorce  not my parents but that of a friend of theirs who stayed with us after being kicked out of his house by his wife. He must have lost his squash partners in the split, because he somehow persuaded my parents, both committed leftists, to do an unconventionally conventional thing  join the Heights Casino, a somewhat elitist, old racket club in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Should Your Neighbors Allergy Be Your Concern?
description: Our daughter and her husband own their home, and on their property, they keep a beehive as a hobby. A family of four just moved in next door (a father, mother and two small children). The father told our daughter that three members of the family are allergic to bee stings. He is concerned about the beehive. Assuming that keeping bees on your property is legal, what should prevail here  the law or ethics? NAME WITHHELD

title: Who Made Those False Eyelashes?
description: One day in 1916, while filming Intolerance, D. W. Griffith studied an actress in a Babylonian costume and felt something wasnt right. Seena Owens eyes, he said, should be twice as large and supernatural. He ordered his wigmaker to use spirit gum to glue a pair of lashes made from human hair onto Owens eyelids. One morning she arrived at the studio with her eyes swollen nearly shut, the actress Lillian Gish, who was also in the movie, wrote in her memoir. Fortunately, Mr. Griffith had already shot the important scenes. Within a decade, false lashes became standard equipment for actresses  and for flappers who imitated the baby doll eyes that they saw on-screen.

title: Jessica Lange Carries a Big Stick
description: The Big Profile

title: January Is Hollywoods Very Own Leper Colony
description: Which came first: January or unbearably bad movies?

title: John Mackey, the Kale King
description: In your new book, Conscious Capitalism, you write that Whole Foods sees its customers as its most important stakeholders and that the company is obsessed with their happiness. The biggest complaint I hear about Whole Foods is how expensive it is. Why not drop prices to make your customers happier?  People always complain about prices being too high. Whole Foods prices have dropped every year as we get to be larger and we have economies of scale. Also, people are not historically well informed about food prices. Were only spending about 7 percent of our disposable personal income on food. Fifty years ago, it was nearly 16 percent.

title: Annotating the Feds 2007 Deliberations
description: Crucial passages shed light on the debates, decisions and judgment of Ben S. Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and other policy makers as the financial crisis heated up between August and December 2007.

title: Algeria's Response to a Hostage Crisis
description: TimesCast: A dramatic Saharan raid, with little hard information. | Lance Armstrongs confession is Oprah Winfreys victory. | A charismatic preacher carves out a place in Pakistans political scene.

title: In the Shadow of Oprah, a Sundance Ovation and Musical Interludes
description: PARK CITY, Utah  The most highly anticipated production onscreen on the opening night of the Sundance Film Festival was, of course, the Lance Armstrong interview.

title: The Canal to Nowhere
description: By January 1863, Union forces had successfully pounded their way down the Mississippi River to Memphis, and had pushed upstream from the Gulf of Mexico to Baton Rouge, La. The only footholds the Confederates had left on the river were Vicksburg, Miss., and Port Hudson, La. As long as they controlled those vital points, the eastern Confederacy and its western Trans-Mississippi Department remained connected. If the Union could capture them, the Confederacy would be split in two, its interior line disrupted and the Mississippi River opened once again to Northern trade.

title: John Mayer Sings in Public for First Time After Vocal Troubles
description: Having struggled with vocal problems that forced him to cancel a tour last year, the songwriter John Mayer sang in public for the first time in nearly two years on Wednesday evening, performing at a fund-raiser for firefighters in Montana, The Bozeman Daily Chronicle reported.

title: John Galliano Begins His Fashion Recovery
description: John Galliano is stepping out of fashions penalty box.

title: Mother Admits She Put Pistol in 7-Year-Olds Backpack, Police Say
description: The mother of a 7-year-old who took a handgun to his public elementary school in Queens was arrested on Friday, the police said.

title: Big Music Companies Are Said to Pursue a Top Dance Promoter
description: Last year, the growing popularity of electronic dance music, or E.D.M., brought out the deal-makers of the music industry as if drawn to the scent of prey. A handful of big dance promoters were sold, and one media mogul, Robert F.X. Sillerman, announced plans to build a $1 billion dance music empire. But the year ended without any big, market-defining deal.

title: Wheelies: The Chemistry Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: On Our Radar: A Call to Halt Arctic Drilling
description: John Podesta, a former chief of staff in the Clinton administration, and Carol Browner, President Obamas former climate change adviser, call on the president to block Shells drilling plans in the Arctic. Following a series of mishaps and errors, as well as overwhelming weather conditions, it has become clear that there is no safe and responsible way to drill for oil and gas in the Arctic Ocean, they write. [Bloomberg View]

title: Popcast: New Owners for Vintage Hits?
description: January 2013 is perhaps a month like any other to you. But in the music business, its the calm before the storm.

title: This Realm, This Engla Land
description: After Richard III, last of the Plantagenets, was slain at Bosworth Field in 1485, his body was said to have been taken to the church of Greyfriars in Leicester, but after that nothing reliable is heard about what became of it. He is the only English king, after the time of the Normans, who has never been placed within a royal tomb, Peter Ackroyd writes in Foundation, his rambling, affectionate new history of the remote English past. In September, archaeologists from the University of Leicester dug up a parking lot at the long-razed Greyfriars site and found, well preserved as if by a carefully wrapped shroud, the bones of a man whose skull had been hacked open and whose spine was curved, as Richards was said to have been. Sensation ensued among ordinary Britons, who flocked to comment on online forums and thronged the excavation site.

title: Reeling in the Years
description: My father, who was a scrupulous and seasoned engineer, said on one of our last road trips that there was a part of a person that was always 17. Hed been telling me another story about his youth on the farm, and he was grinning at the time. I could feel Jim Harrison grinning the same way in his glorious novella The River Swimmer, which celebrates the manifold lessons of that heady year by following the outsize adventures of 17-year-old Thad, a strong, dreamy farm boy who is inexorably drawn to water.

title: Second Selves
description: In an interview that was published in Bomb magazine a couple of years ago, a journalist admitted to Adam Phillips, the British psychoanalyst and writer, that though he loved Phillipss many books and essays, he could never actually remember anything that he read in them. Phillips was delighted. Thats the reading experience Ive always loved. Certainly, when people say to me, as they often have done, I cant remember anything afterward, I think, Great, thats the point!

title: Up Front
description: Sheila Heti, who reviews Adam Phillipss Missing Out: In Praise of the Unlived Life in this weeks issue, shares his interest not only in unlived lives but also in the lives of others. Writing fiction is a good way to inhabit other minds, if not other lives, Heti said in an e-mail. Her most recent novel, How Should a Person Be?, is told from the perspective of Sheila, a young playwright eager to make art and attain fame, who is not to be confused with the author  at least not completely. For the Sheila of the novel, being famous is synonymous with being blessed. In a religious context, youre blessed because God watches over you, but in the secular context the biggest thing that could watch over you is everybody, Heti explained. She mistakenly imagines this blessing will absolve her from being in difficult and painful relationships with others, and instead she can just kind of float along, untouched and beloved.

title: Louise Glcks Metamorphoses
description: Poetry has always been the handmaiden of mythology, and vice versa. Sometimes poets are in the business of collecting and tweaking existing myths, as with Ovids Metamorphoses and the Poetic Edda. Other times poetry applies a mythological glamour to stories and characters from history, legend or even other myths (the hero of the Aeneid is a minor character from the Iliad). Then there are poets who equate the idea of myth with the supposedly irrational essence of poetry itself. Here is Robert Graves in 1948: No poet can hope to understand the nature of poetry unless he has had a vision of the Naked King crucified to the lopped oak, and watched the dancers, red-eyed from the acrid smoke of the sacrificial fires, . . . with a monotonous chant of Kill! kill! kill! and Blood! blood! blood!  Which might sound more like a strip club picnic gone badly awry, but you get the idea.

title: Road Ready
description: In January 1949, Jack Kerouac failed to appear for an afternoon date with a woman called Pauline. He had told Allen Ginsberg he planned to marry her  the finest woman Ill ever know  once she had unshackled herself from her truck-driver husband, who, according to Joyce Johnson, was accustomed to slapping her around to keep her in line. In the meantime, Kerouac began an affair with Adele Morales (later to become the second Mrs. Norman Mailer). His failure to keep the rendezvous with Pauline, however, had nothing to do with affection for Adele; rather, he had overslept after a night of sex games with Luanne Henderson, whom Jacks muse Neal Cassady had married when she was 15, and who, according to their friend Hal Chase, was quite easy to get . . . into bed. The tryst had been engineered by Cassady, who was hoping to watch, Johnson says, to show Luanne, by then 18, how little she meant to him. Two days later, Kerouac called on Ginsberg and found Luanne covered with bruises from a beating Neal had given her. Johnson describes Kerouac as shocked by the sight; nevertheless, they all went out to hear bebop, partly financed by money stolen by Cassady. In response to being jilted, Pauline confessed her affair to her husband, who tried to burn her on the stove. Kerouac described her in his journal as a whore. All the while, Ginsberg can be heard in the background: How did we get here, angels?

title: Fame and Misfortune
description: Black Dahlia & White Rose is Joyce Carol Oatess 25th book of short stories. Her immense productivity  the torrent of novels and stories that began in the early 1960s  means that every release meets with the same question: Does she have anything fresh and urgent to reveal at this point in her long and very fine career? The answer, with her latest, may depend on how you regard Oatess descriptions of older women.

title: A World of Its Own
description: What if conventional wisdom has it exactly wrong? What if Haiti, instead of being mired in retrograde customs and superstitions the developed world cast off centuries ago, is in fact ahead of the curve? What if, as Amy Wilentz posits in her excellent Farewell, Fred Voodoo, Haiti has always been the most modern of nations, at the forefront of every major historical trend since Columbus dropped anchor off the Hispaniolan coast?

title: Armstrongs Critics Largely Unmoved by Interview
description: Whatever its impact on the broader public, the first of Lance Armstrongs two nights of televised confession appeared to have little positive effect on the cycling and antidoping communities.

title: Inside the List
description: THE MOTIVE: David Baldaccis latest novel, The Forgotten, is at No. 12 in its eighth week on the hardcover fiction list. Its hard to imagine Baldaccis fans looking up from the books breathy sentences  The smell of sex was all over her. He wondered if she realized that  to ask themselves what compels Baldacci to face the blank page every day; really, isnt the smell of sex enough? Be that as it may, anybody curious can find Baldaccis thoughts on the matter in Why We Write, a new collection of interviews edited by Meredith Maran, in which 20 well-known authors try to analyze what, exactly, keeps them at it.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: LENINS KISSES  By Yan Lianke.Translated by Carlos Rojas.  Grove, $27.

title: Dead Reckoning
description: Old homicide cops never die; they just shuffle off to the cold case department. Thats where Michael Connellys maverick, Harry Bosch, found himself after his ill-considered resignation from the Los Angeles Police Department. The same spirit of insubordination periodically lands a career detective like Jussi Adler-Olsens Carl Morck in some dead-end division like Department Q. And in the honorable tradition of the watch commander known as the Oracle in Joseph Wambaughs Hollywood Station procedurals, every veteran seems to feel duty-bound to take one last crack at an unsolved murder before he retires. Come to think of it, every active homicide assignment involving a longtime serial killer seems to lead to the cold case files.

title: A Scream. A Splash. Send in the Mops.
description: NEW YORK Fashion Week is around the corner, and as any aspiring model knows it can be a cutthroat scene. Ask any of the girls who walk for the House of von Macram. That is if theyre not already dead.

title: A Nod to Film Music, a Changeable Band and a Swedish Poet
description: Petra Haden

title: Streisand to Receive Film Society Honor
description: 12:35 p.m. | Updated  Barbra Streisand will receive the annual Chaplin Award at a ceremony in April, the Film Society of Lincoln Center said today. Among Ms. Streisands many accomplishments on screen and stage, the society singled out in particular the 1983 Yentl, which was the first film to credit a woman as writer, director, producer and star.

title: This Weeks Movies: Jan. 18
description: In this weeks video, Times critics look at the crime drama Broken City with Mark Wahlberg, Luv with Common and the documentary Greenwich Village: Music That Defined a Generation. See all of this weeks reviews here. And watch more This Weeks Movies videos here.

title: Courts Are Right to Hold Argentina to Equal Debt Treatment
description: Harry Tether is a retired managing director at JPMorgan Chase.

title: Site to Be Seen | Luxup
description: If James Corsellis and company have their way, Luxup.com is going to make it nearly impossible for anyone truly hungry for haute fashion not to score exclusive deals and memorable shopping experiences  long before theyre available to the masses.

title: Tweets From Milan Mens Fashion Week
description: The Paris mens shows are already underway, but heres a look back at some of the tweets from the Milan shows that got our attention.

title: Shumperts Return Boosts Knicks Defense, Depth
description: If Thursdays Knicks game felt a little retro, it may have been because of Iman Shumperts appearance in his first game of the season. These days, the second-year guard keeps his hair in the style of a high-top fade, which was ubiquitous in the late 80s and early 90s. Shumperts No. 21 was previously worn by Gerald Wilkins, who sported a similar haircut. In fact, Wilkins was nicknamed Doug after rapper Doug E. Fresh because both had high-top fades.

title: Jan. 20  26
description: THOUGH Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II had many Broadway successes  Oklahoma and South Pacific among them  their 1957 musical version of Cinderella was made for television and, until now, has never been produced on Broadway. But RODGERS & HAMMERSTEINS CINDERELLA, while promising to honor the soaring romance of the original, features a new book by the witty Douglas Carter Beane ( Xanadu, Lysistrata Jones) that includes some modern touches and, we can assume, a quirky twist or two. (The shows Web site features the tag line Glass slippers are so back.) Laura Osnes (Bonnie and Clyde) plays the title role  Julie Andrews did the honors in the 1957 version  and Santino Fontana (The Importance of Being Earnest) will portray her rather neurotic prince. The rest of the company includes Harriet Harris as Cinderellas stepmother and Victoria Clark as her fairy godmother, with Mark Brokaw (The Lyons) directing. Previews begin Friday. Opens March 3, Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, (212) 239-6200; cinderellaonbroadway.com .STEVEN McELROY

title: Check Me Out
description: Busted by the two-way mirror.

title: New Yorkers Caught Checking Themselves Out
description: The passers-by who lingered to adjust a collar or smooth down unruly hair never knew that a photographer was on the other side of the two-way mirror, dressed in black clothes, a ski mask and gloves so his own reflection wouldnt show up in the pictures he was taking. According to the photographer, Brad Farwell, the pedestrians he observed at four different Manhattan locations  the Bowery, Midtown, NoLIta and the Lower East Side  were much the same. But the time they spent looking at themselves differed, depending on the day. Sunday Downtown was a time for leisurely strolling and reflecting on what they saw in the mirror. On a weekday in Midtown, though, the looks were the most unguarded, because they were so much quicker, Farwell says. The checking themselves out wasnt about ego. It was more of an appraisal. They were sort of looking at themselves as they really were.

title: Next on Oprah: More of the Same
description: So now that the Great Lance Confession has finally been broadcast, the big remaining question is not whether you will go back for a second helping of arrogance souffl in Friday nights not-so-dramatic conclusion of Oprah Winfreys two-night bonanza (heres betting you wont). No, the question is: What exactly did all of that accomplish? Do you know anything more Armstrong-related than you did before, even if you watched every disingenuous minute of it?

title: Theater Reopens in Aurora
description: The newly remodeled and renamed Century Aurora cinema opened for the first time since the shooting.

title: Off the Charts: A Slow Recovery Is Better Than None
description: In 2012, U.S. industrial production surpassed its 2006 average for the first time since the downturn began in late 2007.

title: Inside the Feds 2007 Deliberations
description: On Friday the Federal Reserve released the transcripts of its discussions in 2007, the year the housing market, the financial markets, and the broader economy began to unravel. Focusing on the crucial period from August to December, reporters from The Times shared their findings on what the transcripts reveal in the blog entries and tweets below.

title: The OWN Channel Gets a Boost
description: The Times's Brian Stelter takes a look at Lance Armstrong's confessional interview with Oprah Winfrey, which may be a turning point for her low-rated OWN cable channel.

title: Rethinking the Dandy Man
description: We love coincidences. This season its the leopard spots that appeared in Kim Joness Louis Vuitton show (for cashmere and mink needle-punched coats and fur trim) and in sweaters at Raf Simons, noticed in his showroom but not on the runway.

title: Gussie Moran, a Tennis Star Who Wore a Daring Wimbledon Outfit, Dies at 89
description: Gussie Moran, who as a ranked American tennis player in 1949 caused an international stir and gained worldwide fame for competing at Wimbledon while wearing a short skirt and lace-trimmed underwear, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 89.

title: Your Twitter Tips for Going Vegan
description: In this weeks Well column, How to Go Vegan,, we asked you to send in your favorite tips and tricks for adopting a solely plant-based diet on Twitter. We received a range of responses, from quirky ingredient combinations that replicate a nonvegan dish to simple mantras to get you in a vegan frame of mind. Here are some of our favorites. To see the entire list of submissions, visit the hashtag, #vegantips.

title: Algerias Role in Hostage Crisis
description: The Timess Steven Erlanger discusses the lack of information surrounding an Algerian military response to a hostage situation at a remote gas field facility.

title: A Warhol Film Surfaces, but Is It His?
description: ANDY WARHOL created movies by design, by chance, by mistake, and sometimes by doing nothing at all.

title: In Canada, Honda Unveils Gear Concept
description: In a panel discussion with designers at the Eyes on Design awards presentation at the Detroit auto show on Tuesday afternoon, Dave Marek, design director at Honda R&D Americas, talked about the invigorating effects of a move.

title: Armed in Kentucky
description: When I went to a gun store in Lexington, Ky., recently to shoot a variety of guns, I knew I was in gun country. What I hadnt quite appreciated was the extent to which I had wound up in the beating heart of gun country. But after I got back to New York, my new friend Andrew Silton, a former financial consultant who writes a terrific blog, Meditations on Money Management  and whose analysis of Cerberus and the Freedom Group I quoted in my December 21 column  sent me some eye-opening statistics. He compiled a list of the 50 states ranked according to how many background checks for firearm purchases had taken place in each state. At the very top is Kentucky, with 15 million checks over the last decade  in a state with only 4.4 million people. That is 3.41 searches per person.

title: Cleaning Leeks
description: Sooner or later there will come a point where you will need to clean a leek. Melissa Clark shows how.

title: Roasting Renders Leeks Tender and Versatile
description: LEEKS AND I have been best friends for years. Weve done everything together. Sauting, steaming, poaching, frying, braising, baking into a gratin and simmering into soup  that allium and I have had many adventures.

title: Timeline: The Feds 2007 Discussions
description: The Federal Reserve has released the transcripts of its 2007 meetings, when the housing bubble started to burst and the global financial crisis began.

title: When Old Friends Meet the New Baby
description: My daughter celebrated one month on this planet just last week. She is a glorious little babe, happy and chubby and sleeping and eating like a champ. We feel especially lucky that shes doing so well, because as first-time parents, my husband and I still feel like were so green, we glow like a neon sign. We regularly consult Google to make sure that nothing bad will happen to our girl after hearing her grunt while breathing on the baby monitor. Im no teenage mom  I got pregnant a week shy of my 30th birthday  but were the first in our close circle to have children, so to our childless pals, we are fonts of superior pregnancy and baby knowledge.

title: New Tribune Chief Signals Greater Television Focus
description: Two-thirds of the Tribune Companys revenues currently come from the newspapers it owns. But that most likely wont be true a year from now.

title: A Les Miz Medley at the Oscars? Possibly (But Count Out Russell Crowe)
description: Will the Oscars put to the test all those tales of the Les Misrables stars singing live? The Daily Mail in Les Miz-mad England reports that Samantha Barks, who made a rare stage-to-screen transition as Eponine, is in talks to perform on the telecast with her co-stars. Possibilities include group numbers like One Day More or Do You Hear the People Sing with Amanda Seyfried and Eddie Redmayne, or a medley with Anne Hathaways show-stopping I Dreamed a Dream and Hugh Jackmans Who Am I? (or, more likely, Suddenly, an Oscar nominee for best song).

title: Obama to Turn Campaign Machinery to Promoting Policy
description: WASHINGTON  A new political operation created to advance President Obamas agenda in his second term will be allowed to raise unlimited money and accept corporate contributions, but officials said Friday the donations will be disclosed.

title: Comme des Garons: Fall 2013 Menswear
description: Paris

title: Fiscal Affinity Fraud
description: Innocent that I am, I never heard the term affinity fraud until the Bernie Madoff affair hit the news. But once you hear it, the concept is obvious: people are most easily conned when theyre getting their disinformation from someone who seems to be part of their tribe, one way or another.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Zlatne Uste Golden Festival in Brooklyn celebrates Balkan and Gypsy music at Grand Prospect Hall, 263 Prospect Avenue, in Park Slope. Events will run on Friday from 7:30 p.m. to 12:30 a.m., and tickets are $35 at the door or $30 in advance online. On Saturday, the festival will run from 6 p.m. to 2 a.m., and tickets are $55 at the door and $48 in advance. Children ages 12 and under are free.

title: Nokia Lets You 3-D Print Your Own Phone Case
description: Nokia is turning its Lumia phones into a bit of an arts-and-crafts project. Now you can print your own cases for them.

title: Comme des Garcons
description: Mens fall 2013 collections in Paris.

title: Seattles New Showrooms
description: Once home to the citys original Auto Row, the Pike-Pine Corridor is now the epicenter of the popular Capitol Hill neighborhood.

title: The Sweet Spot | Quizmasters
description: A. O. Scott and David Carr test their audience, and themselves, matching TV shows with their particular places. If they say Minneapolis, you say ...

title: Action Star With Savoir-Faire and a Killer Kick
description: TO paraphrase Paul Simon, every generation sends an action hero up the box office charts, whether it was the swashbuckling Douglas Fairbanks in the silent era, the stoic John Wayne midcentury, the hip Steve McQueen in the 1960s and 70s, or the musclebound Sylvester Stallone in the 80s.

title: In a Mobile Kitchen, Bringing Brooklyn Love to a Presidents Choir
description: When the Grammy award-winning Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir performs The Battle Hymn of the Republic at President Obamas second inauguration on Monday, one thing is for sure: They are not going to be singing on empty stomachs.

title: The Sweet Spot: Jan. 18
description: This week, A. O. Scott and David Carr test the abilities of their viewers, and themselves, to match television shows with their respective settings.

title: Medelln, From Sky to Street
description: Soar above the city and zoom down to ground level to see nature, neighborhoods and more.

title: I Just Got Back From Medelln!
description: IF Medelln is still a city that puts its visitors on guard, you wouldnt know it from my traveling companions choice of footwear. I cant believe youre wearing pink sneakers here! I exclaimed to my friend Ryan, minutes after we arrived at the airport of Colombias second biggest city. Theyre not pink, Ryan told me. Theyre salmon khaki. Theyre pueblo rose.

title: For Obama, Second Term Brings a New Look
description: The White House has released the new official portrait of President Obama. Shot on Dec. 6, by White House photographer Pete Souza, the portrait features Mr. Obama, smiling broadly, standing in the Oval Office. The portrait is a slight departure from the 2009 version, which featured a close-up shot of then President-elect Obama, with a solemn expression and a blander background.

title: In a Minnesota Bog, a Festival of Birds
description: ON an early winters evening in northern Minnesota, a convoy of five snappy yellow school buses rolled out into the dusk. From the windows, the distant horizon of pointy evergreens and wide-open expanses of frosted wetlands looked like a frozen dead zone. But we were on a tour to see life  bird life.

title: A Christian Pioneer of Home Schooling Looks to Its Future
description: Back in 1993, when Mary Pride and her husband appeared with their eight children in the first issue of Wired magazine, it was hard to say what seemed strangest: that the Prides were Protestants who rejected birth control, that they home-schooled their children or that in home schooling they relied heavily on computer software. All those choices would have seemed bravely countercultural, or just weird.

title: The Lights and Nights of Reykjavik
description: THE sky above Reykjavik was as dark as black ice, save for a handful of diamond stars. As a cutting wind whipped off the frigid sea and blew down the narrow streets lined with brightly painted storefronts, shivering pedestrians tightened their scarves and scurried into cozy bars and restaurants to find warmth.

title: Private Equitys Penguins on Parade
description: Twitter cant seem to get enough of Stephen A. Schwarzmans penguins.

title: In Reversal, House G.O.P. Agrees to Lift Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON  Backing down from their hard-line stance, House Republicans said Friday that they would agree to lift the federal governments statutory borrowing limit for three months, with a requirement that both chambers of Congress pass a budget in that time to clear the way for negotiations on long-term deficit reduction.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Lawrence Wright discusses Scientology; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Emily Bazelon talks about Sonia Sotomayors new memoir; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Drought Points Up Critical Role of Waterways
description: When people think of the Mississippi River, they might have visions of Mark Twain and old steamboats. But few Americans understand the vast amounts of shipping traffic that still makes its way up and down the river, part of the worlds largest navigable inland waterway.

title: The Secrets of Grand Central
description: In his new book Grand Central: How a Train Station Transformed America, Sam Roberts of The Times goes behind the scenes at Grand Central Terminal ahead of the centennial.

title: Treasury to Begin Selling Off Its Remaining G.M. Stake
description: The Treasury Department said on Friday that it would begin selling off its remaining 19 percent stake in General Motors, as part of the Obama administrations plan to unwind its bailout of the automaker.

title: John Geddes, Managing Editor, Is Leaving The New York Times
description: 2:37 p.m. | Updated John M. Geddes, a managing editor at The New York Times for the last decade and one of the top three editors at the newspaper, has decided to leave. In a note to the staff on Friday afternoon, Mr. Geddes, 61, said he was accepting a buyout package and would depart in the next few months after helping the newspapers masthead through its transition.

title: Cirque du Soleil Announces Layoffs
description: Cirque du Soleil will be laying off 400 people starting at the end of January, mostly at its Montreal headquarters, the troupe has announced.

title: In Average Pay, New York Workers Trail Counterparts in Several Big Cities
description: Is this why some California cities are going bankrupt?

title: One Comics Identity Crisis
description: In his first television special Dane Cook charged onstage wearing a black tank top and crouched like a giant frog aiming to catch a fly. I think every comic wants to be a rock n roll star, he said in that 2000 show. I do. Thats my dream.

title: Car Sales Worldwide Are Slow to Rebound
description: THE United States industrial economy has finally returned to where it was in 2006, something that few other major developed countries have accomplished. But car sales, a sign of consumer economic health and confidence, remain well below the level of six years ago across the spectrum of countries. In Europe, car sales fell last year to the lowest level since 1995.

title: Tough Flu Season in U.S., Especially for the Elderly
description: This years flu season is shaping up to be worse than average and particularly bad for the elderly, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the nations top federal disease-control official, said Friday.

title: Parodies in Israeli Politics
description: As Israel faces another election, television shows featuring political satire compete with traditional advertisements as vehicles to shape voter opinions.

title: Honda Recalling 748,000 Odysseys and Pilots
description: Honda is recalling about 748,000 of its popular sport utility vehicles and minivans because the drivers side air bag may not deploy properly, the automaker informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Lawmaker Seeks Details on Foreclosure Reviews
description: The high cost of reviewing foreclosures at big banks has ignited an inquiry by one member of Congress.

title: A Look Ahead to Obamas Inauguration
description: David Leonhardt, the Washington bureau chief, hosts a preview of President Obamas second inauguration. Reports from Washington, Chicago and California.

title: Book Review Podcast: Inside Scientology
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Michael Kinsley reviews Going Clear, Lawrence Wrights new book about Scientology. Mr. Kinsley writes:

title: Photos of The Moment | Louis Vuitton
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Labels of Married Life, in a New Light
description: I NOW pronounce you husband and wife, the minister said to Anthony and me 22 years ago. Although I was thrilled about what we were undertaking, I cringed. Being pronounced a wife felt archaic and just plain weird. I went with it, squeamish but thankful that at least wed gotten past the days of man and wife.

title: Not With A Bang But With A Whimper
description: When youre wrong, youre wrong. I thought that by ruling out any way to bypass the debt limit, the White House was setting itself up, at least potentially, for an ignominious cave-in. But it appears that the strategy has worked, and its the Republicans giving up. Im happy to concede that the president and team called this one right.

title: Down and Out in Paris
description: Fashion has turned decidedly away from the corporate world this season. It wasnt that long ago that Raf Simons and Kim Jones of Louis Vuitton were making elite power statements; during the recession, Mr. Simons predicted that young men, concerned about jobs, would want tailored clothes. Other designers didnt stint on the polish.

title: Sauers Return from Concussion Still Uncertain
description: GREENBURGH  The one injury blemish on an otherwise healthy Rangers roster heading into the abbreviated 2013 N.H.L. season is defenseman Michael Sauer, who is still out indefinitely after the concussion he suffered more than 13 months ago.

title: Will China Have to Abandon Its One-Child Rule?
description: Chinese officials released data on Friday showing that the countrys economy grew faster than previously anticipated at the end of last year. Investors greeted that news enthusiastically while virtually ignoring another, more worrying development: The countrys working age population has officially started declining. In 2012, for the first time in recent memory, the number of Chinese between the ages of 15 and 59 fell  by 3.45 million to 937.27 million.

title: Algerian TV Interviews Workers Freed From Gas Facility
description: Algerias ENTV news channel interviewed a number of local and foreign workers who had been held captive in a gas facility and were freed on Friday, with some of them expressing relief from hospital beds or a bus in this video.

title: Timeline on Mali
description: Mali has been in turmoil since 2012, as events there and in Algeria raised the possibility of drawing an increasing number of foreign countries into direct involvement. Below, a timeline of the two crises.

title: Exclusive | 2628 Broadway
description: A whimsical glass penthouse on the Upper West Side is about to enter the market for $12.5 million.

title: A Claustrophobes Pop-and-Rock Nirvana
description: A whimsical glass penthouse on the Upper West Side with forever views, absolute privacy, and a rock n roll decorating theme  even the wallpaper in the downstairs powder room is a compendium of vintage Rolling Stone magazine covers  is about to enter the market for the first time since its original owner, Jeff Grady, bought and customized it in 2007. The asking price for the four-bedroom three-and-a-half-bath multipillared pop-art playpen in the sky is $12.5 million.

title: Finding Advice for More Modest Retirement Investments
description: If youre perfectly capable of running your own retirement savings, selecting the right mix of low-cost investments, rebalancing at the right time and not buying and selling out of fear or greed, then good for you.

title: Armstrong Confession Draws 4.3 Million Viewers to Oprahs Network
description: 4:45 p.m. | Updated  Lance Armstrongs confession to Oprah Winfrey played out in the sports media for three days by the time she was shown on television asking, Did you ever take banned substances to enhance your cycling performance? and he was shown saying yes.

title: N.F.L. Coaching Carousel Stops: Who Won?
description: A few whirlwind weeks after black Monday, the N.F.L. coaching carousel has filled all eight vacant jobs, with Arizona making the final move Thursday by hiring Bruce Arians. That one bucked the odds by perhaps being the most logical of the bunch, with Arians having done a terrific job as interim coach of the Colts during Chuck Paganos cancer treatment.

title: What Is Middle Class in Manhattan?
description: DRIVE through almost any neighborhood around the country, and class divisions are as clear as the gate around one community or the grittiness of another. From the footprint of the house to the gleam on the car in the driveway, it is not hard to guess the economic status of the people who live there.

title: How to Get Reasonably Priced Help With Investments
description: This weekends Your Money column is of a piece with several Ive written in the past, all revolving around the question of how to get competent people to help you with your investments for a reasonable price.

title: After a Die-Off, Runts to the Rescue
description: It doesnt take an expert to understand that logging and violent storms cause massive damage to forests. What is less obvious, however, is the devastating effect that the removal of trees and vegetation can have on streams and lakes.

title: Kids Draw the News: Bus Strike Comic Strip
description: Updated | Feb. 4, 2013 We are no accepting submissions for the Kids Draw the News assignment about New York Citys school bus drivers strike.

title: British Leader Sees Wider Threat in Algeria Attack
description: LONDON  With more than 60 hostages still missing and many feared dead, Prime Minister David Cameron told Parliament on Friday that the Qaeda-linked attack on a remote Algerian gas installation demonstrated the need for Britain and its Western allies, including the United States, to direct more of their diplomatic, military and intelligence resources to the intensifying threat emanating from the ungoverned space of the North African desert, treating it with as much concern as the terrorist challenge in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: In a Dingy Studio, Making Hugh Jackman Audition
description: No matter where the Les Misrables folks end up on the Oscar stage, it will be a long ways from their humble beginnings with the movie. Yes, humble: All of the marquee singer-actors  even Hugh Jackman, known Broadway star  auditioned live for Tom Hoopers film, in a variety of rundown, run-of-the-mill audition studios.

title: The Long, Cold Slog
description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

title: Goldman Awards Blankfein $13.3 Million in Stock
description: Lloyd C. Blankfein is getting a raise.

title: Among University of California Applicants, Latinos Take the Lead
description: As colleges continue to review  and tally  the thousands of applications that have poured into their admission offices this school year, a demographic milestone has cropped up in California.

title: Girls Ratings Down From Season 1 Premiere
description: With the amount of media attention that the HBO series Girls has received, it would be easy to assume that the show is watched by millions of curious television viewers. But so far, the news medias enthusiasm for the show has not translated into increased ratings.

title: Updates on the Gun Violence Debate
description: The Lede is following the debate on gun violence in the wake of the shootings in Newtown, Conn., with reports from our correspondents and from around the Web.

title: Drill Team Beats the Odds
description: Chicago drill team overcomes street violence to earn a spot in Obama's inaugural parade.

title: Is There Any Way to Defeat Venus and Serena Williams?
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  When Venus and Serena Williams step onto the court at the Australian Open on Saturday afternoon, they will tower over their second-round womens doubles opponents in ways other than height.

title: Nothing Regular About This N.H.L. Season
description: Seven seasons have passed since the salary cap era began in 2005-6, and each season has produced a different Stanley Cup winner. The N.H.L. is unpredictable in normal seasons.
