description: The rap on Tomas Berdych is that he has no Plan B, that he can play tennis only one way: with blistering pace and power. It is a formula that has taken Berdych, a 6-foot-5 player from the Czech Republic, close to the pinnacle of the mens game.

title: Prince Harry Compares War to PlayStation, and Taliban Are Not Amused
description: A Taliban spokesman said on Tuesday that Prince Harry must have mental problems, following the broadcast of remarks by the royal in which he said that killing militants from an Apache helicopter was similar to playing video games.

title: A Reunion of Car Model Makers
description: PHOENIX  By 1953, Anthony Joslins parents had saved $3,000, and earmarked it for sending their son to college. But Mr. Joslin was able to pay for his own tuition, room and board at North Carolina State University after winning a scholarship for the 1/12-scale car model he designed and built.

title: Met Reports One Millionth Visitor to New Islamic Galleries
description: In the 14-and-a-half months since the Metropolitan Museum of Art opened its new galleries devoted to the arts of the Islamic world  which it calls the galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia  they have become one of the Mets most popular attractions. On Friday, officials there reported that attendance at the galleries had topped the one-million mark  meaning an average of about 2,550 people a day, and 14 percent of the total attendance for the museum during the same period.

title: In Winning Design, City Hopes to Address a Cramped Future
description: Updated, 5:42 p.m. | The apartment of New York Citys future, as the city imagines it, has all the amenities of modern life: wheelchair-accessible bathroom, a full kitchen, space for entertaining and access to a gym, communal lounge, front and back porches and a rooftop garden  all in 250 to 370 square feet.

title: Apparent Subway-Train Suicide at Times Square
description: A person jumped in front of a subway train at Times Square around 10 a.m. Tuesday morning and was fatally struck, witnesses and the police said, leaving bystanders both shocked and fascinated by the macabre scene.

title: Chanel Coming to a Clearing
description: The idea is to make the shoulders beautiful, Karl Lagerfeld said on Monday night in the Chanel studio before his spring haute couture show. A model stood before him in a black wool suit, the neckline opened over a face-flattering white beaded yoke. This is really molded on the shoulders.

title: Harvey Weinstein, Film Fan (and That Includes Lincoln)
description: PARK CITY, Utah  Who has the power to shush the president of the United States, even on his own inauguration day? Here at Sundance, its Harvey Weinstein.

title: A Longtime Power Spot Eyes a Wider Audience
description: Tom Brokaw was in the other day. So was Mehmet Oz, the celebrity doctor. And some other people that shall remain nameless because I dont want to give them any press, said Esther Newberg, the influential literary agent.

title: A New Group Aims to Make Programming Cool
description: The presence of technology in the lives of most teenagers hasnt done much to entice more of them to become programmers. So Hadi Partovi has formed a nonprofit foundation aimed at making computer science as interesting to young people as smartphones, Instagram and iPads.

title: Pressures at Home, Tensions Offshore
description: Chinas gross domestic product grew 7.8 percent in 2012, its slowest pace since 1999. The growth slowdown appears to have bottomed out, and for the fourth quarter of 2012 the economy grew at 7.9 percent, slightly ahead of expectations.

title: Therapist Sentenced to 103 Years for Child Sexual Abuse
description: An unlicensed therapist and respected member of an ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn was sentenced on Tuesday to 103 years in prison for repeatedly sexually abusing a young woman, beginning the attacks when she was 12.

title: Look of The Moment | Diane Kruger
description: The Look: French Connection. Checklike black and white with a prim Peter Pan collar is Palais Royal-pretty with a black beret and wispy braid.

title: Should Colleges Stop Giving Credit for High A.P. Scores?
description: Dartmouth College, the Ivy League school in New Hampshire, has recently announced that it will no longer give college credit to students who score well on Advanced Placement tests, my colleague Tamar Lewin reports:

title: Turning Them Into Us
description: In his second inaugural address, President Obama stressed the great American we, the sense of national unity and common purpose that allows us to achieve great things while looking out for one another. His speech described a never-ending, mutual journey toward betterment  as one nation, and as one people  and youd have to be a pretty solitary, grudging soul not to have been impressed.

title: An Israeli Election That Lacks Fervor
description: TimesCast: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is likely to retain his post. | Why foreign policy figured only superficially in Israeli campaigns. | Coming home to Staten Island.

title: Polls Open Across Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is widely expected to win re-election, but some voters still say they are undecided and many lack enthusiasm for Israeli politics.

title: Critical Stance on Europeans May Jeopardize Britains Influence
description: LONDON  Last year, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain used his appearance at the World Economic Forum to vent frustration with the European Union, listing some of the policies he would ditch if he could throw off Europes regulatory shackles.

title: Comedy Central Makes Deal with Sirius XM
description: Comedy Central is expanding to radio, having concluded a deal with Sirius XM Radio to create a new channel revolving around stand-up comedy and relying on material produced by the comedy cable network.

title: Pros Get the Shots You Can Share
description: Many travelers these days feel that going on vacation and failing to document it on Instagram, Flickr or any number of other photo-sharing sites is much the same as forgetting to send a postcard might have been a generation ago. Its a little antisocial.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Jill Applebaum joined JWT New York, part of the JWT unit of WPP, as creative director. She had been senior vice president and group creative director at the New York office of DraftFCB, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, where she most recently was overseeing creative development for Oreo cookies, including the brands 100th anniversary campaign.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Egan-Jones Barred for 18 Months on Some Ratings
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that Egan-Jones, the upstart credit ratings firm run by Sean Egan, was barred for 18 months from issuing certain government-recognized ratings after the firm made misstatements on an application with the government.

title: Nebraska Governor Approves Keystone XL Route
description: 10:10 p.m. | Updated  An updated version of this post is available here.

title: Gant Rugger Devotes Ads to Bros and Their Clothes
description: Editors Note: This issue of In Advertising comes to you on Tuesday because of the holiday on Monday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

title: Beyoncs Inauguration Performance: Live or Prerecorded?
description: Beyoncs performance of the national anthem at President Obamas second inauguration on Monday was everything it should be: soaring, moving, symbolic and musically superlative. But was it actually live?

title: As Knicks Can Attest, Johnson Still Presents Problems
description: When Joe Johnson joined the Brooklyn Nets in the off-season, he brought with him a nickname, Iso-Joe, that spoke to his reputation as a scorer using one-on-one isolation plays. In his Atlanta heyday, he was the focal point of one of the N.B.A.s most efficient offenses. His accurate stroke and tremendous size for a shooting guard  he is 6 feet 7 inches and built like an N.F.L. wide receiver  made him an impossible matchup for most teams.

title: The Appeal of Investments That Cost More and Return Less
description: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, The Behavior Gap, was published last year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

title: For Olympic Stadiums, a Sad Life When the Cheering Stops
description: Critics of extravagant Olympic building can point to once-grand facilities that have gotten little use and fallen into disrepair in many Olympic cities.

title: Hamas Paints Malaysian Premiers Visit as a Stand Against Israel
description: GAZA  Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia visited the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip on Tuesday on what he called a humanitarian mission but Hamas portrayed as a defiant stand against Israeli restrictions on Gaza.

title: Disco Inferno at Fire-Sale Prices as Studio 54 Items Go On the Block
description: While some aspiring clubgoers would have paid almost any price to get their names into the guest book of Studio 54 during its disco-era heyday, acquiring that guest book in 2013 would have set them back $7,200, based on the results of an auction of items that once belonged to the Studio 54 co-founder Steve Rubell. The collection, which was sold on Saturday by Palm Beach Modern Auctions in West Palm Beach, Fla., consisted of art and memorabilia that Rubell had assembled before his death in 1989, and which he had left to his former companion, Bill Hamilton.

title: Prosecutors Call for Investigation on Greek Deficit
description: ATHENS  Greek prosecutors called on Tuesday for a criminal inquiry into the actions of the head of Elstat, the countrys statistical authority, and two of his subordinates over claims that they overstated the countrys budget deficit figures, forcing it to swallow unnecessarily harsh austerity measures.

title: Wheelies: The Charity Corvette Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Must I Get a Flu Shot?
description: The calculus of getting a flu shot is pretty straightforward: If I dont, I could get sick  and potentially get a bunch of other people sick too. I work in an open-air office, eat in crowded restaurants and take the subway. But heres the thing: I dont want a flu shot. I dont feel right about it. My mother, an M.D., who now practices alternative medicine, was  and is  anti-vaccine. Like a kid inheriting his parents faith, I grew up with a strong sense of that value system. Am I ethically obligated to get a flu shot? BEN REININGA, NEW YORK

title: Rajat Gupta Seeks Reversal of Insider Trading Conviction
description: Rajat Gupta, a former Goldman Sachs board member, has asked a federal appeals court to reverse his conviction on insider trading charges, arguing that a judge made a series of incorrect rulings during his trial.

title: Maker Aware of 40% Failure in Hip Implant
description: An internal analysis conducted by Johnson & Johnson in 2011 not long after it recalled a troubled hip implant estimated that the all-metal device would fail within five years in nearly 40 percent of patients who received it, newly disclosed court records show.

title: Obama Starts Second Term
description: TimesCast Politics: A look at the presidents agenda. | Challenges await on Capitol Hill. | Highlights from Mondays festivities.

title: S.B.A. Signs Its First Venture Capital Fund to New Investment Program
description: While many small businesses are waiting for the federal government to write rules for so-called equity crowdfunding, the Obama administration is moving forward with another effort to funnel investment capital to start-ups. Last week, the Small Business Administration announced that it had granted a venture capital fund from North Carolina the first license to participate in a new program to encourage investment. The program essentially makes government-guaranteed loans to venture capital funds, which in turn use the debt to make equity investments.

title: PET Scan May Reveal C.T.E. Signs, Study Says
description: For years, researchers have had to use tissue obtained posthumously to diagnose chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., the degenerative brain disease that has bedeviled athletes, soldiers and others who have sustained repeated head hits and concussions.

title: Street Style: Faux Fur
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Jan. 14.

title: Irina Dvorovenko, Principal Dancer, to Retire From American Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater audiences have watched Irina Dvorovenko, a principal dancer with the company, in more than three dozen roles over 16 seasons and on May 18, they can see her final interpretation, as Tatiana in Onegin at the Metropolitan Opera House. Ms. Dvorovenko, 39, will stop dancing at the house after that final performance, the company said on Tuesday, without providing an explanation.

title: Armani Priv: Spring 2013 Couture
description: Paris

title: Unfinished Luxury Tower Is Stark Reminder of Las Vegass Economic Reversal
description: LAS VEGAS  It turns out there is something more complicated than shoehorning a seven-building, 17-million-square-foot, $8.5 billion complex of hotels, casinos, high-end shops and luxury condominiums  known as CityCenter  into the bustling heart of the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Model-Morphosis | Ming Xi at Chanel
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2013 Fashion Week in Paris. Here, the model Ming Xi for Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Peter Phillips and hair by Sam McKnight.

title: Giorgio Armani Prive
description: The haute couture collection in Paris.

title: A Public Servant Tries to Do His Civic Duty
description: He oversees an office of more than 600 lawyers who together juggle more than 80,000 cases. He has argued before the United States Supreme Court and been involved in negotiating a billion-dollar contract. But one much more quotidian experience with the law escapes Michael A. Cardozo, the head of the New York City Law Department. He has never served on a jury.

title: N.F.L. Lifts Suspension of Saints Coach
description: With the Super Bowl to be played in New Orleans in less than two weeks, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell gave Saints fans a reason to celebrate Tuesday, reinstating Coach Sean Payton after a suspension of nearly a year for his role in a bounty scandal.

title: For Chris Andersen, Another Chance
description: N.B.A. history is full of successful reclamation projects, stories of players making the most of second chances. That roster includes Bill Walton with the legendary 86 Celtics, Dennis Rodman on the Bulls of the late 90s, and Jerry Stackhouse with the Nets this season.

title: Burst of Iraq Violence Amid Political Crisis
description: BAGHDAD  A series of attacks left at least 24 Iraqis dead on Tuesday, in the latest outbreak of violence amid a protracted political crisis.

title: Niche Design
description: A tiny studio apartment proves that the more (artfully arranged) stuff you put in a room, the bigger it seems.

title: Bartenders Are Doing More Than Taking Orders
description: Around the neck of every bottle from the fledgling spirits outfit the 86 Co.  the gin, the vodka, the tequila, the rum  is a small glass ridge. To the untrained eye, it looks like a packaging flourish. It is not.

title: Sea Level and the Limits of the Bathtub Analogy
description: In my article in Tuesdays Science Times about the risks of long-term sea level rise, and in an accompanying podcast, I reported on the link between past instances of global warming, caused by natural fluctuations in the climate, and higher shorelines.

title: Reverberations After the Bolshoi Attack
description: When a hooded assailant flung acid in the face of Sergei Filin, the director of the Bolshoi Ballet, late on Thursday night in Moscow, the attack almost instantly made headlines worldwide.

title: 1966 Ford Mustang Brings Bidders Back Together
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  While marquee vehicles generated tens of millions of dollars in the recent collector-car auctions here, a quieter drama played out Saturday at the Barrett-Jackson sale, closing a circle between two hobbyists who first connected a year ago.

title: Challenges Await on Capitol Hill
description: The Times's Jonathan Weisman discusses the legislative possibilities in President Obama's second term.

title: What Obama Looks to Accomplish
description: The Timess Richard W. Stevenson takes a look at President Obamas second-term agenda, including priorities such as climate change and gun control.

title: Literary Web Site Enters the E-Books Fray
description: As the commercial landscape for books continues to shift, a prominent literary web site, The Millions, is celebrating its 10th anniversary by getting into the publishing game.

title: In New Orleans, a Trio of Thrifty Lures
description: It promised to be my easiest frugal assignment yet: five days in a paradise of cheap eating, cheaper drinking and free music in the walking- and biking-friendly city  New Orleans. A self-imposed prohibition on dropping money in the touristy French Quarter would make things easier, even during the ramp-up to the Super Bowl, which the city is hosting Feb. 3, and to Mardi Gras Day, on Feb. 12.

title: 4 in Hospital After Shooting at Houston College Campus
description: HOUSTON  A dispute between two men at a community college in the wooded northern outskirts of Houston led to a shooting on Tuesday that left four people hospitalized and touched off fears that the campus was the site of another mass shooting.

title: The Following on Fox Opens With Good Ratings
description: After a dismal fall, the Fox network finally got some good news Monday with the premiere of its highest-profile project of the year, The Following. Initial ratings for the intense, hyperviolent drama were solid, especially on a tough competitive night.

title: How Companies Can Sue Defendants in Insider Trading Cases
description: Insider trading was once said to be a victimless crime. Yet, many parties can claim that they were harmed by such actions, including those who were on the other side of the actual trades, the stock market, the corporation whose shares were involved in the inside trades or even a hedge fund used as the vehicle for the trading.

title: Not So Exceptional
description: American presidential inaugurations, which some critics deride as coronations  the cannons! the fancy dress balls!  are, for others, the most conspicuous and enduring symbol of our democracy. Thats how Senator Lamar Alexander put it Monday, in his brief speech shortly before the presidents swearing in.

title: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
description: Has Joe Flacco convinced any remaining doubters? And Colin Kaepernick? How do the ravens prepare for the 49ers (and vice versa)? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers about the Super Bowl and other football topics. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear next week on The Fifth Down.Comments for this feature are now closed.

title: Children Are Not Our Friends (Until They Are)
description: When my children were little, I was always a bit baffled by parents who talked about being friends with their children. Maybe I expect too much from my friends, but I like to hang out with people who read chapter books and bathe without being told. Im big on reciprocity in my friendships  we exchange views and experience and occasionally good advice. I dont tell you when to go to bed. You dont tell me when youre done pooping.

title: Table Talk | Hinoki & the Bird in Los Angeles
description: The first thing you notice upon entering the new Los Angeles restaurant Hinoki & the Bird is the hinoki, a Japanese cedar wood that lines the walls and perfumes the air with a crisp, citrusy bouquet. Veneer-thin sheets of it  set on fire to infuse black cod filets with their smoke  waft like incense as the plates cross the room, sending curious noses skyward in their wake.

title: Love and Lectures, Living on From the Grave
description: In Anthony Minghellas 1990 film, Truly Madly Deeply, one of the great weepies in cinematic history, a bereaved woman (Juliet Stevenson) is visited by the ghost of her dead, cello-playing boyfriend (Alan Rickman). It doesnt go well. He brings friends over. She asks: Are you telling me there are dead people in my living room watching videos?

title: Reports Reveal Financial Challenges, but Few Solutions
description: The important and self-important of global finance are again gathering at the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. This year, the mandatory reading should be two recent reminders from JPMorgan Chase and the Federal Reserve that we are light years from understanding or preventing financial crises.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 22
description: A view of the day in sports, including the European figure skating championships in Croatia and the African Cup of Nations soccer tournament in South Africa.

title: This Years Governors Ball to Feature 60 Acts
description: Kanye West, Kings of Leon, the xx and the Lumineers are among 60 acts who will appear at this years Governors Ball Music Festival , a three-day event on Randalls Island that will start on June 7. Started three years ago, the festival has expanded in size and scope each year, and this time around, the promoters, Founders Entertainment, have booked an eclectic group of performers, representing genres like electro-pop, rap and folk-rock. Among the other hip-hop acts on the bill are Kendrick Lamar, Nas and Azealia Banks. Indie rock is well represented, with Feist, Grizzly Bear, Beach House, Dirty Projectors and Best Coast making appearances. The folk-rock groups Of Monsters and Men and the Avett Brothers are also on the bill.

title: Robin Hood Trading Tax Nudged Forward in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  A hotly contested tax on financial trades took a big step forward on Tuesday when European Union finance ministers allowed a vanguard of member states to proceed with the plan.

title: Still More Mortgage Protections Unveiled
description: Last week, the federal government capped a slew of announcements about new mortgage rules aimed at protecting borrowers with another announcement of more rules designed to protect borrowers.

title: Have a Health Question? Ask Well
description: The Well section of The New York Times is starting a new online featured called Ask Well. If you have a question about fitness, nutrition, illness or family health, the staff of The New York Times Health section is ready to help you find the answer.

title: A Church Choirs Show at the Inauguration Brings a Burst of Brooklyn Pride
description: When Senator Charles E. Schumer introduced the singers of The Battle Hymn of the Republic at President Obamas second inauguration, he first called them the award-winning tabernacle choir, as if the huge crowd were expecting another, more famous group, the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

title: Teaching History With Film: Lincoln, Argo and Zero Dark Thirty
description: Three of this years Oscar contenders  Lincoln, Argo and Zero Dark Thirty  invite viewers to look at history, either through the lens of the distant past (as in the case of Lincoln) or through recent events (like Zero Dark Thirty), and to question the degree of truth and fiction at work in the retelling of these events.

title: Creole Spices Power a Super Bowl Feast
description: For fans, the focal point of Super Bowl Sunday is the game itself. For someone like me, the spouse of a fan, the main event is the hours or even days leading up to kickoff, when I come up with a menu that is as much fun for me to cook as it is for guests to eat.

title: Morgan Stanleys Pay Later Plan
description: Is Morgan Stanley mortgaging its future through compensation?

title: Modestly Sweet Wines for Spicy Super Bowl Snacks
description: The New Orleans chef Brian Landry has shared four Creole-inspired recipes for a Super Bowl celebration. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with them; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

title: Exploring Wine Pairings Without Fear or Favor
description: BEGINNING THIS WEEK, I will suggest wines with recipes that cry out for pairing ideas. Not on every recipe, but maybe one or two a week, like todays for chorizo boudin balls and Creole-spiced shrimp (part of an array of Super Bowl suggestions). I must say, though, that while I am eager to offer pleasing ideas, I do so with no small amount of trepidation.

title: The Envelope, Please: Leobardo Espinoza
description: Leobardo Espinoza Jr., a high school senior in Kansas, says that having a lot of scholarships to consider can be a double-edged sword.

title: A Dolls Magic, Free to Renew
description: Update | At a Library, an Outpouring of Support, and New Dolls (Jan. 25, 2013)

title: Work Ahead for Seattle Rookie
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The rise of academies caused an unusual situation during last weeks Major League Soccer SuperDraft because not one player from the University of Akron was called to the podium.

title: S.E.C. Fills Senior Enforcement Spot
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Tuesday that Vincente L. Martinez, a veteran of the agency, will run a powerful unit that culls tips about Wall Street wrongdoing.

title: The Softest Shoe: Tap in Socks, Even Bare Feet
description: St. Marks Church in the East Village is a site of awful temptation for a tap dancer. The gleaming wood floor is a perfect surface for tap, yet tap dancers are forbidden to scuff and nick it with their metal-tipped shoes.

title: Krescendo
description: Inside the Boerum Hill pizzeria, where a modest facade conceals remarkable pizza.

title: Secrets of the Glittering Pizza Oven
description: PIZZA IS NOT A HUMBLE food, and great pizza is not usually made by humble people. Some of the proudest and most willful cooks you will ever meet are pie slingers.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Groupon Goes Gunless, and Siris Roots
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Cable News Networks See Big Falloff From 2009 in Inauguration Ratings
description: CNN scored a big ratings win among the cable news networks covering the Inaugural events Monday, but the numbers declined significantly from four years ago for all the networks.

title: Google Still in a Struggle With Mobile
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Although Google is scrambling to meet consumers as they flock to mobile devices, the question is whether it is moving fast enough.

title: Restaurants Turn Camera Shy
description: When it comes to people taking photographs of their meals, the chef David Bouley has seen it all. There are the foreign tourists who, despite their big cameras, tend to be very discreet. There are those who use a flash and annoy everyone around them. There are those who come equipped with gorillapods  those small, flexible tripods to use on their tables.

title: The Non-Surge in Government Spending
description: The fiscal debate in Washington is dominated by things everyone knows that happen not to be true. One of those things is the notion that we have a fiscal crisis, an assertion belied both by the low interest rates at which the Feds can borrow and by the fact that medium-term deficit projections really arent that alarming. Another is the notion that our current deficit is driven by a surge in government spending.

title: A Life of Being Smitten With This Species, That Habitat
description: Attenboroughs Life Stories, a three-part installment of PBSs Nature, serves as a David Attenborough retrospective of sorts, with Mr. Attenborough himself the genial host for a tour of his long career as a maker of nature programs.

title: Defying Common View, Some Syrian Kurds Fight Assad
description: ALGHOOZ, Syria  The arc of Omar Abdulkaders transformation from farmer to fighter resembles that of uncountable others in Syria, where since 2011 tens of thousands of men have been drawn into a civil war.

title: Reid Optimistic for Filibuster Deal in Senate
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said Tuesday that Democrats and Republicans were making progress toward resolving their differences over the filibuster, but he left the door open for an explosive backup plan that even some in his own party are resisting.

title: Off the Menu
description: PREVIEW The Williams and Shakespeare Pub

title: Jets Ryan Involved in Car Accident
description: Jets Coach Rex Ryan avoided injury after being involved in a three-car accident last week in Bethlehem, Pa. Ryan crashed his red Ford Mustang on Jan. 14 after allegedly running a red light at a four-way intersection. His vehicle slammed into another car, which collided with the third car. No one was injured. Ryan received a written warning but was not fined.

title: Europes Odd Couple, France and Germany, 50 Years Later
description: BERLIN  France and Germany recently issued a joint postage stamp as part of a yearlong celebration of the 50th anniversary of the lyse Treaty, the landmark agreement between the two former enemies.

title: Wonder Woman at Sundance
description: PARK CITY, Utah  There was a Wonder Woman theme at the Women in Film brunch held here on Monday, at the home of Jacki Zehner, a Sundance Institute trustee. Kitchen helpers had Wonder Woman aprons; cocktails napkins bore her likeness and the slogan Saving the world makes me thirsty.

title: A Flashback to the Late 1960s, With a Vision Understated and Sincere
description: For the moment Christopher Owens has settled on an era. As the leader of the band Girls, he hopscotched among retro possibilities: surf-rock, punk, folk-rock, 1970s John Lennon. Now, with his first solo album, Lysandre, he has narrowed his time frame and genre choice to late-1960s folk-pop.

title: Agency Moves to Retire Most Research Chimps
description: Almost all of the 451 chimpanzees owned or supported by the National Institutes of Health that are now at research facilities should be permanently retired from research and moved to sanctuaries, with planning for the move to start immediately, a report from an N.I.H. council unanimously recommended Tuesday.

title: The 40th Anniversary of Roe v. Wade
description: Its the 40th anniversary of Roe v. Wade. Do your kids know what that means?

title: I.B.M. Reports 6% Increase in Profit Despite Flat Revenue
description: For years, I.B.M. has delivered on a formula: strong earnings gains with scant revenue growth.

title: So You Want to Learn to Cook in France?
description: Ever since Julia Child taught cooking classes in her Paris kitchen decades ago, many an American living in the city has guided visiting countrymen on the intricacies of French cooking and eating. But not all of them have been as knowledgeable as Ms. Child.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Food and Farm Policy

title: Front Burner
description: In a new weekly column, Florence Fabricant recommends things to read, taste, covet, order, cook, give and more.

title: In the Dairy Case, Ripe Prose
description: They can tell you about torment. They can describe long, frustrating hours sitting in dark, stinky basements and caves, pen in hand, trying to get the flow of the words just right.

title: Are You a Master of Cheese Description?
description: Theres something about cheese. It inspires people.

title: Where Swag and Publicity Go Hand in Hand
description: 10:12 p.m. | Updated  PARK CITY, Utah  One of the biggest bummers about Sundance in the eyes of many longtime festivalgoers is the Great Glom On  brands trying to bask in the media spotlight generated by the premieres of more than 100 feature films. Robert Redford, Sundances founder, contemptuously refers to them as rogue marketers.

title: The Field Hand Who Was an Artist From Midnight to 6
description: Robert Wilson, the director and visual artist best known for experimental theater pieces like Einstein on the Beach, is directing a new chamber opera at Peak Performances at Montclair State University in Montclair, N.J. Zinnias: The Life of Clementine Hunter, based on the life of that outsider artist, has its world premiere on Saturday and runs through Feb. 3. Hunter, a black woman who lived from 1887 to 1988, picked cotton on a Louisiana plantation and began painting in her 50s, though she never had formal training. With a libretto and music by Bernice Johnson Reagon and Toshi Reagon, and a story and book by Jacqueline Woodson, Zinnias also reunites Mr. Wilson with Sheryl Sutton, the performer who starred in the provocative silent opera Deafman Glance, which brought them both a lot of attention in the 1970s. Mr. Wilson and Ms. Sutton were interviewed together at Mr. Wilsons downtown Manhattan studio; Mr. Wilson was also interviewed between rehearsals and by telephone. These are excerpts from the conversations:

title: A Champion of Dutch Composers Comes Ashore Without Much Flash
description: Since its founding in 1985, the Utrecht String Quartet has become central to the musical life of the Netherlands and an important touring ensemble in Europe. So it is curious that it is only now making its first American tour, which included a rewarding program at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon.

title: A Veterans Plea to President Obama
description: Dear Mr. President,

title: Flamenco With Room Enough for Everyone to Shine
description: Listening to the flamenco guitarist Paco Pea play solo, you might believe a few guitarists were helping him out, hidden backstage. Hes that good. And yet whats most admirable about this modest virtuoso, who can hold an audience spellbound on his own, is how he surrounds himself with artists of similar caliber and lets them shine.

title: Bystander Shot Near Empire State Building Sues Police
description: A college student who was one of nine bystanders inadvertently shot and wounded by the police outside the Empire State Building in August became the first one to file suit against the city on Tuesday.

title: Questioning Its Marvels and Morals
description: Welcoming President Obama to his second term, PBS has scheduled Rise of the Drones, an examination of one of the more controversial items on his agenda, as Wednesday nights installment of Nova.

title: Water, Water Everywhere, for a Duet
description: This weekend at Judson Memorial Church an imaginary storm left the dancers Carlye Eckert and John Sorensen-Jolink stranded together at sea. Fortunately, someone threw them a life raft. Unfortunately, it wasnt enough to save them.

title: Paris Mens Fashion Week Fall 2013 Accessories
description: Statement pieces and staples from the runways in Paris.

title: Bradford City in Dreamland
description: The Bantams of Bradford City have been punching above their weight for quite some time, and now the club from West Yorkshire, England, finds itself in an unlikely place  Wembley Stadium  where it will play in the League Cup (a k a the Capital One Cup) final on Feb. 24.

title: Celebrating the Unorthodox With Startling Footwork and Incessant Talk
description: The American Realness festival, which ended on Sunday, was in many ways not just a demonstration but also a celebration of the alternative and unorthodox. Of the 15 performances I attended (almost all at the Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side), 4 featured drag, 5 featured nudity or striking degrees of physical exposure, and 8 featured players both talking and dancing.

title: Boy Meets Girl. Song Ensues.
description: The very title of the winter-season opening show at the Caf Carlyle, Broadway Romance, promises cuddly nostalgia with minimal anxiety and hysteria. Three reliable Broadway hands  the singers Howard McGillin and Rebecca Luker, with the musical director and occasional vocalist Ted Sperling on piano  deliver on that promise. The sequence of mostly well-known theater songs offers a sophisticated variation on an old story: boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl back, with marriage and children added.

title: 3-D Experience for the Ear
description: At a time when it seems that every other movie is enhanced with 3-D technology, it is rare to be awed by a stereophonic experience. No glasses were required at Sundays concert by the Budapest Festival Orchestra under the direction of Ivan Fischer, who created volleys of sound so vividly three-dimensional that you sometimes had to resist the impulse to duck.

title: Landmarks Commission Approves Library Changes
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted 6 to 2 on Tuesday to approve changes to the exterior of the New York Public Librarys Fifth Avenue flagship building.

title: As ESPN Debated, Manti Teo Story Slipped Away
description: On Jan. 16, a fierce debate raged inside ESPN. Reporters for the network had been working for almost a week trying to nail down an extraordinary story: Manti Teos girlfriend  the one whose death from leukemia had haunted and inspired him during a triumphant year on the field for Notre Dame  might be a hoax.

title: Norman Sturner
description: Mr. Sturner, 72, is the president and chief executive of Murray Hill Properties, a full service real estate company that specializes in office properties in Midtown Manhattan. The company, which Mr. Sturner co-founded in 1971, owns or manages about seven million square feet of office space, including 1180 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Are iPhone Sales Waning? The Numbers Dont Say So
description: Reports last week suggested that people might finally be tired of Apples iPhone, citing sources that said sales were weaker than expected. But the latest numbers do not support that conclusion.

title: Microcosm of Society, Seeking an Anchor
description: In Europe as in the United States, immigration is a politically contentious issue most often addressed in abstract demographic and ideological terms. There have been movies that try to give the problem a human face, focusing on the struggles of families and individuals, frequently with well-meaning sentimentality.

title: Projection of Hip Implant Failure Rate
description: An internal analysis conducted by Johnson & Johnson in 2011 after it recalled a troubled hip implant projected that the all-metal device would fail within five years in nearly 40 percent of patients who received it.

title: The Liberal Hour
description: I naturally preferred my own version of President Obamas second inaugural to the speech he actually delivered yesterday, but the substance of the two was roughly similar. The president clearly feels that his re-election both reflects and ratifies a larger leftward shift in American politics: His address reached backward to ground this new progressive era in the American past, offered explicit nods to the demographic groups and constituencies whose present-day growth has made it possible, and then sketched out an agenda suited to a more left-of-center future  climate change legislation and green industrial policy, a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants, the universalization of gay marriage, new gun control laws, etc. It was not a speech designed to co-opt opponents of this agenda, to put it mildly  particularlythose opponents whose control of the House of Representatives will make this agenda difficult to implement. But those of us who watched his negative, joyless re-election campaign and assumed that this president would begin his second term as a lame duck were only half-right. While theres still good reason to think that Obamas biggest legislative accomplishments are in the rearview mirror, the fact that he could win a clean victory despite the grim economic backdrop seems to have given him more confidence in the staying power of his coalition, and the continuing short-term impediments to his agenda in Washington seem to have liberated him to play for the longer term instead.

title: Drug Is Shown to Help Pancreatic Cancer Cases
description: Celgenes drug Abraxane prolonged the lives of patients with advanced pancreatic cancer by almost two months in a clinical trial, researchers reported Tuesday, signifying an advance in treating a notoriously difficult disease but not as big a leap as some doctors and investors had hoped.

title: Pentagon Clears Commander Over E-Mails
description: WASHINGTON  A Defense Department inquiry into potentially inappropriate e-mails between Gen. John R. Allen, the American commander in Afghanistan, and a socialite in Tampa, Fla., has cleared him of wrongdoing, senior Pentagon officials disclosed Tuesday.

title: A Tax Bite Tailored to Help All
description: What would happen if the government raised everybodys taxes?

title: Picking a Winner Amid a Field of Bold Theories
description: There are a number of theories as to why Michelle Obama, who has generally spread her fashion love around to many designers, would select the same one for both of her inaugural gowns. An obvious one is that she likes a Jason Wu dress.

title: What Does Public Support in Obamas Second Inaugural Speech?
description: Inaugural speeches are often criticized as long on rhetoric and short on substance. But President Obamas second inaugural address on Monday was surprisingly specific about his second-term goals.

title: Aladdin Will Launch in Toronto Before Broadway Run
description: The new Disney musical Aladdin will have a pre-Broadway tryout in Toronto for nine weeks starting Nov. 13 before opening in New York at the New Amsterdam Theater in spring 2014, Disney Theatrical Productions announced on Tuesday. Disney had previously declined to confirm that Aladdin would be the next show at the New Amsterdam after Mary Poppins, which is scheduled to close on March 3.

title: Scene City: Bipartisan for a Night
description: Washington power brokers host their own A-list inaugural party.

title: Bridging Party Divisions Over Canaps
description: WASHINGTON  At 9:30 p.m. on Sunday, when the city was awash in out-of-towners and inaugural festivities, a parade of well-dressed guests of a certain age arrived at the Madison hotel.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Syria, Mali, South Africa and more.

title: New Site Makes It Easier to View City Spending
description: The New York City comptrollers office plans to unveil a new Web site on Wednesday that will make it easier to view, analyze and download information about city spending, empowering fiscal watchdogs and the City Council in their battles with mayors over the budget.

title: In New Ad, Conservative Group Questions Hagels Ethics
description: The American Future Fund, a conservative group opposed to the nomination of Chuck Hagel as defense secretary, is opening up a new front in its effort against him with a national television campaign painting him as ethically challenged.

title: Sanctuary From Storm Is a School Again
description: Since the hurricane charged through the Belle Harbor enclave of the Rockaway Peninsula, the redbrick church of St. Francis de Sales has been the heart of the areas relief initiatives, even as it was itself battered. The warped floors of its adjacent grade schools soaked gymnasium became a sanctuary to thousands of people a day who came here for hot food and dry clothes.

title: Pittsburghs Three Rivers, Now a Public Attraction
description: PITTSBURGH  Pittsburgh exists for three reasons: the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio.

title: Recovery Begins Slowly for Award-Winning Jockey
description: It speaks to his nature that on the day he was to receive the Eclipse Award for jockey of the year for the third consecutive time, Ramon Dominguez planned on riding a full card at Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens before flying to South Florida for the ceremony Saturday night. Dominguez did not get the chance.

title: Foul-Smelling Cloud Drifts Over France, Alarming Residents
description: PARIS  It wafted over northern France late in the night and reached southern England by morning on Tuesday, a noisome cloud that roused inhabitants from their sleep with its nauseating stench. There were thousands of frantic calls to emergency services, from Normandy to Paris, with residents describing the smell of household gas or rotten eggs, but the authorities moved quickly to calm fears.

title: In New Term, First Year Is Crucial for Obama Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  The Constitution may promise President Obama another four years in the White House, but political reality calls for a far shorter time frame: he has perhaps as little as a year to accomplish his big-ticket goals for a second term.

title: Microsoft May Back Dell Buyout
description: The effort to take Dell private has gained a prominent, if unusual, backer: Microsoft.

title: Postal Service Losing Out on Federal Contracts, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Even the federal government turns to private shippers rather than the Postal Service when it wants to send packages.

title: Gospel of Intolerance
description: The filmmaker Roger Ross Williams reveals how money donated by American evangelicals helps to finance a violent antigay movement in Uganda.

title: Gospel of Intolerance
description: Raised in Pennsylvania, I grew up in the black church. My father was a religious leader in the community, and my sister is a pastor. I went to church every Sunday and sang in the choir. But for all that the church gave me  for all that it represented belonging, love and community  it also shut its doors to me as a gay person. That experience left me with the lifelong desire to explore the power of religion to transform lives or destroy them. I became interested in Uganda, an intensely religious country that attracts many American missionaries and much funding from United States faith-based organizations. The American evangelical movement in Africa does valuable work in helping the poor. But as youll see in this Op-Doc video, some of their efforts and money feed a dangerous ideology that seeks to demonize L.G.B.T. people and intensifies religious rhetoric until it results in violence. It is important for American congregations to hold their churches accountable for what their money does in Africa.

title: Super Bowl Ads Will Be Heavy on Colas, Beers and Cars
description: EACH year within the Super Bowl, Madison Avenue plays an Ad Bowl, as marketers spend large amounts of time and treasure to create commercials that will, they hope, win plaudits and move merchandise. And within each Ad Bowl, two categories of consumer products usually account for a supersize amount of spots: automobiles and beverages.

title: Eritrea: Calm After Coup Attempt
description: Eritrea appeared calm on Tuesday, a day after renegade soldiers stormed a government ministry and briefly took over the state-run airwaves, according to capital residents. Shops, offices, banks, schools are all open, a resident wrote by e-mail. And cars and buses and taxis seem to be running normally. The writer added: The situation is murky. Nobody seems to know whether there was a coup attempt, or the whole thing was staged for some sinister purpose.

title: Many Medicaid Patients Could Face Higher Fees Under a Proposed Federal Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Millions of low-income people could be required to pay more for health care under a proposed federal policy that would give states more freedom to impose co-payments and other charges on Medicaid patients.

title: India Warns Kashmiris to Prepare for Nuclear War
description: NEW DELHI  Indian officials are advising residents of strife-torn Kashmir to prepare for a possible nuclear war by building bombproof basements and stockpiling food and water, adding to tensions between India and Pakistan, both nuclear powers, after deadly cross-border skirmishes in recent weeks.

title: U.S. Trade Representative Will Step Down
description: Ron Kirk, the United States trade representative, will step down in late February, his office said Tuesday. Lael Brainard and Michael Froman, two top administration aides on international economic policy, are considered among the front-runners to succeed him, people knowledgeable about trade policy said.

title: Torrey Pines Has the Feel of Home for Woods
description: SAN DIEGO  For somebody who has not lived in his native Southern California since 1996, Tiger Woods seems at home at Torrey Pines Golf Course, where he will make his 2013 PGA Tour debut this week at the Farmers Insurance Open.

title: The Missing President
description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: In a Crowded City, Storage Rooms With Amenities
description: Their Day-Glo stripes light up blocks. Their cheeky billboards line highways. They are even the subject of shows on cable television.

title: The Last Calendar
description: BY the time he was 76, my father was frail. His balance was poor and he had trouble walking. He lived alone in Baltimore in a big house full of stairs, and watching him come tottering down those stairs was terrifying. Each time, I thought he might fall. He refused to make the house safer  no stair lifts, no grab rails (they would disfigure the house, he said)  and would not consider living anywhere else. When my brother and his wife invited my father to move in, the invitation was vigorously declined. And we lived in three different cities, far apart.

title: A Cold Shoulder for Russian Dissidents
description: MOSCOW

title: Security Council Condemns North Korea Rocket Launching
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council on Tuesday unanimously condemned North Korea for launching a rocket last month, with Pyongyangs main ally, China, taking an uncommon step by joining the criticism.

title: Break All the Rules
description: First, my congratulations and condolences to John Kerry for being nominated to be our next secretary of state. There is no one better for the job today and no worse job to have today. It is no accident that weve started measuring our secretaries of state more by miles traveled than milestones achieved. It is bloody hard to do big diplomacy anymore.

title: For Rape Victims in India, Police Are Often Part of the Problem
description: NEW DELHI  Not long after telling the police that she had been raped, a woman from South Delhi looked out her apartment window and saw the man who had attacked her laughing with an officer who had given him a ride back from the police station.

title: Akerss Leg Has the 49ers Crossing Their Fingers
description: In this, the strangest season of his N.F.L. career, David Akers connected on a 63-yard field goal, nearly shanked his way out of employment in San Francisco, underwent treatment for a double hernia injury, received death threats on social media, shuttered his Twitter account and won a job competition that took place before the playoffs started.

title: The School Bus Mess
description: New York City mayors have long tolerated one of the most inefficient school transportation systems in the country  made so by a labor agreement that undermines competitive bidding and poorly designed bus routes.

title: More Questions Are Raised in Boeing 787 Battery Fires
description: Investigators in the United States and Japan indicated on Tuesday that many questions remained unanswered in their search for the cause of two incidents in which lithium-ion batteries burned on Boeing 787 aircraft.

title: Was Beyonc Singing Live, Or Was It A Recording?
description: Beyoncs performance of the national anthem at President Obamas inauguration on Monday was everything it should be: soaring, moving, symbolic and musically superlative. But was it actually live?

title: Abortion and Health Care, 40 Years After Roe v. Wade
description: To the Editor:

title: The Antidote to Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Coke Blinks
description: Once again, Coke has blinked. It famously did so in 1985, when it introduced new Coke, replacing its original formula with one it thought would have greater appeal with its audience. It was wrong then.

title: Amgen Gets a Gift From Congress
description: For a disheartening example of how intense lobbying and financial contributions can distort the legislative process in Washington, consider what happened to the fiscal cliff bill approved three weeks ago by Congress.

title: U.S. Begins Airlift of a French Battalion to Mali
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon is airlifting a French battalion to join the fight in Mali against Islamist militants, Pentagon and administration officials said Tuesday, but the United States has not yet agreed to a request from France to provide refueling tankers for its warplanes.

title: Is Atheism a Religion?
Justice and Prosperity
description: When Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. congratulated President Obama after he completed his oath of office on Monday, Americans heard the cordial, affirming voice that regularly fills the courtroom of the Supreme Court. But the chief justices graciousness did not mean he was endorsing the president or his views.

title: An Inaugural for the 21st Century
description: To the Editor:

title: Country Returns to City Radio: After 17 Years, a Home in New York
description: Country music is all over television, on dramas like Nashville and talent competitions like American Idol. Country stars are among the most consistent moneymakers in the concert industry. The genres growing sales are among the few bright lights of the music industry.

title: Some Algeria Attackers Are Placed at Benghazi
description: ALGIERS  Several Egyptian members of the squad of militants that lay bloody siege to an Algerian gas complex last week also took part in the deadly attack on the United States Mission in Libya in September, a senior Algerian official said Tuesday.

title: Algerian Attack Puts Focus on Worker Security
description: HOUSTON  The gas complex in Algeria that came under attack last week, like scores of oil and gas fields around the globe, had been a world apart from the country that surrounded it, an oasis of relative luxury in a nation emerging from poverty.

title: Report Faults Food Groups Sponsor Ties
description: A new report by a public health advocate criticizes the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics, a trade group presenting some 74,000 dietitians, for allowing corporate sponsorships of its organization.

title: Gas Complex Worker Tells of Terror and a Desperate Escape
description: BERGEN, Norway  After militants stormed his remote desert workplace last week, Liviu Floria, a Romanian gas worker, locked the door and sought refuge under a desk. For five hours, as he stayed hidden, he communicated by text message with a Romanian co-worker in another part of the sprawling In Amenas gas facility.

title: Wal-Mart Toughens Fire Safety Rules for Suppliers After Bangladesh Blaze
description: Facing criticism for selling garments made at a Bangladesh factory where 112 workers died in a fire last November, Wal-Mart Stores told its worldwide suppliers Tuesday that it was adopting tougher rules on fire safety at its contractors and would have zero tolerance for suppliers that used unauthorized subcontractors.

title: New York Archdiocese to Close 24 Schools
description: The New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese announced Tuesday that it would close 22 elementary schools and 2 high schools, saying it could no longer afford to spend millions each year supporting schools that were not economically self-sufficient.

title: Lottery Numbers
Sexual Abuse Files Cast Shadow on Los Angeles Cardinal
description: Cardinal Roger M. Mahony, for more than 25 years the savvy shepherd of the Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles, retired nearly two years ago to a renovated yellow house behind his childhood parish, pledging to stay in the spotlight by continuing to fight for the rights of immigrants.

title: Former Raiders Accuse Coach of Sabotaging Super Bowl
description: The game was played 10 years ago, but on Tuesday, the Super Bowl between the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Oakland Raiders was at the center of a stunning accusation, briefly supplanting the game that will be played in less than two weeks as the talk of the N.F.L.

title: A New Bed Helps a Former Nurse Ease Her Pains
description: Her face is kind and disarming, her posture confident, and when she talks about her life, she speaks with a mix of sincerity and sarcasm.

title: Honey From Red Hook Was Missing, and So Was the Right Reason
description: After getting sworn in for his second term, President Obama joined his wife and 220 others for the traditional Inaugural Luncheon, held in the Capitols grand Statuary Hall.

title: At Davos, Is the Party Over?
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  In previous years, the Friday night of the World Economic Forum was always filled with big dinners and blowout parties.

title: When a Tough-Talking Governor Stops Talking
description: AUGUSTA, Me.  Temperatures soared into the mid-50s here last week but the capitol building was nonetheless in the grip of a big chill.

title: Carrying a Cause to the Super Bowl
description: To appreciate how much traction the legalization of same-sex marriage has gained, you can look to the Inaugural Address that President Obama just delivered, in which he used some of his precious 18 minutes to throw a spotlight on the issue and to make his support for it clearer than ever.

title: Chow Line
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  One of the things that took some getting used to when I started writing Wordplay was the intricacies of the New York Times Stylebook. In many cases, periods are placed after initials in The New York Times and I would like to think that Joel Faglianos puzzle today pokes a bit of fun at that editorial policy.

title: Like, Innocence, and, Um, Experience
description: God, this must be so boring for you!

title: Corrections: January 23, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Dont Get Up. App Makes Your Couch a Cool Spot.
description: Everyone is out having a great time  no, not just great, an amazing time  and youre on the couch, hovering on the border between pajamas and underwear. Suddenly, the quick, the beautiful and the fully dressed invade: chirps from phones and pop-ups on screens are announcing their social media check-ins, mapping out the lands of awesome times. None of those places, needless to say, are your living room.

title: Adding the Fire to a Simmering Feud
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  In the two weeks since Carmelo Anthony lost his cool against the Boston Celtics Kevin Garnett, he has not played a game in another N.B.A. city. He has not been subjected to taunting from opposing fans only too eager to bring up the trash-talking insults from Garnett that may have gotten under his skin. He has, in other words, not had to run a gleeful gantlet of harassment designed to knock him off his game.

title: Governor of Nebraska Backs Route for Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The governor of Nebraska on Tuesday approved a revised route through the state for the Keystone XL pipeline, setting up a decision for President Obama that pipeline opponents say will be a crucial test of his intentions on climate change.

title: Obama Speech Leaves G.O.P. Stark Choices
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas aggressive Inaugural Address on Monday presented Congressional Republicans with a stark choice over the next two years: accommodate the presidents agenda on immigration, guns, energy and social programs and hope to take the liberal edge off issues dictated by the White House, or dig in as the last bulwark against a re-elected Democratic president and accept the political risks of that hard-line stance.

title: Charismatic Leader Helps Israel Turn Toward the Center
description: RAMAT GAN, Israel  With his good looks and suave manner, Yair Lapid had long been a celebrity and symbol of success here, building a strong following as a prominent journalist and the host of a popular television show.

title: Holding Back the Japanese Economy
description: The Bank of Japan has announced that it will take steps to try to increase Japans inflation to a target rate of 2 percent.

title: Iran Currency Falls Further on Concerns Over Bank
description: Irans currency, weakened by Western sanctions and economic mismanagement, has fallen further in value over the past few days in an apparent reaction to a leadership problem at the Central Bank that has stirred new concerns about political tensions, money traders and outside economists said Tuesday.

title: Stephens Upsets Williams in Stunner
description: MELBOURNE  What was supposed to be a learning experience against one of the greatest tennis players in history turned instead into one of the bigger surprises in tennis history as the 19-year-old Sloane Stephens introduced herself to a global audience by rallying to defeat her 31-year-old American elder, Serena Williams, on Wednesday, 3-6, 7-5, 6-4.

title: Allergan to Buy MAP Pharmaceuticals for $958 Million
description: Allergan has agreed to pay nearly $1 billion to acquire MAP Pharmaceuticals and gain full control of its experimental treatment for migraine headaches, the two companies announced Tuesday night.

title: Taiho, Dominant Postwar Sumo Champ, Dies at 72
description: Taiho, widely considered the greatest sumo wrestler of postwar Japan despite the fact that he weighed scarcely more than 300 pounds, died on Saturday in Tokyo. He was 72.

title: Climate Change and Population Growth Meet Along the Brahmaputra River
Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Jan. 23, 2013
description: If youre a woman in distress, the last thing you want to do is go to the police.

title: Floridas Great Python Hunt
description: Thousands have signed up for a one-month, open-invitation contest to search for pythons in South Florida.

title: N.R.A. Leader Denounces Obamas Call for Gun Control
description: WASHINGTON  Wayne LaPierre, the executive director of the National Rifle Association, angrily accused President Obama on Tuesday of demonizing law-abiding gun owners and of wanting to put every private personal firearms transaction right under the thumb of the federal government.

title: The Brewing Terror Threat in Thailand
description: BEIJING  Islamic terrorism never went away, though it seemed perhaps to have quieted down after the death of Osama bin Laden in 2011. But is it back now, stronger, as the crisis in Mali shows? And is southern Thailand a next crisis zone?

title: Brodeur Is Steady as Ever in the Devils Home Opener
description: NEWARK  Cries of Lets Go Devils! were followed by an obscene chant repeatedly aimed at the rival Philadelphia Flyers on Tuesday night, leaving no doubt the N.H.L. had returned to the Prudential Center after a 119-day lockout.

title: Is There One Right Way to Run?
description: In recent years, many barefoot running enthusiasts have been saying that to reduce impact forces and injury risk, runners should land near the balls of their feet, not on their heels, a running style that has been thought to mimic that of our barefoot forebears and therefore represent the most natural way to run. But a new study of barefoot tribespeople in Kenya upends those ideas and, together with several other new running-related experiments, raises tantalizing questions about just how humans really are meant to move.

title: Federal Class-Action Securities Lawsuits Fell in 2012, Study Finds
description: As the stock markets improved last year, it appears, demand for federal shareholder lawsuits diminished.

title: Word of the Day | eulogistic
description: eulogistic \y-l-jis-tik\ adjective

title: Dolores Prida, Columnist and Playwright, Dies at 69
description: Dolores Prida, a Cuban-born journalist and playwright who wrote candidly and wittily about local and national politics, romance and other personal matters, and the joys and vexations of the Hispanic experience in America, died early Sunday in Manhattan. She was 69.

title: Joseph Eger, Horn Player and Activist, Is Dead at 92
description: Joseph Eger, a French horn player, conductor and advocate for progressive causes whose work sought to promote harmony in both senses of the word, died on Jan. 13 at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 92.

title: Public Universities to Offer Free Online Classes for Credit
description: In an unusual arrangement with a commercial company, dozens of public universities plan to offer an introductory online course free and for credit to anyone worldwide, in the hope that those who pass will pay tuition to complete a degree program.

title: A Plan to Save New Zealands Birds: Get Rid of Cats
description: HONG KONG  A prominent New Zealand economist has set off a storm by suggesting that cats should eventually be eliminated from his country, claiming that they are posing a dire threat to native bird species.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO2) SING YOUR SONG (2012) In 1956 Harry Belafonte, above, became the first recording artist to sell more than a million LPs with his album Calypso and in the process broke color barriers as he rose to success in an era of segregation. He won Grammy, Tony and Emmy Awards but was also blacklisted during the McCarthy era, spied on by the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., and threatened by the Ku Klux Klan, state troopers and Las Vegas Mafia bosses. This documentary from Susanne Rostock distills more than 700 hours of interviews, excerpts from F.B.I. files and archival film to chronicle the life and times of Mr. Belafonte, now 85, from his birth in Harlem and his childhood in Jamaica to his work with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his activism against apartheid in South Africa and his actions to counter gang violence and the incarceration of youth.

title: Rape Trial Challenges a Jam in Indias Justice System
description: NEW DELHI  For Sonia Gandhi, Indias most powerful politician, the 23-year-old victim of the fatal gang rape last month embodied the spirit of an aspirational India.

title: News Quiz | January 23, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Europe Is Edgy as Cameron Seeks to Loosen Ties
description: BRUSSELS  The French are engaged in a lonely military adventure in Africa. The Germans are preoccupied with domestic elections rather than regional affairs. Unemployment in some countries is at historic highs and economies across Europe are still mired in recession.

title: At This Years Jaipur Lit Fest, Feminism, the Dalai Lama and Cricket
description: NEW DELHI  It is that time of year again when the pink city of Jaipur in Rajasthan State warms up to host a carefully curated panel of literary greats from across the globe for the Jaipur Literature Festival, South Asias biggest annual literary event. In its sixth year now, the five-day event will kick off on Thursday at the majestic Diggi Palace, where 283 writers will appear before an audience of several thousand people and engage them through conversations and book readings.

title: Indian Star Tells of Life and Marriage in Media Fishbowl
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Sania Mirza of India is the most celebrated female athlete in South Asia.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 23
description: NEWS  A weakened Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu emerged Wednesday from Israels national election likely to serve a third term, according to preliminary results and political analysts, after voters on Tuesday gave a surprising second place to a new centrist party founded by a television celebrity who emphasized kitchen-table issues like class size and apartment prices. Jodi Rudoren reports from Jerusalem.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 23, 2013
description: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the Fifth Down blog post Quirks of the Game: The Rise of the Pick-Six.

title: The Mystery of the 200-Mile Cat Journey
description: In A Cats 200-Mile Trek Home Leaves Scientists Guessing, Pam Belluck writes about an indoor house cat, lost on a family excursion, who somehow found her way home.

title: What Do You Do When You Encounter Obstacles to Success?
description: When David Chang first opened the Momofuku Noodle Bar, his tiny Manhattan restaurant, he could barely pay himself a salary. He had trouble keeping staff. And he was miserably stressed.

title: Former Chinese Leader Steps Back, Fueling Speculation
description: HONG KONG  A decade after he stepped down as Chinas top leader, the powerful Communist Party elder Jiang Zemin has used the death of a former rival to signal that he may allow his political shadow to recede and give the nations newest leader more room to consolidate his authority.

title: Study Links Cognitive Deficits, Hearing Loss
description: Theres another reason to be concerned about hearing loss  one of the most common health conditions in older adults and one of the most widely undertreated. A new study by researchers at Johns Hopkins Medicine suggests that elderly people with compromised hearing are at risk of developing cognitive deficits  problems with memory and thinking  sooner than those whose hearing is intact.

title: Deutsche Bank Agrees to Settle Energy Trading Inquiry
description: Deutsche Bank has agreed to a settlement with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission over charges that the bank manipulated Californias energy markets in 2010.

title: North Korea Hints at New Nuclear Test in Rebuke to U.N.
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea said Wednesday that its nuclear weapons program was no longer negotiable, and indicated that it might conduct its third nuclear test to retaliate against the United Nations Security Councils tightening of sanctions against the country for launching a rocket last month.

title: Juggling Too Many Scholarship Applications, and Learning to Let Go
description: Now that Ive finished college applications, Im transitioning to searching and applying for scholarships. The more I search, the better Ive become at finding them and the more I realize that there is an abundance of scholarships for which I qualify.

title: The Early Word: Take Two
description: Todays Times

title: Further Thoughts on Assessing Regulatory Costs and Benefits
description: 2/7/13 | Updated to clarify counting methods in the study.

title: Day Two Highlights From the Senior Bowl
description: MOBILE, Ala.  The second day of practices Tuesday continued to reinforce the sense of urgency that the Senior Bowl director Phil Savage must be feeling to improve the direction of the all-star game. While most writers would agree  including the two of us  that the Senior Bowl has a lot to offer its players, scouts and news media, the fact that 25 percent of the players initially invited to the event turned down the chance to participate isnt a point that is going to disappear this week when more players disappear from practices. The Clemson big-play back Andre Ellington withdrew. The Texas A&M slot man Ryan Swope was watching on the sidelines without pads. So were linebackers John Simon and Trevardo Williams.

title: Thai Court Gives 10-Year Sentence for Insult to King
description: BANGKOK  A labor activist and former magazine editor was sentenced to 10 years in prison on Wednesday for insulting Thailands king, the latest in a string of convictions under the countrys strict lse-majest law.

title: Monster Fish Surgery in the Wilds of Guyana
description: Dr. Lesley de Souza, a research biologist at the John G. Shedd Aquarium, writes from Guyana, where she studies the regions rich aquatic wildlife, including the arapaima, one of the largest freshwater fishes in the world.

title: A Crystal Award for Charlize Theron
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The actress Charlize Theron and two documentary filmmakers received awards for their humanitarian work as the World Economic Forum opened in Davos Tuesday.

title: Familys Visit Confirms Chinese Dissident Is Alive
description: BEIJING  Family members of one of Chinas most prominent dissidents, Gao Zhisheng, visited him in a prison in the western region of Xinjiang this month, according to Mr. Gaos older brother and a human rights advocacy group. The visit was the first confirmation in nine months that Mr. Gao was still alive.

title: The Feminine Mystique at 50
description: Every writer yearns to create a book that will seize the moment  to perfectly encapsulate the problem of an era before other people even notice the problem exists. Of course, that almost never happens. Mostly were happy if we can manage to explain, in an interesting way, something people already know is going on. But Betty Friedan won the gold ring. When The Feminine Mystique emerged in 1963, it created a reaction so intense that Friedan could later write another book about the things women said to her about the first one (It Changed My Life). If theres a list of the most important books of the 20th century, The Feminine Mystique is on it. It also made one conservative magazines exclusive roundup of the 10 most harmful books of the 19th and 20th centuries, which if not flattering is at least a testimony to the wallop it packed.

title: Can a Web Site Get Visitors to Feel the Cotton?
description: My company, Abes Market, is an online marketplace for natural and organic goods that connects Americans who want to live a more healthful lifestyle with passionate business owners they may not otherwise find. We get hundreds of thousands of visitors every month, and our monthly sales growth has been in double digits. Based in part on that experience, the editors of Youre the Boss have asked me to be the host of regular conversations on the blog about what works and what doesnt when selling online. Were looking for small businesses that would like to have their sites evaluated by the blogs readers. (If you are interested in volunteering your site, please see below.)

title: Could Cyril Ramaphosa Be the Best Leader South Africa Has Not Yet Had?
description: By the time I met Cyril Ramaphosa in 1992, he was Nelson Mandelas choreographer at the negotiations that would eventually bring three centuries of white dominion to a thrilling and relatively peaceful end. Every day a polyglot, multiparty assembly  of former prisoners and their onetime oppressors, Communists and Bantustan autocrats and Afrikaner nationalists and union militants  mingled in a conference center outside Johannesburg to discuss what would be, in effect, the terms of surrender.

title: Pocket Guide to the Jaipur Literature Festival
description: India Ink asked writers, publishers, literary agents and fans of the five-day Jaipur Literature Festival what events they are most looking forward to this year. Here are their responses:

title: On Our Radar: Clean Energy, Sullied
description: The ongoing discovery of links between the Mafia and Italys once-booming wind and solar industries raises questions about the use of government subsidies for renewable energy. [The Washington Post]

title: The News They Carried
description: ISTANBUL  Last Thursday was a major news day in Turkey, and part of the story was that the Turkish media failed to report a major event in the Kurdish southeast of the country.

title: At Davos, Financial Leaders Debate Reform and Monetary Policy
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, apologized again for the banks recent $6 billion trading loss, this time in front of an audience that included the elite of the financial world. But in keeping with his confident demeanor, it was a diet portion of humble pie.

title: Bill Callahans Statement Denying Super Bowl Sabotage
description: The former Raiders coach Bill Callahan released a statement Tuesday night denying accusations that he tried to lose the 2003 Super Bowl against Tampa Bay.

title: Contemplating Obamas Place in History, Statistically
description: With President Obamas second term under way, we have begun to see more reflections on how he might come to be regarded historically.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft May Back Dell Buyout
description: Microsoft is in talks to help finance a takeover bid for Dell that would exceed $20 billion, report Michael J. de la Merced and Nick Wingfield in The New York Times. Microsoft is expected to contribute up to several billion dollars.

title: Stalking a Python
description: Floridas wildlife agency is organizing its first python hunting competition. A group known as the Florida Python Hunters is out to win the challenge. Will it even catch one?

title: Florida Holds High-Profile Hunt for Low-Profile Creatures
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  For as long as anyone can remember, hunters here have wielded machetes, knives, rifles and crossbows as they swept past thickets of mosquitoes and saw grass in pursuit of alligators, feral hogs, bobcats and vermin of all sizes.

title: Mad Men Set to Return on April 7
description: The fifth season of Mad Men concluded last June on notes of ambiguity: Don Draper was considering a proposition from an alluring stranger; his wife, Megan, had embarked on her acting career; Roger Sterling was enjoying an altered state of consciousness; and Peggy Olson, having quit the Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce agency to join a rival firm, was on a field assignment, watching dogs do, well, doggy things. Where does this 1960s period drama go from here, and what will happen next to its characters?

title: To Heighten the Art? Take It to Vegas
description: THERE WAS THIS FEELING that You cant put a diva in a trunk, the director Michael Mayer is saying, eyes alight with triumph, during a break from rehearsals for his bold new production of Rigoletto, which opens on Monday evening at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Fantasy Football Accuracy Rankings for 2012
description: Sara Holladay is the Fantasy Football Librarian.

title: Keeping the Internet Safe From Governments
description: Even before the World Conference on International Telecommunications took place last month in Dubai, Internet activists anticipated trouble. So did Congress, which issued a resolution calling it essential that the Internet remain stable, secure and free from governmental control.

title: Chipping Away at Poverty  an Exchange
description: Advocates of Supplemental Security Income, or SSI, have been steaming at a December column that I wrote from Kentucky, arguing that it unfairly maligns a program that is a lifeline to the disabled. Heres one criticism , heres another, and here are letters we published. Ive tweeted some of the criticisms and responded with tweets, but I havent really engaged in a broader discussion, so thats what Id like to do here. First, youll see below a memo from two attorneys from Community Legal Services in Philadelphia to the Timess Public Editor (theyve agreed to make the memo public), and then (after their footnotes) a response by me to the points they raise.

title: Opinion Report: The School Bus Strike
description: From the editorial page

title: For Dell Deal, Silver Lake May Find a Partner in Microsoft
description: Silver Lake may have found a deep-pocketed investor to join a takeover effort for Dell. Microsoft, Dells longtime ally, is in talks to contribute up to several billion dollars to a potential bid, which could exceed $20 billion, a person briefed on the matter tells DealBooks Michael J. de la Merced.
