Investigators said Mr. Kekhman was not a target of the investigation. The Joint Fruit Company filed for bankruptcy last year after creditors sought repayment of the loans. Mr. Kekhman issued a statement saying that he was outraged by the fraud allegations against company officials and that he was cooperating with law enforcement.

title: Protesters Clash With Police in Cairo
description: Protesters clashed with the police on Thursday in Cairo near Tahrir Square on the eve of the second anniversary of the uprising that toppled President Hosni Mubarak. Three police officers and dozens of protesters were injured in skirmishes after protesters tried to dismantle concrete barriers that had been set up around the Interior Ministry after previous demonstrations. A coalition of opposition groups has called for a major rally in Tahrir Square, the center of the 2011 uprising, to voice opposition to the new Islamist-backed Constitution and President Mohamed Morsi. The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group allied with Mr. Morsi, has asked its supporters to observe the anniversary by taking part in community service projects far from the square, a plea aimed at preventing renewed fighting between the factions.

title: The Perils of DVRing the Australian Open
description: How does one fit eight hours of tennis viewing into a workday without getting fired or divorced? Thats the question I face four times every year when my life revolves around tenniss major tournaments to the detriment of work and family life. Twice in the past five years, I made the mistake of booking trips to Latin America during the Australian Open and found myself up in the middle of the night, watching grainy images of barely recognizable figures on dodgy Web sites that infected my laptop with viruses. Never again.

title: Towns Next Hit From Hurricane Is to Tax Revenue
description: Localities across the New York region, already reeling from the cost of cleaning up from Hurricane Sandy, are confronting the prospect of an even bigger blow to their finances: a precipitous decline in property tax revenues.

title: Two Children Who Need All of Mothers Energy
description: Nine steps lead to the front door of the Tam-Diaz household. Thirteen more lead from the first floor to the second. And Colleen Tam-Diaz feels the strain of every one.

title: Even in Sickness, a Promise to a Son to Fulfill
description: It has been more years than she can remember since Dolores Lora tried to solve a math problem or was tested on her spelling. She could not believe how much she had forgotten as she watched one of her sons tackle his homework with ease.

title: With Verdict Cast Aside, a Mystery Is Renewed
description: The murder of Denise Raymond, in 1995, was extraordinarily savage by any measure.

title: Unexpected Focus at a Mayoral Forum
description: This years campaign for New York City mayor was expected to turn on police tactics, education policy and economic development.

title: Victory for Anthony and for Knicks
description: BOSTON  He was booed during the introduction of the Knicks starting lineup. He was booed when he touched the ball on the Knicks first possession. While the sellout crowd at TD Garden was generally restrained (by Boston standards) in its treatment of Carmelo Anthony, he would enjoy the last laugh.

title: Word of the Day | venom
description: venom \ve-nm\ noun

title: Boston Crowd Boos Anthony, but Bitterness Is Left Behind
description: BOSTON  Max Goldstein of Manhattan dutifully paid more than $100 for his upper-bowl seat at TD Garden on Thursday night. To him, it was money well spent.

title: Whats On Friday
description: 1:30 P.M. (IFC) ABOUT A BOY (2002) In Paul and Chris Weitzs adaptation of Nick Hornbys novel Hugh Grant plays Will, a London Lothario with a Peter Pan complex who must face up to his irresponsible ways when Marcus (Nicholas Hoult), the socially inept 12-year-old son of a hippie-dippy single mother (Toni Collette, above, with Mr. Grant, right, and Mr. Hoult), begins to stalk him. Rachel Weisz is the artist on whom Will fixes his sights; he uses Marcus to help seduce her. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that Mr. Grant, leaning on his mumbling charm until it turns into its opposite, is an ideal cad. Like High Fidelity, another of Mr. Hornbys works, About a Boy finds redemption in a stale, gooey pop song, in this case Roberta Flacks Killing Me Softly, Mr. Scott added. Its a cheap trick, but one thats guaranteed to work every time. You succumb to the movies warmth and bonhomie because the alternative is to remain in the isolating, self-protective cynicism from which Will has been lucky to escape.

title: News Quiz | January 25, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Where Science and Religion Coexist
description: MUNDGOD, India  Religion and science have not always been easy friends, as Galileo could attest.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 25
description: NEWS  A blunt and explicit threat on Thursday from North Korea that its weapons programs would target the United States, and that it would proceed with a third and higher-level nuclear test, poses a stark challenge to the Obama administration at a time when it hoped to focus its major diplomatic effort on restraining Irans less-advanced nuclear program. David E. Sanger reports from Washington and Choe Sang-Hun from Seoul.

title: In Jaipur, a Strong Showing From Pakistan, Despite Calls for Boycott
description: JAIPUR, Rajasthan  Amid much controversy, the Jaipur Literature Festival opened with a large selection of Pakistani writers on Thursday.

title: Which Companies Sustainability Promises Do You Believe?
description: H&M, the Swedish clothing retail giant, has vowed to become greener and more sustainable when it comes to the water it uses to make its clothes.

title: North Korea Warns of Retaliation if South Helps Enforce Tightened Sanctions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea turned its anger on South Korea on Friday, warning the South Koreans they could suffer physical countermeasures for any enforcement of the tightened international sanctions meant to stop its ballistic missile and nuclear weapons activities.

title: U.S. Envoy Apologizes for Ships Grounding on Philippine Coral Reef
description: MANILA  The United States ambassador to the Philippines apologized Friday for the grounding of an American naval ship on a reef in a marine sanctuary, the latest in a string of embarrassing episodes for the United States military in the country at a time when the administration is pushing a pivot to Asia and the American military has increased its presence in the Philippines.

title: Test Yourself | Critical Thinking, Jan. 25, 2013
description: This question was written by Katherine Schulten from an Opinionator post by Linda Greenhouse headlined Misconceptions.

title: Grand Central Terminals Many Secrets
description: In the video The Secrets of Grand Central, Sam Roberts gives viewers a tour of the century-old New York City train station.

title: Familiar Rooms, Hidden Faces
description: If looking at Alison Bradys photographs makes you inexplicably uncomfortable, then she has accomplished her goal. Her images are carefully structured to blend the familiar with the unknown  antique furniture and vintage fabrics juxtaposed with unnaturally twisted body forms  with the hope of getting viewers to ask one question: I know these objects, but why does this all feel so foreign?

title: Was There a Toy You Wanted as a Child But Never Got?
description: Was there a toy you coveted as a child, but couldnt have because it was too impractical or expensive, because your parents were philosophically opposed to it, or for some other reason? What was it, and why did you want it so much?

title: Time to Recognize Mild Cognitive Disorder?
description: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, published and periodically updated by the American Psychiatric Association, is one of those documents few laypeople ever read, but many of us are affected by.

title: Chinese Leader Takes Conciliatory Tone in Meeting With Japanese Lawmaker
description: BEIJING  Chinas new leader, Xi Jinping, offered Japan a conciliatory tone during a meeting with a senior Japanese politician on Friday in what appeared to be an effort to reduce the escalating tensions between the countries over islands in the East China Sea.

title: France Is Sweet on Sugar Man
description: A love story is developing between the French and Rodriguez, the Detroit-born musician who flopped in the 1970s, was a star without knowing it in apartheid South Africa and was rediscovered last summer in the United States when the documentary Searching for Sugar Man was released.

title: Italy's Oil Leader Is Pursuing Its East African Bet
description: MILAN  Tucked away in a building on the outskirts of Milan is the nirvana room, so called perhaps because of the good tidings it contains. There, geologists working for the Italian oil company Eni don 3-D glasses to contemplate fluorescent images of underground geological formations and try to divine which might be worth tens of millions of dollars in exploratory drilling.

title: Getting Sales Representatives to Sell
description: During a previous She Owns It business group meeting, Beth Shaw, who owns YogaFit, said she realized she had to ramp up her sales efforts. Toward that end, she brought on a sales manager with a 60-day contract that is up in February. So far, results have been lackluster, leaving Ms. Shawto wonder whether her expectations are realistic and whether she is offering the contractor the proper incentives to sell sponsorships of YogaFits conferences and its branded merchandise.She asked the group how quickly they expected new sales representatives to sell and what type of learning curve they expected.

title: Five Questions for: Prajwal Parajuly
description: Prajwal Parajuly is an Indian writer whose first book The Gurkhas Daughter, a collection of short stories on Nepalese-speaking people, was recently released in India. He spoke to India Ink from the Jaipur Literature Festival.

title: A Hip-Hop Aesthetic With a Careful Grasp on History
description: ASAP Rocky, the flashy Harlem hip-hop star, just released his first major-label album, Long.Live.ASAP (Polo Grounds/RCA), which made its debut atop the Billboard album chart. Behind the scenes is ASAP Yams, his longtime friend and collaborator, who serves as something of a spirit guide, helping to shape Rockys hybrid hip-hop.

title: Measles and Weasels
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Pakistan is currently threatened by a measles epidemic. According to the World Health Organization, 103 children have died from pneumonia and other measles-related complications between Jan. 1 and 19. In Sindh, the worst-hit province, 66 deaths have been recorded this month; in Baluchistan, 33.

title: Daily Report: In a French Case, a Battle to Unmask Twitter Users
description: A French court on Thursday told Twitter to identify people who had posted anti-Semitic and racist entries on the social network, Eric Pfanner and Somini Sengupta report in Fridays New York Times. Twitter is not sure it will comply. And so goes yet another dust-up in the struggle over speech on the Internet, and which countries laws prevail.

title: Free Expert Advice for Rahul Gandhi
description: He formally became the vice president of the governing Congress party this week, and is expected to throw his hat into the ring for Indias top job in the 2014 general elections, but Rahul Gandhi, the 42-year-old reticent scion of Indias Gandhi dynasty, remains something of a mystery.

title: Not Like the Old Boss: Hip-Hops Spirit Guide
description: THE STORY OF NEW YORK hip-hops 1990s championship years is in many ways the story of rapper-executive dream teams, pairings that shaped the sound of the city and, after that, the world. The Notorious B.I.G. and Puff Daddy, Jay-Z and Damon Dash, Ja Rule and Irv Gotti  all of these partnerships made the behind-the-scenes swami as crucial a hip-hop figure as the rappers they helped mold.

title: Opinion Report: Gerrymandering in Virginia
description: From the editorial page

title: Europes Banks to Pay Some 3-Year Loans Early
description: 5:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Five Questions for: Aminatta Forna
description: Aminatta Fornas most recent novel, The Memory of Love, won the Commonwealth Writers Prize Best Book Award for 2011.

title: For Michael Jackson Bio, Trying to Even the Score
description: When Randall Sullivan published his biography of Michael Jackson in November, he said he thought the singer was innocent of child molesting but he could not be absolutely positive. He said that after surgeries and more surgeries, little was left of Mr. Jacksons nose besides his nostrils. He argued that despite two marriages, Mr. Jackson was probably a virgin when he died.

title: A Long Island Accent in London
description: Dear Diary:

title: Ackman Vs. Icahn, the Rematch
description: ACKMAN VS. ICAHN, THE REMATCH | A high-profile feud on Wall Street went another round on Thursday, when the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman responded to comments by Carl C. Icahn. In a scathing news release, Mr. Ackman questioned his opponents integrity after Mr. Icahn publicly criticized Mr. Ackmans method in betting against Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company.

title: Deadly Turn in Protests Against Iraqi Leadership
description: BAGHDAD  At least seven protesters and two soldiers were killed Friday in clashes that started after Iraqi Army forces opened fire on demonstrators who had pelted them with rocks on the outskirts of Falluja, west of Baghdad. It was the first deadly confrontation in more than a month of antigovernment protests by mostly Sunni opponents of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

title: Now Shopping | Pigeon
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: U.N. Cites Record Numbers as Syrians Flee to Jordan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  More than 6,000 Syrians have fled to Jordan over the past two days, a record influx that prompted the Jordanian monarch, Abdullah II, to call Friday for more international aid, even as the Syrian government urged refugees to return in a bid that was met with broad skepticism among antigovernment activists.

title: Compuware Rejects Elliotts $2.3 Billion Bid
description: 11:46 a.m. | Updated

title: Coachella Headliners Include Stone Roses, Blur and Red Hot Chili Peppers
description: No Rolling Stones will gather this year in the grassy fields of Indio, Calif., where the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival is held. But concertgoers will get the Stone Roses, as well as fellow British rockers Blur, along with the bands Phoenix, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Vampire Weekend and the Wu-Tang Clan, its organizers said.

title: Ascendant Latin America Seeks to Recast European Ties
description: LONDON  There was a time when Europe regarded Latin America as a stagnant economic backwater, dependent on selling its natural resources to pay its debts and ruled over by a variety of disagreeable despots.

title: As Worries Ebb, Small Investors Propel Markets
description: Americans seem to be falling in love with stocks again.

title: What Were Reading
description: Mens Journal: April Bloomfield reveals her chefly oyster secrets: shuck them perfectly, heat them minimally. The whole point of oysters is that theyre delicious by themselves, she says, offering two recipes.  Glenn Collins

title: Obama Reaches Out, but Not Very Far, to Build New Team
description: WASHINGTON  As he heads into a second term with sweeping ambition in an era of gridlock, President Obama is assembling a new White House team that looks much like the old one, choosing familiarity over freshness even at the risk of insularity.

title: Tighter Radiation Monitoring for Fracking Sites
description: Pennsylvania will step up its monitoring of naturally occurring radiation levels in water, rock cuttings and drilling wastes associated with oil and gas development in a yearlong study that will be peer-reviewed, the states environmental agency reports.

title: Making Sense of Wall Streets Trading Revenue
description: Traders at the top Wall Street firms racked up nearly $80 billion of revenue last year. But understanding how they produced all that money is far from simple.

title: Yet More G.O.P. Obstruction
description: In his first term, President Obama tried to fill two vacancies on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. No luck: Senate Republicans blocked both of his nominees. Unsurprisingly, theyre showing no signs of letting up. As Legal Times reported on Wednesday, theyre delaying hearings for Srikanth Srinivasan, an exceptional and moderate candidate.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Officer Sentenced to 30 Months in Leak
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  A former Central Intelligence Agency officer was sentenced on Friday to 30 months in prison for disclosing the identity of a covert agency officer to a freelance writer, representing the first time that a C.I.A. officer will serve prison time for disclosing classified information to the news media.

title: Playing Catch-Up
description: Students at Rockaway Park High School for Environmental Sustainability are back in their school, and they're struggling to make up for lost time.

title: A Tale of Two Islamisms
description: BAMAKO, Mali  Last spring radical Islamism took over the north of Mali. Three fundamentalist militias with links to Al Qaeda hijacked a Tuareg uprising and after seizing two-thirds of the country, enforced Shariah at gunpoint and smashed religious monuments, eliciting comparisons to the Taliban.

title: Brothers Crash Out of X Games
description: ASPEN, Colo.  A few hours before his sons were strapped to stretchers and slotted into separate ambulances, having crashed their 500-pound snowmobiles upon landing from 100-foot jumps, Wade Moore discussed what it was like to watch Caleb and Colten Moore fly through the air.

title: At Davos: Goldmans Chief Bears a New Look
description: Chief executives often treat the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, as a chance to air fresh ideas about business and economics.

title: Consumer Spending and Inequality Denial
description: Ive been debating rising inequality with the usual suspects for a couple of decades (despite what it says on this piece, it was actually published in 1992). And what you always encounter from the right is a sort of defense in depth: claims, based on tortured statistics, that it isnt happening; claims, based on similarly tortured statistics, that it doesnt matter; and claims that anyway its a good thing. You might think that people would have to choose one of these lines: you cant simultaneously say that inequality isnt rising and that the rise is a good thing, can you? Well, yes you can; were engaged in a political defense of the 1% here, not research.

title: Mayor Says Some 2013 Candidates Just Sound Ridiculous
description: It could be a long year for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Look Ma, No (Human) Hands
description: Felix Salmon has been converted to the cult of the self-driving car; indeed, this is starting to look like a real thing. And Im impressed.

title: Friday Reading: The Greenest Cars of 2013
Feeling For | Laroses Hats
description: We really believe in brands that specialize in one item and do it very, very well, says Marc Beaug, one of the founders of the Paris-based hat label Larose. Beaug, a style writer, and Isaac Larose Farmer, an event planner/entrepreneur, created the label as a side project. It hinges on a single item: a cap with a five-panel formula for men (though women can certainly wear them, too). Pauline Brosset, a chapelire (hat maker) who has also worked with Kenzo, completes the team and executes the designs.

title: When Arsenal Played Long Island
description: The announcement of the New York Cosmos bid for a soccer stadium as part of the Elmont Town Crossings project at Belmont Park, along with their return to play at Hofstras Shuart Stadium in the North American Soccer League fall season, brings Long Islands Nassau County  long a hotbed for youth soccer  back into play as a potential host for high-profile international friendlies.

title: Busiest Arena? The Talk-Show Couch
description: Now that Manti Teo has made his appearance as daytime television fodder  complete with studio audience, Katie Couric questioning him as if he were a wayward third grader and parents crying on cue  can we please squelch this little trend of turning sports controversies into television entertainment events? Somehow, sports has wandered into this weird realm of image consultants and makeup artists, where Oprah Winfrey is snubbed and we are leaked tidbits of what somebody said in an interview taped two days ago so it can be milked for optimal promotional value.

title: Murray Outduels Federer and Heads to Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE  It was quite a night of tennis and ultimately a rough night for Roger Federer, who not only swore in the direction of Andy Murray but was also beaten in a Grand Slam tournament for the first time by Murray.

title: Reader Response: Medicare Options and Quality of Care
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Chambliss Announces Retirement From Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Saxby Chambliss, the Georgia Republican who helped lead efforts to find a bipartisan deficit reduction compromise, announced on Friday that he would retire at the end of 2014, a decision likely to set off a battle on the Republican Partys right flank for a successor.

title: This Weeks Movies: Jan. 25
description: In this weeks video, Times critics offer their thoughts on the action film Parker with Jason Statham, the Israeli drama Yossi and Im Sang-soos Taste of Money. Find all of this weeks reviews here.

title: The Accidental Writer
description: I became a writer when I was hit on the head with a rock. It was 1969, I was 6 years old and my mother had dropped me off at a friends birthday party. It was June, and I remember the backyard of that house, in Mandeville Canyon, the hot California sun on my hair, the screams of the children as they ran around the yard. The partygoers had assembled into a big and rowdy gang, chasing the birthday boy, trying to get him to crawl through the spanking machine (a joyful and sadistic enterprise in which the children stood in a row and the birthday boy crawled through their legs, getting whacked along the way). The adults gathered inside, trying to ignore us. Then the birthday boy picked up a big rock. And he threw it.

title: Woman Fatally Struck by a Bus in Canarsie
description: A woman was struck and killed by a private charter bus while crossing a street in Canarsie, Brooklyn, on Friday morning, the police said. No charges were filed against the driver, the police said. The woman, whose name was not released, was hit while crossing East 105th Street near Avenue K around 7:15 a.m. She is in her 40s, the police said. Her husband told NBC 4 New York that she was crossing the street to catch a city bus when the private bus turned left off Avenue K and struck her.

title: Watery Wonders
description: Go diving off the coast of Malaysia to experience what Jacques Cousteau called an untouched piece of art.

title: War by Other Means
description: For the counterinsurgency experts of a century ago, the extension of European empire into the Middle East offered exciting possibilities. The Italians bombed Libyans on the eve of World War I, but that was just the beginning. From 1919 onward, the fledgling Royal Air Force was busy dropping bombs on Afghan, Somali and Iraqi tribesmen. In 1926, French artillery shelled the center of Damascus. It was in this context that Elbridge Colby, an American Army captain, wrote an article, How to Fight Savage Tribes, in order to educate his countrymen and challenge what he saw as their nave faith in international law.

title: Ask Well: Squats for Aging Knees
description: Question:

title: Editors Choice
description: GOING CLEAR: Scientology, Hollywood, and the Prison of Belief,  by Lawrence Wright. (Knopf, $28.95.) In tone, the author of The Looming Tower takes a calm and neutral stance toward Scientology, but he makes clear that its like no other church on earth.

title: Reading for His Life
description: By Joe Queenans reckoning, in his 62 years of life he has read at least 6,128 books. Should he continue to read at his current clip (100 to 200 books annually), he calculates that given natural life expectancy, he has only some 2,138 books to go. The clock is ticking, he warns, for him and for us all. If that makes you want to abandon this review immediately and grab the nearest Dostoyevsky, no hard feelings.

title: Running Through His Mind
description: Genius, it seems, is almost always accompanied by eccentricity, if not madness. Those rare instances of genuine brilliance that we find scattered throughout history  in the music of Ludwig van Beethoven, the paintings of Vincent van Gogh, the mathematical equations of John Nash  often appear to have come at great cost to the minds that produced them. The work of Eadweard Muybridge is no exception.

title: The Rise of ASAP Rocky
description: The young Harlem rapper ASAP Rocky recently topped the Billboard album chart with the release of his major label debut album, Long.Live.ASAP. This week, Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the album, what it means to be post-regional in a genre so obsessed with place, and what Rockys success might mean for hip-hop in general.

title: Up Front
description: Candice Millard has written for a number of publications, including National Geographic, Time and The New York Times Book Review, but she is probably best known for her two books, The River of Doubt and Destiny of the Republic, the first about Theodore Roosevelts expedition to South America, the second about the assassination of James A. Garfield.

title: On a Stage Shared With Trains, a Voice to Stir the Soul
description: He sat quietly on the platform of the 42nd Street subway station, a haven for buskers of varying talent, this rumply, gray-mustachioed man, dressed in thick layers and a Yankees cap. From his shopping cart, which he had packed with two amplifiers, CDs of his music for sale and a plastic tip bucket, Geechee Dan cued his background music.

title: Geechee Dan Plays the 42nd Street Subway
description: He once played splashy uptown venues like the Cotton Club. Now, seven nights a week, Geechee Dan takes the stage in the underbelly of New York City.

title: What Does It Mean to Be Comfortable?
description: In 1999, government workers in Mexico took their last officially sanctioned siesta. Until then, it was normal for clerks and bureaucrats to take two- or three-hour breaks in the middle of the workday. Many of them went home for lunch, took a nap, then returned to their offices, working into the evening to make up for lost time. The siesta used to be commonplace in Spanish-speaking countries, but the tradition was already waning as Latin Americas economies developed throughout the 80s and 90s. As companies and governments modernized, they adopted the same schedules as their counterparts in other countries. Mexico failed to properly anticipate the effect this would have on energy consumption.

title: Popping Wheelies in Charm City
description: Baltimores dirt-bike street riders.

title: Clip: 12 OClock Boys
description: A preview of a scene from a film directed by Lotfy Nathan about the people who ride dirt bikes on the streets of Baltimore.

title: We Were Joy Division
description: It all started with the Sex Pistols. I saw them twice in 1976  two gigs weeks apart at the Lesser Free Trade Hall in Manchester  Bernard Sumner (our guitarist) and I went together with a couple of friends to the first gig, and at the second gig I bumped into Ian Curtis, who would become our lead singer. They were only on for half an hour, but when they finished, we filed out quietly with our minds blown, absolutely utterly speechless, and it just sort of dawned on me then  that was it. On the way home that night we decided to form a band  Joy Division. The name was Ians idea.

title: The 1.13.13 Issue
description: CATCH A FALLING STAR

title: Steve Cohens Nemesis?
description: The Big Profile

title: Who Made That Military Dog Tag?
description: During the Civil War, more than a quarter of dead soldiers remained unidentified. I saw two human skull-bones, one pelvis and two jaw bones lying on a stump with no trace of a grave, a newspaper correspondent wrote in 1866 about his tour of Southern battlefields. Even mothers could not recognize the weathered corpses of their sons. In order to increase the chances that they would receive proper burials, soldiers bought customized name tags made of metal or wood. When pinned on the lapel or worn around the neck, a tag could help bring the dead soldier home. Soldiers did a lot to try to be identified, says Luther Hanson, curator at the U.S. Army Quartermaster Museum. Some soldiers even wrote their names on the bottom of their shoes.

title: Ray Kurzweil Says Were Going to Live Forever
description: As a futurist, you are famous for making predictions of when technological innovations will actually occur. Are you willing to predict the year you will die?  My plan is to stick around. Well get to a point about 15 years from now where were adding more than a year every year to your life expectancy.

title: Image of the Day: Jan. 25
A Fathers Grief, and the Toll of His Gun-Control Crusade
description: FOR SALE BY OWNER declares a sign on the porch of Al Valentins house on Ellis Avenue in the Bronx. Inside the spotless brick home, he shows off the place like the seasoned real estate pro that he is. Soft light. Solid floors. And not only one basement level, but two  and all done according to code. In the back, where a pool once was, a barbecue pit.

title: Acting as a Mediator at the Crossroads of Faith and Film
description: PARK CITY, Utah  On the day before she entered a Catholic boarding school in August 1967, as a 15-year-old who felt the call to be a nun, Rose Pacatte indulged in a final fling with the secular world. She went to the local drive-in to see The Dirty Dozen.

title: The Heat of Battle
description: War is a popular subject for shoot-em-up video games. Beyond the 3-D animated battlefields, however, lie several engaging multimedia history apps that take interactivity to a different level  and explain why people have answered that call of duty over the years.

title: Common Core Practice | Cheating Scandals, Fractals and Creative Descriptions of Cheese
description: As Arctic air sweeps across much of the nation, our classroom collaborators in New Jersey have created three new, quick ways to use Times content, address Common Core Standards and  at least if you take them up on their food-writing idea  have some fun.

title: Gallery Stroll: Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  Unpredictable weather means winter isnt the most popular season for visiting Istanbul, but it is a great time for gallery-hopping: Many of the best museums and art spaces in the Beyoglu district have just opened compelling new exhibitions.

title: Neighbor Versus Neighbor
description: What might have been a political polemic or a partisan pitch in the hands of a lesser writer, Rilla Askews fourth novel is a study in the categories and contradictions that dissolve families, dissect communities, and split nations. With a topic as incendiary as immigration at the storys core, Askew could have trod heavily over her subject matter and garnered passionate responses from both sides of the political divide. Instead she personalizes the issue, exploring with a deft hand and an unflinching moral vision the gray areas of an argument so often presented in black and white.

title: Adventures Underground
description: When I first came to live in New York, in 1976, I was enthralled by the graffiti in the subways. It seemed a language from some secret world beneath the city, letters that were barely letters, shaped by hands you never saw: a call to resistance, maybe, notes from the underground.

title: Ends of the Earth
description: This past summer I found myself traveling with a strange man straight out of Melanie Challengers book On Extinction. He was an Alaska homesteader, firefighter and fishing guide, and for a week he led me down a remote rivulet in Alaskas interior. The ostensible purpose of our trip was to fish the biggest remaining sockeye salmon run in the world and at the same time to make a case for opposing what would be the continents largest open-pit mine to be built atop said salmon run. But the more I tried to establish a narrative about this man, the more he broke up my effort with a kind of wilderness attention deficit disorder. No sooner had he hunched over to differentiate the identities of the shades of sage and white in the blooming tundra than he would hear the call of a ptarmigan. This in turn would lead to a discourse on the connection between migrations and snow melt and the desperation of grizzly bears in particularly snowy years. He was so profoundly knowledgeable, and everything he said felt incredibly nuanced and relevant. But at the same time his accounts were often tedious and circular and without any point that an impatient New Yorker could discern.

title: Poetry Chronicle
description: ALIEN VS. PREDATOR  By Michael Robbins.  Penguin Poets, paper, $18.

title: Exiting the Stage
description: The pre-eminent fictional Marlowe is still the hard-boiled detective created by Raymond Chandler, but novelistic treatments of the real-life Elizabethan playwright Christopher Marlowe are running him a close second. The earliest, now seldom read, was a book called It Was Marlowe, published in 1895. Its author was an Ohio lawyer, Wilbur Gleason Zeigler. More recently there have been Anthony Burgesss Dead Man in Deptford and Robin Chapmans Christoferus, both published in 1993, the 400th anniversary of Marlowes death, as well as Tamburlaine Must Die (2004) by the Scottish thriller writer Louise Welsh. The list goes on.

title: Sunken Treasure
description: Some visitors to Venice, dazzled by its beauty, are struck speechless; a great many more, to judge from the ceaseless flood of books about it, have the opposite reaction. The library of literature inspired by the city and its wealth of masterpieces was already vast 131 years ago, when Henry James wrote his essay entitled Venice. It is a great pleasure to write the word, James began, but I am not sure there is not a certain impudence in pretending to add anything to it.

title: Stairway to Hell
description: Heres a sport to make an ironman whimper: Running to the top of a very tall building.

title: Floating Ideas
description: The only thing mid-20th-century scientists disliked more than being wrong was being told they were wrong by a woman. Marie Tharp, barely acknowledged in her life and nearly forgotten since her death in 2006, frustrated her male colleagues on both fronts. Working at a time when female scientists set off reflex skepticism, Tharp drafted the first comprehensive map of the ocean floor, which led to the acceptance of the once-mocked, now fundamental theory of continental drift. Not bad for someone whose discoveries were initially dismissed as girl talk.

title: Loggerheads on a Gun Bill
description: TimesCast: Different sides in the debate offer diverse proposals. | Conditions on the U.S.-Mexico border. | A school in Brooklyn comes back after Hurricane Sandy.

title: How to Make an Ironman Whimper (and Cough)
description: When you watch the video from the start of last Februarys Empire State Building Run-Up, an 86-story stair race, one man stands out. Thomas Dold, a 28-year-old German wearing Bib No. 1, is already a few inches ahead when the starting horn blasts. His shins are canting into a run, and with his left arm hes pushing at the chest of a runner to that side of him. A split second later, his right arm juts up to block more runners.

title: Unlikely Pairings and Potential Breakouts
description: PARK CITY, Utah  One of the charms of Sundance is the way it throws artists, filmmakers and others together, and that combined with the smallness of the town and the relatively few places for parties makes it not uncommon to see, say, Justin Biebers manager a few paces from a veteran star of The Wire in a pop-up club in the basement of a ski lift.

title: In Quebec, a Celebration on Skis
description: Snow squeaked under my boots as I turned up the Rue Ste.-Anne and into the tangerine glow flowing from the streetlampsoverhead. The storm that had blown in that afternoon had eased up for the moment, and in the distance I could just make out the sandstone spires of the St.-Michel church still shrouded in fog.

title: A Monsoon, Then Underwater Magic in Malaysia
description: We were in fins and snorkel masks, navigating the thicket of wooden posts that lift the Sipadan-Kapalai Dive Resort above the limpid waters of the Sulu Sea off Sabah, Malaysia. Around us were enough tropical fish to make not a school, but a university and all its departments: a score of yellow-and-black-striped tigerfish, stock-still under the stairs; a massive grouper, presiding over an artificial reef; banner fish, angelfish, starfish, parrotfish, needlefish, you name it, lounging amid corals and darting between rocks.

title: Book Review Podcast
description: This week, Joe Queenan talks about his reading habits; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; J. D. Biersdorfer discusses new apps about famous wars; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Mud, Leeches and Stunning Beauty in Tasmania
description: I stole my first glimpses of Tasmanias rocky southern coastline from about 2,000 feet up, peering through the rounded pane of the cockpit window whenever I felt composed enough to look up from my sick bag. Beside me, our pilot, Thomas, was riding the yoke as if it was a mechanical bull, trying to keep the single-engine Cessna steady as gusts roared in from the Southern Ocean.

title: Verizon Expands Shared Data Plans Into Business
description: With its new shared data plans, Verizon Wireless is succeeding at pushing consumers to spend more money on wireless data. So why not roll out those plans to businesses?

title: Photos of The Moment | Valentino
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: Deadly Riots Erupt Across Egypt on Anniversary of Revolution
description: CAIRO  Violence erupted across Egypt on Friday as tens of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square to mark the second anniversary of the countrys revolution with an outpouring of rage against the rise to power of the Muslim Brotherhood. At least seven protesters and two police officers were killed in clashes in Suez, the state news media said.

title: Helicopter Parents Make Children Miss Milestones
description: Yet another account of educators describing wild instances of helicopter parenting is making the rounds, this time from Australia. The Sydney Morning Herald reports that two-thirds of school psychologists, counselors, teachers and mental health workers who responded to a survey by the Queensland University of Technology reported seeing some instances of overparenting while more than a quarter said theyd seen many.

title: New-Home Sales Soar  and Remain Low
description: New-home sales rose 20 percent in 2012, the government said Friday. That is the largest annual gain since 1983.

title: Paperback Row
description: HOPE: A Tragedy,  by Shalom Auslander. (Riverhead, $16.) Auslanders previous books  the story collection Beware of God and the memoir Foreskins Lament  are propelled by the authors struggle with the constraints of his Orthodox Jewish background. In Hope: A Tragedy, his first novel, hilarity alternates with pain as a doleful family man in upstate New York finds a prickly geriatric squatter in his attic: she claims to be Anne Frank and is working on a novel to eclipse her girlhood diary.

title: AT&T Will Buy Some Verizon Spectrum for $1.9 Billion
description: AT&T said on Friday that it had agreed to buy some spectrum  the radio waves that carry wireless calls and data  from its main competitor, Verizon Wireless.

title: The Conundrum of Food Waste
description: Each year, 1.3 billion tons of food  about one third of all the food produced globally - ends up wasted even as hundreds of millions of people go hungry. This week, two United Nations agencies opened a global campaign to address that conundrum, calling for changes in the way that food is harvested, transported, processed, sold and consumed.

title: Weekend Fare
description: A festival of beer, bourbon and barbecue will feature two tasting sessions on Saturday at The Tunnel, 608 West 28th Street, in Chelsea. From noon to 4 p.m., the focus is on bacon, and from 5:30 to 8:30 p.m., a barbecue plate is included with the unlimited samplings of beer and bourbon. Limited tickets are available only at the door, at $135 for the first session and $120 in the evening.

title: Popcast: ASAP Rocky Arrives
description: The young Harlem rapper ASAP Rocky recently topped the Billboard album chart with the release of his major label debut album, Long.Live.ASAP. On this weeks Popcast, the host Ben Ratliff talks to Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The Times, about the album, what it means to be post-regional in a genre so obsessed with place, and what trends in hip-hop Rockys success might augur.

title: U.S. Withdraws From Project With Russia on Civil Society
description: MOSCOW  The United States is withdrawing from a bilateral Russian-American working group on civil society, a three-year-old project that embodied the spirit of the reset between Washington and Moscow, in answer to Russias recent crackdown on civil society groups.

title: Court Rejects Obama Move to Fill Posts
description: WASHINGTON  In a ruling that called into question nearly two centuries of presidential recess appointments that bypass the Senate confirmation process, a federal appeals court ruled on Friday that President Obama violated the Constitution when he installed three officials on the National Labor Relations Board a year ago.

title: Off the Charts: Who Trusts the Banks
description: As the financial crisis recedes, bankers are growing less unpopular in the United States, but are still are still trusted far less than bankers in emerging economies.

title: 15,000 Crocodiles Escape From South African Farm
description: JOHANNESBURG  About 15,000 crocodiles escaped from a South African reptile farm along the border with Botswana, a local newspaper reported Thursday.

title: Inside the List
description: THE PLEDGE: Regular viewers of the Today show on NBC know Hoda Kotb as Kathie Lee Giffords chipper co-host and frequent drinking partner during the shows fourth hour, when glasses of wine are such a staple that Saturday Night Live has taken note. So when Kotb and Gifford swore off alcohol for all of January, it was an eventful pledge  and an ill-conceived one, as it turned out, since it coincided with the publication of Kotbs new book and the parties to celebrate its release. According to The New York Post, Gifford was spotted drinking chardonnay at a luncheon she organized for Kotb, just nine days after the announcement on the air of their alcohol sabbatical. You caught me, Gifford said through a representative. You cant celebrate a book launch without it.

title: On Wall Street, Putting Shareholders Second
description: Wall Street has found a new way to put shareholders second. Many banks are finally bowing to pressure to restrain compensation, but Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase are now trying to stifle investors from voting on legitimate matters at their upcoming annual meetings.

title: Protesters and Police Clash in Egypt
description: Tens of thousands of people filled Tahrir Square in Cairo to observe the second anniversary of the revolt against Hosni Mubarak.

title: Where Banking Crisis Raged, Trust Is Slow to Return
description: WHAT have you done to me lately?

title: Con Ed Seeks Rate Increase
description: For Consolidated Edison, the pause after the storm in asking for utility rate increases is over.

title: Hurricane Victims Granted Extension to Apply for Federal Aid
description: New Yorkers whose homes were damaged or destroyed by Hurricane Sandy have been granted a 30-day extension to apply for federal assistance for home repairs and other needs and to the Small Business Administration for loans, officials announced Friday.

title: Japans Role in Making Batteries for Boeing
description: As the search for the cause of smoldering batteries in Boeings grounded 787 Dreamliner continues, investigators and Congressional oversight committees may want to look into a related and potentially sensitive issue: how was the Japanese company GS Yuasa chosen to manufacture the innovative but now suspect lithium-ion batteries on the 787?

title: Even a Developer Can Love a Landmark
description: Rarely do the owners of old buildings converted to residential condominiums request inclusion in a historic district after they have adapted the facade, but the developers of the Park Union in Brooklyns Park Slope neighborhood are doing just that.

title: In U.S. Team Camp, Will Bruin Is a Standout
description: The U.S. national team has now entered into its final week of January camp in California and many young players are looking to force themselves into head coach Jurgen Klinsmanns plans with important qualifiers fast approaching.

title: Amid Criticism, Global Rule Maker Defends Regulatory Efforts
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  The head of a panel that writes the global financial rulebook answered criticism that the so-called Basel Committee has gone soft on banks, arguing that lenders need more time to adjust to new regulations because the financial crisis has lasted longer than anyone expected.

title: G.O.P. Rebranding
description: There is no shortage of people in the Republican Party who think the message voters sent in November was that Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan werent conservative enough.

title: Wheelies: The High-Tech Future Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: When You Dont Do What You Meant To, and Dont Know Why
description: Editors note: Heres one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in ourSmarter Livingcollection.

title: What the Small Player Can Expect When Using a Lobbyist
description: IF there is one thing most small-business owners have in common, it is that they have far less ability than big corporations to affect what happens to them politically.

title: The Sweet Spot | Hoaxes
description: A hoax is a hoax is a hoax. A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about some recent ruses.

title: 20 Outfits, Coming Right Up!
description: Three outfits stood on dress forms at Dior, including a spring suit with miniature yellow flowers embroidered in the neckline of the pale blue gazar jacket. I asked Catherine Rivire, Diors longtime director of haute couture, if she had a client for the three-piece suit. Not that the cost would have deterred a rich client, but I wondered about the newness of the design.

title: Calendar: Upcoming Events in Mumbai, Las Vegas, New York City, San Francisco
description: Kala Ghoda Arts Festival, Mumbai Visual arts, cinema, music, literature and cuisine can be explored at this festival, Feb. 2 to Feb. 10. It usually draws 150,000 people, many of them residents of this city of more than 13 million. Not that one goes to India to avoid crowds.(kalaghodaassociation.com)

title: And the Champion of Cheese Description Is
description: This week when we asked you, the readers, to dazzle us with your cheese-extolling skills, we had no idea what we were getting into.

title: Q & A
description: Great Condo, With Stabilized Tenant

title: A Technical Debate With Broader Implications for Deal-Making
description: The emerging issue of dont ask/dont waive standstills is a debate that, lets face it, only a Delaware deals lawyer could love. But it has the potential to change the way that public companies are sold.

title: Textures From Near, Far and Out of a Psychedelic Haze
description: Fllakzoid

title: Comeback, a Scene at a Time
description: SUN VALLEY, CALIF.  She walked back and forth across a parking lot behind a converted-warehouse soundstage here on the industrial fringes of the San Fernando Valley. Brett Butler was smoking a cigar, her hair in curlers, practicing her lines  of which there were not many  over and over again.

title: Court Faults E.P.A.s Biofuels Mandate
description: A federal appeals court has thrown out part of the Environmental Protection Agencys biofuels mandate, saying that it was based on a wishful assessment of how much cellulosic fuel could be produced.

title: Rubio and Paul Embody Conservative Debate Over Foreign Policy
description: Both were propelled into the Senate in 2010 by the passion of the Tea Party movement. Both are possible contenders for the 2016 Republican presidential nomination. And both are now trying to develop their commander in chief credentials through their seats on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where they had high-profile opportunities this week to engage on the big issues of the moment.

title: In Iraq, No Retreat Protests Turn Deadly
description: As my colleague in Baghdad, Duraid Adnan, reported on Friday, at least seven civilian protesters and two soldiers were killed in clashes that started after Iraqi Army forces opened fire on demonstrators who had pelted them with rocks on the outskirts of Falluja, west of Baghdad.

title: Bill Pullman Joins Cast of The Other Place
description: Bill Pullman (now starring at the president in NBCs 1600 Penn) is joining the cast of The Other Place beginning February 5, the Manhattan Theater Club has announced. Mr. Pullman will take over the role of Ian from Daniel Stern, whose final performance in that role will be February 3. Mr. Stern is taking an early leave from the production at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater because of family matters in California, according to a press release from the Manhattan Theater Club. The new drama by Sharr White stars Laurie Metcalf as Juliana Smithton, a businesswoman beset by a medical crisis and is directed by Joe Mantello (Other Desert Cities:). It was recently extended through March 3, after opening last March at the Lucille Lortel Theater.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 25
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural highlights from this week.

title: Runaway Crocodiles, a New Stomach Virus and Helpful Dolphins
description: Friday in science, crocodiles on the loose, coffee fraud, a sleepy squirrel wakes up and melting glaciers. Check out these headlines from around the Web.

title: As Obama and Clinton Sit for Joint Interview, Some Look to 2016
description: President Obama has only just started his second term but already, with the announcement that he and Hillary Rodham Clinton will appear on the CBS News program 60 Minutes on Sunday for their first joint interview, he has set off speculation about whether his onetime rival is privately his choice for a successor.

title: The Sweet Spot: Jan. 25
description: A hoax is a hoax, of course, of course  or is it? In this weeks video, A. O. Scott and David Carr talk about some recent doozies.

title: Look of The Moment | Arizona Muse
description: The Look: Sun Block. A light-reflecting yellow check shift, powered by a coordinating bag and lady pumps, is todays brightest idea.

title: Apple Takes Aim at Providers of Underage Laborers
description: Labor recruiters in China last year knowingly provided underage workers to a supplier that built parts for products from Apple and other companies.

title: Federer Loses Cool as He Loses Match to Murray
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Calling Roger Federer unflappable is normally as bold a statement as calling Shaquille ONeal tall.

title: HBO Orders Third Season of Girls
description: Girls run the world  not only in Beyoncs song lyrics but on HBOs schedule, too. The cable channel announced on Friday that it was picking up a third season of Girls, its hit comedy created by Lena Dunham and starring her as the foremost of a group of Brooklyn-based friends learning to navigate their young lives.

title: Chinese Party and Business Officials Fired in Sex Scandal
description: BEIJING  The young women met the officials for illicit trysts with video cameras hidden in their purses. Every detail of the encounters was recorded. Then a group of men confronted the officials with the video recordings and made demands.

title: A Former Top Swimmer Gives Happiness a Chance
description: BISMARCK, N.D.  Dagny Knutson approached her 11th workout of the week with an intensity that burned like chlorine. Her coach, Kathy Aspaas, said Knutsons pacing and purpose during the high-mileage practice harked back to when she was the most promising teenage swimmer in the country.

title: Curiosity, Then Concern for a Dolphin in Difficulty
description: A dolphin found its way into the headwaters of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Friday, apparently trapped where nature has long struggled to survive.

title: The Roaming Chickpea Comes Home to Roost
description: THE HUMBLE CHICKPEA is believed to have been born in the Middle East, probably ancient Turkey, and it has done a lot of traveling. It landed in a lot of places around the Mediterranean, and was transported to the far reaches of Asia, the Indian subcontinent, the Americas and Australia. It is an international legume, one that assumes a different name wherever its found.

title: A Seat Belt Reminder and a Smile
description: It is the most ignored  and usually most soporific  moment of any flight: the safety announcement, that pretakeoff ritual that often leads to travelers closing their eyes. Who among us, after all, doesnt know how to unbuckle a seat belt? Yawn.

title: Greek Opposition Leader Seeks Conference on Debt
description: The 38-year-old leftist opposition leader in Greece who could become its next prime minister on a wave of simmering popular fury over the governments austerity measures, called on Friday for a European summit meeting to ease the crushing debts that threaten not only his country but all of Europe.

title: Priebus Re-elected to Lead Republican National Committee
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Reince Priebus was re-elected chairman of the Republican National Committee on Friday, overcoming divisions and tensions in the party as he pledged to remake and restore the Republican brand before the Congressional elections next year and the 2016 presidential race.

title: A Courtship Marked by Longitudes and Latitudes
description: Africa, Asia and the Middle East are not exotic or abstract destinations for David Muehlke and Patricia Choi. They are, in fact, places where Mr. Muehlke, a foreign service officer at the State Department, and Ms. Choi, a public health adviser at the Department of Health and Human Services, have staked their futures and that of the family that they hope to have one day.

title: Test Run: Vine, Twitters New Video Sharing App
description: Applications designed to let you record and post short videos to the Web almost always disappoint. The final products tend to be too grainy, too noisy and too shaky to be worth watching.

title: A De Niro Campaign That Takes a Page From the Streep Playbook
description: LOS ANGELES  With less than a month to go before the Oscars, studios are putting their muscle into campaigns on all platforms. The Weinstein Company, a master of the form, has made a TV spot to show viewers  and Oscar voters  the many facets of Robert De Niros best supporting actor-nominated performance in Silver Linings Playbook.

title: Living in His Own Tiny Home, Before He Was a Billionaire Mayor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may now be one of the wealthiest men in the world, with gracious estates scattered across the globe from Bermuda to London, but it was not always so.

title: Who Should the Nationals New Racing President Be?
description: You have to give the Washington Nationals credit. They have turned a piece of game-day entertainment silliness  the Presidents Race  into a pop culture phenomenon, so much so that Teddy Roosevelts first victory in the last game of last season took on a life of its own.

title: In Surprise, Educator Tied to Cheating Rejects Deal
description: MEMPHIS  In an 11th-hour reversal, an educator accused of running a large test-cheating ring in three Southern states rejected a plea deal on Friday and elected to go to trial.

title: Trouble on Tuesday Nights
description: Every broadcast television network has a slate with shows that do not perform to expectations. Take Tuesdays on ABC. This week, the series premiere of The Taste, a cooking competition show in the mold of The Voice on NBC, drew 5.8 million total viewers, according to Nielsen data. That is a decent audience sampling, but ultimately unimpressive considering its time slot competitor, the very popular NCIS on CBS, was a repeat.

title: Lakers Glass Appears Empty at Halfway Mark
description: LOS ANGELES  As Kobe Bryant tries to make sense of this train wreck of a season, he may want to note that Lakers stars of the past sometimes felt miserable, too.

title: Celery, Center Plate
description: For many people, celery is best used as a garnish, part of a snack tray or perhaps to stir a Bloody Mary. But to Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, celery can be a main course. She writes:

title: F.D.A. Likely to Add Limits on Painkillers
description: Trying to stem the scourge of prescription drug abuse, an advisory panel of experts to the Food and Drug Administration voted on Friday to toughen the restrictions on painkillers like Vicodin that contain hydrocodone, the most widely prescribed drugs in the country.

title: Yuji Ramen Opens Campaign to Start a Restaurant
description: Yuji Haraguchi, whose Smorgasburg stand, Yuji Ramen, is popular for its mazemen or dry ramen, which is more of a stir-fry than soup, has announced a series of five-course omakase (chefs choice) ramen dinners, to be held upstairs at Whole Foods, 95 East Houston Street (Bowery) from mid-March through May.

title: On Our Radar: A Spinning Solar Cell
description: A solar venture says it has developed a spin cell technology using specialized lensing and a rotating conical shape that could generate five times more electricity from a given amount of land than conventional solar methods. It says the electricity would cost only 8 cents per kilowatt-hour, compared with 10 to 15 cents for electricity generated by conventional photovoltaic panels. [Clean Technica]

title: Book Review Podcast: Joe Queenan on a Lifetime of Reading
description: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Ligaya Mishan reviews Joe Queenans One for the Books, a memoir about life as a voracious reader. Ms. Mishan says that Mr. Queenan, a famously dyspeptic humorist, is in this book mostly in celebratory mode, writing of his love of literature. Ms. Mishan writes:

title: Feeling For | Atelier Nunus Uno Tote
description: One rarely needs another tote bag. That is, until a tote as beautifully proportioned, functional and smart as Atelier Nunus leather Uno comes along, and then needing gives way to wanting, which leads to asking how many colors it comes in (the answer is two: burgundy and tan) and next up, considering buying both.

title: Silicon Valley Companies Lobbying Against Europes Privacy Proposals
description: Silicon Valley technology companies and the United States government are pushing hard against Europes effort to enact sweeping privacy protection for digital data.

title: India Needs to Reset Its Moral Compass, President Says
description: NEW DELHI  President Pranab Mukherjee on Friday warned about the danger of corruption corroding Indian public life and called on the country to reset its moral compass in light of a grisly gang rape and murder of a young woman that have stirred outrage and protests in India and around the world.

title: Married to the Plan. Still Looking for a Possible Groom.
description: Kate Owens, a 34-year-old project manager for I.B.M. who lives in Clifton Park, N.Y., had planned her wedding for more than a decade before marrying last June.

title: Not Selling Gray Hair Short
description: Cindy Joseph, a model, knew she was being subversive when she stopped tinting her long, loose waves more than a decade ago.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Jan. 25
description: More photographs.

title: Does Your Child Like Your Baby Sitter Best?
description: This weeks quandary comes via Michelle Cove and Facebook. Michelle (the author of I Love Mondays, and Other Confessions From Devoted Working Moms) was speaking at a Parent Talk event when a parent put up a hand and asked, What do you do when you truly believe your kid likes the nanny/baby sitter better?

title: The Right Tone for a Sensitive Zombie
description: How many scars should line the faces of the undead? How blue (or purple or pale) should their lips and skin be? How much blood is too much blood? These and many other questions can plague filmmakers who tackle the zombie movie genre, and when that zombie movie is also a romantic comedy, the questions get all the more complicated.

title: How Bright Horizons Took Care of Bain Capital Over the Years
description: For nearly three decades, the day care center chain Bright Horizons Family Solutions has taken care of children. It has also taken very good care of Bain Capital.

title: Disputing a Charge on Your Credit Card
description: If you have ever disputed a charge with your debit or credit card company, you know what a potent weapon this type of complaint can be.

title: Li vs. Azarenka: A Study in Contrasts in Australian Open Final
description: MELBOURNE, Australia  Each woman in the Australian Open final Saturday has already reached the finals in Melbourne this decade, has won one Grand Slam title and will be playing in her third Grand Slam final.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Persepolis Tops the Paperback List
description: There is activity on each of our graphic books best-seller lists this week. At No. 1 on the manga list is Vol. 2 of Missions of Love, a romance series. On the hardcover list, at No. 3, is Dark Tower: The Gunslinger  The Man in Black, the latest adaption of Stephen Kings epic, published by Marvel Entertainment. At No. 4 is Vol. 2 of Wonder Woman, part of the New 52 initiative by DC Comics that reintroduced all the companys heroes. Wonder Woman has always been tied to Greek mythology and this version is making great use of those mischievous gods and goddesses.

title: The Card of My Dreams, Always Elusive
description: It was a spring day in 1998, and my best friends mother was on the other end of the phone. The news wasnt good: her nephew wanted his baseball card back, despite the deal his younger brother had made to sell it to me for $2.

title: Reports From Your Own Credit Card Disputes
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I tried to give people a users guide to disputing credit and debit card purchases. The ability to turn problems over to your card issuer is one of the most powerful weapons in a consumers arsenal, but you dont want to be wielding it constantly. Merchants are people, too, and disputing a charge causes them real hassle and expense.

title: A Dead Date: Thatll Kill a Romance
description: Everybodys last night on earth is a sick joke, Sean, a single young New Yorker, says defensively.

title: Pentagon Reverses Some of Its Censoring of a War Book
description: WASHINGTON  In an illustration of the governments changeable ideas of what should be secret, Pentagon censors have decided that nearly half of more than 400 passages deleted from an Afghan war memoir can be printed without damaging national security.

title: Wielding Influence, Even if Youre Small
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, writes about one of small businesses disadvantages  they do not have the resources that the big companies do to wield political influence. But, as Paul points out, that does not mean they cant wield any influence.

title: A Hedge Fund Dogfight, Live, Mesmerizes Wall Street
description: For a half-hour on Friday afternoon, the eyes of Wall Street were not on the usual fixations, like the fiscal talks in Washington, or Apples earnings or a potential takeover of Dell.

title: Week in Review: Rumble on Basic Cable
description: Hedge fund magnates take their feud to CNBC. | A sign to Wall Street in Obamas picks for regulators. | Goldman overcomes its latest headache. | Jesse Eisinger of ProPublica on a suit that hints at behavior by bankers in a bubble. | Microsoft may back a Dell buyout. | Andrew Ross Sorkin says that prophecies made in Davos dont always come true. | Its tax edge on thin ice, private equity is regrouping. | Looking skyward in Asia.

title: Jim Courier Wins Australian Open Again
description: As if the gutty, four-hour, five-set Australian Open semifinal today between Andy Murray and Roger Federer werent enough to make East Coast tennis fans glad they woke up at 3:30 a.m. to watch it live, viewers who hung on to see Jim Couriers interview with Murray (scroll toward end of video) after his victory got an extra treat. Courier, who won the last of his four Grand Slam titles in Australia exactly 20 years ago, was a power baseliner as a player. As an interviewer, though, hes a crisp serve-and-volley man. His questions are brief and informed, and they encourage his subjects to actually say something, as opposed to the all-too-common inane sportscaster queries like How big was that . . . ? and What does it mean to have . . . ? Courier was overshadowed during his fine playing career by contemporaries like Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi, but as an on-court interviewer, hes almost unbeatable.

title: A Look Back at Trisha Brown
description: Images from the choreographers career.

title: The Knicks, the Lakers and Lin: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

title: On Lookout in Davos for Next Growth Story in Emerging Markets
description: DAVOS, Switzerland  With Europe in a sharp slowdown and the United States forging only a slow recovery, the business and academic elites gathering here are scouring the global landscape for any new economic success story. And a number of countries are stepping forward here at the World Economic Forum to peddle their tales  even if the smart money knows that betting on emerging markets continues to berisky.

title: Pure Dance, Pure Finale
description: THE CHOREOGRAPHER TRISHA BROWN has made dances worth arguing about for more than 50 years, and for at least 30 years her dances have been loved across the world. Many of todays best-known choreographers  including David Gordon, Mark Morris and Stephen Petronio  have cited her influence, whether for the poetic fluidity of her movement or for the steely, analytical methods of her choreographic structures. A pioneer of the pure-dance experimentalists of the 1960s and 70s, she challenged and changed the way we define dance performance.

title: On the Market in the Region
description: An arts and crafts home in Larchmont, N.Y., and a six-bedroom colonial in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: A Lenox Hill co-op, a Greenwich Village co-op and a Carroll Gardens condo.

title: January Is the Cruelest Month
description: BY late January many of us residing in northern latitudes arent sleeping well, overeat and are looking forward to the long sunlit days of July. Some people even get clinically depressed: a recent study revealed that some 10 percent of New Hampshire residents suffer from seasonal affective disorder. For too many people, this might seem like just a quirk of their personalities, or worse, a shortcoming. But the cause for our malaise lies in the working of our genes, organs  and, ultimately, in the chemical structure of moon rocks, like the ones returned by the Apollo space program.

title: From Readers: Complaints, Kudos and Suggestions for 2013 and Beyond
description: One thing Ive found out about many Times readers is that they are not short on opinions  and not hesitant to share them.

title: Successful and Schizophrenic
description: LOS ANGELES

title: From Note Pads to Shoulder Pads
description: ON A RECENT EVENING the British soul singer Jessie Ware was in her South London flat, staring helplessly at a suitcase. Im just kind of packing for tour as we speak, really, she said. Im one of those people who gets her suitcase out a week before theyre going on holiday, just because youre afraid youre going to miss something. And then of course you miss something anyway.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 25
description: A view of the day in sports, including handball in Barcelona, Spain, and beach soccer in Doha, Qatar.

title: Bundesliga: Best-Run League in the World
description: You may not have noticed, but the landscape of European soccer has recently changed. Like the tectonic shifts of one continental plate against another, the goliath European leagues have been rubbing shoulders and stepping over each other for some time now, carving out the modern world of soccer one television deal or coefficient at a time.

title: 2 Outlets Find Prized Sources in Algeria Siege: The Fighters
description: PARIS  There were no reporters on hand when Islamist militants emerged from the sands of eastern Algeria last week to storm a gas facility full of international workers, and Algerian security forces cordoned off the site during the hostage crisis that ensued, keeping the news media out.

title: George Condo, On View In and Outside the Metropolitan Opera House
description: A large black-and-white banner featuring a court jester by the artist George Condo is currently up on the faade of the Metropolitan Opera House. The image advertises the Mets new production of Verdis Rigoletto, which opens there on Monday, and also an art show, George Condos Jesters, also opening on Monday, at Gallery Met, the seven-year-old space in the south lobby of the opera house.

title: PepsiCo Will Halt Use of Additive in Gatorade
description: PepsiCo announced on Friday that it would no longer use an ingredient in Gatorade after consumers complained.

title: A Teenager With a Stylist
description: BORN IN ATLANTA but raised in Los Angeles, where she currently lives, Chlo Grace Moretz, who turns 16 next month, started acting a decade ago. She has several films coming out this year, including Movie 43 this month, Kick-Ass 2 in June and Carrie in October. Ms. Moretz was in Paris last week during the spring 2013 couture shows.

title: Holocaust Film to Be Broadcast to Iran
description: LOS ANGELES You just cant keep an Oscar-winning documentary down. Genocide, a Holocaust film that won the best documentary feature Oscar in 1982, resurfaced this week in one of the unlikeliest of settings: On satellite broadcasts into Iran and elsewhere in the Middle East.

title: For Mazda, Its Diesels at Daytona
description: When three Mazda 6 sedans roll onto the starting grid for the Rolex 24 endurance race on Saturday, theyll be packing a technology the company says has never before competed at the Daytona International Speedway: diesel engines.

title: Racing Fuel From the Fat of the Land
description: When the Grand-Am racing organization created the GX class of competition for alternative-fuel cars, its official supplier, Sunoco, was not ready with a suitable diesel blend. So Mazdas motor sports managers, mindful that the 2013 season kickoff was quickly approaching, decided to try a synthetic clean-diesel fuel that has powered naval vessels, aircraft, heavy trucks  and has been tested in rental fleets in the United States.

title: Were Related. So?
description: These four scions figure real estate is in their genes, but none assumed that taking the reins of a family business was a career endgame.

title: Being Related to the Family Firm
description: When the last name of the real estate agent sounds suspiciously like the brand name of a prominent real estate firm, its probably no coincidence: the family business has beckoned and an heir who very likely has vast lifestyle options has instead leapt into the iffy role of a residential real estate salesperson.

title: Paths to Expiring, in Alphabetical Order
description: He made it past the letter K. But at some point during L  the one about the masturbation contest to the death  the poor guy ran out of the movie screening, threw up and left. Who knows what X would have done to him.

title: Quinn, Cool to Soda Ban, Gets Donations From Coke
description: The American soft-drink industry, fighting Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs restrictions on sugary drink sizes, is courting a lawmaker who could eventually have the influence to overturn the rules: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and a leading mayoral candidate.

title: Oscars Will Highlight Musicals (Well, 3 Musicals Anyway)
description: Anyone concerned about the Oscars interpretive dance quotient can rest (slide, shuffle, repeat) easy: the producers have announced that the show will feature a tribute to recent movie musicals.

title: 40 Years After Roe v. Wade, Thousands March to Oppose Abortion
description: WASHINGTON  Three days after the 40th anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court case that legalized abortion, tens of thousands of abortion opponents from around the country came to the National Mall on Friday for the annual March for Life rally, which culminated in a demonstration in front of the Supreme Court building.

title: A Conductors Adventurous and Reserved Sides
description: At 82, Lorin Maazel remains one of the most prodigiously skilled and experienced conductors in the business. Yet during his seven-year tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic, which ended with the 2008-9 season, he sometimes seemed curiously disengaged, especially toward the end.

title: Movie Review | Parker
description: A Times critic reviews 'Parker.'

title: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 25
description: Subjects include a march for stricter gun-control laws, a cold spell in the city and the approaching centennial for Grand Central Terminal.

title: Movie Review | Yossi
description: A Times critic reviews Yossi.

title: For Federer, Anger Goes Only So Far
description: At 6-5 in the fourth set, with Andy Murray serving for the match and a spot in the Australian Open final, Roger Federer hit a ball close to the baseline that Murray thought was out. No call was made, and Murray pantomimed displeasure  just for a moment  then played on.

title: Movie Review | Taste of Money
description: A Times critic reviews "The Taste of Money."

title: Human Sounds, Painful or Haunting
description: Within the contemporary-music scene of New York, the vocal ensemble Ekmeles inhabits its own neighborhood on the border between music and linguistics. The name of this ensemble, which is dedicated to music by living composers, refers to the Greek term for notes of indefinite pitch and intervals with complex ratios that destabilize the perfect proportions of harmony theory, elements that in ancient Greece were considered inappropriate for music.

title: Looking to Israel for Clues on Women in Combat
description: JERUSALEM  One of her fellow soldiers lay dead, and her Humvee was being fired upon. She saw one of the attackers  three armed men who had penetrated Israels border with Egypt  reach toward his waist. Fearing he was about to detonate a suicide belt, she fired two shots at his head.

title: Derelict 19th-Century Building Continues Its Decline
description: Down on its luck was how John M. Weiss, the deputy counsel for the Landmarks Preservation Commission, described the derelict hulk of 502 Canal Street in Lower Manhattan in November after flooding from Hurricane Sandy prompted the Buildings Department to bar entry.

title: Fox Says Its 3-Year Relationship With Palin Is Over
description: Sarah, where are you? one of Sarah Palins 3.4 million Facebook fans wrote on her wall last week. Has your contract with Fox ended? another fan asked the day before.

title: A 17th-Century Masterpiece Discovered at the Ritz in Paris
description: PARIS  The Htel Ritz Paris, famous for its bar, its swimming pool and its assignations, had a treasure hiding in plain sight, an exceptional painting that had been hanging on a wall for decades without anyone paying it the least attention.

title: Most Israelis Are Not Listening
description: JERUSALEM  The Oscar-nominated documentary The Gatekeepers braids the recollections and reflections of six former chiefs of the Shin Bet, Israels internal security service, into a disturbing narrative of their countrys occupation of the Palestinian territories since 1967. In the United States the confessions of these tough terrorist hunters have startled and provoked audiences, fueling the criticism among Jewish liberals of the right-leaning Israeli governments expansion of settlements in the West Bank.

title: Officials in Azerbaijan Claim to Restore Order to Rioting City
description: MOSCOW  Officials of the ruling party in Azerbaijan said on Friday that the police had restored order in the city of Ismayilli after two days of rioting and calls for the local governor to resign. Local residents, however, said the police were still making arrests and the city remained on the brink of martial law.

title: Amid a Shake-Up, JPMorgans Risk Officer Takes a Leave
description: 8:58 p.m. | Updated

title: A Place That Makes New York Real Estate Look Cheap
description: Think its expensive to buy a home in New York? Try moving to China.

title: Jan. 27  Feb. 2
description: The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain has been replaced by pahk yah cah in Hahvahd Yahd. And a gender switch has rendered Henry Higgins a Hannah and Eliza Doolittle an Elliot. But The Makeover, a Hallmark Hall of Fame production on Sunday at 9 p.m. on ABC, retains the bone structure of George Bernard Shaws Pygmalion, in which a professor of phonetics wagers that he can train a Cockney flower girl to pass as a duchess by way of proper speech and manners. Set in contemporary Boston, The Makeover updates the tale, with Higgins (played by Julia Stiles) as an educational consultant and grammar stickler who decides, after a failed run for Congress, to transform an unkempt beer salesman (David Walton) into the perfect candidate. But she has to subdue that South Side accent before Washington can be conquered  or love pursued. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

title: Madison Avenue Reveals More of Its Super Bowl Playbook
description: Super Bowl XLVII is now only IX er, um, make that nine days away, and the closer the game draws, the more information Super Bowl sponsors are sharing about their plans.

title: Balthazar Korab, 1926-2013
