title: Portlandia: A New Format
description: Part 12: The Portlandia creators reveal their dream guests for the show, and talk about what makes the format of Portlandia different from almost anything else on TV.

title: Portlandia: Feminist Bookstore
description: Part 7: The Portlandia creators explain why so much of the shows comedy is performed through relationships, couples and friendships.

title: Portlandia: Saddam Hussein, Rock Star
description: Part 2: The Portlandia creators recall how Carrie and Fred first met, and explain what makes great music and great comedy similar.

title: Portlandia: Put a Bird on It
description: Part 13: The Portlandia creators recall the origins of the Put a Bird on It sketch, and take a question from a baby.

title: Portlandia: Adult Hide and Seek
description: Part 10: The Portlandia creators describe the audience theyre imagining when they write the show.

title: Portlandia: Nina and Lance
description: Part 8: The Portlandia creators reveal their favorite characters on the show, and talk about which rules of sketch comedy the show tries to break.

title: Portlandia: Slide Whistle Quota
description: Part 14: The Portlandia creators discuss the role of sound effects on the show.

title: Portlandia: Code Switching
description: Part 15: The Portlandia creators talk about the role of improvising on the show, and describe how they get into character.

title: Portlandia: Disaster Aesthetic
description: Part 4: The Portlandia creators recall how director Jonathan Krisel became involved in the show, and explain whose idea it was to set the show in Portland.

title: Portlandia: Hometown Show
description: Part 6: The Portlandia creators talk about how actual Portlanders respond to the show.

title: Portlandia: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the creators and stars of IFCs Portlandia.

title: Portlandia: Comedy Is Like Alchemy
description: Part 9: The Portlandia creators describe the process of writing the show, and talk about how they find the scenes as they shoot the show.

title: Portlandia: Ingroups and Outgroups
description: Part 3: The Portlandia creators talk about how their familiarity with the indie rock world influences the show, and reveal which other shows gave Portlandia its creative DNA.

title: In the Air, Minor Tiffs Can Escalate Fast
description: At a time of heightened security concerns, disgruntled airline employees and frustrated passengers can be a combustible combination in a crowded aircraft, as travelers find themselves subject to lots of rules and little wiggle room to challenge them.

title: A Connecticut Mother Makes Bangles of Recycled Guns
description: Jessica Mindich is a jewelry designer who has begun transforming recycled pistols, rifles and shotguns from Newark into a line of sleek bangle bracelets. Twenty percent of the proceeds will go directly to the gun buyback program in Newark, she said.

title: Video: Tate Donovan on Living Like 1979
description: LOS ANGELES  The multilingual Middle Eastern verisimilitude of Argo that Ben Affleck spoke about in his SAG acceptance speech was mostly achieved in and around Hollywood. Mr. Affleck had hoped to shoot in Turkey, he said over the weekend, but most of Argo was actually filmed here in Los Angeles, with local actors. As George Clooney, a producer of the film, pointed out, there is a large Persian population here.

title: A Crash Course in Playing the Numbers
description: The chances are that you turn to this part of the newspaper in search of some reliable tools for optimizing your health. The chances are that you periodically visit a doctor for the same reason.

title: That Daily Shower Can Be a Killer
description: The other morning, I escaped unscathed from a dangerous situation. No, an armed robber didnt break into my house, nor did I find myself face to face with a mountain lion during my bird walk. What I survived was my daily shower.

title: TimesCast Media+Tech: Changes at The New Republic
description: The right to unlock cellphones expires. Chris Hughes, publisher of The New Republic, discusses its redesign. An animated look at how technology may change our daily routines.

title: When Corruption Helps the Bottom Line
description: Michael S. Pagano is the Robert J. and Mary Ellen Darretta Endowed Chair in Finance at the Villanova School of Business.

title: Making Doughnuts in the Snow
description: Looking out our windows on the sixth floor of the Times building on Saturday, Kathy Ryan, our director of photography and resident Instagram fanatic, spotted this sight. She climbed to the 10th and 11th floors of the building to capture the image, which she posted to Instagram.

title: Safety and Fines Continue to Be Hot Topics
description: NEW ORLEANS  The news media covering the Super Bowl are often criticized for the lack of attention paid to the actual game of football. But as the Baltimore Ravens and the San Francisco 49ers get ready to play in Super Bowl XLVII, the talk has largely been about the game on the field, and how dangerous it can be.

title: Pay Still High at Bailed-Out Companies, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Top executives at firms that received taxpayer bailouts during the financial crisis continue to receive generous government-approved compensation packages, a Treasury watchdog said in a report released on Monday.

title: Whom Would You Pick for Supporting Actor?
description: With his victory at the Screen Actors Guild, Tommy Lee Jones may have edged a little closer to an Oscar victory for best supporting actor. But the category is chock full of strong candidates, all of them previous Oscar winners.

title: Hes Got Voice, Looks and Fans. And Hes 11.
description: An old soul is the last thing you would expect to find inside Justin Bieber, an old entry on his Web site says. But all it takes is one listen to the 15-year-old soul-singing phenomenon to realize that he is light years ahead of his manufactured pop peers. Mr. Bieber, now 18 and as big a pop star as ever, is the model for the 11-year-old with an old soul in Teddy Waynes sad-funny, sometimes cutting new novel, The Love Song of Jonny Valentine.

title: Office Working to Close Guantnamo Is Shuttered
description: FORT MEADE, Md.  The State Department on Monday reassigned Daniel Fried, the special envoy for closing the prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and will not replace him, according to an internal personnel announcement. Mr. Frieds office is being closed, and his former responsibilities will be assumed by the office of the departments legal adviser, the notice said.

title: Immigration and Republican Self-Interest
description: Here is Ezra Klein, explaining why Republican are suddenly looking more, shall we say, transigent on immigration than theyve been on taxes:

title: U.S. Team Drills Through to Antarctic Lake
description: An American research team finished drilling through a half-mile of Antarctic ice on Monday, reaching the surface of subglacial Lake Whillans and retrieving water samples that will be studied for the presence of life, according to the teams Web site.

title: Starter: At Bocuse, Recreating the Classics
description: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants.Weather was hardly a deterrent to the diners. Though a deep freeze lingered Saturday night, customers eagerly fled the windy 19-degree temperature for the warmth and welcome of the new $3 million Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Boy Scouts Join the Present
description: Last July, the Boy Scouts of America were the target of richly deserved outrage when they announced that after two-years of soul searching, they had decided not to change their policy banning gay members and gay Scout leaders. The Supreme Court had said it was their right to do that  but what kind of post-19th century discussion could have led to that nonsensical decision? When President Obama publicly disagreed with the B.S.A.s decision, the Scouts waved off his objections and said they would not reconsider.

title: In a Quick Shift, Scouts Rethink a Ban on Gays
description: The Boy Scouts of America, with its traditions of youth in uniform and the character-building virtues of honor, has always looked back to an older, more structured image of America, when gay and lesbian people were invisible and silent. It was a view reaffirmed in Scout policy as recently as seven months ago. Openly gay scouts and scout leaders need not apply.

title: U.C.L.A. Receives More Than 90,000 Applications for Fall 2013
In Performance: Gia Crovatin
description: The actress performs a scene from Neil LaButes In the Beginning, part of a program by Theater Uncut at the Clurman Theater.

title: An Italian Bank Caught in the Vortex of Election Politics
description: MILAN  The chief executive of a regional Italian bank embroiled in a scandal with political and even Europe-wide implications said Monday that recent revelations of past mismanagement and questionable deals would not impede efforts to turn around the beleaguered institution.

title: What to Eat With Slovene White Wines
description: Youre bound to find a cheese  something hard, runny, funky, sharp or mild  to nibble with a Slovene white wine, so you could serve cheese and be done with it. But finding a dish is not a particular challenge, either. Just pick something pleasant and white-wine friendly, because what will be in the glass will be intriguing enough. The Eastern European geography led me to think of stuffed cabbage, but with a light chicken filling and dressed with sour cream. You may have to grind your own chicken; most butchers will not do it, but your food processor will. Freezing the cabbage overnight eliminates the need to boil the leaves to soften them. FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: In Step With New Orleanss Comeback
description: NEW ORLEANS  Tom Benson took his wife, Gayle, to Commanders Palace last week, choosing that Garden District restaurant for dinner on the night when his basketball team was rebranded and a few days after his football team was reborn.

title: When Publicity Precedes Peer Review in Climate Science (Part One)
description: | Updates below |Last year, after opponents of hydraulic fracturing made much of an unpublished paper by a doctoral candidate in economics who reported finding health impacts in infants from nearby gas drilling operations, I wrote a piece titled When Publicity Precedes Peer Review in the Fight Over Gas Impacts.

title: Table Talk | Bones in Paris
description: It was at the helm of the much-acclaimed Au Passage restaurant that James Henry first made ripples in the Paris food scene. His delectable small plates were so well received that he decided to venture on his own. The result is Bones, which Henry unveiled earlier this month. The dcor is spare with overhanging industrial light fixtures being the prominent design feature. The interior (an Irish pub in its former life) was deconstructed so that only the raw framework of bricks, wood and tiles remain  hence the skeletal name, Bones.

title: Opening a Sketchbook and Finding a Spark
Before Word Can Spread, Partys Over at a Brooklyn Speakeasy
description: The room at the corner of Greenpoint Avenue and Franklin Street in Brooklyn fell silent on Saturday night as several loud bangs were heard at the door. A latecomer to the party unfolding inside, Stephanie Han-yu, was on the phone and reported that three squad cars were on the street.

title: Between the Recipes, Scribbles Speak Volumes
description: When her mother died three years ago, Lynell George, a writer and assistant professor of journalism at Loyola Marymount University in Los Angeles, assumed the responsibility of making the familys traditional New Years Day gumbo. Leafing through her mothers cookbooks, she heard her mothers Creole-inflected voice in the margins.

title: Breast Pump Coverage Under New Law Varies In Practice
description: As part of its coverage of preventive health-care services for women, the Affordable Care Act requires many insurance plans to provide equipment and services to promote breast-feeding, like breast pumps and lactation counseling, at no extra cost.

title: Market for Bear Bile Threatens Asian Population
description: The six bears that arrived this month at Animals Asia, an animal rescue center in China, had the grisly symptoms of inhumane bile milking. Greenish bile dripped from open fistulas used to drain gall bladders; teeth were broken and rotted from gnawing on the bars of tiny cages.

title: Toasted Chiles Add Complexity to a Dish
description: Making short ribs chili nachos is the subject of this weeks column and video, and I mention that the chili part of the dish was inspired by a recipe I learned from my friend Nick. Nicks chili is an extremely complexly flavored dish because instead of chile powder, he uses a combination of whole dried chiles.

title: San Francisco Players Carry On Legacy They Know Little About
description: NEW ORLEANS  The San Francisco 49ers last won a Super Bowl on Jan. 29, 1995. Colin Kaepernick, the teams current starting quarterback, was 7. The team may have five Super Bowl wins, but Joe Looney, San Franciscos youngest player, was alive for just one of them. The same is true for three other members of the active roster.

title: Unexpected Sights (and Sounds) on a Drilling Platform
description: OVER the years, as a producer of national and international television programming, Ive traveled a lot. Even though many trips have been to remote areas in Africa or South America, the roughest travels are quite often the domestic flights in my native Norway.

title: Hide and Seek With Deer Mice
description: In the annals of genetics, the deer mouse has so far played only a small role. The major work has been done in nematodes, fruit flies or laboratory mice  a variety of inbred strains coming originally from the house mouse (Mus musculus)  with a few other species, like the three-spined stickleback, finning in the background.

title: A Life in Science: Hopi Hoekstra
description: An interview with Hopi Hoekstra, a leading researcher in the cutting edge field of genetics of behavior.

title: Digging Deep in the DNA
description: CAMBRIDGE, MASS.  Hopi E. Hoekstra is standing in the attic of Harvards Museum of Comparative Zoology among horns and pelts, an elephant skin under a table here, giraffe parts over there.

title: Street Style: Wedged Sneakers
description: The best of readers photos from the week of Jan. 21.

title: On the Job in Afghanistan, Female Soldiers Reflect
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the shadow of transport aircraft, rows of helicopters and supply pallets, women in uniform are a well-established part of the fabric of military life on bases and near the front lines in Afghanistan  a minority, to be sure, but one so common on the job that its hardly seen as an issue.

title: Genes That Make Mice Dig, New York as Anti-Crime Model and Mistreated Hypertension
description: Hopi Hoekstra on how mouse burrows are like hair color, John Tierney on crime and punishment in New York City and Jane Brody on why your blood pressure medicine might be wrong.

title: Flu Forces Tegan and Sara to Reschedule Beacon Theater Shows
description: Illness has forced the Canadian duo Tegan and Sara to cancel shows at the Beacon Theater on Monday and Tuesday nights, a publicist for the group said.

title: Do It Yourselves: Two Black Flag Reunions Set for Summer
description: Greg Ginn, the guitarist and principal songwriter for the seminal Los Angeles punk band Black Flag, said he has resurrected the group with a new lineup and intends to put out an album and tour this summer.

title: Making the Cut
description: For $100, students in Kansas City can learn how to butcher a freshly killed pig and take home the spoils.

title: Bacon, and How It Came to Be
description: KANSAS CITY, MO.  For Alex Swanstrom, an auditor at a financial firm, cutting into the dead pig wasnt hard. It was what happened next that made him rethink whether whole-animal butchery was something he was ready to dive into.

title: The Chief of Yahoo Lifts Sales, and Spirits
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Marissa Mayer, just by being Marissa Mayer, has done more to move Yahoo forward in her first six months as chief executive than any of her five predecessors did over as many years.

title: When an Elephant Falls
description: Africas elephant slaughter continues, as described in this short dispatch from the marine conservationist Carl Safina, whos ventured far from his usual oceanic domain to do research for his next book. He offered the photographs and note below as a Your Dot sketch ahead of a long post he plans to publish on his blog next week:

title: Law Enforcement Rarely Uses Search Warrants in Getting Twitter Data
description: United States law-enforcement agencies by and large do not establish probable cause or obtain a search warrant from an impartial judge before they seek information about a Twitter user, the company said Monday in its second transparency report.

title: A Rich, Generous Wine to Pair With Short Rib Nachos
description: Melissa Clark shares her recipe for short rib chile nachos in her column, A Good Appetite, to prepare for the Super Bowl. Here are some thoughts on what to drink with them; share your suggestions in the comments section below.

title: House Committee Pushes N.F.L. Union on H.G.H. Testing
description: NEW ORLEANS  The leaders of the House of Representatives Oversight Committee, upset about the failure of the N.F.L. to finalize with its players union a drug testing program for human growth hormone, warned the union in a letter Monday that they may call players to testify at a hearing on the matter.

title: Ring in the New (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Mom Ousted as Boy Scout Leader
description: When the Boy Scouts of American told Jennifer Tyrrell that she couldn't lead her son's troop, she took action.

title: Interpreting Brain Waves
description: In late 2011, Canadian researchers using a novel method of interpreting electroencephalograms asked 16 patients in an irreversible vegetative state to move their hands or toes. In three people, the scientists found brain activity similar to that of healthy people given the same instructions. The result suggested that the vegetative patients in fact might be hearing and understanding what was said.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 28
description: The day in sports, including a send-off rally for the Ravens in Baltimore and Tiger Woodss victory at Torrey Pines.

title: Link to African Ebola Found in Bats Suggests Virus Is More Widespread
description: For the first time, scientists have found evidence of the African Ebola virus in Asian fruit bats, suggesting that the virus is far more widespread around the world than had been previously known.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Egypt, Mali, Brazil and Saudi Arabia.

title: Double Helix Serves Double Duty
description: Last Wednesday, a group of researchers at the European Bioinformatics Institute reported in the journal Nature that they had managed to store digital information in synthetic DNA molecules, then recreated the original digital files without error.

title: Not a Difficult Choice (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes, 21 Years Apart, in a Homage to Brahms
description: Although no one mentioned it at the time, there was a subtle symmetry to the recital that the cellist Steven Isserlis and the pianist Kirill Gerstein presented at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon. The bulk of the program was devoted to the two sonatas for cello and piano by Brahms, bedrock repertory pieces completed roughly 21 years apart: the first in 1865, its successor in 1886.

title: Walkabout  1/28: What to Do With Your Dreamliner Ticket, and Jersey Shore
description: Not So Dreamy After a spate of battery fires grounded Boeings 787 Dreamliner fleet, Japanese investigators said they found no quality control problems at the maker of the lithium-ion batteries. (New York Times)

title: Viagra as Diet Pill? One Day, Perhaps
description: New evidence suggests that the erectile-dysfunction drug Viagra might have another use: helping burn away excess fat.

title: Yemen Seizes Sailboat Filled With Weapons, and U.S. Points to Iran
description: WASHINGTON  The authorities in Yemen have seized a boat in their territorial waters filled with a large quantity of explosives, weapons and money, according to American officials briefed on the interdiction. The officials said Monday that there were indications that Iran was smuggling the military contraband to insurgents inside Yemen, although they declined to provide details.

title: Excerpt: Invisible Man
description: Teagle F. Bougere in a scene from the stage version of Ralph Ellisons landmark 1952 novel, at the Huntington Theater in Boston.

title: New Albums by Trixie Whitley and Kris Kristofferson
description: TRIXIE WHITLEY

title: Vain Glorious | Get Your Glow On
description: The Northeast is finally emerging from last weeks deep freeze, but the skin-battering effects of frigid temperatures and arctic winds continue to wreak havoc on the face. Its been a dry season without much rain or snow, so the air is especially low in humidity. When you combine that with all the time spent indoors, where were subject to radiant heaters, its causing very dry skin, explains the Manhattan dermatologist Anne Chapas. While slathering on a rich cream every day might seem like the best fix, hydration is only half the battle. You really need to exfoliate to remove the dead cells on the surface, which will in turn allow your moisturizer to penetrate better, Dr. Chapas says. T asked five dermatologists to reveal which face products they trust to gently bring healthy radiance out of hibernation.

title: Soprano and Mezzo Turn a Big Hall Into a Salon
description: As they introduced their recital of French music on Sunday evening at Carnegie Hall, the soprano Rene Fleming and the mezzo-soprano Susan Graham asked the audience in the vast house to imagine that they were in a cozier room.

title: Cooking With Paul Bocuse
description: Inside the new $3 million Bocuse Restaurant at the Culinary Institute of America.

title: And Now for Some Real-Life Enemies
description: Action movies illuminate the anxieties of their age. Their villains represent our fears, or at least those that the filmmakers presume we have. These bad guys are the evil-of-the-moment that we might most want to see punched in the face: Soviet masterminds, drug dealers, Silicon Valley moguls, terrorists, media barons.

title: After Staff Reductions, New Appointments at The Times
description: 9:06 p.m. | Updated The New York Times announced on Monday a restructured masthead and some significant newsroom appointments, while also saying that the staff reductions the company was seeking had been accomplished primarily through voluntary buyouts.

title: Senators Call Their Bipartisan Immigration Plan a Breakthrough
description: WASHINGTON  A bipartisan group of senators unveiled on Monday a set of principles for comprehensive immigration legislation that includes a pathway to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants already in the country illegally, contingent on first securing the nations borders.

title: A Broken Promise
description: Im sure youve had one of those moments when you hear that a celebrity or other public figure has just died and you think, Really? He was still alive?

title: In Plain Sight, but Somehow Unseen
description: BOSTON  The ringing speeches and singing sermons never seem to stop in the stage version of Invisible Man, Ralph Ellisons landmark 1952 novel about a young African-American in search of himself, now at the Huntington Theater CompanysBoston University Theater after stints in Chicago and Washington. Although the books protagonist does not find his voice as a professional orator until midway through his harrowing journey in a racially divided America, in Oren Jacobys faithful but lifeless theatrical adaptation the hero often seems to be presiding at an invisible podium, providing us with crisp talking points about the cruel truths of the black experience.

title: The Show Goes On at the Bolshoi
description: A look at a recent performance of La Bayadre at the Bolshoi Ballet in Moscow, which has been the focus of a criminal investigation since Sergei Filin, its artistic director, was attacked.

title: Precautions Urged for Drivers With Diabetes
description: Dan Fried, a 47-year-old videographer who has Type 1 diabetes, never made it to the diner to meet his brother. As he drove through New Jersey that night in November 2010, he said his blood sugar fell and he became disoriented. He pulled his van to the side of the road, where state troopers, who had received a call about an erratic driver, found him slumped behind the wheel, barely coherent.

title: The Drug-Dose Gender Gap
description: Most sleeping pills are designed to knock you out for eight hours. When the Food and Drug Administration was evaluating a new short-acting pill for people to take when they wake up in the middle of the night, agency scientists wanted to know how much of the drug would still be in users systems come morning.

title: Online Reaction to Immigration Overhaul Plan
description: As my colleague Julia Preston reports, a bipartisan group of senators announced on Monday that they have agreed to work toward overhauling the immigration system with the aim of providing a pathway to American citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants.

title: Shaken but Determined, the Bolshoi Dances On
description: MOSCOW  At 7 p.m. on Sunday, the vast and intricate machine that is the Bolshoi Ballet swung into motion here. A fan switched on, sending the sacred flame that is the centerpiece of Act I flickering upward; the ropy vines of a primeval forest were pulled down taut with weights. Dancers peeled off layers of wool and took their positions with fixed professional smiles, rib cages pumping the air, as if everything were normal.

title: Changes at the Top, but the Dancers Endure
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  Miami City Ballet, one of Americas most beloved dance companies, is in an interim condition. Its repertory for the 2012-13 season was chosen by its departed artistic director, Edward Villella, but the company is led by his successor, Lourdes Lopez. While its too early to tell how the change in leadership will affect the companys style, a recent visit showed the dancers in fine fettle.

title: Boy Scouts Consider Lifting Ban on Gay Leaders and Scouts
description: The Boy Scouts of America is reconsidering its long-standing policy of refusing to allow openly gay leaders and scouts.

title: Hostess Names McKee as Lead Bidder for Drakes Brand
description: Hostess Brands forged ahead with its dismantling plan on Monday, officially picking the maker of Little Debbie snacks as the lead bidder for its Drakes brand.

title: In Occupy, Well-Educated Professionals Far Outnumbered Jobless, Study Finds
description: More than a third of the people who participated in Occupy Wall Street protests in New York lived in households with annual incomes of $100,000 or more, according to a study by sociologists at the City University of New York, and more than two-thirds had professional jobs.

title: I Pick, Something That Ends in N
description: 36: The percentage of newborn boys in America whose names end in n.

title: A Talk Show, Kris, Is Planned for Kris Jenner
description: MIAMI  The next person in line for a daytime talk show from Foxs syndication division is Kris Jenner, the matriarch of the TV-friendly Kardashian family.

title: Teething Problems in the Debut of Mazdas Diesels at Daytona
description: Three diesel-powered Mazda 6 racecars making their debuts at the Rolex 24 Hours of Daytona endurance contest all failed to finish.

title: Three Automakers Combine Forces on Fuel-Cell Cars
description: An existing fuel-cell alliance between Ford and Daimler added a third partner, Nissan Motor, on Monday to form a new international brain trust to develop hydrogen technology. The companies hope to start the worlds first affordable, mass-market fuel-cell electric vehicles as early as 2017, they said in a statement.

title: Research Chimps Retire, Yaks Make a Comeback and More
description: Heres a peek inside one part of a science editors job: each week the team meets to discuss the articles that are about to be published in the big medical and scientific journals, which are released to us in advance under strict confidentiality rules. We pick the ones we want to write about and decide how important we think they are  possible front-page news, for instance, or worthy of a short item.

title: Costly Last-Minute Deals for the Super Bowl Crowd
description: HOW much? For corporations and individuals headed to New Orleans for the Super Bowl this weekend,the answer is: a lot.

title: Dolphin That Died in Canal Was Chronically Ill, Necropsy Shows
description: The dolphin that died in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn on Friday had many health problems, including a damaged kidney and stomach ulcers, and appeared to have stopped eating, all indicators of chronic illness, a biologist who performed a necropsy on the animal said Monday night.

title: For Many Digital Music Services, Free Is Not a Choice
description: The competition among streaming music services is going global. It is also increasingly going free.

title: Koch Hospitalized 2 Days After Being Released
description: Former Mayor Edward I. Koch was hospitalized again on Monday afternoon because of a buildup of fluid in his lungs, his spokesman said.

title: Congress Approves $51 Billion in Aid for Hurricane Victims
description: WASHINGTON  Congress gave final approval on Monday to an emergency aid package of nearly $51 billion to help millions of victims of Hurricane Sandy, ending the legislations long and complicated odyssey.

title: Security Shares Spotlight at High School Game
description: CHICAGO  The cars were screened in the parking lots of the stadium on Chicago State Universitys South Side campus. The fans walked through metal detectors; their bags were scanned, too. Police lined the arenas entrance. The teams of teenage boys wore T-shirts during the pregame warm-ups bearing a simple, yet stark message: Shoot Hoops, Not Guns.

title: Former Jefferies Trader Is Charged With Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors charged a former senior trader at the Jefferies Group on Monday with defrauding his clients  and the government  while selling them mortgage-backed securities after the financial crisis.

title: Israeli Secularists Appear to Find Their Voice
description: JERUSALEM  Speaking to a group of ultra-Orthodox men shortly before he officially entered politics, Yair Lapid, a proudly secular talk-show host, declared that in a century-long competition to define Israels character, we lost and you won.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: G.E.s Internet, and Facebook Search Warning
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: Original Suspect Is Cleared in Texas Campus Shooting
description: HOUSTON  Prosecutors dismissed charges Monday against the 22-year-old student accused of being the gunman in a shooting here last week at a community college campus, an episode that generated widespread news coverage as many feared a mass shooting.

title: Transportation Authority Defers Plan to Phase Out MetroCards
description: Plans to eventually replace traditional MetroCards with contactless bank cards are being revamped, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Monday, because banks have not distributed the cards widely enough.

title: Manti and the Mating Game
description: As we wring our hands over the impulsive hookups and Internet hoaxes of modern romance, let us pause a moment and travel back to the days long before text messages, Photoshop and all other manner of digital bedlam. Let us return to a halcyon world of agrarian ways and contemplate the unflustered situation of a fertile lass on the cusp of womanhood centuries ago.

title: Sewers, Curfews and a Ban on Gay Bias
description: VICCO, Ky.  In a former pool hall that is now the municipal building for a coal smudge of a place in eastern Kentucky called Vicco, population 335, the January meeting of the City Commission came to order. Commissioners and guests settled into patio chairs, bought at a discount and arranged around a long conference table. Those who smoked did.

title: Jeter Back on Field, Right on Schedule
description: The surest sign of any approaching spring is Derek Jeter taking ground balls at the Yankees minor league complex in Tampa, Fla., just as he has each year at this time for the better part of the last two decades. On Monday, Jeter began his annual rite essentially on schedule, three months after having surgery to repair a broken left ankle.

title: When Jim Crow Drank Coke
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.

title: A Second G.O.P.
description: On the surface, Republicans are already doing a good job of beginning to change their party. Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana gave a speech to the Republican National Committee calling on Republicans to stop being the stupid party, to stop insulting the intelligence of the American people.

title: The Changing Face of a Small Kentucky Town
description: The commission in Vicco, Ky., voted to ban the discrimination of anyone based on their sexual orientation or gender identity, a move that makes Vicco the smallest municipality in Kentucky and, possibly, the country to enact such an ordinance.

title: Chile: Former Leaders of German Sect Sentenced
description: The Supreme Court announced Monday that six former leaders of Colonia Dignidad, a German sect in southern Chile, had been sentenced to 5 to 11 years in prison for acting as accomplices to the sects leader, Paul Schfer, in the sexual abuse of minors in the 1990s. Ten other defendants received suspended sentences. One of the six, Dr. Harmut Hopp, fled to Germany in 2011, and the German government has denied Chiles requests for his extradition. Mr. Schfer founded the self-sufficient religious sect in 1961 after fleeing West Germany, where he was accused of sexually abusing boys. He died in prison in 2010 while serving a 20-year sentence for the sexual abuse of 25 minors at the sects compound. Colonia Dignidad also served as a clandestine torture center during the dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, according to official human rights reports.

title: Venezuela: Official Death Toll in Prison Clash Is 58
description: The minister of prisons, Iris Varela, said Monday that a prison clash that broke out Friday between inmates and National Guard soldiers had killed 58 people and injured 95. The director of a hospital where the bodies were taken had previously said that 61 people had been killed and 120 injured. Most of the dead were inmates. On Sunday, officials said that they had moved more than 2,000 prisoners from the prison in Barquisimeto, a northwestern city, and sent them to other prisons around the country. The mayhem occurred after troops were sent to search the notoriously violent prison for weapons and establish order. Government opponents have criticized the handling of the episode and say that moving prisoners to other overcrowded facilities will make conditions at those prisons worse.

title: Stop the Honking? New York Suggests Its a Lost Cause
description: Cabbies do it from the back of a taxi line at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, coaxing their colleagues to move up a spot. Commuters do it at the mouth of the Holland Tunnel, flabbergasted that others in a city of eight million might share their route.

title: Now Were Talking
description: The thousand-mile journey to comprehensive immigration reform has begun, as you might expect for Washington, with a single memo. Eight senators, four from each party, released it on Monday: a statement of principles behind a deal to overhaul the system in one big bill. It calls for more border and workplace enforcement, more visas for needed workers and legalization  with a path to citizenship  for 11 million undocumented immigrants.

title: M.T.A. Cites $1 Billion Cost to Install Gates on Subway Platforms
description: Amid a spate of deaths on New Yorks subway tracks, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials cautioned on Monday that any plan to install platform safety doors throughout the system could be prohibitively expensive, but they introduced another possibility: a high-tech system that would detect a person on the tracks.

title: The Netherlands: Queen Says She Will Step Down
description: Queen Beatrix announced Monday that she would abdicate on April 30 after serving as the Netherlands head of state for 33 years. Her eldest son, Prince Willem-Alexander, 45, will succeed her in the largely ceremonial role. In a speech broadcast on Dutch state television, the queen said it was time for a new generation to take on the responsibility of leading the country. Prime Minister Mark Rutte thanked the queen, left, for her service, calling her an icon. Mr. Rutte added that Queen Beatrix, who turns 75 on Thursday, had applied herself heart and soul for Dutch society, according to The Associated Press.

title: A New Push on Domestic Violence
description: Turning to a critical piece of unfinished business, Patrick Leahy, the Democratic chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, joined last week with a Republican colleague, Michael Crapo of Idaho, to reintroduce legislation to reauthorize the Violence Against Women Act, the 1994 law central to the nations efforts to fight domestic violence, sexual assault and stalking.

title: And in Last Weeks Gun News ...
description: Monday, Jan. 21:

title: Les Misrables and Irony
description: I may have missed it, but I dont recall USA Today devoting a full one and three-quarters pages to a movie, never mind a movie thats been out for some time now. But there in the Life section of the Weekend edition was a lengthy discussion of Les Misrables, or, more precisely, a discussion of the furiously negative responses the musical epic has evoked from a gaggle of critics who simultaneously trash the film and express an incredulity verging on outrage at fellow moviegoers who dont share their view.

title: The Treachery of Translators
description: The fact is, there were always going to be a lot of fish in Vingt mille lieues sous les mers. When a publishing house commissioned me to produce a new translation of Jules Vernes 19th-century underwater epic, I was confident of bringing a degree of joyous panache to the story of Captain Nemo, his submarine, the Nautilus and that giant killer squid. But I had forgotten about its systematic taxonomy of all the inhabitants of the seven seas.

title: 75th Career Tour Victory Serves as a Bright Opening to Woodss Season
description: SAN DIEGO  There is a shop in the village of La Jolla, Second Act West, where people flock to find vintage clothing. Seven miles away, Tiger Woods rooted around in the past on Monday and dug up his designer game from a few years back, turning Torrey Pines into his second act, west.

title: Twice as Many Structures in FEMAs Redrawn Flood Zone
description: New federal flood maps released on Monday revealed the grim news that many New Yorkers were girding for after Hurricane Sandy sloshed away: More areas farther inland are expected to flood. Tidal surges will be more ferocious. And 35,000 more homes and businesses will be located in flood zones, which will almost certainly nudge up insurance rates and determine how some structures are rebuilt.

title: France Says Syrian Rebels Need Aid to Fend Off Chaos
description: PARIS  Frances foreign minister warned countries supporting the Syrian opposition on Monday that unless they honored their pledges of aid, the control of Syria could fall to militant Islamist groups.

title: The Mount Laurel Doctrine
description: The New Jersey Supreme Courts 1983 ruling in the Mount Laurel fair-housing case is rightly regarded as one of the most important civil rights decisions of modern times. The ruling, which greatly influenced fair-housing policy across the nation, limited the use of exclusionary zoning as a means of preventing the construction of affordable housing in wealthy communities.

title: Syrian Presidents Wife Is Pregnant, Lebanese Newspaper Says
description: Just as tens of thousands of Syrians are scrambling to get themselves and their children out of war-ravaged Syria, President Bashar al-Assad and his glamorous wife, Asma, apparently are taking the opposite approach. They are having a baby, according to a Lebanese newspaper sympathetic to the Assad family.

title: Bands Bodies Likely Found in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Several bodies found in a well in northern Mexico appear to be members of a large, popular musical group and its crew who were reported abducted at gunpoint last week after a performance.

title: The 49ers Great Injustice
description: When quarterback Alex Smith lost his starting job to Colin Kaepernick while out with a concussion, it sent a dangerous message to players in the N.F.L.

title: For Search, Facebook Had to Go Beyond Robospeak
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Human behavior is Facebooks business.

title: Iran Gives Iranian-American Pastor 8-Year Term
description: An Iranian-American pastor imprisoned in Iran since September, Saeed Abedini, has been sentenced by a revolutionary court in Iran to an eight-year prison term on charges of disturbing national security by creating a network of Christian churches in private homes, the Iranian Students News Agency reported Sunday.

title: The 49ers Great Injustice
description: When quarterback Alex Smith lost his starting job to Colin Kaepernick while out with a concussion, it sent a dangerous message to players in the N.F.L.

title: Should the E.U. Stick Together?
Catholic School Closings
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title:
Biotech Firms,
Billions at Risk,
Lobby States to
Limit Generics
description: In statehouses around the country, some of the nations biggest biotechnology companies are lobbying intensively to limit generic competition to their blockbuster drugs, potentially cutting into the billions of dollars in savings on drug costs contemplated in the federal health care overhaul law.

title: Ex-Dictator Is Ordered to Trial in Guatemalan War Crimes Case
description: MEXICO CITY  A Guatemalan judge on Monday ordered Efran Rios Montt, the former dictator, and his intelligence chief to stand trial on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity in connection with the massacres of villagers in remote highlands three decades ago.

title: Reliving Horror and Faint Hope at Massacre Site
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  The gunfire ended; it was so quiet they could hear the broken glass and bullet casings scraping under their boots. The smell of gunpowder filled the air. The officers turned down their radios; they did not want to give away their positions if there was still a gunman present.

title: Yankees Sign Juan Rivera to Minor League Deal
description: The Yankees signed the right-handed-hitting outfielder Juan Rivera to a minor league deal, according to a person with knowledge of the agreement. Rivera, a 34-year-old veteran from Venezuela, will compete with Matt Diaz and Russ Canzler for a spot as a reserve outfielder.

title: Playing Whac-a-Mole With Piracy Sites
description: OVER the years, the fight against online piracy has led to countless lawsuits by media companies and to escalating levels of law enforcement, all with mixed results.

title: Probable Choice of Game Referee Draws Skepticism
description: NEW ORLEANS  In many ways, it is fitting. Four months after the N.F.L. began its season with replacement officials  who struggled to complete a coin toss, confused which city a team hailed from and incorrectly identified whether the offense or defense had caught a critical pass in the end zone  another referee controversy is looming as the Super Bowl approaches.

title: Skilled Science Workers at Focus of Second Senate Proposal on Immigration
description: As one bipartisan group of senators released its blueprint on Monday for a comprehensive overhaul of the immigration laws, another group in the Senate was ready to present a proposal addressing one dysfunctional aspect of the system: a shortage of visas for highly skilled immigrants working in science and technology fields.

title: Nominee for Sheriff Has Worn Banks Hat
description: You dont want to mess with Mary Jo.

title: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Jan. 29, 2013
description: One look, and your life was absolutely changed.

title: Bipartisan Plan Faces Resistance in G.O.P.
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  At Tommys Country Ham House, a popular spot downtown for politics and comfort food, not much has changed since 2007, the last time conservatives here made it crystal clear to politicians how they felt about what they see as amnesty for people who entered the country illegally.

title: Sweet TV Deal Will Taste Bitter to Fans
description: In Los Angeles, the number of teams remains constant. Its just the number of regional sports networks that grows.

title: A Prosecutor Loath to Say Not Guilty
description: The freedom walk of the recently imprisoned is unavoidably moving.

title: School Support Grows Even Under Specter of a Taliban Return
description: MARJA, Afghanistan  The headmaster of the boys school in this corner of southern Afghanistan has savored the past three years, a rare run of uninterrupted school terms that filled his classrooms and drew students from miles away.

title: Education Dept. to Hear School Closing Complaints
description: PHILADELPHIA  The United States Department of Education is investigating complaints that plans to close or reorganize public schools in Philadelphia, Detroit and Newark discriminate against black and Hispanic students, as well as those with disabilities, a department official confirmed on Monday.

title: Goes Well With Meat
description: Administrivial NPR Appearance Alert! Just a heads up that I will be talking about language and  uh, what do they call it when you know lots of really fancy words? Dont tell me, its on the tip of my tongue  Anyway, tune in to NPRs Colin McEnroe show Tuesday, January 29 from 1-2 P.M. Eastern and join in the fun as we discuss the wonders of the English language, whether having a larger vocabulary makes you more smarterer, and whether this country is going to heck in a hand basket because no one can ever remember whether its i before e or the other way around.

title: Comptroller Criticizes Cuomos Plan to Cut Pension Costs
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos plan to allow municipalities to defer more of their pension costs came under fire Monday from the state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, making him the second prominent Democrat to take aim at the plan. Mr. DiNapolis office said in a statement that it had serious concerns about the plan, in part because of its potential impact on the funding level of the state pension system and the balance sheets of local governments.

title: Corrections: January 29, 2013
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Lottery Numbers
As Music Streaming Grows, Royalties Slow to a Trickle
description: Like plenty of music fans, Sam Broe jumped at the chance to join Spotify two summers ago, and he hasnt looked back.

title: Bloomberg Asks for Legislatures Help in Teacher Evaluation Fight
description: ALBANY  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday urged the State Legislature to intervene so that New York City does not lose hundreds of millions of dollars because it missed a deadline this month to finish negotiating a teacher evaluation system.

title: Letter Said to Be Chvezs Is Read at Meeting
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Venezuelas vice president read an 11-page letter bearing the signature of President Hugo Chvez to a regional summit meeting on Monday, the latest effort by the government to show that its absentee leader remains in charge.

title: Rescue Plan Is Emerging for Hospital in Manhattan
description: Manhattans only remaining hospital south of 14th Street, New York Downtown, has found a white knight willing to take over its debt and return it to good health, hospital officials said Monday.

title: With Arnott Deal Off, Scoring Help Still Needed
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  What do the Rangers want, and where can they find it? They could answer the first question easily enough ahead of Tuesdays home game against the Philadelphia Flyers. But the second question baffled them.

title: Caribbean Nation Gets an International Go-Ahead to Break U.S. Copyright Laws
description: WASHINGTON  A long-simmering trade conflict between the United States and Antigua and Barbuda appears to be boiling over.

title: Libya Denies Plans of Quick Trial and Execution for Qaddafi Spy Chief
description: PARIS  Lawyers for the Libyan government on Monday said that Libyas former intelligence chief, Abdullah al-Senussi, is expected to be tried by a civilian court in Libya in May at the earliest and will not face a summary trial and execution in the coming days as claimed by his defense lawyer.

title: Trial Testimony Begins in Officers Killing
description: Testimony in the trial of two men accused of murdering a police officer during a botched robbery attempt began on Monday with accounts from two officers who were present when their colleague, Officer Peter J. Figoski, was killed.

title: In California, Son Gets Chance to Restore Luster to a Legacy
description: LOS ANGELES  During a 1960s renaissance, Californias public university system came to be seen as a model for the rest of the country and an economic engine for the state. Seven new campuses opened, statewide enrollment doubled, and state spending on higher education more than doubled. The man widely credited with the ascendance was Gov. Edmund G. Brown, known as Pat.

title: Lopez Reminds Magic What They Could Have Had
description: Long before he was snubbed by Eastern Conference coaches and ignored by N.B.A. fans, Brook Lopez had his talents dismissed by the executives who steer the Orlando Magic. The insult was indirect and perhaps not intentional, but it was an insult nonetheless.

title: The Ravens Are Happy and Ray Lewis Is Retiring. Repeat as Needed.
description: NEW ORLEANS  By the time Coach John Harbaugh of the Baltimore Ravens addressed the news media here on Monday night, his brother Jim, the coach of the San Francisco 49ers, had already faced the masses twice. In terms of the media circus of Super Bowl XLVII, an argument can be made that arriving first is not much of an advantage.

title: Knicks to Ask Less of Kidd After Asking for Whole Lot
description: After playing five minutes in Sundays game against the Atlanta Hawks, Jason Kidd headed to the bench, put on a white Knicks T-shirt and began talking with his teammates. He never made it back on the court. Instead, he went in the opposite direction, to the teams locker room, where he spent the second half as his teammates battled to a 106-104 victory. Now the question is what direction Kidds health is going with half of the regular season remaining.

title: An Unusual Weather Turn Even for the Midwest: 8 Degrees Quickly Becomes 74
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  T. J. Abogado huffed and puffed, his buzz cut and face sprinkled with sweat. He was wearing short navy blue shorts, but his red T-shirt was now in his hand.

title: Preliminary Flood Zones
description: Maps released on Monday by the Federal Emergency Management Agency put more of New York Citys south shore into flood zones.

title: Klinsmann Eager for Progress From Defender With Potential
description: CARSON, Calif.  While Omar Gonzalez has spent the early years of his career stockpiling trophies and plaudits, the international part of his rsum has remained largely empty.

title: Max Kampelman, Who Led Arms Talks, Dies at 92
description: Max Kampelman, an American diplomat enlisted by Democratic and Republican presidents to negotiate cold war treaties with the Soviet Union on nuclear weapons and human rights, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 92.

title: Works From a Major Indian Art Collection to Be Auctioned at Sothebys
description: For more than a decade now Amrita Jhaveri has been quietly buying the best examples of modern and contemporary art from her native India. Ms. Jhaveri, a former Christies expert who is now a collector and writer, has decided to sell a portion of her collection at Sothebys in New York on March 19. It will be the first single-owner evening sale of Indian art held at Sothebys in more than a decade.

title: Ravens Game Away From the Game
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Before the Baltimore Ravens left for New Orleans on Monday, they packed up all of their equipment and gear. With a long week ahead of them before the Super Bowl on Sunday, players and staff went to great lengths to include everything they considered most important, everything vital to their performance.

title: German Politicians Remark Stirs Outcry Over Sexism
description: BERLIN  A comment by a male politician about how well a female journalist could fill out a dirndl has prompted an outcry from women across Germany and a furious debate over the prevalence of casual sexism in Europes largest economy.

title: Hiroshi Nakajima, Leader of W.H.O., Dies at 84
description: Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima, a Japanese physician who as leader of the World Health Organization started campaigns to fight malaria and other infectious diseases but whose tenure, from 1988 to 1998, was marred by repeated accusations of mismanagement, died on Saturday in Poitiers, France. He was 84.

title: Family Says Prognosis Poor for X-Games Snowmobiler
description: The prognosis is poor for Caleb Moore, the snowmobiler who was critically injured Thursday at the Winter X Games in Aspen, Colo., a relative said. Its almost certain hes not going to make it, his grandfather Charles Moore told The Denver Post. Moores family released a statement, saying, Caleb is in critical condition and is being closely monitored.

title: Heavy Rains in Australia Leave 4 Dead
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Punishing winds, torrential rains and powerful ocean swells have inundated large areas of Australias two most populous states, driving thousands of people from their homes and killing at least four people.

title: Omar Gonzalez: Progress Meets Potential
description: As the United States national team comes out of winter hibernation Tuesday for a friendly against Canada (9 p.m. Eastern time, ESPN2), Andrew Keh of The Times checks in on defender Omar Gonzalez. Always held up as a player with great potential to be a factor for the national team, and a solid success in Major League Soccer, Gonzalez still has a relatively thin international rsum  two caps, the last in January 2011. Read Andrews article here, and come back to comment.

title: Researchers Revise Helmet Rating System
description: Researchers whose ratings for football helmet quality have become popular throughout the industry have revised their system to create a more complete method of determining the probability that a player wearing certain helmets will sustain a concussion.

title: Word of the Day | minatory
description: minatory \mi-n-tr-e, mi-\ adjective

title: Five Questions (Plus a Few More) for Selma Dabbagh
description: Selma Dabbagh is a British-Palestinian fiction writer based in London. Her first novel, Out of It, which is set in Palestine, was published in 2011. A lawyer and mother of two, she is also working on her second novel, about expatriates, which is coming out next year. She spoke to India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival, which she was attending for the first time.

title: As Asia Grows, So Do Prizes
description: BEIJING  A new Asian prize that pays more than the Nobel Prize will launch next year, joining an expanding list of cash-rich awards in the region as prosperity and philanthropy grow. Yet one prize  Chinas Confucius Peace Prize  set up in 2010 in apparently outraged response to the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the jailed Chinese dissident Liu Xiaobo  seems to be unable to establish itself. In fact, as one commentator wrote in the state-run Global Times late last year, the award has been widely mocked.

title: New Home Office Deduction Is Simpler, but Smaller
description: The new simplified home-office deduction that the Obama administration unveiled earlier this month comes with a trade-off: While more of the very smallest businesses will probably opt to deduct home-office expenses for the first time, using a new streamlined form, many will get a much smaller deduction than they would if they filled out the standard form.

title: News Quiz | January 29, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 29
description: NEWS Protests in the Suez Canal city of Port Said and new clashes in Cairo on Monday came a day after President Mohamed Morsi declared a state of emergency and a curfew in three major cities. David Kirkpatrick reports from Port Said, Egypt.

title: Departing South Korean Leader Creates Furor With Pardons
description: SEOUL, South Korea  With less than one month left in office, the departing president of South Korea, Lee Myung-bak, granted special pardons on Tuesday to political allies, a longtime friend and dozens of others who have been convicted of corruption and other crimes. The pardons ignited a rare quarrel between him and the president-elect.

title: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 29, 2013
description: The question was written by Jessica Lahey. It comes from the Green blog post Discolored Slopes Mar Debut of Snow-Making Effort.

title: Protesters and Police Clash in Egypt
description: In the article Protests Grow on Fifth Day of Unrest in Egypt, David D. Kirkpatrick writes about the growing unrest in Egypt.

title: China Leader Affirms Policy on Islands
description: HONG KONG  China will never bargain over what it deems to be core territorial and security interests, the countrys top leader, Xi Jinping, said in his first published speech setting out his foreign policy views since taking over as head of the Communist Party.

title: Workers of the World, Sit Tight
description: For 25 years, Monty Newcomb has worked at the same chemical plant in Calvert City, Ky., making products that hold pills together and remove sediment from beer. In his early years, Newcomb watched his union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, lose one battle after another in its ongoing struggle with management. In the 80s and 90s, workers throughout the country justifiably feared that their plants might close and move to a union-free state. Or that they might simply import products from low-wage, nonunionized countries like Mexico and China. Newcomb told me that at his company, International Specialty Products, workers were disgruntled and the work suffered  for example, more than 20 percent of one chemical they produced didnt pass inspection.

title: Obama Speech Expected to Embrace Immigration Plan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is expected to embrace an ambitious proposal by a bipartisan group of senators to overhaul the nations immigration laws, using a speech in Las Vegas Tuesday as a call to arms for one of his top legislative priorities.

title: Who Will Win Super Bowl XLVII?  Will You Be Watching?
description: The Baltimore Ravens are playing the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl XLVII on Sunday.

title: Eastern Promises
description: ISTANBUL  Someone at the Turkish Foreign Ministry must be muttering to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, Heres another nice mess youve gotten me into.

title: Israel Skips U.N. Review on Rights, a New Move
description: GENEVA  Israel became the first country to withhold cooperation from a United Nations review of its human rights practices on Tuesday, shunning efforts by the United States and others to encourage it to participate.

title: Murdoch Apologizes for Grotesque Netanyahu Cartoon in British Paper
description: LONDON  Rupert Murdoch, the media tycoon whose British newspaper outpost has been mired in a phone hacking scandal, took the unusual step of apologizing personally for a cartoon printed in one of his titles here, The Sunday Times of London, that depicted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel building a bloody wall trapping the bodies of Palestinians.

title: Delhi Gang Rape Trial Will Be Held in Delhi, Supreme Court Rules
description: NEW DELHI Indias Supreme Court dismissed on procedural grounds a plea on Tuesday to transfer the New Delhi gang rape trial outside the city.

title: Outsourcing, Insourcing and Automation
description: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform  Why We Need It and What It Will Take.

title: Can the Ravens Learn Anything From 42-13?
description: San Francisco and Colin Kaepernick scored a lot of points (73) and gained a lot of yards (952) in their impressive run in the N.F.C. playoffs, one reason theyre favored to win the Super Bowl against Baltimore.

title: Is a Full Ride Enough to Upgrade a Fallback School?
description: I expected it to be like any other Tuesday. School started early in the morning, at 7 oclock, I had homework due in most of my classes, and we had tutorials in AVID. (The tutorials use a method of asking and answering questions to strengthen our critical thinking skills.)

title: Chaos in Egypt Stirs Warning of a Collapse
description: CAIRO  As three Egyptian cities defied President Mohamed Morsis attempt to quell the anarchy spreading through their streets, the nations top general warned Tuesday that the state itself was in danger of collapse if the feuding civilian leaders could not agree on a solution to restore order.

title: France in Mali
description: Franois Hollande draws a line in the sand in Mali.

title: Fighting Fat at India Inc., One Dosa at a Time
description: Six-footer Sanjay Jain is at least 15 kilograms (33 pounds) overweight at 95 kilograms. Typical of many of his Bangalore peers, Mr. Jain puts on weight, loses weight and then starts the whole cycle anew.

title: My Talking Head Does Morning Joe
description: Here.

title: Citing Critical Report, N.B.A. Agent Urges Players to Oust Union Leader
description: Arn Tellem, one of the N.B.A.s most powerful player agents, is calling for the ouster of the union chief Billy Hunter, a step he is urging his clients to take next month during the annual players meeting at the leagues All-Star weekend in Houston.

title: Q&A: How to Set Up Twitter Lists
description: Q.

title: Five-Ku: Haikus About Jason Statham
description: While the world was scrambling to anoint the next big action hero  a crown that has rested, often uneasily, on the brows of everyone from Vin Diesel to Dwayne (the Rock) Johnson to Tayler Lautner to Chloe Moretz  Jason Statham sort of sneaked up on us. Or rather, he sneaked up on us wearing a Savile Row tailored suit, then snapped our necks, then said something charming in a Cockney accent. (British accent-ologists, feel free to correct me here.)

title: Introducing Fashioning Change: Wear This, Not That
description: Im the founder and chief executive of Fashioning Change, a start-up that helps shoppers purchase stylish, money-saving, safe and sweatshop-free alternatives to top name brands.

title: Honk Honk!
description: The Transportation Department is taking down Dont Honk signs across town. Critics worry the city has given up on curbing noise pollution, but few New Yorkers seem to mind.

title: Daily Report: For Search, Facebook Had to Go Beyond Robospeak
description: In The New York Times on Tuesday, Somini Sengupta reports on the eclectic team that Facebook assembled to create its search tool to help users find answers to many kinds of questions.

title: The Royal Blog
description: Norodom Sihanouk, the former king of Cambodia who died in October and is to be cremated next week after an elaborate four-day ceremony, is invariably remembered as a man of many talents: a political chameleon and a filmmaker, a jazz saxophonist and a ladies man.

title: Is S.E.C. Nominee Too Connected?
description: In choosing Mary Jo White, a former prosecutor, to lead the Securities and Exchange Commission, President Obama seemed to signal a resolve to get tough on Wall Street. But the other section of Ms. Whites rsum  her years representing Wall Street names as a rainmaking partner at Debevoise & Plimpton  could prove troublesome. How conflicted is Ms. White? Lets count the ways, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in his DealBook column. Her clients from finance have included JPMorgan Chase, the board of Morgan Stanley and Kenneth D. Lewis, a former Bank of America chief executive.

title: Number Trouble
description: Last week we revisited our perennial problems with who and whom. This week, another favorite grammar gaffe: the failure to match singular with singular, plural with plural.

title: In Performance: Gia Crovatin of Theater Uncut
description: Neil LaButes short play In the Beginning is about the Occupy movement that grabbed national headlines, beginning in 2011. Gia Crovatin plays a character called the Child, who here tries to explain the importance of the protest and why she so desperately needs to be involved. In the Beginning is part of Theater Uncut, an evening of short plays about the political and economic challenges in several countries, that runs through Sunday at the Clurman Theater.

title: OpenTable to Acquire Foodspotting for $10 Million
description: Booking a restaurant reservation on the Internet is more convenient than calling a hostess or jotting your name down on a waiting list, but it can feel impersonal. OpenTable, the online reservation business, says it is acquiring a start-up to make booking a table a bit more intimate and social.

title: European Cloud Over Ford
description: DETROIT  Last year, Ford Motor broke ranks with other auto companies when it announced major cuts in its troubled European operations, including the closing of three factories, to address a sharp downturn in sales on the continent and an oversupply of vehicles.

title: Opinion Report: Immigration Reform
description: From the editorial page

title: Plane Crashes in Fog in Kazakhstan, Killing All 21 on Board
description: MOSCOW  A passenger plane crashed in heavy fog outside of Kazakhstans largest city on Tuesday, killing 21 people, Kazakh emergency officials said. The crash was the second aviation disaster in the country in a month.

title: On Our Radar: A Clean Air Act for China?
description: Dense smog shrouds eastern China for the second time in about two weeks, forcing airlines to cancel flights and factories to shut down temporarily. Meanwhile, nearly 32,000 heed an online call by a real estate tycoon to declare their support for adoption of a clean air act. [Associated Press, Wall Street Journal]

title: Gleacher to Leave His Investment Bank
description: 9:32 a.m. | Updated with interview with Mr. Gleacher

title: Tuesday Reading: The Risks of Taking a Shower
Missed Connection on the R Train

title: Bringing the Sinatra Style Out in Rigoletto
description: Shortly into Act I of the Metropolitan Operas new production of Verdis Rigoletto, which opened on Monday night, the boyishly exuberant tenor Piotr Beczala, playing the Duke as a Frank Sinatra-like playboy in a stylish white tuxedo, grabs a microphone  fake, of course. He then sings the aria Questa o quella to a rowdy, decadent crowd at the Dukes gaudy casino.

title: Elliott Management Calls for Board Shake-Up at Hess
description: Elliott Management is calling for a board shake-up at the Hess Corporation.

title: For Mayor, A+ in Spanish Is Still on the Horizonte
description: BALTIMORE  Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs shaky, determined and unembarrassed stabs at the Spanish language have earned him the admiration of the citys nonnative speakers and the mocking of a Twitter parody account, @ElBloombito.

title: Diving Into the Coral Triangle
description: Drew Harvell is associate director for environment at the Atkinson Center for a Sustainable Future at Cornell University. She is studying the health of coral reefs and marine ecosystems in Indonesia.

title: Stargazing at the Miraval Resort
description: Just over 9,000 feet up Mount Lemmon in the Coronado National Forest sits the University of Arizonas SkyCenter, which houses the largest telescope in the southwest open for public observing. The university boasts an elite academic astronomy program, and the telescope is a Tucson treasure; scholars travel from around the world to spend an evening studying the far-off galaxies visible from the observatory.

title: as the Netherlands Salutes Its Departing Monarch
description: THE HAGUE  Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands announced on Monday that she would abdicate on April 30 in favor of her son, the Prince of Orange, Willem-Alexander.

title: Biography of J.D. Salinger Coming in September
description: J.D. Salinger, one of the most reclusive authors of the modern era, will be the subject of a new biography written by David Shields and Shane Salerno and released by Simon & Schuster, Jonathan Karp, the publisher, said on Tuesday.

title: Adversaries in Syria Trade Blame for Scores of Killings in Aleppo

Insurgents and the government accused one another of carrying out the killings in what appeared to be the latest civil war atrocity.

More recently, he was a sounding board for Ben Sherwood, the president of ABC News, as Mr. Sherwoods Good Morning America finally ended the Today shows streak.

title: Other Voices: Can Climate Science Communication Matter?
description: The first 15 years or so of my coverage of the greenhouse effect and global warming focused on geophysical and environmental questions, along with energy and forest policy. Around 2005 I started paying more attention to the internal climate  meaning, how human perception, or misperception, of climate science and environmental risk influences the decisions, or indecision, of individuals and societies in the face of climate change.

Stravinsky, Petroushka

description: The players who have gathered in New Orleans for the Super Bowl took an array of talents with them  passing, running, chasing down quarterbacks  but little did they know that their most useful talent in the week leading up to the big game would be tightrope walking. Denial has come in handy, too. Head-faking the big issue in the room? Invaluable.

description: Fresh clashes on Monday came a day after President Mohamed Morsi imposed emergency law in three cities, including Port Said, where protests turned deadly.

title: Chinese Activists Demand Clarity on Domestic Violence Law
description: BEIJING  Li Yan, a woman from Sichuan Province who was convicted of killing her abusive husband, faces execution. As activists in China fight to save her life, three women last week delivered a petition with more than 12,000 signatures to the National Peoples Congress in Beijing, demanding transparency in the drafting of a planned national law against domestic violence.

title: Redefining Home in Tidewater Virginia
description: Matt Eich was raised in the tidewater area of Virginia, a series of seven cities and smaller shore communities separated by water yet connected by bridges, tunnels and the presence of many large United States military bases.

title: Laurents/Hatcher Award Goes to Daniel Pearle for A Kid Like Jake
description: The new play A Kid Like Jake, about raising a child in the world of Manhattan privilege, has won the 2013 Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award, an unusually structured prize that provides $50,000 to the writer and an additional $100,000 toward the production costs for the shows premiere. The playwright is Daniel Pearle, and Lincoln Center Theater has already announced that it will mount A Kid Like Jake at the Claire Tow Theater in June through its LCT3 program, which provides tickets for $20.

title: Frank Ocean Wants to Press Charges Against Chris Brown
description: Frank Ocean, the R&B singer and songwriter, wants to press charges against Chris Brown after the two were said to have fought over a parking spot near a Los Angeles recording studio, a move that could jeopardize Mr. Browns probation on a previous assault conviction, Reuters reported. Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to assaulting Rihanna in 2009.

title: Report Gauges Companies Approach to Advertising on Social Media
description: Since the arrival of social media platforms, companies have tried to figure out how to best use them to get their messages to consumers, often with mixed results. Some brands have embraced the notion that social platforms like Twitter allow constant interaction, for better or worse, with their customers.

title: Face Time | Elsa Hosk
description: Elsa Anna Sophia Hosk, a very sweet and exceptionally beautiful model from Sweden, was recently named the face of Pink, a subdivision of Victorias Secret. Just 24, shes already worked for Christian Dior, Dolce & Gabbana, Lilly Pulitzer, Ugg and Nine West. Here she shares some of her thoughts on style, classic rock, her love of natural products, and food.

title: Whats On Tuesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) HENRY FORD American Experience chronicles the life and times of Ford, from his childhood on a Michigan farm in the 1860s and his dream of becoming a machinist in Detroit to his pursuit of racecar driving, the winnings from which allowed him to incorporate his Ford Motor Company. The result was the revolutionary Model T, a lightweight, durable and fast automobile that cost $850 at a time when the average car sold for more than $2,000. Soon the company was producing 1,000 cars a day. Taking its cue from the meatpacking industry, the company established the first automobile assembly line and controlled nearly half of the American car market. Ford, above with the Model T, also paid a $5 daily wage to reduce turnover, with strings attached. Immigrant workers had to attend the companys English-language schools, and inspectors from the sociological department would delve into their private lives. As Ford became one of the richest men in the world, he found his hatred for the wealthy elite increasing; he allied himself with the common people. But as his ego expanded, so did his anger. Ford blamed Jews for the countrys problems, bullied those who worked for him and displayed withering cruelty toward his only son, Edsel, who died at 49  a death many blamed on the unrelenting stress of trying to please his father.

title: When Good Drivers Pay More for Insurance Than Bad Ones
description: Some big insurance companies charge higher auto rates for lower-income drivers, even if the drivers have safe driving records, an analysis from the Consumer Federation of America finds.

Amtrak and the California High-Speed Rail Authority have developed trains capable of operating up to 220 miles an hour for service on both the East and West Coasts, and the California authority received final bids to build the first leg of the states high-speed rail project, 29 miles of track in the Central Valley. This brings the states largest infrastructure undertaking in history one step closer to breaking ground later this year, Mr. LaHood wrote in his Fast Lane blog.

title: Go Ahead: Google Shooting
description: That is what my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I did last week in compiling the stories for todays column. The column gives only the smallest of hints as to how many shootings there are on any given day; my guess is that even Google doesnt find them all. To give you a fuller picture, weve reconstructed the Google search for shooting from Monday to Saturday last week. Since the Newtown shooting on December 14, the United States has suffered 18 gun deaths per day, for a total of 1,330. In case you were wondering.

title: Good News for Bad People as Showtime, Cinemax and BBC America Renew Series

Showtime said that it had ordered new seasons of its dark comedies Shameless (about a Chicago family gone to seed); Californication (about an author struggling  and sometimes not struggling  with his sex life); and House of Lies, about a group of unscrupulous management consultants. All three series have seen their viewership grow over previous seasons, Showtime said, and will resume production later this year in Los Angeles to begin new seasons in 2014. Don Cheadle, a star of House of Lies, was a surprise winner of the Golden Globe for lead actor in a comedy or musical series earlier this month.

title: Tanqueray Brings Back Malacca Gin for a Spell
description: In 1997, Tanqueray introduced a new gin called Malacca. It was softer, wetter and less juniper-forward than its London Dry counterpart, and bottled at a lower proof. But by 2001 it was pulled from the market as the company focused on other products. From there, the legend grew. Mixologists who tasted it said it was as close as you could get today to Old Tom Gin, a sweeter, 19th-century style of gin essential to recreating certain pre-Prohibition cocktails. The thirsty hunted for stray bottles.

title: Women in Combat? Some Marines React
description: When my squad arrived at our outpost in Afghanistan in 2010, one of the first things we did was outfit our living quarters with trash bags, cardboard and salvaged wood to ease the vicious winds. Going to the bathroom proved equally challenging. We urinated into a metal pipe fed through a Hesco barricade filled with dirt and burned our feces in a metal drum. There were no showers or water for showers, so, after each days long and grueling foot patrols we pulled on new socks and used baby wipes and body powder. It was miserable but we endured the misery together.

title: Guantnamo Lawyers Seeking 48-Hour Visits

Defense lawyers for Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others accused of being accomplices in the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, asked a military tribunal judge in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, on Tuesday to let them stay in prison with their clients for 48-hour periods every six months. But military prosecutors called that request unreasonable, saying the defense should be allowed only a single two-hour visit.

title: Talking Talent | Benjamin Walker
description: The Juilliard-trained theater actor Benjamin Walker, who played the 16th president on the silver screen in Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter and Andrew Jackson on Broadway, has taken a break from American politics to star as the booze-swilling Brick in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof at the Richard Rogers Theater through March 30. At a sculptured 6-foot-3, Walker successfully embodies Brick with bourbon-soaked vulnerability and plenty of southern charm. Thirty minutes before curtain, a cool and collected Walker answered Ts questions about crutches, lap dances and his almighty mother-in-law, Meryl Streep.
