How does history have a way of cropping up where you least expect it: at the bottom of a forgotten old storage box, under the dirt of Central Park or in the memories of a long-running TV dance show?

title: Alvin Ailey Troupe Headed to the David H. Koch Theater
description: The march to the Koch continues. Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has become the latest dance company to take up residence at the David H. Koch Theater in Lincoln Center. Ailey said on Tuesday it would present seven performances at the Koch from June 12 to June 16, in addition to its touring and regular season at City Center.

title: The 49ers Quarterback Drama? Steve Bono Has Been There
description: The Fifth Down recently talked with former Pro Bowl quarterback Steve Bono about one of his former teams, the San Francisco 49ers, who will play the Ravens in the Super Bowl on Sunday. Bono went 5-1 for San Francisco in 1991 when he replaced an injured Steve Young (Joe Montana was out for the season). Bono, 50, also played for the Vikings, Steelers, Chiefs, Rams, Packers and Panthers in his 14-year career. He now is a partner with Constellation Wealth Management Associates.

title: The King of Cakes
description: In New Orleans, the king cake reigns supreme  just dont find a baby in your slice.

title: Catsimatidis Announces Bid for Mayor
description: John A. Catsimatidis, the billionaire owner of the Gristedes grocery chain, stood on the steps of City Hall on Tuesday and announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for mayor of New York City.

title: A City Drenched in Sugar
description: NEW ORLEANS  Other cities might be trudging through cabbage season at this point in winter, but New Orleans is eating cake. From Twelfth Night to Mardi Gras, which is Feb. 12 this year, daily consumption of king cake  a round of sweet dough glazed with purple, gold and green sugar  is more or less compulsory. Its a clue that although this citys rmoulades and gumbos and Sazeracs are renowned, there is also a world of sweet treats to explore.

title: Producers Scramble After Investor Withdraws From Breakfast at Tiffanys
description: The Broadway producers of Truman Capotes Breakfast at Tiffanys are scrambling to raise $1 million after an investor pulled out of the $4 million show, according to a spokesman for the production, which began rehearsals on Monday and is scheduled to begin performances on March 4. The cast, led by Emilia Clarke (HBOs Game of Thrones) as Holly Golightly, have been told that the production would be in jeopardy if the money was not replaced quickly. The plays spokesman, Rick Miramontez, declined to identify the investor who dropped out, but said some additional money had already been raised and the producers were working hard to find the rest. Another Broadway-bound show this season, Rebecca, fell apart because of money problems after four of its investors were revealed to be phantoms. The producers of Breakfast at Tiffanys  Colin Ingram Productions Limited, Donovan Mannato and Dominic Ianno  are relative newcomers to Broadway.

title: Streaming and Micropennies: The Footnotes
description: In Tuesdays paper, I wrote about the royalties that musicians and record companies earn from online streaming companies like Spotify, Pandora and YouTube.

title: Its Pensioners on the Side of Hedge Funds Making Their Case Against Argentina
description: Maria Teresa Muoz, a retired secretary from Buenos Aires, has something in common with Paul E. Singer, the billionaire hedge fund manager who is suing Argentinas government.

title: Rebecca Lawsuit
description: A copy of the civil lawsuit filed by the producers of the Broadway musical Rebecca against their former press agent.

title: Rebecca Publicist Sued Over E-Mails to Investor
description: The twisting and twisted tale of the Broadway musical Rebecca, which fell apart last fall after several investors were revealed to be phantoms, has a new chapter  and its a doozy.

title: With Attitude and Tonics, 22 Gins Mixed and Matched
description: Cata, which opened on the Lower East Side last September, specializes in tapas and gin and tonics, a combination, its fair to say, that is not available on every corner. Not like burgers and fries. Soup and salad. Or even gin and tonic.

title: Carville and Matalin Part Ways With CNN
description: 3:59 p.m. | Updated James Carville and Mary Matalin, staples of CNNs political programming for over a decade, are parting ways with the channel, CNN confirmed on Tuesday.

title: Altidore the Target of Racist Chants
description: Jozy Altidore scored another goal for AZ on Tuesday in a Dutch Cup match, but it was the events before and after he scored that have brought condemnation.

title: Ex-Janitor Convicted of Raping Girl in School Basement Repeatedly
description: A former Brooklyn middle-school janitor was convicted Tuesday of repeatedly raping and sexually abusing an eighth-grade girl, the district attorneys office said.

title: Hiring Help to Lure a Husband Out of a Bedroom
description: It takes extensive puppeteering to get Jeff Backhauss debut novel where he wants it to go. The first thing that Hikikomori and the Rental Sister must do is come up with an American hermit and agoraphobe with a set of traits that are much more common in Japan. This book needs a man who has withdrawn from society and will not leave his room, although Mr. Backhaus cannot replicate the subtle ways Japanese society enables traumatized young adults to try to erase themselves that way.

title: From a Chance Meeting, Lincoln Emerges
description: Watching the two-and-a-half-hour Lincoln, with its wartime scenes, epic Congressional and marital showdowns and presidential death, viewers might not think that its backstory involved a lot of winnowing and trimming. And yet, thats exactly what was necessary, as Kathleen Kennedy, a producer of the film, revealed in a recent panel discussion hosted by the Producers Guild of America.

title: Audience, Ready to Play Your Part?
description: For Claude Wampler, subterfuge isnt a fashionable artistic device. She needs it.

title: The Test Will Join Television Talk Shows
description: MIAMI  Imagine a tabloid talk show like Maury distilled to its essence: the enduring question, are you the father?

title: Lewis Avoids Questions About Banned Substance
description: NEW ORLEANS  Amid all the hoopla at Tuesdays Super Bowl media day, Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis dismissed a report that he had used a banned performance enhancing substance this season to help recover from a torn triceps.

title: Incestuous Amplification, Economics Edition
description: Back during the early days of the Iraq debacle, I learned that the military has a term for how highly dubious ideas become not just accepted, but viewed as certainties. Incestuous amplification happen when a closed group of people repeat the same things to each other  and when accepting the groups preconceptions itself becomes a necessary ticket to being in the in-group. A fundamentally flawed notion  say, that the Germans cant possibly attack though the Ardennes  becomes part of what everyone knows, where everyone means by definition only people who accept the flawed notion.

title: Under Fire, Chesapeake Co-Founder to Depart
description: 9:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Stolen Facebook IDs and All About Zelda
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: A Story Known Far and Wide, in Denmark at Least
description: Until this month, if the Danish director and screenwriter Nikolaj Arcel was known at all in the English-speaking world, it was as the co-writer of the screenplay for the original version of The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo. But after winning two prizes at the Berlin Film Festival a year ago, the latest film he directed, A Royal Affair, is now getting attention in Hollywood as one of the five contenders nominated for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film.

title: Right Tune, Right Singer: Pure Alchemy
description: Bemused, the title of the singer Christine Andreass deliciously tangy show at 54 Below, is one of the most misused and hard-to-pin-down words in the English language. As Ms. Andreas reflected on its meanings at Sunday evenings opening-night performance, one synonym, thunderstruck, stood out.

title: BlackBerry 10 Critical to Research in Motion
description: OTTAWA  Research in Motions introduction on Wednesday of a new BlackBerry phone will be the most important event in the companys history since 1996, when its founders showed investors a small block of wood and promised that a wireless e-mail device shaped like that would change business forever.

title: A Better Immigration Plan
description: President Obama hit the right notes when he made the case for overhauling the immigration system in a speech in Las Vegas on Tuesday. He spoke one day after a bipartisan group of eight senators released their own blueprint for a comprehensive reform bill, and the back-to-back events gave the odd sensation  rare during the Obama administration  of seeing Congress and the White House moving in more or less the same direction.

title: Where to Eat in Staten Island: Lakruwana and Beyond
description: This week I review Lakruwana, a showcase for Sri Lankan food and crafts in Staten Island, a part of town that Times restaurant critics have not often written about.

title: Modernizing the New York Public Library
description: Michael Kimmelman on the $300 million plan to renovate the legendary structure.

title: In Renderings for a Library Landmark, Stacks of Questions
description: None of New Yorks great buildings embody the spirit of the city more than the New York Public Library, the cherished century-old Beaux-Arts landmark in the heart of Midtown Manhattan. But cities change  New York all the time  and even the greatest buildings may need to change with them. So it was that more than four years ago the library announced a $250 million plan (since revised upward to $300 million and still rising). Norman Foster, the celebrity architect, was enlisted to revamp and modernize the 42nd Street building.

title: If You Like A Taste of Honey, Try Little Dragon
description: If you hated disco back then, chances are you might stop reading. But if there is even a tiny possibility of reconsidering, I ask you to stick with me and give this weeks post a chance. According to an online biography of the group, the opening line of A Taste of Honey's 1978 hit song, "Boogie Oogie Oogie," was inspired by an especially tough and unresponsive audience at an American military base. Hazel Payne, one of the singers, yelled to the hostile crowd: "If you're thinkin' you're too cool to boogie, boy oh boy have I got news for you! Everybody here tonight must boogie, let me tell ya, you are no exception to the rule!"

title: Does Championing Marriage Exclude Single Parents?
description: The Institute for American Values has issued a fairly remarkable Call for a New Conversation on Marriage. Its president, David Blankenhorn, is perhaps best known as the expert who testified against gay marriage in the Proposition 8 trial in California, and then changed his mind, publicly, with an Op-Ed article in The New York Times.

title: Requiem for the Barflies
description: Joe Iconis performs a song-and-dance number from his imagined musical about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Bloomberg: The Musical: Hes Not Calling the Tunes
description: BEGINNING on Wednesday, Encores! is bringing back Fiorello!, the Pulitzer Prize-winning 1959 musical about Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, to celebrate its 20th season. Fiorello! was the first show to be revived at City Center in a concert staging, the Encores! format that has become a New York cultural fixture. Why that show? La Guardia saved City Center from the wrecking ball, explained Jack Viertel, the programs artistic director.

title: In Energy Taxes, Tools to Help Tackle Climate Change
description: To understand the complicated politics of climate change in the United States, you may want to talk to Pamela Johnson, president of the National Corn Growers Associations Corn Board.

title: In Limbaugh Interview, Rubio Charms the Host
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, continued his conservative media tour Tuesday with an afternoon telephone interview on Rush Limbaughs talk radio show. The back and forth went so well, from Mr. Rubios point of view, that at 6 p.m. his office was still tweeting out highlights from the exchange.

title: History-Rich Georgia Island Wins Second Look on Taxes
description: DARIEN, Ga.  Residents of a tiny barrier island in Georgia on Tuesday won a temporary reprieve from property tax increases that they feared would drive them from their historic community.

title: A Jazz Reunion at the Fame School
description: This is about jazz, so well improvise, starting with Jimmy Owens, the renowned trumpeter, composer and bandleader. In cool threads (red jacket and green scarf), hes remembering back more than 50 years to his days at the citys High School of Music & Art, before it merged with the High School of Performing Arts  the Fame school  and before they moved together to Lincoln Center  before there really was a Lincoln Center.

title: After Fire, Some Brazilians Fault a Nations Sense of Fatalism
description: SANTA MARIA, Brazil  First there was the shock over the chaotic nightclub fire here that killed more than 230 people, many of them promising university students. Then there was the grief as families began burying their dead.

title: Nigeria: Money Promised to Clean Up Lead That Killed Hundreds of Children
description: President Goodluck Jonathan promised this week to release $4 million to clean up villages where hundreds of children have died in the worlds worst outbreak of lead poisoning.

title: John A. Catsimatidis Runs for Mayor
description: John A. Catsimatidis, the Greek-born billionaire, said that he will seek the Republican nomination to be the next mayor of New York City.

title: Looking for New F.B.I. Headquarters, the Government Proposes a Trade
description: WASHINGTON  For nearly 40 years, the F.B.I. has had its headquarters in a massive example of Brutalist architecture on Pennsylvania Avenue. But the federal government hopes to swap the building and its prime location for a sprawling new home in the suburbs, and there seem to be plenty of developers eager to help make that happen.

title: Lessons for Entrepreneurs in Rubble of a Collapsed Deal
description: One lesson to be learned from Goldman Sachss victory in a legal dispute over its role as the adviser in the sale of the speech recognition company Dragon Systems may be an old one. If you dont know who the chump is, then youre probably it.

title: Seeing Big Promise in Manhattan Corporate Apartments
description: Silverstein Properties, the developer of the World Trade Center complex in Lower Manhattan, is shifting gears to expand its presence in the citys corporate apartment market.

title: Welcome to Britain. Our Weather Is Appalling.
description: LONDON  The 100 Years War actually lasted 116 years. Pantomime dames tend to be men dressed as women. The hovercraft was invented by Sir Christopher Cockerell. York Minster has very nice stained-glass windows. Margaret Thatcher successfully tamed the unions and turned London into a powerful international financial center by deregulating the financial markets.

title: Bipartisan Hunting Buddies
description: WE are as different as North and South. One of us, John Dingell, is a liberal Michigan Democrat and the other, Jim Baker, is a conservative Texas Republican. We met during the Reagan administration and have often found ourselves on opposite sides of political battles. We have the bruises to show for them.

title: Oher, Subject of The Blind Side, Tries to Keep the Focus on Football
description: NEW ORLEANS  The subject that always follows Michael Oher followed him to media day at the Super Bowl on Tuesday. Oher would prefer to concentrate on football, on his job as offensive tackle for the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Ski Resort Needs Bigger Wastewater Signs, Agency Says
description: As I reported here earlier this month, after a decade of legal battles Arizona Snowbowl recently became the first ski area in the world to make snow totally out of wastewater. It is piped directly from a sewage treatment plant in neighboring Flagstaff.

title: A Harbaugh and a Hoosier
description: NEW ORLEANS  When the gossip finally reached the Western Kentucky athletic department  that the daughter of the football coach was dating the young basketball assistant  there was one natural reaction.

title: To Open Eyes, W-2s List Cost of Providing a Health Plan
description: WASHINGTON  As workers open their W-2 forms this month, many will see a new box with information on the total cost of employer-sponsored health insurance coverage. To some, it will be a surprise, perhaps even a shock.

title: Incestuous Amplification, Further Illustrated
description: In reference to my last post:

title: Treat Greed in Africa as a War Crime
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia

title: Perry Changes Tack on Rainy Day Fund
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  For years, Gov. Rick Perry has urged Texas lawmakers to resist the temptation to tap the billions of dollars in a state emergency account known as the Rainy Day Fund.

title: 9/11 Health Fund Pays Out Its First 15 Awards
description: A federal fund set up to compensate people sickened by the Sept. 11 terrorist attack made its first awards on Tuesday, to 15 first responders.

title: In Thailand, Power Comes With Help From Skype
description: BANGKOK  Millions of people across the globe have cut the tethers to their offices, working remotely from home, airport lounges or just about anywhere they can get an Internet connection. But the political party governing Thailand has taken telecommuting into an altogether different realm.

title: Pettitte Will Not Pitch in World Baseball Classic
description: Andy Pettitte officially withdrew from the World Baseball Classic on Tuesday, according to Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman, ending any further questions about whether Pettitte would pitch for the United States in the tournament.

title: Ravens Center, Long a Trader of Blows, Ponders Their Impact
description: NEW ORLEANS  For nearly 15 seasons, for more than 200 games, Matt Birk has blocked and mauled and protected. He has anchored offensive lines, both in Minnesota and in Baltimore, which meant he has suffered through various neck, elbow and knee injuries. He has made six Pro Bowls. He has opened holes for Adrian Peterson and Ray Rice.

title: Vegetables in Winter, Served Family Style
description: BIRDS EYE, the frozen vegetable brand, will introduce new TV advertising for its Steamfresh Chefs Favorites side dishes on Feb. 4, the first work by its latest ad agency, BBDO.

title: Why Palestine Should Take Israel to Court in The Hague
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Did Star Wars Need Ben Affleck?
description: Last weeks news that J.J. Abrams will direct the first of the new round of Star Wars movies inspired a certain amount of carping about having both of American pop cultures most famous sci-fi franchises in the hands of the same not-universally-beloved director. But the emerging consensus seems to be that Star Wars fans should be grateful to have a filmmaker with sci-fi experience in the directors chair. Heres Slates Aisha Harris, for instance:

title: Reforming Immigration for Good
description: IN Las Vegas yesterday, President Obama made it clear that an overhaul of Americas immigration laws was his top domestic priority. He expressed cautious support for a bipartisan plan by eight senators that would create a pathway to citizenship for 11 million illegal immigrants in exchange for tougher border enforcement, employment checks and temporary work visas for farmworkers and highly skilled engineers and scientists.

title: U.S. 0, Canada 0
description: United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann picked a young lineup sure to please Major League Soccer officials for Tuesday nights exhibition game against Canada in Houston (9 p.m. Eastern, ESPN2). All 11 United States starters play for M.L.S. clubs.

title: Albert Rabil III
description: Mr. Rabil, 49, is chief executive of Kayne Anderson Real Estate Advisors, a unit of Kayne Anderson that owns student housing properties.

title: Lawns Into Gardens
description: The seed catalogs have arrived, and for the roughly 15 percent of Americans who appreciate the joys and rewards of growing some of their own crops, this is a more encouraging sign than Groundhog Day or even the reporting of pitchers and catchers to spring training.

title: Its P.Q. and C.Q. as Much as I.Q.
description: President Obamas first term was absorbed by dealing with the Great Recession. I hope that in his second term hell be able to devote more attention to the Great Inflection.

title: Laying Out Broad Principles, but Leaving Recourse Open
description: In laying out his proposal for an immigration overhaul in a speech in Las Vegas on Tuesday, President Obama offered both carrots and sticks to persuade lawmakers in Congress to pass the ambitious legislation this year.

title: New Denials, and New Questions About What Is Next
description: The Yankees had dated Alex Rodriguez for four years before popping the question after the 2007 season: Will you take this 10-year, $275 million contract? Rodriguez said yes, and together they have had some fun. But a marriage that starts with a lie is bound to fall apart, and that is what has happened.

title: Judge Dismisses Federal Suit Over Credit Histories in Hiring
description: A federal judge in Ohio has dismissed a lawsuit that accused the Kaplan Higher Education Corporation of discriminating against black job applicants.

title: The Boy Scouts Fall Short
description: Just a week after President Obama made ending antigay discrimination a central message of his Inaugural Address, the Boy Scouts of America provided more evidence that greater acceptance and inclusion is becoming a social norm.

title: Congress Takes Up Gun Violence
description: Senate hearings on stronger gun controls are scheduled to begin on Wednesday before a divided Congress and a nation agonizing over how to prevent more of the carnage that killed 20 schoolchildren and six adults last month at a Newtown, Conn., elementary school. The gun lobbys opposition to reasonable controls is already fierce, and political courage is, as ever, wavering in Congress. But this singular opportunity to curb the gun violence must not be wasted in more of the posturing in Washington that tolerates 30,000 gun deaths a year.

title: MF Globals Bankruptcy Nears a Happy Conclusion
description: When Mahesh Desai checked his MF Global account 15 months ago, his $580,000 nest egg was gone.

title: Questions for Hagel's Confirmation Hearing
A River View, Ruined
description: To the Editor:

title: Hypocrisy in College Sports
description: To the Editor:

title: Harsh Abortion Curbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryans Critique of Obama
description: To the Editor:

title: A Church Made Up of Sinners and Saints
description: To the Editor:

title: For Republicans, a Push From Voters on Immigration and a Tug on Gun Control
description: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the White House prepare to refight two epic policy battles from the past  a new agenda to stem gun violence and another to address the nations heavily criticized immigration system  political, demographic and economic shifts are propelling immigration changes forward as forcefully as they are pulling lawmakers away on guns.

title: Boeing 787 Battery Was a Concern Before Failure
description: Even before two battery failures led to the grounding of all Boeing 787 jets this month, the lithium-ion batteries used on the aircraft had experienced multiple problems that raised questions about their reliability.

title: Where 50,000 Guns Recovered in Chicago Came From
description:
The Chicago Police Department traced the origins of about 50,000 guns that it recovered between 2001 and March 2012.
More than half of those guns came from outside the state.

title: Off the Pedestal
description: NEW ORLEANS  Alex Smith put on the headphones and then did what he has done for the past two months with the San Francisco 49ers  he waited without complaint. A minute passed. Then two. Then three. The imminent radio interview was not so imminent anymore. The producer apologized. Smith smiled.

title: A Rocky Path for the 787 Dreamliner
description: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner, the first new commercial plane from Boeing in more than a decade, has been troubled by a long series of production and safety problems.

title: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Jan. 30, 2013
description: Chicago is like a house with two parents that may try to have good rules and do what they can, but its like youve got this single house sitting on a whole block where theres anarchy. Chicago is an argument for laws that are statewide or better yet, national.

title: F.D.A. Approves Genetic Drug to Treat Rare Disease
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new drug Tuesday that not only treats a rare inherited disorder that causes extremely high cholesterol levels and heart attacks by age 30, but does so using a long-sought technology that can shut off specific genes that cause disease.

title: New to Most Fans, IGF-1 Has Long Been Banned as a Performance Enhancer
description: In theory, at least, IGF-1 seems almost too good to be true.

title: Dont Worry About Me
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  True Fact: Tito Puente taught The Girl how to play the maracas when she was three years old. This was purely by accident, mind you.

title: Corrections: January 30, 2013
description: NATIONAL

title: Solicitations by Liu Aide to Be Focus in Fraud Case
description: A senior aide to John C. Liu, the New York City comptroller, solicited campaign donations on his behalf from friends and family members and offered to reimburse them, according to statements by a lawyer and a prosecutor on Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Scout Plan to Allow Gays Ignites Debates on Local Level
description: A proposed shift by the Boy Scouts of America away from its national policy banning gays, leaving the decision to local councils, has divided scouts, families and troop leaders, with thousands taking to the organizations Facebook page and other online forums to express their views in passionate tones of anguish, opprobrium or approval.

title: Images Complicate Jury Selection in Cannibalism Case
description: One photo is a bizarre mixture of soft-core pornography and cannibalism: a naked woman lies face down in a roasting pan, hogtied, with an apple in her mouth. Another image seems like a Mad magazine cartoon gone awry: an illustration of a woman, bound and naked, making small talk with a man as he boils her in a glass pot.

title: Strict Gun Laws in Chicago Cant Stem Fatal Shots
description: CHICAGO  Not a single gun shop can be found in this city because they are outlawed. Handguns were banned in Chicago for decades, too, until 2010, when the United States Supreme Court ruled that was going too far, leading city leaders to settle for restrictions some describe as the closest they could get legally to a ban without a ban. Despite a continuing legal fight, Illinois remains the only state in the nation with no provision to let private citizens carry guns in public.

title: After Losing Their Captain, the Rangers Hold On for a Victory
description: It was not pretty, as Michael Del Zotto attested after he scored one goal and set up another in the Rangers 2-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday. But, as he added, the Rangers found a way to win.

title: Gun Rights Backers, Stung by Cuomos Law, Push to Undo It
description: ALBANY  More than 100,000 people have signed online petitions denouncing New Yorks recently enacted gun laws. Gun owners are contemplating civil disobedience, vowing to ignore a requirement to register firearms they own that are now classified as assault weapons. And some are even calling for the impeachment of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: At Media Day, Spotlight on Head Injuries Grows
description: NEW ORLEANS  It has become a staple of Super Bowl week, as much a part of the pregame to the N.F.L.s biggest event as the annual media day: a discussion of how football is being affected by head injuries and the mounting evidence that long-term brain damage can be linked to injuries sustained on the field.

title: Searching for a Way Out of Limbo
description: Here was a detail, Tania Gordillo thought, that could have been lifted directly from her own living room. It was about 10 minutes into the speech on immigration reform President Obama delivered Tuesday afternoon in Las Vegas.

title: Battery at Center of Inquiry
description: Lithium-ion batteries on Boeings new 787 Dreamliner were involved in 2 recent incidents. The exact cause is not yet known, but lithium-ion batteries have a history of overheating when being charged, particularly when the charge gets too low.

title: Modesty in Ultra-Orthodox Brooklyn Is Enforced by Secret Squads
description: The Brooklyn shopkeeper was already home for the night when her phone rang: a man who said he was from a neighborhood modesty committee was concerned that the mannequins in her stores window, used to display womens clothing, might inadvertently arouse passing men and boys.

title: Lottery Numbers
To the Big Stage, the Long Way
description: NEW ORLEANS  While Sundays Super Bowl will feature two quarterbacks from colleges with relatively unheralded football programs, it would be incorrect to say that either Baltimores Joe Flacco, who went to Delaware, or San Franciscos Colin Kaepernick, who played at Nevada-Reno, have the most modest college pedigree in the game.

title: With So Many Ailing, Knicks Focus on Plan B
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jason Kidd and Tyson Chandler missed practice Tuesday as injuries continue to cast doubt on the Knicks ability to sustain their performance in the second half of the season.

title: For Ailing Boston Mayor, a Vigorous Return
description: BOSTON  It was the 20th time that Thomas M. Menino, Bostons longest-serving mayor, had delivered an annual address to this citys assembled political class. But it was the first time he had delivered it under so much suspense.

title: Gallows Humor, and Smog, Engulf China
description: BEIJING  Heres a joke circulating among 10-year-olds at my sons state elementary school in Beijing:A Chinese man recently arrived in America visits the doctor.Doctor, I feel unwell.Where have you come from?Beijing.Breathe this, the doctor says, holding out a pipe attached to a car exhaust.Thanks, I feel much better! the man says.

title: Butch Morris Dies at 65; Creator of Conduction
description: Butch Morris, who created a distinctive form of large-ensemble music built on collective improvisation that he single-handedly directed and shaped, died on Tuesday in Brooklyn. He was 65.

title: Japans Leader Expresses Willingness to Meet Chinese Counterparts
description: TOKYO  Japans new prime minister, Shinzo Abe, has said that he is willing to meet with Chinese leaders to cool tensions in an emotional island dispute, asserting that the two countries should not let the disagreement further damage their huge economic relationship.

title: Listless U.S. Squad Plays Canada to Draw
description: The first game of the year for the United States mens national team was a disjointed one, as they stuttered to a scoreless draw in their friendly match Tuesday against Canada at BBVA Compass Stadium in Houston.

title: Wear a Helmet When Hitting the Slopes
description: Recently, researchers from the department of sport science at the University of Innsbruck in Austria stood on the slopes at a local ski resort and trained a radar gun on a group of about 500 skiers and snowboarders, each of whom had completed a lengthy personality questionnaire about whether he or she tended to be cautious or a risk taker.

title: Top Federal Prosecutor of Corporate Crime Resigns
description: 1:42 p.m. | Updated with formal announcement

title: Jean-Lon Destin, Dancer, Dies at 94
description: Jean-Lon Destin, a Haitian dancer and choreographer who brought his countrys traditional music and dance to concert stages around the world, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Word of the Day | spatial
description: spatial \spa-shl\ adjective

title: Geraldine Rhoads Dies at 98; Edited Womans Day
description: Geraldine Rhoads, who in 16 years as editor in chief of Womans Day magazine guided it toward covering the womens movement while still embracing its tradition of homespun advice, died at her home in Manhattan on Saturday, three days before her 99th birthday.

title: He Sings the Songs, and His Audience Does, Too
description: 2:30 p.m. | Updated I was the Justin Bieber of the 70s. Really. Just ask your mother, Barry Manilow boasted from the stage of the St. James Theater early in Tuesdays opening-night show of his return to Broadway for the first time in decades.

title: Flacco Not a Fan of Super Bowl in New Jersey
description: NEW ORLEANS  Baltimore quarterback Joe Flacco, one of the quietest and most polite players in the middle of two boisterous franchises in New Orleans for Super Bowl XLVII, made some waves Monday night when he was quoted as being critical of the decision to hold the Super Bowl at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., next year.

title: Sweet Taste of Victory for Dhoni and Co.
description: The one man who appears to be the most relieved after the 3-2 win in the five-match one-day cricket series against England is the Indian captain, Mahendra Singh Dhoni.

title: Whats On Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WHO KILLED LINDBERGHS BABY? On March 1, 1932, Charles and Anne Lindberghs 20-month-old son, above, was kidnapped from the familys home near Hopewell, N.J. Negotiations stretched out for weeks, but the boy was never returned. His body was found two months later less than five miles from Hopewell, and, after a two-year investigation, Bruno Richard Hauptmann, a German immigrant living in the Bronx, was ultimately found guilty of extortion and murder. He was executed on April 3, 1936. This Nova episode reopens the case as investigators use contemporary forensic and behavioral-science techniques to determine what really happened to the child, and why.

title: India Ink Is Taking Your Questions for Thomas Friedman
description: Thomas L. Friedman, the New York Times Op-Ed columnist, has been a regular visitor to India for a decade.

title: News Quiz | January 30, 2013
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper. Good luck!

title: Australian Leader Calls for Elections After Tough Year
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Prime Minister Julia Gillard announced on Wednesday that federal elections would be held in September, ending speculation over the timing with an unusually early announcement that will kick off what is sure to be a bruising, almost nine-month-long campaign season.

title: IHT Quick Read: Jan. 30
description: NEWS An activist group in Syria said on Tuesday that the muddied bodies of scores of people, most of them men in their 20s and 30s, had been found in a suburb of the northern city of Aleppo. Video posted by opponents of President Bashar al-Assad seemed to show that many had been shot in the back of the head while their hands were bound. Hania Mourtada reports from Beirut and Alan Cowell from London.

title: Player Ratings: U.S. (0) vs. Canada (0)
description: The United States national team played to a dull and nearly unwatchable scoreless draw against Canada on Tuesday night, and that was cause for alarm.

description: JERUSALEM  Israel has decided to transfer to the Palestinian Authority the tax and customs revenue that Israel collected last month on the authoritys behalf, to help ease the authoritys economic crisis, a senior Israeli government official said on Wednesday.

title: On 3rd Try, South Korea Launches Satellite Into Orbit
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea succeeded in thrusting a satellite into orbit for the first time on Wednesday, joining an elite club of space technology leaders seven weeks after the successful launching of a satellite by its rival, North Korea.

title: Pressing Mali Effort, French Forces Enter Rebel Stronghold
description: TIMBUKTU, Mali  The streets were largely empty here late Wednesday except for the husks of burned-out vehicles and a small group of jumpy Malian soldiers manning a military checkpoint, one of whom accidentally fired his weapon into the ground as he checked documents.

description: Does defense win championships? Stat-geek sports fans like me tend to distrust this old saying. Scoring a point helps just as much as allowing one hurts. And in football, the proposition risks ignoring the role played by the likes of Tom Brady.

description: Some photographers live for the the thrill of the unexpected happening right in front of them. Others prefer a more ordered world, where each occurrence is telegraphed far in advance.

title: The Spy Novelist Who Knows Too Much
description: Last June, a pulp-fiction thriller was published in Paris under the title Le Chemin de Damas. Its lurid green-and-black cover featured a busty woman clutching a pistol, and its plot included the requisite car chases, explosions and sexual conquests. Unlike most paperbacks, though, this one attracted the attention of intelligence officers and diplomats on three continents. Set in the midst of Syrias civil war, the book offered vivid character sketches of that countrys embattled ruler, Bashar al-Assad, and his brother Maher, along with several little-known lieutenants and allies. It detailed a botched coup attempt secretly supported by the American and Israeli intelligence agencies. And most striking of all, it described an attack on one of the Syrian regimes command centers, near the presidential palace in Damascus, a month before an attack in the same place killed several of the regimes top figures. It was prophetic, I was told by one veteran Middle East analyst who knows Syria well and preferred to remain nameless. It really gave you a sense of the atmosphere inside the regime, of the way these people operate, in a way I hadnt seen before.

title: Death and Defiance
description: CAIRO  The spate of demonstrations that has hit Egypt over the last few days is complicated. Some people are protesting against President Mohamed Morsi, the Muslim Brotherhood and the countrys new Constitution, which was approved in a rush in December. Some are protesting against police violence and provocation. Some are protesting against unemployment, social injustice and the lack of general improvement in their daily lives since the fall of President Hosni Mubarak, two years ago.

description: BANGKOK  A group of lawyers investigating a violent crackdown in Myanmar in November that left Buddhist monks and villagers with serious burns contends that the police used white phosphorus, a munition normally reserved for warfare, to disperse protesters.

title: Opposition in Egypt Urges Unity Government

description: After months of criticism of his compensation plan, Aubrey K. McClendon is retiring as chief executive of Chesapeake Energy on April 1, the company announced on Tuesday. A larger-than-life figure, Mr. McClendon co-founded Chesapeake and built the company through a series of deals that shaped the natural gas industry. Its an end of an era, said Fadel Gheit, a senior oil analyst at Oppenheimer.

title: Wednesday Reading: Your Disney Questions Answered
Tune in To | Rachel Zeffira
description: Rachel Zeffira is nothing if not a lateral thinker. When she was 17, a bureaucratic error nearly resulted in her deportation from Britain and caused her to lose her place at a music school in London. So Zeffira, who is from Canada, reinvented herself as a 26-year-old substitute French teacher (a language I dont speak) and stayed in England until she raised enough money to continue her studies in Verona, Italy. Years later, when she and her bandmate from Cats Eyes, Faris Badwan (the frontman of the Horrors), were looking for a venue to play their first gig, she used the contacts shed made in Italy to secure an appearance at a Vatican Mass attended by several cardinals. I told them we were a choir, she says. They thought our backup singers looked a little too sexy. At the last minute we had to rush out and buy opaque tights and shawls. In her latest example of creative adaptation, the classically trained soprano and multi-instrumentalist has melded sacred music with a baroque pop sensibility on her debut solo album, The Deserters. It was released late last year in Britain (the North American release, on Paper Bag Records, is scheduled for March) and is earning rave reviews, with the BBC memorably describing it as tummy meltingly wonderful. Dreamy, seductive and sparse, The Deserters has a quiet lushness thats markedly different from the girl-group-tinged sound of Cats Eyes, though Zeffira hesitates to specify how. I like to leave it to the listener to describe the music, she says. I dont like it to be spelled out.

title: The Gun Report: January 30, 2013
description: After my column on Tuesday about a weeks toll of gun violence, a number of readers suggested that I continue to publish examples of gun deaths that resulted from accidental shootings, momentary rage, a feud with a neighbor, a drive-by shootingand all the other reasons American kill each other with guns. I think it is a good idea. For the foreseeable future, my assistant, Jennifer Mascia, and I, will be culling one or two news stories each day, and linking to them on my blog.

title: Dutch Arts Groups Shut Down as Funding Vanishes
description: AMSTERDAM  In the 1980s and 90s, the Netherlands had a reputation as a kind of paradise for artists. Graduates of fine arts academies could receive long-term grants and special housing subsidies to support them so they wouldnt have to get day jobs. Edgy theater groups and small contemporary classical ensembles were fully financed to create innovative and experimental work. The government even bought art directly from artists who werent particularly commercial, maintaining it in large storage facilities, simply to support artistic production.

description: Despite two serious safety failures and new questions about the reliability of its lithium-ion batteries, Boeings chief executive said Wednesday that he saw no reason to retreat from using the new but volatile technology on its 787 jets.

title: Updates on the Senate Hearing on Gun Violence
description: In her brief but moving and emotional remarks, Gabrielle Giffords, the former Representative from Arizona who was shot in the head during a mass killing in 2011, told members of the Senate Judiciary Committee to be bold and courageous as they considered ways to reduce gun violence. The Lede followed the testimony of Ms. Giffords, her husband Mark E. Kelly and other witnesses, including Wayne LaPierre, chief executive of the National Rifle Association. As my colleague Jennifer Steinhauer reports, this was the first Senate hearing since the Dec. 14 mass shooting at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., that killed 20 schoolchildren and 6 staff members.

title: Going Abroad? How the State Department Can Help
description: Heres some perspective on how drastically our travel habits have changed in recent years: In 1989, seven million Americans had passports, according to the State Department. Today 113 million do. Gone, too, are days when Americans stuck almost exclusively to the London-Paris-Rome circuit, said Brenda S. Sprague, the State Departments deputy assistant secretary for passport services. That gives them the potential to get in more trouble, she said. But now theyre better able to keep in touch with us, and we with them. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Sprague on what help the State Department can offer you abroad.

title: Stone Links: Jane Austen, Ethicist? Pope Benedict, Marxist?
description: Like his predecessor John Paul II, who wrote his doctoral dissertation on the German phenomenologist Max Scheler, and wove a keen understanding of philosophical history into encyclicals like Fides et Ratio, Pope Benedict XVI also seems quite comfortable engaging in philosophical debate. Judging by his interactions with Jrgen Habermas, among others, one might assume that the Pope stands for a political and theological conservatism quite at odds with Marxist tradition. Yet they, and indeed Benedict himself might be surprised to find that, as a post at First Things explains, he evidently has his admirers on the left. Four Italian Ratzingerian Marxists of the Old Left have issued a manifesto hoping to enlist the Pope in their fight against a consumerist-inflected secularism. Strange bedfellows? Maybe not, considering that a few close readers of Benedicts 2007 encyclical Spe Salvi have noted that the Pope cites Max Horkheimer and Theodor Adorno to help refute the plausibility of the thesis that, with the waning of theistic belief, man himself is now called to establish justice.

title: Feeling For | Proenza Schoulers PS11 Wallet
description: Proenza Schouler has reworked its infamous PS11 bag, which graces the arms of every Hollywood starlet and Park Avenue socialite, into a must-have wallet in fluorescent pink. With a bold hardware closure and ample room for cash, keys and lipstick, the PS11 doubles as a clutch for a night on the town. For those wanting to forgo the clich dinner date and really make their special someone smile, this Valentines Day is in the bag.

title: The Cotton Bond Bubble

On Monday I saw a fun historical fact on Twitter about the United States womens national team : Six years ago to the day, I received my first cap against England in the Four Nations Tournament in China. At the time, Greg Ryan was the coach. When Pia Sundhage took over, I was hopeful that Id make a place for myself as a regular on the team. All these years later, I am thankful to have been to many training camps, participated in the World Cup qualifying tournament, and have 16 caps and one goal.

The keyboard-equipped phone might be the key to attracting former BlackBerry owners, but it is getting less marketing love.

title: Eating Among Locals on a Venetian Island

But thanks to a culinary newcomer, theres a reason to return. Opened last April by Giovanna Arcangeli  a Murano native who planned events at the legendary Harrys Bar for a decade and knows a thing or two about preserving a cultured calm in the midst of a touristy enclave  Acquastanca is a refuge from all that. We wanted to create a place where guests would be able to relax and enjoy good food in a warm, quiet atmosphere with locals, Ms. Arcangeli said.
