description: LaTroy Hawkins, 40, a right-handed reliever, has joined the Mets on a minor league contract, the team said Thursday.

title: Major Jazz Eminence, Little Grise
description: THE STANDARD LINE on Wayne Shorter is that hes the greatest living composer in jazz, and one of its greatest saxophonists. He would like you to forget all of that. Not the music, or his relationship to it, but rather the whole notion of pre-eminence, with its granite countenance and fixed coordinates. We have to beware the trapdoors of the self, he said recently.

title: Why Do More Moms Take the Lead on Parenting?

description: Michael Becker, a doctoral student at McGill University, was a scientific diver on an expedition to Lake Untersee, Antarctica.

title: How Facebook Can Justify Its High Valuation
description: Facebook deserves the benefit of the doubt about its rocketing costs. The social networks bills jumped about 80 percent in the fourth quarter. Thats worrying  its twice as much as the top line grew. But all-important mobile advertising revenue doubled in 90 days. The potential profit justifies heavy investment.

title: Meet Booking.com
description: Booking.com, a lodging Web site popular among European travelers, last month began its first ad campaign in the United States. Unlike Hotels.com and other sites, it makes bookings directly with properties rather than buying inventory from them. That means for its roughly 265,000 listings, the traveler pays upon checkout rather than in advance, and cancellation depends on the hotels policy.

title: Should I Let My Son Join the Boy Scouts if the Gay Ban Changes?
description: Steven Petrow, the author of Steven Petrows Complete Gay & Lesbian Manners, (Workman, 2011), addresses questions about gay and straight etiquette for a boomer-age audience.  [This week's question arose from a conversation with an acquaintance about the news on Monday that the Boy Scouts may eliminate its national ban on gays.] [UPDATE: On Feb. 6 the Scouts announced they are postponing the decision till May.] Send questions for Civil Behavior to stevenpetrow@earthlink.net.

title: The X Games, Driven by Risk, Have First Death

description: Is the private equity industry ready for a name change?

title: 36 Hours in Innsbruck, Austria
description: The Alps might be for skiing, but the self-styled capital of the Austrian Alps, Innsbruck, lives for just about everything aprs  eating, drinking, shopping and partying. Despite its founding as the capital of the Tyrol in the Middle Ages, the city on the Inn River maintains a consistently youthful attitude, thanks in part to 30,000 university students in a population of just 120,000 residents, while a new interest in world-class modern architecture by the likes of David Chipperfield, Dominique Perrault and Zaha Hadid is starting to compete for attention with the Renaissance-era buildings and labyrinthine lanes of Old Town. By all means, enjoy the nearby slopes, like those at the Stubai Glacier. But dont be surprised if the lifts you enjoy most are the ones that take you to the citys many rooftop bars, upscale restaurants and dance clubs that go all night.

title: Man Suspected in Phoenix Shooting Is Found Dead
description: PHOENIX  A man who opened fire at an office complex here was found dead on Thursday from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the nearby city of Mesa, the police said. One of his victims, a lawyer, was placed on life support and will not survive, according to a statement from the firm where he worked.

title: In Nunn and Warner, a Reminder of the Tower Hearings
description: It has been nearly a quarter of a century since the Southern drawls of Senators Sam Nunn and John W. Warner echoed through a Senate hearing room as an embattled defense secretary nominee fought for his job.

title: Why American Giant Re-Designed Its Web Site
description: Last week we kicked off this column with a behind-the-scenes look at American Giants Web site. Started by Bayard Winthrop in February 2012, the company sells high quality, American-made sweatshirts not through retail stores but rather online. This presents the challenge of marketing a sweatshirt based on quality that cannot be touched  relying instead on the power of photography and story telling.

title: The Pro Bowls March to Irrelevance

title: New York Live Arts Introduces Arts and Ideas Festival
description: New York Live Arts, the movement-based arts group led by the choreographer Bill T. Jones, is expanding its footprint by introducing an annual festival of arts and ideas. The inaugural festival will run from April 17-21 and explore the work of the neurologist Oliver Sacks, Mr. Jones, the executive artistic director of Live Arts, is planning to announce on Friday.

title: Tough Questions for Hagel at Hearing
description: Chuck Hagel, President Obamas nominee for secretary of defense, had some sharp exchanges with Senator John McCain.

title: E.P.A. Cracks Down on Rat Poisons
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency is moving to ban the sale of a line of mouse and rat poisons made by Reckitt Benckiser, saying that the manufacturer has refused to adopt the agencys safety standards for rodenticides.

title: Cheesy Blasters and Doughnuts
description: If youre planning on watching the final episode of 30 Rock on Thursday night, you might want to munch on some of Liz Lemons favorite foods. Those could include macaroni and cheese, meatball sandwiches, doughnuts and Cheesy Blasters (hot dogs, pizza and cheese). And of course, cupcakes. The blog Ezrapoundcake.com compiled A 30 Rock Tribute Menu.

title: Staples to Covet
description: David Neville and Marcus Wainwright, the designers of Rag & Bone, showed their fall mens collection on Wednesday evening, offering a reminder of their biggest strength. That is, making classic wardrobe staples seem suddenly covetable.

title: Together for Beethoven
description: When musicians play together, whether in a violin duo or a 100-piece orchestra, they must of necessity listen to one another. That simple fact was central to the vision of the conductor and pianist Daniel Barenboim and his good friend Edward W. Said, the Palestinian American literary scholar, when they founded the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra in 1999.

title: Culliver Apologizes for Remarks About Gay Players
description: NEW ORLEANS  A contrite Chris Culliver walked into a conference room at the San Francisco 49ers team hotel on Thursday, politely asked a few reporters to move so he could reach his chair, then answered questions about the negative comments he had made about gay players in the N.F.L. at the Super Bowls media day.

title: Momenta Quartet in Queens
description: As one of New Yorks oldest communities, settled in 1635 by a handful of Englishmen under the auspices of the Dutch East India Company, Flushing, Queens, can also lay claim to being one of the citys most diverse neighborhoods. Vibrant, overlapping enclaves, with origins in China and Korea, Central and South America, Greece and Italy, and the Indian subcontinent live alongside Conservative, Orthodox and Reform Jews, all in the shadow of Flushing Meadows, Citi Field and Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: More Things to Love About the BlackBerry 10
description: The BlackBerry 10 is a big, big deal for BlackBerry. (BlackBerry is the new name for Research in Motion, its maker. Finally, they can stop explaining to people that BlackBerry is the name of the product, not the company.)

title: In Virginia, Cuccinelli Makes a Conservative Case for Governor
description: One way to think of the Republican candidate for governor of Virginia is as Son of Santorum.

title: A Gin Game, Played With Tonic and Tapas
description: CATA, which opened on the Lower East Side last September, specializes in tapas and gin and tonics, a combination, its fair to say, not available on every corner. Not like burgers and fries. Soup and salad. Or even gin and tonic.

title: Mishandling of DNA Evidence Is Found in Over 50 Cases at Crime Lab
description: The New York City medical examiners office said Thursday that it had discovered more than 50 cases in which it failed to upload critical DNA evidence samples from crime scenes to the states DNA database, preventing those samples from being compared to genetic material from convicted offenders.

title: Two More Pakistani Polio Workers Killed
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A roadside bomb killed two polio workers in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, in the third such attack this week on workers struggling to immunize children against the crippling disease.

title: For the Stars of 2 Short Films, Going to the Oscars Isnt a Sure Thing
description: LOS ANGELES  As the Oscars approach, the jockeying for tickets to the ceremony is sure to be fierce, especially with so many films with large casts and numerous producers.

title: For Sacramento, Energy Upgrades With No Upfront Costs

title: Europe Says Drug Makers Paid to Delay a Generic

title: Syria Says It Has Right to Counterattack Israel

title: My Yiddishe Mama
description: To the Editor:

title: Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013
description: Images from the films nominated in the shorts category for the 2013 Academy Awards.

title: Campus Banking Practices Come Under Scrutiny
description: College students are much sought after as banking customers, since young people are likely to stick with the institutions they choose for their first accounts.

title: Report Faults German Governments and Museums on Handling of Nazis Loot
description: The German newspaper Der Spiegel has published a devastating indictment of German governments and museums handling of an enormous amount of valuable art, jewelry, land and more looted by the Nazis, calling it a moral disaster that began in the 1950s and continues to the present day.

title: Christie Gets His Chance for Revenge on Letterman
description: 4:14 p.m. | Updated Chris Christie has been a favorite target for David Letterman over the last few years, and on Monday night he will get his chance to strike back.

title: A Souped-Up Pilates Workout
description: IVE always liked the theory of Pilates. The reformer machine at the core of the workout is supposed to make for a long, lean body and help flatten the abs more effectively than stomach-toning activities like crunches and situps. In reality, however, the few classes Ive taken have done nothing to work up a sweat or amp up my heart rate  not the best outcome for an adrenaline-seeking exerciser like me.

title: Deutsche Banks Capital Trick Will Be Hard to Repeat
description: What capital hole? Deutsche Bank has closed the gap on more capital-secure peers by selling noncore assets and refining its risk models, thereby avoiding the need to tap or dilute existing investors. Other banks have done fancy footwork like this. But Deutsche Bank has been characteristically aggressive.

title: Prosecutor Shot to Death in a Town Near Dallas
description: KAUFMAN, Tex.  A county prosecutor in this small town southeast of Dallas was fatally shot on Thursday morning near the courthouse by one or perhaps two gunmen, whom witnesses described as wearing masks, black clothing and tactical-style vests, the authorities said.

title: Zip Your Lip
description: Is there any way to ask a potential boyfriend whether hes gay? I am a woman and have just started seeing a guy my friends think is gay. He belongs to a religious community in which people his age are usually married, so something is up. I cant yet say hes not into women. But part of me worries that if I dont clear this up explicitly, I will always feel insecure about his affection.

title: Guns and Approval Ratings
description: One of the first rules of politics is that youre supposed to pretend you dont govern according to opinion polls  that you put the good of the country ahead of reelection. In D.C. they sometimes forget to even pay lip service to this idea. Compromise always comes before courage; legislators focus on whats possible as an excuse not to try something bold.

title: Onward to Disaster, With Hardly a Stop
description: In thanking the agent responsible for his new short-story collection, We Live in Water, Jess Walter gives a shout-out to the literary social worker who found homes for these troubled kids. Not every writer thinks of his stories as troubled offspring, but in Mr. Walters case its a fair description.

title: On Our Radar: Cans of Fresh Air
description: A recycling magnate and showman makes his point about Beijings alarming air pollution by selling cans of fresh air that is purportedly from less polluted places in China. [Reuters]

title: Finally Stepping Out From Behind the Computer
description: Do you want to start a press with me? my friend Steven asked me in an e-mail three years ago. He meant starting a small publishing house together, not a cider press or a newspaper.

title: In the Studio | LaContrie
description: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

title: That Awful Film, Incredibly, Has a Following
description: ON a cold night in early December a young crowd packed into the cozy 72-seat screening room at the 92Y TriBeCa. The film that was about to be shown would be accompanied by live commentary from the hosts of The Flop House, a podcast dedicated to bad movies. Those hosts were two moonlighting writers from The Daily Show, Dan McCoy and Elliott Kalan, and their laconic friend Stuart Wellington. After a short introduction, the three sat in the front row as the lights went down.

title: Lena Dunham to Create New Comedy Show
description: With a series that she stars in, produces, writes and occasionally directs, and a book she is contracted to deliver, Lena Dunham clearly does not have enough to do.

title: Koch in Intensive Care
description: Update, Friday, 7 a.m. | Former Mayor Edward I. Koch died at 2 a.m. Friday. Read his obituary here.

title: Fighting Was Easy. Hockey Was the Hard Part.
description: Chris Nilan, the well-known former N.H.L. enforcer, has battled substance abuse since his retirement in 1992 and was once arrested for shoplifting. But he does not blame his troubles on 13 years of fighting in professional hockey  quite the contrary.

title: After Reshuffling Funds, Breakfast at Tiffanys Producers Plan to Proceed
description: The Broadway producers of Truman Capotes Breakfast at Tiffanys have sorted out money problems that had the potential to derail the planned opening in March, a spokesman for the show said on Thursday. One of the Tiffanys investors, who had been responsible for about $1 million of the shows $4 million budget, had told his partners that he was bowing out, and the shows cast and creative team was notified on Sunday that the producers needed to replace the money quickly or the play might be canceled.

title: Mayor Denies Commenting on Womans Derrire
description: On Monday, he did not meet with reporters after testifying before the Legislature in Albany. On Tuesday, he refused to take questions on anything but his budget proposal at City Hall. On Wednesday, he did not appear in public.

title: An App to Help You Choose a Name (or Spend Hours Analyzing the Possibilities)
description: I am all finished having babies  but if I did have another baby, it might just be so I could have the fun of naming it. I love names (what writer doesnt?). I loved naming my children (even though, in retrospect, one of those names was more popular than I had hoped). I like reading about names. And if I had had this app when I was pregnant, Id have been sunk.

title: At News Conference, Beyonce Offers a Live Encore
description: NEW ORLEANS  Beyonce seemed to embrace the Super Bowl spirit on Thursday by taking the time to address off-field distractions just as so many players have had to do all week.

title: Links, If Youre So Inclined
description: If new state Ag-Gag laws pass, reporting factory farm abuses would be deemed an Act of Terrorism. (More on whistleblower suppression efforts here and here.) Maryn McKenna writes that one of the potential consequences of animal production being hidden from view is the proliferation of multi-drug resistant bacteria in chicken due to the overuse of antibiotics. (One of the great takeaways from this piece: If you grew as fast as a chicken, youd weigh 349 pounds at age two.)

title: Folk Opera
description: Mo Yan, winner of the 2012 Nobel Prize in Literature, has a deft way with similes: salty, sometimes gross, usually unexpected. Comparing womens breasts to ripe mangoes is almost a clich, but to describe the nipples as rising gracefully, like the captivating mouths of hedgehogs is arresting. Passengers disembarking from a train do so like beetles rolling their precious dung. A rich meal of pork lies on a mans stomach, churning and grinding like a litter of soon-to-be-born piglets.

title: Case Offers Peek Behind the Curtain of a Security
description: The private mortgage-backed securities market grew to be a virtually inscrutable giant. Each securitization contained thousands of mortgages and as many as dozens of different securities, some of which could emerge unscathed even if others produced total losses for investors.

title: Now Collaborating | DKNY for Opening Ceremony
description: The sportswear label DKNY has teamed up with the cool kids cult shop Opening Ceremony to reissue select styles from the 1990s. Available tomorrow, the 15-piece collection starts at $145 and includes logo tees, bodysuits and outerwear rife with street-style nostalgia. The standout of the lot is a cropped puffer jacket with an oversize logo, which was first released in 1991. However, dont expect to pay the same price from two decades ago. As if.

title: Morgan Stanleys Chief Gets a Base Salary Raise
description: James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, will receive a huge raise in his base salary this year, but his overall pay package for 2012 was down from 2011, according to a filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Reveling in the Multicultural Possibilities of Paper
description: Paper is an organic material, almost like human skin, the artist Zarina Hashmi has said. You can scratch it, you can mold it. It even ages. In Zarina: Paper Like Skin, Ms. Hashmis exhibition at the Guggenheim, its that and more: paper is sculpture, poetry, currency and, above all, a kind of permanent home for a nomadic spirit.

title: Congress Passes Debt Bill as a $1 Trillion Ax Looms
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate gave final approval on Thursday to legislation suspending the statutory debt ceiling until May, officially turning Congresss attention to the next budget showdown: $1 trillion in across-the-board military and domestic spending cuts set to begin on March 1.

title: 30 Rock Ends Its Run
description: TimesCast: Tina Fey exits her sitcom as an irreverent pioneer.

title: Wheelies: The Company Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Under the Microscope
description: During the California earthquake of 1906, the marble statue of Louis Agassiz toppled off the second story of Stanford Universitys zoology building and plunged headfirst into the ground. The great scientist, with his head buried in concrete, his upturned body sticking up into air, became an iconic image of the earthquake. Agassiz is often remembered as a fallen man, Christoph Irmscher tells us. His rejection of Darwinian evolution and his conviction that America belonged to the whites only are an embarrassment to science. A decade ago, an eighth grader at the Agassiz School in Cambridge, Mass., came across a description of Agassizs racism and suggested the school change its name. It did, calling itself after the schools first African-American principal, Maria L. Baldwin.

title: Todays Scuttlebot: Googles Grand Canyon and Crowdfunded Space Programs
description: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

title: New Paul Taylor Work to Premiere at Vail International Dance Festival
description: The latest new work by Paul Taylor, 82, the modern dance choreographer, will see the light of day in Colorado. The Vail International Dance Festival said on Thursday that Mr. Taylors 139th work  so far unnamed and performed by the Paul Taylor Dance Company  will have its premiere on Aug. 5 at the festival, which runs from July 28 through Aug. 10 in Vail and Beaver Creek, Colo. Larry Keigwin, Brian Brooks and Charles Riley are other choreographers who will have new pieces on the program, the festival said.

title: Theater Talkback: The Rough Beauty of Everyday Speech
description: Generally speaking, we dont go to the theater to listen to conversations that we might just as easily hear while waiting in line at the grocery store or commuting on the subway. Among the essential gifts most great playwrights possess is an ability to take the dross of humble human speech and give it a silvering polish.

title: Drinking Wine, From a Chore to a Choice
description: Wine is old, ancient, neolithic. It has been consumed throughout recorded history. Yet wine as we know it today is relatively new. Where it originated, what it tasted like and represented, and how it was transformed over time are explored in Paul Lukacss fascinating new book, Inventing Wine: A New History of One of the Worlds Most Ancient Pleasures, published in December by W. W. Norton & Company.

title: Tattoos Impressions in Print and in Film
description: Tattoo artifacts are earning scholarly respect and providing fodder for collections.

title: International Nature
description: BEIJING

title: Could Electric Vehicles Fly Out of Showrooms?
description: Steven Chu, the secretary of energy, gave a short talk on electric vehicles on Thursday at the Washington Auto Show. Dr. Chu, a physicist who is widely expected to be departing shortly from the job he has held for four years, described the progress made so far and what would have to happen next to make electric vehicles a mass-market product.

title: S.E.C. Names Interim Replacement for Khuzami
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission named a longtime agency prosecutor, George Canellos, to be its acting enforcement chief on Thursday, positioning him as one of the top cops on Wall Street.

title: In Massachusetts, House Democrats Vie to Replace Kerry in Senate
description: BOSTON  Representative Stephen Lynch began his first day as a candidate for the Senate on Thursday by casting himself as a workingman of humble origins who could connect with average voters better than his fellow Democrat, Representative Edward J. Markey, whom he will face in a primary in April.

title: Always Carrying a Big Stick
description: At one point in the 1967 spy spoof The Presidents Analyst, the psychiatrist portrayed by James Coburn marvels at the psychological benefits of being a secret agent: You can vent your aggressive feelings by actually killing people! Hockey players cant go quite that far, but they can whack, body-block and generally pummel their opponents in the melees that arise in the course of games.

title: Deutsche Banks Lonely Fight With the Fed
description: It was supposed to be an uneventful conference call for senior executives at Deutsche Bank, one of Europes largest lenders. But a nerve was clearly struck as the executives took questions from analysts on Thursday.

title: Bad, Badder and Baddest
description: The multiple bullets that pierce multiple brains in Bullet to the Head  boring holes into people as disposable as paper gun targets  suggest that the title refers to an ideal rather than being merely descriptive. It implies, in other words, an appreciation and awareness of the principles of contemporary action cinema, and perhaps even a sense of play in respect to the genre. And while the veteran action director Walter Hill hasnt done much to enliven this dull, unmemorable material, with its mechanically moving parts and popping gunfire, its dull-red splatter and spray, he has brought a spark of wit to the proceedings, starting with the figure of Sylvester Stallone.

title: Composers Rescued, if Briefly, From Obscurity
description: Matthias Weckmann, Johann Schmelzer, Johann Kaspar Kerll and Antonio Bertali have been largely confined to historical footnotes. But these 17th-century composers received a vivid airing in the Morgan Library & Museums Gilder Lehrman Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: Assembling Tulips
description: The large Jeff Koons sculpture, purchased by Stephen A. Wynn at Christies for $33.6 million, was recently assembled for display in the Wynn Theater rotunda.

title: Trying Again on Celluosic Biofuels
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said on Thursday that commercial production of cellulosic fuels would start this year (even though it said the same thing last year and in 2011 and was proved wrong). And it proposed to require that refiners use 11 million gallons of the material this year.

title: Outsider Art Fair
description: A look at works in this years fair at the former Dia Art Foundation in New York.

title: Comedy Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Comedy

title: Itll Be a Mixed Marriage: Just One of Them Is Alive
description: The zombie romance Warm Bodies is cute and amusing enough to catch on cable one day, where its star-crossed, blood-drenched lovers will eventually present sweet relief from the apocalyptic freakout that is the AMC series The Walking Dead. If The Walking Dead is Lost with zombies and a high kill rate, Warm Bodies is effectively a riff on every teenage romance ever told, from Ovids Pyramus and Thisbe on. Boy or, in this case, zombie meets girl. Zombie loses girl. Zombie  well, you know the rest, though here the familiar balance comes with human tartare, screams and the unsettling image of John Malkovich as the leader of the seemingly last people on Earth.

title: Growth Predicted in Home Renovations
description: Homeowners who have been holding off on home improvements, be it a new kitchen or replacement siding, are more likely to call in the contractors in the year ahead.

title: Health Troubles Cause Trisha Brown to Leave Her Dance Company
description: Trisha Brown, a dance experimentalist of the 1960s and 70s who went on to help define contemporary dance performance, has decided to withdraw from leading the company she founded because of health problems but has given her blessing to its continued existence, her associates said on Thursday.

title: Looking Back, With a Few Twists Still
description: At the end of Wednesdays opening night performance by the Trisha Brown Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music there was no curtain call from Trisha Brown herself. She announced in December that two of the four works on the program are to be her last new dances. Inevitably there was a sense of loss. But who would have known that from the audience in the Howard Gilman Opera House? Cheers were hearty for all four pieces.

title: Dont Call the Cleaning Crew. That Yellow Spill Is Art.
description: The sculptor and Conceptualist Wolfgang Laib is the honeybee of the international art world. Since the 1970s, his trademark activity has been gathering pollen from trees and plants in the countryside near his home in southern Germany. He puts the pollen in bottles and flies to distant places around the world to create ephemeral installations of yellow dust on museum and gallery floors and inseminate the minds of viewers with thoughts of harmony between human civilization and nature.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Movies

title: Theater Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Theater

title: Republican Committee Begins Midterm Election Cycle in the Black
description: The Republican National Committee, which started the 2012 campaign cycle in deep financial distress, will begin the current period without any debt and with $4.7 million in cash on hand.

title: Pfizer Spins Off Animal Health Unit in $2.2 Billion I.P.O.
description: Making medicines for livestock and pets may not seem to be as sexy a business as social networking, but Pfizers animal health unit is poised to enjoy the biggest stock market debut since Facebooks offering last spring.

title: Pop Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Pop

title: Far From Epic Length, but on the Shortlist for Oscar Glory
description: Is the glass half-full or half-empty? In the movies, at least, the balance between hope and suffering usually tilts decisively toward hope. That is the predominant mood of The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2013, an anthology of three programs: live action, documentary and animation.

title: Shades of Casablanca
description: The little lamp tucked behind the bar at Ricks Caf in Casablanca is an unlikely vessel for a genie. The base is dark with age. The beaded shade has long since unstrung. Its Italian. And yet, it did possess conjuring powers in the extravagant hands of the late, great decorator Bill Willis.

title: A Strong Sitcom Pedigree to Stand On, and Live Up To
description: Belles, a new comedy on TV One about a family-owned restaurant in Atlanta, serves its black-eyed peas with a heaping side of television history. Its part of a direct line of descent that includes The Mary Tyler Moore Show, Taxi and The Cosby Show. As sitcom bloodlines go, thats hard to beat.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Jazz

title: Record Prices, and Some Duds
description: There were record prices for artists like Fra Bartolommeo, Sandro Botticelli, Pompeo Batoni and Hans Memling at the old master painting auctions held on Wednesday and Thursday at Christies and Sothebys in New York. But there were also scores of works by artists like Goya, Bassano and Guercino that went unsold without so much as a bid.

title: A Two-Person Exhibition With Someone Who Isnt Here
description: Museums have changed significantly over the last several decades, so that they showcase more contemporary art but also try to balance their budgets by bringing in larger audiences. This sets up a challenge for artists. who must operate on multiple registers, speaking to aficionados as well as to the uninitiated. Sharon Lockharts show at the Jewish Museum does this beautifully.

title: Uber to Roll Out Ride Sharing in California
description: Californians who dont want to drive will soon have more ways to hire a ride. Uber, a start-up company that offers a smartphone app for summoning cars, is expanding its service to support ride sharing so ordinary citizens can drive people around in exchange for money.

title: Short on Letters and Long on Hue
description: These days we claim to want the natural, the simple, albeit with a Wi-Fi connection. Perhaps that explains building names like Azure, Platinum, Indigo, Jade and Blue. You could call it the Crayola method of apartment-house naming. Certainly the names are more down-to-earth than, say, the old-style Parc V and Capri.

title: Feeling Right at Home on the Fringe
description: The Outsider Art Fair, a wonderfully eccentric jewel in the crown of New York art fairs, has a renewed radiance. For the first time in its 20-year history, it occupies a building retrofitted for art: the clean, well-lighted spaces of the former Dia Art Foundation. This places it in the western reaches of Chelsea, once again confronting the world of contemporary insider art with irrefutable proof that the most lasting work comes from unstoppable emotional necessity, an especially useful lesson for the moment.

title: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Classical

title: Exclusive | 22 Jane Street
description: A deceptively compact brick carriage house with an eccentric past and an idiosyncratic present is about to enter the market for $9.1 million.

title: An Artist-Owned Carriage House in the Village
description: A deceptively compact brick carriage house at 22 Jane Street with an eccentric past and an idiosyncratic present is about to enter the market for the first time since the artist Jim Dine bought it in 1997. The asking price is $9.1 million.

title: Political Animals That Slither
description: There are two natural showcases for envy, ambition and the pettier yearnings of the human heart  high school and Washington. Everybody remembers 10th grade, and most people think they know whats really going on in the federal government.

title: Addictive Soy Sauce With Ruinous Power
description: You shouldnt think of the title of John Dies at the End as a spoiler in the conventional sense, thought there is a character named John and, well, you know. This movie, written and directed by Don Coscarelli and based on a novel by Jason Pargin (writing under the pseudonym David Wong), is not really about John (Rob Mayes), in any case, and is either entirely spoiler-proof or completely self-spoiling. It lays waste to linear narration, thematic coherence, psychological plausibility and just about everything else you might expect to encounter. It zigs, zags and trips over its own feet and on its own home-brewed hallucinogens. Its a ridiculous, preposterous, sometimes maddening experience, but also kind of a blast.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Dance

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 1-7
description: Art

title: Trisha Brown Dance Company
description: Images of dancers in performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 1-7
description: Around Town

title: Senator Has Long Ties to Donor Under Scrutiny
description: Dr. Salomon E. Melgen, a wealthy Florida eye surgeon, has always been happy to help out his friend, Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey.

title: Taking Back the Night, Slasher Style
description: Men are pigs, and women are sick of it, says Girls Against Boys, a dumb, dreary, lets-get-back-at-them slasher in which pulverized genitals pass for feminist critique.

title: Spare Times for Children for Feb. 1-7
description: BAMKIDS FILM FESTIVAL

title: Please, No Stompers Overhead
description: A decade ago, Andy Hall settled into a one-bedroom East Village walk-up, but was driven out by a stomping next-door neighbor. So he moved to a two-bedroom walk-up nearby with a roommate.

title: Making Web Sites Completely Addictive
description: Looking for a real estate agent who loves dogs? Youll find 314 results for dog lover on Corcorans redesigned Web site.

title: An Insistent Voice From Behind Bars
description: Coverage of public discourse in the United States often makes it seem as if the only ideologies still in the game were the far right and the moderate everybody else. But Mumia: Long Distance Revolutionary, a documentary by Stephen Vittoria, is proof that there are still outspoken champions of views too radicalized to qualify as left-wing: people distrustful of law enforcement, the political system, the justice system, the news media and the very notion that America is at heart the land of the free.

title: Trader Accused of Misleading Clients Leaves Goldman Sachs
description: Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading clients over a controversial mortgage deal, is no longer working at the firm.

title: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
description: Photos from Gaza City, Syria, Mali and Pakistan.

title: The Fishing Industry Looks Ahead
description: John K. Bullard, an official long-entrenched in the fishing industry, said New England fisherman will adapt to changing quotas and move toward a sustainable future.
